Title: Innovative and sometimes funny but not Oscar-worthy
Review:
This is a polarising movie and it's easy to see why. The story of a stressed and unhappy Chinese laundry owner who gets sucked into parallel universes in order to save the world.

It's a mix of sci-fi, martial arts, slapstick and absurd, sometimes puerile comedy. The acting is very good but probably not worthy of Oscars for everyone ; Jamie-Lee Curtis is a standout. The direction is good but not as good as the other Best Director nominees. The script is amusing but shallow. It's certainly innovative and many will find it entertaining, which it is (mixed in with silliness).

My problem is that for a film to be truly great, it needs to generate strong emotions, invite contemplation and have substance. Simply telling a funny story is not enough. EEaaO is really just lightweight fairy floss. They shouldn't be giving Oscars for that, but then the Academy has lost it's way a bit lately. Films are getting the gong based on misplaced sentiment or hype, not on merit.

Title: It's an art film!
Review:
It's hilarious watching the pro wrestling crowd lose their minds over an art film winning the Oscar. This is a Studio A24 production, which means limited appeal and high intellectual expectations for the audience. We saw the same indignation over A24's Moonlight, which was also a powerful and gritty exploration of the human condition.

Yeoh and Quan, deserved their awards. Their multiple character arcs in the multiverse were believable and heart wrenching. Not going to quibble about Curtis, but I certainly could.

This is a quirky film about love, and the many ways we express and fail to express it to each other. (For those who didn't "get it")

Production value is amazingly high for a $14 million budget. It's clearly a work of love with A-list actors taking less than their market value to be a part of the production.

If you enjoyed other A24 films in the past, don't hesitate to watch this one.

Title: i don't understand
Review:
There was a time we had master pieces of sci-fi and story telling like the Matrix, for example, that weren't even nominated to the oscar of best picture. And now we have this messy convoluted story of a film winning everything everywhere at the same time. Can anyone make sense of this??

The quality of this film is at the same level as the matrix sequels, and that's the best i can put it, when i watched it i could never think this would get so much buzz. The bar is set very low this days i guess. It's one of those films you watch it one time and you're done with it.

I give it a 6 because it's not bad movie. Just an ok movie.

Title: I don't see the hype.
Review:
It's not often I treat myself to a blu ray, based on the fact that this one seven Oscars, I ordered it, and have just finished watching it. That's ¬£22.99 that could have been spent on much better things.

..am I missing something, the credits rolled, the first thing I had to ask myself, what was that all about? I'm all for ambiguity and films, but I feel I should at least be in on the joke or story, I felt like an unwanted guest, on the outside, looking in, but the event was too self indulgent to allow for understanding.

The latter part of the film is more interesting and definitely better paced, I thought the early parts were way too sluggish, extra caffeine was definitely needed.

The visuals were ok, if a little too much at times, but the films strongest element had to be the acting, I must give credit to Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis.

Original, yes, well acted, most definitely, fathomable, that's the stumbling block.

The title definitely fits the film. I understand why people like it, I didn't care for it.

4/10.

Title: Nothing, nowhere, all at once
Review:
Very painful watch. I had to do it in three takes. Just pompous and grotesque: no backbone, erratic, superficial. If the intention was a tale about ordinary lives and multiverse dreams, it falls flat.

The accolades and the praises are shocking. The vacuum of this movie is impressive.

The musical theme during the credits is good. Except that, my rating is 0 all way through.

Characterization is between non-existing and clich√©. There is no multiverse alternative worlds in the film. It shows only trivial reality in various disguises. The artificial collage and the poor rendition of the concept deliver production of cold images. The film is not an immersing experience as probably was its ambition. Bad-Bad, to me. Maybe I am not alone to have watched it this way.

Title: Some of the most fun I've ever had while watching a movie.
Review:
There's really something for just about everyone in this movie. It's part Kung-fu action, part absurdist comedy, part cerebral sci-fi, and part indie family drama. I think this is an instant classic that uses the art of cinema and movie-making to it's fullest potential.

They really throw everything AND the kitchen sink at the wall and somehow it all sticks and becomes a really fun and really special film that I would recommend to pretty much anyone.

Michelle Yeoh is fantastic as is the whole cast. The writing and direction is phenomenal and innovative and creative and it features of the best editing I've ever seen. It's a really wild movie, but if you sit back and absorb it, I think you'll have a good time.

Title: A very bravely action
Review:
In the first days of the release of this movie, I praised and praised it on many critic and and analysis sites. I wrote that this movie is a giant masterpiece in the new millennium. I wrote that this film is like the paintings of Edvard Munch and "Nicolas Poussin ", which have been made into the movie. And I said that mankind has not been able to create such a thing for centuries. And I also praised the perfect script. But after seeing a lot of negative comments, I became doubtful and some questions arose in my mind. Maybe I thought about the vagueness of Tan's story and changed my mind. When the movie won seven Oscars. I watched it for third time and asked myself, what is the definition of a smart story? If we want to logically create and define an intelligent story (I emphasize, logically), what should we do? And can social effects affect my poor understanding of modern art? In both cases, the answer was yes. And must be done in this way.

We adapt ourselves to life, boys. The last night Oscar action is not only very bravely but is so differentt actionin last twenty years. And is a very game changer act for the continues.....

Title: A unique experience
Review:
There is so may "what-ifs" in life. So many questions. Evelyn Wang, the protagonist, is able to know the answer. Evelyn, a Chinese-American laundromat owner, discovers a lot of parallel universes---and within them---different versions of herself and her family.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a comedy science fiction action film that is also bizarre and eccentric even. This film easily becomes one of my favorite movies I've ever seen.

The story deals with love, family, being lost, and a lot of things all at once. Michelle Yeoh is brilliant, relatable and funny as the main protagonist. Ke Huy Quan, who quit acting in 2002, returns in this movie as well, portraying Evelyn's klutzy and naive husband Waymond, and his acting is perfect as well. I am also impressed a lot with his action scenes, and most of the stunts were performed by him. Amazing. Stephanie Hsu is incredible playing Evelyn and Waymond's rebellious daughter. Jamie Lee Curtis also stars as an IRS agent, and she too is wonderful in this film. She, Michelle and Ke Huy Quan will surely be nominated for an Oscar, and it will be Jamie Lee's first nomination if ever.

The story will make you laugh, thrilled, cry and sometimes you will feel everything all at once. Yeah. The dialogues are also great, with a plenty of beautiful moments to offer. One of my favorite aspects are also the cinematography, editing and soundtrack. It was just done so well.

I wish someday, I can find someone who I'd love to do my laundry and taxes with.

Overall a beautiful movie, so i give it a 10.

Title: Absolutely Insane
Review:
This movie is the most insane, action packed, heartfelt movie I've seen in a long time. Absolutely perfect, no complaints, I hope this film goes on to win several awards and has cult status for years to come.

Title: Inventive and unique movie experience
Review:
Greetings from Lithuania.

I think i admired "Everything Everywhere All at Once" (2022) more then i actually liked it at end this movie. I did like it, but i didn't love it because it was a bit to much for me. I won't go into spoilers or details, because this movie has to be seen to truly understand it. I liked how ingenuous it was, and i highly admired creators for creating such a piece of work. Title: There is always something to love
Review:
A woman tries to do her taxes.

In order to keep from giving anything away, I will be vague. The creativity on display is immense. I thought that it would be overpowering and exhausting, but it actually manages an impressive focus, never losing us. It fits multiple genres and does them all well. To describe it, I would say it is an ADHD acid trip, emotionally engaging, funny, and displays a ton of emotional intelligence. I admire the lack of cynicism and exploration of nihilism. And no, I do not agree that this believes in the latter. Someone featured in it does. There's a difference. Every actor does an incredible job. I really hope this leads to way more work for the ageing cast, as it proves beyond a shadow of a doubt they still got it.

This features strong violence, sexual material and language. I recommend this to anyone that believes they might like it. 10/10.

Title: Decent movie but headache is unavoidable
Review:
The movie is breathtaking. Every scene is like moving art and to top it off there are some amazing fight scenes too BUT the movie at times feels like a Bollywood movie. Even with those elements , I didn't mind it but the story is just not polished enough. There are at least 3-4 endings and it felt like the movie couldn't decide which final route to take.

The daughter in this movie is extremely annoying and doesn't know what she wants in life even though her mother already gave her everything.

I liked the movie but the ending didn't feel complete to me.

It could have been much smarter in delivery and in my honest opinion , the movie is overhyped but because of AMAZING Breathtaking visuals I will give it a steong 7.4/10.

Title: Good Idea but just too long
Review:
If this film had been about 40 minutes shorter I would have left the cinema thinking innovative, fun, imaginative, good acting, good action scenes and nice message. As it was it just went on too long with too much repetition and a failrly obvious family resolution playing out far longer than needed. It was a film in dire need of an editor.

Title: Bad overstretched failure of a film
Review:
First let me start by saying that the acting is great, seriously, but it stops right there. The film on the other hand is the product of someone's random thoughts, badly edited, way over stretched scenes and ideas which repeat throughout the film over and over at random intervals. I have no problem with slow movies at all. I've seen "Moon", "2001", and many other "slow" movies, and I loved most of them. I love art in general, I love staring at great paintings, admiring sculptures, and reading a good book. This is not only a slow movie, but also one where every single idea is massaged over and over, and then massaged again, and when you think it is done being massaged, the director or editor massages it a few more times until you are so fed up with that idea and scene that you feel like leaving the theater. The movie is about love, care, and relationships, but other than that there is nothing deep or complex about the story. Alternate reality is not a new concept, yet the writer chooses to add too much complexity where it isn't needed, it makes the movie difficult to follow, especially due to the alternate reality / multiverses of the story.

While in the theater I heard many people laugh at some of the dumbest jokes, then I realized OK, this movie is targeted to an audience who enjoys these types of punch line jokes.

All in all I found this movie a complete disaster, hence the one start rating.

Title: It's not good at anything
Review:
The fighting is clumsy shaky cam and has many cuts as the worst B movies from Hollywood. The actors are not that great (in this film). The story is beyond derivative, it's just a mix up of The One and Marvel's Multiverse. For no reason., they added some made-up goofy environment and side characters. And some progressive issues to make it Hollywood approved.

It's quite telling of the times this hot piece of garbage got so many awards and managed to trick a lot of people to go and watch it. It's not entertaining, it's not funny, it's not good action, it's not original.

I started it with low expectations but even those were shattered within the first 20 minutes.

How did they pick this over Top Gun Maverick, an imperfect movie but in another level at every category compared to this. Or The Whale, a simple movie with great acting and direction?

How is this best film editing, for example.

I like Yeoh and Curtis, but this is far from their best.

Title: Everything Everywhere All at Once Review
Review:
A Chinese woman living her worst life is swept up into a interdimensional catastrophe where she alone can save the universe.

This film is incredible and I cannot believe the Daniels were able to pull off this crazy story. This film combines a number of different themes and genres and somehow makes it work.

You get some extremely good martial arts action along side some raunchy comedy and the two make for an extremely entertaining film. That combined with a complex multiverse story and a family dynamic intertwined makes for an incredible film.

The pacing of this is very quick and you do not feel like you've been there for 2 plus hours. It moves quickly but allows you to get to know the characters and develops them very nicely.

Michelle Yeoh is phenomenal as the lead character Evelyn, Oscar worthy. She is moved from being funny to being an action hero to being this extremely emotional character so flawlessly and it's amazing to see.

Stephanie Hsu is also extremely good in this film. The rest of the cast is also across the board outstanding. Ke Huy Quan, James Hong, Jamie Lee Curtis all give great performances in their respective roles.

In terms of gripes, there are times where too much is going on and it's hard to follow and as a result certain aspects are lost. But it doesn't happen overly often. Also this film can be over the top at times in terms of raunchy comedy. This didn't bother me but I can see others being disturbed.

Overall this film is incredibly well done. Their ability to combine a number of different genres and make it flow so well is something I've never seen before.

9.5/10.

Title: EEAAO is outstanding - you must see it if you get the opportunity!
Review:
A truly sensational film! The utter definition of a must-watch.

'Everything Everywhere All at Once' is impressive from every single viewpoint. I had heard murmurs of it being a great film, yet it still managed to completely smash my expectations. This 2022 release features a superb cast, a fascinating story and some top notch visuals. The editing and pacing, in particular, are brilliant.

The onscreen talent are all fantastic, but Michelle Yeoh is still the absolute standout from this. What a performance! I could watch her in this role over and over and over. With that said, Ke Huy Quan (welcome back!) is awesome as well, as are Stephanie Hsu, James Hong and Jamie Lee Curtis. Everyone plays their part very, very well.

All of the humour lands, with some parts being truly funny. It also manages to show supremely enjoyable action alongside a highly meaningful side too. In short: EEAAO is outstanding - you must see it if you get the opportunity!

Raccacoonie üëÄ

Title: Unlike Anything I've Ever Experienced Before
Review:
What a piece of art this was. I don't want to give anything away so I'll just say this film made me laugh, cry and go "wtf?...sometimes all at once. It was an incredibly original vision that seems to have had incredible care and quality put into it by everyone and was just such a unique experience. I would recommend it to anyone to give it a shot.

Title: Hotdog Fingers, So Creepy And Funny
Review:
A simply stunning creative masterpiece.

This movie is so well written and acted, the lengthy-ish running time whizzes by in a flash of hotdog fingers and racoons.

I spent much of the time watching the show wondering who I thought was the best supporting actor, the Dr Jones kid of Jaime Lee Curtis and at the end I still couldn't decide.

Best of luck to the judges of the Oscars on this one. Incredible entertainment, funny, great action and enough dildos to fill a um, thing.

An instant cinematic classic that will help drive people back to the movies.

Don't miss this remarkable piece of movie history :)

Title: Did an AI bot write the script?
Review:
A seemingly purposeful mess of nonsense. Nowhere near as clever as it thinks it is. I wanted to enjoy this but it was contrived, left no meaning apart from 'there's this concept of a multiverse' and we should appreciate what we have in life. Big and good concepts, but there's a detachment in how the story is told. Just too chaotic to create something you can latch on to, so it becomes unintentionally superficial. On the upside the acting is great, with well deserved gongs for the leads. Why do I have write six hundred characters for one of these reviews? I've made my points concisely without switching people off with a case of TLDR.

Title: Marvel style humour. Boring and repetitive.
Review: "All in Everywhere at the Same Time" is a well-acted, well-directed film with very good sound editing and mixing, however, I don't like its marvel-like humor, its criticism seems hollow, its slapstick style is unconvincing and its editing is tiring, the good editing of the film is lost when you use it to excess, and that happens with all the good aspects, after an hour and a half, everything stops working and at a certain point I just disconnected from the work, I thought about everything , except for the movie there in front of me, I don't understand how hype it is and the theaters are so full, it's the same audience that stays in queues for hours to see "ant-man" or any canned food of that kind, and at the end "All in All Place at the Same Time" is a gourmet canned food with good ideas that gradually self-destruct, leaving a giant shell of scraps behind. I like the universe created and I like the performances, but all this doesn't hold back the great tangle of "nothing" that we have here, in which even its great differential, the "humor" is weak, its Oscar competitor, "Inisherin's Banshees" it is a film with a humor that is also present but of an infinitely superior quality and tune. Note 7/10.

Title: Like modern monty python, without the great humour
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: 2 hours of nonsense
Review:
The movie starts (20-30 minutes) "fine", quite annoying with MCU type quips and jokes that almost destroy the exposition destined to explain the main character and her circumstances (and a bit the secondary characters), but good enough to get us interested in the premise.

After that though, it quickly becomes non-stop nonsense, movie references, and repetetive action sequences full of "quirky" "jokes"/"gags" that were only embarrasing, if anything.

The plot and characters are so simple, we (me and my cousin) guessed what the movie was going to say and how it was going to end after15 minutes. Also the tonal disnonance between raunchy humor and "old school" sentimentality was jarring.

In the end, even Disney movies were/are more sophisticated in their way to tell this type of "feel good" stories.

Title: Great idea, but this one is not for me
Review:
The movie is okay. I get the message. I like the creativity and some dialogues, but in my opinion, it's overhyped. For some it might be confusing, dizzy and unbearable to watch, even to me, I couldn't stand some parts, and I have a very high tolerance towards this type of films. I know the point is to overwhelm and have some funny, ridiculous scenes from all the nihilistic, madness and existentialist plot, but it's not my stuff.

Title: An oddly poignant goofball masterpiece (2022 list excerpt)
Review:
There is too much to say about Everything Everywhere All At Once to neatly summarize it here -- and there's a good chance you've already heard everyone else go over it anyway. I've seen people call this their new favorite film of all time, and while I'm not prepared to go that far (almost out of protest, since the film has amassed a weirdly touchy fanbase), I can see why this has moved a great many people:

The way that its relentlessly zany multiverse-hopping actually has thought behind it and stays largely consistent. The way it takes cues from the Wachowskis, Wong-Kar Wai, Douglas Adams, and even Pixar while still feeling original. The way it makes us teary-eyed at even the goofiest sights. The way that its initial craziness -- its full understanding of the fact that an infinite multiverse brings infinite possibilities of comedy and action (take notes, Marvel) -- eventually leads to oddly poignant musings on purpose, meaning, and the futility of worrying over what one's life could've been; in harping on the paths one could've taken, at the expense of what's already there; of endlessly pondering what power we have in the great cosmic comedy that might already have its ending planned when all you really should be focusing on is holding someone's hand (whether or not you inhabit a universe where everyone has sausage fingers).

It's not that we're all "small and stupid" and that life is pointless in the grand scheme; it's that the point of life may as well be a simple one.

And really, I think something similar can be said of the way that people connected with this film. For all the nifty things about it and all its "grand" ambitions, it's ultimately just a sweet movie about family; about love. Plain and simple.

The mother-daughter dynamic at the center isn't new, but it's rare to see it mainly from the mother's perspective. She's played excellently by Michelle Yeoh, who is backed by a hilarious Jamie Lee Curtis, a cute-yet-menacing Stephanie Hsu, a similarly multifaceted Ke Huy Quan, and of course, the utterly legendary James Hong, still on fire at nearly 100.

I'd say "go see it" but you probably already have.

Title: Multificent!
Review:
I laughed, I cried; I peed myself but couldn't access the multiverse. There seems to be a massive disclosure going on. Everywhere I look there are info drops about time ravel, other dimensions and truths that have always been there but kept hidden. Glad this was made...

It all makes sense now...

Title: Great acting, mediocre puzzling story
Review:
I can see why there may have been oscars given out for best and supporting actors, but this is not a great or memorable film. I found it incredibly puzzling and stressful to watch. At the core of it is an exploration of the relationship between a migrant woman and her daughter. And also the breakdown of her marriage. She steps in and out of alternate realities that ends up frustrating and confusing the viewer rather than achieving its goal of entertainment. It's a flurry of impressive visuals and film editing without substance in my opinion. I don't know how this film got the hype it did at the Oscars, but that's the mysterious world of Hollywood for you. In any event, you could take this film or leave it.

Title: Certainty unique
Review:
Definitely a unique film. After watching hundreds of movies, I met Everything Everywhere All at Once through my girlfriend.

I've never seen anything like it, it's okay that he inspires in other works like, Inception, Butterfly Effect, Matrix, Rick and Morty (Interdimensional TV), 2001 - A Space Odyssey, and still manages to maintain its originality.

The film is divided into two parts, the first funniest part manages to amuse the viewer very well in the face of the oddities that it is impossible to predict what will happen next. The second, deeper, makes us reflect on what really matters and what our role is in the world.

The plot is out of the ordinary as the title suggests, and the photography, clothing, makeup, performances and soundtrack correspond to the film's proposal.

A film with all certainty unique and that was born classic.

Title: Exactly what you expect from the title
Review:
If the Oscars ever decide to present an award for 'Most Apt Title to a Movie', this film 100% gets my vote for being the first laureate. When you look up the definition of the word "maximalist" in the Oxford dictionary, the poster for this movie should be the first thing you see. At its core, Everything Everywhere All at Once has a rather familiar premise, where our female protagonist suddenly finds out in her everyday life that she lives within a multiverse and has the power to prevent the destruction of everything as we know them. What makes this movie stands out from its peers is the mind-boggling commitment of the filmmakers to really show the viewers what an infinite number of universes looks, sounds, and feels like from the perspective of a character caught in their wake.

I am honestly very conflicted about this movie. On one hand I am in absolute awe of what this movie was able to achieve in terms of raw impact on the viewers through an all-out sensory assault. It is without a doubt one of the most visually-daring and creative films I've seen in quite a while, with an endless number of insane action sequences flowing from one scene to the next. The story really goes to the max with using the multiverse context to pull off every joke you can and can't think of, frequently conjuring up tens of different skits within a single minute. On another note, something I really appreciated is that underneath all the dizzying spectacles there is also a very heartfelt and touching story about family and living for kindness.

Where the movie gets exhausting for me is from its shear overbearingness of its presentation through the majority of the runtime, which I fully acknowledge is the point and that many others won't feel is a problem. I did thoroughly enjoy the frantic style for the first hour, but after that the relentless attack does start to wear out its welcome and feel a bit repetitive. Some of the jokes also didn't land that well for me, which relate back to the presentation style whereby random bizarre things happen almost nonsensically one after the other due to the presence of the multiverse, making them feel like watching YouTube compilations of meme clips - funny for a while but starts to grate after that. I enjoyed the movie more towards the final act where it focused back on the characters and their relationships, so I personally would've preferred the movie to have struck a bit more balance on developing that aspect with the visual extravaganza exhibition.

To summarise, Everything Everywhere All at Once fully delivers on the potential of its title by giving an acid-trip-esque experience that is designed to mystify and overwhelm the viewers in what might well be the craziest multiverse movie in any timeline or universe. I always appreciate when the filmmakers have the guts and bravado to stick and execute their vision without compromise, and by golly if Daniels did not do just that. As a final note, I have to give a shout-out to A24 again: not all of their movies fully work for me, but you can count on them to be unique and to leave a lasting impact.

Title: Everything is nonsense about this movie.SKIP. OVER RATED.
Review:
Everything is nonsense about this movie. SKIP. OVER RATED.

I couldn't take it after 1 hour. It feels like a bad cartoon and even though there are good actors (the only reason I lasted 1 hour) I gave up.

Not once I laughed. I am not sure what it is supposed to be... A failed fun intellectual movie? TBH I don't care.

Difficult to believe it won so many Oscars. Maybe for the actors. But best film??? I can't believe it didn't go to Elvis.

It is too bad that IMDB has changed its poclicy about reviewing and now we have to write a minimum of 600 characters. This movie doesn't deserve more than a few: SKIP OVER RATED and BAD.

Title: Holy Bagel
Review:
Don't ask. Go and see it, because you've never seen a movie quite like this one. It is a fantasy/comedy, but at times that is reversed. I will now make an attempt at a review.

The middle-aged owner of a failing Chinese laundry is being audited by the IRS, her lesbian daughter brings her 'friend' home for a visit, her infantile husband is of marginal help and her father is senile. On a visit to the IRS her husband reveals himself as an alien who can show her how marvelous her life would have been in other galaxies, to which he gives her access.

Sound confusing? Just go and see it. It is extremely entertaining, and I'm going to see it again to fill in the considerable number of incoherent spots I still have. Oscar noms for Best Actress (are they still called that?) Michelle Yeoh and for Editing and Special Effects.

P. S. The hole in the bagel represents the way to inner peace. (Don't ask).

7******* Website no longer prints my star rating.

Title: A Trip Through The Multiverse
Review: Everything Everywhere All at Once: A voyage through the Multiverse as Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh) tries to survive an IRS audit. She is contacted by her husband Waymond (Ke Huy Quan) from a different universe as he dybbuks this one. She must battle a supreme villain, Jobu Tupaki who is also her own daughter, Joy (Stephanie Hsu). The IRS agent Deirdre Beaubeirdra (Jamie Lee Curtis) is also Dybbuked by a murderous acolyte of Jobu. Great fun as alternate Evelyns possess her body and use their skills to fight back. There is even a universe where everybody has hotdogs instesd of fingers and this segment has a great pastiche of apemen discovering weapons from 2001: A Space Odyssey. There is also a film within a film, actually it's kind of this film, watch by it's star another Evelyn. The traverse of the Multiverse occasionally brings the Marvel TV series Legion to mind, both in production design and charcter traits. Essentially it's a story about the search for meaning, understanding and love. Great performances by Yeoh, Hsu, Curtis, Quan along with James Hong as her father. Written and Directed by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert. 8.5/10.

Title: "I love you"
Review:
I've wanted to watch this for some time now, and was not disappointed.

It's chaotic, VERY creative and more importantly.. it delivers on an emotional level, with a message that should reverberate with anyone, out of shared pain, experiences and a desire for something better.

For me, just like it's title, it has a little bit of everything. It might have been predictable in some developments, unrealistic in others (even with the weird rules it sets for itself, but for obviously-fabricated-memorable-moments) and a few lows and slow-paced scenes. But it doesn't matter, because execution is everything! I was entertained, touched and excited as well. It does things we expect and but it also delivers something you probably have only ever imagined. And it works very well. Specially the way it ends the conflict it started, and how it all feels very human.

I also quite enjoyed the superb sound editing!

Easy recommendation for anyone interested in having a small journey. One that might leave you exactly where you started, but with a small smile that might spark something unexpected. I don't know.

Title: Everything Everywhere All at Once
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Magical, Sensational and Monumental Filmmaking
Review:
This is multiverse of Madness is done right. Everything Everywhere All at Once is a sensational and monumental achievement in filmmaking. With a spiffing and enticing screenplay, and smashing ensemble cast, this one takes you on a joyride that trips you down but you still like in any way. Immaculate writing and a superlative fusion of multiple genres make this an out of a world experience. Drop everything, take a deep breathe and cherish this phenomenal film.

When we deal with the multiverse, it is bound to be complicated, but with vivid and colorful cinematography this one explains it more beautifully. You get action, romance, family drama, science fiction, and fantasy all coming in one. The Ratatouille reference was pleasantly done. Superlative performances from Michelle Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu, and Ke Huy Quan and that heart-touching climax is worth your time.

Title: Entertaining but completely overrated
Review:
First things first: it's a good movie. I enjoyed watching it. It had mostly good acting, it was funny, most fight scenes were hilarious.

But at the same time it's too long, drawn out badly paced, repetitive and sometimes frustrating to watch. The ending could have been done in 10 minutes instead of like 30 minutes without losing anything storywise.

The over the top praise this movie gets is a thing I don't really understand to be honest. Maybe it's a sign of the times, showing how bad cinema has become, when a good but also quite flawed movie like this gets so much attention.

Nonetheless I'd recommend watching it, as it is refreshingly different to the crap that comes out of Hollywood. Also it's mostly free of clich√©s that make most modern movies so unwatchable

In summary: entertaining and funny but not even close to being the best movie ever, as some claim.

Title: Inventive but just too weird for me
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

Title: A beautiful exploration of nihilism vs existentialism
Review:
On the surface, "Everything Everywhere All At Once" is an absurd action-filled comedy about an immigrant family that discovers their ability to travel across dimensions.

Underneath the surface, it's a deeply philospohical film exploring the themes of nihilism and existentialism, and the core meaning of life.

Through its blend of surrealism and comedy, the film manages to make these philosophical questions accessible and engaging, inviting audiences to join the main character on her journey of self-discovery.

This is one of the most beautiful movies and stories I've seen, and it's one to be watched and rewatched, and it deserves every award it has received.

--

If you watch this film and don't get it, I'd recommend watching one of the videos on YouTube that talks about the philosophy and/or symbolism of Everything Everywhere All At Once. If you still don't like it, that's fine, not everyone likes the same thing.

Title: We go in a circle, do laundry, do income taxes, do laundry ... is that all there is?
Review:
Besides anything else this is a very manic movie. It plays on the (certainly fictional) concept that there are an infinite number of parallel universes and each of us exists in each of those, with particular traits and skills. We witness each character exploring a number of their alternate existences. Distilled down it is about finding your true self and building loving relationships with others. My wife and I stared watching it, she gave up after just 10 or 12 minutes, too off-kilter and manic for her. I watched all of it but in three different sittings.

The focus is on Michelle Yeoh as Evelyn Wang. Over 20 years earlier she starred in "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" and here she gets to use some of her martial arts skills. While I admire what the filmmakers did here, for ME it would never become one of my favorites, to re-watch periodically. Too manic and off-kilter and too many symbolic elements to make sense of.

This comment by a reviewer reflects my own take:

'Though I usually like high-concept creative films, this time I must admit I felt lost in all its odd layers of storytelling and couldn't emotionally get with such an incoherent film that just kept piling on absurdly illogical sci-fi things to its base plot until I ultimately had enough.' (Review by Dennis Schwartz)

At home on DVD from our public library.

'

Title: You won't see a more original film this year!
Review:
This film is so creative! It's really a film about family and love, but told in a way I've never seen. It has so much heart that it'll have you grinning and tears in your eyes all at same time. All the performances are fantastic. You can tell all the actors are having so much fun. Michelle Yeoh can definitely carry a film. She's was great. It was great to see Ke Huy Quan back in a film again. He does a lot of heavy lifting in this one and honestly deserves a Best Supporting Actor Oscar nomination. Jamie Lee Curtis literally lets it all hang out, and you can tell she's having more fun in this movie than any of the new Halloween films. The only negative thing I can say about this film is there is an image that is blurred unnecessarily. I highly recommend this film and hope it's remembered in awards season.

Title: How a multiverse should be done
Review:
This spectacular, bonkers, incredibly original, laugh out loud and incredibly moving film puts all other attempts at a multiverse to shame. And most other films for that matter.

It is so utterly unique that it is hard to compare it with anything that has gone before it.

That it was even made gives us all hope that, amongst all the regurgitated clones, lazy and unoriginal films that are made each year, a true diamond can still be found in the rough.

Everything about this film is nearly flawless. The script is one of the heros. It's tight, hilariously funny, moving, ribald (don't let kids watch it!) And, despite the utterly chaotic nature of the film, still flows and manages to keep the viewer informed enough to abandon it for being to hard to follow, which is no mean feat.

Yeoh is incredible in everyday. She shows the full range of her talents, which are broad indeed.

The rest of the main cast are superb and the casting team should be commended.

The action is, as you'd expect, it brilliant and varies enough not be become repetitive, a perennial problem with many martial arts movies.

The score is great, as is the direction and editing, which, once you've seen the film would have been a tough gig indeed.

Ive just watched it a second time and enjoyed it even more as there is so much going on, it's hard to take it all in on first viewing.

Let's hope more original films now get a chance at life. God knows, we need the..

Title: mind blown
Review:
I was resistant to watching this movie at first, because I'd seen the directors' previous, awful Swiss Army Man. But the buzz was so strong that I finally broke down and watched it. And it is crazy and exciting and touching and like nothing else.

The movie throws out ideas like the world is ending in five minutes and all the ideas need to be used before it does. The story goes everywhere and I dare you to predict anything.

The cast is great. The biggest surprise is Ke Huy Quan, because when I saw him I was like, "this guy is amazing, how have I never seen him before?" and it turns out he was the kid actor from Temple of Doom and his career had petered out years before. Which is tragic, but hopefully he gets to make a bunch of movies after winning the Oscar.

Also great performances from Michelle Yeoh (as always), and really, everyone.

If you like movies that keep you on your toes and mess with your head, you should definitely watch this. It's so much fun.

Title: Stunned
Review:
I'm 68 years old and have seen a lot of films in my time. There have been only a few times when I've left the theater in something of a state of awe for what I've seen. This was one of those times. It is a psychedelic rollercoaster, a Kung Fu flick, a love story, a family story, an immigrant saga and a comedy all wrapped up in quantum physics. It is also surprisingly moving at times and the ultimate message of the film is sorely needed today. I really can't praise it highly enough though I know it's not going to be everyone's cup of tea. Michelle Yeoh was simply amazing.

Title: Utterly Unique, Endlessly Creative, Effortlessly Funny and Surprisingly Deeply Emotive.
Review:
I have been fascinated for years by the concept of the multiverse as a narrative device, in the past roughly four years, mostly, I think, because of Sony's stupendous 'Into the Spider-Verse', and probably Adult Swim's 'Rick and Morty' multiverses seem to be everywhere, largely in Marvel and DC's respective universes, but, thanks to the Daniels, we've got an entirely new take on how the idea of a multiverse can be used in media. I hadn't, and still haven't seen the Daniels' previous film 'Swiss Army Men', but the abundance of praise this film was receiving is what made me so excited to see it, reading some of the reviews I knew that, at the very least, I'd like it, but, in all honestly I wasn't expecting to love it as much I did; I had heard of the film's creativity and overall just unique feel, but I still don't think I was fully prepared for the madness that awaited me. The story, in its most simplistic description, focuses on a Chinese woman named Evelyn Wang (Michelle Yeoh) trying to do her taxes, and this very simplistic premise, which, by the way, does spin off into an utterly chaotic multiverse plot, is one of the film's greatest strengths, as, despite all of the hyperactivity and action, the plot isn't overstuffed, its very simplistic premises allows its more symbolic elements and emotional beats to flourish more freely, and, in turn, be more impactful. The film's humour was the thing I was worried about the most, as I am very specific, or, more honestly, very picky, when it comes comedy, the bizarre, in-your-face nature of the comedy in the film, as showcased in the trailer, anyway, can work for me, but typically, I prefer more low-key comedy. However, the comedy here surprised me by being both utterly bizarre yet, surprisingly the film's dialogue has a very sarcastic vibe to it, the film manages to combine to styles of very different types of humour to create a completely new and unique comedic experience. The performances are probably some of my favourites since 'Parasite', everyone brings their A-game, though, Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Qaun particularly stunned me. However, all of the stuff mentioned above wouldn't have mattered if it weren't for the Daniels' phenomenal direction (and writing, though I did already cover that) as well as the truly sensational editing by Paul Rogers, which brought the film together so well.

'Everything Everywhere' is such a unique and special film, that already feels like a classic, and a testament to what filmmaking can be and do.

Title: Kill Bill and Inception Make a Beautiful but Stupid Love Child.
Review:
The genre is hard to define. Think Kill Bill meets Inception, but silly. It attempts to meld comedy, mind-bending sci-fi, and action into one, which it does to an extent, but fails to make it more than a sum of its parts. It was a great idea with an arguably poor execution.

A slow-burning first half turns into a fast, colourful, adventure sailing through the multiverse. It's a visually impressive piece that pounds the senses and ends with a wave of feel-good fun. Everything Everywhere All at Once oozes originality and creates a new mind-bending world in which to immerse yourself.

Yet, originality alone cannot carry this film. The jokes did not always land. The script was so simplistic it sometimes felt like it was directed towards children - something belied by the unnecessarily sexual nature of many scenes. Possibly the worst issue is the many plot holes. In a modern world where anything is possible, the choice of martial arts as the main medium of warfare is unexplained.

To use an analogy from the film, Everything Everywhere All at Once is like a clay pot that holds your attention in the moment, but is so full of cracks that it fragments the moment you start to reflect any deeper.

Title: Michelle Yeoh in the Multiverse of Madness
Review:
Why take drugs when you can experience whatever fever dream this film was?

Truly one of the most bonkers and most creative movies I've ever seen! Phenomenal performances, great characters, an engaging story, an amazing soundtrack, stunning visuals, cool action sequences, and genuinely funny moments while exploring deep themes and having a touching message that will no doubt resonate with audiences.

If you don't watch this movie then you are committing a crime! One of the best experiences of 2022.

I decided that I had wasted enough of my time and gave up on it. All it did was remind me of what a waste of time it is to listen to anything the SAG or Academy Award people have to say.

Title: Easily the best movie I've seen in theatres in decades.
Review:
This movie is so good it's mind blowing. At a time when every other movie is a formulaic super hero blockbuster that, while entertaining in their own right, often have literally nothing valuable to say, Everything Everywhere All at Once shows us that we can have great action blockbusters that also have something to say about life, love, happiness, and our own infinite regrets.

As much as I loved this movie though, it should be said it definitely will not appeal to everyone as I witnessed several people walk out of the theatre when I saw it. I can only imagine why they left, but looking at some of the negative reviews here my guess is it was either because they felt offended by something in the movie, or because they just did not understand it. That's unfortunate, because they're truly depriving themselves of one of the best movies in recent years, if not all time.

Title: Migraine central
Review:
This is a frenetic, bombastic visual spectacle that will either leave you flabbergasted, overwhelmed, confused or nauseated ; or possibly a combination of these feelings.

At the heart of the film there seems to be a heartfelt message. However the journey to get there takes you on a acid fuelled wild ride full of hotdog fingers, rubber phalluses, bum-bag nunchakus and racoonouille.

In turn this fast-paced vomit-inducing journey detracts from the overarching conclusion leaving you overwhelmed with everything you've just witnessed.

There were certainly parts which were hilariously ridiculous, filled with adrenaline fuelled action and emotionally deep but my overall feeling at the end was just exhaustion.

They tried too much, everywhere, all at once.

Title: I Left the Theater Speechless in the Best Possible Way
Review:
A Chinese-American woman is struggling in nearly every aspect of her life. She is in the process of getting divorced from her husband, her laundry business is struggling, she has distant relationships with her family including her own daughter and she is being audited by the IRS. On the day she and her family go to a meeting with an IRS inspector, her husband's mind gets taken over by someone from the Alpha Universe. Evelyn Wang learns that she needs to connect with different versions of herself in different timelines. This is because there is an evil entity named Jobu Tupaki that is seemingly trying to destroy the different universes. In the parallel universes, Evelyn learns different skills to fend off against her enemies which seem similar to her hobbies.

Going into Everything Everywhere All at Once, I was pretty excited for it, but also a little worried that it might be overhyped due to the sheer acclaim it received over the past few weeks. Just from the trailer alone, this looked unique and stunning. It looked like the type of movie that I dream of seeing in theaters. Original, action-packed, creative and funny. I prepared myself for a movie with a bonkers story... and yet it still manages to stun me.

I do not think there has ever been a movie that I have watched in a theater that left me speechless the way Everything Everywhere All at Once did. I don't think I have seen a movie as creative and original as this... ever, at least as far as brand new movies go. EEAaO takes its already insane premise and goes as deep as possible with it exploring different possibilities a single person could live, how it can all go wrong for them in seconds and how when a person decides to go rogue and stop caring, it affects the people they are around. Watching this movie made me think of all of the possibilities I could have had and what decisions I made led me to where I am today. That was one of the biggest takeaways I had from the story and the script does a wonderful job exploring this insane premise to its fullest.

But of course, you cannot have a story like this and not have humor. This is one of the funniest movies I have seen. The jokes in this film had me cracking up like crazy. It can go from physical comedy to more subtle things like references and situational comedic moments such as making fun of the chosen one trope or how Evelyn's world keeps going from the Alpha Universe to her normal universe. That leads to some hilarious moments of physical comedy. For me though, the funniest scene in the entire film is a specific fight with Jobu Tupaki against a few of the security guards. That scene made my mouth drop like no other scene did. I could not believe the utter nonsense I was watching and I loved every minute of it. This movie is comedy gold as it is not afraid to push the boundaries at all.

Despite the wacky nature of the script, the movie does not lose its way of the sad and touching moments such as Evelyn's relationships with her family and spouse both in this universe, and in the parallel universes. This leads to me Evelyn herself. Despite Evelyn's rude attitude and unpleasant nature, you cannot help but feel bad for her during this film. She is shown how successful she could have been, she seems to get frustrated about everything and everyone and she her relationships with her family are distant at best and disastrous at worst. However, you can still she has a caring and loving side and her experience through the multiverse shows her this side of her. In fact, the multiverse shows several different sides of Evelyn! She uses them in combat to go from being a confused and scared woman to being just as strong as Alpha Waymond. This makes Evelyn a very intriguing and flawed protagonist that I enjoyed watching develop.

Michelle Yeoh is terrific as Evelyn Wang. Every single expression, emotion and line of dialogue she delivers are all on point. Yeoh captures the fear, confusion and fright a woman who is exploring alternate timelines of herself has while fighting against people controlled by others in the multiverse trying to kill her. I'm not too familiar with Yeoh's filmography, but this movie makes me want to see more of her films. Then there is Ke Huy Quan as Evelyn's husband, Waymond. This man has so much diversity in this role from a bumbling, but kindhearted family man who is struggling just as much as Evelyn is to a badass agent from the Alpha Universe. He is perfect in both roles and he is a great action star too. However, the scenes where he is Evelyn's husband work beautifully because of his sincerity and sweetness in the role. Quan shows how diverse he is with this role as the same man with two vastly different personalities.

The rest of the performances are great too like James Hong showing great comedic chops as Evelyn's father while showing some hidden depths to that character, Jenny Slate as a bratty customer and Stephanie Hsu as Evelyn's daughter Joy and as the villain Jobu Tupaki. Just like Evelyn, Tupaki had some depth to her actions. Hsu captures the creepy vibe from her character as well as those depths that are explored. Jamie Lee Curtis as the IRS agent also manages to give a performance that shows a soft spot to her seemingly cold hearted nature which makes her shine. Finally, Harry Shum Jr. Cracked me up in his role in the movie, but I don't want to spoil it. All in all, this is a fantastic cast.

There are even some martial arts fight scenes and they are a blast to watch. I love the editing techniques used in them. They make the fights energetic and fast paced without making them confusing and shaky. Each fight had me smiling because they involved wacky antics as well making them all feel different from each other. The cinematography is beautiful as well with many shots reflecting the situation Evelyn is in with her different dimensions as well as her fractured relationships. The sound design is what really shines though. This movie sounds amazing with how it sets up the tone of the film and how it portrays the fighting sequences as fun, but brutal. The soundtrack is awesome as well with a beautiful musical score and some great vocal tracks as well.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is not only easily the best movie I have seen this year so far, but it is my favorite movie that I have seen in theaters in years. In a world where there are so many franchise films and remakes and reboots, this is the type of film I love seeing come out. It has so much to say about decisions, love, hatred and family while being hilarious, awesome and original at the same time. While I think some people may be turned off by some of the trippiness of the movie and visuals, I highly recommend this movie to everyone who wants to see a great original film. Seriously, if you have plans to go to the movies soon, this is a must watch. I don't think I will ever see another film like Everything Everywhere All at Once.

Title: Multiverse, without Marvel Superheroes
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: A Fun Romp into the Multiverse
Review:
I recently had the opportunity to view this movie, and I'm certainly glad I did. It's a decidedly unique take on the genre of science fiction/action/adventure. The acting is top notch, especially Michelle Yeoh's portrayal of the protagonist, Evelyn. It's bizarre, funny, smart, sweet and a whole lot of fun that will maintain your attention from start to finish. Is the film's message particularly deep or profound? No. Is it one of the greatest movies I've ever seen? No. But it's a wild ride that ought not to be missed for its uniqueness. Edit: As of 4/28/2022, this movie has landed on IMDB's Top 250 list, the only 2022 film thus far to reach this remarkable milestone. As of this edit, the movie is at #57 with an average rating of 8.4. It's likely to go higher, because the movie's IMDB page show it as 8.8 with 26K ratings. How high will it go? Who knows? Top 15 maybe? At any rate, I'm so happy that this has occurred.

Title: That's something different that we normally get and it's positive.
Review:
I think we can all agree this isn't the easiest movie to watch. You have to be really focused all the time, otherwise you will lose important things in order to follow the story. It's a difficult story but certainly not a bad one, on the contrary, it's a visual fest sometimes. If you don't like slow paced movies you should give this one a try, as it is the complete opposite, very fast paced, jumping from one scene to another in no particular order. I thought the storyline was very imaginative, almost made me wonder what drugs they used whilst writing this story. The acting was also very good, especially from the lead actress Michelle Yeoh, but the rest of the cast was also faultless. Everything Everywhere All at Once is a perfect title for this spectacular movie. Some people might need a second viewing to fully understand the whole concept but since the quality of this movie is of another level that shouldn't be a problem.

Title: it really was everything everywhere all at once
Review:
I'm gonna be honest here and say I was disappointed that I didn't absolutely LOVE this movie like so many other reviewers- but I hope through my explanation you can see why. Is this a bad film? Oh, absolutely not. It's incredibly charming and delightful at times, and even very meaningful- and made me cry towards the end. Where my problem lies with this film though is through its messaging. There are some basic flaws to be had with this one, it can be predictable at times, its pacing can kinda drag, and there are quite a few cliche moments here and there- but most of them feel insignificant enough to ignore and enjoy the incredibly bizarre atmosphere and story this film is trying to tell. Its overall meaning though feels a bit squired, and feels very mixed in my mind. I know it means well, but I can't help but feel it doesn't do enough to satisfy me. All this time they are dealing between the relationship of the mother and the daughter, and still as the film comes to an end we see the mother nitpicking and not changing. She seems willing to change, but then does nothing in the end to resolve these facts and it just feels a bit too messy to ignore. Not only that, but the fact that just because the mom loves the daughter is an excuse for her to keep hurting her- is not okay, and I feel kind of hurt that a lot of that goes unresolved and the tone seems to pick up where the story has no right to let off. If you can get past that, the film is enjoyable. It definitely feels otherworldly, and has a very unique feel. It's easily a very originally made film, with some familiar elements, and visually it is also quite beautiful to watch and see unfold. The acting is incredible and I love how detailed and full of life each little character is, never shining away from darker elements, even if it means not fully settling things. It has some missteps here and there for me, and I can't ignore certain aspects of it- but in the end, Everything Everywhere All at Once does deliver on its promise enough to be enjoyable and is certainly a memorable watch.

My Rating: 7.3/10.

Title: A Revolutionary Game Changer in Profound Storytelling
Review:
Rarely does a film manage to explore so many themes about the multiverse all at once successfully, because the ones that do have to defy all plausibility to achieve a worthwhile story. In the case of Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert's latest feature Everything Everywhere All At Once, the endless imagination shown on screen has never felt so sincere. With the film having garnished critical acclaim from critics and moviegoers alike, one has to wonder how this movie managed to pull off an overly complicated multiverse premise. The answer, as simple as it may sound, lies in one unhappy woman in an unfulfilled life.

The film stars Michelle Yeoh as Evelyn Quan Wang, a Chinese American woman who faces a serious IRS audit. Upon discovering a more serious threat in parallel universes, Wang must connect with alternate versions of herself to prevent ultimate multiverse destruction. With that premise established, not even that synopsis alone can summarize how overly complex the storytelling is. By subverting this story of an unhappy woman's life in her failing business along with her naive husband Waymond and changing adult daughter Joy, the film knows how to balance its highly tense tone with a lot of absurdist humor and familial pathos. On top of that, there can't even be one genre to describe the movie, as there are numerous elements of black comedy, sci-fi fantasy, martial arts action, and even experimental animation. Of course, at the story's heart is a bittersweet domestic drama dealing with marital problems, immigration trauma and a struggling mother-daughter relationship. In the end, the creative elements cleverly service the swirling multiverse angle in lieu of a straightforward drama.

In analyzing the meaning of life through generational nihilism and otherworldly profoundness, the filmmakers accomplished telling so many different stories while bringing them all back to the main focus. While the film can go on a bit long in its excessive imagination, it makes every scene worth the runtime with a fun mix of entertaining fluff and emotional substance. For all of the entertaining action choreography, gripping stakes and hilarious transition from one weird world to another, the craziness has a purpose in developing Evelyn past her mistakes in order to move towards being a better person. Given how much society tends to put down those who think outside our own universe, never has one whole movie felt like such a relatable palate cleanser. Maybe it might be from the cast's spot on performances, especially depending on the universe, but seeing so many different points of view on one subject matter alone makes the experience far more sympathetic than it might have been without everything occurring all at once. It's all out there in the best possible way.

Of all the weirdly unconventional thrill rides of a motion picture in the history of filmmaking, very few seem to even come close to the absurd brilliance of Everything Everywhere All At Once. While it might seem like a lot to take in as far as tackling so much in more than two hours, it will surely inspire at least one human being to find proper meaning in their life once and for all. Regardless of who you are and where you are, I would recommend this to everyone in the world. It's a movie with a lot on its mind, just like how you will feel after seeing it. That alone is worth risking everything for just one view.

Title: Great beginning. Messy Endings.
Review:
Part 1: Everything was pretty solid. Interesting premise, great action scenes and humour. Was enjoying it a lot.

The parts onwards just spectacularly derailed. It became an incoherent loud mess of nothing. It felt long but didn't really serve an overall purpose. I understand the ending and the "message" but it felt messy in my opinion.

The final act really had to deliver to be able to fully appreciate and enjoy this film. In which it failed.

6.5/10 (rounded down)

Title: Overhyped is all I could say
Review:
Not a bad movie at all. But I expected more from a movie that won seven oscars. The main plotline could have been different from sexuality. There are lot of issues other than this that could have been a core for the family storyline. The multiversal concept was nicely blended as it should ideally be for this genre. The only problem I have is with the propaganda that comes in every movie and this is probably the sole reason why it was being pushed towards mainstream media. The acting, direction, cinematography is quite good, has a lot of finesses specially the character of the husband. But at times, the story might stretch even though the pacing is fast and there is no explanation as to why this was the case.

Title: A Pointless Bucket of Tedious Sophomoric Visual Metaphors
Review:
The onslaught of Visual Metaphors gets old, and one is looking for the film to just get it over with and end. So disappointing - doesn't live up to expectations nor the hype. First half has some engaging moments, but it could have wrapped up scenes without "explaining" what we already knew. I don't need a primer to explain the content and themes of a film thank you very much.

This film could have been so much better, but it fails to rely upon the intricate visuals (so painstakingly laid out), deciding instead we needed "explanation" of the filmmakers' intent. Such a hedge essentially ruined this film - it is awkward and runs about 45 minutes too long because of it. Nice effort visually - my rating is frankly higher than I feel it should be, but the visuals were often witty, so...5.

Overall, I had to force myself to see entire film, and it was painful. I feel cheated out of "what could have been." Perhaps one Director would have made a difference. Don't know. Won't ever know. It's a self-indulgent mess. üí£

Title: Terrible Movie - Stay Away
Review:
I have a unique perspective on this movie. I write articles on quantum physics and parallel universes. Also write a newsletter on ancient mystery schools. The writing is trash. It looks like a sophomore in High School took an High School quantum physics basic course and wrote the script. The script was ALL wrong. The acting was good. The directing sucked, why the subtitles. When subtitles enhance the movie, put some in. Here they detracted from the movie and made the movie suck even more. The Bruce Lee marital arts sections were wrong, long and boring. FIRST MOVIE IN 30 YEARS THAT I WALKED OUT OF -- and got my money back.

Title: There will be a before and after this movie
Review:
I watched this movie with my wife. She hated it. I loved it. It's that kind of movie. You either love it or you hate it. The bits that made me laugh were the bits that lost my wife. She thought it was ridiculous at times. That it went too far. I disagree. Like the 1st Matrix, the concept here allows for everything to be possible. Imagination is the limit. The Matrix being a blockbuster action movie, it was stuck within its own limitations. This independent movie has no limitations, no boundaries and it shows. It goes as far as it can. It made me care, it made me laugh, it made me unconformable at times. It made me feels many emotions that a sci-fi movie doesn't usually make you feel. This movie is a metaphor, an allegory of life. In the end it made me reflect on my own life and my past choices.

I understand it's not a movie for everyone. I don't judge. It's not about "getting it". I understand some people don't like it and feel a bit angered by the overall praise.

Anyway, it's a bold movie that took some major risks. And it paid off. I believe other movies will learn from this one and be inspired by it. And that there is a before and after this movie.

Title: And the Oscar goes to...
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: WOWWW!
Review:
My first instinct is to say "they don't make em like this anymore" but that begs the question: "when did they ever?"

Everything Everywhere All at Once is genuinely one of the best films I have ever seen. I have nothing to say other than I loved every second of this masterpiece. No movie is objectively flawless; it's simply not possible. This just so happens to be a film that works for me on every level. In a release lineup packed with Fantastic Beasts, Sonic 2 and Ambulance, This movie is the one to see if you're looking for something truly special.

Title: Best Picture?
Review:
This is a good movie. It might be a Very good movie. But there is nothing, not one exceptional quality about this movie that puts it into the top tier of films.

The reason this is a problem is in 2022? There were some 9/10, 10/10 type movies that were exceptional in: writing, direction, overall production, camera, story, characters, entire sum of parts.

Everything Everywhere All at Once? Does not live up to its pretentious title, let alone stand up to other truly great films, made by great film makers.

By comparison, this movie comes off as experimental, and a first try by young film makers. In recent history, the South Korean movie Parasite? That was an exceptional film, with a stunning degree of detail, made by a master director who has honed his craft for decades!

This is a very good movie about an asian American family with culturally interesting array of issues, injected with a bizarre science fiction element, borrowed from recent superhero films. Funny thing is, the meta-verse idea? It's reason for existing? Has more to do with making the same franchise over and over again, trying to give it meaning... Is it clever use in this film? Maybe? But everything feels staged, unreal - and that lack of grounding makes for tedious moments and scenes, where as a viewer? Ok! Thats weird, and makes no sense, except as following words on a page, script?

Reminds me of reading about the script evolution of the movie Eternal Sunshine for the Spotless Mind ... A Great movie. The original script drafts were wildly experimental, having to do with repeat visitations to the same memories over and over - but over time and drafts? That script was tamed/mastered, and made for a touching, grounded, fascinating science fiction experience - not to mention, including an apt title that fit the content.

Everything Everywhere All at Once? How could that title Ever be satisfied? Isn't best picture, best actors, best directors supposed to be about Merit? Isn't supposed to be about what is objectively the best? I know it's a subjective sector, but there are real metrics that can be analyzed - and this film comes up woefully short in every single respect! This is seriously like giving Spiderman: No Way Home several academy awards because it was a good entertaining movie, that everyone involved somehow found a way to politic into critical success. That doesn't mean either are bad movies... But it does mean that the Academy award winners are a joke - don't reward merit, which makes that entire celebration of the arts? Questionable. I do still think, by and large, nominations still have value, but on this current path? Even nominated movies may end up chosen for reasons other than actual film making merit, which is unfortunate.

Title: A spark of light in the infinite cinematic universe of darkness
Review:
This here is the Evangelion of the cinema. Finally, after 3 years - a movie that actually I didn't have to FFW most of the time. It's wacky, it's confusing in a proper measure when it's the right time to be confusing, it's preposterous at times (Look for a guy doing it with a table lamp) but if you are not one of those people who watch a part of a movie, or read a part of a book, and decides on a judgement with an incomplete experience - you will watch this entire epic and you might just enjoy, or have fun, or feel relieved in this time of uncertainty. I wanted to say something about prizes and Oscars, but let them slap around. Awards don't make a good movie, good writing and execution do. And this was obviously a hard movie both to write and execute - and it was done accordingly. I am happy I've taken time to watch this, and I don't remember a movie leaving such a good taste after finishing it for a long time now. This is great.

Title: Good but...
Review:
I honestly expected more from an A24 film. With all the hype, I expected this film to be a total mind f$%^ and to leave me excited, confused, and wanting to think more about it.

I say it's good because it is, I think it's hyper relevant for today. The movie is all about the infinite possibilities in the one life we live and the crippling anxiety that comes with the choice to live one life out of infinite. This plot is interesting, the cinematography is fun, the humor is, well not my speed. I just think the plot could have been utilized in a more cerebral and thought provoking way.

That's all, I hope you found this review helpful. I would recommend going out and seeing the film and I would be interested if you agree or disagree.

Title: Everything Everywhere All at Once - Bites Off More Than It Can Chew
Review:
This is a thought-provoking film; and an entertaining one as well. However, it certainly does bite off a bit more than it can chew. The subject of alternative universes has been done several times before; a few better, but most not as good as this film. The two Dannys do a fine job writing and producing this film. The film can even pass for a horror movie since it includes the IRS, a far more horrible monster than any ever conceived on film. Michelle Yeoh does a very nice job in her role as does Ke Huy Quan as her husband. I think at one time or another, we all would like to be in alternate universes. Just too much on the plate here.

Title: Nice to see Yeoh, to see Yeoh Nice.
Review:
I was a bit concerned that the hype for "Everything Everywhere all at once" might lead to inevitable disappointment when it came to seeing it, and perhaps for the first 10 minutes or so, I felt like that might be the case. Fortunately, though, once the real plot of the film began, I was blown away on a cavalcade of humour, wit, but mostly just ideas, that make the film a pretty unique experience.

Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh) is generally disappointed with how her life has turned out. None of the three relationships in her life, with her husband Waymond (Ke Huy Quan), her father (James Hong) or her daughter Joy (Stephanie Hsu) is particularly happy and her laundrette is in trouble, and due for a tax audit. One the day of the audit, she's contacted by an alternate version of her husband who explains that he's been searching the multiverse for her, as she might be the only hope against a dark force.

Already I feel like that's more plot than I'm happy giving to anyone who might be interested in seeing "Everything Everywhere All at Once". Once the plot starts in earnest it's really a film unlike any other - there are some elements like "The Matrix" and some a bit like "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" but to describe it as being like either film isn't really. It's a constantly inventive story, thrilling just to look at, let alone to follow along with. It's consistently funny, despite its moments of action and occasionally mild horror.

It's grounded in a great performance though from Yeoh and terrific supporting ones from Ke Huy Quan and especially Stephanie Hsu. That grounded performance is paid off too, in a resolution that, without spoiling anything, is surprisingly profound and emotional.

I can see why it won't gel with some people but with me it absolutely did and I was dazzled, amused and moved throughout.
