Title: Highly original and exhausting at the same time
Review:
As "Everything Everywhere All at Once" (2022 release; 139 min.) opens, we are introduced to Evelyn Quan, who along with her husband, runs a laundromat. For reasons unknown, the laundromat is being audited by the IRS, and a meeting with the IRS auditor does not go well. Then out of the blue, Evelyn's mind is taken over by her husband's alternative from the Alphaverse, one of apparently thousands of alternative universes out there... At this point we are 10 minutes into the movie.

Couple of comment: this is the latest from writers-producers-directors Daniel Kwam and Daniel Scheineret (a/k/a "the Danierls"). This is only their second feature length movie, after 2016's critically acclaimed "Swiss Army Man". Like that movie, in "Everything Everywhere All at Once" they bring a highly original premise and story line. Frankly, the plot is so off kilter that it doesn't even make any sense, nor need it be. Instead, one simply sits back and enjoys whatever is unfolding on the screen. Michelle Yeoh is outstanding as Evelyn. I didn't realize that the IRS auditor is played by Jamie Lee Curtis until the credits rolled. I don't know if others felt the same, but I felt a bit overwhelmed, if npot exhausted, by it all and I watched the entire movie over two equal parts on consecutive evenings. That does not mean that I didn't like the movie, let me be clear.

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" was an unexpected box office hit during its US theatrical run that started last Spring, For whatever reason I just didn't feel drawn to it. Then earlier this week, it gathered an amazing 11 Oscar nominations, more than any other film, and I told myself I really needed to find out what the buzz was all about. I watched the film earlier this week (it's streaming on Showtime). Glad I did. If you are in the mood for truly something very different and uniquely original, I'd readily suggest you check this out, and draw your own conclusion.

Title: A Classic for the Future
Review:
I was losing my mind while watching it. There are lots of things and reference that keeps you pump up, and it's just hilarious.

However, the main metaphor of the movie just seem very weak, and draggy at the end. At its basic, it's about a mother daughter relationship, however, the chemistry and backstory isn't there to justified the ending that was chosen.

That said, I choose not to be too bothered by it, and just enjoy the film at its surface.

Producers: Russo Brothers, Casting Director: Sarah for all you marvel fans.

Title: Amazing...
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is an Action - Comedy movie in which we watch a middle-aged Chinese immigrant getting into an extraordinary adventure. She will soon find herself trying to save her own existence by exploring other universes.

I was simply fascinated by this movie and I have to admit that it left me speechless. The plot was a big surprise for me since it contained plenty of action and it was combined very well with mystery and fantasy. The direction which was made by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert who are also the writers did an amazing job and they presented their main characters and the plot very well. Regarding the interpretations of both Michelle Yeoh's who played as Evelyn Wang and Ke Huy Quan's who played as Waymond Wang were outstanding and they made the difference. In conclusion, I have to say that "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a nice, interesting movie and I highly recommend everyone to watch it.

Title: um, what was that?
Review:
Had such high hopes for this movie. It's one of those that the title just grabs you without knowing anything about it. Almost convinced my wife to watch it with me. Well, I'm glad I didn't. The movie had so many awkward moments and it tried to send a message of some kind the whole time, but somehow I did not buy it. It reminded me of some other multiverse movies(it borrows from them too), but does its own, I call it goofy version, which I did not enjoy at all. I haven't seen it mentioned here, but there's something about it that made me recall Cloud Atlas. Maybe because it involved same characters in different scenarios? I can see the effort put in it and the acting was quite good, but after it was over I felt like watching some random fan fiction parody. To me it does not feel like a complete movie and it is understandable considering the smaller budget. However, there should be a fine line between cheap production and just having low budget. A real masterpiece is the one you can never guess the budget for it. The movie is okay to watch even if a bit long, but doesn't come even close to TOP 250.

Title: Deeper Meaning
Review:
The continuous message of who we might be in various permutations of the universe made me think deeply about my relationship to my mom who died 5 years ago- and to my siblings alive today. I did NOT expect it- I am not a deep thinker or movie crier, but OMG this one required a box of tissues. Loved it.

Title: A multiverse of brilliance
Review:
The thing that impresses me most about this movie is how it remains coherent in spite of the multiple threads, not least the different iterations of each character, and how it manages to bring those threads together at the end, to be poignant and relevant, but to do this and be laugh-out-loud hilarious, too - that's something special.

Up until Everything Everywhere All at Once, I hadn't seen either Michelle Yeoh or Jamie Lee Curtis do comical performances (I do watch movies and TV, honest), so the whole thing was a double delight!

We could talk about the science fiction and how the movie was another take on the multiverse, but these were mere vehicles to whisk us along and communicate some strong themes, much the same as the outlandish weirdness of Being John Malkovich.

It does demonstrate something I've learned as an aspiring writer: it makes no difference how implausible a situation is so long as the characters acknowledge and respond to things as we would ... to a degree - here I'm thinking about the head-with-legs scene in The Thing with Kurt Russell.

An excellent movie.

Title: Deliciously insane!
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is totally and completely bonkers in the best way. It's charming, heartwarming and incredibly weird. Michelle Yeoh is great in the lead role, and the entire supporting cast all do an excellent job pulling off a story that is as far out there as it gets. The film is hilariously funny, action packed, and very genuine is its message, presenting a timely theme of generational change and the existential crisis of modern youth. Top notch editing also makes the madcap story progression really shine, overall one of the best films I've seen in a while.

Title: Last year I took psychedelics for the first time. They didn't deliver the insight this film did.
Review:
Amazing, cathartic, and intense. Seriously, I'm 63 years old, and there's not much that surprises, let alone dynamicly engages me in a way I have not experienced. Last year, over several months I experimented with several psychedelic substances. They did not deliver one tenth of what this movie did. I'll leave it at that. I do believe that those of average intelligence will hate this film, and the ones and threes bear this out. Either this film will wildly exceed your every expectation, or it won't.

Title: Metaphorical Fullness
Review:
The Daniels (Kwan and Scheinert) are a pair of young North American directors and screenwriters, who started out making music videos and managed to make the transition to film, using a lot of digital effects and a good dose of imagination.

They have in this film the consecration of Hollywood, which has certainly seen in this duo, an innovative cinematographic language, capable of captivating a young audience, accustomed to the breakneck pace of video games, in this age of the Internet and comics adapted to cinema.

The work is interesting, displaying a set of parallel metaphorical universes, from which it extracts, however, banal, albeit well-intentioned, narrative and ethical solutions to everyday problems, no less banal.

The real innovation of the film is the combination, in a single package, of a breakneck pace, a delirious imagination, an amalgamation of popular culture references, with a special focus on martial arts films and a panoply of state-of-the-art visual effects.

It may not excite those over 40 years of age, but it certainly impresses, while seeming to ecstatic the younger ones.

Title: Movies this beautifully made come once every other decade. An absolute masterpiece.
Review:
I'll keep this review simple and short. Yes it is a great and beautifully made movie, from the cinematography to the script writing, the acting and the costume design, everything about this movie was done to almost perfection.

If you make the decision to see this movie, after 2 hours you'd be filled with so much emotions, good emotions you'd probably cry tears of joy. A job well done and the high ratings you see isn't just hype.

Enjoy the ride.

Title: One of the most creative movies to come out in a while
Review:
In today's landscape of superheroes, reboots, generic action/adventure movies, this film stands a head above the rest for trying to do something different. It's incredibly absurd, wildly creative, hilarious, and emotional. Try seeing it in the movie theater at least once because I can assure you, it is an experience.

Title: Beautiful art that makes you FEEL
Review:
I saw this film in April 2022 without knowing anything about it; I went into the theater blind and not expecting anything in particular. By the end of the film I was shocked by how much I had laughed and cried.

The chaos demonstrated throughout the film is indicative of the chaos of our current world, the chaos in our minds as we try to navigate our careers and families and self, and the chaos of the unknown. I don't think I've ever teared up quite as much I did at the conclusion of the film. In the end, this is a movie about empathy, family, love, and kindness. The pure, unfiltered emotion that pours from this movie is so magical. I love-LOVE-a movie that can make me feel so much.

Title: Something missing.
Review:
Definitely a very creative movie. The directing, cinematography, and acting are great, especially from the lead (Yeoh).

The movie is missing something that I can't quite put my finger on, and it keeps it from being the masterpiece it probably could have been. My only tangible complaints are an over-abundance of touchy feely crap, and that the husband is absolutely obnoxious. Even just his voice grates on you. The movie is also at least half an hour longer than it really needed to be.

None of these issues explain why it was so hard to pay attention to this movie though. The entire time I thought that I /should/ be enjoying it, but I simply wasn't. I have no idea what the actual issue is, it just seems like the movie could have been much better than it was.

Title: A blast of an adventure, both absurd and profound
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Review:

Title: "Was that it?"
Review:
Being of a certain age , you grow accustomed to the hype blowing in and then back out again around the major award ceremonies so I took with a pinch of salt all the praise Everything, Everywhere, All at Once has garnered.

After sitting through the 2 odd hours all kinds of review comments came flashing back to me but to my honest surprise all I could think was "is this the worst film" ever to win the best picture Oscar?

Still several hours after finishing the film I can't see any highlights and this film was supposed have the best actors of the last 12 months?? Really????

The premise of the film is genius and has an endless amount of potential but what I took from it all was just a mixed mess of mediocrity I know it's all a matter of taste but how this movie ousted All Quiet on the Western Front from best picture at the Oscar's is just a joke.

Title: Watched a couple times
Review:
In the first 30 mins, I thought... hmm.... Low budget and crazy movie, but funny, ok, I can continue. I did not pay enough attention at the beginning but just casually watched it.

Then, I found that there are so many messages and meanings inside. I was so touched at the end.

I love this movie so much, I watched a couple times and found that I missed a lot at the beginning.

Highly recommend u to pay more attention to all the details. I think I need to watch it again.

Thanks to the 2 Daniel boys as what James Hong said.

Thanks to Jackie Chan for not taking this movie. I am sure Michelle Yeoh and Kwan play way better than him.

Title: A NEW GENRE MASTERPIECE
Review: Daniel Kwan & Daniel Scheinert's dazzling, mind-bending, muti-verse fantasy epic film is unlike anything that has ever been seen on the big screen. I did not get a chance to see this unique film in cinema this past year, I recently saw it on the Amazon prime steaming service. Indeed the story is complicated and the film itself is very confusing at first, but it is truly a fantastic motion picture filled with grandiose ambitions and vivld imagination. It concerns a middle-aged Chinese immigrant named Evelyn Wang, brilliantly played with a serious conviction by Michelle Yeoh who won a richly earned Oscar, Golden Globe Award and SAGA Award for Best Actress, her wimpy husband Waymond, terrifically played by Ke Huy Quan who delivered an Oscar, Golden Globe Award and SAGA Award winning performance for Best Supporting Actor, who both own and run a large neighborhood laundromat that is on the verge of financial failure. The troubled Evelyn also struggles to cope with her rocky marriage to Waymond, her judgmental father Gong Gong, wonderfully played by the legendary 94 year old veteran character actor James Hong, and her insecure gay daughter Joy, superbly played by Stephanie Hsu in an Oscar and SAGA Award nominated turn for Best Supporting Actress. Because of her mounting income tax troubles Evelyn now has to face a shabbily-dressed IRS auditor from hell named Deirdre Beaubeirdre, sensationally played by a nearly unrecognizable Jamie Lee Curtis in an hilarious scene-stealing Oscar, Golden Golden Award and SAGA Award winning performance for Best Supporting Actress. Evelyn's unpleasant meeting with Deirdre at the IRS office will change her life when she becomes swept away in a insane muti-verse adventure in which she alone will save the world from an all-powerful evil entity while connecting with the other lives she could of led. Exceptional Oscar winning direction by Kwan & Scheinert who also won Oscars for their amazing Original Screenplay. Impressive visual effects, and striking cinematography by Larkin Seiple, and an evocative Oscar nominated score by Son Lux. This new surrealistic genre masterpiece is genuinely moving and utterly hilarious not to mention visually stunning. Winner of 7 Academy Awards including Best Picture.

Title: Unique, exciting, funny, touching... literally "everything", as the title implies.
Review:
This is a movie for which I came in with no expectations or prior knowledge, except something about googly eyes. Having watched the trailer after the fact, I think I still would not have been prepared for just how absurdly fantastic and out of this world EEAAO would be. This movie is probably one of the most unique films I've ever seen. It's not simply the visuals as others have pointed out that make this movie so different. It is also the direction, storytelling style, humor, and just the entire vibe of the movie, which blends and shifts between different elements and styles as fluidly as our protagonists shifts between versions of herself.

The writing and direction here are top notch. While it does rush through the specifics of how the multiverse travel works, it explains precisely enough for you to follow along while not boring the audience with too many details. The main plot is laid out early, and is relatively straightforward, but still has enough twists and turns along the way to make it really fun and interesting. Our main antagonist and the main plot device are... fantastic, you'll see. The writing really shines when it comes to character development. This is heightened due to us of course seeing multiple versions of each character. We are able to see how characters differ in various universes, but also the core things that stay the same and really make each character who they are. More so than any other multiverse movie (which there are a lot of these days), this film really uses the alternate versions well as vehicles in order to further develop the main versions of our protagonists. A big part of this is the direction, and how the jumps between different multiverses are shot and timed. This is especially incredible during fight scenes, in which it will often quickly snap back and forth between the different versions of characters. It looked really slick and I'm in awe at how they were able to film it so well.

As far as the acting - every single member of the cast was so superb. Michelle Yeoh was INCREDIBLE, I truly hope she gets nationwide recognition for her work here. She had amazing stunts as always, but also had scenes in which she could really showcase her acting and comedic timing. Ke Huy Quan, the actor who plays Waymond, was equally superb in my eyes. Some of you might recognize him as the little kid from Indiana Jones: Temple of Doom! His entire character is so unique, playing mostly a fragile man with a high pitched voice, but he really shines in ways you would not expect. He has one of the most memorable and well delivered scenes in the whole movie, which nearly brought me to tears. It seems he does not act much anymore but I would love to see him in more stuff. Stephanie Hsu, the daughter, was also fantastic and brought an amazing charisma to the movie. Good ole reliable James Hong did his thing as always. Probably the most interesting and funny performance to me was Jamie Lee Curtis as Deirdre, the IRS lady, who had some hilarious moments throughout the movie. All in all a stellar job from the entire cast.

While I will likely need a second watch to try and fully grasp the message here (though not every movie has to have one), I did have a few takeaways on initial watch. I think this film really tries to tell us to appreciate what we have, even though it is quite literally focusing on the "what ifs" that lead to the alternate realities. Again without spoiling, each version of our protagonist has some flaws (some REALLY weird ones as you'll see) or some regrets. Applying this to just our non-multiversal reality, we tend to focus on what our peers around us have that we don't, when we should actually realize that everyone has things they regret or feel are missing. We should instead focus on fully cherishing the life we have and loving the people immediately around us. Another message, closely related to the first, seemed to be that we should sometimes slow down and just soak in what is around us rather than constantly worry about what is next. One particular scene involving silence and rocks especially drove this home. This soundless scene was placed so perfectly in the middle of a super audio-visual movie, and really made me feel how nice it was to just soak in the silence sometimes.

A24 absolutely killed it with this one. I cannot wait to see what they have in store next. And I sincerely hope this film gets the recognition it deserves and wins awards. 10/10.

Title: Totally original movie with plenty of depth. Brave in themes and execution. But not all that exciting or emotionally affecting
Review:
This film has great depth and the themes within it were great. It looks at such things as interconnectedness, family, personal power, free will, and the epidemic of the modern age - nihilism. In a world which seems determined to deconstruct absolutely every cornerstone on which society and humanity has been built, even down to the most intimate parts of ourselves e.g. Gender, nihilism to many feels like an inescapable black hole the devil pushes them towards and that they constantly struggle to avoid being sucked into. The Bagel is a representation of that lurking black hole that Joy has almost given into. Though many films have brooding or dark characters burdened by nihilism, Everything Everywhere is brave enough to build a film around it as the central obstacle for overcoming, and to have an open discussion about it, and is brave enough even to put forward an antidote - love. We need more films brave enough to offer people stories and forums for making sense of the challenge of finding meaning in our perplexing and chaotic modern world. So I enjoyed the depth within the film very much.

It is also totally original in its style of execution and blending of genres. I've not seen a film quite like it before. It is a mix of superhero, sci-fi, action, comedy, and pulls influences from many places, often in an obvious and conspicuous way which makes it feel rather meta. It is a clear homage to such films as The Matrix, Police Story, and the MCU. It was so original in style that while watching it I was unable to form much judgment or grasp any familiar holds with which to make sense of it. I just had to watch it as if with a child's mind, to take it all in to make sense of only later on. So this part of the experience was also enjoyable and, as a film fan, the inspiration admirable.

However, at the end of the day when all is said and done, I didn't get into the story or the characters all that much. The acting didn't match the ambition of the film, the jokes largely fell flat. And it suffered from what most superhero movies do, which is having way too many gratuitous action sequences.

So overall, it has depth and enjoyable ideas and is definitely one to watch and has earned its place in film history with its originality. But it doesn't have the characters or emotional affect for me to be excited about watching it again.

Title: Everything and Everywhere
Review:
The Dans have managed a marvelous achievement with this movie, in that neither me nor anyone with me lost interest for a moment throughout its entire duration. "Everything Everywhere" is frenetic, feverish, beautiful, strange, and ambitious - and it reminds me why I love to go to the movies.

I've just seen something the likes of which are mostly wholly original. A dash of culture clash for comedy, a sprinkle of family disconnect for drama, and a whopping platter of multiverse (just barely hanging on to science fiction) are familiar from other works. Yet in this concoction, it's bliss to my dumb little brain that aches to be entertained with something new each time I visit a theater.

I loved the whole cast, but I'd like to note Stephanie Hsu, who proved she had chops in The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel but enraptured me with her role as the complicated Joy. I enjoyed the honesty with which other characters were portrayed - their failures, flaws, and even kinks help illustrate (and illuminate) them. I was taken in by their chemistry and made to laugh at their weirdness. And anytime a legend like Jamie Lee Curtis holds nothing back, I know I'm watching a special production.

The unfortunate thing is, I think many people will be put off by the colossal questions the Dans tackle. It's not like they were actually trying to solve the mysteries of the universe, but they do prod it and play with it in colorful fashion; and any time you dabble with existential confusion, it can draw away from concrete ideas that actually do have answers. I think the filmmakers achieve something beautiful with this film, because despite their exploration of "the meaning of life" (worded more accurately as "our feeling like small pieces of $#!t"), they manage to loop back to simple offerings. Such as, perhaps simple emotion, shared with a loved one, is worthy of our perseverance. Or better yet - perhaps nothing matters at all, so why not just enjoy our time here. There is brilliance in squashing high concepts into digestible thoughts, and it's done in satisfying fashion here. Credit to the performances who sell their emotions, because without them it wouldn't have worked.

Then there's the pure joy of sitting through a hallucinogenic, action-packed, billion-colored stream of scenes, each one with its own hilarious Chekhov's guns and costumes and props of absurd variety. It's excitement you can cash in at the end and chew on for awhile.

It's not a perfect movie, but who am I to point out its flaws? I thought the pacing was too delirious in the first act, but someone else might call it effective. Some jokes didn't land because of their goofiness, but a different audience could have laughed. I really have few complaints. It's rare to witness something so unique shine so bright. Sometimes I feel like I've seen every "kind" of movie, but then one like this (or Parasite, Her, Good Time, or the directors' previous standout Swiss Army Man) reminds me I'll never have seen it all.

One thing I know for sure is that I'm buying a ticket to every movie these two men make for the rest of their careers. I can't believe this early season of movies includes a gem as lovely as this one.

Title: I don't understand the hype
Review:
I watched this film when it first came out on Amazon Prime in the UK. I was looking forward to seeing it. The premise sounded great, the trailers I'd seen looked pretty good and everyone seemed to be raving about it. The whole 'possible worlds' thing is really fascinating to me, I love sci-fi and anything that makes you think and question your own reality. So it's safe to say I was primed and ready to enjoy this film.

So I watched it, and it was... OK. That's it. I found it very underwhelming to be honest. Nothing particularly thought provoking or special. Much of it seemed to me to be an extended fight scene with some farcical elements. I'm not sure if they're supposed to be funny or not, I didn't find them to be especially funny.

After the Oscars bestowed it with so much praise I decided to revisit EEAAO and see if there was something I'd missed. Maybe I just hadn't been in the right frame of mind, or I've not paid enough attention. I thought there must be something that other people were seeing in this film that I'd failed to pick-up on my first watch. However, the second time around I didn't even finish it. I got tired/bored, turned it off and went to bed.

This is certainly not a terrible film, the acting is fine, there are some good action sequences, I think it just misses something with the plot. There's is so much possibility with a film about multiple universes, more than just a world of possibilities, there are literally MANY worlds of possibilities and yet you end up watching silly sequences like someone getting beaten up with massive dildos. Which is fine, I don't have a problem mixing sci-fi and comedy, it's just not really that funny. Or sci-fi.

Maybe that's the point, maybe it's trying not to take itself too seriously, and so to avoid getting too deep into the sci-fi elements of the story it makes light of them so that it focusses more on the interpersonal drama of the characters. In fact I might have enjoyed a comedy drama about this dysfunctional family more without all the multiple realities complicating things.

Whatever it is, it doesn't quite work as a character drama and it's not really that good as a multiverse sci-fi film.

Watch it, you might enjoy it, a lot of people seem to, but if you're particularly into sci-fi you might be a bit disappointed as that side of it isn't all that well executed, and if you're expecting it to be funny, well, it's not really.

Title: An experience
Review:
I get it now. Watching this movie was truly an experience. For the most part, it was hilariously ridiculous at times that I could not help but burst into laughter but there were some poignant moments too that made me feel a little sad and I even cried at the end. It took me a while to understand that this movie is about love and relationships - with oneself, with a romantic partner, with a family member. And through the Asian American lens it showed a different and thankfully non-stereotypical perspective. I don't know how to explain it but I feel like I came out as a changed person after watching this movie. The cast was amazing too and the awards they won are absolutely well-deserved.

Title: Open your third (googly) eye...
Review: Overwhelming in scale yet intimate in scope, 'Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022)' lives up to its title and is easily the best movie about the multiverse since Peter B. Parker crash landed in Miles Morales' world in 'Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse (2018)'. Daniels' second outing swaps farting corpses for sausage fingers, focusing on a woman whose world is cracked into an infinite number of fragments when an agent from an alternate reality informs her that she's the only thing in existence capable of stopping an upcoming cataclysm. The flick is as silly as it is sincere, playing with absolute absurdity but anchoring it within grounded relationships and character flaws. It's utterly ridiculous but oddly resonant, throwing so many high concepts at you that you're forced to accept each of them as soon as they come your way. It's very much a 'go with it' type of affair, even if its mechanics are surprisingly airtight and could be explored even further than they actually are. Just when it threatens to crumble under the weight of its increasingly out-there elements, the feature shifts gears and becomes a much more philosophical experience. Its first half is concerned with the what, while its second is concerned with the why. Tackling the bracing question of what it means to exist, seemingly alone, not just in an unfathomably large universe comprised of billions of galaxies, but in an infinite expanse of universes each as incalculably vast as the last is no mean feat. A trillion possibilities spiral into a trillion more until unfulfilled potential practically becomes as irrelevant as it is inevitable. It isn't a nihilist affair, though. It has an undercurrent of hope and, despite its heavy material, it never drags you down by feeling dour or sour. It dares deal with the existential questions guaranteed to have kept you up at night at least once, and it emerges with a fairly strong grasp on what makes life worth living. On top of that, the movie is just a ton of fun. It's an absolute riot with a quick pace, plenty of laughs and a strong emotional core. It's bright, colourful and incredibly inventive. It's also super stylish, presenting itself as a myriad of genres and changing visually each time it does. The most amazing part of all is that its visual effects were completed by just nine people - including the two directors - who learnt how to do them by watching free online tutorials. If that doesn't give you faith in the film industry, I don't know what does. In the end, the flick just exudes passion. It's an experience that feels hand-crafted to its very core, the rare example of a fantasy epic not stained by the obvious influence of studio interference. It's the sort of thing that puts a big smile on your face for its majority, especially in its more straightforwardly enjoyable first half. There are some truly fantastic action sequences here that evoke the wonder of Jackie Chan's early work, so much so that I'd easily say they're some of the best of their kind in years. That's not to imply the second half isn't successful in its own right. It has a genuine philosophical depth to it and its emotional underpinnings are properly resonant. Even though the affair doesn't affect me as much as it perhaps strives to in that latter regard, it still hits fairly hard and does everything it can to keep itself as down-to-earth as it needs to be for its impossibly elusive concepts to have any real weight. The real stakes are much more important than the just end of the multiverse precisely because they're actually much smaller. It's a really smart way of grounding the feature without dampening its creativity whatsoever. Creative doesn't even begin to describe this, either. It's such a bracingly original, thoroughly interesting and invigoratingly entertaining experience that it's impossible not to recommend. It's weird, wild and wonderful. Of course, it isn't perfect... but what is?

Title: Got to be my favourite movie of the year
Review:
This film was an explosion of surrealist comedy mixed with hard-hitting commentary on a realistic issue which can occur in the lives of many families.

I loved all the characters and their journey's from beginning to end. The dialogue was really sharp and the strange non-linear storytelling was super effective.

In another universe I could have seen a film made around the same subject-matter which removes all the surrealist elements, but I'm so glad that the strange nature of this film was the route that they took. There is something truly special about films like this and I can't wait to get my own copy on blu-ray/DVD.

Title: This Must Be What Being On An Acid Trip Is Like
Review:
It was well shot, well acted, well choreographed and well edited. Almost everything about it is awesome. That having been said, it falls short on what really would have made it amazing... watchability.

It is simply far too far "whacked out" and we found ourselves waiting for the cacophony to stop... but the maelstrom continues from beginning to end. We didn't enjoy it as much as we had hoped we would. This movie is what a novel written by Picasso would look like: random visual chunks thrown against the canvas.

Sorry, but we definitely would not go to see this movie a second time. As much as there certainly was a great effort put into producing it by all who were involved, it is far, far too avant garde and did not impress us very much.

Title: It Really Was Everything! Wonderful and Sincere.
Review:
This movie has everything- kung-fu, action, science fiction, other worlds, and even some things The Matrix doesn't have! That's a joke but there are some obvious similarities. Everything Everywhere All at Once is also really funny. The film was enjoyable and relatable as it dealt with a comic but deep existential search for life, not unlike I Heart Huckabees(2004). The movie also addresses generations and the culture of Chinese-Americans in similar ways to The Farewell(2019) and Saving Face(2004). I saw this movie as jam packed with beautiful ideas, themes, and different elements of film that really made it something special. Oh, and Michelle Yeoh was inspiring with an unbelievable performance. I left the theater feeling a sense of awe.

Title: One of the craziest and best movies I've ever seen
Review:
The first step is figuring out how to turn the concept into a tale, and they excelled beyond all comprehension in the process of turning a story into a motion picture. Second, everything worked flawlessly. Everything in the movie, including the visually stimulating soundtrack, the inventive action, the faultless acting, and the character writing, was just excellent. Title: Rather impressive movie...
Review:
For some reason, then I had been putting off getting to watch "Everything Everywhere All at Once" a couple of months. And let me just say that it was a mistake on my account.

The storyline in "Everything Everywhere All at Once", as written by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, was rather impressive. It was a very original storyline, one that proved every bit entertaining and enjoyable, as it was bizarre and hilarious. There were so many things going on in "Everything Everywhere All at Once", that the movie is well worth watching more than just once.

I was initially drawn to the movie as it had Michelle Yeoh on the cast list, and she was spectacular in this movie. I dare say that her performance in this 2022 movie makes it worth the 139 minutes of watching the movie. Now, she wasn't alone in carrying the movie, because the entire cast performed quite well. It was a blast to see Jamie Lee Curtis in this movie and in such a role. The movie also had the legendary James Hong on the cast list.

Visually then "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a trip in its own. There are so many things going on that it is hard to take it all in at once. And as such, the movie can easily be seen more than a single time. And the visual effects in the movie as spot on and look good, which definitely talks in favor of the movie.

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" was a blast of a surprise and a very enjoyable movie. Keep in mind, that the storyline itself is a bit spaced out and out there, but it works so wonderfully well. This movie from writers and directors Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert is a movie that I warmly recommend you to watch.

My rating of "Everything Everywhere All at Once" lands on a well-deserved seven out of ten stars.

Title: The Emperor's new clothes
Review:
Honestly sometimes I think I am not on the same planet as other viewers: did we actually see the same movie? This movie was so confusing, repetitive and downright boring that I am stunned by reviewers that call it the best thing since sliced bread. To me it was a mish mosh of crazy events with the same characters cropping up as different beings - the whole thing happening in three parts -- I knew this because each part was written on the screen, oh thanks for that. I can see ex-acid heads and druggies loving it, finding it mind-blowing, literally, but for me, no, this movie was pretentious and pseudo artsy and basically like I already said, boring and repetitive. How it won so many academy awards is beyond me.

Title: Mindblown
Review:
There is so much to take in from the plot of this movie, i decided not to be too overwhelmed even though it concerns something almost everyone can identify with. The script is very clever, but everything else is even better. The soundtrack works beautifully, and the editing is amazing to say the least. And as for the superb cast, Michelle Yeoh turns in a flawlessly perfect performance, while James Hong is delightful and Ke Huy Quan is top notch as well. Then there is Harry Shum who is a riot and the absolutely marvelous Jamie lee Curtis is spot on in her turn as different versions of Deirdre from different universes. Expect a lot of heart, a lot of soul and a lot of zaniness from this mindblowing film that you will benefit more and more from repeated viewings. Take it from someone who knows.

Title: Wild, memorable and emotional
Review:
The most insane, visually compelling and long-winded story of generational trauma that I've seen in quite some time. And this is the same year we got an animated movie about a family tradition of passing down period pandas.

EEAAO is like an acid trip that pulls you in every possible direction, you never know what'll hit you next but you can't look away. The Daniels' take on exploring alternate realities is a refreshing and action packed one. There were so many times I couldn't tell whether to laugh or just look on in horror, but I smiled consistently throughout.

The strained dynamic between Joy and her mom slowly becomes apparent until a dramatic and tear-jerking conclusion. One scene in particular toward the end of the film really stuck with me in both how ridiculous and how sad it was, you could say it really.......rocked. I liked that between all the crazy and surreal aspects that the themes were cohesive and understandable, no "EEAAO Explained" youtube videos needed here.

I can't quite say that this became the new greatest film of all time for me. But it was truly original and fun, and an impressive step up for The Daniels' film style they established with Swiss Army Man. I'd love to watch it again soon and see how many little details I may have missed this first time around.

Title: Maybe the most perfect movie I've ever seen
Review:
At first, I was a bit apprehensive that it would live up to the hype. But then it kept giving, and giving, and giving. I bought popcorn but a quarter way through the movie I was so choked up that I barely ate any of it. It's almost every genre wrapped in one--I laughed at some parts, hid my eyes behind my hands at some parts, and held back tears at others. It was a rollercoaster. The main character is like Neo if he were to be reincarnated into an old Chinese woman. Just go see it :)

Title: A hot steaming pile of metaphysical nonsense
Review:
Have to love Michelle Yeon in this film, she was great, as usual.

The rest of it? Well, on occasion amusing, but mostly a waste of time This parallel universe smorgasbord pretends truly Deep Thoughts, but essentially boils down to a young lady having a temper tantrum, convinced her mother doesn't understand her. Oh, really? Yawn. The ultimate answer? Love your family. Uh huh.

Yeah, those "insights" have been stated many, many times before, usually in a much more elegant and impactful way than does this film. The movie has a few good moments, but falls pitifully short of its grand aspirations.

Title: BUCKLE UP AND DON'T BLINK!
Review:
THE METAPHOR is alive and well, and it's a crying shame that these fun-hating low-star-raters haven't taken the time to familiarize themselves with it! I do have to say everything made a lot more sense upon my second viewing; the content is so jam packed that is easy to forget some of the details. Although this movie is a comedy, I had wet cheeks from crying happy tears at the end. I have always admired Michelle Yeoh in every role I have seen her play, so I knew to expect good things. However, I was not prepared for the numerous outrageous, ridiculous moments that had me frequently laughing out loud! There is nothing too random or too taboo for this film, yep, there went there...and there...and there!. If there is a message I took from this, it is that life is a chaotic, yet beautiful mess, and it should not be taken too seriously because NEWS FLASH: it could always be worse (for example, wieners for fingers and piano playing toes!).

Title: Well-Executed Risky Genre
Review:
The style of EEAO reminds me a lot of Stephen Chow's over the top comedy genre. This style is normally seen in B Movie, but if it is executed well, it has a lot of potential to be an iconic legendary movie. Because the styles and the humor are sooo weirdddd...

Kudos to the team to pull this off. This is not an easy achievement, to blend absurd comedy with heartfelt deep drama.

TBH, I am not quite getting the message of this movie. It is as weird as Matrix and Life of Pi. And because as far as I understand, the storyline was structured like a collage, stitching small pieces of individual incident. It also involved a lot of symbolism and homages to popular culture. Again, this is a style you can find in Stephen Chow's movies, Chow mastered it, but rarely seen in Hollywood movies. Perhaps Kill Bill can come close to this style.

I am not gonna comment on the acting part. Yeoh, Lee-Curtis, and James Hong are solid actors.

7/10 from me. This is a movie that may reach a legendary status.

Title: Perhaps the greatest edited film of all time.
Review:
Instant cult classic. Must see. Hilarious. Exciting. Touching. Unforgettable. Mind bending. Find this film and watch it ASAP. Wow.... yes wow!

Title: Audacious to a fault
Review:
When the trailer for this film was released, I didn't quite know what to think. As a strong supporter of A24 and as someone who appreciates Michelle Yeoh's acting skills, I was hoping this would be good, but also did not know whether its totally "out there" weirdness and tons of multiverse-related subplots would end up being a film more in love with itself than with its audience. While initially somewhat skeptical, I decided to see it after hearing ecstatic reviews and word-of-mouth from audiences. I'm certainly glad I did, as the film's unique audacity and strong performances make the film memorable, although it's not without its flaws.

The film follows Evelyn, who helps run a laundromat being audited by the IRS. One day while working on her taxes, she is sucked into a multiverse with infinite possibilities of potential past lives she could have had. In the multiverse, she is confronted with family struggle spanning a variety of different "verses," and can "jump" between them. One should not go in, if at all possible, knowing significantly more about the plot than this. The film's two co-directors, together known as "Daniels," deliver a visually engaging feast given that the film has an economical budget. Blending high-octane martial arts fights with loopy, quirky visions and a heavy dose of stylization, you can tell the aesthetics of the film took so much talent to produce. It's so offbeat and strange that even if you don't love everything you see, you just have to admire some of the creativity--at least initially. The Daniels previously worked on directing music videos (including the one for "Turn Down for What,") and you can tell their attention to style continues to work wonders in their directing methods today. By blending action with "verse jumps" and stylistic motifs, the film's editing--when at its best--can be spectacular and may remind the viewer of other tightly edited, stylized films like "Baby Driver." The acting is generally strong, as Yeoh provides a clear emotional range with unique degree of expressiveness and thoughtfulness.

Viewers will initially be impressed by the level of originality on display here--at least at first, because the film doesn't feel as precise and unique in the second half compared to the first half. While some of the action scenes (such as the first one) are extremely well choreographed, they start to get a bit repetitive and exhausting after a while. They all more or less have a similar style--and sometimes that style can be unique (especially if "verse jumps" are involved in clever ways,) but at other times it can start to wear out its welcome. The pacing of the film isn't particularly disciplined, but given the infinite nature of the "multiverse," that might have been partially intentional. Nevertheless, the gradual increasing in redundancy in a few scenes combined with the lengthy, not-always-consistent runtime definitely means that the film's length could have been trimmed, and that despite the high level of creativity, sometimes it's possible to have too much of a good thing. The film's dialogue and attempts at philosophical messaging are solid, but these elements are strangely not ambitious like its visuals and attempts at crafting a variety of narratives.

While the film clearly works the strongest in its first half and may gradually feel a bit exhausting to some, it still is a thoroughly unique independent film that you certainly won't forget about after seeing. 7/10.

Title: Massively overhyped utter garbage
Review:
I love weird movies. I love sci-fi movies. I love kung-fu movies. I love action movies. I love comedies. True to its name, Everything Everywhere All at Once tries to be all these things, and more. It fails in most everything.

There are some positive things, but it is a short list. The basic idea and the message the movie tries to impart are potentially interesting (but the movie fails completely in conveying them, to such an extent that it has to literally try to spell them out at the end). Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis give their all despite the relentless nonsense they are put through. Cinematography is rather good. Fight choreographies are decent.

Everything else is just missing. There is no comprehensible plot. Michelle Yeoh's character is the only one who even tries to be anything more than a comic book caricature, and the superhuman abilities make even her totally unrelatable. Pacing is abysmal. There is nothing original nor funny in the movie. It steals ideas from a multitude of sources (like The Matrix, Marvel universe, Hong Kong kung-fu movies, animes) with an utter lack of vision on how to put any of them into good use, and adds "comedy" via elementary-school-yard-funny level completely random stuff (like butt plugs, hot dog fingers and googly eyes).

I love ice cream. I love sushi. I love pizza. I love Chinese food. I love hamburgers. There is artistry in creating delicious combinations from unexpected ingredients. But if you just blindly toss every possible ingredient you can think of into a blender, you get unsavoury, inedible mess. Tossing nonpareils on top does not help, nor does supersizing the deplorable sludge. That is what Everything Everywhere All at Once is.

Title: A beautiful chaotic mess.
Review:
Seems like everybody makes a Multiverse movies nowadays.

I'm a fan of Michelle Yeoh since Police Story 3... she lately for the past couple of years kinda have a renaissance in her acting career... she is everywhere... movies and TV.

Of all the movies she's in...I think she never play a role that carry a movie... she always part of ensembles. This is the best movie she's ever in that shows how great of an actor she is. She not just have a wide acting range... she have ALL the range.

This is the movie that her agent need to put in the top of her resume as reference when sending to movie studio for casting.

The movie itself kinda amazing... a beautiful chaotic mess, action packed, funny and emotional... I love how Multiverse were explained in the movie and the approach to Multiverse itself is very unique and new. The jump pad where they tap into Multiverse skills are hilarious.

The only one negative for me is the 3rd act... somehow the film maker couldn't find a way to neatly wrapped up the conclusion. Since it is a beautiful mess that are chaotic... the 3rd act keep going on and on and it become exhaustive. The runtime is around 2 hours... it could be tighten into 1 hour 45 minutes.

HIGHLY... highly recommended... 8/10... the actor who played the husband is the kid in Indiana Jones and The Temple of Doom and The Goonies... he done a lot of acting work since then but I always remember him from that 2 movies.

Title: A Cinematic Trip For The Mind And Soul
Review:
Upon seeing the trailer for Everything Everywhere All At Once, I sensed this film was something truly different. I have to say I wasn't disappointed in the slightest.

I won't say much about it other than it was much deeper and moving than I expected. It'll leave you dizzy and teary eyed, and I mean that in the best way possible.

Even though it's packed with action and lots of laughs (verbal and visual), this film demands your attention. So save the popcorn, Skittles and soda for the next Marvel schlock-fest, and buckle up, because you're in for one hell of a ride.

10 out of 10.

Title: The Multiverse Of Madness Is Moved By Love
Review:
I'm so overwhelmed by the dynamic of this movie. My logic and intellect is stretched to its limit and then released. There's like a mini big bang in my head. This movie is crazy, wild and out of this world. Pun intended. But somehow through all of those craziness and dizziness, I've managed a scrap of truth. That the multiverse is moved by love. If you haven't watched this movie, then get ready to have your mind blown into tiny little pieces and then get it assembled back whole again. It's a once in a lifetime experience.

Title: Utterly Bonkers
Review:
You could just leave it as the title says. I'm not doing any spoilers as I think it would spoil the fun when you watch it. First of all the acting is great. Michelle Yeoh deserves a clutch of awards for putting in a stellar performance. The supporting cast are great. The film itself is split into 3 parts. Everything , Everywhere and All at once.

Everything (Part 1) was the best of the three, the last part is only about 10 minutes long. If part 1 had ended the film, which it appeared to do , I think this would have been worthy of a 10 but part 2 kicked in and it was a bit long. You know when you start looking at the clock wondering when this is all going to get wrapped up. Don't get me wrong its still very good and the fight scenes are something to behold. Especially the one involving a butt plug (yes you need to watch this)/. So excellent film if it got a snip in part 2 it would have been a 10,

Title: If Marvel made this you would hate it.
Review:
What's the difference between this and every recent movie made by Marvel? It's perhaps a little bit more innovative, but the biggest difference is the budget. They do great work with the limited budget which they have, but other than that it's pretty bland.

It's overwhelming and the multiverse-stuff doesn't make too much sense. If you see past the illogical stuff it's perhaps more of an enjoyable ride, but you could say the same thing about Marvel. The dialogue and humor is better than your average Marvel-movie, but the similarities are too similiar. This might aswell have been the sequel to No Way Home and it would make perfect sense.

What message was the movie trying to convey? That life is beautiful? It wasn't delivered very good which made the climax quite underwhelming. Even though the movie has a far amount of problems, it is a enjoyable and funny movie. Go see it.

Title: Beyond bizarre with crass imagery
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Not impressed
Review:
I gave this a chance because of its Oscar wins. It's easy to see why current Hollywood decided it was good, since so much about it fits diversity quotas. I wasn't impressed. I did not like the look of the movie at all. The cinematography, lighting, color choices, etc aren't pleasing or interesting. Some might defend those choices as emphasizing the drabness of Evelyn's everyday existence, but it got no better when the wild multiverse stuff kicked in. Countless movies have far more impressive, more involving, more interesting, more coherent, more clearly thought out visuals. Evelyn's story is not particularly compelling (nor are the characters around her), nor are there any profound insights given. What we get is a pseudo-philosophical, rather nihilistic point of view that says life is essentially meaningless. No, the movie is.

Title: I'm not a sci-fi fan....but THIS!? Wow.
Review:
Full disclosure. I never watch science fiction and have never been a fan. I only watched this because of the hype AND I am a huge fan of Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis. Another honesty - IF I'd tried to watch it before the Golden Globes, I 'might' have turned it off half hour in. A 'what the bleep is this?' moment. I'm so gad I stuck with it (and may watch it again to see the nuances I missed first time round). Be prepared to go on a wildly frenetic, confusing, mind-boggling ride. And be prepared to also have your own inner thoughts challenged and poked. What an incredible ride. What an incredible insight opportunity in to your own life. Bravo to all the actors, the writers, director and the phenomenal editing.

Title: Completely Bonkers but Also Vibrant and Heartwarming
Review:
When Everything Everywhere All at Once begins, it doesn't just show you it's hand. The start of the film is a very sober look at Evelyn Wang's (Michelle Yeoh) complicated and largely grim existence. It could have been an indie drama at first glance, but if you're walking into this movie blind, you're in for quite the surprise. When we make our way to the movie's true genre (science fiction), we hit those universe hopping devices with Evelyn and we're going for a ride. This is both one of my favourite parts of the movie and my biggest complaint. You never know what's going to come next in this movie for better or for worse. There are some moments that perfectly accentuate the plot and the characters and then there are others that are going to leave more sensitive members of the audience either clutching their pearls or stomping out of the room. Everything is truly unpredictable from moment to moment, you can still plot the overall arc towards Evelyn's redemption but good luck determining where you're going next. These choices maintain the tension and the stakes so well but it undercuts the accessibility of the movie to everyone. This is a tradeoff that some people would gladly take but I saw this with a friend and it just didn't work for them with how scattershot Everything is (ALL HAIL THE BAGEL!).

One of my favourite choices that the creative team made with Everything was that they didn't paint Evelyn as the hero with the heart of gold who just needed an opportunity trope. Evelyn isn't despicable or even off-putting but she's all too human. She enjoys playing the martyr, she's ungrateful, she's not accepting of her daughter's choices and she's extremely critical of those around her. They have to walk a tightrope with her character being too unlikeable but I found the movie knew just when to pull back minus one or two slips. My favourite character was her husband Waymond from the original timeline. I just wanted to give him a hug and tell him he deserved better but his compassion and his inner strength hidden behind his meek exterior was inspiring (more on that later). The central players also gain perspective as the movie goes along in a way that didn't ring false or feel too sappy which is an accomplishment all by itself.

I'd call the cast of Everything recognizable but not truly elite. If you've been watching movies for the past 30 years, you know who Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis are but the names in the credits may not catch everyone's eye. It's nice to see Michelle Yeoh in a true starring role, she gets a character she can really sink her teeth into and she's great. I didn't recognize Ke Huy Quan but he was also noteworthy as largely mild mannered Waymond. I liked Stephanie Hsu as Joy, she played her character well but I do wish we had gotten to see more of a range from her instead of her being just sombre and snarky 90% of the time. Jamie Lee Curtis deserves a lot of praise just for doing so much of the ridiculous material in this movie. On top of that, she was able to do it without winking at the audience. She played her character seriously and I was ultimately impressed with her dedication.

Even with all the kooky scenes and awe inducing plot beats, Everything is definitely a movie with a message and to it's credit, it never loses sight of that. Everything doesn't say something that you haven't seen in another movie but I was surprised that I connected with it so completely. As I stated above, Evelyn's dissatisfaction with how her life turned out is understandable but her negativity is sucking the "joy" out of life for those around her. Waymond is the real hero and he breaks it down for her about fighting the hopelessness of the chaos in life with kindness and sincerity and how happiness can be a choice even when things seem bleak and depressing. The overall thesis of the movie is that even if there isn't a purpose to life and we're all doomed to live and die in a what amounts to a drop in the ocean of time, we get to choose what makes our life valuable and there is limitless beauty in that idea. This such a wonderful argument and I almost got emotional when Evelyn uses this realization to stop being so selfish and heal those who she's hurt. Even if the philosophical ground Everything covers has been tread upon before, it presents it in a humbling and heartfelt manner. Even though I had to be patient and wade through some annoyingly crazy stuff to get there, it was still worth it.

I feel weird endorsing this movie in the end. Normally, I would be the one calling it too obtuse to translate or too artsy to reach it's audience. But as much as I can't give it a perfect grade, Everything, Everywhere disarmed my preconceived biases. There are good performances, some insightful character development and a message that affected me as the end credits started to roll. Everything won't be a movie I revisit over and over again but it was a unique experience that I'm going to remember both for it's most bizarre and it's most touching moments. Based on it's quality, I'd recommend this movie wholeheartedly but I have to add the disclaimer that you have to be prepared to take what Everything throws at you. It's not going to be your average couple of hours of streaming content, it'll be both better and more memorable.

Title: Insanely Good! (I never leave a review but this film needs to be watched!)
Review:
Its as if Rick and Morty's interdimensional cable and The Matrix fell in love and birthed a heartfelt arthouse sci-fi film baby.... ....and it's AMAZING.

I hope this movie is as commercially successful as it is critically acclaimed because it deserves it. And Hollywood needs to invite more bizarre ideas and bold filmmakers like this to make more creative works on the regular.

There's no way to accurately describe it in words and do it justice.

It's something new...which is refreshing in a sea of reboots and rehashed ideas.

It dares to be different, and earnest, and silly, and vulgar, and genuine...all at the right moments and often all at the same time.

Remember that incredible dream you had one time but can't fully explain to everyone how it made you feel because it defies words?!

Well here it is on screen! You just need to go and WATCH IT!!

Title: Not as Good as I Hoped
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Shockingly incredible film
Review:
Went in expecting a great film, and even with those high expectations, I was completely blown away. I laughed hysterically, tears welled in my eyes, even the action (though not always perfect) was excellent.

Everyone should see this movie as soon as you can (safely of course).

It almost feels like this movie had a little bit of everything, it touches your life, gives you happiness, gives you sadness, gives you power, gives you hope and takes you into the arms like nobody ever did. A story should be told in a way that anyone can accept.

Been watching movies all the time but there are few such movies that can stay with you forever and I think my memory has today saved this movie.

People who are more enthusiastic about space and physics for that matter would have loved the even more i hope so as I did too.

The strings that it touched in my brain is incredible. I went on a trip to my childhood and came back to present with this movie and I hope I have learned a big lesson of life through this movie and that is to be kind and love those who love you.

Title: A fun if overstuffed ride, sausages included!
Review:
When it comes to almost universal praise, 2022 breakout hit Everything Everywhere All at Once is in a league of its own when you consider that audiences alongside critics from across the globe have bandied together to hail Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert's (aka Daniels) mind-melting experience an instant classic, a feature that once more confirms originality in the film industry is not in fact dead and dormant, in an age where arguments have been made that cinemas are now all about Marvel and comic creations, not content as loaded and downright insane as what we have here.

With a swell of support in all forms, having finally had the chance to enter the darkened cinema and partake in what Daniels has in store for viewers (an oddness that is familiar to anyone that's seen their previous films), I can see why and how Everything has become the sensation it has been and credit where credit is due with the film managing such tricky feats as making us care for subtitled rocks or people sporting sausages for fingers, while also giving industry veteran Michelle Yeoh a role that she will long be remembered for and a chance at Oscar glory while also providing a grand re-entry to the big screen for 80's child acting legend Ke Huy Quan but as the age old saying goes, there is such a thing as too much of a good thing.

Clocking in at over two hours and taking place almost exclusively in a coin operated laundry and an IRS office building, despite its many detours and snippets of other worlds and lives of our main trio, Everything is unquestionably unique and unlike anything you've ever seen before (trust me there are things here you can never un-see) but once its end game becomes apparent and you become overtly aware at its messaging and its running jokes, the films almost endlessly proceeding finale that literally spans a good 30 - 40 minutes ensures the films enthusiastic momentum and relentless energy that is so fantastic early begins to become more of a chore rather than a pleasure to sit through.

Like a good party that overstays its welcome, Daniels could've easily packaged up their narrative and the procession of slow-mo action set pieces or repetitive ruminations on the pointlessness of life that is overridden by the love and friendships we can hold close to our hearts into a much more bullet like whole, one that would've pierced the heartstrings faster and more effectively as they look to take viewers on a surprisingly emotional journey that maintains that this film is much more than adult orientated jokes, inventive violence and concepts that don't hold up to much further scrutiny.

Regardless of the fact, this wildly imaginative film (one could argue almost too imaginative with countless ideas and scenarios getting little breathing time in amongst the many varied angles the film takes) gets bogged down the further it runs in circles and messaging, there's an abundance of visual joy, sensory overload and good will towards characters that makes Daniel's film one that would be one impossible not to appreciate in one way or another.

Whether you look at the film as a straight up comedy, one with dramatic depth tackling life's big questions or one that just reveals in its immaturity, Everything is something no matter where you look and one that clearly has hit a chord with audiences crying out for a feature that goes for broke trying to be incomparable to anything else available to consume.

Final Say -

With wild imagination, inventiveness and charm, Everything Everywhere All at Once provides us with what is likely to be the most out there and playful feature film of the year and while it loses steam in a notable way past the three quarter mark, this energetically directed and brilliantly acted oddity stands out in a big way from a marketplace dominated by familiar offerings.

3 1/2 fanny packs out of 5.

For more reviews check out Jordan and Eddie (The Movie Guys)

Title: Everything Everywhere All at Once deserved all the praise it got!
Review: After months of Hype, I finally watched this on an airplane flight on Philippines Airlines from The Philippines to San Francisco. It was such a melange of images and various storylines that were either real or not (or maybe they all were) that it was a fascinating watch, that's for sure! Funny and touching and adventurous all over, it was quite an enjoyable ride. Great to see Michelle Yeoh (who I knew from Tomorrow Never Dies, Crouching Tiger-Hidden Dragon, and Crazy Rich Asians), Ke Huy Quan (previously a kid in Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom, The Goonies, and a short-lived family TV show called "Together We Stand"), Jamie Lee Curtis (no need to cite what's she's known for), James Hong (I found out he was in something I've seen him in, Flower Drum Song), and Stephanie Hsu (this one might be the first time I've her in something) all in this one! They all were excellent in their multiple roles and the three of them that won deserved the Oscars they got. As did the directors and all the other technical categories. But while I'm glad this won Best Picture, I actually wanted another movie in that category to win, Elvis, which is what I'll review next on this site.

Title: Greatest movie of all time
Review:

By the end we were all sobbing and agreed this is the best movie we've ever seen. Don't watch a trailer. Don't even read this review. Go watch it please and enjoy the laughs, cries, set design, costumes, and incredible acting. 10/10 across the board.

Title: Unnecessarily LONG and Over-Edited
Review:
The film is basically two hours of long, drawn out slow motion effects. That is NOT an exaggeration.

I sat in the theatre asking my boyfriend what the time was because it kept jumping into slow motion so unnecessarily. It literally could have been a 90 minute film, but it's basically two hours of slow motion and colours and minimal story. It's all about the slow motion.

I was more engaged when they were in the laundromat telling the normal story and lost interest as soon as the film became all exposition from Short Round and all the slow motion Kung Fu that took way too long.

Disengaging as hell.

Title: Poignant, unique, fun, interesting, heartfelt - a must-see!
Review:
'Everything Everywhere All At Once' is a simple story about a family's search for meaning. It also happens to be a mind-bending, multiple-universe, kung-fu, sci-fi epic! Evelyn (Yeoh) and her husband Waymond (Quan - Short Round from 'Temple of Doom'!) run a laundromat and have some issues with their marriage, their daughter Joy (Hsu) and Evelyn's father, Gong Gong (Hong). What starts out as a family drama doesn't take long to turn into a fight to save the multiverse when another Waymond shows up to enlist Evelyn's help.

From the directors of 'Swiss Army Man', "the Daniels" sure know how to do surreal well, but make sure there's plenty of laughs and idiosyncratic comedy. The alternate realities are explained quickly and simply - no time is wasted and the plot and action is always moving along. Yeoh, Hsu and Quan are all great, as is Jamie Lee Curtis in her role(s). Yeoh should get extra credit both for the stunts/fights at her age (it is 20 years since 'Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon'!), as well as pulling off both a martial arts expert and boring housewife at once.

While there's plenty of bonkers thing going on - Hsu's costumes are excellent, some hilarious sex jokes, great/unexpected use of "Absolutely (Story of a Girl)"- the heart of the film is the relationship between Evelyn & Joy and Evelyn & Waymond. There's some sad moments and some beautiful ones, especially the quiet desert scenes, but we're left with a great underlying message of love and kindness giving the world meaning.

Title: Wish it would have been 30 mins shorter
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once (2022)

From the creators of LSD, DMT and other tripping narcotics comes a weirdness bonanza that crosses boundaries between comedy, action and sci fi. The enjoyment of this film will come down to how much you are willing to suspend control, strap in and plunge into the madness. For the first hour or so, I was thoroughly loving the ride as I admired the multiverse execution, laughed and even pondered some philosophical elements. Then came a level of saturation as I had my fill of weirdness but the ride was still continuing; only I wasn't enjoying it anymore.

The film is about a middle-aged woman trying to make peace with her life choices and the miserable situation she ended up in. In another life, she could have been a singer, chef or even an actress and on the way to filing her taxes, she gets a chance to experience all those possibilities... at the same time. Michelle Yeoh makes this film work thanks to her diverse skillset ranging from martial arts to emotional sensitivity. Jamie Lee Curtis was another standout with the mannerisms and maniacal facial expressions.

The chaotic nature of the film blends ridiculousness, Jackie Chan action and comedy which you might find enjoyable depending on your taste. The creativity is next level but as the film progresses, many of the elements begin to look weird for the sake of weirdness. The creators layered the story with philosophical and nihilistic elements but it's hard to pay attention to them when you have a chubby girl with a pig fighting people with dildos. It is also a parody of movies like Kill Bill, Ratatouille and others but instead of paying homage, it looks like one of the Scary Movies.

Narrative-wise, they skillfully managed to present a complex topic in a digestible manner while integrating impressive action and humor. There was supposedly some emotion in it, but the lackluster pacing with 5 climaxes spawning endless new cycles diluted any semblance of heart, causing the actual ending to feel unsatisfactory. It is definitely a fun movie that people should see because of its unique premise and cool nature, I just don't understand why is everyone worshipping it.
