Title: The cast saves the movie.
Review:
The one redeeming thing about EEAAO is the acting. Michelle Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu, and Ke Huy Quan hold your attention throughout the entirety of this film. They're capable of distilling the craziness of the movie's plot into something plateable.

The story itself isn't bad, just the execution. The Daniel's style isn't for me. They're technically proficient but they make creative choices that are strange and stupid. EEAAO falls of the rails at multiple times throughout the runtime because the story is just too confusing.

I wouldn't watch this again. To me, it's very overrated and the gimmick of the multiverse gets old very fast when it's as convoluted as it is here.

Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

Title: Nothing burger with everything on it.
Review:
Matrix plus hitchhikers guide in a frenetic modern asian-cinema style.

There's an audience for this. But it's not me.

My wife liked the mother daughter aspect. My 14 year old daughter was ambivalent.

I found it derivative of so many other, better, sources. Matrix obviously. The infinite improbability of hitchhikers guide. Scott pilgrim. Etc etc etc.

The comedy was low brow and unfunny. My young boys thought the dildo fight was funny. No one else did.

The acting by "short round/data" was really amateurish. He has a sweet presence but he's only only marginally talented. It's absurd that he received accolades for this.

Honestly, we all thought he was much younger than michelle yeoh. It took everyone a minute to realize they were married. He looks 38, she looks 58.

For all its chaos it could be dull, for all its attempts at family drama it was not compelling. For all its slapstick it was not very funny. (unless you loved the ghostbusters reboot).

This felt like a film made by millennials for millennials... hyperkinetic, ambitious, but with no real grounding. No cohesiveness in vision.

Title: Feeling Befuddled After Viewing
Review:
I understand the main point of the movie. It could have been told in a way that was more pleasant to view and that took a lot less time. Instead it is scene after scene, and way too many of them... AND contains some of the most stupid, long, drawn-out and boring, nonsensical scenes. Without being cruel in any way I can honestly say it gives one the feeling the movie was filmed and edited by someone who has a very, very short attention span.

I was curious about it when I read the description but not enough to want to view it. I happened to be watching my favourite talk show host, Graham Norton, the evening that Jamie Lee Curtis was a guest. After hearing Jamie and Graham both rave about how the movie is so good, surprisingly unexpected and incredible it then grabbed my interest. Jamie actually moaning 'oh it's so good'... 'oh it's so good'... 'oh it's so incredibly good'. Jamie went on to describe the movie to be multi-verse but at the center of it she said there is love, kindness, family and unity. I didn't pick up on the feelings if they existed. Another part that I didn't see was Jamie's description of a certain scene as being one of the most moving parts of the movie. I watched the scene but anything moving just moved right over me. And there is talk of Oscars for this thing?... The only Oscar that should be handed out, and deserved, is for Jamie's near orgasmic representation she gave on Graham's show, 'oh it's so good'... 'oh it's so good'... 'oh it's so incredibly good'. That turned out to be the best bit of acting I have seen in a long time. I believed it. But it is NOT so good...it is not even a little bit good.

Title: If "Sorry to Bother You" was actually smart.
Review:
I had seen STBY in an advance screening and was immensely disappointing. Having a "twist" came at the cost of its characters and plot being half-baked. Not so here. This film is hilarious and visceral from beginning to end. Its absurdism and sci-fi elements enhance the story rather than serve as a twist. The cast is stellar throughout and clearly had a blast making the film. This is a prime example of making a script that is truly designed for a visual medium - you could not tell this story outside film, and that's a good thing. Clever and fun action paired with sincere dialogue and stunning visuals, EEAaO is a tour de force of high concept filmmaking done without sacrificing humor or entertainment for the sake of being "art."

Title: sensory overload warning
Review:
I have mild autism and was not able to enjoy this movie. It felt like scrolling 2 hours on TIKTOK in one go. The story seemed interesting but my brain just couldn't handle the style/pace in which this movie was shot. I was anxious the entire time and was not able to sit trough it.

I think that movies like this should have a warning, the same way some video games have.

I don't know what else to say. Still have about 174 character left. But I wanted to write is as I think it's important.

Anyway, there are some good moments in this movie, but overall "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is just Too Much IMO.

Title: I liked it a lot, but even if you didn't, you must admit it's remarkably creative and ambitious
Review:
There's no question that EEAAO is one of the most well-regarded movies of the year, and it's leading the charge in Oscar nominations with a total of 11. It's is to be expected, since it's very much not a blockbuster and more the type of film the Academy would tend to award. At the same time, it is a bit of a surprise given that it's a very out-there kind of movie, with an almost outrageous concept and even more outlandish execution.

That being said, it's almost a miracle that this movie works at all, given that it is very true to its title, it's a lot of things at the same time. Incidentally, that's what takes a lot of people out of the movie.

In a very summarized way, EEAAO tells the story of Evelyn, an immigrant middle-aged woman from China living in the US, where she manages a failing laundromat with her husband Waymond and daughter Joy. Her marriage to Waymond is failing, her daughter Joy feels like her mom does not truly understand her for who she is and resents her for it and the laundromat is at risk of closure due to an imminent IRS audit.

At this critical moment in her life, Evelyn finds herself day-dreaming about what her life could have been like, and incidentally, people from other dimensions pop into her life and ask her help in stopping an interdimensional threat that is on the verge of destroying the entire multiverse and dooming it all to non-existence. In combating this threat, Evelyn understands the true value to be found in her simple life and re-contextualizes her outlook on the world and on her relationships.

On paper, this seems wacky enough, but what's interesting is that the character work on Evelyn and the overall themes of the movie are pretty grounded and not wacky at all. If the multiverse aspects of the plot were removed you would have a typical premise for a drama about a struggling family of Chinese immigrants struggling to integrate socially and financially in the ruthless capitalist system of the United States. And that would be pretty Oscar-bait in itself with plenty of social commentary going on, which is fine. But EEAAO, having those dramatic components, uses the premise of looking at alternative versions of your life as a twist on that premise to heighten the themes in a pretty creative way.

Mind you, the multiverse stuff is not just a gimmick used to make the plot seem or artsy, indie, or wacky for the sake of it. While I understand it may seem that way, what it actually does, besides breaking genre tropes, is expand the themes of the character story underneath and turn it into a more existential exploration of what we value in life, no matter how small or meaningless, of the need to reject nihilism, and of how a different perspective can change our whole outlook of ourselves and others. The movie just wouldn't allow for that if that part of the movie was excluded.

That said, this is a big reach for a movie with a small budget and contained settings, so you really have to let your imagination run wild to embrace the concept as it develops and that might be a stretch for some. The editing is fast, cuts are even faster, the movie rarely slows down to fit it all in. It works amazingly well for me and is a testament to economic film making and sharp editing, but for others it came off as disorienting.

It goes without saying that the acting is pretty damn good from everyone in this small cast, they completely buy into it and run with every crazy concept, which makes them land as they should. Additionally, there are scenes that are so incredibly hilarious in concept alone that it made wish I had such ideas.

In the end, if this movie isn't for you, I understand. It is kind of absurd, very silly at several points, incredibly fast-paced and definitely unfamiliar to most audiences. But even if that is the case, before you judge it a 1/10, consider the scene with Waymond talking about how he fights, or with Evelyn reconnecting with Joy in the parking lot at the end of the movie. Because those, to an extent, embody the true point, the message of the movie, and solidify the fact that there is something being said here besides people with sausages for fingers, googly eyes and Ratatouille references (all of which are great jokes for me).

Consider also, that even if you like movies that are more grounded in essence, plot and character, we have a lot of movies like Elvis (as an example only, I know Elvis is good), or Top Gun: Maverick (again, great movie, but it's a sequel, it's more Top Gun), or The Fabelmans (it's another Steven Spielberg movie, directed in the same way, with little innovation). There are not a lot of movies like EEAAO, it shares similarities with other multiverse stories in concept alone, but it uses that concept to explore entirely different things, in a different way, with a shoestring budget and somehow doesn't fall apart.

That's impressive to me, it is to be commended, and it's how the art of making movies evolves and avoids stagnation. Just my opinion.

Title: attention deficit disorder special
Review:
Michelle Yeoh does an admirable job of displaying dozens of different emotions in the multiple personas of the same character in this movie. Unfortunately, most are shown in disjointed snippets as the film speeds through high speed transitions.

I actually had trouble staying awake while watching this film because of the sensory overload of too many images changing rapidly.

Frankly, I think that employing a multi-universe is lazy storytelling. Need a special skill escape to danger? Just tap into a version of yourself in an alternative universe and utilize in your current situation.

The hot dog finger universe was funny for a few seconds but required a massive suspension of disbelief. Who, exactly, built that piano with their non-functional hotdog fingers?

The movie slows down and becomes emotional and poignant at the end. It was a satisfying conclusion.

Title: This movie is definitely chaotic and that is the point of overthinking what could have been
Review: Watched this on a streaming service when our family just recently subscribed into one on a smart tv. I've heard how great this movie is but I should have prepared more for the chaos that was about to ensue. I would really have much preferred watching this at home as I don't think I can handle that much visually in theaters. But I think the editing and production was great enough to show the parallels of the timelines and the actions. I didn't like some of the embarrassing scenes but I think that's just me with any kind of scenes like that on other films. I did enjoy the rest of the movie even if most of the humor wasn't really my thing but I get the point of those. Just going with the flow and not thinking too much about everything or else it will be easy to get stuck questioning a lot of things. I do like the originality and the creative execution of a fairly simple story of acceptance of what ever already happened and dealing with problems in an optimistic way. It was a fun experience and it's probably not one that I would watch over and over again as it was already fulfilling the first time.

Title: May be one of my favorite movies of all time
Review:
I actually knew nothing about this film going in. I literally had no expectations except I heard it's excellent. And yet it still surpassed my expectations. This film lives up to its title, in execution and reaction.

I cackled in laughter at the absurdity of the humor, I cried, I was entranced, etc. I tend to have a short attention span and long movies are hard for me (I fell asleep during The Batman) but this kept my eyes glued to the screen from start to finish.

It feels like a movie that takes inspiration from so many others but mashed them together as an amalgamation of all their best elements while being it's own thing.

Title: Emotional rollercoaster! The worst movie ever yet the best one!
Review:
In this order -> At the beginning you get confused about all the hypes and get disappointed. You don't halt watching it because you wanna understand what the movie is about. You reach halfway with that confused state. Then you start to understand the concept -> then you start to enjoy it somehow -> then you get the point of the movie and you start to think about yourself -> then you start to think about this cruel world -> at the last part of the movie you completely understand the message of the movie and you become emotional with what you see in it. You may cry but at the end you may see and feel the better version of you running on your body. The movie ends then you join the group who hyped the movie.

"PLEASE BE KIND, ESPECIALLY WHEN WE DON'T KNOW WHAT'S GOING ON"

bye.

Title: Great visuals, poor content, bad storytelling
Review:

Also the first part of the movie was about really good, the confusion, and that fact that no one seemed to have the right answer. And then everything became about love and acceptance. I think our generation need to acknowledge that tough parenting is not necessarily bad, it's what makes you a good and strong person who's able to deal with things like mental illness and the cruelty of the world. Nothing matters?? No, everything we do matters, everything we do affect other people and affect future generations.

Title: Yep! Worth seeing.
Review:
It is understandable that some people refer to an apparent immaturity in the construction of this film with regard to the dimensions of action or fiction. In fact, it is sometimes a little disconcerting the lack of impact of some script pages or scenes that, if placed in the hands of a better salesman, could become much more memorable for the viewer.

Even so, this fact does not have the negative impact that one might expect for the film as a whole.

This is not a film that seems to take itself too seriously compared to its action and fiction competitors, because perhaps its proposal is for a more interesting story, told in a deeper way than they manage to propose.

If you are looking for a film with a big heart, with an invitation to reflection that each of us can embark on in our own way, with a generous dose of absurdity, some good mood and very good interpretations, this is a film that will be worth your while.

Title: Great first 2 acts, the 3rd act was too long.

Title: Cow dung
Review:
Absolute Cow Dung. More can not be said about this one.

The same goes for the Oscar judges or the board that decides which movie is the "best picture". The entire Oscar bandwagon must be dismantled. Both the movie makers and the Oscars are high on LSD or other such psychedelic substances. If the movie maker claims that I did not understand the movie because of my shallow I. Q, then these guys must anyway be banned or banished from making movies that are beyond the capacity of normal human intelligence(considering downcasting my I,Q is right). Our two hours were completely wasted on this tripe, and as somebody mentioned, it was a colossal waste of time, home electricity, apparatus wear and tear, and the family who was coerced by me to watch this because it was an "Oscar's Gem".

I would cordially invite Mr. Will smith to come to the podium and slap the whole oscar board for showering this misery on us.

Title: Solid 10/10
Review:
Hands down probably the best movie I've seen in 2022. And top 10 all time. Great and tremendous acting. And the story makes you think and overall purpose is fantastic. Very emotional but that's ok. Only cons is it's alittle long but definitely a must see... that's it.

Title: Just pure brilliance.
Review:
I can't say I've related to a movie more in so many different and diverse possible ways. The film captures so many facets of the human experience. It is genuine heartfelt, smart, philosophical, funny, thrilling and wild.

Title: Art, Action, and Audaciousness
Review:
Creativity, breaking so many rules and yet tying everything together in a clear and relatable story arch. Visually stunning, too. CGI that completely serves the needs of the film.

Breathless action that veers into the ridiculous.

It's an audacious work of art. The best film of 2022. The best film of the 2020s. Certainly one of if not the best films of the 21st Century.

Gonna give it ten starts.

As a comedy, action, think piece, it doesn't perhaps land quite as powerfully on a single emotion as some other films. It covers too much ground. Also, my wife hates it, mainly because it was confusing and had some gross humor.

Title: Absolutely loved the madness
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Showing off
Review:
I don't understand Why would a film maker need all this propaganda of shiny clothes, weird makeup, freaky characters, mixed up science fiction ideas to deliver a message to their audience.

I normaly root for new ways of filmmaking. Everything, everywhere, all at once is an innovative film. You will definitely not be able to anticipate what's about to happen, but it actually felt exhausting to keep up with it and after a while it wasn't worth it, because you realise it doesn't make sense, it's just for show, it's just to draw this big big attention wave with not much behind it but some simple messages.
6 out of 14 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: A little exaggerated in the alphamultiuniversal trips, and fun in its acidic humor...
Review:
Evelyn Wang is a Chinese immigrant in the United States who has the tough mission to save the world by crossing several parallel universes and exploring all the lives she didn't get to live.

Her house is very familiar to me, and I go into autopilot mode often, do I live in a parallel world too... Full of meanings, and filled with analogy, using the insane madness of the Alphaverse as a subterfuge... An appeal to her universe to that everyone stop fighting and be kind even when life doesn't make sense... Although I spent half the film confused, I really enjoyed the reflections, a little exaggerated in the alphamultiuniversal trips, and fun in its acidic humor...

Review:
Like doing drugs without the hangover. If you've ever wondered what doing psychedelics is like, watch this. These writers deserve an Oscar. They probably have twelve in another universe.

Title: Pretentious but visually impressive film.
Review: I saw her in the cinema a couple of days ago. It is a visually stunning film; I was kind enough to myself not to read about it so I could sustain the sense of surprise that is mandatory in these kinds of events. His idea is not original and we are used to the self-reference of the producers: the same directors of Avengers Endgame play with the concept of the multiverse in a more humorous tone, obviously linked to another work of theirs: Community. With a reference also to The Matrix we can then affirm that the creative sources are clear. What the film does stand out in is technical and acting. The main cast is competent and stands out with solid performances in what is undoubtedly a high-level challenge; there is material here for several Oscars. But the problem is the script: the youthful character that triggers the delirious arc of the film is severely unsympathetic and the mother's subsequent reactions are terrible. Here the delirium is dressed in morality and it is impossible to accept the sentimental conclusion of the script because it is unacceptable and dangerous. The basic idea is a young woman who wants to be accepted by her family and what follows is a journey of love and relationship recovery. To this sounding boring they added extraordinary elements that fortunately make drinkable something that would otherwise be unbearable. I was happy to see two of the most famous faces of the Martial Arts Club in their roles as security guards. It is a light but powerful film. It can be seen without much expectation.

Title: emperor's new clothes
Review:

Title: Awesome!
Review:
Part fantasy, part action adventure, part drama and part comedy. Everything Everywhere All At Once is all of those things but most of all it has heart. It's about choices made learning what matters. It's so dreamlike and surreal but at its core it's about love and acceptance and kindness. Is it overly complicated? Yes and no. It's like life itself but on a grand scale that throws everything at us visually and keeps us guessing but that's like life we have to go through a lot to learn the simplest and most important things. This could have gone so wrong but thanks to a deft script, superb directing and editing and actors who take us convincingly on an incredible journey.

Title: what's with Hollywood and bagels?
Review:
A little known piece of movie trivia. For the 1978 film Superman, when Marlon Brando was first hired to play Jor-El, father of Superman, he spooked the producers by explaining that, as a Method Actor, he was not sure if he should play the role as a giant bagel? What is it with Hollywood and metaphysics and bagels? This one of a kind film uses clever writing and excellent actors to explain Quantum Theory. Which, for those who care, is not 100% compatible with Einsteinian physics. The film is a wonderful experience, but is not truly entertainment. For example, it takes an entire half-hour just to connect with the viewer, runs too long, and is not likely to be your first choice for a re-watch. But it does take its special place in film history, and it definitely lingers. ((Designated "IMDb Top Reviewer." Please check out my list "167+ Nearly-Perfect Movies (with the occasional Anime or TV miniseries) you can/should see again and again (1932 to the present))

Title: Bonkers
Review:
I'm telling everyone this is Multiverse of Madness!

But seriously, what a simple story shinning through a bursting-through-the-seams concept. When you settle down from all the trippy visuals and shinny lights, the crux of the story carried by the two amazing central ladies is what a movie's really supposed to be.

The concept of storytelling is there to complement the story and not the other way around. And frankly, this movie needs to be seen because no way of explaining it by memory to someone who hasn't seen it wouldn't do the film justice.

Love it or hate it, just go and see it for yourself. I promise you don't want to miss this one and see it later on a phone inside your room. Let the visuals and the loud sounds wash over you inside a sparsely populated theatre because this one will stay with you for a long time.

Title: Loving this hype backlash baby
Review:
I saw this movie in March of 2022 on its opening weekend, not knowing anything about it. It was one of the most exciting movie experiences of my almost 40 years on this planet. The creativity and cleverness was just off the charts. People in my theater were howling with laughter at Racccocooie, hot dog fingers, and the butt plug fight. The acting was phenomenal, I could not believe the kid from Goonies pulled off that role the way he did. My gf and I literally walked out of the theater asking ourselves if we had just seen one of the greatest movies of all time.

However: I did not think this movie had a chance in hell at becoming an awards contender, and it is still blowing my mind that EEAAO kept up its hype for an entire year and won 7 Oscars. It's a very niche and weird kind of style.

Not surprisingly, the number of angry reviews being flooded onto here in the post hype backlash is a testament to the fact of EEAAO's highly specific sensibility. I can only say that I an glad so many others felt the same way as me in 2022 about the film, and that all these 1 star reviews, with their saltiness and utter confusion, are bringing me additional, infinite, everything bagel-sized joy.

Title: The Real Multiverse of Madness
Review:
The movie is full of absurdities. The movie was very difficult to watch, but it was also fun. Acting was very very good. I liked the movie. Parallel universes were not bad, and traveling between parallel universes was also absurd and fun. Anyway i liked.

Title: Transcending.
Review: Everything Everywhere All at Once is the multiverse movie to end all multiverse movies. Following Evelyn Wang, a Chinese immigrant who is swept up in an insane adventure, where she alone can save the world by exploring other universes connecting with the lives she could have led. This film is hilarious, overstimulating, unique, stylistic, existential, life-affirming and deeply impactful, with every filmmaking aspect operating at a consistent masterclass level. Probably one of the most spectacularly fun theater experiences I've ever had. You can feel every piece of cinema which inspired this film, just as well as you can feel all of the future filmmakers who will be inspired by it, and we're likely to see its influence on the cinematic craft for decades to come. For the massive scope of the film, Everything Everywhere never forgets the human element which drives the film, a deeply profound and infinitely relatable story about the paths we take, and the importance of the things which matter in our lives over that which could have mattered. It's transcending. You will laugh, you'll probably cry. Most of my theater was doing both. If you're ever going to take a recommendation of mine, make it this. My sympathies for anyone who doesn't get to see this in a theater.

Title: The most accurately named movie title ever
Review:
This is definitely the most difficult review I've written because when I think about this movie my mind is literally "everything , everywhere, all at once". The only comparison I have for it is like Inception meets Matrix.

There are definitely many ways to interpret the film but one major theme stood out to me. First, I think the biggest theme is that while nihilism may be easy to succumb to and even a tempting comfort , there is so much more to life if you open your eyes to everything around you and cherish the simple joys of life.

With regards to the movie itself, I wouldn't say that I was really enjoying it while watching, it is certainly overwhelming and difficult to keep up with, but all of its themes really made me reflect which certainly is valuable.

For this movie you truly need to watch it yourself because your interpretation of this movie is probably impacted by your own personal background and circumstances more than any other movie I've seen.

Title: Unique!
Review:
There's really something for just about everyone in this movie. It's part Kung-fu action, part absurdist comedy, part cerebral sci-fi, and part indie family drama.

Everything, Everywhere dazzles with its creative vision, but it marries the bizarre and magical with the mundane and the ordinary to make a statement about human potential and how often we let our daydreams - what could have been, should have been, will or won't be - roadblock who we are. The movie obliterates the veil of ordinary to reveal the extraordinary, but it never loses itself within its relentless, wacky, metaphysical vision.

Title: Garbage movie, run away ass fast as you can.
Review:
The directors' experience before making this drivel was a DN Snake video an SD c g get s movie 'Swiss Army Man'. That's all you need to know.

That this and 'Oscar' are even mentioned in the same sentence tells you how broken the nominating process is.

I don't really know who's ramming this movie down everyone's throats, but I've seen more plausible plots in old Troma movies. Here, the creators just throw everything at the screen, hoping something will stick. They figure if the plot/location/time/scene changes often enough, then people will be too busy trying to make sense of it all instead of realizing they're being duped.

Possibly the stupidest movie I've seen in 2-3 decades, and I have a pretty high tolerance for schlock.

Title: Phenomenal on every level
Review:
The prefect amount of humor, positivity, sadness, and action. Nothing on this movie feels forced, the pacing is perfect, and the acting is outstanding. Bravo.

Title: Fun and smart
Review:

One of my favourite films of the year.

Title: Creativity at its peak
Review:
Wow! What a movie.

I thought that it would be a good creative movie. Well I was wrong, it's not just good, it's great. Almost everything in this movie is fresh. So fresh that you just can't look away from the screen. The characters, the music, the action everything is very fresh.

If you want to watch something totally new just watch this movie. But if you don't like new concepts and ideas then just don't watch it. It's not for you.

It has only one problem, It's super creative and because of this everybody can't understand it. And you really don't have to understand it to enjoy watching everything happening everywhere all at once.

10/10.

Title: Go See It
Review:
EEAAO totally lived up to the hype for me. Michelle Yeoh was beyond amazing, and the Daniels showed their fluency in cinematic and visual language to the point that every scene begs to be re-watched. Talented, brilliant, incredible, amazing, show-stopping, spectacular, totally unique, never the same, completely not ever been done before, unafraid to reference or not reference...

Title: The message everywhere all at once
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

Title: Speechless
Review:
I can't say anything that will do this movie justice, but:

Other than a very slightly drawn-out ending, it simply gets everything right.

Yang Ziqiong and Jonathan Ke Quan were both absolutely brilliant, start to finish.

The combination of action, sci-to, kung-fu, everyday life drama, misery, powerful emotional plays, subtle comedy, crude comedy, and the flat out weird, probably shouldn't work but completely did.

The scenes pulled their weight, the sound track did, the splashes of arthouse (which I generally dislike) fit in perfectly and worked so well.

The natural Chinese-English hybrid conversations between husband and wife were a nice touch, too.

And the ending was exactly what it needed to be.

Title: The idea is very interesting but the execution was not
Review:
Sorry, 6 out of 10. I don't know what I've watched.

Don't get me wrong, The actors were great and I love parallel worlds/timeline stories which I dissect for others to understand. But this one? It was as if a newbie writer wrote a story with all the genres in the world and jammed it into a 2-hour movie with a lot of unnecessary sexual scenes.

The constant switching between universes were also very distracting. It is understandable, the idea is there, but they used it excessively. It is fine if done in novels but totally not in a live-action (or animation) show.

The comedy. Was it really necessary to add that genre? All the comedy scenes were funny but the tone of the story, the plot, it doesn't fit at all. The excessive use of comedy not only was a distraction but it killed the movie.

It started as science fiction, turned into sex fights, became a comedy, then a teenage drama.

It was fun at first. Then it dragged on and eventually "what is the show about again?"

Title: Jaw-dropping
Review:
I made my account just to review this movie. I saw this movie two days ago and I keep coming back to this page to see how many reviews it's received. As of now, it's at about 8,000, which makes me sad. It tells me that not enough people are seeing this incredible movie. From beginning to end, this movie was immaculate. The story was intriguing the entire time, the cinematography was awesome, the editing was out of this world, and the acting was great all the way around. This movie had me laughing hysterically one moment and brought tears to my eyes the next. Overall, this is going to be the best movie of the year, if not the decade. 10/10.

Title: Nothing matters. Except the bagel
Review:
I got excited after seeing the high rating. However this is another good concept wasted in the name of propaganda. When you combine time travel, alternate universe travel with emotions and good character arcs you can make great movies. Although I cannot even imagine what character arc would mean when time is not linear. It requires a great writer to write that script. These guys weren't.

First of all there were some really good ideas in the movie. Like crossing paths with the same guy and talking about alternate futures in the alternate universe. However the biggest 2 problems for me where the lack of any logic. You can create alternate universes but usually when you go beyond the lifetime of a person in any time travel movie, that person probably ceases to exist. So alternate branches of reality like sausage fingers and rocks should have been excluded. Also how did they achieve the same level of civilization without the ability to grab things. I though opposing thumb was one of the 3 key advantages over other apes.

Second issue is that the daughter lives all alternates realities, experiences everything, realizes that there is no difference in being a rock or human. She realizes "nothing matters". Except the "bagel" of course. She cannot give up the bagel and she will destroy the universe just to prove that she likes bagel. That part is the propaganda needed for an Oscar. And the part that made this movie absurd. At times it looked like "scary movie" or "epic movie" series. Bunch of absurd scenes stitched together.

Title: Recurrent and boring concept
Review:
Recurrent and boring concept, and despite my interest for Asian cinematography (my first mistake, this movie is just Big Hollywood with three Asian American actors and a Malaysian actress), Jackie Chan action/comedies and super-hero sagas, this is definitely neither a mind-blowing nor revolutionary film.

Or maybe it is just the easy multi-meta-verse excuse that I cannot agree with (Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse (2018) was amazing) and the ridiculous "She's not most people", bizarre "Your coffee tastes wrong, our institutions are crumbling".

Or it is the constant explanation of the whys and hows: "In my universe...", "You will learn to Jump Verse"?

So when Evelyn (played by Matrix's Neo) asks Alpha Waymond (interpreted by Po in Kung Fu Panda) to "explain it all to me, right now" and he starts StarWarsing her, I had to quit.

In a nutshell, definitely not Oscar material.

Wait, what?

Title: Absurdity at its finest
Review:
If you enjoy movies with lots of action, this movie is for you. If you enjoy movies with lots of emotion, then this movie is also for you. If you enjoy movies with well-written characters and a moving plot, then this movie is for you, too. This movie is pinnacle cinematography, from the special effects and costume design to the camerawork and acting. Every minute detail is purposeful, which can be somewhat overwhelming near the end. However, I promise that no matter what kind of viewer you identify as, there is something for you to love about this film. The cinematic experience offered is unlike anything you have ever witnessed, and if you are sensitive to philosophical and profound concepts, then you will dwell on this for many years to come.

Title: Strange but brilliant
Review:
It's amazing how many people will say that a movie is bad just because they can't understand it and I've noticed that some of the negative reviews are from people who didn't even watch the whole film, how can you rate a film when you only watch part of it??

I have to be honest and say that I think that the first part of the film was a bit to long ( I would have given it a 9 but for that ) but overall an excellent film and well worth sitting through, a good storyline with some great special effects and interesting enough to keep you watching.

Happy watching.

Title: Watch this movie. You need it.
Review:
Very impactful movie, i cant really imagine how they managed to write it and make a movie out of it.

This movie had a lot to teach with a lot of deep messages underneath the surface, it will take a little time to unpack all of it for anyone who watches it that is why it is a good movie.

The actors did a great job, and i noticed that the stunt guys from the martial club youtube channel are in this movie too, the same people who were in Shang Chi as well, they were hillarious in this one so i am happy for them : )

I am happy that i saw this movie, it elevates the standard for every movies out there.

Title: Optimistic nihilism and pure absurdity as the cure for existential dread many need right now.
Review:
I would rate this a 9.5/10 if I could, not in the habit of giving out 10s as the perfect film seems impossible to achieve without cinematic obsession the likes of which would drive the average person to early death.

Regardless, EEAaO is a fantastic film. Think Kung Fu Hustle x John Dies at the End with a backbone of Mr. Nobody if all were the best possible versions of themselves and had more heart than all three combined.

Definitely one of the most daring, beautiful, and off-the-wall insane films I've seen in a long time.

High octane action flits back and forth to heartfelt tearjerkers and the absurdly hilarious, possessing a raunchy randomness only Daniels can evoke. Give them the multiverse and the Russo Bros, you've got a cohesive epic with excellent performances from everyone.

Genuinely moved by this film. Despite the exceptional components, it transcends these to become greater than the sum of its parts. I teared up on two separate occasions, all while the crowd was roaring throughout

I will need to see this movie a few more times to get every moment, as there is very little breathing and blinking room-one of my largest and only qualms was the lack of time spent exploring alternate paths to a degree I would like overall. This, however, ignores the message of the film which I believe has to do with optimistic nihilism or the idea that the meaninglessness of the universe is a chance to make your own meaning with what you have.

It's an important message that we all need to hear every once in a while. Hug someone close and tell them you love them; for all we know we only get one path-but make sure you scream it in a language they don't understand because life is unfair and absurd (Then take them to go see Everything Everywhere All at Once, it slaps).

Title: I was mesmerized. Until...
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Great Movie
Review:
Rating: 9.1 Overall, a great movie that is very unique in how it blends many genres that is driven by its performances, writing, and action, but it does falter a bit from an inconsistent plot structure, fast pacing, and ending that is very feel good.

Very Good to Great Direction (Did a really good job in helping choreograph the different fight scenes, fast cuts in helping drive the narrative, and getting the most out of their actors in many different parts in the film; sometimes they do get lost is in their own pace as they cannot keep up with the fast pace they have created and did not do the best in helping bring the whole thing home), Good to Very Good Acting (Great from Michelle Yeoh (Really is able to command the film and show multiple dimensions in her performance as she helps the character grown from her insecurities to a confident lead in the end), Pretty Good to Good from Stephanie Hsu (Is fine in helping portray a multiple sided character that is a angsty teen with villain capabilities, but her performance can get really annoying at times as she plays too strong into the Villain and teen tropes to where her performance becomes a bit limited and annoying), Very Good from Ke Huy Quan (really steals the show sometimes as he still has that charm that Short Round had while still moving a bit past to show his ability to show multiple dimensions as an actor), Good from James Hong (Plays the typical character that he usually plays but does a good job in doing it), Good to Very Good from Jamie Lee Curtis (Shows her experience in the role and is able to be a monotonous anti-hero very well), Good from the rest of the cast), Very Good Story (Very good concept and does a good job in explaining the concept, the storytelling of the film is also very good as the audience is very captivated by what is happening and what will happen next; there are some issues with overall plot construction and how everything is distributed), Great Screenplay (Very witty and the jokes are very good, there is also a lot of symbolism present in multiple ways (even absurd ones)), Decent Score, Great Cinematography (really comes to light in the fighting scenes), Very Good Sound, Incredible Editing (Is used in a very good way in helping tell the story and show the different worlds the characters are going through in parallel), Decent Visual Effects (Is fine given the budget but can really show sometimes in how cheap it is), Good Makeup, Good Costumes (Helps in differentiating the different worlds), Plot Structure is the movie is a big issue as it is split into three parts but puts way too much into the first than the final two (especially the last one) as the final two parts feel a bit rushed (to where 10-20 minutes from the first part could be cut out and the exact same movie would be there), Pacing was incredibly fast to where many details can be lost if not paying attention (due to how content dense the movie is), Build to climax is very well done and a good epiphany for the main character as she learns her importance; climax was very underwhelming as it tries a bit too hard to be feel good to where it just feels incredibly forced and unrealistic, Tone of the movie is a bit unique as it blends multiple genres (whether it be martial arts, comedy, absurd comedy, and even drama), One of the better movies to tackle the multiverse as it is clear in how it explains it (though is still fast and dense)

Title: Emotions Everywhere All at Once
Review:
As an avid movie watcher, I will say that this movie does in fact have everything, everywhere all at once. A two-hour movie that hums along and when I got to the end, I was out of breath. This movie has it all: rich characters, a solid plot and cinematography that blew my mind. On top of all this, there's a simple, yet profound message for all of us.

I can't say enough about this movie and how, after a few hours, it still resonates. I might have to watch it again as I know it will be time well spent. An absolute fascinating film that I didn't want to end. I rarely say that about a movie.

We will see these folks (everyone from director, cinematographer, producer, actors, editors) on stage come Oscar night.

Title: What the hell did I watch?
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

Title: The real multiverse of madness that Marvel failed to make. If Nolan was asked to make a high-concept absurdist sci-fi flick, he would have made this film.
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once (2022) : Brief Review -

The real multiverse of madness that Marvel failed to make. If Nolan was asked to make a high-concept absurdist sci-fi flick, he would have made this film. Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert had an idea for a multiverse flick way back in 2010 - the same year when Christopher Nolan made "Inception". However, it took them a long time to gather things, and then we saw Marvel entering the multiverse zone with one of their most popular superheroes, Doctor Strange. It is strange that Everything Everywhere All at Once released in the same year when Doctor Strange and Wanda decided to go bonkers in the Multiverse of Madness. However, the film couldn't live up to the hype. But if you are amongst those who weren't satisfied with the Strange vs Wanda battle due to weak writing (like me), then make sure that you catch this high-concept entertainer. This absurdist sci-fi flick is expectedly weird, wild and awfully rubbish, but doesn't fail to entertain you with some crazy ideas and amazing sequences. The film tells the story of a Chinese woman who discovers that she must connect with parallel universe versions of herself to prevent a powerful being from causing the destruction of the multiverse. There is much more to it that can't be spoiled, but yes, you can be warned and made prepared for emotionally intellectual topics like existentialism and Nihilism, with some absurd and yukk-ward moments. Michelle Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu, Ke Huy Quan and James Hong have given good performances along with the brilliant supporting cast. Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert deserve a big round of applause for their out-of-the-box thinking and audience-friendly vision. Neither Nolan nor Marvel could manage to deal with this high-concept topic by arranging the comedy in a perfect manner. The 2 Ds have done it. Except for children, this one is strongly recommended to everyone who loves watching unique entertainers.

RATING - 7/10*

By - #samthebestest.

Title: Amazing amazing screenplay!!!
Review:
There are only few movies where the element of chaos form the central piece. The antagonist has no motive and only wants chaos to exist. And, the VFX and screenplay were simply superb is carrying out this theme throughout the movie.

There are long fingers, fancy dress and even a rock. The theme of chaos in the Chinese immigrant family with the conflict between nothing matters and being good is a meta philosophical treatment totally unexpected for this kind of "time travel" /"universe jumping" film.

Kudos to the makers for coming up with such a novel idea. You have to watch this for the great storyline and acting performance!!!

Title: Maybe overrated?
Review:
At the beginning I was really bored, but I can't deny that it got better and more interesting later, but still, eleven Oscar nominations for this? I'm not sure. To be honest I'm not sure if I liked the movie or not. I think it was worth to watch but didn't impress me that much.

The movie obviously had some impressive scenes and dialogues but they were really a few. And as the title of the movie says it is literally about everything all at once, but is that a good thing? I mean mentioning so many concepts at a very superficial level? Is it good? I think that is why I couldn't emotionally connect to the movie or it didn't make me think that much. Adding so many ingredients to a salad doesn't necessarily make it delicious, maybe you can show off with that but still it's not delicious! I feel the same about this movie, it was just too much and not that deep.

One other thing I didn't like about the movie is that I think it is like a collage of many other movies and animations. There are many scenes that remind us of other movies, (Rick & Morty for example) which I don't think is a good thing. But I also wonder maybe the directors did that on purpose to kind of mock the film industry? Not sure.

Also sometimes during the movie I thought it doesn't make any coherent sense, and I felt like the directors must had been on drugs. :D

But I kind of liked the way they showed parallel worlds, it was a bit overwhelming at the beginning but I think this theory itself is overwhelming so they did an okay job on this, even though I'm waiting for a better movie about multiverse! (Haven't seen and impressive one so far.) And the humor was not bad, not that impressive either. It made me laugh out loud at a few scenes.

Overall I think it was okay but not great.

Title: Been a long time since I fell inlonve with a film.
Review:
Probably the BEST I've seen in recent years.

It struck fast, it struck hard, it struck everything everywhere all at once.

If you take a moment to disconnect from popular media and judge the movie as it's own you'll love it even more. Comparing it to Matrix, Rick & Morty, Back To The Future and whatnot - it's all pointless and makes you miss the feeling of the film itself.

I can feel so much similarity with the absurdism & nihilism "The Hitch Hikers Guide To The Galaxy" offered me. On purpose or not, it matters less, but the feeling of having to deal with the absurdity of life with a straight face - Absolutely stunning and hitting. Just like the book series I mentioned.

Of course, if you don't enjoy or handle less well dark comedy & fast yet complicated plot, don't force yourself. But if you push past the discomfort and try and focus on the philosophical points of the film - I doubt you'll regret it. I've seen so many people miss the point by complaining about the humor or similarity to other things, which is an absolute shame. I don't mind people not liking certain stuff, but for the love of god, at least UNDERSTAND the film first.

Title: Wonderfully dizzying, albeit too much to handle at times
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is an Asian American indie drama cleverly disguised as a hilarious quirky Marvel-like adventure. With its inventive hyperactive script, it is a breath of fresh air amid the superhero blockbuster era and a role of a lifetime for Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan with a full showcase of their talents.

Evelyn Quan, a Chinese American immigrant who runs a laundromat with her husband Waymond Wang, is having a bad day. The laundromat is being audited by the IRS, Waymond is about to serve Evelyn divorce papers and their daughter Joy wants Evelyn to accept her Caucasian girlfriend Becky.

Written and directed by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinhert, otherwise known as The Daniels, the story, to quote Mel Brooks' Spaceballs, moves at ludicrous speed.

It's entertainingly dizzying keeping up with the zaniness. When the multiverse adventure begins, the film revels in irreverent humor and unapologetically indulges in its weirdness.

It's all too much to handle, but fun. I was admittedly lost in the second chapter. Everything made enough emotional sense to carry me through despite that I was struggling to explain how it all worked.

I am happy that Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan won Best Actress and Best Supporting Actor at the Oscars. It's exciting to see that the hype was on their side as they swept the Golden Globes and all the other acting accolades leading up to the Academy Awards. Both actors showed an incredible amount of range in their parts. Who can do drama, comedy, fight and do their stunts in one movie like this?

Years ago, Everything Everywhere All at Once would have just been an indie sleeper on the top of the Best Films of the Year You Missed list. Now, it's a zeitgeist movie and the film everybody everywhere is talking about it.

Weirdness is trending. How times have changed...

Title: Cool, unique and family drama under sci-fi
Review:
It might be the first time i cried since spirited away. I despise rating system, and i don't normally do this. Cause reviews are subject and sometimes way too personal.

But Everything Everywhere All at Once is just built different. I didn't expect to get that much experience watching a film with the tacky multi-universe sketch. But i'm genuinely surprised and overwhelmed by how good it helps the plot. This design is not just used to create a Nolan-ish crazy high-budget scene, but serves as a perfect bridge to the ending.

The ending just makes me bawl like a baby. Again, any asian child or any child can relate so much to this movie. Wonderful, wonderful job from the two Daniels.

And final thought for the haters: i do not expect everyone understands some of the idea toched by this movie. However i am amazed by people not understanding, but rejecting.

Title: Like a modern-day Matrix with a comedic spin
Review:
EEAaO is something that you most certainly have never seen before. Closest thing I can ascribe it to is something like a modern-day Matrix film. It's an incredibly unique assault to the senses, in a mostly good way.

The universe-hopping premise makes a great backdrop for some great set pieces (we all know about that hilarious trophy fight), but I found the plot about a mother's waning relationship with her daughter that was wrapped around it to be what made the film. It's easy to write this film off as just nonsense, and it can come off as that sometimes, but it does have a touching moral to it underneath its bombastic, epileptic exterior.

I think its biggest issue is that it goes on for a bit too long - there were several moments when I thought the film was wrapping up, but it just kind of kept on going. With so much going on "all at once", it can also get pretty much. By the end of the film, I was thoroughly exhausted.

Pretty good film, overall. Best picture? Probably not in my opinion, but still worth watching, if only just the one time.

Title: What a joke. Best movie of the year? What??!!
Review:
Seriously. What a joke. The Oscars have never been by far any sort of guidance for me, but I can't help feeling curious about the movies they award. This is probably the most irrational one of all time.

I can't agree with ANY of the aspects awarded by the Academy, it's a seriously flawed movie, with a very weak script and dialogs, average performances (when not lousy), mediocre cinematography and repetitive cheap humour.

The story tries to be complex but it's just messy. I understand what's going on and what it wants to say, but its choppy editing and frenetic pace is just unenjoyable and uninteresting. I literally fell asleep in the cinema, and thought of walking out at least twice but stayed to the end to really see if there was any redeeming value in it. There wasn't.

Part of the boredom and walking out feeling was the cringe dialog. It got me rolling my eyes throughout the last hour, especially at the end with all that speech and preaching about life and love and blah, blah, blah.. terrible. After watching two hours of cheap, quirky, repetitive and unfun humour and cheap choreographies don't come to me trying to be serious and dramatic (and clich√©) because it's not the time or place.

Best actress??? WHAT??!! None of the performances were worthy of big praise! It's a cheap looking action flick, what the hell?!

The costumes and set design are quite horrible. Seriously. Costume design got another award! What is it to praise about a costume made of teddy bears? Originality? NO. Hard work? NO. Is it interesting? NO. Sets are just boring. I don't remember a single one that was interesting or at least looked good. Even the "final fight" was lame. That's part of the poor, uninteresting cinematography, below average. I've seen LOTS of TV shows that look WAY better than this "Academy award winner". Again, what a joke.

It's not even a case of high expectations, it never looked amazing in the trailer for me. I was interested in the concept, and as I said, the awards made me curious, but if it hasn't won all those prices, I'd be trashing it anyway, because it's a really bad movie for me.

Finally, I have to say, as an action/fighting movie, it's also very mediocre. The choreographies are average, nothing I haven't seen in a Jackie Chan's TV movie on a Sunday afternoon. Seriously boring.

I even find disrespectful how this movie got the prize against the other WAY BETTER movies competing.

And again, WHAT A JOKE.

Awards aside, this is a bad movie.

Title: Hauntingly Beautiful
Review:
This movie absolutely consumed me from the first second. My entire being, soul and all, aches in awe of this film. This movie transcends genre and should be considered essential viewing for all audiences. A story of immense loss and heart-breaking love, the actors' performances completely draw you in and make you forget that you are outside of it. So incredibly silly at times, and yet personally relatable on so many fronts. The hype is absolutely real and should be heeded; you will not experience a film like this again for a very long time. Your heart will yearn for what you see, and yet you will see yourself in their shoes at many turns. Just absolutely bloody brilliant. Bravo!
13 out of 24 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: This is a Love Story, a Mind-Bending Love Story, Told Through Many Lives and Many Loves
Review:
This movie is about a woman who is a wife and mother. She is also a daughter to her aging father. It's about her struggles with all of these roles in differing universes.

This movie is about life and lives that could've been and maybe are. It's about love that should've been and maybe never were.

It's told beautifully and interestingly in such a way that just as in the film, time itself has no meaning or concept as you sit in your seat in the theater watching the screen.

Also, just as in life, in this movie, all is shown here but it is told is three announced chapters: Everything, Everywhere, and lastly, All At Once.

There are tremendous action sequences, laugh out loud comedic scenes, and dramatic dialogue-driven sequences that are needed to propel the story forward like a slingshot, that are needed make the heart soar just as much as other times it can make the heart break.

This will be one of 2022's greatest films in a year that has thus far been unexpectedly packed early on with some fantastic titles.

Everything Everywhere All at Once has it all. And you should be there to see it all. At least once.

Title: My favorite film of 2022 is one for the ages
Review:
I was skeptical due to the multi-verse storyline, which I've honestly had little interest in exploring historically speaking. That said, the combination of the cast and A24 intrigued me enough to put my multi-verse prejudice aside and go in with an open mind.

Though it took until the second act to really come together for me, the set up was essential for letting the elaborate story unfold. There were a few times I thought it was trying to do too much, but that idea would subside with each action sequence or poignant moment between the truly lovable characters.

In terms of comparisons; it has shades of 'Matrix' (R. I. P.) but with far more heart, humor and creativity. There was a Charlie Kaufmann-esc depth to the script that ultimately drew me into this world of infinite imagination. Unlike Kaufmann, Daniels ('Swiss Army Man') have a dramatically more optimistic view of human nature that I found both refreshing and necessary considering the world we find ourselves in post COVID.

The third act is transcendent in every sense of the word. Without giving away too much, I can say for certain that they stick the landing with such poise here that I found myself misty eyed and laughing for a solid 30 minutes. It's rare that a film -let alone a science fiction film with an unlikely combination of characters- elicits such a profound emotional response from me. From what I've been seeing and hearing I'm not alone there. A+

On a related note, I would place 'Everything Everywhere All At Once' right behind 'Moonlight' and 'Ex Machina' as my top A24 film to date. Kudos once again to the greatest independent entertainment company in existence.

Title: Awesome
Review:
This film was amazingly executed, with a film that has so much ground to cover it is very easy to run the story too long, but this film has the perfect run time for it. The acting is outstanding as well.

Overall, 8/10.

Title: Genius. Deserves all the accolades
Review:
My first review! Well because everything everywhere touched places in my heart that I didn't know exist! All those parallel dimensions where we could be anything but this present version of ourself, where we feel so trapped that unknowingly we keep pushing our loved ones away. Letting go or not, and how sometimes expressing love can heal or start the journey towards healing, is shown through breathtaking graphics and beautiful acting! Very rarely a movie makes me this happy and this joyful!

Title: a Marvel movie done by Satoshi Kon
Review:
EEAaO is a great movie for a new generation, I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to folks who aren't into high paced movies where you have to pay attention. People who aren't unsure should maybe check out the music videos those two guys directed first to give you a hint. I'm saying that only because I have seen audiences leaving the cinema halfway through the movie, which is a great sign in my opinion. But it is also a double edged sword: it cuts really deep, but sometimes less is more. There are a lot of over-indulgent parts, especially when it comes to running jokes and the 4th act. I think this could have been edited down to a good half an hour, since the catharsis overstays it's welcome.

It's still a great movie regardless, since I always prefer highly original material. Although there is a huge amount of hommages from many famous movies, one that stuck with me after the movie is the editing. There is an element of Satoshi Kon's editing style in how previous scenes are being re-contextualized in a collage of time and space. It's a concept Kon was famous for and Nolan seems to be still striving for. It's really interesting to see other diretors applying this concept. Since I watched Doctor Strange Multiverse of Madness two weeks ago, the comparisons came up necessarily while I was watching. And I was wondering why this movie feels so much better than Doctor Strange in that regard. Obviously there are characters you truly care about here who amount to more than quips.

I honestly prefer Swiss Army Man over this one, but I'm glad that DANIELS is back and hope to see more movies from them in the future. It is truly a great ride once you embrace it.

Title: What Matrix 4 should have been.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: It's hard to make a movie about the multiverse
Review:
It's a complex film that spans a variety of themes, but does each one justice with a carefully written script, wonderful performances, and a healthy dose of bizarre humor to counteract its bleak story. It's a strange movie because it's brave with its creative decisions; as well as rare, but without getting lost along the way. An entertaining and moving story that is testimony to the ambitious and ingenious vision of its filmmakers and the immeasurable talent of its protagonist. It can occasionally feel excessive, but the directors pause for emotional beats that lend weight to the chaos. The noise is part of the experience, but sheer creativity is the reward.

I had to make myself watch this to the end. I'm so glad I didn't have to pay for it. Was this worthy of an Oscar?!'Not To Me!! Was it even in the category of Shindler' list" to win so many Oscars?!' To be kind to another and accept each other?! Not sure how can anyone sit through this.

Title: ALMOST EVERYTHING I EXPECTED
Review:
This is a fun rollercoaster romp across the multiple dimensions of familial relationships. A fantastic metaphor for dealing with inter-generational despair and disappointment. The gags made me burst out laughing at times and yet the core message was much deeper. That of forgiveness and the the strength of family bonds. Not subtle but fun.

That said, I felt the movie was 10 or 15 minutes too long and could have been edited down to keep my attention.

Yeoh is fantastic as ever. A great watch just to see her! Took me a while to recognise Jamie Lee Curtis. I reckon her best performance ever!!

Title: One of my top 5 movies of all time
Review:
I went into this movie not knowing what was going on. No idea what the story was, not knowing the premise, and just watching everything unfold throughout was the best way to watch it. It was hilarious, emotional, thought provoking, and it was entirely fueled by Michelle Yeoh's undying commitment to the role. Also, Ke Huy Quan returning to the big screen in years was refreshing. Jamie Lee Curtis being able to adapt to a role, and keep is wondering what's happening with her is amazing. The movie as a whole was a refreshing, original idea, and it dives into the mindset of each character, and what they're going through. It's a phenomenal film.

Title: Well... I'm still processing.
Review:
First of all, not a bad movie as many are review as a low 3/10.

The movie has some flaws, but overall they are not enough to receive crap reviews. But also, movie is not great.

It starts really good, and get pumped really hard and that's good thing, but then it all start happening really out of sense, the rules of the multiverse start to be broken (for the purpose of the film, which is a bad thing in my opinion) and physics... breaking physics really took me out of the fights (stupid fights)((but good fighting moves).

The concept was great, the story was good, movie to watch once in a few years. Lead and supporting actor were good. VFX good.

Not bad, non great.

Title: A genius 45 minute movie trapped in the body of a 2 hour 20 flick
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

Title: Absolutely exemplary, truly brilliant, difficult to even put into words
Review:
Let's be frank: It's not possible to overstate how brilliant this film is. Filmmakers Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert have given us a movie that is, truly, everything and everywhere, scattered and all over the place, nothing and all simultaneously. There is no stone left unturned, no inclusion to outlandish, far-fetched, and absurd to lump together, no idea that isn't thrown at the wall. Kwan and Scheinert have given us a hodgepodge mishmash smorgasbord as outrageous as 1967's 'Casino Royale,' 'Beyond the valley of the dolls,' 'Attack of the killer tomatoes,' every most preposterous B-movie, every most senselessly pompous and grandiose blockbuster, and every hopelessly overcooked blend of genres all smashed together into one picture. By all reason, this should be a horribly sloppy, nonsensical, blustery low-grade fancy of the sort we'd expect to see from Jim Wynorski, Charles Band, J. R. Bookwalter, The Asylum, Uncork'd Entertainment, or gods know what else. Instead, it's one of the most singularly imaginative, ingenious, flawlessly well made, stunning, captivating, entertaining features that has possibly ever been made. 'Everything everywhere all at once' is an instant modern classic, a true masterpiece.

There's no reason whatsoever why any of this should work as well as it does. Absurdism, surrealism, profundity, major drama, martial arts, science fiction, action-comedy, parody, satire, obscenity, racism, homophobia, animal cruelty, love, abject cartoonishness, family, universality, morality, kindness and cruelty, weakness and strength, nihilism and hope, unreserved bombast, art film loftiness, warmhearted sincerity, fierce violence - all this and much, much more, in a bizarre, kaleidoscopic cacophony of 139 minutes. Such far-flung notions apply to every single last aspect of the feature, even the aspect ratio. Sound effects, sound design, cinematography, direction, editing, lighting, costume design, props, effects, hair, makeup, production design, art direction, characters, dialogue, scene writing, the story, plot development, mechanics of the multiverse, music, choreography, pacing, comedy, messaging, tone, and more are all subject to the same wild whims wholehearted earnestness and indulgence, flipping in an instant from one mood or concept to another perhaps multiple times in the same scene. This is to say nothing of the acting, with everyone in this amazing cast giving extraordinary performances of arguably greater versatility than has ever been required of anyone in one other particular title. Michelle Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu, Ke Huy Quan, James Hong, Jamie Lee Curtis, Jenny Slate, Tallie Medel, and all others involved turn in displays wholly unlke anything else they've ever done. I'm simply astounded.

To discuss anything about this film, any one single element, would require a vast quantity of words far exceeding the space one is typically allotted. To discuss the picture at large, in substantial detail, almost seems like a Herculean task. All that I can say is that the title speaks as much to the content, and every small facet represents, as it does to the unremitting, all-consuming panoply of ideas that informed the work of the filmmakers, the cast, and the crew. From top to bottom, left to right, and inside-out, 'Everything everywhere all at once' is both overwhelming and not enough, wonderfully satisfying and rewarding but never leaving us sated, farcical and sensible, haphazardly kluged and precisely calculated - too much, and not enough. In recent years there have been multiple highly acclaimed and very popular movies that have played with the idea of the multiverse, and it's at best questionable if any of them have struck a chord of originality, a spark of genius, in the way that this has. While I heard nothing but good things about EEAAO and anticipated enjoying it before I sat to watch, never in my wildest dreams could I have been prepared for what it actually is. It's so over the top that I can't imagine it will appeal to everyone, yet crafted with such extreme passion and care, and bound up with such welcome, heartfelt authenticity and humanity, that it speaks directly to everything that audiences love about the medium in the first place. This is the type of picture that, love it or hate it, everyone needs to see at least once. I'm blown away. 'Everything everywhere all at once' is absolutely incredible, and isn't to be missed.

Title: Maybe I'm missing something...??
Review:
I can imagine that some people would really like this film. I mean, it has a lot in it- action, comedy, wildly unexpected twists.

But personally, I need to really understand what's going on, and be invested, to sit through a full 2 hour 20 minute film. It took me a while to get my head around what was happening and by the time I did, I didn't really care.

The characters were alright. They definitely tried to flesh them out, but with the exception of Joy, the daughter, I didn't really care about any of them.

Overall, it just felt very average and I was checking how much was left to sit through from the 90 minute mark.

Title: This is Why I Go to Movies...
Review:
It's been a really long time that I've seen something that reminds me of why I love movies.

It's rare I find a movie that is so human that you experience the gamut of emotions in one film. All of the actors were great and the characters well written. I laughed, I cried, I sympathized, rooted for, identified with, saw myself in some parts, it hit some inner child wounds, had me deep in philosophical thought and made me contemplate human nature...all in all it was a spiritual experience.

Human connection, The Human Condition, Family Dynamics and Dysfunction, Our Connection to the Universe.... I couldn't believe what I had seen and couldn't wait to see it again I knew that when I did I would see even more in it.

When they get it right it's like having an out of body experience and this is what seeing this movie the first time did.

Michelle Yeoh deserves all the awards possible for her acting very few people could pull this role off and she did it brilliantly.

What I really appreciated most were the obvious metaphors for mental health and the need for human connection and family support done in such a transcendent yet digestible way.

Title: beyond imagination
Review:
See!? That's all I'm saying. Humanity is overrated. We're smaller than we think... I always impress by this kind of movies & series like Westworld.

I love the casting of the movie especially Ke Huy Quan but I couldn't get in touch with Stephanie's acting.

The story was beyond my imagination. Maybe the first hour of the movie was kind of boring but it was totally worth it. Only problem that I have with this kind of movies is that most of them have a happy ending. I don't know maybe eventually we have to enjoy little things in our life and say: yes we know that we are nothing in this universe and we can't do anything, but we're happy!...
