Title: Fever Dream
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is most definitely a highlight of this years catalog of cinema releases despite its flaws. Its wildly imaginative and has a radical new take on the multiverse concept. Its endlessly imaginative and really feels like a film where literally anything could happen. Its also really well crafted, especially for its budget. Its even more of an achievement given that it was made during the pandemic. Despite this I did find myself wishing there was more use of animation perhaps with the racacoonie sections.

Its by no means perfect though and has some significant flaws. It at times, like with the films of Wes Anderson, finds itself stylistically being quirky for the sake of being quirky due to a desire to have a unique and signiture auteurist style. This maximalist, post-modernist fever dream aesthetic is at times quite detrimental to the experience. One find themselve overwhelmed and confused, and the swifty pacing can makes it difficult to keep up. This sensation is also contributed by it being bursting with too many ideas and I think it should have been cut down. It definitely feels detrimentally long which is in part contributed to by in the third act every scene feeling like its the grand finale.

Overall its a brillianly funny and imaginative film which poeple will be talking about years from now. Despite its flaws I would highly recommend watching it. There really is nothing like it.

Title: Multi layer masterpiece!
Review:
Give this movie all the awards!!!

This is one of those special/rare movies that we only get once a decade. To not watch it would be making a huge mistake. There are so many layers to this movie.... the storytelling, the cinematography, the perfect editing, the incredible acting, the perfect dialog, the amazing effects, the topics that it explores, the lessons it teaches, the widsoms it shares.... and that's just the beginning of it. There is so much more in this movie. It's the kind of movie you have to watch at least a few times. Once is just not enough.

The scene with the two stones was probably my favorite one. So incredibly original.

This movie breaks all the molds and completely shattered all my expectations. I was constantly on the edge of my seat. I didn't know what to expect next and I knew that it wouldn't be more than a few seconds before something wild, crazy, totally unique and unexpected happened next.

This movie is truly "everything, everywhere, all at once."

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: An ode to Chinese migrant mothers
Review:
This movie was a fantastic telling of a Chinese migrant's story in an English speaking country. It's the story of my mother, and many others like her.

These women left all that was familiar and known for a country where they did not speak much of the language, or understand much of the culture. They left when most people are in their prime, when their potential was just about to blossom, and went to run a small business and live frugally so that their children could have a brighter future. But that future is a sea of unknown possibility, one that cannot be controlled, or even necessarily understood.

Michelle Yeoh does an incredible job (as she always does) of portraying a woman who is coming to terms with the internal conflicts of her past sacrifices, emotional trauma, cultural expectations, the love for her daughter, her relationship with her husband, and the harsh, unforgiving realities of running a small business in the US. Ke Huy Quan similarly amazes with his acting ability, becoming switching between different versions of the same man at the drop of the hat and portraying the typically misunderstood and underestimated, quietly spoken Asian man to perfection.

The story is about how our internal conflicts can both hinder and help us on our path to reconciliation and becoming the best versions of ourselves through choice and acknowledgement.

As a first generation migrant to an English speaking country from Hong Kong, I want to thank the entire movie team for their kind, nuanced, entertaining and heartfelt telling of our mothers' migrant stories. For telling this story in its messy entirety, and not just settling for a hygienic, polite version reiteration of migrants achieving the American dream, you have done us all an enormous service.

Title: Not for everyone
Review:
Know what to expect...the idea is great and wonderful but the practical filmography and scenes that were VERY out there and extravagant is not for everyone. Personally to me it was too much, and I enjoyed some parts but would not necessarily watch it again or recommend.

Title: Highly Overrated
Review:
Not the popular opinion, but this one is another disappointing multiverse outing.

Unlike Dr. Strange: Multiverse of Madness, this one received overwhelming positive reviews which was the very reason for me giving this movie my time. But it turned out to be a dud. It took me to the verge of giving up after the first hour, and thought it might get better but alas not. Performance wise cheers for Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan. Other than that, it's silly and takes you on a skippable acid trip.

Bottom line: Definitely not worth the hype. Watch it without any expectations and you just might like it.

Watch it on Amazon Prime Video.

Title: Everything Everywhere All at Once
Review:
Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh) leads a hard, somewhat complicated life with her argumentative daughter, Joy, with whom she does not gel, a disappointed and demanding father who she still seeks to impress and a crumbling marriage to Waymond, Ke Huy Quan. She is also in trouble with the IRS regarding her laundromat in the shape of IRS auditor Jamie Lee Curtis.

Suddenly a version of Waymond from the Alphaverse tells her that Jobu Tupaki is out to destroy her and the universe, so she must draw on her skills and powers from the many other Evelyns across the alphaverse to defeat her.

It would be meaningless to try to explain or indeed do justice to the many elements of this bizarre plot. Often very funny, sometimes quite sad, it for the most part travels at incredible speed, featuring endless amazing and bewildering images that feed, ultimately, what this is about - there's no place like home. In watching this highly regarded, popular and soon to be ultimate cult film, it is perhaps understandable why some will find this a pretentious mess, but for those that do like a film on the edge that you are unlikely to completely take in on your first viewing - you do need to concentrate - it's best just to sit back and let it wash all over you and enjoy. There are no films like this - I did briefly feel it might be a very distant cousin of 'Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy' but it is definitely its own beast and incredible to think it came out of America.

Title: What in the heck was somebody thinking?
Review:
This is the second movie from this year's Oscars that I have seen and thought was STUPID!

I admit, I'm not a fan of multi-verse plotlines. But, you know, a similar plotline was in the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy. And that story was great! So, I know that odd plotlines can be great.

But this plotline seemed like it was written by two high-schoolers who made up weird stuff for the characters to experience. I tried watching the movie three times, moving forward from where I had quit. And still, I just didn't care.

So, no spoilers in this review. If you like movies that are intelligent, with great dialogue and super acting - THIS IS NOT IT!

Title: Nothing matters
Review:
This movie can be a little over the top for some, especially if you don't like confusing moives. But if you like movies what you need to move your braina little bit, you're gonna love this one. It's not too much if you pay attention.

Beneath all this mess there is a valuable lesson in here: Nothing matters. Nothing what we do or have done matters because it's all going to be forgotten at some point and the world will end. So why bother? Why try to enjoy anything? The solution according to the movie is, because we can do it together. And it does have some truth in it. Even the worsts things are better if we have someone to lean on.

Title: Fun but overrated
Review:
You want a feel good film with a very original idea operating on a low budget with an impressive vision, this film's for you. Some of the scenes are truly fantastic in terms of visual scope. I do enjoy the film, and if it was on - especially towards the end - I'd stick it through to see if my opinion changes. Though I believe in a few years this film won't be remembered or degraded for some of the stupid stuff in this.

I must admit - I HATE the action, every time a plug was being shoved up a rectum for comedic effect I scoffed. When the action started I just wanted to go back to the dialogue and characters which were compelling. The comedy isn't really that funny and more like if you asked a 13 year old what they laugh at. The endings quite cliche and happy which works with the film, but after a while you understand where it's going and that makes the film go down.

The acting is fine. Michelle Yeah and Ke Huy Quan are great in their roles. However, Jamie Lee Curtis is extremely overrated and Stephanie Hsu is criminally underrated, undoubtedly she deserved to win over some bumbling, narc with a funny way about them. Hsu's character is complex and damaged and just 100x better.

Good, not great, and a solid film from the Daniels who realised their vision quite expertly, but it all comes down to taste and I don't like stuff like Rick and Morty - that show is smart, not funny. The film's the same. I understand why people would emotionally resonate with the film but I just don't.

Didn't deserve Best Picture, Martin McDonagh deserves that for underrated tragedy Banshees of Inisherin.

Title: This is cinema. - Martin Scorsese
Review:
"Every new discovery is just a reminder that we're all small and stupid."

The rumours are true! Everything Everywhere All at Once is one of the finest pieces of film of all-time. An instant-classic, a movie you know will stick with you for a long time, something you'll be constantly referencing and recommending to your friends. This is why I love cinema, this is why people go to the movies, this is why strangers meet in a dark room with a giant screen in front of them. To be able to feel connected with everyone, to make sense of this thing we call life, to just forget all our problems for an hour or two and be transported to another universe.

This did a lot for me. It really did. It payed my taxes, walked my dog, payed my university bills, took the trash outside, cleaned my windows and filled every single inch of my heart with emotion. I crackled, sobbed and was left in a beautiful state of awe. But then again what else would you expect from a Comedy/Action/Science-fiction/Drama/Sausage/Romance movie directed by the amazing, creative, evil geniuses 'The Daniels'.

An overstuffed odyssey about fighting against time and fighting against Juju Chewbacca. A 2 hour and 20 minutes long movie about the insignificance of our existence and a 2 hour and 20 minutes long movie about the significance of our existence. Something that shouts at you that ''Nothing Matters", but inevitably makes you leave the theather thinking about how everything actually matters, you just don't have to overthink it.

There aren't enough words to describe Everything Everywhere All at Once and I feel like I want to dedicate my life to writting about this movie because from the moment I started to write this review I felt like I could never do this any justice.

Michelle Yeoh. A name I won't forget. This woman gave one of the most dazzling, profoundly delightful performances I've seen on the big screen. An Hanniball Lector-Anthony Hopkins type of performance. She carried so much with her performance, from being an asian immigrant woman in the United States working her ass off to reach the American Dream to a care-loving preocupied mother that at the end of the day just wants to be in harmony with those around her.

It has everything, an astounding, loveable cast, an emotional, strong and heartfelt soundtrack, one of the best works with editing and special effects I've seen in recent memory, a brilliant and a once in a lifetime writting and directing job from Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert and a redifined meaning of the multiverse that allows the audience to break any previous concept they might had about it.

Everything Everywhere All at Once had a budget of 25 million dollars and looks more refined and expensive than any of this big-budgeted movies flying around Hollywood. Cinema is to be made with love for the craft, passion and creativity and when made like that I feel like it can move worlds. And I know this might not mean a lot, but this surely moved mine.

Today I felt like I watched something I may never experience again and I just wished everyone could watch this too. This was indeed Everything! Everywhere! All at Once!

Title: Falls apart in the final
Review:
If I'd only watched the first 2/3's of this movie I'd probably give it like an 8 or 9.

The final 1/3rd is shockingly bad, starting around we get some smarmy textual dialog spoken by some rocks(supposedly on a planet without people, but you can see a road in the distance...)

After that it just degenerates into random nonsense and over the top feel good garbage trying to cram its dull message down your throat.

I didn't even want to finish it by the end, it was so uninspired & boring.

Wish the movie had stuck the landing, but oh well.

Title: No words
Review:
This movie was so perfect that it doesn't even warrant an analysis. And that's saying a lot coming from the biggest overthinker. It just left me with no words. The only reason I didn't give it a 10 is because I'm still so confused - and it's not confusing. Figure that out.

Update: After a few days of contemplation about this film, I wanted to add my more developed thoughts. I am so glad that I gave this a few days to settle.

EEAAO is not a literal sci-fi, for those who may not understand. It is a metaphor for the meaning of existence, and it concludes that no one knows that meaning. Very simple. All the silliness and randomness is to open your mind to possibilities (much like hallucinogenic drugs).

So, whatever meaning that you extracted from watching this, that is unique to you. That is the hallmark of good art. Watching this movie will shift your perspective if you are open to it. In other words, if you have an open mind at all to begin with.

I have always considered myself to be very open minded, but came out realizing how I've become more closed over time. We tell ourselves that we understand the world, our purpose, our place. We become more comfortable and complacent over time. If you feel this way, be prepared to be rattled out of your shrinking box and wake up a little more.

Title: Very interesting, creative movie.....
Review:
I didn't know what to expect and was totally impressed with this thought provoking, visually amazing movie. Michelle Yeoh is a wonderful actress and was fantastic, as was Ke Huy Quan and Stephanie Hsu. Yes the movie deserves some awards. However, when you compare it to some of the other shows that are up for awards (The Fabelmans, Tar, All Quiet on the Western Front in particular) there is no comparison...in my opinion. All of the high tech, sci-fi, overly sensationalized movies are becoming old. Whatever happened to the feel-good, beautiful movies? Yes, this movie had a message and did hit on our society today and I did appreciate that. But I would rather not feel so exhausted after watching a movie. Sorry....just my opinion.

Title: Much ado about little
Review:
Using the term "overrated" is to hop on the opposite bandwagon. One which says this is "the worst film ever". Not true. However, there is a strange amount of hype and bias behind a film that does very little, other than showcase some talented actors.

To put this in perspective, EEAAO recently surpassed Lord of the Rings: Return of the King for the most awarded movie ever. This is absurd on a level that is hard to put into words. Regardless of it you are a fan of LOTR, what it accomplished on screen may never be surpassed. It took a beloved book and created a movie that is equally if not more beloved and a legion of followers that spans generations. It was a film that is beautiful in every way. EEAAO is not that by any measure.

Is it unique? Yes, but to a fault. It attempts to convey a message through absurdity. The filmography is praised, but it is nothing that hasn't been seen. It borrows from the "multiverse" crazy we see in every superhero movie over the past several years. This is not the Matrix, which shaped a genre.

Award based on merit. Don't award a film based on the domino effect of opinion and expectations. 6 is generous. 8/10 is bloated by a sea of "10/10's".

This isn't a bad movie, and for some they may love it. But, it is not an 8/10 and it is not an best picture caliber movie. Don't believe me? Scroll the IMDB top 250 and be reminded of the amazing films on the list that barely achieved 8/10 let alone an Oscar.

Title: SHORT ROUND!!!
Review:
I'm only thirty minutes in, and just watched Ke Huy Quan beat down six security guards with a fanny pack full of rocks. This fight scene is better choreographed and presented than ANYTHING in the new Matrix film, while maintaining a comical edge that keeps the brutal concept fun. Quan sells it hard too. I had no idea he could move like that. I decided to give it a watch because Michelle Yeoh is awesome, but I didn't know I'd be getting a long overdue dose of Short Round. . . Lo Pan too. I don't care where this movie goes from here, the first thirty minutes have me convinced this is a 10/10. Perfect blend of cast and genius filmmaking. Highly enjoyable.

Title: It somehow lives up to it's title
Review:
What can I even say about this movie. It does everything, goes everywhere, and it still feels grounded in it's deeply human story, exploring the strained relationship between a mother, her husband, and her daughter. Every character in it feels developed, and both the lead performances and the supporting performances are nothing less than superb.

Evelyn is an aging Chinese immigrant who has to deal with owning a dry cleaner that is being audited by the IRS, maintaining her relationship with her daughter and her husband, and taking care of her father. Her problems immediately escalate when another version of her husband from an alternate universe takes control of her husbands body and explains to her that she is the chosen version of herself to stop a great multiversal evil. She is then sent down a path where she sees the lives of alternate versions of her life and the roads not taken, and begins to understand the meaning of her own life and her choices.

This movie is absolutely beautiful. Extremely funny, fast paced, action packed, and emotionally bittersweet. This is a movie I could watch anytime, anywhere, over and over again.

Just awesome. 99/100.

Title: Absurdism well played out
Review:
Might as well have been Nothing Nowhere Sporadically. If you can tune yourself to absurdism, this movie is a great watch. Michelle Yeoh Choo Kheng plays that role exceptionally well in that role in a way that is absurd, funny, and down to earth at the same time. The bagel, however, was way too absurd for me. The role of Joy Wang could have been better portrayed, while Ke Huy Quan gives a very decent supporting performance. The combination of multiple roles and capabilities of the main character, and the swift switch between those roles, sometimes with absurd overlaps, makes this a worthwhile watch even if absurdism doesn't interest you.

Title: Trippy, confusing, mental, ridiculous but you have to see this film!
Review:
I never got to see this when it first came out and we know the buzz around this film after the Oscars. We have one hell of a film on our hands! This has to be one of the most imaginative movies thats been made in a very long time. Directors and writers creating something without any studio interference.

When you have the blockbuster of the second doctor strange come out at the beginning of 2022 and this at the end of 2022, the contrast is the same as the distance in time. One is awesome and one was disappointing. This was certainly the first.

This is able to introduce all the elements that Doc Strange 2 wasn't able to deliver on. We had a small glimpse of what Rami can do with was the directors flexing their creative muscles to create something ridiculous! So much of the movie i was stilling in awe of what was going on, there was nothing that i knew what was going on. It sent a twist into the multiverse that was just perfectly twisted.

The whole cast was prefect, there are people calling that Jamie Lee Curtis shouldnt have won the award but its the same as Anthony Hopkins in Silence of the Lambs, small screen time massive impact on the story and that is safe to say here as well. The only thing better than that is Ke Huy Quan being awarded his oscar by Harrison Ford, an awesome and wholesome moment for all movie fans!

Theres wholes to this film for sure but i cannot deny i enjoyed every moment of it, just waiting for each change to truly understand this mental world that was created.

Title: So much more than I expected
Review:
I went into this not expecting much. But this movie is so much more than I ever expected it to be and will go down on the list as one of very few movies that got me crying.

Amazingly entertaining with no fear of not taking itself too seriously and embracing the ridiculousness of life while dealing with ultimately very difficult topics.

As someone that struggled with a severe depressive episode Joys story felt terrifyingly familiar.

The movie is not for everyone as the absurd fantasy sci fi setting wont work for a lot of people and thats fine. Its amazingly unique in keeping its lightness, silliness while still giving the time and attention to very relevant and difficult topics.

I keep trying to find a way to review this without spoilers but all I cant really say is its a fun, action packed exploration of choosing life, choosing people, choosing your focus, choosing your fights, choosing your path, seeking meaning and understanding, and mindfullness at a time when you are constantly bombarded either by your own thoughts or people and media around you, clawing at your brain to give them attention.

Imo one of the best movies of its genre in a long time.

Title: This is a fun watch...
Review:
All the choreographed fight scenes reminded me of another great film, "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon." And just like "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon", this film didn't forget that at its' core, it's a love story.

It's extremely confusing at times but it's great fun to watch.

Title: My Dad just couldn't remember the title.
Review:
I suppose they thought they were being impressive with their anything-goes, aesthetic.

It's all kind of fun. The humor is fresh, the story is actually engaging enough for you to meet them halfway with their internal mechanics and they do not waste the potential to give us a sense of perspective on how no matter how trapping our lives seem, we live in a cosmos where anything might be a possibly.

The first three minutes mislead me and for a while I thought that we were watching someone's fantasy or some kind of Family Guy style cut-away that was non-canonical. I was a little disappointed that the whole thing wasn't in Mandarin.

The plot element with the taxes was anxiety educing, man.

Deliberately goofy and kitsch and not above a joke about situationally necessary sodomy, this was an epic and poignant experience.

Title: Watch it before you die kinda movie
Review:
Watching it for the second time, in theatres this time and it got slightly boring but still, it is one of the best ever made films with so many things to connect our lives with.

*here's my initial review: (and I still have the same opinion)*

This is the real multiverse of madness, an amazing roller coaster ride.

It is a full commercial, sci-fi, family/emotional drama, crime, thriller, fantasy, humor, love, life, ALL GENRES IN ONE üëå

The film is almost like a combination of these films:

Lucy in relation to the presentation of the evolution of human civilization,

Transcendence for the evolution of the mind,

Inception for jumping between universes like in dreams,

Avatar for connecting with other souls,

Matrix for gaining skills like martial arts, singing, etc, more as you practice it,

12B for the combinations of lives you could've lived,

Interstellar for daughter's love & also a black hole.

After watching this film, it feels like having had a satisfying full meal.

This film is easily one of the best films ever made in the entire film history.

Title: Much muchness
Review:
Well, that was a lot. I guess I shouldn't be surprised considering the title. That being said, it seems odd to critique a film for having too much going on when that's kind of the point, but I'm gonna do it anyway. There's a lot of fun, entertaining, and even emotionally resonant stuff going on, but there's also too much going on to allow the kind of focus on any one thing to have the kind of impact this could have had. Is it about mothers and daughters? Finding connection in the world? Finding meaning through other people? It's all of these things, but emotional resonance happens when attaching these ideas to characters and their stories in a specific way to actually let the ideas flow through them while giving us the emotional connection to the characters going through it, adding intellectual depth to something that pulls at the heart strings. Having roughly five different variations on the same idea compete for attention undermines them all.

Okay, enough complaining for now, because while I do think the film needed a good bit of cutting down, there's so much to enjoy.

Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh) is the co-owner of a little laundry in Los Angeles with her husband Waymond (Ke Huy Quan). They have one daughter, Joy (Stephanie Hsu), who has a girlfriend Becky (Tallie Medel), a situation that they are trying to hide from Evelyn's father, Gong Gong (James Hong), visiting from Hong Kong. Evelyn's life is a mess. The laundry is failing and in massive tax problems. She has this propensity of picking up new hobbies and then filing the expenses as tax deductions. The strain of the whole situation has led Waymond to gathering the paperwork for a divorce that she's too busy to even notice. There are regrets that she has made the wrong choices in life to lead her to that moment.

They have an appointment with Deirdre (Jamie Lee Curtis), a tax auditor at the IRS building, but as they go up the elevator, Waymond suddenly removes his glasses, starts speaking differently and with more confidence, while scribbling out random instructions for her to follow (including putting her shoes on the wrong feet). Sitting there with the auditor figuring out the sad, pathetic story of their lives through their receipts, Evelyn figures that there's nothing to lose, so she tries it, and she's suddenly in something much, much larger than a tax audit of her laundry. Alpha Waymond, the form of her husband from an alternate universe, has reached out to her because she is the one version of Evelyn that will become powerful enough to defeat Jobu Tupaki, an incredibly powerful being that has been moving from universe to universe killing Evelyn's all along the way.

The painting of the portrait of Evelyn's life is wonderfully (and perhaps overly) detailed, providing us with a very clear picture of the miserable little life she leads. It becomes ironically funny when we find out that she is literally the most pathetic form of herself across the entire multiverse, failing at literally everything, which, in handwaving logic, means that she has the capacity to become the greatest version of Evelyn to face off against Jobu. Her discovery of the multiverse is both fun and frustrating. Fun because the rules established are so consciously absurd (doing something completely random and out of character slingshots your consciousness in the right direction of another version of yourself that you then tap into in order to gain some kind of skill that you don't already have like, say, the mastery of kung fu), but frustrating because there is a lot to explain. It's not just the rules, but also the central conflict which gets treated opaquely for a while until the movie just gives up and lets you know a couple of moments later.

Jobu Tupaki is another version of Joy from the Alpha universe where Evelyn was one of the great scientists and discovered how to communicate with other universes. She pushed Joy to the breaking point where she became able to jump between universes without the aid of technology like everyone else, and there's been a race to find the right Evelyn ever since. What Joy actually wants with Evelyn is never as clear as it should be, I think. What she wants overall, though, is just the logical application of nihilism: she wants to commit suicide. This gets manifested in another of the movie's intentional oddities, a cosmic everything bagel that will consume Jobu and erase her existence.

The second half of the film is Evelyn slowly growing in power and also becoming more like Jobu herself. There are a lot of fights as Alpha Waymond works with Evelyn to try and keep her safe. She ends up at war with herself, mostly manifested with her desire to lose herself in a reality where she is a big movie star, but it also happens to be a reality where she never left Hong Kong with Waymond. So much time is spent on this that one would imagine that this is the central conceit of the film, but the antagonist is a version of Joy. So, this is about her connecting with her family, right? I could buy that, but then there's Deirdre. A surprising amount of time in the lead up to the finale is about connecting with Deirdre, mostly in a universe where people have hot dog fingers (an idea alternatively funny and really gross) and connecting with her. So, it's about relationships being what's really worthwhile? That makes sense, but this is where we're getting really diffuse. Oh, and then there's the Ratatouille parody called Raccacoonie where Evelyn works in a hibachi grill with a great chef who's hiding a Raccoon under his toque. I mean, it's funny, but it just goes to show how overstuffed this film is.

Why does that matter if it's funny? That it's funny is what saves it from being a drag at all, and it's obvious that most audiences feel like that's enough. I just get frustrated when there's obviously a point and the film can't get to it. In fact, it throws everything out of focus when there is a point and the film intentionally obfuscates it. Does that make it a bad film? Not at all. The movie is so filled with attempts to entertain and an eagerness to as well, that I can only hold this narrative frustration against the film so much. Still, it's there.

So, I've complained enough. I really do like this film. It may be overlong and overstuffed, but it's fun from beginning to end. Its colorful, light, and energetic approach to its concept overcomes a lot, especially when combined with the quality action choreography. Both Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan's talents are on full display as they fight their way all around the large IRS building set. Quan's early fight with nothing but his fanny pack is a real highlight. It should also be noted that virtually the entirety of the film (I'd estimate about 90%) takes place on two sets (the laundry and the IRS building), while never feeling constrained. Finding new places to film within the sets while messing with lighting help really give the small-budgeted film a much larger sense of scale than expected.

Yeoh carries the entire film on her back, and she is the film's foundation. She gives Evelyn in every reality a sense of life from her lived-in exhaustion early through to her bewilderment at discovering the larger universe around her to even her take as herself at a film screening, she's imbues the whole film with emotional truth. Quan reveals himself to be far more than Short Round or Data several decades later, easily alternating between versions of Waymond, one weak and wounded the other eager, smart, and proactive. Hsu as Joy is solid, and it's always a joy to see James Hong, especially while decked out in a mech-suit made from office equipment.

It's really not hard to see why Daniel Kwan's and Daniel Scheinert's creation captured the imaginations of so many people. It is Joseph Campbell's basic hero journey given a crazy, unique skin. At its core, it tells the kind of hero myth we've been telling each other for millennia told well, with energy, and uniquely. That it's overlong and overstuffed doesn't seem to bother most people. It just bothers me a little bit is all.

Title: More of a nightmare than a piece of art...!!
Review:
Worst movie I've ever watched, Oscar is lost in its own mess... I personally was always that kind of a person who believed that certain type of mindset, old generation, so called "boomer" traditions (I don't like that label though) and stuff, are not necessarily right but there is for sure a boundary there which human being is missing it for good as time passes on!

Art is now being mocked and ridiculed by new rising mindsets.

If screenwriters used to try hard to stack certain incidents in a story in a way to not only give audiences a great point and message; but also bring us the beauty and art of storytelling without tiring everyone and mocking their sanity; then nowadays, a new hidden Agenda is rising by ourselves to take meanings out of everything and say: well, a 4-year-old child's idea for a story with a little bit of adulthood kinky tastes, can be a masterpiece as well, cause why not(!!!) .... This is sad! This is literally too much... not even a comedy but just a Mockery!!

If we change all we'd experienced and all that we now call old, prejudicial, misogynistic, racist etc, etc, just in sake of Changing it for satisfaction of replacing it, then mankind's progression throughout history would be gone and pointless!!

If like we start to call two parallel lines on a piece of paper as "Art" then we have insulted and cheated on every single master artists throughout history who have spent all their lives to create beauty of "Art" by researching, studying and experimenting every single aspects of our world to get to that final point of mastery.

"Everything, Everywhere, All at once" is more of a nightmare in this way than a piece of art which had brought the most insane childish and lame ideas that one could ever imagine on screen and more shockingly, won most Oscar awards!!!

I can literally say if one can make This and harvest all prizes, then if they give me enough money, I can write and direct a dreadful childish idea worst than anything you all could ever think about and to add a bit of reason just in case, give it some sort of ending message of "leave your children alone, stop controlling them, accept their differences" and as it seems, possibly for next Oscar, they'd give me all the rest prizes that Oscar 2023 gave to other projects (maybe unwillingly, seems like in their hearts they wanted to give them to "Everything, Everywhere, All at once", even animated feature(!!!), yeah, cause, why not? I guess the scenario is: Let's change how we perceive animations(!!!)...) and literally harvesting all with no single one remaining...

There were potentially better nominees in every single part that this movie won it... It's just terrifying to think about the future of the the Art of Cinema even for me who was always avoiding being fanatic...

Anyway, just don't waste your time on this, there are seriously real masterpieces out there which are getting ignored cause mankind is missing the point somewhere...

Title: Genius
Review:
This movie is genius. The way, it's chaotic fast pace story line (rather a mosaic of nonsenses) forces you to listen and watch and through that touches your soul several way. A way to help you realize, the life is wonderful and you just have to exist and enjoy the world around you, find its beauty. Existensism vs nihilism, choices vs acceptance, fight vs kindness, regrets vs hope. The whole movie is both a chaotic bucket of metaphor and a single beautiful metaphor of life.

If you haven't watched it, do it as a roller caster: don't try to control, steer, analyze, predict or explain, just sink in and enjoy this piece of pure art.

Title: Yeoh Delivers on All Cylinders in a Confusing Cosmic Journey
Review:
It's glorious to see the redoubtable Michelle Yeoh play so many facets of her considerable talents in one singular film in 2022, but directors Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert (known collectively as 'Daniels ') pile on the intense multiverses on Yeoh's put-upon character to such an excessive degree that the end result was more exhausting than fulfilling. Yeoh plays laundromat owner Evelyn Wang who is struggling with an IRS audit and a disaffected lesbian daughter. Ke Huy Quan and a heavily glammed down Jamie Lee Curtis lend spirited support, though Stephanie Hsu was the standout as Evelyn's frustrated daughter. It's worthwhile just to see Yeoh play such a fully dimensional star role with such panache.

Title: Fresh take on the timeless "alternate universe" theme
Review:
This movie is a journey that takes us through the life of Evelyn, an overburdened, stressed-out middle aged mother, wife, and business owner that simply can't catch a break. Soon after the start of the movie, we are transported into various alternative universes in which she resides, all of which are created by the decisions previously made in her life. Essentially, the setting in this movie is similar to a choose-your-own-adventure book.

Evelyn is called upon by people in other parallel universes to defeat the villian, who is eventually identified as her own daughter. As Evelyn moves through various universes, she sees how her life might have turned out had different choices been made throughout the years and millennia. The movie is filled with irreverent humor that had some moviegoers belting out hearty guffaws! There are elements of the over-the-top type of martial arts scenes you might find in spoofs of kung fu movies. But at this movie's core, we find that it is a story about how you can choose to love the life you have and embrace it completely. As Evelyn is shown all of her different realities in the parallel universes, she still comes back to love the one she is currently living in with all of its problems and flaws.

The movie drags on just a bit long. Jamie Lee Curtis's role in this movie adds to the quirkiness. The visuals are presented as a sort of dream sequence at times and they provide constant stimulation.

It's definitely worth a watch and is truly a unique movie that incorporates a lot of common thematic elements.

Title: How Did This Happen?
Review:
I went in to this thinking I would absolutely love it, and that it would save me from a bad film-going streak I seemed to be on. No such luck.

Who thought this gibbering, nonsensical pile of rubbish was a good idea? Its greatest sin, though, apart from its self-satisfied incoherence and gleeful, endlessly stupid cartoon violence, is that it takes its hyperactive, sugar-rushed, calorie-free content and sticks a sickly sweet, syrupy blob at its heart, pretending it has substance and that it's one of your five a day.

This was the equivalent of a migraine: The first half gave me a headache, the second made me want to vomit. I never walk out of a cinema, but during this film's seemingly interminable length I came so, so close so, so many times.

Title: Astonishing!! This is not just a movie, it is a cinematic experience!
Review:
Oh, wow, where do I even begin with this movie? When have I ever seen a movie where every single scene surprised me, and almost every scene had some sort of shock factor. 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' is not just a movie; it is a cinematic experience!

Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh) owns a Laundromat. She lives with her husband, Waymond (Ke Huy Qua) (who wants to divorce her), her Father, Gong Gong (James Hong) (who is very sick), and her daughter, Joy (Stephanie Hsu) (who is in a lesbian relationship). On her way to tax inspector Deirdre (Jamie Lee Curtis - like you've never seen her before!), Evelyn's life is about to change. In the blink of an eye, her normal existence spins out of control and she finds herself in an alternate universe, being called upon to save the multiverse.

If you thought 'The Matrix' was complex and confusing, just wait until you see 'Everything Everywhere All at Once'. The difference with 'Everything...' lies in its presentation. This film is so incredibly unpredictable and every scene is absolutely magnificent! The stunt choreography is jaw-dropping. The visuals are mind-blowing. The costumes are amazing. The editing is inane!!! Editing this film to obtain the desired effect must have been an absolute nightmare. But it looks STUNNING on screen.

As Evelyn jumps through the multiverse - referred to as Verse Jump - she encounters characters out to eliminate her, and in the process she must protect those she loves. The fact she can't trust anyone - not even her own family - makes her task a daunting one, to say the least. The film's antagonist is Jobu Tupaki (who is Joy in another universe), who could destroy the entire multiverse with a black hole she created.

There honestly was not a single dull moment here. This film surprised me every step of the way. Never before have I seen a film with so much going on - non-stop - and entertained me every single second. There's some really funny humour here, and then also a dose of slapstick. But the presentation was so astonishing that the slapstick didn't bother me as it generally would. The funniest thing by far, was the fight scene with huge dildos, and the butt plugs!!!! Absolutely hilarious!! The 'talking rocks' scene was just as funny, but also thought-provoking.

I'll admit, I didn't understand everything here, but hell, from an entertainment perspective, I was so entertained that it didn't matter. I will no doubt be watching this again several times, and I'm sure it will make more sense with every repeat viewing. I was completely and utterly enthralled by 'Everything Everywhere All at Once'; I was glued to the screen for its entire running time.

Title: Strange but Amazing
Review:
Seriously one of the strangest movies that I've ever watched and yet it had me in tears by the end of the second act where the meaning of the entire movie is revealed. This movie is like if you took the Matrix, Secret Life of Walter Mitty, and Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon and mixed them all together to create a quirky thought-provoking film that has you cheering for Michelle Yeoh (CTHD) and Ke Huy Quan (of Goonies fame) if each of the multiverses in which they exist. Is it for everyone...probably not. Could have easily seen Awkwafina in Stephanie Hay's role but the latter did a great job as the daughter. But, I won't be surprised to see Yeoh, Quan and Jamie Lee Curtis (in a role so far removed that she is largely unrecognizable) receive Oscar nominations come awards time. Suspend your disbelief before watching and then sit back and enjoy the ride.

Title: A good movie but not as said
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Fantastic!
Review:
Wow this is a great movie. The cast is perfect and great acting performances by all. Jamie Lee Curtis delivers probably her best of her career. The story is original and can be complex at times. You really need to pay attention throughout to keep up with the evolving storyline. I can see some viewers not getting it and losing interest. Although, there is so much action throughout that this alone should keep viewers from straying. Cinematography is amazing and the stunt choreography is outstanding. You can tell there was a lot of thought and effort out into each scene. There are also funny, sarcastic moments all through the movie that flow well. I highly recommend this film and it gets a solid 8 for me.
7 out of 20 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Enough material for 90 minutes
Review:
I loved the casting, acting, and plot. CGI doesn't do a lot for me but I didn't mind as it was necessary to advance the story (for once). But 139 minutes? It was already repetitive after an hour or so. One could argue that "everything and everywhere" takes time, or that it should take time--even at the expense of clarity and originality--but either way it shouldn't feel like an eternity. All the martial arts and gags were funny somehow even though fairly unoriginal. Nevertheless, I couldn't help but feel the directors lost control of the pacing and rate of revelation--which was glacial. It also felt like the editors were paid by the screen-minute rather than for doing their job, which is to yell at directors and be brutal for the good of the finished product.

It deserves a 6 for the good stuff, not a 1 for the idiots who kept saying they didn't understand what was going on. It wasn't rocket science, just way too long.
3 out of 4 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Nothing Nowhere none at any time
Review:
I've watched my share of boring, uninteresting movies. However, it is unusual to come across a movie that is as painful to watch as this one. This movie is literally painful to watch as it gave me a pounding headache only after 30 minutes or so. I had to take two Tylenol Extra Strength tablets after watching (seriously).

I am a first-generation Asian American who raised a teenage girl, so I should be able to comprehend the protagonist's mind better than most. Yet, I could not sympathize with any single moment of the movie. I repeat NOT A SINGLE MOMENT.

As the title of this movie indicates, a lot of things happen on the screen. Yet, not a single moment was meaningful or had any depth. Everything happening on the screen was a series of absolute randomness without any meaning whatsoever. They were simply an excuse of flashing 2nd-rated CGI. The endless repetition of the same random craziness led to unbearable boredom and headache, and ultimately drove me crazy. You would have more fun watching a hamster turning a wheel as it will at least put a smile on your face.

This movie is one of the biggest Hollywood hypes I've ever had a displeasure of suffering from. No ordinary human being should be able to enjoy this movie, so I suspect that the hype was driven by all the mindless "free" thinkers who were brainwashed by the critics and influencers bribed by the studio. It is not surprising as we are living in an era in which Kim Kardasian is revered by the crowd. Yet, it is truly sad that people lost their own ability to think themselves and simply herded by someone else's opinion.

I sincerely hope that the average rating of this movie goes down as people come to senses.

Title: Great Movie! Must watch!
Review:
Review Title says it all. Unique, New and a must watch.

Very funny. Very cinematic. Have not felt this way about a movie or show since squid game.

.... .... ...
10 out of 19 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: Wildly stunning, imaginative, and wonderful
Review:
I've been trying for days to find the words to describe this genre-defying movie. At its core, this is a film about family, acceptance, and learning to embrace the better parts of the here and now, despite the noise and pressures of the lives we live and the choices we have made. The vehicle Evelyn takes to her realization is a mind-shredding roller coaster of energy, sight, sound, and conflict, as she travels the many paths of lives she never led to the ultimate goal of happiness and contentment in the life she chose to lead. It is a ride that takes the audience places they could never have imagined they would go. I loved every minute of it.

This movie is packed with action, laughter, humility, love, silliness, crudeness, and depth, as the "everything" of Evelyn's multiverse existences join forces to guide her to a life-affirming understanding of what really matters. Quite simply, it is one of the most original, creative, and rewarding films I have seen this millennium. 10/10.

Title: Strangely beautiful
Review:
I don't understand how they do it. This movie is absolutely absurd and over the top on one hand, yet simply beautiful on the other. The humor can be jackass-level crass, yet somehow the moment of reconciliation feels so cathartic that I literally had tears streaming down my face. I'm old and jaded, so it takes a lot to touch my cold, dark heart. Did I tell you I don't get it? The happy ending plot is fairly clich√©, almost formulaic even, but it works to the degree I didn't think possible for something with so much tropes. If it's food, it's like somebody takes stuff out of a gas station, then inexplicably mixed it up to create a Michelin starred meal. Inconceivable, and yes, it means what I think it means.

Title: Entertaining and fun, but not much else for me personally.
Review:
Okay i decided to go see what's the hype around this film.

I wasn't super excited from trailers so i didn't really have expectations at all.

But where is this all hype coming from?

Is there some kinda Tiktok trend about this or something that i don't know because i don't have Tiktok?

Or maybe this just wasn't for me.

Yeah this is very fast paced, fun and entertaining action comedy.

Not probably my favorite genres.

Multiverse story that to be honest would've been much more exciting about ten years ago.

Some nice relationship drama between characters, but in the end that felt quite shallow.

Now this basically is like Marvel movie script that was just polished to be something little more unique.

There definitely is certain strangness in this that was fun.

But still suprisingly conventional story.

Great performances definitely.

Visually beautiful film.

Attention to details was really good thing in this definitely.

Very entertaining and fun movie, but sadly not much more for me personally.

I'm happy that some others liked it more.

Title: Epic Emotional Rollercoaster
Review: I heard good reviews about this. And usually when reviews that are this good, it is bound to be overhyped. But I gave it a try anyhow to see if it lives up to the hype. Not going to lie, it started off kind of messy, and I had a hard time following the story switching between the english and chinese language. The scenes in the first half of the movie appeared incoherent and it was hard to understand what was going on. But then I discovered that this incoherence was consistent, like some mathematical constant and came to realization that maybe I should not approach this movie with logic and I should not try so hard to understand it, but rather let the movie take you in for the ride and get into it for the sensation of it all and see where it goes. And oh my, how it delivered. I wasn't expecting such an epic emotional rollercoaster experience, even with all the crazy over the top things happening on screen, it blended very well together. It literally included everything, everywhere, all at once that you ever wanted in a movie. This was a masterpiece of a movie. Instant timeless classic, and topics touched upon that are very relevant for our times. This also shows you that representation matters! It gives us a whole range of new and interesting perspective and content we never knew we wanted! My compliments for the script writers and producers for giving us this gem of a movie and it certainly lived up to the hype and more!

Title: The chinese restaurant's Matrix
Review:
Surprised that none of the comments I read (although I probably missed a lot), didnt compare it to the Matrix. Although certainly better alternative than messy and ugly Matrix 4, has pretty much the same introduction and location where the dimension travel begins, while the links to philosophy and religions are also present.

Michelle Yeoh has grown to be my favorite Asian actress and is certainly great here. The levels of imagination used and the ludicrous moments are outstanding.

However it feels that the budget was limited and that we watched an extended director's cut.
1 out of 3 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: I haven't enjoyed a movie this much in years!
Review:
Anyone who knows me knows how much I love Michelle Yeoh, who was my main draw for wanting to see this. An entire multiverse of Michelle Yeoh? Yes, please.

And this movie doesn't disappoint. It's funny, it's charming, and it has real heart. I saw it at the drive in with my roomie, my first outing in public since before the Bad Days of early 2020. Unfortunately, some of the subtitles were a little hard to read and blurry on the screen, which wasn't helped with the distance we were at, but despite only knowing a few words in Cantonese and Mandarin and with sorely outdated glasses I was still able to follow the gist with the careful sprinkling of English, body language and tone, when the captions were too blurry.

I have chronic pain and fatigue and managed to stay mostly motionless and comfortable in my seat because I was utterly engrossed in this ridiculous, wonderful film.

When it's released on digital next month, my roommate and I will be buying a copy immediately to rewatch.

Title: I hate star ratings
Review:
It's very stylish, inventive and very well made, great cinematography, great cast Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis! But at about an hour in and i felt like it's just not quite doing it for me and i found myself wanting to do something else with my time. I'm really not sure why. I'd still rather see more movies like this get made other than yet more Marvel/DC character spin offs, the whole superhero concept is getting extremely tiresome to me. Maybe that's why i just couldn't quite get into this because it still felt a bit like a superhero movie at times. I'll give it another go soon and will probably feel embarrassed about this opinion and delete it. Maybe it's a case of it's not you it's me.

Review:
... to try to watch it till the end, but I absolutely had to give up halfway because I was feeling I could lead a completely different life if I just stopped watching this senseless waste of my time.

Title: What a great film!
Review:
It is great to see a movie that steps outside of the standard boundaries of normal film.

This film can be a metaphor for so many things spiritual and what can represent meaning in our lives.

I would thoroughly recommend this to anyone who has not seen it and who also has an open mind.

I'm surprised not to see this on the top 250 movies on IMDb. Since I believe it's a passes, so many of the other titles on the list.

Hopefully we can see more from the producers and writers who have helped put this film together.

I really have nothing negative to say about this film hence why I have given it the score 10 out of 10.

Title: The best movie I've ever seen
Review:
This movie changed the way I think about life and all of my relationships. I was completely absorbed from start to finish - it was absolutely charming, heartfelt, witty, fast-paced and genius. When I left the theater I felt like I was still immersed in the story. I thought about it nonstop for the rest of the week.

Anyone who has a bad thing to say about this movie clearly did not watch it with an open mind. It takes patience and you have to pay attention fully or you will miss major plot points. It's a movie that rewards you for paying attention.

I show it to everyone I know. Could not recommend this film more!!

Title: Incredible Composition
Review:
This Film is able to unite slap stick with real deep philosophical topics and a really beautiful romantic family story. Daniel Scheinert and Daniel Kwan are able to put really funny scenes in the film to get the perfect pacing between a heartwarming story and the sense of life from the point of view of very old Asian culture that ist still a great view on the things. If you are unsure wether you should go in this movie or not I can just tell you to definitely see that movie.

Title: Good but Overrated
Review:
I really enjoyed the film, it had a great concept, I really liked Michelle and Ke performances but people out here are saying is a master piece of cinema. I think they are not used to watching many truly good films for them to put this movie in that spot, and come on 11 Oscar nominations? Comparing it to other movies that came out this year it really surprised me, personally I wouldn't have nominated it for anything, from my point of view you get an Oscar nomination because you are the best of the best and for me this movie falls short of that

It's a good entertaining movie about family but nothing more.

Review:

Title: Comedy Can Be Deal Breaker
Review:
Tldr; Everything Everywhere All at Once is basically a Matrix Multiverse Comedy. The humor can be a deal breaker.

The amount of creativity this film is oozing with is amazing and it even has some great touching moments near the end relating to "the everything bagel."

But the deal breaker won't be the main villain's and main protagonist's acting (because they nailed it) or the well done cinematography. The deal breaker for most people, who decide this is a terrible, average, or GOAT film is the Comedy!

If you don't find yourself laughing at the constant humor throughout the film. Trust me, stop watching it, because it won't get better for you. You would be better off watching Matrix. Which is just as action packed and mind bending, just without the humor.

Other than that, as previously stated, everything else about it is perfect.

Title: In what universe is this film getting 10 stars?
Review:
As a multiverse fan, this film is an embarrassment. A multiverse usually has some kind of design, some kind of logic that helps viewers enjoy the ride. Look at Dr. Strange and Loki. They both have simple rules that fans can follow. This film is just a chaotic mess. Perhaps it's no surprise that some of the commenters, who are raving about this nonsensical romp, are comparing it to the chaos in their own minds. The quick cuts and sudden universe changes come off as a gimmicky attempt to make you believe that something is actually happening. But, there is just no substitute for an actual plot. What a bore.
249 out of 400 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: The most brilliant family drama movie ever made
Review:
This movie shouldn't work. The pure insanity this movie is at times should not make it any more than a cheesy action movie but it is so much more than that. The themes that it is able to extract through the pure stupidity and joy of it makes it so absolutely incredible to watch and view and the journey it took me on was one I will never forget.

The plot of this movie is so incredibly convoluted and so much is action is packed into this one film but the way the story progresses you truly never feel lost. This is absolutely insane to think about considering how this movie is shot and how quickly it moves but it however a plot that anyone can reflect on and examine for how incredible it is Plot:2/2

The ability for the actors in this film to shift from serious to funny roles is absolutely amazing but the most major props must go to Michelle Yeoh and Stephanie Hsu. There constant clashing weather as mother and daughter or as mortal enemies creates such a wonderful dynamic and one that everyone watching can feel drawn too. However, major props must also go to Ke Hyu Quan whose role as Waymond may be one of the best as well. His ability to quick witted and campy whiles also being one of the biggest drivers of the plot during the third act makes him as well every other minor character so incredible and crucial to the plot of the film.

Acting:2/2

This is the absolute craziest story I have ever seen and what I should have been throughout the entirety of the film was confused, grossed out, and bored and yet I was captivated for every minute of the film. This film gave so many incredible camera shots and artistry throughout the film that it just keeps you on the edge of your seat and brings you closer to these wonderful characters whose lives you feel so intwined with.

Storytelling:1.75/2

This film has creativity in spades. The simple family drama mother daughter story has been told so many times but this one did it in such a unique way that it can and will never be replicated again. The fact that someone even thought of a story like this and to tell it in this way makes this story so absolutely wonderful to digest Creativity:2/2

From the costumes to the music to the cinematography, every little minuet detail of this film bring it to the next level. You can tell that every decision was purposefully placed in order to make this movie the absolute best it can be and while there are so many moments when this movie shouldn't work but everything is done so particular that it ends up being perfection Other Factors:2/2

This movie should have never worked and yet it might be the greatest family drama trope ever told because everyone can relate to this film. Everyone can relate to asking why are we here and why this life and that's what makes it so wonderful. This movie shows our purpose for why we live the way we live and the over the top campiness only adds to the overall enjoyment.

Overall:9.75/10.

Title: Excellent
Review:
In a time where often it starts to feel there are no more good movies being made, or even worse the world feels upside down, this movie gives hope in a very imaginative way. It's like Charlie Kauffman meets kick-ass.

Its artful, warm, cosy, funny and profound. And yes, the message is super cliche: "love, not hate" but packaged so well, in an action flick even, it feels new and fresh.

Not that the movie is completely perfect, it's not, but it doesn't matter, it's about taking something away from it that made it impactful for me and of course the beautiful arty approach.

The biggest thing I got from it is: it doesn't matter. People that make big or small things so important, are pursuing power and wealth etc. What does It all matter If you get sick, die or hurt good people along the way? All the rules people tell you to follow or feelings to feel are just not important. Just love each other for who they are. White, black, gay, it, them etc it doesn't matter if you don't hurt one another. We're all different and the same at once.

And yes, I also look at the woke community and the cancel culture they're building. Stop doing that! It's an unfriendly and inhuman approach. People are not out there to get you. One person doing a bad thing doesn't mean they're all bad. We are all victims of bad people. Talk about it, try to change it, but do it right. Don't become "them" that you hate so much.

I feel this movie targets everybody. Look in the mirror, try to be nicer. Why do so many people think there's more important things than that?

Thanks for this trippy and revealing experience. It's probably a movie I'll only watch once, but what an original experience it was.

Title: Masterpiece!
Review:
Just simply a masterpiece, probably in my top 10 films of all time. It's just beautifully directed, written and acted. Some people won't get it, and I'm sorry about that.

Title: An absolute masterpiece
Review:
This is an absolute incredible surprise, out of nowhere these directors brought us one of the most fun, colorful and "alive" movies in a long while.

I'm not exaggerating when I say this movie has the most heart and soul put in it out of pretty much everything I have seen.

The creativity, the color, the humor, the wholesome message throughout the movie and pretty much everything is done well here

Absolutely deserves all of the awards it is nominated for, this is a really one of a kind movie and perhaps one of my favorites ever

I really can't recommend this enough, an absolute joy to watch no matter on which screen.

Title: Too Hyped
Review:
I felt this movie was more of an experience than just a movie, I did enjoy it especially the start but towards the end it lost me a little.

It's quite hard to explain the concept, I went in knowing absolutely nothing about the movie, I hadn't even seen a trailer. The fight scenes were beyond creative and fun, the drama in the second half of the movie kind of fell a little flat for me.

I would definitely recommend watching it, it's good but a lot of reviews saying it's the best movie of the year and even in years are a little much in my opinion BUT I can see why people do really like it, it's definitely refreshing to see this kind of movie in the cinemas. Have some fun with it, I did.

Title: Everything I Wanted, All At Once
Review:
I haven't felt like this since watching Being John Malkovich over twenty years ago. What a fantastic and deep movie which explores existentialism, nihilism, and regret. However, it really is a story of a mother and spouse's relationship with her husband and daughter, particularly the latter.

Michelle Yeoh demonstrates a new side of an overstretched parent who also chooses not to see her daughter and is losing her. She is incredible in the first twenty minutes of giving off the day-to-day chaos energy the universe throws at her.

I'm sorry, but not surprised, to see so many negative reviews here. This is a purposefully chaotic, strange, and whiplash movie that so rarely graces the screen these days and is so refreshing to see Hollywood still has some originality. Kudos to the producers who green kit this, I can't imagine the gut wrenching of that decision. I hope it pays off in spades at the Academy Awards.

Title: Well, i wanna praise it too, but...
Review:
I must say we dident really enjoyed watching this, and waited it to be over. We went after to eat burger, and was too tired even to talk with eachother. Title: The best film of the year so far and one of the best movies ever.
Review:
"Everything everywhere all at once" is directed by "Daniel Kwan" and "Daniel Scheinert".

It stars Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan, Stephanie Hsu, Jamie Lee Curtis and James Hong.

This "A24" film follows a Chinese Immigrant called Evelyn is forced into a mission to stop the multiverse from crumbling. In doing so she must try and fix her relationships with her family.

I heard a lot about this film and I really wanted to see it. I can truly say not only is it the best film of 2022 but it's also one of the best movies I've ever seen.

The positives

This films message and story are incredibly well written. Every character has a well earned character arc. It's story is wacky but it works. The concept sounds ridiculous on paper but the script makes it work by explaining things clearly and making characters motivations clear and understandable. It also manages to take the audience and it's characters on an emotional journey that never gets dull. All the acting is excellent. The standout is of course "Michelle Yeoh" who deserves to win best actress at this moment in time. The action is amazing to look at. It's clever choreography and flashy editing make it more thrilling. The music fits the movies tone and atmosphere and also adds more thrill especially in the action scenes. The films cinematography is absolutely flawless. The lighting to the camerawork just make the film nice to look. There's plenty of long takes that just add that freshness to the film. Finally, the film is also incredibly funny. So many times me and the audience laughed out loud and I'm so happy that an original idea is making audiences come to the cinema more so that we can have a brilliant atmosphere.

The negatives

I can't find any big problems apart from tiny nitpicks and that's not affecting the rating.

Conclusion

"Everything everywhere all at once" is an incredible piece of cinema. It's story and characters are fantastic, the acting is brilliant, the action is thrilling and edited brilliantly, the music adds more thrill to the film and the comedic moments hit nearly every time. This is now one of my all time favourite movies for a reason and I encourage anyone who can see it to watch it.

I'm going to give "Everything everywhere all at once" a:

10/10.

Title: What movies should be
Review:
This film is a reminder of what can happen be when it's made not as a cash grab but a piece of art. I have never been so emotionally affected by a film before. Some people won't get it. But if you're burdened by a nihilistic thoughts and in search of some meaning in a depressing world, this film is a wonderful reminder of why we keep going.

Title: Hilarious parallel universe movie with a deep message & kung fu
Review:
This is a unique sci-fi/action/comedy, with a captivating twist on the parallel universe theme. Incorporating several Kung Fu action scenes which also come with unusually comedic twists. The story is pretty deep but not in an overly pretentious way, and while there are a few brief moments where the writing crosses the line into cringe, for the most part the story is excellent. It's definitely helped by the superb acting by all of the main characters, and in fact the entire cast of this movie did a great job.

There's not really a single slip up from any actor in the entire movie. This may be, at least in part, due to the director being able to bring the best out of the actors. Cinematography is also great although it's clear to see the directors have experience in music videos so expect a little bit of that aesthetic at times.

If you've seen parallel universe movies before, you'll already know it's best to just go ahead and watch it instead of hearing about it described in a review.

This review was written using precisely-squirted ocean water on the blazing hot sand of a nudist beach. It was later transmitted to this universe for the sole purpose of appearing on this website.

Now back to the beach..

Title: One of the craziest most touching films ive ever watched
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Takes a while to explain itself but a fun ride of a film
Review:
This is the sort of film you need to watch a few times to actually "get it" and soak in all the subtext missed from the first 2 times watching.

The film has more potential than it allows itself to explore. That which borders on deep Existential personal journey allows itself to be dosed with woke and soak with the basic premise moving from the genre of "sci fi multiverse" to "teen emo angst" story rather rapidly, and not in a subtle way.

Big fan of Michelle Yeoh since the 80's and definitely this one gets to showcase her multitude of acting scope. Worth watching more or less, but more for the Martial Arts display and less for the Rattatoie references. *

Title: Pointlessly Absurd But Watchable
Review:
There is no doubt this films insanity is unbelievable weird, but in the same breath it's incredibly engrossing. Jumping in and out of parallel lives at insane speeds don't feel bad if you get lost. All the accolades it got will be divisive, but in my opnion it is deserved.

Avoiding tax evasion and managing a failing laundromat, Evelyn Wang (Michelle Yeoh) seems to be the chosen one to save existence. Travelling through multiverses coinciding with lives she may have led.

Screenplay and Direction is quite original and held up by a stellar cast, all of which won their oscars and deservedly so. Your expectations may or may not be high, however it will either capture your attention or have you pulling hairs.

Title: In this movie lies laws of life
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once, lives up to it's title of everything being everywhere all at once.

This is a busy movie with large to little detail that could be easily missed, so I recommend watching it when you're well awake and have time.

Now I truly believe this movie will be a hit or miss based on the type of person you are, your beliefs and perspectives. But I will say that if you watch it once in your current mind and come out hating it or confused by it, ask yourself.. have you ever wanted to be more than one thing but felt you couldn't? Were you ever sad and felt that misery had to be the way forever? Do you ever feel stuck in your reality? That things can't be different? If you answered yes to any of these, this movie is for you. And if you don't get it, go back and watch it again, this time try and apply it to your current situations in life. I did, and it enlightened me greatly.

I watched this at a pivotal time in my life/former relationship and while stuck in the thought process of hating labels and "why can't something be more than one thing?". I believe because of that and who I am, this movie hit home...real hard. I laughed, cried and got confused even. But at the end it was like the movie spoke in code that I well understood. Me and my now-ex watched it while struggling to figure out what our relationship was now that I wanted one thing and he wanted another, we couldn't find middle ground and were caught up with labels, expectations, feelings and the worlds reasonings. This movie alone answered our muddled questions.

This movie is like art at the museum. You don't always get it at first, sometimes you have to walk around it and catch it at different angles in order to have something click. I would say it's even a movie that has a time and a place in which you should watch it, for you to understand. My life was calling for this movie and was aligned with it when I viewed it. Therefore it spoke volumes. I hope it does and did the same for you.

Everything Everywhere All at Once acts like a true therapy session and life lesson if you dig deep enough, let go and let it. There's no saying what lesson to be learned for you personally, it all depends on you. But it won't leave you empty handed, and if you feel it's left you so? Search for the message because I'm telling you it's there.

The acting was superb as well as the animation and out-the box creativity. My soul needed this movie.

Title: Everything Electric & Smooth
Review:
I would give it a 10 but rewatchability is difficult. Everything is set up as a "new shock" moment.

Michelle Yeoh plays a smooth, level headed leader in otherwise a totally electric family, with many electric things happening (story related). It's very watchable, real, and has a natural dramatic contrast so never boring.

Easy to watch, acting is real, but many scenes are soley electric aggression after a while and it's Michelle's characters role to untangle them.

The movie as a whole needed more structure and break moments, and a simpler ending. Too long was spent on emotionally strong scenes that weren't resolved properly (characters never really getting what they want, or agree'ing to compromise). Many scenes ended with Nihilism and/or revisited multiple times.

Wildly better than any movie made in the last five years.

Title: It's a lot
Review:
I went into it with an open mind. Let's start with the positive: I liked the actors and they gave good performances. I also liked the fight scenes and the message. However, it was nonsensical, absurd and bizarre. I felt lost and nearly gave up watching it because about an hour in, the silliness and jumping around just became too much, and I really didn't see the point of it; still don't. By the end, I was disappointed, mentally exhausted and relieved once it was over. My husband believes that was the point-for us to go along for the crazy ride with the lead character (Evelyn/Michelle Yeoh) to feel what she felt. I guess.
