Title: Crazy, wacky, and fun.
Review:
I want to say that Everything Everywhere All at Once is completely unexpected, but if you saw the trailer for this film or watched Swiss Army Man (the previous effort from this creative team,) you kind of go in expecting things to be extreme and odd. The film is delightfully off-the-wall once the action gets started, and I was ready for anything. What I can say completely surprised me about this film is that it made me laugh more than I have in a theater in a long time. When sitting in a theater with a dozen other people who clearly weren't getting the same enjoyment out of the film, I felt no guilt whatsoever when I was all the only one laughing like a fool at so many of the crazy moments. I know humor is extremely subjective, and there were a few things that some might find offensive instead of funny, but I was tickled by it repeatedly. I also think they abandoned some logic in order to embrace the insanity. Discussing logic might seem like a fool's errand in a movie like this, but there is still an internal logic established that should be followed, and I'm not sure that was always the case here.

The cast was remarkable in Everything Everywhere All at Once, particularly since they are all playing so many different versions of the same people. I struggle to think of anyone who could have done as much with the lead performance as Michelle Yeoh did. She is brilliant and crushes every insane thing she's asked to do. It was fun to see Ke Huy Quan doing his best Jackie Chan impersonation in a role that seems like it was clearly written for the latter actor. I haven't seen Quan in many films lately, so it was great to see him crushing it here, and holding his own. This was the first time I've seen Stephanie Hsu, but she did a great job playing the daughter, who becomes a vital character in the plot. Jamie Lee Curtis was almost unrecognizable, which worked great for me because I had no idea she was in the film, so I got the slow recognition as I started to register I knew that actress. I will say, one of the coolest things about the film is that there were so many powerful women driving the story, although that's diminished slightly because it still required the man to fix things.

I think part of the reason Everything Everywhere All at Once is being highly praised is the way it tackles some heavier topics despite the insane premise. I wanted to be overwhelmed with the way they delved into the complexity of the relationships in the movie, but it never quite brought a tear to my eye. I feel like they undercut some of the emotions by handling it through such odd visuals and a number of weird worlds, so when they returned to normalcy it didn't click as much for me. Although it's possible I simply didn't like the way it was resolved at the end. There was a moment earlier in the film that totally worked for me because I connected with the lesson that the protagonist learned, but the conclusion didn't pack the same punch. I also wonder if the filmmakers (and most of the reviewers I've read) think the movie is far more profound than it is in reality. It's hard to say, as I've only seen the movie once, and there's certainly a lot of crazy stuff to digest. Perhaps on further viewings I'll get more from Everything Everywhere All at Once and rank it even higher.

Title: powerful
Review: This is one of the most bizarre movies I have ever seen, but, ultimately, it is also one of the best. Writers and directors Kwan and Scheinert have created a very engaging and creative story and filmed it in a manner that is quite fascinating. It grabs you from the get go and never lets you go until the very satisfying ending. However, it only works successfully because of the outstanding performances of the entire cast. The Oscar nominations earned by newcomers Stephanie Hsu and Ke Huy Quan, and by veteran Michelle Yeoh and the grandest veteran of them all, Jamie Lee Curtis, are all well-deserved. Their faith and joy in the parts they play are evident and remarkable. Yeoh is just terrific and Curtis is a real scene stealing hoot here. The direction gets fast and furious as the rather complicated shenanigans play out, but ultimately, this is a beautiful and moving story about how the human spirit of friendship and family can always survive the worst obstacles that life throws at us. Brilliantly executed and acted by all involved. Certainly deserves its 11 Oscar nominations and its rank as the most Oscar nominated movie of 2022.

Title: What Multiverse of Madness Should Have Been
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Title: Tiw Everything everything all the time
Review:
Today I watched Everything Everywhere All at Once and on a second watch it made me cry again

Let's bring up something here, I really didn't like the Daniels last movie I watched Swiss Army man. It was overly "quirky" and it's humor did not make me laugh very much at all, often making me cringe. I didn't see death of D. L. but I heard that movie is better than Swiss army Man, though that apparently is also divisive( I will get to it it's on my watchlist). To say the least, I was not expecting much here...

But after letting this digest, watching it a second time, I can say this is definitely a masterpiece of film making. The Daniels have made something that is truly special and is so insanely relatable. Like this speaks to me on such a deep level. But even with the deeper meanings of the film, the film making elements of this film are... just... so incredibly unique and impressive.

This movie is phenomenal, I love it even more on a second watch. Great cinematography, fantastic fight choreography, flawless acting. It's clear that there is heavy inspiration from the matrix, but inspiration does not stop this film from being completely it's own unique experience. This story is intelligent and interesting, the characters all feel so fleshed out and even though ridiculous... realistic too? It's so well done.

It's seriously hilarious and it never stops, it just gets more and more ridiculous and you would expect that to take away from the emotions in the film but it doesn't. The way these directors effortlessly blended tones is just a spectacle, you can go from crying, to laughing, to crying while laughing in a minutes time.

The best part of this film has to be the acting and action. Michelle Yeoh gave legitimately a career defining performance. She's gave it her all and it shows so much. Stephanie Hsu did incredibly too, she was very funny, and I loved the way she could change her personality on a dime. Ke Huy Quan was incredibly nimble and his performance was also stunning. Everyone did great. Everyone was super good at their action too, the way these people fight, it's so intense and I love the way the camera follows Certain fighting shots. Also the fights are very funny too, it's great.

There is not a single element of this film that is bad, but if there is anything that could be improved it could be some of the music choices, some don't feel as effective as others, but this doesn't mean that the music is bad. I really appreciated 95% of the choices here but as someone who's trying to be as critical as possible, this is my only real critique of this film.

Truly, this is an excellent piece of cinema that everyone should see. You'll learn something about yourself.

I originally gave this a high 9/10, I wasn't sure if I wanted to give this a 10, but on a second watch, knowing what it is, I am happy to bump this up. I love this movie, it's become one of my favorites for sure.

Low 10/10.

Title: Words cannot describe what I watched but what I do know is it is a chaotic messy masterpiece!
Review:
This movie had me laughing during multiple parts, had me sad in others, if you've ever watched an arthouse film this one by Daniels is truly a beautiful one! I wanted to see this for the past 3 months now, I finally got to see it last night because they opened it up to more theaters this is truly a crazy film. With an extremely unique way of addressing the multiverse and in a way I feel it pokes fun at marvels multiverse which is ironic when you see who the producers are (spoilers it's the Russo brothers the men behind Endgame. Which was the introduction to the multiverse in the MCU) as the film was about to end I had the question "is that it?" Not because it had a cliffhanger ending as a matter of fact it's ending feels like a closed book. But because I wanted to keep watching the reality jumping chaos.

One thing that should be noted is that everything that's happening on screen through every reality is happening at the same time as each other. Go see this film and you'll see what I mean. I truly loved this film and I will probably go see it 3-4 more times before it leaves my theater.

I should give a warning to some people who have troubles with seizures. This movie has a lot of flashing lights that may give you some trouble.

Title: Something is seriously wrong.... Academy!
Review:
Absurdism randomness seemingly all fresh from what the world is making lately, but it doesn't mean it's amazing no matter what. EEAAO is a movie that is so hyped at Oscars probably to attract the viewers only.

When the fantastic lol takes over the fantastic life journey of keen observation and genuine interest in a motion picture, when money matters, sponsorship matters, movies like Women Talking gets ignored for acting and baseless actors like in EEAAO gets flooded. Time will come when Academy will be ashamed of such choices of North Eastern Asian obsession.

All the immature and cool people are gonna love this movie. So if you are one of them, go and enjoy with a popcorn. It's worth it all, and those who value something genuine, well y'all can go and tuck yourself for this is not your time.

Title: One hell of a multiversial ride
Review:
I couldn't stop comparing this with The Matrix since both these movies share a common technology but in EEAaO there is a catch. I don't want to spoil these moments but these goofy elements are what makes this movie an original. There are so many inspiration and Easter eggs of other movies but still there's uniqueness in this movie. Everything in EEAaO is a masterpiece - Stunts are funny and serious at the same time , The cast have aced their roles , Editing deserves an Oscar and the Cinematography is a contender for Oscars ( Though I'm sure The Batman would win it ).

The themes of Nihilism and Existentialism are discussed in a scene consisting of rocks and if that scene doesn't convince you to watch this movie then I don't know what will.

Title: Masterpiece
Review:
All great movies should do 3 things. They should entertain you, they should move you, and they should make you think.

Everything about this movie is entertaining. This movie has a plot and action sequences rivaling the biggest budget marvel films and some of the most creative fight sequences ever imagined. The plot and its subsequent action sequences and dialogue is so inspired and endlessly inventive. The filmmakers took the idea of a "multiverse" and used it to craft one of the most entertaining (and hilarious) stories to ever grace the big screen.

Everywhere you look, this film is thoughtfully written with profound human experiences, deep, relatable characters and strong moving moments. Throughout the flashes of multiverse madness we are shown such a gripping and powerful story about family and relationships that is so brilliantly acted by a cast that is able to jump from one beat to another, broadcasting a spectrum of colorful emotions all while soaring through character arcs so wrought with emotion you may even find yourself tearing up.

All at once, this movie is profound. This movie is as deep and intelligent as it is bonkers and emotional. The centrifugal force pulling all of this together is the movie's philosophy. This is one of existential meaning; touching upon the surface of our daily interactions, all the way to our complex personal relationships, and even deeper down to our universal purpose and the meaning of every one of our actions. This movie is as much a dissertation of philosophy as it is anything else. There are so many movies and shows exploring the idea of "the multiverse" but by far this is the most critical and complex to date. It uses this theme to dive straight into a theory of everything, exploring the age old of why we are here.

I can't recommend this movie enough. It's so richly inspired and so delightfully fun, moving and thought provoking. This movie is Everything, Everywhere, All at Once.

Title: Unlike anything you have seen before, it's Everywhere all at Once, a modern masterpiece - My Ultimate Review
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is the second film written and directed by Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, you really see how they have grown as filmmakers and storytellers from their previous feature film "Swiss Army Man". Everything Everywhere All at Once has been described by The New York Times as a "swirl of genre anarchy" and incorporates elements of comedy, science fiction, fantasy, martial arts films, and animation. It's a unique movie and the interesting thing is how Kwan and Scheinert had researched the concept of the multiverse as far back as 2010, and they began penning the screenplay by 2016. So it's been like a passion project, in a way. Before watching this film, I thought it was supposed to be this action packed sci-fi film, but I was wrong. Everything Everywhere All at Once is actually a bittersweet domestic drama and a marital comedy, a story of immigrant striving and a hurt-filled ballad of mother-daughter love. Then it incorporates multiple other genres into the film, thus giving us some impressive sci-fi sequences but also some superb action sequences which are choreographed in such a great way. It's just 139 minutes of entertainment. Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert have created something special and worth watching.

An aging Chinese immigrant is swept up in an insane adventure, in which she alone can save the world by exploring other universes connecting with the lives she could have led.

Michelle Yeoh plays the lead role in such a brilliant way, showing her impressive acting range when she ultimately ends up portraying different versions of her character. The same would be said about Ke Huy Quan who plays her husband and Stephanie Hsu who plays her daughter, but Michelle Yeoh is terrific and her performance is one of the film's highlight. Meanwhile the supporting cast has names like Jenny Slate, Harry Shum Jr., James Hong, and Jamie Lee Curtis.

The film explores the concepts of the meaning of life and nihilism, also themes of existentialism and Asian-American identity. Anne Anlin Cheng wrote in The Washington Post: "It's not only that the multiverse acts as a metaphor for the immigrant Asian American experience, or a convenient parable for the dislocations and personality splits suffered by hyphenated (that is, "Asian-American") citizens. It also becomes a rather heady vehicle for confronting and negotiating Asian-pessimism". The theme of meaning of life and the deep story regarding the relationship of mother and daughter and the marital themes was my favorite parts of the writing, well all the themes really were brilliant.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a complex film that encompasses a variety of subjects, but it does justice to each of them with a superbly written script, spectacular performances, and plenty of bizarre humor that doesn't drag on too long to counter its bleak story. It's a film with a deep message that executes its themes perfectly, making you think and reflect about them. It's directed, edited and written with such brilliance. Acted perfectly. The humor might not be for everyone, sometimes it was too bizarre and extreme, but it works if you get immersed enough into the movie which was easy. Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert has a strong imagination, the film wouldn't have been as good if it wasn't for just that, their imagination. Beneath the bizarre humor and over the top sequences lies a film worthy of everyone's attention, it's deep as it's extreme, it's a masterpiece that could have easily been a failure. But it became a box office hit (A24's highest-grossing film at the domestic box office) but also universally acclaimed by critics and audience.

Title: Good but Flawed
Review:
I really wanted to like this movie more than I did. It was very original, had decent acting and interesting effects. It was also unnecessarily confusing, too long by about 40 minutes And from what I can figure out quite illogical in its use of multiverse theme. It also didn't help that the hardware they were using to zip around the Multiverse looked like it was from a 1980s science-fiction movie. Some of the fight scenes were cool, but had a lot of unnecessary slapstick comedy thrown in which really doesn't work for me and seemed very out of place. Worth a watch though.

Title: EVERYTHING SAYS IT ALL...!
Review: Michelle Yeoh is up & front & center in this unwieldy inter-dimensional comedy which finds a harried laundromat owner going through the motions as everything seems to be going wrong for her (she's being audited by an overzealous IRS rep, played by Jamie Lee Curtis, her hubby, Ke Huy Kuan, is about to file for divorce & her gay daughter, Stephanie Hsu, wants to show off her girlfriend to her family & possibly bigoted grandfather, James Hong). The pressure becomes so paramount Yeoh is visited by another Kuan from another universe who explains her heightened state may fracture time & space as she knows it. Fighting both physically & emotionally to keep it together soon runs the gamut of the film's run time (a bit too long for my taste but my viewing partner loved it) as the inventive directors, the Daniels (Swiss Army Man), throw everything & the kitchen sink at the screen (love the parody of Wong Kar Wei films) to bring this phantasmagoria to existence w/all the actors game for the lunacy (especially Kuan who pretty much retired from acting but came back for this) w/a nice showcase for Yeoh who steps up to the challenge to steer a picture by herself. Also starring Jenny Slate as a customer (identified as Big Nose, sheesh!) & Glee alum Harry Shum as a chef.

Title: Yin and Yang
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Too easy to get lost in
Review:
It's a good movie. It just tries to do too much and it's so easy to get lost during it. There are so many things happening all the time that I couldn't really relate to or identify with any scene or relationship. I loved the beginning and I liked the end, everything in-between felt too complicated for me to fully enjoy.

I liked the exploration of the protagonist's relationship with her daughter, I thought it was an interesting take and the cinematography and CGI are incredible.

It just felt too long and repetitive sometimes.

Overall it's a cool and creative idea but that doesn't necessarily make it an interesting movie all the time.

Title: A simple story at its heart
Review:
The real beauty of this film is the simple and relatable familial story at the heart of it. Strip away all of the effects, the confusion and the distractions - it's a story about a family struggling to find their happy place. It's something that resonates, and once this becomes clear the film starts to make a bit of sense.

The challenge of this film is that you need avoid pausing every 10 minutes or so to figure out what the heck is going on. It starts with a family's trip to the tax office preparing for an audit and then 'boom' the pace changes, it's fast and frenetic, much like the dialogue - and it's hard to keep up. It's worth noting that you're not familiar with this genre of film, then you maybe won't like it, but if you do, you'll simply immerse yourself and go with it.

The struggle with the film is that for a large portion of the film it doesn't really go anywhere - fight scene after fight scene. The set up is good and the finale is great - it just takes some time to get there. The film tries to be serious, thought-provoking, clever, silly and funny all at once. Personally, I think the multi-verse aspect is overdone and parts of the film feel plain stupid.

Above all, this is a seriously original film and that has to be lauded - it just isn't that good. You'll be glad you've watched it but probably won't watch it again.

Title: Can I get my money back?

Can I please get my money back ?!? Was the jury at the Academy of the Oscar on some drugs or did they actually see the movie? For me this is a big embarrassment really, they should be ashamed giving this movie any Oscar at all. Shame on you. I'm angry. Is there any refund of my money I spent on this rubbish?

Title: I get it, but I am 67.
Review:
Yes, I agree, it's a mess. It's hard to watch on so many levels. It makes your head hurt. You are confused. Who do you love and whom do you trust? You want to be in charge of your life, but are you really in charge?

This is a very chaotic film. It never gives you a darn break for almost all of it. Fascinating, but you want to stop watching.

I wanted to turn off, like 3 times. Everything everywhere part was un-centered and ridiculous. I kept with it. I kept watching as life delivered was indeed true.

(we) as a whole are a mess. Yes. I know you are in control. But are you really. Have you really sought out your life.

Can we deliver on a level to make things important stand out above trivial things that embrace us and capture our lives?

In summary, if you want to get down in the grit, watch it. Make things happen. This is what this story is about. Chaotic and resolution.

This. Is. What this A24 film is about. I get it.

Title: There are infinite metaverses lurking in your brain. Absolute genious. Lots and lots of laughs. Inmense Michelle Yeoh
Review:
Evelyn Wang is exhausted from facing the endless responsibilities of running the family business, unable to accept her daughter's sexuality, hurt by the estranged relationship with her father and the demands that he has always placed on her, bored with a husband whom she considers a nullity and an obligation, depressed for feeling like a failure and bitter for considering that her life is not what it should, could and deserved to have been.

A party in honor of her father, an unexpected visit from her daughter's girlfriend, a divorce lawsuit from her husband and a tax audit that threatens to close the family business precipitate the crisis.

But to her aid come the infinite metaverses that have always existed lurking in her brain.

Although an intriguing and teasing first shot shows several successive reflections in a mirror, and a misterious shot of the security camera (not seen by Evelyn), I think we can't go wrong, it all comes from Evelyn's mind. As she herself says: everything she thinks, even the craziest, comes to life (Ratatouille becomes Raccacoonie, and in some corner of her mind a glimmer of hope can make her think of a planet without life but where the stones have gogle eyes). In any case, these metaverses will serve in the film to reflect, develop, comment on Evelyn's problem, and to herself to face her temptations and her fears, and take her own decisions.

Great joke about the fashion of metaverses and other pseudoscientific nonsense, unprecedented display of inventiveness that is not afraid of bad taste or the most wildly unjustifiable ideas, superb display of technical expertise brilliantly applied to the story, glorious tribute to the talent of the great Michelle Yeoh and the most hilarious movie that has been seen in many, many years, Everything everywhere all at once triumphs on all fronts. Gloriously chaotic by definition, it invents rules to forget them after a few minutes, because it is a living organism that is constantly changing and evolving like Evelyn's own mind. The film relishes in being absolutely unexpected and unpredictable.

The cast is magnificent in its entirety, brilliant Stephanie Hsu, Jamie Lee Curtis and Ke Hui Kwan, but above all Michelle Yeoh stands out in the role of a lifetime, a tribute to an extraordinary career, which shows us that her abilities are so extraordinary like that of its complex film character.

There are many cinematographic references, of course to martial arts cinema and its star-system, but there is certainly a lot of Fellini (Otto e mezzo, Giulietta degli spiriti), Sirk's melodramas, and winks to Bergman (Persona), Bu√±uel (L'age d'or) and Keaton (Sherlock Jr.)

A masterpiece, to which you can only put the but (not so important given the geniality of what it offers us) of lengthening its resolution in a somewhat unnecessary way, and putting its structure at risk with too many successive climaxes. But it's unfair to criticise a film when it dares to say so many things in such an imaginative way.

Title: Good, absurd, funny
Review:
Normally I like for a plot to make sense, and I understand the complaints from those who think it doesn't, but over the years I've tried to be a little more patient with movies and I found this one interesting even though it wasn't wrapped up nicely with a bow. Great cinematography, acting, production,. You can tell that this movie had a nice budget.

I don't care anything about Oscars but the fact that this got 11 seems a bit much. When Gone With The Wind or Citizen Kane were out there were probably only five categories for Oscars and now there are probably 200. Does best key grip person get an Oscar? Probably. So the 11 will be broken as they continue to roll out more categories but nevertheless it is a good movie.

ABOUT MY REVIEWS:

I do not include a synopsis of the film/show -- you can get that anywhere and that does not constitute a meaningful review -- but rather my thoughts and feelings on the film that hopefully will be informative to you in deciding whether to invest 90-180 minutes of your life on it.

My scale: 1-5 decreasing degrees of "terrible", with 5 being "mediocre" 6- OK. Generally held my interest OR had reasonable cast and/or cinematography, might watch it again 7 - Good. My default rating for a movie I liked enough to watch again, but didn't rise to the upper echelons 8- Very good. Would watch again and recommend to others 9- Outstanding. Would watch over and over; top 10% of my ratings 10 - A classic. (Less than 2% receive this rating). For Lifetime Movies for Chicks (LMFC), drop the above scale by 3 notches. A 6 is excellent and 7 almost unattainable.

Title: Unconventional & Creative
Review:
If you want a film that holds your hands and guides you through the story the EEAAO is not the film for you. If you want to be spoon-fed explanations for what is going on then EEAAO is not the film for you. If you struggle with assembling a IKEA cabinet, the EEAAO is certainly not for you. On the other hand, if you like daring, imaginative an original story-telling, the EEAAO is absolutely worth checking out.

The cast are fantastic and the concepts are very well explained. The effects are insane given the size of the budget of the film. The editing is top notch and it is laugh out loud funny too.

Title: A uniquely fun and welcomed experience
Review:
It's been over a week since I watched Everything Everywhere All at Once and my mind is still frazzled. Partly because of when I saw it and partly because of how it pulled off a unique multiverse experience that had a strong story, comedy, action, sci-fi and unreal editing/design. It's a film that I'll need to re watch.

It's also one of those film that required a lot of thought to think up and just as much work, if not more, to pull it off. Whilst it probably won't click for everybody, some parts are really over the top, it's worth experiencing at some point especially if you are looking for an action/sci-fi film outside of the MCU and DCEU. If Doctor Strange and the Multiverse of Madness didn't work for you, check this out.

That's twice A24 has surprised me this year and their next film, MEN - a horror, is only a week away.

Title: Sound and Fury, Signifying Everything Everywhere All at Once
Review:
I'd heard good things about this, but the fact of the matter is it's basically just any of the Matrix films jumbled up with some overused Spider-verse/ Dr Strange / Rick & Morty, etc. "multiverse" plot ideas that I've seen far too many times now to find innovative or get excited over.

I admire the filmmakers attempting something technically more challenging than the average flick but the end result is just a very shallow and boring film with no interesting characters to connect with or care about, and it felt to me just another one of those recent things made by people who've grown up almost exclusively on video games and so confuse unlocking game levels with storytelling. Because of this, no characters feel real or believable: everyone in it's just an NPC, and so their lives and life events have no weight or depth.

It's all sound and fury, signifying nothing, and I'm sorry to have to say I couldn't get all the way through it. But my own life's better for that.

Title: BRILLIANT
Review:
I'm not going to get into symbolism or break down the themes of the movie in this review. All I have to say so that this movie has everything you could want. Great acting, directing, visuals, HILARIOUS comedy, beautiful drama, stellar action, fantastic fantasy, amazing commitment to quirky weirdness, original and captivating creativity, beauty in the benign. This film made me cry twice during the runtime and then it had me literally crying in the street about 10 minutes after I left the theatre from just reflecting and taking in what I just saw, I even cried while trying to have a sit down lunch with my partner and the beauty and emotions and themes from the movie were just so visceral that I couldn't keep in the tears. It's so beautiful and it takes you on such a ride and you feel every emotion. When nothing matters, you find out what truly matters.

Michelle Yeoh is someone I've always admired for her baddassery and talent, and here she is at her best and she shows that she is a versatile and incredible talented actress to the world that might not already know of her amazing abilities. This movie is special, and entertaining, beautiful, meaningful, and such a fun ride. I can't rave about it enough. Just go see it! Let it take you on this journey and you maybe you will also cry on the street and while trying to order lunch after the movie. I'm eating a 10/10 which I RARELY do! I usually save 10/10 for just my personal faves that I love. This is my new favorite and I don't know how or if it'll ever be topped.

Title: Beautiful
Review: Everything Everywhere All At Once. I'm a grown man and I cried through almost the whole movie. Maybe a little because their sad little struggling existence in the beginning looks a lot like one I've lived. A lot because the movie has so much authentic emotion and that it breaks and fills up your heart. A lot because it's so imaginative and joyous that it had a profound effect on me that I would just get so overwhelmed watching it I'd tear up. It's so original and on top of it so many Asian faces. It means so much that there's so much Asian culture and experience in such a big movie, but that Asian-ness is no more consequential than if they were Irish. It's a part of who they are, but it's not all they are. It makes us all the more connected despite our differences. But the last thing is the idea that we all have so much potential. So many possibilities. And maybe we always have, possibilities. Shortround, all these years later is BACK. In real life. So that message rings true. And he is wonderful in the movie by the way. After all this time he found his potential again. Everyone does personal best work in this film, especially Michelle Yeoh. One of the great film performances. Ever. The effects and editing weren't more of the same thing we've seen and gotten spoiled by seeing often. All that production and detail instead applied to sights we've never seen in places you'd least expect it. It might not have the same effect and affect on everyone, but I thought it was just beautiful. There's so much humor and originality and unbridled imagination and the ability to take ideas, that like the multiverse has been done many times, but make them feel fresh and new. We're lucky if we have people to walk through the world with, and even at our worst we can remember there's still something to love in us all. How beautiful is that?

Title: A beautifully made movie about love
Review:
Definitely one of the most well crafted movies I've ever seen!

A movie that requires your 100% attention at all times as it's jumping between two languages and although it's themes are simple and very human in nature the way that the film makers chose to communicate them are very complex and hard to understand, which in my opinion makes this movie a cinematic masterpiece. Furthermore, the acting was impeccable and the directing and cinematography are diverse and interesting, having been inspired by numerous Asian and European films !!!!

The film might be concealing it self as action with numerous amazingly filmed fight scenes and themes as a multiversal threat but at its core it's a movie about love and the complexity of human relationships. The relationship between a parent and their child, between partners, in laws and most importantly the one one has with himself!

Title: Sorry. What did you say?
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Bananas
Review:
Bananas is the word that comes to mind if I had to describe EEAAO in one word.

This film gets all its 7 stars for acting, originality, and frequent bouts of bonkers hilarity. I haven't cried laughing in a long time and kudos for having a scene good enough to get that out of me. It was the score in that scene that actually put it over the top for me.

That's a good transition. "Over the top" is the best way to describe the 3 missing stars. It tried to take itself way too seriously at some points for something so zany overall. In my opinion if the heartfelt scenes and the moral messages could have been less heavy handed, I think it would have had a better impact.

I hate to say I found myself bored at times and the run time could have been shortened. It tried to tie up literally every single minute storyline and character, except for some reason with Big Nose, who should have had a bigger role in the plot I think.

Overall it was a really fun experience and I'm glad it exists in this universe.

Title: Bizarre and Amazing All At Once
Review:
What an absolutely thrilling ride!

Everything Everywhere All At Once is absolutely bizarre, hilarious but also incorporates a really touching underlying story.

This movie is getting a lot of buzz, and WOW is it justified! You've got the stellar acting of Michelle Yeoh accompanied by Stephanie Hsu, Ke Huy Quan, James Hong and Jamie Lee Curtis. A perfectly twisted story that morphs into a very relatable ending thanks to writer/director duo Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert.

Although it's hard to describe EEAAO without spoiling some fun scenes, I definitely recommend this as a great watch!

Title: A Wild Ride That Is Sure To Entertain Everyone
Review:
Everything Everywhere All At Once is an absurd adventure, which somehow teeters on the line between Asian arthouse, and accessible adventure film. Daniels manage to coordinate action, suspense, and comedy in such a way that flows flawlessly, and allows each element to compliment one another. Every decision made is purposeful, and every technical element is strong. Michelle Yeoh puts up what is perhaps her best performance to date, and is supported by a slew of spectacular co-stars, such as Ke Hua Quan and, Jamie Lee Curtis. This is a film best analyzed after a second watch due to its relentless action, and chaotic atmosphere. The set design, hair and makeup, visual effects, and cinematography will undoubtedly warrant this film consideration come Oscar season. Everything Everywhere All At Once is a film that will be enjoyed by everyone, as it's artistic elements are sure to intrigue any cinephile or film student, and it's accessibility is sure to entertain any average movie goer. Daniels have proven their range, and genuine talent with this film, and have managed to make something unforgettable on what is only their sophomore effort as a duo.

Title: Not sure what all the fuss is about.
Review:
Edit: Seven Oscars for this film just show how desperate Hollywood has become and how low the bar has sunk. Good luck to the winners but this is just style over any real substance. There were so many other worthier potential winners. Shame on the Academy.

There are a few moments in this film where someting profound or original is said but that's about it. I don't get why everyone is tipping Yeoh or Curtis for Oscars as the acting in general is frenetic, shouty and average and overshadowed by the special effects. The storyline about multiverses is an interesting concept but the execution of this is confused and poorly executed. I'm willing to bet that a lot of people 'like' this film because they don't want to be seen as missing the point. I'm guessing that the point is about making the most of your life decisions and realising that everyone has a tale to tell and bears the scars of living. At the end of it all is there any point to life or to this film. I've seen worse films but I was expecting more after all the hype.

Title: it's better than drugs jeremy!
Review:
Every new film/series is just a reminder, that we've barely scratched the surface in the infinite possibilities of storytelling and who knows what great new film/series is coming next... to make us feel even more tiny in this vast world of cinema.

Been wanting to write a review for this since long ago but I couldn't really frame what I had to say for it up until now when I rewatched it today.

This film is as absurd as it can be in it's presentation, and that's a good thing. Filmmakers are afraid to tap into weird and absurd things nowadays because of the possible financial losses. Which makes this film feel really fresh in it's concept, it's storytelling, it's action, it's humour, everything is a result of peak imagination from the writer-directors Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert.

Michelle Yeoh. Stephanie Hsu, Ke Huy Quan, James Hong. Jamie Lee Curtis, each and everyone in the cast is so good that there is not a single loose thread in the acting. They're all just perfect.

The story, phew. I can't really describe it to you but just to summarize, it's essentially a story about a mother who is a failure but doesn't want her daughter to be the same, but even if she's a failure, it doesn't matter because it does not change the fact that she is always gonna be her daughter and nothing in this vast multiverse can change that unconditional love a mother has for her child. Michelle yeoh literally travels the entire multiverse to save her daughter and is stubborn (as she should be) in not letting her precious child go.

I didn't think this film would manage to make me cry when I stepped into the theatres to watch it for the first time. But so happened the first and, lo and behold, even after rewatching it today, I cried. The film manages to tap into every human emotion possible and makes you feel things. Makes me happy, sad, angry, surprised, bitter and so much more.

The aspect which I loved the most? The editing. If this film hadn't been edited the way it has been. I think it wouldn't be able to achieve the status it has achieved as of now. It's so good, it's mind-boggling. I will try my best to recreate some of this in the future if I can because this film really opens up a lot of editing techniques which I've rarely seen before.

Just watch this guys, it might become your favourite film of the year. A huge shoutout to A24 for producing this risky project and releasing it before the over-hyped Doctor Strange: Multiverse of Madness which, let's be honest, was barely about the multiverse and straight up disappointing.

Title: A temporary breath of fresh air.
Review:
Sure, it's probably the best movie of the last decade, but that's not saying much in a decade riddled with medicore superhero films, covid interruptions, and so many streaming services dropping the bag on not being able to produce one goddamn good movie.

While watching the film, you get the impression that this could be the start of a new era of unapologetically weird, fun, moving films - lead by A24. Then you step out of the theater, and put the rose-tinted 3D glasses away, and discover that the movie is actually quite shallow and empty, and doesn't leave you thinking about it for weeks, like Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind or Inception would.

It's a sad fact that there's just not much to think or talk about with the actual story of the film. It's fun, enjoyable, and moving in the moment, but won't have you reevaluating your life.

But I'll be keenly looking forward to seeing whatever ke huy quan, A24, and The Danels make next! They have all proven their talent and I hope they'll continue to lead the next decade of film into weird, exciting, moving places.

This is a must-watch!

The visuals were great and some of the findings were very clever but the repetitiveness of the same jokes over and over and over again was tiresome. I honestly felt that they didn't know how to finish the film. An hour earlier would have been a great choice.

Title: All the bling without the substance
Review:
I see the appeal of this movie but it left a bagel-hole in my soul. The pacing was kept at a good pace, appropriately balancing exposition, action, and character-development for the most part; although the plot slowed down too much in a couple different story-lines. It's generally well-produced, well-acted, and well-written--with a few plot holes still left in--but the narrative is rather self-indulgent and promotes a vacuous philosophy. The writers/directors unsuccessfully deaden their nihilistic bent with non-ironic, melodramatic sentimentality that rings hollow to the ears after all the pontificating that came before. The ultimate ideology of the movie undermines any gravitas or truthfulness of its final moments and its attempted rescue out of meaninglessness.

Title: The story is pretty stupid, but pretty genius
Review:
The title says everything you need to know about the story. The cinematography was pretty impressive though. Shooting on Panavision I think was a smart choice specifically for the colors the sensors provide. An interesting and really good choice was the DP switching between anamorphic and spherical glass to differentiate universes. Very subtle, but had a huge impact on the visual story. The lighting was alright. There was the one cool effect that was achieved by triangulating Astera's Titan Tubes which gave quick-moving light that keyed different parts of the face. Other than that, I thought while stylistic, the lighting lacked originality. Besides the Triangulation of the Titan Tubes...that was cool, and definitely a striking catch-light in the reflections in the eye. I liked the use of soft lighting mixed with hard back lighting. It made the fight scenes pop and feel "marvel-esc" out of nowhere. Overall, great work by not only Larkin Seiple, but the entire G&E and PD.

Title: Hold on to your hats folks!!
Review:
Hold on to your hats, folks, because "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is one wild ride of a movie. Directed by the duo known as Daniels, this film takes you on a journey through multiple universes, and let me tell you, it's heck of a trip!

Michelle Yeoh stars as a badass middle aged woman who discovers she has the power to travel through different dimensions. And who knew that power could come in so handy when you need to fight off a bunch of bad guys? Yeoh's performance is nothing short of amazing, and it's a testament to her talent that she can make kicking butt in multiple universes seem so effortless.

But what really makes this movie shine is the incredible supporting cast. Ke Huy Quan plays Yeoh's husband/mentor, and He is simply amazing, and of course their daughter Stephanie Hsu? Well, let's just say that if you're looking for a laugh, she's got you covered. Between the three of them, you'll be laughing, crying, and cheering throughout the entire movie, and not to forget about the one and only Jamie Lee Curtis who played completely different character comparing to her other movies and oh my! She nailed it.

The special effects in "Everything Everywhere All at Once" are mind-blowing, and the way the film plays with alternate realities is pretty trippy. I mean, there are moments where you'll feel like you're on an acid trip, and that's a good thing! (Not that I even tried it, but I heard from people who did!!) The cinematography is also gorgeous, and every shot looks like it was plucked straight out of a surrealist painting.

But what I really love about this movie is how it balances the absurdity with the emotional depth. Yes, there are moments where you'll be scratching your head and wondering what the heck is going on, but there are also moments where you'll be moved to tears. This movie has heart, and it's not afraid to wear it on its sleeve.

In short, "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a movie that defies description. It's a mash-up of action, comedy, sci-fi, and drama, and it somehow manages to make all those genres work together seamlessly. If you're in the mood for something completely bonkers and unapologetically weird, this movie is for you. Just make sure you buckle up, because you're in for one hell of a ride.

Title: I'd like the salt bagel instead!
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once (2022) Directors: Daniel Kwan & Daniel Scheinert Watched: 12/19/22 Rating: 3/5 stars

Too much all at once Googly eyes, hot dogs, and rocks Absurd time travel Profound fun with keen acting But I'll take a salt bagel!

The tanka is a thirty-one-syllable poem, traditionally written in a single unbroken line. A form of waka, Japanese song or verse, tanka translates as "short song," and is better known in its five-line, 5/7/5/7/7 syllable count form.

Title: This generation's next visual spectacle, and that's not even the best part
Review:
There are times when a film can be so unabashedly creative and original that it can be hard to collect your thoughts or even pigeon-hole it into a genre. Sometimes, perhaps with films such as "Swiss Army Man" (2016) or "The Lobster" (2015), the creative overflow can convolute the tone and diminish the overall impact of the storytelling. However, when filmmakers can strike the perfect balance and deliver something that is a visual spectacle, gut-wrenchingly hilarious, and emotionally impactful, it can be true movie magic. "Everything Everywhere All At Once" is of the latter and it is one of the best films that I have seen in years.

Michelle Yeoh stars as Evelyn Wang who, in a day where her family's laundromat is being audited by the IRS, is sucked into the multiverse where she must work with other versions of herself to save the world. Multiverse narratives seem to be the new hot writing trend in Hollywood and can been seen everywhere from superhero flicks to sci-fi dramas. I think that it will be a real challenge to find one more masterfully created than "Everything Everywhere All at Once".

The film was written and directed by The Daniels and if sci-fi, comedy, drama isn't the best word to describe the film then how about this: CRAZY. We are talking dildo nunchuck-wielding, Mad Max on crack level of insanity, but, they somehow make it work. The action is beautifully helmed, the editing is perfectly chaotic, and the explosion of creativity is expertly realized. I have never seen a movie like this in my life.

Perhaps some of the action relied too much on slow motion and perhaps the first act was slow to start because of exposition but, honestly, the more I try and nitpick the more I realize the choices all serve the tone of the film. The real magic of "Everything Everywhere All At Once" is not the impressiveness of the Multiverse storytelling, but how it is used to serve the overall theme of the narrative. Family, marriage, maturity, parenthood - these are all themes that have countless films under their umbrella, but none of them are like this. Get out and support this film - it deserves your attention.

Grade: A+

Title: Insane And Heartwarming

The Daniels managed to create a film that is wildly creative and entertaining whilst also making it profoundly touching. It's insane, unique, hilarious, emotional and I recommend you go out and support it.

Title: Pure Brilliance
Review: I've only seen this film once and that was shortly after it was released in theaters for the first time. Almost a year later I'm still in awe of the brilliance that this film is and the Daniels are two truly brilliant directors that deserve all the praise and accolades they are receiving, same for the rest of the cast and everyone involved. The film had me laughing, crying, and feeling so much hope and joy and I truly believe it will go down as one of the best films of the decade. This will be the film you see added to the Criterion Collection years from now, and will definitely be in the top 100 films of all time list. To put so many moving elements together (comedy, sci-fi, action, drama, mystery) all in one and make it work shows how talented the directors are and the cast was a cherry on top. Ke He Quan's performance was heartwrenchingly beautiful and what a truly wonderful comeback for him after a 20 year hiatus. An Oscar would be the most deserving award for him, especially after he thought his acting career was over despite being a child star. Stephanie Hsu is truly pheonomal and as her first major role, she takes the spotlight and gives so many layers and dimensions (literally) to her character which really showcases how talented she is and I hope she too can get an Oscar win. Lastly, Michelle Yeoh is brilliant. Perfect casting and I must give credit again to the Daniels for making a 50+ woman the lead protagonist in the film and really showing the world what a talent she is given her longevity in the film industry. This is the first film I've seen of hers but I have so much respect for her. While the lead actress category at the Oscars has some strong contenders, she too is worthy of the award for her performance.

Title: Really good and innovative, but it didn't deserve that much awards in the 95th Oscars
Review:
To start with, this is a good movie. It has some strengths, such as the script, which is original, even if there are obvious influences from movies like "The Matrix", the acting, which is really decent (although Michelle Yeoh has played better roles and didn't deserve, in my opinion, to be awarded with the "Best Actress in a Leading Role" Academy Award, and it is a fast-paced movie, so you won't get bored. Also, the direction is very nice, the visual effects are very impressive and it ultimately has an uplifting message, so it's not a waste of time. But, as I see it, it needn't have won the MOST awards in the 95th Oscars (7), whereas other films like "Tar", "The Banshees of Inisherin" and "The Fabelmans" went on to win none of the awards they were nominated for. It has some risque moments, as well. It's a genre-busting movie, that touches upon some serious issues, that it is fun to watch, too. I don't say it's a movie you shoud avoid, but to me it seems a bit overrated.

Title: Significance will be felt for years to come
Review: It's not at all an overstatement to suggest Kwan's film will be seen as the emotional encapsulation of a strange time in history. The primary narrative of a family's fight and the quotidian impact of the fractures within, are simple foundations for a poignant introspection of social undoing. This film tries to pull us all back from the brink; the fear, the hate, the spite, we all engorge upon. The intersectional personal stories are meant both as sincere examinations of the contemporary moment and also points reifying the brinksmanship we all engage in. Reviews will tank the movie simply because of its LGBTQ pointing sup-plot, others will lionize this content and ignore other nuances, perhaps of heteronormative qualities. None of this matters...Nothing matters. We really all are insignificant pieces of crap. Or desperately lost people who suffer the conceit of consciousness, abetted by time and history. But if all of that makes you feel alone, maybe you aren't But unity doesn't arrive through magnifying the grief of our struggles. Peace might come in letting go, and maybe being kind. We're all so convinced fighting defines your value. Sure, it does to a degree. But we might want to constantly evaluate that.

Title: Madness with a message
Review:
A psychotic dream? An allegory of the universal struggle against nihilism? A family saga? Al three at once? Some do not get it - "too wacky". Poor souls, lost in an universe where failing laundry-ownerscan't be heroes. But hey, this is 21st century reality. Even Parliament can be stormed. So is it strange that Michelle Yao is a superhero and Jamie Lee Curtis is a villain? That parallel universes and the bagel of doom exist? If you appreciate the Big Lebowski, go. If you are the 'Go Superman-type, don't.

If you have no sense of the absurd, don't go. But if you do, see it. Especially if you are the type like me that watches The Big Lebowski over and over again because you enjoy madness with a message. And so what the message-heavy ending. As The Dude said: aggression will not stand, and if we ever needed reminders of that, it is now. Plus: enjoy references to everything ever made, from In The Mood For Love to Edward Scissorhands and Karate Kid to Ratatouille, beating Tarantien at his own game.

Title: The clash of two alternative nihilist perspective
Review:
1) If nothing matters, then all the pain and guilt you feel for making nothing of your life goes away.. 2) The only thing I do know is that we have to be kind. Please, be kind. Especially when we don't know what's going on... ---Everyting everywhere all at once The clash of two alternative nihilist perspective, If nothing matters, if evrything is pointless should we be self consumed and care less about anything, or should we care about the relations we have and be more kind because afterall it gives atleast some meaning to our life? The concept was really a unique one but I really think this movie could have offered way more. It had all the ingredients to be a cult classic but turned out to be a draggy film with confusing storyline, the humors were unfunny most of the time. I wish Christopher nolan directed this film. Still I will recommend this film just because of the underline concept as there are very few films which can actually challenge our sperficial idea about life.

Title: The most overrated pointless mess, travesty that it won so many Oscars
Review: This movie is a jumbled, hurried mess of a bunch of ideas that I feel everyone jumped on the bandwagon because they felt they were supposed to give it flowers that it does not even come close to deserving. It's a fast-paced whirling dervish of nonsense with little to no point. And don't even get me started on all it's undeserved wins at the Oscars - an absolute low for the Academy Awards, when there were other films FAR more deserving in nearly every category. It's an instant headache and one of the most dizzying annoying pieces of try-hard "art" ever captured on film. I cannot overstate how un-clever this film is, while some critics and fans must have been tricked into thinking it was a "must watch" - in reality, it is 140 minutes of blah, blah, blah combined with some nauseatingly fast action sequences. Not only is this this not worth watching in the slightest, it's one of the biggest wastes of time out there. You will likely be told: "just watch it!" (If you haven't already), but if you don't want to suffer through nearly 2.5 hours of utter garbage, I'd suggest skipping it. My score of 3/10 is being kind, due to the obvious amount of hard work that all involved put into making this ridiculous thing. It's jumbled rubbish - don't believe the hype.

Title: And, somewhere in an alternate universe, the Oscar goes to a 'Rick and Morty' episode
Review:
Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh), apparently the most underachieving and least content Evelyn in the multi-verse, learns to tap into the potentials and abilities of other multiverse Evelyns when she is recruited to battle the evil Jobu Tupaki, who has created a deadly metaphor than could destroy all of the infinite realities. Title: I'm ending my aspiration to write films.
Review:
I'll never write a film this good. So why bother? I had a somewhat similar idea, but they did it so much better than I ever could. So.. why bother. Nothing matters.

Title: Acting was superb
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Very introspective and irreverent
Review:
One of the best original movies I have seen in a long time and it goes to show you what can be created when Hollywood studios make way for original content and not just franchise bait. This movie was sci-fi, action, comedy, and family drama all wrapped in one with a fantastic story and great cinematography and lighting. The story constantly keeps us asking what the meaning of life truly is and how our choices can truly butterfly effect something down the road but this movie is one that'll have you thinking about it for day after.

Title: It's a marmite film... and I LOVE marmite!
Review:
The pace is insane. The plot line is proposterous. The cinemotography is gorgeous. And certain characterisations are bizarre.

EEAAO is certainly a one off, and needs to be watched and embraced with an open mind. I totally get why there are haters but I loved it. The film is deliciously layered and Yeoh supported by a middle aged Short Round are superb. And Jamie Lee Curtis looks like she is having the time of her life.

I cant remember a recent film where I was moved, laughed or intrigued in equal measure. There are no spoilers here. Let's just say that this unique film stretches your intellectual and emotionally intelligence and if your mind is up for it, you're in for quite a ride.

Magnificent. I can't work.out what this film really is but I love it all the same.

Title: A MASTERPIECE !!!
Review:
This is a must watch movie for everyone including old and young. It is so interesting to watch such a masterpiece created by two "evil geniuses" as quoted by Michelle Yeoh.

This movie has been a multi universe kind of a gig that shows us about family, love and kindness. All the characters are just so amazing to watch and as well they brought their best acting.

It is one of a kind movie which I think comes out like every 10 years or so. So please if you can go watch it, it is worth it and again, two thumbs up for the actors and directors and producers and everybody who took part to create this amazing and fantastic movie.

Title: film doesn't understand women
Review:
The movie doesn't understand its main character. This is clearly a masculinist interpretation of a remarkable woman's ingenuity. I could give many examples but will settle on her portrayal as one who bailed on all of her dream projects, such as singing, kung fu, cooking, and so on, and barely holds herself together for survival. What the hell? She had a family and a business to hold together. It is as though the movie blames her for life being difficult, and then is amazed when she pulls it together. Women do that every day. The film is far more sympathetic to the husband, so befuddled by the amazing women around him he wants to bail with a divorce. I read that this story was originally written for Jackie Chan, with a male lead. Maybe that would have worked because the writers clearly don't understand women. Watch it for the acting. Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis are both amazing and deserve their accolades. And yes, the cinematography, costumes, and other technical aspects are excellent.

Title: Everything Everywhere All At Once Was Just A Not So Special Family Drama Story That Adds With Cool Special Effects And Some Multiverse Elements In It That Didn't Work With The
Review: Everything Everywhere All At Once was just a not so special family drama story that adds with cool special effects and some Multiverse elements in it that didn't work with the real story at all for me, emotionally didn't work, blown away by it? Not really surprisingly, and it's too long, ok performances by all the cast and with all the flaws and it did might sound harsh but it wasn't truly a bad movie overall but it just not the one that at very least ok too for me so i was still pretty much disappointed, despite the cool special effects and the Multiverse thing, the real story of the film was really my major problem because it didn't fit with the other side of the story, and if you erase all the Multiverse stuff, it might be even work more, it just doesn't connect, it's a mixed bag of a feeling, it felt very forced, again i like the super weird Multiverse thing that they did, the special effects, the style, the color, the lighting, the cinematography, the score, and performance was still ok, but as a whole combined with the real story, it didn't work for me, and it's surprisingly becoming my new unpopular opinion on possibly the most talked film of 2022 and the one that got a lot of praise, not for me.

Title: My head!!!!
Review:
I think they were trying to be deep and profound, but what resulted was two hours of head-splitting chaos and confusion. It is a shame, because I had high hopes for this movie. I just don't understand the hype. They tried too hard to be weird. I think at the end they were trying to pull the heartstrings, but I was too confused to know for sure. I'm not even sure what the movie was about. I think it had something to do with familial relations, or perhaps current tax laws? Whatever it was, they should have had an epileptic seizure warning.

Title: A Beautiful Mess
Review:
The title describes itself perfectly because everything is really everywhere and happening all at once during 2 hour 15 mins.

I kept asking myself 'What the hell is going on, what kind of absurdism is that ?' in the first hour of the movie. I even thought that, the directors were trying so hard to be philosophical and fathomless. I'm sure many people would quit watching it after a couple of minutes, which they SHOULD NOT !!! That's why I decided to shoot a review, as it may help others to appreciate the movie and not to quit watching. The movie asks for patience from its audience, but it pays the reward.

It starts with a unique storytelling that I think, I've never seen in any movies before. It's absurd, surreal, and too complex to comprehend if it really tries to show something to the audience or just tries to be as it is. As I've stated above it's a must watch but hard to finish. The first half of it makes you smile a lot, and cringe a lot at, as some scenes are the goofiest ever, without spoilers, I could say the ways people use to jump from universe to universe linking another version of them will shock you.

The second part of the movie (approx. After 1.30), the tone of it completely changes, when the story starts to unfold. All the philosophical tone, and absurdism turn to an emotional rollercoaster between generations. And here we have the most unique way of telling the story of most ordinary people (a Chinese immigrant couple on the verge of divorce who works a laundry in the USA dealing with daily issues of life). Without further ado, I have to say that I've never got so emotional for a long time, and I even cried, and tbh I cried a lot.

I haven't watched such a unique movie since Parasite. I just loved the movie so much. I also loved the acting of all the cast, but especially Michelle Yeoh and Ke Hyu Quan. Michelle Yeoh deserves all the awards for which she has been nominated for her flawless performance. I think it's absolutely one of the best movies of 2022 (and all time) and best contender for Best Motion Picture Academy Award.

Title: I am glad I watched it but it was heavy handed
Review:
Glad I watched it. I enjoy seeing a slice of life: how other people deal with the aggravation of life. Especially with all the lying via social media..

And the message here was a fine one. I do like the underlying premise at the end that due to the treatment of the daughter by the mother, the mother will have to work extra hard to win her back. I think that is a lesson a lot of parents of teens and young adults should heed especially since having teens is like a "get out of jail free" card that parents can use to shield their own crappy treatment of their teenage kids.

However, the fight scenes wore thin on me. I liked the beginning as we got to know the world and the "technology". It took me a while to figure out what was happening. But then we had too many fight scenes and too pat a wrap up.

Title: Weirdly Pleasing, But not as Great as Everyone Says it is
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once literally places everything everywhere all at once. As a result, it's just a big, dizzy and prolonged adventure-comedy with lots of humour, touching morals and imaginative messes. There's also frequent changes between spoken languages that can be slippery to catch up with and it would've been best at a runtime of under 2 hours, but 110 minutes or more would do the trick. So like most people would highly disagree on and be able to make fair points that overshadow the not-so-great things in the film, it's a bit of an overrated movie, but is it worth watching?

If you have plenty of free time on your hands, Everything Everywhere All at Once is an action-adventure-comedy loaded with plenty of imaginative sci-fi stuff written and directed by Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert. Their film is very trippy, original and completely weird, which is the entire point. It centres on an interesting but aging Chinese woman who happens to be an unlikely hero as she must fight the creative dangers of the multiverse to save the world. Give it a shot, because it's either something you'll love or hate, and you can usually tell the pacing at the halfway point.

This movie presents a ton of extremely weird, utterly strange and very trippy visuals and effects during the main character's insane adventure. And it's really just an adventure film, although there's frequent moments that are brutally hilarious, like the hot dog fingers and the other crazy stuff. Thankfully, the story is original and that makes sure to entertain you. But to look at the touching elements, this movie does shed light on some parent-child issues and leaves very nicely. Watch this film is you are looking for a bizarrely weird adventure-comedy, but it's just overhyped.

If you liked this review, check out the full review and other reviews at aussieboyreviews.

Title: The most imaginative film you will see all year
Review: Everything Everywhere All At Once is more than likely one of the most imaginative movies you will see all year if not ever. The way in which it delves into the concept of the multiverse is truly breathtaking from both a visual and symbolic standpoint. All of the costumes and locations are vibrant and meaningful to the main characters in more ways than one. This makes every setting and every decision these characters make feel extremely important throughout the entire movie. There's a ton of multiverses that are explored too and the same can be said about the symbolic messages and "hidden" meanings behind this film. The story was executed so brilliantly that there's plenty of time for audiences to adore every single character, provide intense sci-fi action, tons of humor, and serious tones/themes together seamlessly. One minute you might find yourself laughing pretty hard, the next you might be trying to hold back a tear or two. Everywhere All At Once has a lot to say regarding the human condition yet somehow manages to still be a sci-fi epic. A24 movies aren't for everyone but the originality and amazing execution from a filmmaking standpoint is simply undeniable here.

Title: The title says it all
Review:
Everything everywhere all at once. That's it. Yes, it's about multi-universe matrix like alternative realities and weird other worlds, and how the smallest moment or tiniest decision can effect you everything and everybody. It sets out to be hyper clever and is supposed to be insightful, but I just found it very very very annoying, hyperactive, and just plain silly. Was I supposed to care about these characters? Was there a point to this film? It is technically brilliant, and Michelle Yeoh and the cast do a spirited job, but, honestly, given the idea, a much better film could have been made on this theme. I think it'll probably appeal to those who are into computer gaming, The Matrix movies or fantasy and sci-Fi, however, it certainly didn't do much for me.

Title: An imaginatory masterpiece
Review:
Let me start with that the people who rate this low are probably the ones too simple to comprehend the idea of the multiverse and too slow to follow and understand the plot...although they'll claim it's none of those. This movie packs so much thought and imagination into a good two hours that it'll make your brain fire in all cylinders, and your neurons clap in joy from the impulses hitting them. Besides this it is action packed, at times brutal yet wierdly funny. It is also very refreshing that with the cast it takes a break from the generic hollywood actors/actresses and boasts talented professionals beyond the plastic faces of the industry. A must watch.

Title: Mental Rollercoaster?
Review:
The opening shot is a cluttered living space above a family laundromat. That clutter defines the film for me, while the two-fold adjacent universe of life/work offers a simple hint of adjoining "universes" to be explored through-out the long, but enjoyable movie.

My 19 year old boys loved the film, I appreciate how it flirted with philosophies, before finding a pretty safe space in humanism. Although the existential rock by rock shots had an extra appeal for me. Wong-Kar Wei fans will be happy here, and while my kids might not want to hear it, this film stretches quantum and cinematic strings to connect to the superhero genre and MCU.

You want CGI and choreographed fight scenes, you got 'em. Jokes are very carefully thrown and land gently. The use of a surreal gesture for escape velocity in channeling between universes might have been a bit overused. Perhaps the filmmakers subscribe to ultimately to the Cosmic Joke.

The universe(s) here are big, and beyond those for me the film tries to do too much, for too many people. Both my kids and myself really enjoyed the director's previous foray, where they were mostly confined to an island grotto. Yet there was still plenty of room for the outlandish in that smaller but purposeful "Switchblade" of a film.

The notion of a metaverse seems to be ramping up more and more these days in various forms, whether to feed a supernatural hunger for teens weaned off religion, or offer some sense of justice that too often feels pay-walled off for those imprisoned here in the lower quanta of society. I feel an agnostic reaction welling up inside me.

Probably overthinking it, but the film does invite such overthinking...even if it serves best as a giant mental rollercoaster, and you wind up exactly where you started.

Title: Half Of This Works
Review:
I saw Everything Everywhere All at Once seemingly after everyone else I know already saw it. Most everyone I know had for the most part great things to say about it.
