Title: Original? Yes! But this was SUPPOSED to be the baseline, Hollowood!
Review:
Don't get me wrong. This movie had its moments and had me laughing my axx off quite a number of times as well as clap sometimes.. but hey, that's because I was still coming off of sunken cost fallacy and what an utter garbage Gerard Butler's Last Seen Alive was (last seen movie before this...) so there's that.

My first reaction to it after finishing it was 8 or 10, but then when the buzz calmed down and the lights faded, I realized we might have been duped.

This movie felt like Shen Yun-meet-Mission Impossible or rather a Jackie Chan Kung-Fu movie. There are some absolutely amazing cinematography and fine editing skills... but that's about it. Some of the lines were cool and many scenes funny .. and that's it.

It's like a big ol hot fudge sundae or whatever.. which you relish only once. I cannot for the love of my life imagine rewatching it esp. With the DISGUSTING bloody dildo scene.

And what was the raison d'etre for it anyway? To 'shock' viewers? Really?

And true to Hollywood they have to insert some woke meme about a lesbian female teenage daughter. Jeezus Christ.

I might be unduly harsh, but I just want to balance it out. Had it came out in late 90s or early 2000s it would be considered "competitive". I mean this is what Hollywood (Hollowood?) is supposed to be!! THIS should be the baseline. This is the orignality and creativity we expect with ALL movies.

Guess public is numbed out by dumb boring ditzy Marvel movies and boilerplate formulaic action movies like Grey Man with Ryan Gosling and Last Seen Alive, that we are acting we saw the promised land. Halle frikkin lulah indeed.

If you wanna be pretentious and watch philosophical movies and write pretentious reviews then there are in spate.

Tree of Life, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, Pi, Stranger Than Fiction, Truman Show...

This is not one of them. At least not miles by my "rewatching" standard.

Title: A bad Kung Fu Hustle with the story of a terrible Rick and Morty episode
Review:
If you have seen Rick and Morty, or any other multiverse saga (like Jet Li's The one), you know the drill: in the infinite multiverse some nihilist is out of control and threatens to destroy everything. Now jump from universe to universe trying to stop him.

But you haven't seen it with an insane amount of ridiculous Kung Fu fights (because with good fights, Jet Li's The One has already done it), one of them involving two of the fighters trying to land butt first on a buttplug and a dildo, and succeeding and having the dildo protruding the rest of the fight until it is pulled out by the protagonist.

I don't know how this piece of crap got high praise. It is vulgar, repetitive, derivative with not one fresh idea or execution. It feels like it is a parody of something, like the Matrix, perhaps. But even as parody it fails because most of the attempts are humor are cringey at best, vulgarly offensive at worst.

What a letdown. I was hoping for an intelligent take on the multiverse, or to be impressed by fresh ideas. Instead I got a infantile potty humor Kung Fu Hustle, that goes nowhere.

But the worst part of this terrible movie? The characters. Or lack of them. The whole movie is so preoccupied with explaining its Universe and jumping from fight to fight, that it forgets to have engaging characters that are something more than rebellious teenage daughter, worried mom and submissive husband.

I can't remember a movie that had such a promising trailer, letting me down this bad.

For those who have not seen it, a warning I wish I had: if your hopes for this movie goes above having a buttplug fight, and someone putting snot into someone's mouth, recalibrate those expectations. This is not a psychological thriller with great mindfcs. It is a terrible, terrible movie.

Title: Great commentary on the existential dread we all face & the power of love.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Move over Nolan
Review:
This is the first time I'm writing a movie review. But look. This takes first place for my absolute favorite film. It's goofy, daring, moving, thoughtful, thrilling, mindbending and it all works so well. It makes light of the dark and dark of the night and climax so good you'll have to change pants.

There are moments where you're like "I cant believe this is happening in a movie" yet it makes sense and os such a memorable theatre experience.

I might go bankrupt buying tickets to see this daily.

Title: The moment you realize
Review:
Exceptional movie that turns a common potential troubling issue into a visual feast of both exclusion, inclusion and diversity and singularity within the stranglehold of monotony and chaos. Where even stereotypes and racism are touched and erased. When you pass all multiverse that are concerned with fundamental issue of life. In all its forms.

Nothing has been taboe in this highly entertaining whirlwind of visual excellence.

Original in many aspects of cinematic storytelling

Could we have experienced the upper layer on a simpler way? Yes ofcourse. But that would not have original nor does that do justice to what most people feel in these situations. Fact and the matter is that most dealing with issues and inner conflict with a rollercoaster of emotions and a storm of thoughts.

This film does justice to these periods and in this way all what you weirdly feels very relatable.

In short: Everything everywhere all at once A 9 from me.

Title: So many questions and no answers, but that's OK
Review:
We don't know the rules that the world in this movie operates. As information and scenes are presented, it clarifies and confuses us all at the same time. Is the movie playing by its own rules or is it being sloppy? Even if you pay attention, you won't be able to tell. But maybe that's the point.

If you were to ask: What is this movie about? I could give a pretty long list. It's about love, family, suicide, life, pain, confusion, the meaning of life, anger, happiness, kindness, being OK with imperfection (see title).

Relatively early on, we hear the phrase "Nothing matters" and we feel how true that is. Then, the movie tries to convince us otherwise. Successfully? I don't know. But it makes us feel that in this one moment in this character's life, some things matter even if in the infinite span of the universe it may not.

I feel that I should not be rating this movie, but instead giving it a N/A rating. It's not perfect, it can't be, but it does make the viewer emotional and think. I've watched a ton of movies in the last couple of months/years and my first reaction is to point out all the things wrong with them. But with this one, I feel like that's not what it's about. But I'm not sure I can answer what it's about in a way that gets to it's essence (see title, "everything"). But let me give it a desperate attempt.

Life is hard. You're not perfect. Don't give up.

Title: Beware the Bagal!
Review:
I thoroughly enjoyed the film but it might not be everyone's cup of tea. If you come in from a night out that included alcohol, leave this film until another time!

Seeing a Jamie Lee Curtis as the Tax Inspector, plus others, was shock. Well the whole film was a shock.

I summed up the film at the end, with that was weird - but I liked it!

Some funny bits in it, and some touching scenes too.

Title: Genius Movie With Deep Meanings
Review: This movie is genius in it's story telling and the very weird and confusing way it did it. Many dislike the way of how extremely weird it was but underneath all of that a deep emotional and realistic story is told based on the generational trauma of asian families. Many people can relate to the true experience of this film and the daughter's sad story. I believe you need to understand past the hot dog fingers and weird diverse realities in the multiverse to develop a love and understanding of the family's story and relationships. But you need to pay attention of the detail of each reality to also understand the mother's view on her life, just don't let the realities make you think this movie is very weird and "tries too hard to be unique". Everything in this movie is shown the way it is and happens the way it does for a reason and it all plays into the family's relationships, especially the mother and daughter. The movie can end up leaving you confused and wanting answers for the deeper meaning and so you will probably end up searching on the web and watching videos dissecting this movie, I did and I recommend it because it is nice learning more and more about the meaning and symbolism. If you don't enjoy being confused, weirded out, too many elements of a story all playing into one, and just a simple story line enjoyer then you probably shouldn't watch this movie-unless you want to change your view. I personally watched the movie twice, the first time I didn't cry, was left confused, over stimulated by the many things happening, weirded out, and mixed opinions. But, the second time I watched this movie I went in with a open mind, dissected everything that happened, interpreted many symbols, and paid great attention to the detail, then I ended up crying towards the ending as I finally understood the mother and daughter's relationship. Overall a very well made movie, beautiful and diverse cinematography and story telling, unique symbolism, and amazing acting. 9.5/10 I recommend to people with open minds and those who take every attention to detail seriously!

Title: Performances save the movie
Review:
I have about twenty minutes left of this movie and to be honest, I've been wanting it to end for about an hour or so. While I do applaud the filmmakers for creating such a unique world and overall, story...

A lot of the times, the film appears to try too hard; you know to be creative, different and overall, experimental. Sort of feels Oscar baity at times.

The action scenes are impressive and it is neat to see a bad*** female lead. The performances from Michelle and Jamie are STRONG. But I think Ke is the true scene stealer in this entire film! I enjoy his scenes the most; his performance is a great mix of comedy and drama.

I'm not surprised if this film scores a lot of Oscar nomins but in the end, a lot of moments are confusing and difficult to follow/

Title: Absolutely incredible
Review:
You have to see it to believe it. A movie of indescribable and incomprehensible brilliance in all the best possible ways. Stephanie Hsu and Michelle Yeoh give the performances of their career.
5 out of 12 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: Good not Great
Review:
I liked this movie. Really nice editing, production design, acting, creativity, costume design and cinematography. It was fun to watch and engaging. That being said, it was a little forgettable. Maybe it's because the story is too predictable, the lessons too cliched and the character arcs too overused. It comes down to discovering the importance of relationships through magic (in this case universe jumping). From It's a Wonderful Life to Turning Red, it's been done over and over. The bottom line is, this movie is cool looking, fun to watch and pretty funny while not leaving a lasting impression on the viewer. It's a good picture but far from the Best Picture.

Title: Either a 10 Star or a 1 Star Rating - No Middle Ground
Review:
IN A WORLD...where diversity and inclusion matter more than quality or even making sense, this is what rises to the top of the heap. Reviewers and award presenters are falling all over themselves slobbering over this movie. I tried to watch it when it first came out and it was just too silly and stupid to get through more than a few minutes. I tried harder this time, but I still couldn't make it to the end.

Everything Everywhere All at Once took 3:29 to introduce a lesbian scene. And then shortly after, the daughter mentions that her girlfriend can also serve to check off another box in the diversity bingo game we're all playing these days in TV and movies.

"She's half Mexican." She chimed in at the 5:50 mark. Why not give her one more inclusivity* attribute to win the trifecta? They could ring a bell to celebrate.

(*Ha, this recently-invented word, "inclusivity," is so new that it flagged the spell-check on this site).

I have nothing at all against inclusivity and diversity, just don't throw your arm out of the socket patting yourself on the back about it. All it took was a stroke of a pen, so you haven't really done anything. Why do cultural warriors always act like they've been down in the trenches fighting? Furthermore, diversity may lead to equality, something any thinking person favors, but diversity, in itself is not quality. You include representatives of every racial and ethnic group, along with every sexual persuasion on the planet and the movie can still be stupid. For me, this movie was unwatchably stupid.

Joyless people working themselves to death for no apparent reason. Are they starving to death? Why would anyone kill themselves over a laundromat, and evidently, they're stiffing the IRS on their taxes. Sorry, folks, that's part of our system.

The woman is either a terrible actress, or the director doesn't understand acting beyond a childish level of the art, or both. I defy anyone to watch this with the sound muted and just study her ridiculously-exaggerated facial expressions and then tell me she can act.

White lady bad. The tax woman is actually shown as evil, a grotesque slob who is attacked physically, but that's OK because she's a white lady. Wow, nice reverse stereotyping. You'd better be able to take a joke if you are Caucasian these days (wait, can I even say Caucasian?) because White people are awful according to the new rules. A bunch of IRS security guards are viciously brutalized, but that's OK, too, because they are white, or white-ish (even their uniforms are white for the subtlety-impaired).

Here's the thing, I CAN take a joke, I really can. I just don't have to laugh at them if they aren't funny, or if they don't make any sense at all, like everything in this film. The "alphaverse" and "verse jumping" that this movie throws at the audience could be described as infantile and stupid, at least by me, but a lot of folks are eating this up as fast as it can be shoved down their throats.

Furthermore, at 2h 19m it's way too long.

Title: Pure randomness. So good.
Review:
Only just streamed this last night after missing it at the movies.

Man, what a rollercoaster ride!

There isn't a whole lot it doesn't have: there's tonnes of action, drama, & comedy, all expertly blended together with fast-paced editing & mind altering visuals. So, so random but so very good as well. What a triumph!

There's so much going on in this movie that I'll have to re-watch it a few times to really appreciate all of the small details that were lovingly & painstakingly put into this.

I read somewhere that the movie was shot in just over a month, too, which is mind blowing in itself, given all the different sets, costume changes, re-shoots of same/similar sequences in completely different settings, etc...

The acting all around is great & the action is, likewise, amazing. Such a fun, seemingly chaotic but actually well thought-out storyline, but the editing really brings it all together. I'm glad the directors had a clear vision of what they were doing as I reckon the actors would have been pretty confused most of the way through it & probably only pretended they understood how it would all pan out, until all the madness was finally stitched together for the theatrical release.

Great movie. Go & see it.

Title: Excellent movie
Review:
I dont usually write reviews for movies but I felt i needed to after watch this gem. I am a very depressed and sad person who has a hard time see the good in life and the future. This movie made me realize that all of us need to open our minds and start to enjoy life and all we have. We as a human race need to start to come together and love one another again. We need to see what we have right in front of us and enjoy life because it will be over before you know it and we have wasted our whole lives worrying and complaining when we should have been doing what we love and bringing love to our whole. Please see this movie and take it to heart.

Title: Seconds of Time
Review:
Nothing Matters You've seen it all you've felt everything on the edge of nothingness but in this world there is someone or something for every one of us it will be there sooner or later.

Title: Genre bending masterpiece
Review:
EEAAO is the kind of movie you should watch in theaters. I watched it on the plane, what a shame! Even so, i was blown away by that experience and it's the best movie ever made in my opinion.

The beautiful Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan deliver like nobody's business. The acting in this movie in general is phenomenal! There's no such thing as a weak scene in it, every second is truly mesmerising. The film plays with your senses and draws you in completely.

The first half does a good job of explaining the characters and the multiverse, the second half is full of action and plot twists.

The score is this movie's only weakness. It's not bad, nothing about this movie is bad, it's just not very special in my opinion. But that doesn't really matter since you're so invested in the story and the visuals.

Get your popcorn and drink, sit back and relax and get ready for something fresh, heart touching and jaw dropping. This movie is a piece of art.

Title: Everyone everywhere will not agree
Review:
Plenty to froth about here. It's a movie you know for sure will have many mixed opinions. A cocktail of movie genres in one. Die hard action fans will love the action and scratch their heads on everything else. Comic fans will drool with a staring gaze until they choke on a hilarious scene. Romantics and those seeking emotion will find it here , just have to wait till the final 20 minutes or so . Personally, thoroughly enjoyed it. I would put it in my top 5 for 2022. I found some deep moments I related to and I'm sure at one point or another everyone will find a deep connection somewhere at least once as it touches on such a broad spectrum of life experiences.

Review:
If you love creativity and physics and action and a lot of visual stimulation, you will LOVE this movie. It's in my top 10 for originality (although, there are Fringe vibes) it's well done.

Title: Warped Time warp...and over overlong
Review:
Michelle Yeoh is a spectacular actress as seen in this film, knowing that nothing was done in one take, and her myriad of expressions and countless character shifts are truly unique. But this crazed film defies easy analysis. For a fantasy time-warp / character-switch-around, adventure-swirl, this one defies clarification. A 'fantasy', if this is one, must have a kernel of truth from which it moves, even 'Godzilla' or 'Back to the Future' or 'SpiderMan-No Way Home'...or...you-name-it. This one starts with taxes and failing business with a subplot idea of the daughter's live life. It ends with the daughter again...creating the question 'Why did we go through all of this in the first place?' Editing is mammoth with even rocks cascading down on the audience. It runs about eight (??) hours or seems to be even more!! You can try to play the game of 'What's it all about Alfie?' but I am one who just doesn't care. Just save Ms. Yeoh!

Title: Comedy? Action? Philosophical Discourse?
Review:
In my opinion, a truly great film manages to convey profound ideas and feelings to the audience under the guile of entertainment. It is rare to find a film that manages this balancing act as beautifully as Everything Everywhere All At Once.

The film tells the story of a middle-aged woman who is trying to save her business and her family from ruin when the responsibility to save the world from a terrible adversary is thrust upon her. The film makers embrace the absurdity of the premise in a singularly ingenious way. By all means, this is the story of an existential crisis on a cosmic scale, and it delivers an exhilarating resolution to the crisis.

Casting in this film is beyond perfect. Michelle Yeoh's protagonist feels real which is the highest praise I can muster and Stephanie Hsu matches her in every way. The cinematography in this film is surreal and trippy which goes with the territory of making a film about existentialism and the multiverse. The film jumps from fast paced action sequences to absurdly calming moments of quiet and calm all of which is made possible because of wonderful editing.

In conclusion, there are many reasons why this is a great film but I give it 10 stars because it left me with a deeper understanding of life and relationships. I will eagerly wait for the Daniels to come up with more absurd projects. They have made me a fan for life.

Title: Sycophantic Oscars. Entertaining at best.
Review:
This year the US sucks up to China with 7 Oscars!

That tells it all since this movie is entertaining at best and not Oscar material at all.

I came to watch this movie for Doctor-Strange-like 3rd eye, just to find out it's a fake eye, put on Michelle's forehead for no reason!

When I first saw the 3rd eye and the multiverse theme in the movie trailer, I was sure that I was going to watch a Doctor Strange parody comedy, not an Oscar movie.

The only moral of this movie is that "death is peace" - if you're too fed up with all the craziness, pain, evil in this world then death is the only way out. On the bright side, it means "to live is to struggle" - if you choose to live then there's no other way but to get used to the daily struggle and try to find happiness in everything. That's all.

Other than that, this movie is an average overplotted yet entertaining comedic tearjerker. Well done, Academy.

Title: Is It Just Me Or....
Review:
This film has been called a modern masterpiece, it has overwhelmingly positive reviews, it won 7 OSCARS. And the only thing I can say about this movie is that it was okay. I've seen a lot of reviews giving it a 1/10, which just isn't fair because there are some redeeming factors. The fights scenes were pretty cool, the visuals are interesting (nothing outstanding), and the acting is decent, but no Oscar-winning performances in my opinion.

What makes this movie a disappointment for me was that I was left bored and emotionless. I couldn't take this movie and its characters serious. It's just so goofy and weird and then it tries to go all serious at the end. Maybe it's not for me, because it's definitely a film not for everyone.

This movie was just a disappointment for me. For a movie to be called a masterpiece, for it to win 7 Oscars, it has to be perfect or at least close to perfect. But the plot was boring and it held no tension. It's goofy tone removed all the seriousness at the end. Everything Everywhere All at Once was average, and it's definitely a movie not worth 7 Oscars.

Title: Very very very Random, Weird, Funny and Wholesome Film
Review:
The first part of the film is fast paced, very random and weird. But in the second part, events took an unexpected turn. The film suddenly makes you question your purpose on life. You realize that the universe is immensely vast and nothing matters. Then the film strikes the final blow and your heart is filled with emotions.

Easily one of the best films I have ever watched. The creators were very successful in reflecting the soul of 2020s. This film is like a full feature film version of the popular videos titled "Never let them know your next move".

Quirkiness of this film may not be for everyone, but I think everyone must watch this film. 10/10.

Title: A self aware crazy film that you can appreciate
Review:
To state the obvious. This is a crazy movie. It's over the top. It's extremely convoluted. It's a complete mess. But that's what the filmmaker was going for. And while I think a lot of the movie is enjoyable, I find you become numb to a lot of the action quicker than the creators would have liked. Nonetheless this movie has all my respect because of just how crazy and original it is, especially in a industry that loves to churn out safe, formulaic movies. This movie is not perfect by any means, but it's a jolly fun time that is worth a watch. Just don't expect to understand most of what's going on.

Title: MICHELLE YEOH'S BEST PERFORMANCE
Review:
I must say out of all Michelle Yeoh's films that I have watched, this was her best portrayal to date. Not only did she embody a desperate protagonist very effectively, she also made it her own and very unforgettable. The style of direction and writing was not exactly my cup of tea but it was definitely interesting to watch. It was not only Michelle Yeoh that highlighted the story, it was also the supporting characters. This film was definitely one the year's bests.

Title: 7/11 Oscars!
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once:

After winning 7 oscars, I'm pretty sure its time I watch this. When an interdimensional rupture unravels reality, an unlikely hero, Evelyn, must channel her newfound powers to fight bizarre and bewildering dangers from the multiverse as the fate of the world hangs in the balance.

I really don't know why it took me too long to watch this, and I really regret it. Just like the title says, you het everything in this movie. The comedy, the action, the visuals, the acting, and many more, all with a budget of around 25 million dollars (compared to the 200 million for Thor: Love and Thunder). The movies script was so creative. The way the explored the multiverse and jumping through those multiverse was just amazing. The movie was also very fun to watch with all the fight scenes, the really good comedy, and the amazing effects. The Daniels (the directors of the movie) bring everything together in such a nice way and in everysingle frame.

The cast was superb. This is Michelle Yeoh's first big leading role, and she totally crushed it. Her acting was perfect and she felt like she was one with the character especially that she does all her stunts. So glad she won the Oscar, she really deserved it. I really liked Ke Huy Quan's (who plays Waymond, Evelyn's husband) performance, and he also won an Oscar for this role. Jamie Lee Curtis' character was really funny too but I don't think her performance was really Oscar worthy.

My only problem with this movie was that it could've been a bit shorter, but other than that, the movie was so fun and entertaining.

Score:9/10.

Title: Changing sense of DEI of the Academy
Review: The Academy Award 2023 was filled with the momentum of "Everything Everywhere all at onece". Not just the best leading and supporting actor and actress, but also the best director and the best film were dominated by this film. Over the past several years when the US film academy was criticized and accused of lacking sense of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion, the academy continued effort to sit along with DEI. They suddenly appreciated Korean film "Parasite" and to my surprice, they began to value colored actors and actresses. As for "Everything Everywhere all at once", I think that they got too conscious about DEI to evaluate the genuine value of film itself. Many of critics said that "Everything Everywhere all at once" is something tough to figure out what it should say, because of its environment surrounded with multi-universe, which is the concept normally dealt in state of the art physics being really arcane to understand for normal spectators. As in the vision and creed of US film academy, comprehensibility of film might have been stated, "Everything Everywhere all at once" was sort of way-out. Even if the DEI shoud be weighed in, it looks apt to be out of fair valuation. How deep do you think the academy weigh in CEI for fair valuation of performances and contents?

Title: Hilarious, Emotional Chaos
Review:
Absurd and chaotic, Everything Everywhere All at Once brilliantly combines insane comedy with brutal emotion and philosophical discovery.

It doesn't start off brilliantly though, as when at its most sane the plot is difficult to follow. The switching between languages, rushed speech and lack of audio clarity can make the dialogue very difficult to understand. It's very frustrating trying to keep up with the story and this continues in the early multiverse introduction. Only later do you appreciate that none of this particularly matters, the entire plot is impossible so enjoying the mania at face value is probably enough.

A synopsis cannot truly cover the ongoing across three acts, each scene progressively more zaney and inventive. Jumping between universes, scenes can be hilarious and immediately followed up by something deep and cutting. They all add something to the film, keeping it unpredictability and enjoyable throughout.

The visuals cover everything needed without going overboard on special effects, and props and costuming deliver on every occasion. The cast is superb, the largely Asian-American roster switching between personas excellently, and wonderfully supplemented by Curtis.

Not even the most famous 'Multiverse' film to be released in May 2022, but certainly the most unique and undeniably entertaining.

Title: Gimmick
Review:
At first, that movie seems entertaining to look at, but it is a one-trick pony with not much substance. It is like talking about an idea over and over again with no outcome.

The actors do well, outfitting, film equipping and stage managing also do but well...but it goes on and on and on and on, nice idea here, funny gag there and then it ends.

And It leaves me with the feeling of betray. I expected it to be much more deep, I felt even entitled to get more out of this while watching.

This movie is pretentious but in the same time it is still likable.

Maybe, I'm just not able to vibe with the hype: Solid 6 out of 10.

Title: A Top Oscar Contender
Review:
A24 has produced some of my favorite films, The Lighthouse, Moonlight, and Uncut Gems, to name a few. This year, in particular, has been great for the studio. Films like X, Aftersun, and the Whale make up your competition for award season. Then there's this film. The trailers looked interesting, but I skipped it when it came out. When they announced the nominees for the Golden Globes, I decided I should give this film a watch.

This film has a perfect cast. I know that might sound a bit of an exaggeration, but it's true. Michelle Yeoh is great as Evelyn. It's a protagonist that you want to root for. Yeoh deserved her golden globe win, but I believe she deserves an Oscar nomination. Yeoh's not the only cast member that deserves all the awards this season. Ke Huy Quan plays the husband, Waymond, and I loved the character from the get-go. Waymond in the home universe is an interesting character, but it Alpha-Waymond who steals the show. Huy Quan's versatility allows him to go from a loveable husband to a man trying to save the universe. When I first heard Huy Quan's voice, I thought, "Where have I heard this voice before." After a little investigation, I found my Data. No, actually, I found Data. Huy Quan is the Short Round from Indiana Jones and Data from the goonies. I love both characters and didn't even realize Huy Quan had retired over twenty years ago. I'm glad he came out of retirement because he should win an Oscar. Jamie Lee Curtis and Stephanie Hsu also deliver solid performances worthy of Oscar nominations. The film appears all over the place, and that's what makes it so wonderful. You never know where things are going; you're always guessing and trying to figure it out. I hope this film wins all the Oscars it's nominated for; it's that good.

10/10 One of the finest films released during 2022.

Title: A Combo of Great Movie Concepts Put Into One!!
Review: Everything Everywhere All at Once is everything that you have liked about sci-if movies for over the past 24 years done in a semi-realistic style! Starting with 1999's the Matrix, EEAAO as I will call Everything Everywhere All at Once for short for the purposes of this review, borrows greatly from some of the kung-fu fighting scenes that we saw in the Matrix! Now I know what you're thinking, you're thinking "MIke, there's been kung-fu in many other movies especially Bruce Lee movies of decades earlier." While that is true no film re-introduced kung-fu and other styles of Asian fighting like the trio of Matrix films did around the turn of the 2000's. EEAAO re-introduces kung-fu and other innovative fighting styles. I should point out that there is A LOT of fighting in EEAAO, you can see how Michelle Yeoh (Tomorrow Never Dies) won the Academy Award for best leading actress for all of the physical work she had to do in addition to her outstanding acting! The same compliment goes for this year's Academy Award winner for best supporting actor in Ke Huy Quan, once again outstanding physical acting for the fight scenes that he was in plus the emotional acting that he poured out on the silver screen. Ke Huy Quan (Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom) is a very versatile actor and I expect more from him in the years to come! Now to this great meta verse they discuss and experience at length in the movie. No doubts the Academy Award winning directors of the film Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert - two still very young men on the rise in the industry - have been influenced by the Avengers movies that came out not too long ago. As far as I know those were the first movies that really introduced main stream culture to a meta verse, a galaxy of multiple universes similar to this one happening now simultaneously with other universes that had small variations or something similar to it. With these meta verses jumping around throughout the movie they only intensify the action and significance of the relationships between the characters. You could tell that Jamie Lee Curtis had a lot of fun playing IRS agent Deirdre Beaubeidre so much so that she earned the Academy Award for best supporting actress for her work. All in all, EEAAO is a very dense movie but it is a lot of fun! Good directing, good writing, GREAT acting, good action, decent special effects, good humor, and a great sense of fun make this a great movie!! 8 out of 10 stars!!

Title: Go see this movie!
Review:
It's Scott Pilgrim meets The Matrix, with a dash of Konty Python thrown in just for fun. But it's also a meditation on family and finding your place in the world, AND it's a feel good movie on top of that, meaning that you'll want to call your Mom and tell her you love her.

I wanted to watch it again as soon as it ended.

Title: Wonderful Madness
Review:
Michelle Yeoh is one of my favourite actors. She's one of those rare gems who seems to care for the role she's playing and seeks out the unusual. She kinda reminds me of John Hurt in that regards.

As such I was looking forward to seeing this. I missed it at the theatres (curse you covid) so had to make do with renting on a streaming service.

I was not disappointed. Everything Everywhere All at Once is a fantastic film. One of the best I've seen in a long time. And it's so nice to come across something this isn't just some franchise mass produced, money grab content. I love my weird and wild adventures. This gives me hope that cinema isn't dead.

Probably my only complaint (and that might be because I've been mildly depressed for so many years now that I don't actually feel anything anymore) is that I felt there was too much focus on side concepts at times. I just feel like some ideas were awesome to begin with, but wore out their welcome after a while. And that if the film was a little tighter it would've popped more. As is, it's still fantastic and I will definitely add it to my DVD collection (yes I still buy DVDs/Blurays but they're reserved for my favourites)

Title: Everything Everywhere.. thrown in one big bowl and try to eat that soup
Review:
Too much of everything. I couldn't take this movie not even as an improvise, parody, rehearsal, nothing. It had too many ideas and chaos that weren't really making sense. Too overrated for me. I liked some of the moves, but it wasn't enough. This seemed like a big budget Netflix movie, put them in one place and see what happens. I'm sorry, but this is a no for me.

Title: Nothing short of amazing
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once, the latest offering from A24, is set to go down as one the most innovative, heartfelt, and nonsensical movies of the year. Starring Michelle Yeoh, the film follows Evelyn Wang, a woman who learns she has the power to exist in parallel universes tasked with stopping the person trying to destroy them all. Evelyn is feeling an increasing amount of pressure as she preps the paperwork for her and her husband's dry cleaning business to go through an audit while also prepping for a Chinese New Year party as well as dealing with her distant daughter. When an alternate version of Waymond appears to tell her the multiverse in trouble and she's the only one who can save it all, Evelyn is swept up in events beyond her control as she finds a way to save everything, everywhere, all at once.

While the premise may sound outlandish (because it is), at the heart of the movie is the generational trauma and interpersonal drama between the Wang family. Evelyn's rejection of her daughter's modern sensibilities, her ever-growing distance from her husband, a looming threat of suicide, and the baggage of any number of past decisions haunt the film from the first frame to the final one. All this is balanced deftly with the sci-fi elements of dimension hopping and universe-spanning adventures. The best science fiction is that which uses the genre trappings to tell a human story and directors Kwan and Scheinert have managed to weave a story that is exactly that. Is the science part of the movie a bit wonky and hand-wavy? Absolutely. But using it to tell the tale of a family on the verge of shattering that is funny, shocking, emotional, and impactful while also finding clever ways to pay homage to classic movies like 2001 and In the Mood for Love makes Everything Everywhere one of the year's best movies.

Michelle Yeoh finally found a vehicle where she could let her talents fly, and fly they do. Without a doubt, Everything Everywhere is firmly her film; all the elements and themes flow through Evelyn Wang and directors Kwan and Scheinert have given her avenues to show both her comedic and dramatic chops. While we've seen these before (think Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon or her role on Star Trek: Discovery), it's rare we get to see such a substantial amount of both at the same time. Her martial arts acumen is well documented; seeing that combined with the dizzying array of other gifts she presents here reminds us that Yeoh has been a consummate performer for three decades and while there isn't a weak link in the acting in this film, no one else is holding a candle to her.

Stephanie Hsu comes pretty close, however. While Yeoh is the film's main focus, Hsu's Joy is handling a lot of the subtle work throughout the film. In a movie that can only be described as ostentatious, Hsu's muted performance makes Joy one of the standout characters. Carrying the brunt of the film's anguish, Hsu is marvelous as she traverses through makeup and costumes as both Joy and the antagonist Jobu Tupaki, the person willing to burn it all down. Hsu and Yeoh's chemistry is electric as the two play off each other, ending in an aching moment of emotional catharsis that is equal parts relief and revelatory. Yeoh and Hsu sell these final moments, the crux of the entire movie, and thanks to their performances, the film rockets from good to great.

Ke Huy Quan, better known to some as Data from the Goonies or Short Round from Indiana Jones, has less to do in the movie than Yeoh or Hsu but is no less important. A main part of the cause of the breaking family that is the Wangs, Quan's Waymond is the paragon of hope and optimism. Contrasted to Evelyn's depressed where-did-it-all-go-wrong mentality, Waymond's ebullience is both infectious and nauseating. While both Evelyn and Joy get multiple opportunities to shine, Waymond gets one great scene with Eveyln towards the end of the film that makes his character's entire trajectory worthwhile. Jamie Lee Curtis appears throughout the film as well as Deirdre, the IRS inspector set to take all that the Wangs hold dear. As a constant antagonist through the film, Curtis is great in her I-could-really-give-a-shit demeanor as a woman who's just doing her job, albeit at the expense of the Wang's livelihood. While the Wangs are the centerpiece of the movie, Curtis manages to compliment them in every scene she's in. James Hong, in less scenes than Curtis, is a delight to see as always as Evelyn's dad and brings a sorely needed gravitas to his scenes that are necessary to keeping the movie anchored.

Directed by The Daniels (Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert), Everything Everywhere is a follow up to their equally inventive Swiss Army Man. Whereas Swiss Army Man presents a more surrealist type of story, Everything Everywhere pushes the envelope even father in terms of inventiveness and creativeness. The main strength of the film, and in The Daniels' storytelling, is the focus on the main issue: a dysfunctional family. Regardless of every bit of nonsense the directors throw at the audience, from our characters portrayed as rocks to a world where everyone has hot dogs for fingers, the story always reverts back to the Wang family and their interconnected struggles. Technically, Everything Everywhere is a masterpiece, managing to consistently shift through genres without losing sight of the objective. Be it the brilliant makeup Hsu's Joy is decked out in or her outlandish costume designs, the level of detail that went into creating the film reveals how well thought out and meticulous The Daniels and their crew are.

Overall, Everything Everywhere All at Once will go down as one of the most impressive displays of creativity and imagination on screen. Daniels Kwan and Scheinert's ability to pull off a zany, darkly comedic sci-fi movie while interweaving a poignant family drama is nothing short of amazing. By far Michelle Yeoh's best role to date (as well as Stephanie Hsu's), Everything Everywhere shines a dazzling spotlight on the actress' myriad talents and specialties. An outrageously inventive premise, combined with strong acting and brilliant direction makes this a phones down, all senses dialed in must watch immediately.

Title: A contradiction of a movie
Review:
Bear in mind I normally hate sci fi......

It more than passed the 6 (or 10) laugh test. I kinda loved it at times and at other times I was bored. Crappy but great. Deep but shallow. Ridiculously stupid but genius. Mind numbing but thought provoking. A contradiction of a film. I kinda hated it and kinda loved it. The best sci-fi movie I've seen for years. 7 out of ten.

One of the best movies I'd the year.

It's like a Looney tunes cartoon mashed with Crank on drugs. Darkly funny, great performances by a cast who look like they're having a blast.

Title: Thank God for something fresh
Review:
Inventive. Unique. Creative. Bold.

Also over the top. Repetitive. Bloated. Silly.

Hard to tell at times whether it's a work of pure genius or genre blending abursdity.

It's neither. It's a mix of both. Mostly on the smart side. And it's mostly fun.

Definitely different which in today's safe cinematic world of proven brands in the way of endless sequels, spinoffs, reboots and remakes is an absolute godsend. It deserves an Academy award for Originality.

Sadly the Oscar's are now only about virtue posturing and not quality filmmaking.

One thing is for certain, any film over 2 hours better have a damn good reason for doing so. This type of film would be far better served being under that benchmark.

The first hour particularly, is quite repetitive and would have made a much better and more enjoyable experience if it were more concise. The second half works much better but still it is over long and ultimately damages the film as a whole.

Still very enjoyable and quite funny. It just doesn't always hit the mark and can be tiring at times. In others, it really is impressive.

Great acting chops for all the leads. Jamie Lee Curtis was a riot. Great to see Short Round back too. His character actually had a lot of charisma and it's a real shame he hasn't been on screen as much in recent decades as he really lights it up every time he opens his mouth.

Kudos to the filmmakers. I especially love the rocks sequence. Better performances than most Hollywood tossers.

Title: Criminally Overrated
Review:
I watched this movie, based on the hype surrounding it, expecting something nothing short of a blockbuster. This movie is filled with lame characters, muddled storyline, and nauseating directing from someone borrowing heavily from other well known (and competent) directors. Michelle Yeoh had a decent performance with whatever it was she was trying to portray, everyone else seemed like a blur in a sea of garbage throughout the movies 2 hour 19 min run time. Some commenter put "don't do drugs, watch this movie instead." Id have to say that's probably the most cringiest comment of 2022 on this dumpster fire of a movie. 0/10.

Title: Crazy ride of Multiverse!
Review:
Everything Everywhere All At Once succeeds where even brand Marvel fails: the concept of Multiverse.

This requires a right level of ambition and high amount of craziness. A formula which Hollywood couldn't decode, until now.

The writer-director knows what they want and also knows what they want audience to experience, right from the first frame.

Be it the mundane life of the main character or John Wick-style martial arts.

Everyone in the movie is connected, so you don't feel even a second wasted.

I believe this is more than enough for you to give this movie a chance.

Sit back and enjoy the ride.

Title: Great
Review:
This is a movie that is hard to explain but not hard to understand. In my opinion, those are the best movies that give you spectacle but also make you feel something. Every actor in this deserves acknowledged for the hard work they did, right alongside the film makers themselves. The only sad thing about this film is that we will probably never get another movie like it. I will just ha c e to continue to watch it over and over again as it gets better with each view. You get to see things here that we have never seen on the big screen. Couple that with incredible story telling and it is a hit for sure.

Title: Hilarious. Honest. Heartfelt.
Review:
I'm convinced that anyone who is violently upset about this movie is incapable of paying attention, self reflecting, and having fun. Anyone who says it's "overhyped" must live a miserable existence, because this movie is truly a work of art.

It's smart, it's action-packed, it's dramatic, it's funny - and yes, even goofy at times. It's very rare that a film will make you cackle with laughter and cry - not because its content is devastating, but because the story itself is so beautiful, wild and relatable.

The whole cast has great comedic timing while also pulling at the heartstrings. Stephanie Hsu is simply phenomenal in her role; Michelle Yeoh provides a realistic and entertaining portrayal of a mother navigating her relationship with her daughter; Ke Huy Quan's delivery is always charming; Jamie Lee Curtis does great as a supporting actress - and special shout-out to costume designer Shirley Kurata for her incredible mind.

This movie touches on strained family dynamics, existentialism, queerness, absurdism, all wrapped up in an everything bagel. I've introduced it to different friends many times since it came out and everyone has loved it in some way or another.

So if you're one of the few who just "don't get it", maybe keep it to yourself and stick to your predictable Marvel movies.

Title: Just wow
Review:
This movie is a masterpiece. Layered, funny, complex script performed by an amazing cast. The costumes, effects and comedy were fantastic. I was so incredibly satisfied at the end. Please see it, and take someone you love.

All in all I don't think I'm going to be recommending it, there were a couple of times I thought I was gonna turn it off out of boredom.

Title: Great ... to a point.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: This film is *INCREDIBLE.*
Review:
I felt... all of the feelings.

All of them. Often at the same time (or at least in varying combinations).

This film deserves to win Best Picture and Michelle Yeoh deserves an Oscar (which she's not gonna get...)

...but we can imagine the universe where she does. And that universe, like this film, is beyond lovely.

Title: Bagel, hotdog fingers whatever all at once.
Review:
A Chinese immigrant discovered the possibility of connecting with other universes and use her abilities in these universes to save the world as her "alpha univers" husband claims to be the chosen one for this mission .

This film is an example of how good reviews and high expectations can ruin the experience.

For me this film is adopting a new idea and create a big mess, the multiverse principles in this movie are very interesting very creative to be honest but the execution is messy in a weird way.

I'm still asking myself what is special about it, and the only answer is the directing, a decent cinematography, colors and costume designs...every frame was visually stunning.

Turning those creepy ideas into an actual film isn't that easy, that's why I'm appreciating the technical stuff and their efforts.

But, it can't be enough, it's other missed opportunity about the multiverse.

Title: Comparing to PARASITE, yes this movie is indeed overly hyped and rated
Review:
People usually say, "overhyped" or "overrated" if a movie doesn't live up to a fame. Sometimes it's agreeable, but oftentimes it's hard to agree with them because many claims with baseless information like the one with Titanic. How many people can really agree with someone saying "Titanic is overrated"? Well, today I'll make a point of why Everything Everywhere All at Once is overrated with a nutshell information by comparing with the move, Parasite. When Parasite was getting popular in US, I was thinking, "it's probably because it's leveraged by a social trend". However, "Boy, was I wrong" that's what I said right after watching the movie. I could understand why it gained so much popularity. The movie is well scripted and well directed, but most of all, it's a movie that nobody has ever seen before which is probably why the movie received a big applauds and awards at Cannes and others. It's understandable completely that Parasite is definitely not overrated. However, in case of Everything Everywhere All at Once, it's also well scripted and well directed, but the plot and EVERYTHING in this movie is something I've seen in many movies and TV shows over and over especially with multiverse and the family dynamics. There's ZERO wonder why it didn't get any attention from Cannes, and the movie is basically unknown in other countries except US. The movie's fame is only leveraged by the social trend only in US. I can expect this movie will grab a lot of Oscars, and also can expect this movie will easily be forgotten unlike Parasite.

*Keep in mind that I'm not a diehard fan of Parasite. I do like the movie, but I'm only using it because it makes a good comparison with Everything Everywhere All at Once especially with Cannes award.

Title: Stunning
Review:
A breath of fresh air and an incredibly accomplished film. Like watching the Matrix for the first time. Can't wait to see what this team do next. Highly recommended.

Title: Stop asking "What If"
Review:
I've never left a theatre so desperate to rewatch something as I did with Everything Everywhere All at Once. From the very first scene, right the way through to the end - Everything Everywhere All at Once is an assault on the senses in all the best ways. It's quite hard to know where to begin; after all, this is a movie about everything, everywhere, all at once.

Let's start with the story; this is a movie about Evelyn, and the relationships she has with her husband, her daughter, her father, and most importantly - herself. You see; Evelyn is a woman constantly asking "what if...". What if she'd been a doctor? Or not moved to the USA? What if she'd been more than she is? I guess this doesn't really explain the story at all, but I don't really want to spoil the magic for you. This is a movie about Evelyn, and how she finally learns to love the life she has. Of course, this is a significant oversimplification.

Moving on; this movie is a visual treat. The visual effects range from the fantastic to the basic. There's everything from well-choreographed fight scenes (including a very memorable fight where the weapon of choice is a fanny pack), right the way through to a hilariously under-puppeted raccoon. The jarring contrast between the hyperreal and the clearly-fake could've come across as crude, if not unprofessional in any other film. Here, though, it's a well-executed mishmash that works because it's part of a larger collage of pictures equally out of place.

I think the other think that helps meld these two disparate styles together is the fact that, beneath it all, Everything Everywhere All at Once is a comedy film. It's easy to focus on the more sentimental aspects of the movie, especially given the main theme of "acceptance", but it'd be a genuine disservice not to acknowledge the movie as a comedy. From malapropisms, to Michelle Yeohs' excellent delivery - this movie is one of those laugh-a-minute types that never quite gets old. Leaning heavily into the absurd, you can never quite anticipate what might come next. Clearly, absurdist humour isn't for everyone, and there'll be more than a few people who come away from it with a bitter taste in their mouth. However, in my opinion, Everything Everywhere All at Once does a fantastic job of delivering risqu√© jokes without ever delving quite into pure vulgarity. It is, of course, this same absurdity that manages to carry some of the films more tender moments. On paper, two rocks conversing mightn't be the most riveting of ideas; but Everything Everywhere All at Once manages to sell this concept with gusto - to the point where the theatre I was in was loud with laughter most at this point in the movie. Indeed, this is the kind of movie that has you connecting emotionally with two rocks. This, though, isn't the most absurd moment in the film, but to delve too much further would do nothing but dip into spoilers. All I can say is; this doesn't feel like absurdity for absurdities sake. A lot of the time, absurdist comedy can come off very - "hAhA iM SO random RAWR xD". Here, though, it feels much more in service of the point the film was trying to drive home.

Ultimately, I really could sit here and praise this film for hours.

I guess if I had to criticise any aspect, it'd be the world building, which felt a little thin at times, but once I stopped questioning things, and simply watched it for what it was; I found those complaints dissipate. If you watch Everything Everywhere All at Once with an open mind; you can't go wrong. I can't wait to see it again, and you bet I'll be buying the blu-ray the moment it's on sale.

10/10.

Title: Interesting story
Review:
I was drawn into the story at soon as the movie start. It does take you on a crazy ride but the message is simply the love between a mother and her daughter and it seems to be a metaphor to represent it.

The cinematography was very well done as well as the acting.

I saw it in a regular cinema and was very bothered by the switch of aspect ration from 1.35 to 2.39.

It's like watching a trailer for almost two hours.

Similar to what Christopher Nolan did with the dark night.

Title: A well orchestrated mess
Review:
Interesting: so many 1 and 10-star reviews... but it's not perfect or terrible imo. The great part is the production, which is interesting but waaaaay too fast for old people. It's a good story, but oddly "king fu scifi" which is a bit of a turnoff for me (as a scifi lover) and for people who would enjoy the movie more without the fighting, which didn't seem like a natural fit for the plot. But it's Michelle Yeoh so...

Not much needs to be said with all these reviews digging in to details- I'll just add that the reasons people gave it 1 star seemed to have a personal problem with it, especially its style and ideas coming from the Matrix and other movies. Yes, so it's not a completely unique or original story, but that doesn't make it bad. That's just kind of how storytelling works : )

Title: Still processing the fact that I have a new favourite film
Review:
If you're like me, you maybe have had a handful of favourite movies in your life, and you hold them tight and close like little personal treasures. It can be hard to demote a film to "second favourite," especially if it's held the #1 spot for some time, but every so often you see something that challenges for that title. I seriously doubt that I'm the only one who has found a new favourite movie after this experience.

I do very much mean experience, too. EEAAO will have you laughing, crying, and laughing again on repeat for more than two hours. Every genre imaginable fits perfectly and purposefully into the film, and you never feel like the plot has left you behind. The story pulled me through from start to finish as light speed and left me feeling a mix of sonder and joy.

As a clear early front runner for next year's Best Picture (sorry, Dune 2), this movie will make you feel something, everything, everywhere, all at once. Go with a friend, go by yourself, go as many times as you damn well please because nothing matters. Just see this movie.

Title: Kung Fu is in everything, even Cookies
Review:
I saw this Sci-Fi Kung-Fu Comedy last night and enjoyed it.

The humour is a quite deadpan but I laughed out loud a few times.

Its well made, well acted, visually very interesting and fun to watch. This is certainly not a huge budget blockbuster. It sits more within a decent budget indie film.

The Chinese elements of the film ring true in terms of family and tradition and it would seem the idea was to give it all a bit of s slap around the chops. ( With a dildo ?.)

Some of the ideas used are truly absurd and silly which may be too much for certain audiences whereas others will revel in them.

I was somewhere poised in the middle thinking " well thats new ".

There are however deeper meanings to the movie to ponder and the issues sit real and are presented with integrity even if they are not world changing ideologies they are certainly relatable.

The science presented in this film is not to be taken seriously so try not to take it as so.

Overall this was a fun and enjoyable Chinese centric romp about family choices and destiny.

Title: All these ridiculous Low raters lol
Review:
If you check all the 1 Ratings reviewers at least 75% of them has only reviewed 1-2 things ever, kinda makes u suspicious if its the same person lol Anyone to rate this below a 5 is insane and has no idea how to rate movies/shows.

Rating a 1-5 is like those D Lister movies with poor filming crews n terrible camera quality and middle school style CGI.

The lowest you should ever be able to rate a movie of this video quality, acting quality , creativity, CGI quality should be a 6 .

If people rate this a 1-5 then what they rating movies like Anaconda sequels ? Or any Mockbuster movies thats a low budget version of a big name production movie ?

This Movie was kinda confusing here and there but when you reach the end it kinda hit me that this movie can be a metaphor for multiple things related too Real Life and a very good one. It was well directed with amazing Marvel movies style CGI quality and great acting with some nice fight scenes. It might seem very random of things occurring as you watch this movie but everything connects in the end and the creativity was amazing.

Title: I Need to Marinate on This One...
Review:
I wanted to like the movie a tiny bit more than I did. I do think it was a bit long, little hallmark-y with certain elements. The amount of work this movie called for is absolutely almost unfathomable.

A lot to think about here. I definitely loved how surprised I constantly was, I think everything was incredibly polished: from music to choreography.

Here is the moral of the story: I certainly wouldn't mind to seeing a bit more of this originality in media, no matter your thoughts on the movie, this project was a labor of love.

I'm a bit surprised that the weirdness factor was cranked waay up and for this to get pretty widespread acclaim.

Let's keep this originality and high level of polish with future films, I would tune in.

Title: Masterpiece!
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: The best movie ever made
Review:
I don't even know what you could possibly take issue with in this film. It is the greatest of all time. Go in blind and let it happen.

Also I am gay for Stephanie Hsu.

Title: Our collective imagination in a movie - hilarious, action back and beautifully told
Review:
From start to finish this was nothing short but a modern day masterpiece, albeit very silly kind of humor that may not appeal to everyone or not be your thang depending on how you are feeling on the day. For me though, this movie had everything. Fast paced, intellectual, creatively shot, intricate story line with excellently choreographed action scenes and witty very very funny throughout. The best thing was that the story line all hangs together and comes together beautifully to bring an overall much deeper meaning to the entire premise of the movie. It's about human nature, life itself, what makes us who we are - our collective curiosity, magnificence, darkness, all rolled into one. It's a feel good movie that makes you want to see the bigger picture and not sweat the small stuff anymore. This movie will be watched again and stick with me for a long time. I'll always be trying to imagine what in the universe is install for all of us next ! Go watch this !

Title: In 30 years the humanity moved from "nothing else matters" to "nothing matters"
Review:
The movie is in its own cathegory, therefore no rating should apply. Compare it with classical movies, it is nothing, gets a 1... Compare it with modern martial arts movies, it is brilliantly reverting to martial arts essence and gets an 8... Compare it with revolutionary Sci Fi franchises, like The Matrix, it is an upgraded version, that is and is not new in the same time - not sure what rating applies.

The thing is this movie is a bit of every of the above, and others more, therefore should probably be rewatched, and what glues it together and allows a possible rating would be the note that is most constant in the aftertaste, repeatedly, and its value within that cathegory, if it is not one completely devoid of competition. The producers have however mentioned Rick and Morty, and there are other movies concerning multiverses, or game universes, so maybe it is a cathegory in the making, being populated as we speak.

What can I say, without rewatching?

*for the moment I do not know if I even want to rewatch it, the feeling can be described as sort of a brain hangover *it aims to help with some of the disaster felt by young generations, like giving instructions on how to deal with chaos better, because chaos itself ain't gonna be solved soon *it provides similar help for older generations that served as a bridge towards what is going on, although in the story, it was their fault for rushing things and in fact they are the ones who caused chaos and all the pressure the young have today *it feels more like a family centered drama, or a generations centered one, than a Sci Fi *could have skipped the sex-related elements, but I guess they are sending a message for all those who went to this extreme in their quest for meaning and purpose, or just for effing feeling something again in what they perceive as a world devoid of sensorial stimuli *brilliant reintroduction of martial arts, after the mess made by all the commercial movies depicting them - martial arts are NOT originally sports, but energy manipulation, triggering physical effects *lots of concepts from India and Asia mythology and spirituality, weirdly unexplained - I saw interviews where the movie team claims certain names, visuals and gestures are just gamified, jokes or creative randomness - why do they lie?! Mythological motifs of chaos and certain entities that rule it, or generate it, abund, and the movie's elements can be traced back to some of these. And it does not just happen, because they have details - the way Jobu steps aside her mother's head on the stairs, in closeup, is a reminder of how Kali stopped in her destruction after stepping with her right foot above her husband... but I am not completely familiar with these motifs to be able to understand exactly how they used them.. Just noticing they are in the movie, and not "by chance". Also the Indian movie playing on the screen, I would have to know what movie or story is that, to understand a bit... so, more things to find out. Maybe they claim randomness because the young would turn away from "we're repacked for your understanding some very very old things" - maybe... *someone here concluded that the message is "set aside what could have been, and just strive to be happy with what you have, even modest". I think not! There is a complicated explanation in the movie of why this Evelyn is the one needed to solve her daughter's entanglement with the chaos, and it is completely different. I am making an effort here, but by abandoning one dream after another, this Evelyn lives her "failure" version of a life with her eyes wide open, making herself available to see it all from the outside, being herself mobile in concepts and strong when it comes to aknowledge other versions exist. She is un-lodged in one type of life, non attached or less attached to a fixated truth, as her better more successful versions are, therefore open to seeing the possibilities and able to understand her daughter's story *the message IS an empowering one, although hard to pin down; what do you do when there is nothing stable, secure, predetemined and calming around? And it is a fact, beyond the bull*it of "you are just troubled because you have to change the way you think" psychanalytic mantra... what do you do when the world is bluntly going down the drain, as you used to know it? What do you hold on to? The movie wants to help with getting an answer, which could be, I imagine, understood by each viewer in its own way.

Title: the worst kind of good movie
Review:
Everything Everywhere All At Once is a family movie (not family in the prurient PG sense, but in that the movie is about family).

Creative, zany, brilliant in the 1st act. An hour-and-a-half of ridiculous, laughable, juvenile hi-jinks with solid philosophical backing. The last 45 minutes are a redundant bore.

The best movies are ones you can relish repeatedly, that improve with multiple viewings because of details that enrich the context, and you can appreciate how well the story hangs together (even when it might not seem so on the first viewing). The title Everything Everywhere All At Once fits the content, in that you get it all in a single viewing, and there's no reason to see it again.

Title: A movie worth a second rewatch
Review:
It is a great movie with great cast team. The story about a mother who struggling paying taxes in one of her multiverse. The term "multiverse" is one that is often associated with the genre of science fiction, where it denotes the existence of an infinite number of parallel universes, each one branching out from every decision we make. Whether we choose to enter into marriage or not, or embark on a journey to one country instead of another, each choice can lead to a myriad of diverse experiences and interactions with different people, ultimately resulting in the creation of a distinct universe. While every individual has their own unique multiverse, the ability to transition between these alternate realities remains elusive. The film in question depicts the emotional journey of a mother whose profound love for her daughter drives her to explore the latter's ability to move between multiple realities within her multiverse.

Title: What if "Rick & Morty" and "Matrix" had a child?
Review:
I didn't know anything about this movie at all, just found it and watched it, so I wasn't hyped at all.

Can't deny the visual work is very good, costumes, scenarios, special effects, etc. But it's excessively ridiculous, to the point it feels more like a long YouTube meme video but a movie.

Most ideas were already used in Rick & Morty, and the baseline of the movie is Matrix. The beginning of the movie was pretty interesting, but after 1 hour it became boring and repetitive.

It's been a long time since I felt this way watching a film and wanting it just to end. This is a perfect example of how a good idea can turn into a waste. I really wanted to like this film but unfortunately I felt frustrated, irritated, disgusted and bored all at once. I even made an account on this site to rate it lol

Of course it is worth to watch, there are really worst movies out there, but this is not what people are praising it to be. If you like this genre, just watch Rick & Morty, or even The Midnight Gospel.

Title: Randomness Weaves a Web Between This Movie and Us
Review:
Just to get this down somewhere so others who have seen the movie will understand... The morning before we saw this movie was the Saturday before Easter. Our girls, both about the age of the daughter in the movie, were decorating Easter eggs. One of them got the idea to put GOOGLIE EYES on some of them. Earlier in the day, I was filing an amended TAX RETURN, while my wife was doing a lot of LAUNDRY, mostly for our youngest, who came home from college for the Easter holiday. For breakfast, my wife offered our youngest a BAGEL, but she opted for something else.

We then saw the movie not realizing in advance any connection to it and the above seemingly trivial events from earlier in the day. For those who saw the movie, I am sure you can see the connection....and it has us amazed. Yes, apparent random events in our lives can, by coincidence, also show up in movies we see.....but for this movie?...given its objective and that our trivial events happened within our family? Something is going on here! (I changed my rating from a 9 to a 10 because of this insight---see yeah, it's a 10 for me purely for personal reasons given the course of events that led up to seeing the movie)

If randomness *weaves* a web of events, is anything truly random?

For the movie itself, one reviewer elsewhere suggested you 'strap in' and hang on. This movie is a wild ride successfully attempting to give significance to our own seemingly trivial lives if only for a few brief moments in this one particular universe. In the end...be kind.

Title: What's the hype for?
Review:
I mean seriously? What's the hype for? What are they winning awards for?

I so desperately tried to watch this movie with diligence, patience and an open mind. I so desperately wanted to love this movie. But it's sad that I didn't even like it.

Did I watch the same movie as everyone else? Because it's so hyped. Omg. I cannot believe it.

I went back to the movie and tried to see what others could. But I fail. The story is fine. The acting is fine. The costumes are amazing. The direction is below par and the editing ughh. So what was great about this movie guys? Please someone explain it to me.

Title: An unexpected masterpiece.
Review:
People who jokingly call cinema "Kino" often wait on releases by the likes of the Von Triers and Gaspar Noe of this world to be "wowed" by their next masterpiece, give it a 10, and go to wait again.

Rarely do a movie surprise you in a way that is so unexpected, so cleverly delivered and so beautifully written and directed that it immediately puts its creator on the maps of "those to watch" - Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheninert somehow captured lighting and delivered it in movie format, ignoring all conventions, mixing all genres, unhindered by convention.

While the movie is evidently not perfect (the lead 'villain' would probably have been better interpreted by the protagonist, and they know it), it's a masterpiece in its own right. What differentiates this movie from say, a movie like "the matrix" is that it's as profound as any, say, Dogme 95 film while keeping the fantastic imagery top notch throughout.

The movie reminded me so much of "mother!" by Aronofsky, it had some big shoes to fill indeed and filled them very well. Outside a few "oh-hum" over the top vfx shot, EEAaO is powerful throughout its three chapter and paced to perfection.

Probably the best surprise of the year, and a must watch for ... anyone really. True to its title, the movie has something for everyone, everywhere.

Title: Messy, ridiculous, stupid and perfect???
Review:
Everything Everywhere All At Once, the perfect name for this crazy movie.

One of the most original things you'll see in your life.

Even if you don't want to go too deep into it's meaning you'll have a lot of fun.

The movie feels like a videogame, the first 20 minutes of the movie are some kind of tutorial, the rules are explained and once you get everything you'll flow with the action.

What a ride, you'll laugh and the ending if a bit predictable will still make you shed some tears.

Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.
