Title: Please watch it.
Review:
My 19-yr-old son insisted that I watch this. I had already started to, got about half an hour in and couldn't connect. It seemed a bit all over the place. But on his recommendation I gave it another go. And I'm so glad I did. I can't really explain the plot, I just know that it's one of the best films I've seen. I laughed (especially at Jamie Lee Curtis' character. I didn't recognise her at first. Brilliant.), I cried, I felt like I'd been through a spiritual experience. It's great. Just watch it. Even if you're not that bowled over, I can be pretty certain that it will resonate even if only in parts, and will stay in your mind.

Title: I'm noticing a strange trend...
Review:
It seems that many of the one star reviews of this film are coming out around the time this film got Oscar buzz and after it won best picture. Not to suggest that that is the case with every single review, but it just feels a little odd, doesn't it? Not only that but a lot of the criticism towards this film is centred around the Oscars that the film won. "The acting is garbage" or "the writing is nonsensical" and other similar phrases. Now I'm not saying that you need to love this film, but I am suggesting that people should give this film a fair chance to stand on its own rather than hating on it because it has reached the peak of mainstream film attention.

But how exactly do I feel about this film? I think it's wonderful! I saw this film before any announcements about the Oscar nominations and before I even began thinking about my Oscar picks, so just know my actual review portion of this review isn't just an over exaggeration of a 7/10 review to bump the score up but just my honest opinion.

The first time I saw it I thought it was great and absurd. After my second time watching it I understood more of what the film was saying. I've now seen the movie 4 times and it keeps getting better every time. Emotional performances from Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Kwan as well as the amazing writing from Daniels help to make them feel like real people. I can understand how a lot of the absurdist comedy might not be for everyone. Even the people I know who love this film have a few criticisms with its implementation, but in my opinion it suits the film very well and works with how the story is told and surprisingly doesn't feel unnecessarily forced. The film is just in general very funny and is also one of few movies where I get emotional every time I watch it.

The film is a heartfelt journey through love and family contained within an absurd LSD fueled trip through the universe. It might not be for everyone but I consider this one of my favourite films and definitely the best picture of 2022.

Title: Way too long
Review:
The biggest flaw of the movie is that it drags for so long becoming repetitive and always following the same narrative over and over. 1h45 would be ideal.

Title: Rick & Morty has nothing on this
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once could be described as a movie about relationships (mother-daughter, wife-husband, daughter-father), or it could be described as an attempt to find meaning in one's life against the struggles of existence. It could be described as an exploration of choices and whether we meet our potential, or it could be described as a look at the immigrant experience. It could even be described as an epic multiverse-traversing hero's quest against an evil force threatening to destroy reality.

This movie is incredibly energetic, with rarely lull in action or story. The most impressive thing about the film is how it's able to take on so much without getting repetitive or tiresome. It could have collapsed into the singularity of its own premise, or just gotten so silly that the sincere moments were lost, but instead we're left with an experience that's funny, sad, incisive, nonsensical, poignant, thrilling, provocative, and a whole lot more on this Everything Bagel of a film. This film has to be seen to be believed!

Title: There's a fine line between ambitiously bizarre and simply dopey
Review:
And this film sits perilously close to falling on the wrong side of that line.

First of all, Michelle Yeoh is worth every moment she is on screen. Easily the best part of the film, she is spectacular in every scene, with every motion, in every universe she inhabits. Truly a magnificent performance. Ke Huy Quan is also strong in a mostly meek, often comic, role. Beyond that, well, it's a lot of overwrought emotion and bad martial art set pieces. Not a particular fan of sci-fi or martial arts films myself, I can only surmise that the slo-mo and sped-up fight scenes could not possibly represent state of the art technology, as it was more cartoonish than action packed.

Given this kind of science fiction film, with its unabashedly childish conception of what the constitutes a 'multiverse', a significant heap of suspension of disbelief is required. But even at that, the weirdness-for-weirdness sake (which the film freely acknowledges) just kind of falls flat. Even as the film shares a wink with the audience at its own absurdity, the humor plays more as mitigating audience expectations. As if to say 'we're really just joking about his schlock'. And after it all, the message is essentially the same as you get in reading Kurt Vonnegut, but with fewer laughs.

I would absolutely recommend for anyone who wants to see Michelle Yeoh in a beautiful performance. She is absolutely a treasure in this role. For story, stunts or special effects, not so much.

Title: This is a wuxia film in disguise
Review:
I started watching this thinking this was going to be one of those melancholy nonsensical "arthouse" science fiction dramas. Boy was I wrong. This is a wuxia film in disguise (if you don't know what wuxia is: think Jackie Chan).

It's action-packed, hilarious, and insanely absurd. Genuinely funny. Like one moment I'm laughing at something, and then it becomes even more ridiculous, and then EVEN MORE RIDICULOUS. Like fever-dream ridiculous.

It also reminds me of Scott Pilgrim vs The World. Same campiness of the humor and similarly action-packed.

Underneath it all is also a story about generational divides in immigrant families. Filial piety. Acceptance. Marriage. With the central themese being nihilism and the "what ifs" that we all think about.

Title: Everything on a bagel
Review:
This movie has a great mix of drama, action, and comedy! This is what movies should be like. Entertaining on many levels, with depth, character development, a lot of randomness, and laughs. I highly recommend seeing this!

Title: Return to art
Review:
With the recent oversaturation of Marvel Movies, that I'd hardly consider art (as In no real deep telling of a story, using filmography to tell said story etc.) I think this is a good sign for a return to the idea that Films are in-fact an Artform.

I haven't laughed and cried as much over this movie than I have over any other one.

I went into this thinking it was some goofy action/comedy and the first 2/3 of the movie are mostly that, but the last 40 minutes or so, I was constantly in tears.

I wish I could honestly experience this movie all over again, with no prior knowledge of the story and what happens near the end, I'd say its one of the most sweetest and "emotionally realistic" endings I've ever seen to a film.

Title: I liked it. However this movie has some nasty issue with pacing.
Review:
This movie is quite wild. And, overall, it's only flaw is the kind of pacing that tires watchers out.

It's something more or less like this: 20 minutes of slow 20 minutes of non-stop action 30 minutes of action with small breaks 30 minutes of mostly nothing with some action breaks

Action is great, but when the movie slows to "lets talk" part.. it gets tiresome, because it either doesn't end or the topic is eye-rolling'ly lame.

The final message is strong, but because of the pacing i felt simply tired to really care and think about it. So i just accepted it as is, while rushing out of cinema.

Humor is mostly good, there were some scenes i openly laughed. For all the runtime my focus never waned, so that's good.

Should you watch it: If you like Rick and Morty, this show will most likely feel familiar and fun. If you like "weird" movies, then this one should also be fun experience.

Title: Cinema Omnivore - Everything Everywhere All at Once (2022) 8.2/10
Review:
"All hell breaks loose in the IRS building, Evelyn the launderette has no sooner disabused incredulity than minions of Jobu Tapaki start their offensive. Levity bursts out every time when a character must do something utterly ridiculous to acquire a particular skill belonging to their counterpart in another universe, for instance, "butt-hurt" has a literal signification here. The universes imagineered by Daniels range from small variations like Evelyn the movie star, or the martial artist, or the opera singer, to absolute bonkers, like Evelyn and Deirdre become a lesbian couple in a universe where human's fingers are supplanted by hot dogs, or Evelyn is a teppanyaki chef and her younger colleague Chad (Shum Jr., a droll eye-candy!) is puppeteered by a Ratatouille-like raccoon, to the utter abstract, eons later, humans have devolved into stones."

read my full review on my blog: Cinema Omnivore, thanks.

Title: The best quality of this film is ignoring every genre convention.
Review:
In general though I think the sum of its parts is greater than the whole. I do admire it's fearlessness and willingness to put on the screen anything that seems to pop into their head sort of like a stream of consciousness film making. At times it makes for a very entertaining watch but it relentlessly keeps you in sort of a confused state that sometimes I think is a bit too much. I recommend this film for its uniqueness and I think there will probably be other films that are inspired by this and try to imitate it in the future.

Title: Be Kind, you don't Know Everything
Review:
Out of all the universes where we could be anything, be kind.

This movie was extremely confusing even for the most brilliant people on this planet. I attempted to understand the entire plot, what was happening, and I was completely lost. But that's okay. At the end of the day.... You do not know everything about what someone is going through. Whether it be your Dad, daughter, or even a complete stranger, you can't even begin to comprehend. You're lost. I'm lost. So just be kind.

Amazing representation of characters, stunning performances, beautiful costume design, crazy transitions, and thoughtful messages all combine to make the best movie of 2022.

Title: Beautiful, hilarious, and meaningful beyond words
Review:
Absolutely sublime yet action packed and wildly funny and outlandish! Hands down one one of my best movie going experiences ever. It is rare for me to laugh so hard or cry so often during a film, let alone both simultaneously. Thought provoking and beautiful in its presentation of optimistic nihilism. Great stunt work with wide action shots. Wonderful performances from all the actors. Surreal, unpredictable, and perfect!

Title: Strange~Loves
Review:
I swear I will never get this title right. It just doesn't flow right in my head. But that is par for the course of the feature presentation.

I really loved Everything Everywhere All at Once, but it's super hard not to. While I admittedly didn't get it all with this viewing, I felt this movie is special. There's so much more I didn't see and can't wait to upon inevitable multi-viewings. This is why I'm glad I chose to purchase this (unseen) vs. Renting it or getting a free trial/one month of Showtime just to see it. Now I *can* rewatch this enough times to absorb it all.

Hard to describe the plot, but it boils down to an everyday Mother/Daughter/Wife with extraordinary worries/responsibilities/troubles and her unexpected journey of self-discovery through...the multi-universes. This could be the unofficial Scott Pilgrim vs. The World sequel I've always wanted.

It's also like The One and, of course, Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness. It is better than Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness and a hundred times better than The One, but I still do prefer Scott Pilgrim Vs. The World more.

Everyone in the cast is excellent - not one single bad performance, but I will give the most kudos to both Jamie Lee Curtis and my personal favorite of the cast/characters: Waymond Wang played wonderfully by Ke Huy Quan. I instantly felt his warmth, charisma and boy, was he adorable. Plus, a good fighter. And OF COURSE, Michelle Yeoh did great. That 100% goes without saying.

One thing I did not expect: this is a straight-up comedy first. I did laugh out loud so...many...times. Sure, there is action. Beautiful, exciting, fun and wonderfully choreographed fighting. And there is heart. Like a ton of it. But, overall, I really saw this as a comedy-drama with some incidental action.

I don't think I'm gushing over this as much as I believe I will with additional viewings. There's a LOT to take in. Like more flashes/subplots/characters/directions still dancing across my brain from this and the movie ended a while ago. It is one of the most original pieces I've seen in a long time. And it's not just the script. Everything Everywhere All at Once...on the screen.

Jury's still out if I'll raise my initial 8/10-star rating as I've been known to do. But this I know: I will be revisiting the Wang's multiverses again soon.

***

Final Thoughts: Naturally, I'm not going to spoil the ending, but it was 100% the ending I was hoping for. I didn't expect it would happen and I was so very pleased with the payoff. I cannot wait to see this again.

Title: The Movie is Good, but not as good as I though it would be
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Really Fun; Perhaps a Bit Much Rinse & Repeat
Review:
You know when you are bored and you just keep scrolling through Instagram or Facebook videos and every 2-5 seconds is something different and unexpected. This film had that feel as the characters and scenes move frequently between a multiverse. The high-level shallow plot of the main characters owning a laundry mat and having tax trouble are almost irrelevant to the core points being made about the purpose and meaning of one's existence within the universe. There is often rapid scene cutting between the same characters and the difference between their lives in different universes. This is a fun movie to watch for the visuals, editing, whimsical moments and action but perhaps that got a bit overdone by not bring in the weighty topics until too far into the story. It would have been more effective to give more meaning to the fun hectic scenes earlier to help build tension to reinforce core points.

Title: Absurd in all the right ways
Review:
This movie is difficult to describe. It is better just to experience it because no description could do justice to the experience that it brings. It is just absurd and crazy with excellent direction and acting. I cannot for the life of me figure out why the emotional beats didn't resonate that much with me, for I have no idea what I'd do differently or better. Alas, the lack of emotional resonance and a bit bloated runtime are the reasons why I choose not to give 10/10 but rather an 8/10.

The movie is full of fun references that probably demand multiple viewings. At it's core is a very personal story to carry the crazyness trough to the end.

There is a lot to praise. The pure imagination and originality. The direction and cinematography. Abiding to basic dramatic concepts such as Chekhovs gun (or should I say 'plug'). The Acting. If the runtime were a bit tighter or if the movie made me care about the characters a bit more I would have been awesome. Still, it is very good and very recomended, though probably polarizing. My wife for example didn't care for it at all and I can't see some of my friends enjoying this. Give it a chance.

BTW. The 'Husband' seemed familiar the whole time and I couldn't figure out from where do I know him. I never realized I was watching Shortstop from the Temple of doom :D.

Title: Weird, boring, waste of time.
Review:
I was suspicious of a movie that won so many Oscars and I never heard of it. It also peaked my curiosity as I felt it 17TRACK must be really good to recieve such Oscar accolade. Sadly I was disappointed. I watched until the end just to make sure I didn't overlook what the academy felt was so great about it. It just never happened. I found myself pausing the DVD player multiple times just to see how much boredom remained. In fact, there is an actual 'The End' moment on the screen. I felt glad, but then discovered there was still an hour left. Oh brother! I just don't get it. With other rather pretty good movies this past year and this one wins out? Sad. Really sad. I did give it some stars because it was directed well and had some decent special effects. Unfortunately it left me unmoved and bored.

Title: Of all the many worlds...I'm glad I live in one where this exists
Review:
If there was ever a film with a fitting title...this is it, alright.

So much so that I think this might be the single most creative film I've ever seen, and almost certainly the craziest genre mashup I've ever seen. It's a sci-fi, it's a kung fu movie, it's an absurd comedy, and it's a family drama. It is, quite literally, "everything, everywhere, all at once".

It's the best Matrix film since the first one, it's got a beautiful anti-nihilist message, it's an exploration of Asian-American identity and generational homophobia, I laughed, I cried, and it's that rare kind of film that just makes the world look a little better to you once it's over.

I realised when I rewatched The World's End that I'm always more impressed by a film that's doing so much stuff that should not work together on paper, and this is like Daniels took that idea as a challenge. Can we make a film that's like Rick And Morty, Police Story, The Matrix, Inside Out and Monty Python And The Holy Grail all had a massive orgy and produced a baby that should be a mangled heap of organs because of how much none of those things should work together, and yet it goes on to win Mr Universe (and hopefully more than a few Oscars too, unless they decide it's too interesting for them like they probably will.)

And as if all that wasn't enough, the performances are all incredible, the narrative is somehow tight and consistent to no end, the directing, editing and cinematography are gorgeous, the dialogue is hilarious, the characters are all extremely interesting...really the only thing I could possibly complain about if I had to is that the beginning is a little slow.

It definitely does all need to be there to set up later events in the film, but I did find myself wondering where it was all going and wishing it would get a bit more unique - which, well...needless to say that wish was fulfilled in absolute spades. Maybe the next time I watch it that'll be more entertaining now that I'll be expecting it, who knows.

But even if that remains an issue for me, I couldn't possibly call this anything other than a masterpiece for the sheer amount of stuff it's doing all at the same time and doing it all so well and perfectly balanced.

Well okay, I will also call it a work of sheer sodding genius. But I'm done now, I swear.

Title: Worthy of the hype
Review:
It's hard not to be influenced by the whirlwind of positive reception this movie is getting, whether you're tempted to go with the flow, or be contrarian and denounce it. Yet it's simply undeniable that this is an objectively well made film. It's firing on all cylinders, hitting all the points in the holy trinity of what I think can make art special: it's entertaining, it's creative and there's depth to it's message.

Not taking on the dreary, self serious tone of typical award winning films, first and foremost, this is a fun movie. It's loaded with fast paced fight scenes, and jokes that had me genuinely laughing out loud. It's a high functioning adventure comedy that's anything but boring.

It may not be the first to explore multiverse themes, but it's wildly inventive in it's approach to them. As proven by Rick and Morty, absurdism is part of package, and Everything Everywhere All At Once doesn't miss the opportunity to get gleefully ridiculous.

It's not all just an excuse to be weird though, and all the insanity is clearly intended to have greater significance. The film feels pretty clear in it's intent, though it's open ended enough to allow you to pull your own meaning from it. Whether you focus on the family dynamic and emotional themes of finding love and purpose in a sea of possibilities, or are drawn more to the existential questions of staring down nihilism in the age of the information overload, it's certain to give you something to think about when the credits roll.

It's got all the basses covered before even taking into account the marvellous acting, editing and effects on display. It's ambitions are high and it excels at it all. Take your ten you magnificent bastard!

Title: Someone sat down and said "what does doing taxes really mean"
Review:
The movie takes you on a journey with a family who is getting audited. There are so many layers in which the story works, and it's executed beautifully to keep you hooked from the opening shot to the credits. (No joke the audience could NOT get up after).

The movie does not throw everything at you at once, it initially shows you what it is, slowly, it teaches you how to process it's story, and when you're ready, it dumps reality on you in such a brilliant way that you will feel every emotion possible.

The acting was brilliant from everyone involved, the writing is so real considering the topic and genres explored. The cinematography served the story perfectly, almost guaranteeing you not only witness it, but be a part of it too.

The film manages to establish the most grandiose of themes with the most relatable characters, showing the story not just through the characters eyes, but our own eyes.

It sounds clich√©, but very few movies, if any, captures me the way EEAAO did.

The film, in its core, is trying to take the load off our shoulders, the current world we live in has been traumatic for most, and this was just a little reminder to take a step back, breathe, and enjoy the time you have with the people you love.

I can go on and on about the different meanings, but do yourselves a favor and watch it.

Title: The Weirdest Movie I Have Ever Seen
Review:
There are no rules in this film. Absolutely none. In the middle of the movie, I thought, "this is bananas. Where is this going?? This is the craziest thing I've seen." And honestly, I stated getting tired of it after a bit. But just when I started to become weary of the films wacky antics, it started to come together! And by the end this film shows that it has some solid, solid heart. Between its laughable hilarity, and managed to be extremely relatable. It's about finding meaning in the events of your life, it's about accepting your choices and accepting your family members. The acting absolutely sold it. Every single actor in this film to the stunning job. Wonderful, weird, weird work all around.

Title: Very good but not great.

I feel that this movie is at least 30 minutes too long and it would have been vastly improved by good editing. So much of the action sequences were overly repetitive and unnecessary. Do I think this was a very good film? Yes. Do I think it's one of the greatest films? No.

Title: An original idea wasted
Review:
Look - it's a good movie okay. But listen, this is the perfect example of how strangely movies have come to be made today and why it might be worth questioning.

Back in the day we have The Godfather and Memento for example - very focused on story and character arcs. No one single scene doesn't serve the higher purpose of the story. Each action scene carefully designed, again, to serve the story and perhaps even the catharsis of the film. And today we have the Super hero flicks. And Everything Everywhere All At Once fits into this superhero structure.

It offers a concept, a world, a story, only to throw it in the bin in the 2nd act and do a bunch of actions scenes for no greater purpose than generating a dopamine rushed audience. The tempo and flickering lights and action is so very millennial. It's clearly made for a generation that is used to having their brains reward system massaged every millisecond by rolling screens.

Everything Everywhere All At Once is like a half baked The Matrix on drugs with unicorn sprinkles all over it. Maybe you like that, and then that's great for you!

But I was disappointed. The pace is too fast, the characters are underdeveloped, and the original concept stops developing early on only to be replaced by trippy action scenes. It's a video game kind of movie. Another one of many in these times.

Title: Nothing Nowhere None at Once
Review:
With all the hype and the awards that this movie received I was certainly expecting this one to be waaayyy beyond other movies. However, this movie turned out to be just a STUPID OVERRATED 2-HOUR RIDE best for psuedo-intellects.

Its like that painting at a museum where the artist splashes all the colors haphazardly (in the guise of modern art) and then puts it on an exhibition and then people come stare at it and they come up with some earth-moving, mind-bending philosophies that probably only they can see, and if you can't then they just say - Oh, you know what? Its not made for your intellect.

However, if you still don't believe me, go ahead, try your luck and test your intellectual capacity.

Title: A Creative Tour de Force
Review:
This movie surely is one of the strangest, weirdest films I ever have watched. Overall, I thought it was excellent, worth seeing if for no other reason than to watch two hours of incredible originality. There's some truth to the reviews complaining that the movie can feel incoherent in terms of plot and, particularly in the latter portions, verge on sensory overload. The characters themselves occasionally say that what's happening doesn't make any sense, which is a convenient way to gloss over plot holes. But, I think the overall arc of the movie makes up for these shortcomings. Ultimately, it's a moving story about a woman's strained relationships with her family members, especially her daughter, and attempting to correct course before it's too late.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a visual spectacle that veers from absurd to sentimental, comic to tragic, and back again. The film editors and set designers had their work cut out for them, and the costume department deserves an award for Joy's outfits. Even if it all sometimes feels like a bit much - and maybe that's part of the point - the movie is impressively innovative throughout. This is probably the only film on earth with a scene featuring two rocks having a conversation that somehow manages simultaneously to be heartfelt, funny, sad, and entirely bizarre; everything all at once indeed.

Title: Amazingly different movie
Review:
The most unusual movie I have seen, I think. Yes, it is long, but so worth taking it through to the end. Visually it is spectacular, the story is constantly in motion, the special effects amazing. A difficult movie to explain, an element of science fiction, but ultimately a movie about the human heart. If there is a flaw,it is that it is really very, very long, like all modern movies the makers don't seem to understand that sometimes less is more, we actually paused an hour and a half in, and went back to watch the last hour a few weeks later, not sure I could have watched it at the cinema. But ultimately a really worthwhile movie.

Title: "I Got Bored One Day and Put Everything on a Bagel."
Review:
One of the most intriguing facets about the brave new world of film currently being pioneered is watching history repeat itself. Specifically, watching studios become prominent markers of a film's quality, second only to the filmmakers at the helm. In the early days, audiences knew what they were getting just by looking at the opening logos: the MGM lion signified luxury, the Paramount mountain meant a foreign touch, the Universal globe predicted cheaper productions and monster movies, etc. Etc.

Although the trend certainly isn't as strong as it was, there are a few studios synonymous with the films they make and distribute. One such example is A24, a studio known for some of the most creative, complex, and outside-the-box fare today.

It's not that A24 films are universally beloved or hyper-consistent; they have their share of duds and usually cater to one niche or another. Rather, the studio is a prominent signifier of quality to cinephiles because the films they make and distribute never pander to a broad market or tick boxes on an executive's soulless list. The passion of the filmmakers involved is always evident, and a purposeful vision usually drives the creation of the art. This is more so true for A24 than any studio today, and is most evident in their biggest, brashest, and most successful film to date, Everything Everywhere All at Once.

The film follows Chinese immigrant Evelyn during the course of a very unusual day. While turning in paperwork for her accountant to comb through, Evelyn is suddenly thrust into an adventure concerning the multiverse, a concept involving the existence of an infinite number of universes. She must learn about all the possibilities the multiverse presents while battling a great force that threatens its existence, all while trying to connect with her teenage daughter, Joy.

It's easy to see why the film has been universally praised. There are hundreds of different effects but little CGI, resulting in a breathtakingly grounded film. Everything, Everywhere is a grandiose and complex film, a patchwork constructed and assembled with invigorating passion. Many of today's superhero films are just as visually dense, but Everything, Everywhere doesn't boast a room full of animators to yell at and whip for faster, grander results.

With respect to CGI artists, who are woefully overworked and underpaid, this film isn't just digitally synthesized - it's filmed. It's impossible to state my feelings of gratitude when a film feels like it's truly unfolding before your eyes, when it boasts a concrete foundation of verisimilitude, and Everything, Everywhere clears this benchmark with a story that seems like it never should've. It's resoundingly refreshing.

A24 deserves its praise, but the impetus for Everything, Everywhere's creative explosion comes from Daniels. Daniels (Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert) are young, but they're already blazing a path for uncanny, surreal filmmaking, demonstrated in their freshman and sophomore efforts Swiss Army Man and The Death of Dick Long. Their direction is kinetic and all-encompassing, a veritable barrage of places, characters, ideas, and impressive action that assaults the viewer unrelentingly.

One of the film's most special characteristics is the scale of its time; most of Everything, Everywhere takes place during a full day, but also, as the title suggest, transcends time and space, reaching into infinite worlds to set up several intrastory vignettes with their own structure, stakes, and pacing. Daniels do a remarkable job keeping focus and clarity despite the explosion of storylines and emotional stakes. There's a pristine clarity to everything, everywhere, all the time.

The film is chaotic and explosive, but it's the editing which truly sets it apart from other equally boisterous fare. While the overarching story moves at lightening pace, it's also allowed to breathe and steady itself, further orienting the audience during the calamity. Nothing is too stylized either, like, say, Run Lola Run; there's a nice balance of quick cutting to maintain the kineticism and longer takes to envelope the viewer into the world. Whatever editor Paul Rogers was paid to work for Daniels, it wasn't enough. Everything, Everywhere has been lauded for a smattering of reasons, but I truly think the film lives or dies by Rogers' hand - it lives.

Everything, Everywhere is the grandest, most elaborate, most painstaking film of the year, no question. It's size and quantity are easy to admire but it's not without its hiccups. Because of the film's size, scope, and genre-mashing, Daniels can't avoid giving viewers whiplash across the film's many storylines, emotional arcs, and tones; they go about eight layers deep and no moment is anything but fleeting. The lulls are brief but so are the film's many highpoints.

Giving proper credence and pacing to the material would take approximately five hours of runtime, and the film is whittled down to an explosive two and a half. Because of this problem, and not despite of it, the film feels overstuffed. There's so much to get to and so much crazy, random nonsense happening at any given time that Daniels feel like they're rushing to give everyone and everything their due.

A golden film rule for creators is "kill your darlings," which is shorthand for "delete every millisecond of material not essential to telling the story". I can't even comprehend that there were scenes deleted here, either from the film or the script prior. There's just so much of it...probably about fifteen percent too much.

Speaking of the script...it's a bit unwieldy. The story begins relatively slowly and quietly accelerates, a nice method to introduce the context and subtext of the madness before fully diving in. However, the film also lacks structure, eschewing satisfying cause and effect to instead introduce random concepts and characters throughout. The practical use of the multiverse invites a strong inclination toward randomness, but Everything, Everywhere sometimes oversteps the boundary, hurtling, at points, into the arbitrary.

In a macro sense, the viewer rarely knows where they are in the runtime or how much of story is yet to play out. This lack of sense is most clearly demonstrated during a clever gimmick in a theater, at which point Everything, Everywhere feels like it's finally winding down and will be over in the next five or ten minutes...it then goes on for another forty-five.

The performances are pleasant all around. In the spotlight are Michelle Yeoh and Stephanie Hsu as Evelyn and Joy, the mother-daughter duo at the forefront of the conflict. Each plays off the other nicely and they establish a tense but loving chemistry.

Key Huy Quan plays Eveyln's husband Waymond, a sympathetic figure who walks a fine line between put-upon and pathetic. James Hong plays Gong Gong, the patriarch of the family. Every actor also plays a plethora of other roles from other universes, staying grounded and convincing in all manner of costumes and characterizations.

Altogether, Everything Everywhere All at Once is a ridiculously large and raucous film. It maintains impressive focus on character and theme, never letting its central conflict become rote or lost in the hyper speed of the action. If it's ultimately too much of a good thing, it's still the most unique, creative, and ambitious film of the year, and the Daniels deserve significant praise for dreaming it up. I'm sure every eye will be on their next project and there will be considerable attention on this one throughout the year and into awards season. The film has been met with a startling amount of hype, but mostly delivers on every piece of praise it's received. Absolutely worth seeing in theaters.

Don't miss it, and don't take the grandkids (a 15 for good reason: beaten withpenises, finialled doorstops, fingers made of hotdogs... and some!) Enjoy!

Title: A film about multiverse which explores the idea of choices
Review:
Finally got the chance to see this much hyped movie and I absolutely loved the idea it portrayed.

Basically, we're just consequences of our choices compounded over time. And with every choice we've an opportunity to re-write our destiny! This is the idea explored in EEAAO.

Most sci fi films tend to loose plot in the nitty gritties of technical details but this one had a top notch plot (and a realistic one at that, i mean who's not fed up with taxes?) which gives it an edge over other similar films.

The cast is great (the IRS lady did frighten me!!!) The eerie music complements the family tension very well and keeps the viewer engaged.

I just feel they over did the chaos in the 2nd act, otherwise a great film!

Title: Masterpiece
Review:
Not a lot of movies can be so many genres all at once and succeed at it. Comedy, action, sci-fi, drama, thriller and a love story; this movie achieves it all. Simply put, this movie is a masterpiece.

Title: Gripping from start to end
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Convoluted
Review:
This movie is a strange object. Visually impressive, original in its form but also convoluted and overwhelming. The form precludes the depth (if that sentence does make any sense). The goofiness is too strong and emotionally distracting. It's not that funny nor that touching because it tries too hard. Yet there are beautiful moments amidst the sheer chaos.

Michelle Yeaoh is a great actress, really.

And the rest of the cast was very good, especially Ke Huy Quan and Stephanie Hsu. Jamie Lee Curtis was having great fun.

(why does imdb requires 600 characters for this review while there are many shorter reviews posted for that same movie?)

Title: Hold the hot chilli sauce - I can't taste the meat
Review:
The title doesn't lie. It just doesn't tell you what happens when you have "everything everywhere all at once"...you have a mess on your hands!

I can see it lighting up the eyes of a jaded script reader. I'm sure there are not many scripts like it.

But on-screen? It's overwhelming. It's ambitious. It has promise. A heart. But it's all too much for my lil brain to take in and digest at once. We may live in a multi verse but I'm no multi-tasker and this film demands me to be.

Michelle Yeoh is great. There's a lot of messed up stuff going on around her that I don't think was needed to tell the story it ultimately delivers.

Hold the hot chilli sauce a little next time I say.

Title: Too much at once
Review:
People who like this movie but hate the Marvel films are lying to themselves. This is an marvel movie, from the humor, to the formula, to the concept, it completely borrows what makes marvel special. Only thing that maybe is better, Is the filmmaking. The fight scenes are well made.

But the plot, and the concept, and the approach of the atmosphere and design. It just wasn't for me. But even the most objective things, like the plot, or the character-development, it contradicts itself.

(Now a little digression)

You don't need to tick boxes for a film to be great, most of the films that are considered as the greatest films ever made do not do this. They have an artistic approach. Film, no matter if the thematic is good or bad, should always connect with people, or inspire people, or bring people to think. There are so many things that gather my interest because of films, so many things I learned about, whether it's political, psychological, or historical, that's what film is all about and that's why I love films.

But this... I don't see what this wants to be. I don't know what the point of everything was, I thought the the mother and daughter conflict will be the heart of the film, and it would've made the film much better, but it's all thrown away for some jokes. No overall motivation for the daughter to be bad, no introduction to the concept of the multiverse, the whole multiverse is basically trapped into an bagel, and the films answer to all is, Nothing matters, Everything Matters. It tries so hard to tell so much but tells so little. Ke Huy Quan is the only one who deserved his Oscar, Michelle Yeoh's performance is in my opinion nothing special at all. What does she do, besides screaming and fighting? Nothing, she can act greatly, but the character isn't various enough to make her shine.

It frustrates me, that this is what critics call the most ambitious-work of the year. No moments that need to sink in, no moments of depth to think about, is our attention span really that short that this, THIS, is all we can settle with? With every minute so much happening, so much fighting, so much craziness, but no emotions, no feelings, nothing to gather from It. Not only from the movie's characters itself, but FROM the movie's Ideas to YOU. Films inspire and give knowledge.

Everything Everywhere all at once, is too much at once, but still says nothing. No depth in it's plot or ideas, just things... happening. For the sake of nothing.

Title: Not what I expected, in a good way
Review:
I come to watch "Everything Everywhere All at Once" thinking it is some well-made but run-of-the-mill human interest story of a woman finding her way as she navigates family situations. In a way, it is about that, but a third into the movie, you find yourself catapulted into one of the wackiest rides in cinematic history. The movie tries to answer a lot of our existential questions, and it does so through an outrageous adventure that partly doesn't make sense, partly gives you aha moments, and most importantly it entertains you with the visuals, costumes, action scenes, and endearing performances, especially by Michelle Yeoh and Stephanie Hsu who sports the movie's most memorable scene, confidently twirling those "weapons" in the air. Jamie Lee Curtis nails it, too, as a government Karen. Just sit back and enjoy the ride and try not to over analyze this like you would "Tenet" or "Inception." This is a comedy after all.

Title: Everything Everywhere All at Once
Review: This was one of the most unique experiences I've had in a movie for a long time. The directing duo of the Daniels follow up their previous masterpiece, Swiss Army Man, with an equally unforgettable watch for any viewer. The film brilliantly combines a bombastic backdrop of multiverse mayhem while also delivering an intimate family drama that will leave the audience in tears of laughter and in emotion. The film is filled to the brim with imagination, creating a world that feels original and fresh. The performances are stellar with Michelle Yeoh delivering one of her finest portrayals providing heartfelt emotion and relatability to her character. The fight sequences are entertainingly choreographed, with editing and vibrant camera movements that allow the audience to be immersed in the excitement. The comedy in the film is also done well, granting the film the ability to be silly and quirky while never overshadowing the overall dramatic narrative. Despite how much of a blast this film is, the runtime may drag in areas making the film longer than it needs to be. However, the film is an overall joy from beginning to end. Telling a story of imagination and an intimate drama, while also providing characters that feel relatable as well as heartfelt, allows for a time at the movies that will be unforgettable by the time the credits roll.

Title: Instant favorite
Review:
I'm looking forward to sharing this strange, surreal tale with my friends! Exactly my type of humor and randomness. Douglas Adams would probably have had a great time watching such an irreverent reflection of humanity. 10/10 easily, and I'm so excited for the future movies that Daniels make together.

Title: A introspective socially relevant family drama set in a multiversal chaos.
Review:
There are very few movies where tu expect little and gets so much more in return. This is one of those movies. From the plot, story, screenplay and obviously brilliant acting from each and every cast , especially from Michelle Yeoh and Stephanie Hsu to the technical departments like cinematography, sound mixing and VFX, this is a work of art. A Chinese immigrant, running her troublesome laundromat business, facing audit for accounting malpractices founds herself in midst of a multiversal war where some superhuman villain named "Jobu Tupaki" is set to disrupt the balance of multiverse. Now she is the only one who can stop her.

Since the multiverse has become a craze on hollywood, very few writers and directors chose to shed some light on the formation of multiverse. Decisions we take in our life , which shape our future can give birth to realities if they are taken a little bit differently. But be it in a same universe or innumerable universes , the life of us and people we know are held together in a basic thread of passion, love, hate, despair, ego. And thake emotions between the lead lady and all the other chracters are weaved so slenderly that those will keep a long lasting impression.

One of the best movies of 2022 and surely a un- missable one.

Title: Creatively chaotic, a metaphorical masterpiece
Review:
This is one of those films that is hard to describe, and is best to experience. It is an entirely unique film with nothing else like it. It's beautifully random.

There are three chapters, everything, everywhere and all at once. It starts with the mundane struggles of everyday life, very much grounded in reality. The difficulty in managing family, a business and yourself and goes on to show the consequences of losing focus on what matters. Like dominos a failing business leads to being a poor partner and parent, then divorce and a failing relationship with a daughter. Through the film the main character questions what she did to get there, and how different her life would be if she took a different path.

Then it moves on to set the premise for the rest of the film by explaining the universe hopping mechanism. It does this gradually and keeps you guessing about how it all works. All the weirdness that comes along with it is a delight. It sparks so much joy seeing the completely random things the filmmakers could come up with, all the alternate realities. There isn't a dull moment and plenty to make you laugh out loud, gasp with surprise or cringe in horror. No expense was spared when it came to the filming and effects either, all was done to a very high standard and you can see the creators were passionate about what they were making. Even the fight choreography was good. The characters are all great and well acted too.

There is a moral to the story, that you shouldn't stress about the things you haven't accomplished. Don't be everywhere all at once. You should be present and appreciate what you have, even the little things, making the most of the now. There are beautiful and touching moments in the film that make you think about what's truly important in this life.

Many films that are a bit crazy like this one don't usually know how to end, but everything everywhere all at once wraps everything up nicely. I felt there were no gaps or unanswered questions. It was just a wholesome, feel good end to a great film.

It was much longer than I expected, I didn't want it to end. If you watch this film in the right mindset, it will make you laugh and cry, and hopefully feel grateful for who you are.

Title: So much fun, but so long
Review:
This would have been outstanding if it had been less heavy handed and self-indulgent about the fight sequences and multiverse concept. Ok, I get it, get to the point, I was thinking after about 90 minutes. Lots of great stuff here, but ultimately, like, learn to edit.

We also get a lot of exposition through chaotic flashback, but the daughter with whom Evelyn's relationship is ostensibly the focal point gets essentially no backstory. Yes, accepting her daughter is about accepting herself, but how are we supposed to see the parallels when we see nothing about Joy as, like, a person.

Title: Superb
Review:
I've just watched the movie. Twice. Had never done that before. And probably will not either. Time will tell, but right now it feels like the best movie I've ever seen. And probably the best one I will ever see.

It's not superficial. If you just want to relax with some popcorn then this is probably not the best thing for you at the moment.

I think the movie has many layers. For me, it is about the meaning of life. Why live. Very deep and brave.

And it's not boring either. Without that frustrating "just accept things and be happy". As if that's easy!!!

Even more, the movie has quite a bunch of fun action.

It is a very wholesome, multi-layered and rich piece of art with a life-affirming message, especially for the brave ones.

I feel deep gratitude to its creators.

Will definitely rewatch. And show it to my son when he grows up a bit.

I would rate it 11 out of 10.

Title: Life can be a bitter cough syrup sometimes, but...
Review:
..there's still honey in this world to make it better. :)

If there's one movie I can recommend someone, a movie that is x1000 better than superhero-crap we watch, a movie so accurate, deep and meaningful that it will leave your eyes welling with tears after some bizarre funny and mundane scenes... your heart and soul will feel the jolt ‚ö°imprinting itself onto your inertia, so you remember it for good! üòä Life can be a cough syrup sometimes or all the times: This movie is about a family, struggling to cope up with life on every day basis, being immigrant, working hard at a coin laundromat, you know a typical Asian baggage you carry once you get married. There's just so much to take and bear in life--and, it goes for each and every one of us. We all have so much going, and sometimes it all just seems overwhelming. Pressure, depression, responsibilities, bills, taxes, job, children, and on top of that the love and care you once had slowly dried out... is this the life we signed up? Is this what multiverse have to offer? No. Life is what we make of it, and that's precisely the message of this movie. A hard-working, dedicated, devoted yet not perfect mother, and how she copes up with her father-in-law, husband, and a daughter who is affected negatively by all her struggle. Because, she's too busy and bound by societal laws to even truly acknowledge her daughter's sexual orientation. Eventually, little dark cloud turn her too bitter towards life. She'd rather be a rock. And, trust me, when you get to this scene where they're rock--you too would be like, yeah, I want to be a rock too. Life's too much--everywhere and all at once, but there's still kindness and love if we keep it alive. It will make life worth living if we take a break from this world's nonsense we humans have enslaved to. All we need to do is take a break, look around, cherish those around us, and life will become once again beautiful and worth living.

Yeah, I did cry quite a bit. Because, I too had these dark clouds hovering over me.

A MUST MUST MUST watch. I cannot insist more. This is x1000 better than any blockbuster superhero crappy movies you've watched. It's truly a MASTERPIECE that you must own. I am going to buy and add it to my library too. BRB. :)

Title: Hi-yah, asian matrix meets rick & morty plus LSD
Review:
First of all, you must be comfortable with chinese style cinema or you plain just wont like this film. Demons, possession, extremely fast paced, literal good vs evil etc.

The pacing in this film is incredibly quick, with most hollywood films being too slow, this film is too fast. So many different ideas, so many different thoughts, all whizzing past you at a tiring speed. Although its fast with many moving parts, theres zero depth, like a rambling schizophrenic going 1000 words a minute.

Coming back to the crazyness, this film goes full on 12/10 in wackiness, bizarreness and other abstract outside the box ideas. Just like the pacing, its more schizophrenic randomness rather than having rhyme or reason.

The martial arts are good, the technical side and minimal CGI is always nice to see, but its all rather simple with zero depth. This film displays more like a live theatre production, with you constantly wondering when the literal curtains will fall and youll have to start clapping, instead of being a well shot, well planned, well thought out film.

If youre looking for a super random, almost psychedelic, asian stage show experience, this is it. But if you want anything resembling a coherent film, you will be disappointed. This experiment also runs way too long at 2h20m, we all enjoy some crazy, but not for that period of time.

Title: about us all
Review:
I finally saw it before it disappears into nowhere and all of a sudden. I think the movie is really about us. Not just Asian women, not just women in general, but also men as well. Just ask any dads to see if not most of them also worry about their sons not living up to certain paternal expectations, which may be some subliminal extensions of their unfulfilled alter egos or selves? That said, I think that male paternal psyche if it exists may be more oriental than occidental in general. Crazy movie. Very funny and side splitting performances from everybody. This may be a new trend in the dramatic structure of storytelling.

Title: The Title Says It All
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

Title: Absolute Masterpiece
Review:
Do not sleep on this.

Like with their previous movie 'Swiss Army Man', the Daniels take you on another ecentric mad adventure with Everything Everywhere.

Their vision is one of the most ambitious things Ive ever seen on film, and the level of talent on display is breathtaking.

Leave your hesitations at the door and buckle in. Its going to be a bumpy ride!
5 out of 10 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: A visual barrage
Review:
Wow. Where to start with this one.

An overworked laundrette owner with a problematic father, husband and daughter visits a zealous tax inspector to go through her struggling businesses tax affairs, and during the course of the meeting pathways to different universes open up - each one offering a different version of her and everyone around her.

This film is baffling, bizarre and bonkers. Take The Matrix, Brazil and any Jackie Chan movie you care for, chuck them into the washing machine, hit the fast spin cycle and try to make sense of it. Good luck!

Fortunately the machine will slow to a gentle care wash at the end of it's programme; the film concludes in a slower, more reflective manner around themes of love and contentment. And that is a relief - the manic earlier action takes a toll on the senses and the change of pace comes as a well earned reward for sticking with it. It also gives the film a gravitas and meaning it otherwise would not have.

Indeed it is the offering up of a meaningful message that saves the film for me. Had it continued on its zany, comedy violent, power struggle path until the end it would have been nothing more than interesting trash. But the ending gives us something to think about. We are time poor, bombarded with responsibilities, struggling and striving . . . But how much of our our daily obsessions actually matter in the end? Does that really bring out the best in us? 'There are only two certainties in life - death and taxes' - to hell the taxes, think about what really matters in your life before you die. That's what I take from it.

It is creative and visually stimulating film, with strong characters and doses of oddball humour. Some will love the chaotic muddle of scenes as we rapidly switch between universes, times and character types, but for me I think this hand is overplayed. Yes it's unique and inventive, but is that really the best way to deliver what is an interesting plot line? I'm not convinced. I have the nagging feeling that this film could've been so much more rewarding if the creative team were not so wedded to the manic delivery style.

It's certainly a film I know I'll watch again, since trying to absorb everything on first watching is a bit like counting birds in a starling murmuration. Quite something.

Title: Complete mess
Review:
It seems obvious that someone paid a lot of people to write false reviews. This movie is only a big load of crap, of absurd jokes, of boring script, etc. It's seems like a bunch of kids wrote all the silly ideas that came out of their mind in an afternoon and gave it to the producer. It's simply impossible, seriously impossible that it won any prises "legally". Someone somewhere push some buttons, made some phone calls, and that's it... I gave a 2 out of 10 only because I like the main actress. And I felt bad for her, because I am sure that she did not expect such a bad movie. Anyway, any sane person won't be able to give more than a 3 for that chaotic craziness.

Title: Requires a second watch
Review:
This is a complex movie no doubt and despite all the funny quirky moments, it feels a pain to sit through on first watch. However, it is not random and I started to connect a lot of things when I saw it the second time. It is debatable if that is a good thing or bad. The acting is top notch and I like movies which try to show something different and new. It has some good concepts for eg. A multiverse where every branch is slightly different from the previous one based on life decisions and events and farther you go, more surprises you may find was well presented. Overall it is a fun filled mixed bag of comedy, action, philosophy, drama. I would give it a 9.

Title: Hope. Kindness. Are you listening?
Review:
This movie captures all the pain and angst and joy and absurdity of life all at once. I'm not even sure the writers meant it to be such an existential experience but it was for me. They break our lives down into the relationship within this one family but it's goes so far beyond the obvious need to heal relationships and let go of unfulfilled expectations that get in the way of loving one another. The movie speaks to our current pain. Our hopelessness. Our disconnection as we fight over our truths. It speaks to finding hope in the absurdity of our individual lives. Meaning in the meaningless. And of living life within the paradox of death. Were you listening? Or do you need to watch it again?

Title: Use your imagination and love to get out of troubling situations
Review:
EEAAO begins very badly, with incoherent, silly, and nonsensical jumbled scenes. This continues for over an hour. For the first half of it, I can understand all the one star and two star reviews.

I was holding out hope that it would somehow improve, and surprisingly, it did. However, I will fairly state that when the story finally comes together in the final half hour, it definitely still won't be enough for most people. It gets sappy and emotional between mother and daughter as its climactic scene.

Ultimately, I've derived this premise from that chaotic, almost unwatchable first half at times: the movie is about how people can use their imaginations when encountering difficulties and arrive at a decision to use love instead of combat to achieve favorable outcomes in seemingly impossible circumstances. It's about the human imagination's ability to solve problems and arrive at the best possible outcome in that moment.

Now, was it worth that almost unwatchable and silly first hour of mixed up scenes and unrealistic behaviors to tell that story? Probably not, but the meaning of that was to show how in peoples' imaginations, they can be anything they want to be (when they are not liking their current circumstances and outcome), and in doing so, they can realize that none of it matters, and then accept their current circumstance and choose love instead of anger to continue to achieve the best outcome. Use your imagination and love to get out of troubling situations

I didn't like the first half at all, but the final thirty minutes was well done, in my opinion, and it did reach an explanation for what appeared to be a mess of a film in the beginning. However, it's still not enough for me to raise the score higher than:

7/10.

Title: This is by far the best movie I've ever seen
Review:
Nothing is even close. This film is an absolute masterpiece. It is captivating, exciting, visually stunning, funny, original, and deeply moving.

The concept is not like anything I have ever see and at no point did I see where it was going. The action sequences are extremely fun and well done and the storyline and writing are genius. And to cap it off in the end they managed to bring it all together with the painfully universal feeling of futility in trying to find purpose in the pointlessness of humanity.

To come up with something this unique and make it connect on every level a movie can is a remarkable achievement. It is as close to a perfect movie as I've ever seen. The filmmakers made something truly special that sets a new bar for excellence in film for this decade.

Title: "The enemy of art is the absence of limitations."
Review:
"The enemy of art is the absence of limitations." Which is why this movie is artless. I wish Hollywood would ditch the whole idea of Multiverses, and leave it to the scientists, and philosophers. Movie wise, if you can create anything and everything for no apparently logical reason? Then you get lazy script writing, dialogue, design , and effects, since nothing can be impossible. For those who felt moved emotionally or philosophically, or came to some profound understanding of their own existence ?..then yes, its worth a 10/10 rating.

A much more effective film could have been made about family relationships, life choices we make, is it better to regret or accept the consequences? No need for racoons on heads, hot dog fingers, talking rocks etc etc.

Title: one of the best films I've seen since the 90's
Review:
How can you sum a film like this up in just a few sentences without going on a rant? You can't. Here's a few words. Best Film editing I have EVER SEEN, Hands down. It is extremally fast paced. Great Acting. Over the top zaniness that makes you laugh uncontrollably. Yet it has a real heart and will make you cry. Actors are believable and you love them by the end as it reveals heavy eastern idealism about love and family and rejecting nihilism. Some of the fighting is too much, but nothing a pair of google eyes won't fix. One of the best films I have seen in a long time. Nice to see something original, with actors who don't look like perfect runway models... real people, doing real things and then suddenly thrust into the deepest parts of your imagination.

This is not a film for stupid people. For them there is Cocaine Bear.

Title: It was Good-
Review:
I'm sure this will win Best Original screenplay at the Oscars. This was the hyped movie of the year.

Yes, it was good. But, that's all it was. It was just good. It was by no means the best film ever as I have seen/read being claimed.

The main thing of the film: you may not have it all, but more likely than not: you have all you need.

The filmmakers just chose a fantastically strange and drawn out way of putting that on film.

The performances were all good. Michelle Yeoh has never not been great. Same with Jamie Lee Curtis. James Hong is always a delight. And it's great to see Ke Huy Quan is a role other than The Goonies and Temple of Doom - I honestly think he deserves consideration for Supporting Actor here.

Title: Marvellous Multiverse Mayhem
Review:
This film is one of those rare beasts that really is as good as everyone says. The hype is most definitely worth it.

It boasts a truly wonderful, poignant, crazy and colourful plot which has everything from drama to comedy and incredibly fun action scenes.

The performances are all terrific. Michelle Yeoh is a real force in this film, and Stephanie Hsu as her daughter steals the show in a fantastically well crafted role.

The visuals are all spot on. The pacing brilliant. The costumes and score are perfect.

A truly wonderful, wonderful film.

Title: An overblown family drama
Review:
That is what it really is in actuality.

Nevertheless, the acting, the music, the visuals are all top notch despite its ridiculousness.

A movie that can make you cry & also feel stupid at the same time. Some side stuff promoting lesbians & bdsm.

This is coming from someone that is not particularly interested in family drama & teenage/young adult genre.

If you're used used to reading comics/manga/animation & a movie enthusiast, you would probably not be blown away by this movie as much as the hype would suggest.

My mistake was going into the movie with very high expectations. Regardless of that, I still enjoyed it though at the same time felt bothered.

Title: A genuinely unpleasant watching experience
Review:
This film tries very hard to be different and clever. If only it also tried to be enjoyable or at least watchable. It may have many profound messages, but if it does not manage to package them in a way that enables me to spend more than two hours in front of a screen all that effort is plainly wasted. This is a ludicrously busy viewing experience, but that does not in itself make it funny. Unfortunately there are no good ideas in this film, neither visually nor in the dialogue. A lot of good acting talent is wasted on banal characters and a pointless plot. Might this indeed be the first film script written by AI?

Title: Rollercoaster of emotion
Review:
Laughter-seriousness, sadness-happiness, beauty-disgust, and a feeling of profound existentialism...

I couldn't stop tearing up during the last half of the movie. The writer is able to convey the meaning of life, and able to deep connect to my soul. Being kind to others is my strength, and how I fight.

I really don't want to go into any more details because this movie has to be seen by everyone who is able to read subtitles.

Best movie I've seen since Free Guy.

Title: The multiverse of madness we deserved!
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once tells the story of Evelyn Wang(Michelle Yeoh). Evelyn is a Chinese immigrant who gets catapulted into an insane adventure spanning different universes. She learns that she is the only one who can save the world & the multiverse.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a mind-blowing film. Directors Dan Kwan & Daniel Schienert have given us a one of a kind cinematic extravaganza that will take you on a wild ride. The action set pieces are some of the best to ever be put on celluloid. The visual effects are awe-inspiring. The comedy makes you laugh raucously, almost throughout its runtime. The emotional scenes are the perfect foil to the non-stop action and comedy of the movie. Michelle Yeoh is spectacular as Evelyn Wang. Yeoh has given her career best performance here & she definitely deserves an Oscar nomination. Stephanie Hsu is outstanding as Joy Wang. Hsu holds her own in all her scenes with the legendary Michelle Yeoh. Ke Huy Quan is brilliant as Waymond Wong. Jamie Lee Curtis is fantastic as Dierdre Beaubierdre. James Hong is unforgettable as Gong Gong. Everything Everywhere All at Once is a must watch for all the fans of the big screen experience & flawless films. Go and have an insanely enjoyable time!

Title: It's worth watching for those interested!
Review:
Im gonna be totally honest in this review, I did not love this movie. I appreciate it's originality and wacky concepts within the multiverse and sometimes it's pulled off very well but in my honest opinion I think this movie is a little messy. Now that could have been Daniels intention, they are the dudes who made Swiss Army Man after all which was weird as hell and an amazing movie that executed it's weird concept in a very thoughful and emotional way.

They go for a similar approach here with Everything Everywhere All At Once and some of the family drama does work very well in this film but I dunno, I didn't fully connect with this one in the way that i'd hoped to after all the rave reviews. They are brilliant filmmakers but I just didn't fully connect with this one in the way I would have liked to. Im still looking forward to what they bring out next and im sure whatever it is will be just as weird if not more.

Title: WORST MOVIE OF ALL TIME
Review: Everything ALL at Once, WON the Oscar as Best Movie of the year. LOL. That's the stupidest thing I've seen in my 65 years. This movie now bumped the movie I had previously called the worst movie of all time. It was just plain stupid. It was uninteresting. It got so repetitive and boring I almost fell asleep a few times. These people popping back and forth between different realities, just didn't do it for me and from what I read others found it stupid and boring as well. DON'T BOTHER seeing this movie. You will be sorry. Whats with the one reality where people had wieners as fingers? Was this a spoof movie, a comedy, horror, drama? No one knows and no one cares. I left the movie, angry that I was sucked in by the Academy Awards picking it as the best movie of 2022. I will just tell you - it was not!. They got it completely wrong. It was terrible. Horrible. The acting was not great because how can you do a great job acting with the plot was so stupid. Lots of things that happened made no sense. I would have been better off wasting time watching paint dry. Curious Case of Benjamin Button, you are now off the hook. This is now Number 1 - Worst Movie of ALL TIME.

Title: Words cannot describe what this movie meant to me
Review:
And I don't think any amount of words can describe it to you or anyone else.

All I hope to do is convince you to give it a chance. Put away your phone, turn down the lights, get some popcorn and give his movie your fair attention that it deserves.

I don't think I have ever seen a movie that so beautifully captures the Asian American experience so clearly. At the surface this looks like a silly movie, but to me, it's a historical record of what it was like to live in an immigrant Asian family in America. An accurate emotional accounting of what we experienced living in the 90s and early 2000s. It was a painful and wonderful period of time that America might never have again.

Maybe I'm looking into this too much, but it doesn't matter because this is what it means to me and I know I will continue to watch and rewatch this movie probably for the rest of my life. That's how much I love this movie and I'm so thankful to all the creators for making it.

Title: The Quirkiness and Craziness Won't Be For Everyone, But It Really Worked For Me
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: The movie is total bananas
Review:
I just watched it and it is a solid 7.7 for me. The movie is total bonanza. I haven't laughed out loud so much in recent years and some of the scenes may haunt me for a good time awhile in a good sense. Worth watching at least twice, there are a lot of great moments to be appreciated, if you don't look for perfection. This movie is all about "the stupidity of it all". Very happy for the cast choice and I wish for a sequel if you will.

For those of you, who might rated it below 7 are very unfair. The moment you realize what he move is all about, you'd enjoy it for what it is. I like the fact they didn't make it perfect or too serious, which I first thought it would be better, but at the end all made sense.

Title: Very good, but there are better
Review:
It is a fanciful drama or dramatic fantasy. It touches on topics such as depression, the mother/father-adolescent and adult daughter relationship, and gives a twist to the vision that is usually held of what must be done to defeat evil. It's good, but still, personally, I felt like it could have been better. At times I felt that they exaggerated with fantasy, but I must mention that I don't particularly like movies with a lot of fantasy, I prefer drama and precisely the dramatic overtones were what made me like this movie and rate it with an 8 out of 10. Despite everything, I would recommend seeing it.

Title: Not a lot of substance
Review:

I'll pretty much watch anything with Michelle in it. Ke Huy Quan Has been a favorite of mine since the goonies. The set and costume design went crazy. But that's the thing. Title: Spectacular way beyond my expectiations
Review:
Last night I watched a different multi-verse film: Doctor Weird and the Blabberverse of Nonsense, and tonight this. What a contrast. One is a stupid, formulaic, run-of-the-mill franchise film made with the sole purpose of making as much money as possible and nothing else. The other is a beautiful and wonderfully creative, intelligent, extremely original, and deep story supported by perfect directing, acting, and production. And extremely funny at the same time. A true work of art and love.

I can fully understand and respect that this is not for everybody, but if you're tempted this type of unique films, you're in for a real treat. In my book it's the best in decades. It makes me both happy and hopeful that someone invested money in this, while I'm in no way surprised that none of the usual, big Hollywood production companies did.

Title: trippy campy unique
Review:
So I typically don't watch this type of genre of movie. It's a campy comedic-drama. It's silly and heartwarming. It's not for everyone. The movie is not meant to be taken seriously. This is the type of movie people study in film school. There's so many messages in this movie that could be dissected but this movie is too long and irritating at times for me to watch more than once. One message was that doing something deemed weird may unlock a new/better life for yourself. I understand why it won so many awards due to the amount of effort and creativity it takes to put a film like this together. However Jamie Lee Curtis didn't do anything spectacular in this film to deserve an Oscar. The other awards I can agree with bc the film caters to the more artsy eccentric crowd. The lead actress and supporting actor deserved their award imo. I rated 7 because the film takes too long to get interesting. The first 45 minutes of the film is pretty tough and I would not watch this film again.

Review:
