Title: Wow - just...wow...
Review:
I don't even know where to begin - umm - how about with the incessant scatalogical attempts a humor, bodily fluids, vomit and giant dildo fight sequences - oh wait - did I mention henchmen attempting to shove butt plugs in their asses because for some reason it allows them to "channel" another person from the multiverse? Did you get any of that? Yeah me neither.

This film is only receiving this attention because we all know how political the Oscars are and Asian Americans have had a tough go of it the last few years - there is truly no other explanation. In fact - it honestly is embarrassing to see the academy, which already stoops lower and lower every year, nominating this dreck for 11 nominations. You read that right - ELEVEN! Absolute nonsense. I could go on and on and really pick this turd apart but there's no use - You either take the bait and think it's brilliant because it's just so all over the place - or, like me and many others - you see it for what it is - a juvenile, pale comparison to other better films (kung fu hustle, the matrix, etc)

I should have known I would literally detest this film after suffering through forty minutes of boners and farts in the craptastic Swiss Army Man but I foolishly bought into the award season narrative of this film. Man - about an hour and a half in, I was truly hoping for Daniel Radcliffe to pop up with an erection and blast a hot fart in Jamie lee curtis' face to liven up the proceedings. The DANIELS as they call themselves (already annoying just cause of that) have to be the most childish filmmakers to ever get to the level they are at and so quickly and with such little talent. My god - can they not last ten minutes without something poo poo and pee pee related?? Also - movie NEVER ENDS. Holy Christ I thought Lawrence of Arabia was a long movie - this felt interminable. Lastly, and then I'll stop ranting as it's just beating a dead, dead, very dead horse at this point - what the hell even is the messsge of this movie and what was all that s*** with the everything bagel?? My god this movie was HORRIBLE.

Title: See it to believe it!
Review:
Trust me, the first half or even the first 3/4 you might not get this movie. You're going to want to withdraw, but you have to make it to the end to piece it all together. It's a stunningly beautiful movie with some great messages about mother/daughter and husband/wife relationship dynamics... but you have to go with the flow to get there.

Title: Funny, Moving, Clever, Kind, Everything
Review:
It is hard to review this film without diminishing it.

The plot - which makes perfect sense as it unfolds - is actually insane. At several points I stopped and realised what I was watching was just BONKERS.

Yet still, I loved it.

And despite how bonkers the film is. And how deeply philosophical it is, it remains a very emotional film. A very sweet-natured and kind film. That's partly the script, partly the wonderful performances.

I genuinely cried, I uncontrollably laughed. And when the film was over I thought about what I'd seen. And so I had to watch it again. And that time I saw even more and loved it even more. And now I want to watch it again.

This is a rare gem. A film as close to perfection as is possible. It looks stunning. It will make you think. And it just made me feel better for having seen it.

It's my new favourite film. And it's just EVERYTHING.

Title: Hilarious, Bizzare, but Reflective
Review:
This movie is as entertaining, as bizarre and as nuts as the title sounds. At the same time it's a movie that will make you reflect on a lot of things. This might be my favourite 2022 movie. I'm so glad I saw this in a full theatre.

This is a proper multiverse movie. When you see the idea of multiverse in superhero movies, it's cool and all but it's never the main focus of the story. This movie on the other hand, really explores what it means for a person, if the multiverse really exists. It asks you, how would you deal with that fact? Let's say every choice you make just creates another universe where you, and everyone else live with that choice. Let's say there are millions of versions of you who are much better off than you are today. Maybe, because of some bad choices you are where you are today. How would you deal with it? Or does it even matter what choice YOU make anymore? The movie brilliantly nails in this feeling of "Nothing matters" into it's characters, and it's viewers. And still, it gives out a very optimistic message. It redeems those emotions in a satisfying finale.

It might sound that this is a very serious movie. Trust me, this movie is hilarious for 90% of the runtime. It asks all these serious questions in the most entertaining, hilarious way possible. It's full of jokes and has some intense, dark yet ridiculously funny action sequences with great stuntwork too. It's the sort of movie where you'll think "what's even going on anymore?" and not in a bad way, in a very funny way. It's like whatever bizzare, offbeat thing came to the director's mind, he just did it. And I love when creators fully express themselves without holding back. The movie is very fast paced too, full of energy. The editing in particular, is very, very creative.

To make this masterpiece with just 25 million dollar budget, it's a rare feat.

Title: Good Enough
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is excactly what the tittle says. It's difficult to discribe this film A) without spoiling it and B) giving a right account of what is happening. Nothing makes sense and yet, in the end, everything does.

To the core of it all, it's a woman, living a life that she doesn't anjoy, being someone she doesn't want to be. Thus, the movie has this melancholic feeling to it, along with the philosofical questions that raises about family, romantic love, choices, control over our lives as well as the lives of those around us, etc etc

The performances is another killer point of the drama, smooth, without overdoing it even though it was so easy to do so considaring the crazy plot.

So, overall, eight out of ten.

Title: That transactions
Review:
Does anyone think this movie will turn into an action movie?

I can say that the best part of the movie is that it works on many subjects such as love, reputation and hate...

I can also say that the word that defines this movie is transactions. This is the first time I've seen transitions used so effectively in a movie. No one can count the number of universe transitions in the movie, but we saw so many different universes, it was really good.

It is very difficult to understand the subject of the movie, but maybe that's what makes the movie beautiful and remarkable. I guess some people will try to watch it over and over to understand the subject but it won't help them :)

Lastly, I have to give credit to the actors , It was the best acting I've seen in a long time.

Title: Never related so much to a movie!
Review:
Wow! I read that Daniel Kwan had ADHD and that the movie somehow was going to represent this. I was convinced when I decided to watch this that I would not like it, and afraid that it would be another disappointment, trying to depict the craziness that goes on inside the head of a person with ADHD on the big screen. But man was I wrong!

What a beautiful film, with a strong message and crazy scenes. I felt like they took my ADHD-head and made a movie out of it, just added some extra action and sci-fi.

Everything was perfect the way it was, and it should not have been made any other way.

Everywhere they went in the movie was so beautiful, smart and very well thought out.

And last but not least the craziness of this movie worked so outstandingly well together all at once!

Title: A well-directed bunch of non-sense
Review:
The best thing about this film is its quirkiness and its visual inventiveness. It works very well at the level of comedy and surrealist science fiction. However, the core of the story is a family drama which is absolutely shallow and cliche. The characters become omniscient demigods putting at risk the existence of the multiverse due to them being hung up on daddy/mommy issues. And at the end, everything is resolved by the characters simply telling one another how much they love each other and how good life can be if we are optimistic. I kid you not, half of this film is an over the top melodrama, with the philosophical climax of a tumblr post. The movie takes itself too seriously, and drops all the fun of the multiverse for the sake of a generic "heroine beats bad guys with the power of love" action and some LGBT positivity message.

And did I mention how many dildos, butt-plugs and BDSM jokes appear for no reason?

Title: A Masterpiece of Western Storytelling Tropes from a Chinese Immigrant's Perspective
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All at Once," is good because it makes fun of every clich√©d thought you've had in your head. The film is meant to be in your face. The daughter/mother relationship of love vs. Hate vs. Loss vs. Longing etc. Is universal to all relationships. One thing, however, is clear: it is better to give this meaningless existence a try than go mindlessly into the void. This longing to exist is unique to this sort of nihilistic storytelling.

I see... ironically I need more characters because rules exist. I was trying to be concise, which is exactly the point, nothing matters and life is often a chore, but what even is death or non-existence? It's impossible to comprehend truly.

Title: Too much to digest
Review:
Stunning images. But in the end this film has far too much of everything while it would benefit from just a little bit of good old storytelling. It is so colorful, fast and full of incredibly creative details that you will definitely feel dizzy after 2 hours and 40 minutes of massive non-stop brain stimulation. Title: Hollywood is finished
Review:
I am Asian, I live in Asia and this is my honest review. My first movie review.

In 2022, AMPAS (the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences) made Janet Yang their new president. A Chinese-American woman with big pull in the Asian cinema market.

In discussion with the thirty (30) member executive committee of AMPAS, she decided to have a big Asian diversity year for AMPAS at the 2023 Oscars. Yes folks, it is these thirty people who basically decide who will get Oscar nominations.

They searched and found one American made movie with a large Asian cast, a movie called 'Everything, Everywhere, All At Once'. They immediately jumped on it and nominated it for a record eleven Academy Awards. Basically everyone in the film, (except the janitor) is nominated. All nominations are solely to promote this Asian affirmative action agenda. In addition, AMPAS (and Hollywood) are desperately trying push the gay/lesbian lifestyle onto Asian families. I promise you that this will never work and will backfire drastically.

The Cast:

Michelle Yeoh - a 60 year old Malaysian actress who was in the movie 'Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon' back in 1999 and since then has done almost nothing. She was essentially handed an Academy Award this year.

Ke Huy Quan - A Vietnamese-American who was in one movie about 35 years ago, back in this disaster. He has been given virtually every award under the sun for this role.

Stephanie Hsu - A Chinese-American in her first movie, plays the role of an overweight lesbian and for it has been handed every award under the sun.

Jamie Lee Curtis - remember her from 'Trading Places' and 'A Fish Called Wanda' etc? Well she plays the role of an overweight lesbian and has received every nomination under the sun.

None of the above four do anything in the film that is deserving of recognition. Nothing.

The Film:

A thoroughly confusing, badly acted, terribly scripted set of scenes, that make absolutely no sense whatsoever. The movie is like watching a video game that you can't follow.

It is basically about an Asian couple and their lesbian daughter, who work in a dry cleaning store and . . . There is some martial arts . . . And well, that is about it. Oh yeah there is some martial arts again.

The movie was the worst I have ever seen with an Asian cast and to be honest it is actually quite insulting that AMPAS would choose this garbage to disingenuously praise Asians. We are not that stupid and we are also not that desperate.

For those of you who are interested in Asian movies and Asian culture, here are a few great movies I recommend:

Not One Less (1999), China Lust, Caution (2007), China Audition (1999), Japan Three Idiots (2009), India

There are many others, but sadly EEAAO is not one of them.

In conclusion, this was a tragic case of affirmative action gone wrong. Asians make great films in Asia, but putting them in some ridiculous Hollywood nonsense, giving them one thousand awards and fake praise all over the internet is not the way to open doors of opportunity for anyone. It just causes embarrassment for us, resentment for others and makes us Asians look like we are a charity case. Which we definitely are not.

Title: Sometimes what you're looking for, is right in front of you
Review:
It is my pleasure to review the feature film "Everything Everywhere All At Once." Directed by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, this movie is an epic adventure that takes viewers on a wild ride through multiple dimensions and alternate universes.

The film follows the story of a Chinese-American woman named Maureen (played brilliantly by Michelle Yeoh) who discovers that she is connected to multiple versions of herself across different universes. As she navigates these realities, she becomes entangled in a battle against an interdimensional threat that threatens to destroy all of existence.

One of the standout aspects of this movie is its visual effects. The filmmakers utilize a range of techniques to create stunning and imaginative worlds, from hand-drawn animations to trippy 3D environments. Each reality is distinct and fascinating, with its own unique set of rules and physics. The film's vibrant color palette adds to the visual appeal, making for a truly mesmerizing viewing experience.

But the film is not just eye candy - it also boasts a strong cast and a thoughtful storyline. Yeoh delivers a powerful performance as a woman struggling to come to terms with her own identity and the impact of her choices. The supporting cast, including Stephanie Hsu and James Hong, add depth and humor to the film.

One area where the movie falls short, however, is in its pacing. The first act feels somewhat slow and disjointed, and it takes a while for the story to really kick into gear. Additionally, the film's complex concepts and mythology may be difficult for some viewers to follow.

Overall, "Everything Everywhere All At Once" is an ambitious and visually stunning movie that delivers an unforgettable cinematic experience. Despite its flaws, it is a true feast for the senses and a must-see for fans of sci-fi and fantasy. I give it 8 out of 10 stars, and recommend it to anyone looking for an epic adventure that spans multiple dimensions.

Title: MAY BE BEST MOVIE OF OUR TIME
Review:
I don't wish to write too much about this film in my review. Just go see it, and please share with family and friends. I'm a film-lover, i adore movies like "eternal sunshine of the spotless mind" and "interstellar", so based off of the trailer, i was sold. I think i left the theater a different person. If you're someone who has ever dabbled with psychedelic medicine, this is a must-see for you. If you're someone who is struggling with depression, this is a must-see for you. If you're someone who is looking to reestablish bonds with family members or friends, this is a must-see for you. For lovers and nihilists alike, this film tells the story of LIFE, in all of its chaotic glory. I can't say enough about this film, and it had me and my friends speaking for hours about existence and how we felt touched forever. 10/10 film. Has something for everyone (of legal age). I'm seeing it again tonight and i will be purchasing this dvd when it's out. Absolutely absurd, but comforting enough to make you cry. Masterpiece of a film and unforgettably unique.

Title: It sits with me still
Review:
It has been 36 days since I first watched / experienced Everything Everywhere All At Once for the first time and I haven't stopped thinking about it since. I've watched it a second time in the theatres since and I'm already planning seeing it as many times as I can before it exits.

It's just a testament to how beautiful and life changing art can be. It can encompass profound truths; wrapped in comedy, absurdism, philosophy, action and drama all at once. It is brutally sincere in the best ways while stretching comedy and taste in the complete opposite direction. It is a movie that wears both its title and it's heart on its sleeve in a way no one could possibly predict.

At this stage it is almost impossible to talk about its influences or compare it to other works of art, authors or directors because the influences are both overt and subtle. Yes it is if Douglas Adams wrote a script about the motherwound directed by Michel Gondry. But it's also Ang Lee directing the Matrix as if it was a parable of generational trauma instead of coming out as trans. It's an insanely wild ride that has the power to heal and change the people watching it for the better.

It's almost impossible to overstate its power. I have personally seen it help a hardened friend come to terms with their depression and loneliness, and soothe the grief of a couple losing their first born to a miscarriage.

It's art at its most life changing purest and that's the highest recommendation I can give.

A really well made multiverse movie. But the core of the movie is the family dynamics and their seach for emotional connection with each other. Michelle yeoh daniel.

Title: A movie about one girls journey to have her sexuality accepted by everyone, everywhere, all at once.
Review:
Yes...my description might seem extreme...but that is what this movie is about.

Its actually a very symbolic depiction of what our generation is currently going through ...and what certain individuals are prepared to do if their "identity" is not only accepted ...but acknowledged by all...on their knees.

That said...other than some rather extreme scenes involving plugs and other sex toys, the movie was certainly entertaining.

Some great action, good acting, fantastic humour and also a very emotional story about being accepted and loved by the ones closest too you.

This will not be a movie you will soon forget.

Title: About as well-rounded as films come
Review:
I can't remember the last time I saw a film where it was so clear just how much effort had gone into it. The amount of costume changes and set designs and work put into a tenth of a second shot in this film is incredible. There was a lot of care put into 'Everything Everywhere All at Once'.

This film reminds me of what the MCU films could be if they were actually interesting. The concept of a multi-verse (for lack of a better term) is such a good one to base a movie around. The possibilities are endless.

I was surprised by just how funny the film was capable of being. I could tell immediately how smart and clever it was going to be, however I didn't expect the amount of laughs I got.

The film is long at around 2 hours and 20 minutes and it can get a little overwhelming if you switch off even for a moment. Otherwise though this was a thoroughly enjoyable experience. One of the most well rounded films I've seen in a long time. 8/10.

Title: A unique story set in the multiverse
Review:
It's difficult enough to set the things you did wrong right in one lifetime, she managed to set things right in all her lifetimes, in all the universes. I'm not a huge fan of the multiverse (which is often nonsensical, coupled with lazy storytelling), but this film actually has a message for the viewers: Don't ever give up, it never too late to start. You'll get there eventually.

Title: Terrible movie. Could not wait for it to end.
Review:
This movie was awful. I came in very excited based on user reviews but it became clear that all of these people must have been on drugs. The movie is wacky but not in a good way, with seemingly random things happening.

I was just waiting for it to be over and if I was not with friends would have walked out of the cinema.

The one positive I can give it is that it is very original and that is not common in Hollywood nowadays.

Don't be swayed by all the positive reviews, this movie is not worth it.

Title: Wow
Review:
This is the definition of a masterpiece and one everyone should watch as soon as they can as it's the kind of movie that reignites your passion for cinema. There are movies that make you believe in movies. This is absolutely one of them, an original vision in a Hollywood increasingly prone to repetition and redundancy. It may overwhelm lovers of the mainstream, but its peculiarity is also what makes it special. Were only a quarter of the way through 2022, but I am already fairly confident in saying that this is the best film of the year. Not only that, its one of my favorite films of all time.

Title: Authors must've went on an acid trip - and came back telling about it but so that you can understand.
Review:
To keep the repetition among reviews brief: most creative movie I have ever seen, crafted well from overarching storyline and philosophical messages down to tiny details, very compelling character development, flawless acting, visual feast, fast-paced and complex but never overwhelming, utterly hilarious, applied humour ranges from flat-out college humour to subtle situational comedy - very brave, bold, heartfelt, relieving and intelligent.

The movies effect of flipping the viewer between laughing, crying, thinking and awe continued for me after I left the cinema: Sat in contemplation at first, then cried - and went on to have the happiest night of this entire year. This movie can change your life and your decisions.

To add something new: Why is noone mentioning the incredible job that the costume designer had done here?

Title: There's a great movie in here somewhere, but I struggled to make it to the end.
Review:
I'm giving it a 6 because I think it's worth checking out and it deserves praise for trying to do something different. My personal rating would be lower.

Which is unfortunate because there's a truly great 100 minute 10/10 film in here. But it's ruined by pacing issues and a mix of alternate reality shenanigans. Half of which I loved and half of which I hated. And when you're switching from great to terrible to boring and back again every minute you just end up with whiplash.

-------------

Part 1 has by far the worst pacing issues. At 85 minutes it could be an entire movie by itself and you really feel it. It takes far too long to get going, has a really good middle third, and then starts getting lost again.

You could cut half an hour out and the film would be much better for it.

Then as for the shenanigans. Some of them worked for me and some of them just did not. At all. And they kept taking me out of the great experience I was having.

The sex toys in particular I would remove entirely. For a movie that gets surprisingly mature and profound, they were immediately jarring whenever they came up. It didn't come off as whacky and absurd, just juvenile. And incredibly overdone.

The rest I could probably live with if the film weren't dragging on so much, but if I was going to vote I'd also get rid of the hot dog universe and the raccoon. Both were fun, for about a minute. And then just increasingly annoying whenever they came back.

So maybe it's back to pacing issues as the #1 problem from which all else stems.

----------------------

Ultimately then, an interesting but frustrating experience. I'm glad I saw it, and I'd like to see more films try and do something different with the formula.

But thanks to the editing and the pacing, it's a film that I appreciated more than I actually enjoy watching.

Title: Phenomenal. Unbelievably Great. Top 50 Film of all Time
Review:
It'd be impossible to even try to explain this movie. Not just the plot but how many different ways it'll make you feel/react throughout it's run time. I'm definitely not a cryer when it comes to watching movies, at best a handful of movies have made me tear up, this movie did that MULTIPLE times... But also made me straight up belly laugh even more. I LOVED this film.

Title: Great emotional beats, but for many just too weird.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: A whacky chaotic absurd and beautiful love story
Review:
I know that this movie will not be everyone's cup of tea. If you are not an Asian growing up in an Asian household or know the Asian culture really well, it might be difficult for you to understand the issues presented in the movie. The words from Evelyn to Joy about she's getting fat might be harsh but it happens a lot and it's actually coming out of love. I know that doesn't make it right but it's how it is in the culture.

The movie can be chaotic but that's what the point of the storyline is all about. The world is chaotic. Our life is chaotic. Even the ever expanding universe is chaotic. It can be exhausting to watch the movie with that crazy pace. But isn't life is just like that?

This movie is a love story. Between man and woman. Between parents and their kids. Between friends. Even between strangers. The messages might be cheesy but they are always true and they can always be applied to the life and relationship. It was wrapped in absurdity and outrageous scenes. And that is life. Even in the crazy world we are living now, the messages will always be true. That kindness, understanding will always the right way to deal with chaotic life. Some of the lines really hit home for me personally. That 'I would have really liked just doing laundry' or 'that's how I fight' are so poignant.

I really like Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis. I was excited to see them in one movie. And what a treat for me to watch them in this movie. The other actors are also amazing. Playing a character in a movie with this kind of storyline and mix of several different genres are surely not easy.

I do genuinely love this movie. It will be one of those movies that leave everlasting message to me personally. In a crazy world like this where we are bombarded with terrible movies, it's nice to still be able to find gems like this. I hope this is not the last.

Title: A tough one to rate
Review:
This movie is indisputably creative. It's been done by true cinematographers and only cinema could offer such an experience. The formal originality and the involvement of the actors are real and strong. But... and there is a but...

The story is weak. You can try it from any angle and this movie beats a record in the number of angles used in any movie before, the story remains weak.

Yes it makes sense in the end. Fortunately. Because the beginning is a happy mess. But when sense appears, the magic goes away.

The movie is powerful. It has been carrying a lot of spectators and let them with a sense of joy and freedom in the end. But this joy and this freedom won't last because the movie will not reveal anything to each one of the spectators. And that is where its failure stands.

In this, Everything Everywhere All at Once is not a masterpiece. It is an original take, for sure. But it misses it fails in revealing important things in people and in becoming timeless despite it really trying to.

When reaching this level of formal achievement and creativity, I really hope the "Daniels" will improve on their depth and finally reach their goal someday.

Title: The Emperor's New Clothes
Review:
Everyone is in awe of the Emperor's fine new clothes. How stylish they are! How magnificent! How artful and clever! The truth is of course that the Emperor has no new clothes. He's buck naked or if he's dressed at all it's in hand-me-down rags and remnants borrowed from others. But whisper it who dare lest they be thought a doofus, a philistine.

Let's just grasp the nettle here. This is a bad film. It's completely uninspired, using old sf concepts as if they were somehow original or clever. The actors try their best but have so little to work with that they come across as talentless hams which I'm sure they're not. No, the responsibilty for this mess lies with the director and the writers. The only people this will impress are those who have never read or watched intelligent science fiction and obviously there are a lot of them out there.

Such a boring movie and it feels so bloody long and good films never seem long. You never want them to end but with this one you wish it had never started.

Title: A Landmark film brimming with creativity & heart
Review: Films like this remind you why Cinema is such a magical form of art. Exploding with originality & creativity, so many times I was stunned by how they were able to pull off some of the scenes. Its a story of a chinese immigrant facing financial crisis, who is suddenly tasked with the responsibilty of saving the multiverse. The comedy in this film is bonkers and so weird & I loved it, reminiscent of those Stephen Chow's legendary Hong Kong films. The action brings back the flavor of Chinese KungFu movies, so well choreographed. So many philosophies are discussed, the multiverse becomes a reflection of a human's unfulfilled hopes & dreams & possibilities. It dwells on nihilism, absurdism & depression. And all these are bound by strong emotional familial ties and superb performances. Ke Huy Quan is the heart of this film, playing a goofball husband who always disappoints his wife. His words make us realize where the value of life lies. And obviously Michelle Yeoh, what a performance !! She is perplexed, bitter, funny, awkward & so loving. The direction, editing & VFX are revolutionary. This is the film of the Year & You dare not Miss It.

Title: Very creative and unusual, surprising, and a little confusing and silly
Review:
To be honest, in the first 15 minutes, I had no idea what to expect of this movie. It took me by complete surprise. With infinite possibilities, you will never know what to expect from one minute to the next. There are silly parts, goofy scenes, emotional moments, and brilliantly crafted shots. One of the better movies I have watched this year. Very, very creative.

Title: Everything Everywhere was Perfect
Review:
This is a movie done right. The main theme isn't original, but the way its told is truly unique. This is a story that cannot be a read because of the visual aspects that go into it which makes this a perfect movie. The cinematography, the chorography, and the visual effects go hand in hand, while being able to be comedic when need be. The acting was also really well done, no one felt out of place and they truly felt relatable in some aspects. I have nothing negative to say about this movie, that's why it is a ten out of ten in my book.

Title: PERFECTION Everywhere, All At Once
Review:
I haven't been this transfixed by a film since Parasite. THIS is what cinema needed. So fresh, so unique, so epic. This movie never dragged. It was chaotic, high-energy, perfectly paced, superbly acted, and phenomenally directed/produced.

The "multiverse" plot isn't new, but how they navigated this familiar storyline absolutely was. This cast was stellar. Kudos to all involved on the creative side.

The comedic flair of the film was authentic and natural. The stunts were absolutely perfect. The score kept us viewers engaged. The costumes were whacky but also spot-on for the periods they were chosen for.

I want to see this again! Michelle Yeoh better win an Oscar for this. 60 years old and carrying a martial arts film on her back like this?!

Title: Good perspectives
Review:
You know it's not massive acting talent. But I enjoyed this movie because it really provides some interesting perspectives on quantum reality. But moreover, the reflection on what's important is appreciated. People, love and family are always more important than any quantum reality. Like they say, "nothing matters." But ironically, the movie highlights the importance of being together, loving and accepting each other as we are. In the multiverse, there is a version of you that has done everything you ever wanted and dreamed of. So none of it really matters. But people and relationships do matter.

Title: Best picture winner at the Oscar's? Are you kidding me?!
Review:
The Oscars, as we knew them, are no more - haven't been for a while, actually.

Once they represented excellence, when they awarded truly great movies with prizes.

Sure, they sometimes missed the mark. Like in 1976 and 1980 (Rocky over Taxi Driver and Ordinary people over Raging Bull? - pleeease. But at least both Taxi Driver and Raging Bull were nominated)

Everything, everywhere all at once, Nomadland, Parasite, CODA, Power of the Dog - these are not great movies.

Hell, they aren't even GOOD movies. What they are, instead, are movies, that hit all the politically correct notes.

So, that is now the Oscars.

Not artistic excellence, but, as their new official rules state: The Academy of Motion Picture will disqualify movies from Best Picture contention that do not have enough black, gay and disabled actors in the cast and crew from 2024.

Actually, they have done exactly that since at least 2020.

Title: fun,fun,fun
Review:
What a triumph of a movie.

Entertainment, fun, pathos, laughs, surreal elements and a kookie unique story that suprises with every turn of the script.

This movie dosen't take itself too seriously, its aim is to entertain with a brilliant cast who outshine in bringing it alive, with keeping your attention as you ain't quite sure where things are going to in this rollercoaster ride of kinda everything all at once.

They've managed to create a great balance and thought deeply about what they are doing, bringing in their own enjoyment, cynicism, fun and double edged meanings to things, very impressive stuff that sadly makes much of the current Hollywood offerings seem banal and dry in comparison.

Title: Being Michele Yeoh
Review:
Not like anything you've ever seen. Imagine Being John Malkovich made by a mad and warring combination of Monty Python and Disney. And it's even more gonzo and weird and wild and original than that.

Unfortunately, just as you feel drawn into the existential complexities that one half of the creators are trying to explore, the other half interrupts with this godawful family values sugary nonsense. A touch of the Disney idiocy that infects and ruins an awful lot of modern cinema.

And yes it tries too hard and tries to push too many things into a too small container and goes on too long. But unlike almost all modern cinema it actually tries to push the boundaries . And succeeds in many places and many different ways.

And you simply cannot miss it. Miss Yeoh is truly spectacular. A depressed and anxious middle aged owner of a failing laundromat with a husband who wants a divorce and a daughter who seems to hate her, harried by the IRS in the person of Jamie Lee Curtis (worth the price of admission all alone), she finds that she exists in a parallel universe where she is the glamorous, rich, uber successful Kung Foo goddess Michele Yeoh. And exists also, somehow, in many, many other universes as many of the paths not taken in her life.

And it is hysterical in parts. In fact it is so good so often that one is forced to think the family values jam larded over much of it was forced upon the directors by the studio or the backers.

Title: Everything and everywhere
Review:
When I saw the trailer for this movie, I did not know what to think about, but once it won best picture at the 2022 Oscars and people were saying how good the movie was, I decided to check it out. The movie Everything Everywhere All at Once (2022) was outstanding to watch, especially with the great performances from Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan who make this movie entertaining and fun to watch with all the weird stuff that happens in this movie.

Michelle Yeoh gives a fantastic performance as the main protagonist Evelyn Wang; struggling with her family, specifically her daughter, and is learning about the multiple universes out there with the many lives she could have led. She does a lot of stuff in this movie that is impressive from emotional scenes to fight scenes, she does them all outstandingly. Evelyn's husband Waymond Wang played by Ke Huy Quan was great; letting Evelyn know about the many universes and the threat they must face to save everything, while also telling her how to gain abilities from other versions of herself. He was also great in the emotional scenes and action scenes.

The whole movie is very weird, but weird in an incredibly fun way, and it can also be funny in an incredibly entertaining way. The fight sequences are incredible to watch with Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan doing the stunts themselves, along with the many universes they show of the main character being weird, interesting, or surprising in the way they show them. The effects in the movie are exceptionally good, and another actor in this movie was Jamie Lee Curtis, who was incredibly good in the many things that happen in the movie.

The movie Everything Everywhere All at Once (2022) was incredibly good, and I recommend giving it a watch when you have the time. The use of the many universes was cool and weird, the acting was great, the fight sequences were amazing, and the whole concept of the movie is intriguing. Keep in mind that this movie is weird, so you will be asking a lot of questions on certain things that happen in all three acts of the movie.

Title: Worth watching, but just once
Review:
Cinematography was stunning - a feast for the eyes visually. I was immediately captured in the beginning, but I'll admit that this film got weirder and weirder to the point that I almost stopped watching it. Without spoiling anything, let me just say I'm glad I stuck with the film until the end. Despite the over the top ridiculousness of some of the scenes, this film successfully told a contemplative story that'll surprisingly tug at your heartstrings and keep you talking about this movie long after you've left the cinema. The cast was great. I'm glad I stuck with it, but I also don't see myself watching this again. The movie seemed longer than it actually is.

Title: Clearly this wasn't a film for me.
Review:
I have no patience with stories where some individual (or group) is tasked with saving the world - galaxy, universe, multiverse, whatever - from some unspeakable metaphysical doom. Nevertheless, at a friend's insistence amidst the pre-Oscars mania, I sat thru the entire 2 hour & 19 minute kaleidoscope of frenzied special effects, chop-socky fights, silly costumes & deep mystical dialog like "You're capable of anything because you're so bad at everything."

Giving credit where it's due, Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan & also Jamie Lee Curtis absolutely earned their Oscars. Their skilled performances furnished what little enjoyment I was able to derive from this piece of dreck. Best picture?? I'm astonished this pointless piece of supernatural fluff was even in the running! One quote from the film itself sums it up for me: "It's all just a swirling pointless bucket of BS."

Title: TRAGIC... WE'RE SO USED TO IT BEING HANDED TO US
Review:
It's so sad that if a storyline isn't handed to us, it's not good. The name of the movie is "everything, everywhere, all at once" and still you get reviews of people, describing it as "... a mashup of bizarre and strange things happening, I don't get it".... I mean??? Am I missing something? Were people expecting another Marvel movie? Or maybe the new, new, NEW "X-Men"? I like a good X-Men movie just as much as the next person, but holy @&$#! How many of them can you watch? How many of them can they make? I remember when Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon came out they thought it was a bunch of Asians dancing around on the screen. The general population thought it was crap. Ang Lee won a bunch of awards... didn't matter at the time. Now movies like Crouching Tiger are the formula for how all martial art movies look. Innovation.... INNOVATION. Think on that for a minute. Or go see the next DC/Marvel mashup. However, they only MAKE those DC Universe movies look amazing in the ads.

Title: A Masterclass in Creativity
Review:
The Daniel's are a pair of directors who need more love in my personal opinion. This being their third feature length film, it is absolutely bonkers. Having been a fan of their work for a while after seeing "Swiss Army Man," I was anticipating this movie. I had high hopes and they were exceeded. The cast is absolutely fantastic, the script oozes with complex themes of generational trauma, existentialism, and most importantly creativity, and it's an overall intriguing watch. From an outsider's perspective, the movie is nothing more than some weird, dumb movie. However, it's completely the opposite. Never have I seen a movie so perfectly balance so many genres in one film and not seem overstuffed. The Daniel's are extremely creative individuals and it shines all throughout this movie. If you haven't already seen it and you're still on the fence about this movie, go and watch it. I highly recommend this movie.

Permalink

As other reviewers have highlighted, this movie is a trip. It truly exemplifies the mental gymnastics your mind sometimes has to go through to come to a simple realization.

I loved the concept of this film and the overarching themes are deep, emotional, and powerful. It explores topics like love, mental health, regret, and how simple, seemingly meaningless decisions have a butterfly effect on outcomes. For this alone, it is absolutely worth a watch.

What didn't land for me, personally, was the attempt of comedy- mostly in the first act. It just felt too slapstick and ridiculous. Juxtaposed to the deeper themes I mentioned above, it just felt like it didn't mesh and cheapened the experience a bit.

The second act got me back into the movie and I think it didn't a pretty good job and tying all the chaos together to show the viewer what this movie was truly about.

Kudos to everyone that worked on this movie. It was chaotic for the viewer so I cannot even imagine the monumental effort that was put into directing, costume design, and editing this film.

In conclusion- This film was a wild viewing experience, truly everything you've heard it to be. I wanted to like it more than I did, but I felt like it pushed me away at times with how ridiculous it was. Thankfully, it pulled me back in to appreciate the beauty of the film was trying to say.

Title: All the realities are within your grasp
Review:
Brilliant. Good concept dealt beautifully with technology and emotions. What matters st the end is the kindness. Love truimphs hate? Or maybe not. This is the things we love to see and adore. Lots of things on my mind. A good lesson too. The failed parenthood, the burden of existence, fear of not being enough... ups and downs, everything is happening everywhere and it is happening all at once. Can we get through it? Or we will fall into the void. Watch and fall in love.

Title: Thirty minutes in, I know the Academy's got it wrong
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Weird random emotional movie
Review:
I was very very entertained wstching this movie.

It is very weird and there are people who don't understand it. Personally, I liked it very much because it is very random, funny and also very emotionally deep.

At first the viewer doesn't know what is going on but it is very easy to catch up with the plot. The special effects are astonishing and the plot is well written.

I loved the main character with all my heart and how she evolves during the play, becoming more empathetic with her child.

I think the girl who plays the daughter did an amazing job and she deserves every award possible.

The rock scene is my favourite because it is very funny, and I liked the final scene too, although it seems to be very normal compared to the rest of the movie.

I loved the father too and I empathized with him a lot.

I found it a little bit long, though.

Title: Frick'en a, best movie of 2022, calling it!
Review:
Every emotion felt. I got a lump in my throat more than once. Laughed, cheered and applauded more than a couple times. A lot was going one but I was never lost. Exceptional writing. This was a top notch, well written comedy-drama. Thank you for not treating the audience like they are incapable of understanding a multiple layered comedy. I hope more films like this emerge because it's pieces like this that truly should be a game changer. I want to go out and do weird stuff to connect with my other dimensional self now hahaha! Excellent film, wow!
7 out of 15 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: AMAZING!!
Review:
This movie felt like a hug for me, for the people who are suffering a lot, asking themselves what would happen if I did this or that? People with existensial crises and people with suicidal thoughts. Even if you think it is all useless, nothing good is going to happen and you have had enough, there is still a way out. When there is an argument, don't just throw fits, but try to understand and try to be kind, because in the end, we are all humans who are going to die one day. We are stupid and nothing matters in this infinite hole. Yeah, nothing matters, but you matter. In our tiniest, weakest, silliest lives, it matters.

Title: A new standard for what film can and should be

It was the most refreshing, original, exciting, funny, touching, creative film I have ever seen. The first true 10/10 for me. How they were able to tell a cohesive story with everything that goes on in this film is completely mind boggling.... please support this film I promise you won't regret it. A24 continues to save the film industry!

Title: Damn Near Perfect Film
Review:
A truly bizarre mix that I guess could be sold as Matrix meets Parasite. A hardcore acid trip with hilarious scenes (Jamie Lee Curtis is stunning), great acting and dialogue, and a head scratcher bonkers story. The only thing that could've made it a perfect 10 for me is if they tightened up a few scenes (they really threw everything but the kitchen sink into this everything bagel). I laughed out loud several times, got emotional, cried, and screamed during a few scenes. That's all you can ask for in a great movie. See it on the big screen.

Title: What the heck was that?
Review:
An hour in and I couldn't figure out what all the fuss was about. I just about stopped watching. I think that's where the majority of the bad reviewers stopped too.

Around the nth ending I finally saw the light. It was around the same time I finally figured out that was Jamie Lee Curtis.

It ends way better than it started and the start could have been cut by a good 20mins.

Title: Believe the Hype!
Review:
This is what going to the Cinema is all about. Great story, great acting, great action! I laughed, I cried, and I cheered. Please support this film and watch in the theaters, such an amazing experience.

Stephanie Hsu is becoming a breakout star in my opinion. She absolutely won me over in Mrs. Maisel and in Everything Everywhere All At Once she was easily my favorite part of the film. She carries with her perfect comedic timing but also with her serious heartfelt moments.

Title: If one can get past the first 30 minutes it all ends in a brilliant mess!
Review:
In the first 30 minutes, I considered leaving the theater disappointed (the trailer made it look like an awesome film).

I've seen most A24 films, and all have been quite amazing in one way or another.

I'm glad I stayed in the end, though there were points where I did think, "is it over yet?. This is usually only a feeling I get if it's not a very good screenplay or the director has no idea how to end it, or Hollywood decides to take over an ending.

Michelle Yeung is an excellent and brilliant actress and now has shown she can be quite hilarious too.

The daughter in the film I was very impressed with as a young actor with her many different takes on her character, and halfway through, I realized the dad was the kid in the 2nd Indiana Jones film!

The costumes and sets were amazing, and some only appeared for 3 seconds! The directors get high props from basically everything all at once in the editing and filming, except the kitchen sink, as the saying goes.

The screenwriters get props as well with some great comedy hot dog hand universe, and one of my favs was the bagel of existential despair.

There are great moments of Zen-like silences of contemplation in the chaos, like the "2 rocks" overlooking the immense canyons of the creation scene.

However, at its heart, it's really about family, unconditional love, the fears of losing out on something that passed us by when married, but foremost was the bonds of love and hate that all mothers and daughters struggle with we find comes universally, no matter what culture you come from.

A must-see but not perfect or a masterpiece, but I do not believe that was the intent in the end. It's meant to be chaotic, silly, and philosophical.

Sadly with way too many tv and films blasting multi-universe themes these days, I hope all can catch this film before it's too late, like when our pop culture ruins such brilliant ideas and themes if it hasn't already. It may be too late anyway but perhaps not in an alternative A24 Chinese family experiential film universe!

Title: Bored
Review:
I'm trying to sit through this very difficult movie to the end, but my brain gave up after about half an hour. There is no way to make sense of any of this. Is it supposed to be clever? Funny? (It is funny in parts, I suppose) I knew it would be confusing but I expected to understand some of it. I'm bored, tired, confused and I don't care about any of the characters. It's obviously taken a lot of time and skill to produce all the weird effects, I get that. But what a waste of effort, to my mind. I'm not into alternate realities or violent computer games. I don't see how anyone can make sense of this.

Title: This movie made me ugly cry at rocks
Review:
This is my favourite movie of 2022. It does what Multiverse of Madness failed to do, which is present an interesting multiverse tale, while never losing sight of the emotional core of the movie AND exploring deep philosophical ideas at the same time.

Everyone on the cast and crew of this film brought their A game. It's incredible how good the visual effects look when you learn that it was all done by a team of 5-ish people. It made me ugly cry at rocks. There are certain scenes that will stay with me forever, especially when it comes to the character of Waymond Wang. (If you're a Superman fan, Waymond is probably the best "Clark Kent" character that I've seen on the big screen in years. He proves that being kind and believing in the best in others has never gone out of style.)

I don't want to give away any major details since half the fun of this movie is being pleasantly surprised at all of the things that happen in the film. Please go watch this movie!

Title: The most original movie I've seen in a while
Review:
The last movie which made me feel this certain type of way was Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. Such an original idea, combined with great cinematography, makes this amazing. A perfect mixture of comedy, action, sci-fi with big philosophical questions leading the plot. A true 10/10.

Review:

Title: Way Overrated
Review:
This is clearly one of the most overrated movie going and thus a huge let down. The movie is only barely watchable because of a great performance by Michelle Yeoh, otherwise it would be a flop. Watch it but wait until it's available for free.

With so many "best movie" ever type reviews attempting to drive home the exact same point, it is very much suspected most are bots or those trying to monetize the film.

The Good: Michelle Yeoh turns in an award worthy performance. Kudos to other cast members for keeping up with her.

The Bad: Thd film is overly complex, cold at times and an assault on the senses . It gets lost in the weeds mid way through and ultimately takes the writers over 2 hours to tell you what you should be feeling as a human. Fail! Ultimately the film overstays its welcome.

If you like indie style films this "may" appeal to you. However, if you want to sit back, relax and just be entertained there are better options available.

Title: A truly special, once in a lifetime film
Review:
This movie was truly something else. I had heard much praise from so many people, and I've been wanting to watch it, but I kept putting it off and putting it off. But tonight I sat down and said, "okay, I'm watching this dang movie", and an I so glad I did. From the beginning I had a feeling the movie was going to be good, even as it starts a bit slow. But it's just.....wow. There's so much I can say, but just do yourself a favor and watch this incredible movie. I don't understand how it only has an 8.2 on here, but do yourself a favor and ignore the score and just watch the movie.
3 out of 7 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: An OK but fun movie
Review:
When I watched this movie I wasn't prepared for it. I thought I would watch a Sci fi comedy, a common blockbuster movie with the usual jokes and the usual fight scenes. This movie was not that. It was weird and a bit difficult to follow at times, and it had throughout the movie an allegory for family and acceptance? Human relationships in general? It was alright, and maybe it was the factor that made this movie oscar-worthy, but I wouldn't say it was the strongest point. For me I enjoyed the humor of the movie. It made me laugh unknowingly, and I believe it is difficult to find good comedy. The fight scenes were also really nice and the actors all performed exceptionally for such an unusual movie.

In summary, I would say it was an OK and fun watch, following the "multiverse" trend. I can't say if it was oscar-worthy, but I believe it is more original and fun to watch than some previous oscar winners.

Title: What! This is a B grade effort
Review:
I'm a science fiction fan and I particularly love the time travel genre. So as soon as I heard about this movie I put on my list and was even keener to see it once it was slated for the Oscars. Talk about disappointment! How did such a B grade effort get seven Oscars, including Best Picture? The acting was okay, but nothing special. The plot was very ordinary and once you were told what it was about there was simply more of the same with a rather weak attempt at some sort of moral lesson at the end.

Every now and again we see a movie that must've had some sort of 'woke' boost, like 2016's "La La Land" (still sporting an 8 on IMDB - amazing). I believe "EEAAO" is another example of the Emperor's new clothes. I am so angered by the thought that I could have used the two hours to watch something else.

Title: bored boring most of the time
Review:
If you've seen series such as Rick And Morty this is going to feel boring. Yet if you've never seen anything like it you're in for a treat as I've yet to see a movie like it. Yes there's some humor splashed in and the casting is done quite well. They set up the story quite well where everything will work but if it was me I would have just made this into a dark humored series with 10 or 12 episodes.

My big problem is that this movie is WAY too long. Sure we've got Lord Of The Rings to James Cameron films that worked for their over the top run time but no matter how many awards this movie won the director did an awful job keeping our interest. The way they scored the movie with this big epic soundtrack playing signifying that the movie is almost over played throughout maybe last 30-40 minutes to the point which just drives you nuts where you're just pleading to your own multiverse hoping if you did something stupid or embarrassing that this 2 and a half hour long movie would finish. I found near the end of the movie they could have done serious cuts and it would not have affected the story at all. It seemed all they cared about was the special effects, the countless costumes they get the cast to wear. Some for not even a minute each.

Title: Amazing film
Review:
Absolutely gripped, fascinated and thrilled by this entire film. This film was creative, action packed, funny, very well acted and put together. The writing was excellent, the dialog AND story. The acting was perfect, no one was lacking and no one over acted either. To top it off it was casted perfectly, Jamie Lee Curtis is amazing, it was funny to see her take on a more light hearted role in this film. Michelle Yeoh, what a star, her career is making a come back and this film is proof that she is deserving of it.

Great cinematography and film sets. I loved how the film majorly took place in about 6-7 rooms in total but it felt far more than that.

Such creative ideas for all the fight sequences and designs. When it comes to the story it starts off making you think it is just another typical storyline, the big bad wants to kill the main character. But it turns Into something far more powerful.

9.0/10 from me.

Title: The best movie of the year
Review:
2022 has almost come to an end and Everything Everywhere All At Once is without doubt my favourite movie of the year. A24's new masterpiece definetly deserved the hype. It ranges from hilarious to extremly emotional. It is the funniest comedy of 2022 whilst also being a wonderful story about a small family. The action scenes are incredible and the music is used very well.

In addition, it is definetly the most creative movie I have seen in a long time. The whole cast is awesome. In my opinion, Michelle Yeoh should be nominatet for best actress.

The multiverse is handled much better than in other movies that came out this year (e.g. Dr. Strange). The attention to detail impressed me as well as the wonderful use of colour and sound.

Unfortunatly, the plot in the second half of the movie is not as focused as it is in the first one.

Nevertheless, the movie keeps you at the edge of your seat until the credits roll.

After Swiss Army Man I had very high expectations and I am happy to say that the Daniels easily subverted them.

Title: Take a peak at the Bagel
Review:
Finally saw this film after a long wait, firstly Michelle Yeoh should be nominated for an Oscar and Stephanie Hsu for best supporting role.

Maybe i've consumed too many sci-fi films and it take something utterly strange to peak my interest, however, despite the films plot having a sense of familiarity, there's a ton of originality to scratch the itch of a long-time sci-fi fan.

It's not all action tho, a good chunk of the film is a touching story of family and acceptance of one's reality and choices.
1 out of 2 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: 2 hours of Martial Arts in the Multiverse; Brilliant Last 20 Minutes & Michelle Yeoh
Review:
You have to get through the first 2 hours of Martial Arts in the Multiverse to get to the last brilliant 20 minutes of Everything Everywhere All At Once. But in the end, it all makes sense and ties things together. Fun seeing Jamie Lee Curtis in the role of the IRS Agent. I had no trouble in 1 viewing of the film understanding its general concept of family and the conflict that often exists between Mothers and Daughters. Might require a 2nd viewing to figure out some things I may have missed in the movie's first 2 hours. Michelle Yeoh as the Matriarch is outstanding, she carries the full intensity of the film with Oscar-caliber accomplishment.

Title: Beautiful and very creative
Review:

Title: I enjoyed it, but the plot could be better
Review:
I loved the effects, acting and the concept for this movie. However, when you see a movie that introduces you to a new concept, the beginning of the movie is discovering the concept, and the end is putting that into play with the main plot. For this movie, it feels a bit like it never gets out of the concept stage, then when it finally starts making progress on a plot, I wasn't particularly invested in it. I enjoyed the characters, all are wonderfully created and portrayed by the cast, but there could have been more done with the story. I recommend watching this, the jokes, the effects, the talent and the concept are all spectacular, but don't expect much in the plot. I finished this movie wanting more, but not a longer movie, just one with a better version of the plot, I am okay with a simple plot, but this plot was uninteresting and I didn't feel like very much had happened after all that work throughout the movie.

Title: Black Hole Bagel
Review:
This is the most perfect example of a movie made especially for ADHD kids who are unaible to focus more than a minute on anything relevant. They're probably even totally into this kind of brainwash movie, because they think it's the coolest thing they've ever seen.

You're wrong! Be warned! For people who prefer to use their brains instead of leaving them outside at the popcorn shop this is just the latest offence to any intelligence, in case some of it is left after you have been able to watch this thing in full length.

Technically it might be an achievement, actors are as usual unimportant in such a mess, maybe with the exception of Jamie Lee Curtis, it's unbearably silly and the only content being delivered is: Be kind and love one another!

Seriously?

Title: Everything Everywhere All at Once (2022) Review
Review:
Rewatched March 16th, 2023

Even better this time around!!! The Daniels are geniuses. How much is going on in this film is insane. But that's kind of the point of the film: trying to get through all the chaos and noise of our lives to get to what is important, our families. And the Wangs definitely felt like a family, because not everyone gets a long all the time but in the end they do love each other and will do anything for each other. I love that the initial conflict was set with the IRS because many would related to what the characters are feeling in that time.

The acting from everyone was phenomenal. Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan, and Jamie Lee Curtis all deserve their Oscar wins, and Stephanie Hsu (with a deserving Oscar nomination as well) and James Hong are excellent as well. Now I love Curtis's win (especially for her career), but after this viewing I do agree that Hsu's performance was far stronger. You can feel how passionate this film is to the Daniels so the fact that they won the Oscar's for directing and original screenplay is very deserving. The editing is out of this world so was a much deserved win at the Oscars. I remembered the costumes the first time around and was so happy that it got a nomination for it, and this viewing showed me again how amazing they were (I really would have loved to see a win here as well but I guess I can't have everything üòâ). The nominations for original score and song were very inspired, and I paid attention more to them this time around: very nice indeed. Its deserving Best Picture prize at the Oscars along with its other wins broke some stats: Yeoh became first Asian to win Best Actress, first film to win 3 acting awards and Best Picture, and its 7 wins made it the most awarded Best Picture winner since Slumdog Millionaire in 2008.

At the beginning I said the Daniels are geniuses, one thing to leave you with is that they were able to get me to cry when a rock "goes after" another rock....üò≠

Title: The bagel will tell you the real meaning of things
Review:
Some things matter.

I have had high hopes for this film and got more than I hoped for.

It's hard to go on and analyze this film since the title gives you a short summary. It's a lot and the most essential things simultaneously. Everything is complicated, but all makes sense when you think of it simply.

As for the technical part, the production, acting, and humor, everything was just done the right way.

Yet the best thing is that you can relate. It shares its emotions with you. No more words - give it a try. It's a great film.

Title: An utterly fantastic and relevent movie
Review:
What starts off as a quick trip to the IRS quickly spirals into an adventure involving multiple universes and the internal battle of absurdism and nihilism.

The movie is extremely easy to enjoy on a surface level. It has a lot of fun, snappy action, typical of that seen in Jackie Chan or Matrix movies. There's a plot at least in part based in generational trauma, and the acting is superb. The way the multiverse (as annoying as Marvel had made that term) is used makes for a lot of fun and interesting scenes, as well as the kind of drama one goes through when thinking about where their life could've gone had they just made this or that choice.

The real profound thing of the movie however is the battle of absurdism (or existentialism, depending on who you ask) and nihilism. It's the battle of "life is meaningless" vs "you create your own meaning." It's the difference between a life devoid of purpose and a life enjoyed with those around you. It's the difference of a crushing void and a blank canvas. And this movie is the journey of how one would grappel with the weighing thoughts of nihilism, only to be set free with the philosophy of existentialism.

You may not think it's a very complex subject, but it's not one touch upon often by movies, and the number of low scores on this site calling it "meaningless" only goes to show just how many (and I hate to be this guy) don't get the movie.

Title: This flick may not feature as many catchy tunes as . . .
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Title: Best film of 2022?
Review:
It says alot that in the midst of Marvel mania with recent titles such as dr strange and spiderman this film by studio A24 stands out as one of the best in recent times maybe even the best of this year. Everything Everywhere All at Once is a fun multiversal movie full of colour and comedy this film had some truly comdeic moments being and yet kept an emotional story throughout that can truly make you feel for its cast of characters. The story does a great job of setting up each characters story and manages to make sense throughout despite trying (and succeeding) to set up its multiversal rules aswell as a great story and each character in its 2 hour and 20 minute. It is a must watch for evryone this year.

Title: Style over substance
Review:
A thoroughly fun and entertaining movie, beginning to end, but lacks depth. The core of the movie is a pretty cliched story, treading on very, very well-worn ground.

It tackles a lot of big, weighty questions: the significance of our lives in an uncaring universe, midlife crisis, generational differences/overbearing parents, etc. But doesn't seem to have anything new or interesting to say about any of them. It just tells the same basic story with a new and flashy sheen.

The humor is also hit or miss. It takes a lot of shots and some certainly land very well, but much of it also is in the "OMG RANDOM!!1!one!" school of humor, which I find grating but may work for others.

The action choreography was very well done, and all of the fight sequences were a blast.

I'm also not a big fan of it pushing certain stereotypes, such as small business owners talking trash about their customers whenever they're speaking in their native language.

Title: Wow...
Review: People were raving about this film and seeing it now I can see why. I was very pleasantly surprised to enjoy this film as much as I did. As far as I knew it was a weird multiverse film but it was so much more. As I was watching and quarter of the way through it I was like damn this is weird this can't be a masterpiece surely (not in a bad way just weird). I don't mind being proved wrong sometimes. Not only is the movie about the multiverse but also about emotions and family. Michelle Yeoh was great in the movie along with her on screen husband and daughter. The film makes you relate on levels with all three characters and feel what they feel. It's a very deep film that will make you think hard after about what you saw and how you feel about it, in my personal opinion you could learn some lessons from this film about life. It's so unique and stands out from any other film it's guaranteed to make you think and feel something. The visuals in the movie are also stunning it's an absolute visual feast! So the end of the movie, after watching the main character jump universes and kick ass, the end of the movie was so unexpected. I really did not expect the movie to hit me so hard. Probably the most I've cried in a cinema, tears going down my face as I was watching it all unfold with the emotions with the characters and hitting me so hard even when I don't relate with everything it is just so human which was so surprising going into the film. Definitely check out this one for sure cause you'll get something out of it.

Title: Last 30 minutes was enjoyable.
Review:
Pretty long, messy, and was hard to keep my attention. I almost turned it off multiple times. I almost took my mother to see this. We would have had to walk out. Last 30 minutes of the film hit me pretty good, and that's why it gets a 6. The rest didn't make up for it.

Title: I guess I'm getting old...
Review:
I was very surprised when this got 11 nominations.

I watched movie a few months back, and I considered it cute experience, but nothing more.

I watched it like some lighthearted comedy.

But now - nominations didn't give me rest, and I wondered what did I miss the first time around.

I watched it again now, with my full attention to get everything I can from this movie...

Just like I did...

Title: In doubt? Just watch it!
Review:

Title: Kinda Interesting but a bit messy and long
Review:

Title: Didn't do me like others.
Review:
Ok so I will talk about small things that happen in the movie but not spoilers.

I came to this movie late as it had just cleaned out all of its awards and finally thought that I had to. It's good. The camera work is fantastic and style is remarkable. It did small things really well that producers like Disney try and fail at.

For instance: There is a female guard in one scene, this is good diversity as in real life, but where other movies would have the male protagonist and female security guard not technically strike each other, the male character smash's her. THIS IS GREAT! I woman in that position would be in line for physical altercations and dives right in. Most directors and produces want there cake (to include the female guard) and to eat it to (no fighting with the female guard). This is realistic and makes the whole situation believable.

This is one example of small things similar that happen over and over again. It is eerily close to real life which I don't think I've seen depicted in a "sci-fi" movie.

Unfortunately for what ever reason it just didn't do me like everyone else. As stated above it's fantastic and was very existential which critics love, i just finished the movie and started watching YouTube... no affect left.

It's a good movie but personally I wouldn't rate it any higher than 6/10 as I feel that it's lack of impact on me (a business owner and parent) is the point of art.

I am glad that it is getting rewarded as it is intelligent and has all the progressiveness of the best producers out there with out the "eye role" moments.

I recommend if you like time travel, sci-fi, alt-reality type stuff.

Title: The real madness
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Nothing Nowhere Never Again
Review:
This may be the worst movie I have ever seen. It makes absolutely NO sense, it's boring, and the acting is not good. Am I missing something here?! Are we sure it shouldn't have won all the Razzie's instead of the Oscars? I honestly don't think I've ever been so mad at myself for wasting 2+ hours of my life watching this garbage, hoping that at some point it will get better but only gets increasingly weirder and worse as the movie goes on. And how on earth did these actors win most of the acting awards?! They were simply not good, not believable, I didn't care about any of the characters. I just wanted it to end. I think at times it was supposed to be funny but it doesn't wasn't. This movie is just plain dumb.
