Title: Crazy, creative, and deep!
Review:
I love this movie. I had to rewatch it like 3 days after the first view so I could feel it in completely.

It's the same time a great, time traveling adventure, with a bonkers plot, comedy, and some truly insane sci-fi concepts, but, most importantly, it's about love, caring about the most important people in our lives, the tiny moments, that make up our most memorable memory, and, at the end of the day... depression.

Joy is depressed, she's overwhelmed, she's lost, and for most of the movie, the most important person in her life, her mom, doesn't seem to even care, or even acknowledge her presence sometimes. It's imo, an allegory for how we are constantly splitting our focus in a dozen different stuff nowadays, tying to be everywhere, but ending up been nowhere. She is stressed, and out of her mind, that she doesn't even realize what her daughter is going through. And, in a metaphorical way, she needs a interdimensional being to cross the multiverse, for her to finalize realize, she's losing her kid and to help her.

Of course, she doesn't do it alone, and, in figure of the father, Waymond, she learns that, she has to stopping fighting people, stop trying to change people, and actually, just be kind and give your love to the ones who need it, however they might need.

So, this movie is great, I loved it, as you might have noticed. It's so smart, funny, and out of the box completely with its concept, it's breaking of the fourth wall of sorts, and playing with the audience expectations a little bit too. Everyone is great in it, specially Stephanie Hsu and Key Huy Quan, who have to play multiple versions, completely different, from the same character, and they nail every single one of them. Michelle Yeoh is also really solid here, with by far the best performance I have seen from her.

Anyways, I love how it shines a light on mental health. And, at the end of the day the message is that the world is crazy, and most days, it probably doesn't make much sense, but... so what? We should enjoy the moments that do make sense, and share the found memories we have with our love ones.

To sum up, Everything Everywhere All At Once, is a great movie, with a complex story, with some serious underlining themes going on, if you want to see it, but at the same time, manages to be a crazy, and innovative movie about multiverses, with great action scenes, production value, and creative. Loved it, and highly recommend watching it. I would sum it up as Pixar movie, but in live action, and that, for me, it's one of the highest complements I could give a movie.

Title: Genius! No, really, genius!
Review:
Where to start with this masterpiece!!! You laugh hard, you cry loud, you think deep and you get a visual array. I still don't know what this movie was about but I can tell you what it's about! Family values, personal strengths and hurdles, heart ache, love story, fantasy and journey. This is what the world needs after covid, something that pushes the boundaries of all things left and right with balance. People and friends have asked me what is it about and the only answer I give, and in awe, is - "Everything Everywhere All at Once." A - MAY - ZING.

Title: A Philosophical Art Dramedy of Matrix + Cloud Atlas + Sorry To Bother you
Review:
Well.... What did I just watch here?

.... That's certainly what a lot of people will be feeling, after seeing this movie...no..sorry... "Piece of art" I should say, that meets silliness on an abstruse level. Rarely did I ever experience such an emotional rollercoaster, where it goes from silly stupid joke, to intense philosophy, back to an obscene joke, reverts back to social criticism, building up an intense emotional fraction, just to rip you out of this again with a dumb joke.

I love movies, that are dark sheep, disguised in Pikachu yellow cotton candy, so you really need to wait for some fine British drizzling, to see the actual dark core of the satire here.

The chemistry that Ke Huy Quan and Michelle Yeoh have is simply amazing and I would be VERY surprised NOT to see her winning an Oscar for this, even though dramedies tend to get robbed at the Oscars! This goes as well for an INSANE amount of editing work, that needs to be appreciated. With only 2h17 runtime it does feel almost twice as long though, which is not a bad thing, it is a long journey! You could probably write your master thesis in philosophy and social psychology completely based on those two hours, there is so much you could write about this, but I'll end it here, just go and watch it for yourself and form an own opinion.

This is the most bizarre movie you have seen in the last decade or so and the bold level of abnormality this movie delivers, while still being so meta....that's simply an accomplishment of art!

Title: Interesting
Review:
Everything Everywhere Simultaneously tells the story of a woman who is dragged into a challenging adventure where she will have to save the world. Evelyn immigrated from China to America with her husband years ago and started a new life. Leading an ordinary life with her family life and job, Evelyn suddenly finds herself in a crazy adventure where she has to save the world. Discovering other universes connected with alternative lives that she can live in, Evelyn learns that she has the only power to save the universe in the process.

Title: Genius, Brilliant... Film of the Year
Review:
This film, very unexpectedly, blew me away. In one fell swoop, it also ends all multiverse story lines Hollywood can ever come up with, and forever will be number one in it's field. It's that good.

I will not and cannot tell you the plot, you'll have to experience it yourself. But I can tell you this film is about love, regret, making peace with one's choices, and also... taxes. And it does so in the most absurd, endearing and laugh-out-loud way possible, kung fu style, in a freaking launderette.

Quick fire on the production: it's top notch, the special effects are bang on point, the performances could not have been better but most of all, the editing is beyond fantastic.

I laughed, cried, then absolutely bellowed from all this awesomeness. I cannot wait to see what this production team comes up next. Do yourself a favor and take one good decision in this universe: go for it. Hands down, film of the year.

Title: Comedic and humbling
Review:
Although having an inherently positive and humbling message that in life, however meaningless, there can be found meaning through love it can be a little cringey at points. Visually, through multiple scenery and costume channels, the film is amazingly beautiful. It slightly feels that character development could be a little more interesting at times, but, they are indeed relatable to the everyday viewer. Various stimulating action points through martial arts stunts keep the easily distracted viewer intrigued and connected to the basic, yet sometimes confusing, storyline of the film and the individual characters within. Overall, although at points one may cringe, the comedic elements, and substantial message, power the individual viewer's enjoyment.

Title: It's ok if you don't like it, this film doesnt matter to you
Review:
I knew very little about this film before watching it, all I knew was that it starred MIchelle Yeoh as a woman who learns about multiple universes containing multiple versions of herself.

I'm a big fan of Michelle Yeoh, so I was keen to see her in a film that was so unlike anything else I had seen her in.

Eventually I found myself in the right mood to watch a multiverse film, and oh my lord I'm glad I did.

I knew this film would be about roads not taken, about choices and consequences and about our personal insignificance amongst our reflections, it's what we expect from ideas that revolve around the multiverse.

What I didn't expect was a film that explored the nihilism that the multiverse concept evokes, a film that challenges that nihilism in the most beautiful way by saying "if nothing matters, then all that matters is what matters to you".

I need to explain here: My mother recently passed away unexpectedly, and I have found myself drained of everything except nihilism and anger, nothing mattered and I hated the world for pretending that it did.

This film threw my own nihilism in my face and made me look at it with the character of Jobu, a personification of nihilism/sadness/rage.

And as I watched the film I nearly fell into it, I nearly fell into the same logical pit of pointlessness. But just before I did, the film offered me a lifeline in the form of an idea:

If Evelyn can choose what matters to her, if she can choose to find significance in the connections and compassion of her loved ones and their lives together, why can't I?

This is the message in the film that resonated with me, but read these reviews and see the other messages that resonated with other people. See how other people choose/find significance in the nihilistic chaos and how it is different for each one.

For some people the message was about the selfishness of our world/culture today, with a message of hope that we are all human, all with our struggles and successes and a reminder that kindness breeds kindness.

For others the message was that when we are spiraling out of control with too many things to think about or focus on, focusing on one thing that truly matters to us can help us regain our control and find some peace/power in our lives.

See people choosing what mattered to them.

TLDR:

First, this is a film that requires you to be in a receptive/reflective frame of mind to enjoy it fully, if you aren't there or not that sort of person then you probably won't enjoy it as much ( I am so glad I waited until I was in that frame of mind).

Second, Everything Everywhere All At Once will ask you questions, the answers you find will probably change your way of looking at the world and yourself.

Third, even if the film doesn't connect with you on a deeper level, the comedy, action, and dialogue are all top notch and I would recommend the film on those alone.

Nothing matters, but it's ok, because it doesn't matter.

Title: An awesome way of telling a simple story.
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is one of those films where its style over substance, don't get me wrong I think the movie is good, but only that...good, with potential to be great! But it missed the mark for me a little bit, I didn't really care about the characters as we spend minimal time building them so it was hard to feel that deeper connection with them.

The visual effects and cinematography with some aspects of the screenplay were the best I've seen in a movie in the last couple years. It was really great to see such strong Asian actors kill it on screen with the long awaited Ke Huy Quan who was one of my favorite child actors playing Data on the Goonies and James Hong who I don't think I've seen I film from him since Big Trouble In Little China and last but 100% not least Michelle Yeoh who gives an absolutely stellar performance through-out the entire film, even going back to her kung-fu roots which I'm sure was a great sight to see for any kung-fu film fan me included.

What I didn't like about the film is all the answers are just given to the viewer, no room for the viewer to figure things out on their own. Some scenes didn't feel genuine and the script is quite stilted in some scenes, the pacing could have been better but its an a24 film so i guess that's expected .

BUT all in all its a good film with potential to be great.

Title: Still laughing after this meaningless absurdity
Review:
I read the raving reviews, then I watched the trailer and thought this isn't for me. But I was still curious after the great ratings on both IMDB and RT.

...And I just finished watching it. Oh, my. I think I'm living in the hipster-verse, where we absolutely need a movie like this to make a big, flashy statement of superficial hipster quotes: "love is love" and "please accept your children for who they are" and my all-time favourite: "be kind, you don't know what the other person is going through".

I think the writers took some tik-tok messages, added some kung-fu moves, and made a 2 hour film. I'd prefer the 1 min tik-tok messages any day, they'll save me time.

The acting is great of course (thus the 3 stars, one for each protagonist), but the scenario, writing, concept is pure cringy crap. But I get why all the great reviews and why probably this movie will win Oscar awards: because actual good american movies are dead. It seems now movies & critics reviews are made by people who are so out of sync with their emotions and relationships to others, they need to state the obvious, and claim they made art out of this.

Which reminds me of an "artist" who sold his invisible statue for 18,000. That's exactly how I feel about this movie. Like I spend my time to watch nothingness.

Title: Mind blowing
Review:
This movie was done SO WELL. It was thought provoking AND had a fantastic family message. It's definitely for adults and not for young children - but as a parent this movie really got to me. It was done so beautifully. Best movie of the year!

Title: This felt like a catharsis of an asian kid.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Future Nostalgia in a Chaotic Universe
Review:
I remember coming into the cinema with high expectations. I had avoided the trailers like the plague for a blank canvas experience. And it just blew me away.

The editing and storytelling in this movie is incredible! The story is chaotic but fast paced and has just enough of a red thread to keep you hooked.

The chaotic energy feels like a longform improv theatre show where you never know what to expect and random ideas keep making this universe you've been invited to more and more layered.

The use of VFX feels fresh and creative. Watch the interviews with the Daniels - hearing them explain the VFX creation added another round of enjoyment and reminds me of a time when VFX were a more creative exercise than just overlaying CGI.

The performances are great! It is so lovely to see Michelle Yeoh brought to the spotlight she has always deserved.

Everyone in our group of friends was feeling inspired after the film, even though we all focused a slightly different aspects of it. Wonderful cinematic experience!

Title: Better than multiverse of madness
Review:
"Every new discovery is just a reminder were all small and stupid"

Great movie, possibly the best I've seen since Covid, I truly wished it was on cinema's here so I could've enjoyed the amazing cinematography and background music but Sadly I didn't, but for sure of one of the cinema's buy it i will see it again!

The characters are lovely, even that taxes lady I actually didn't hate! The story kinda wrapped itself in the beginning and opened in the second half of the movie and in between the process left me mind blown.

The scene fights are hilarious? I know you're not suppose to laugh but I couldn't help myself, because there's a mix of everything in the movie that in a way you cant actually control your feelings and emotions.

Maybe the only flaw is that i felt some boredom after 45 minutes? I dont know im not the one to judge watching the movie on my TV screen but what i know for a fact is this movie is a MUST watch!

Title: 21st century Jackie Chan
Review:
This movie can be interpreted in two very different ways: 1) A mother trying to cope with her difficult life, strange relation with her too original husband, and especially her sour relation with her only 20 or so year old daughter, and who goes through long hallucinations of an imaginary world with parallel universes; or 2) A science fiction movie where parallel universes are created every time a decision is made, with copies of yourself in each one of them (somewhat like the many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics), and where good and bad affront each other (like in bad blockbusters). The viewer will have a difficult time deciding.

All this would be OK if it were not for the three-quarters of the movie being, admittedly well choreographed, Bruce Lee / Jackie Chan type of martial art infighting between the protagonists and their immediate surroundings. The movie would have been considerably better with 3 to 5 times less fights.

Otherwise, the acting is superb. There are some excellent moments, like the elevator scene or the scene on the top of the cliff.

Review:
I bawled like a baby at this movie. Like full ugly cry in the theatre. Go see it a lot of times. I can see myself rewatching this movie over and over.

Title: Confusing...Yet I Loved It!
Review:
EEAAO is many, many things. While it is very confusing, it is brilliant. The Daniels have probably just invented a new movie genre, that not many people will dare to touch. The many interesting plot points are what brings this movie to life. The amazingly edited fight scenes are well done to say the least. The cast is also wonderful. I loved seeing Michelle Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu, James Hong and Ke Huy Quan's breathtaking performances. I will say, I love Jaime Lee Curtis' other movies, but this wasn't her best work. She was still amazing, but her character should have got more screen time. EEAAO is a very crazy movie that will make you question some things. Chilling dialogue beautifully corresponds with the characters they were put with. Definitely watch this movie, as it is one-of-a-kind,

Title: Almost Everything
Review:
I must admit that I had no preconceived notion of the plot, so there was no layer of expectation guiding my viewing experience. What I did know was that the movie was being considered for several Golden Globe awards and starred a talented cast. I love Michelle Yeoh, the return of Data, Po's dad is always a joy, and the mom from Freaky Friday is my secret crush, what is not to like.

The minute Waymond, the young patriarch of the Wang clan, starts his parkour across the family-owned laundromat, the viewer gets a glimpse of the impending frenetic multiverse that guides the movie for the next few hours, helping it live up to its title... it really was everything, everywhere, all at once.

Throughout the movie, the director quickly and sometimes confusingly trapses through familiar plot elements that will resonate, if the viewer can pull back the curtain of the hyperactive and manic effort from the characters at play. We get glimpses of family strife, parental discord, personal discontent, disappointment, resignation, joy, redemption. To this concern, viewers, please be warned, in an effort to stay in line with the quick moving story or to just relive some of the more bizarre twists, you may need to be prepared with a thumb or forefinger ready on the pause, rewind, go back 15 seconds button. One might offer that it, in fact, adds another level to the multiverse experience. In the end, the movie slows down enough to allow the viewer time to catch-up with the plot and message before the credits roll.

For some this movie will be an exciting ride, one in which the viewer will spend with their hands in the air, exhilarated at every quick twist and turn. Amazed at the intense action fight scenes, giggling at the absurd and over-the-top visual elements chosen for various alternate worlds. For others, it will lack the needed depth to stay connected to the characters and storyline, instead wishing they could opt for an alternate universe in which the viewer decided to skip the movie and catch-up on some streaming binge worthy show.

Title: Strap in for a genre-bending thrill ride. A must-see for a million reasons.
Review:
Pro's: Imagine a movie that has the imagination and mind-bending impossibilities of the Matrix, while also pulling off the reality-jumping acid trip of Dr. Strange. Well, we have one and it's called Everything Everywhere All at Once. It's hard to describe the movie without simply retelling the story, as it truly transcends any traditional film genre. It's not an action movie per se, but it's packed with action. It's not a family drama per se, but you'll feel shades of Beautiful Boy. It's not a comedy per se, but there are genuine laughs peppered in. The movie successfully rolls the best of all of these genres into one and executes. It's also wise enough to not get mired down in any one of the subplots. It keeps moving, often at breakneck speed, too busy warping through absurd and awesome scenarios to get stuck where lesser movies would. The action and effects are thrillingly done. The production value is blockbuster level, a fact quite astonishing considering a team of only 5 people produced all the digital effects for this film. There's a lesbian daughter, but at no time does it become a "message movie" about that. There's a predominantly Asian cast, but at no time does it harp on how "important and brave" it is to tell their story, it just simply tells it without patting itself on the back. The film falls for no traps, it's interested in the plot. The runtime is on the longer side at almost 2 and a half hours, not that you would ever know. It practically crashes and bashes through to the end once it takes off. A ton of thought was put into the visual design of the film, too much to go into here. But of note is the motif of circles, which appear all over the set and costume design, representing the "too much-ness" of everything happening everywhere all at the same time. The movie opens on the image of the family reflected in a circular mirror, the daughter's "everything bagel" is a black circle (echoed when Jaime Lee Curtis circles tax forms with thick black circles), googly eyes pop up on multiple surfaces including main character Evelyn's forehead. Even the family's laundromat is a room stacked wall to wall with the circular washer doors surrounding the characters. This attention to detail is present in everything, everywhere, in the film (pardon the pun). All performances are strong and well done. Veteran Michelle Yeoh's makes her stressed laundromat owner Evelyn a real person. And in a surprise comeback is Ke Huy Quan as dopey husband Waymond. You'll remember him from his 80's stint as "token goofy Chinese kid" in The Goonies and Indiana Jones. And the first half of the movie might have you thinking he's back now to simply put on his "goofy Chinese man" hat. But by the end of the movie he's delivered the most heartfelt moments to the audience, and expanded into a layered, wise character. Rarely does a film deliver on an interesting and inventive plot, thrilling action, and real drama in a way that lands without getting distracted with any of the aforementioned pieces. It's simply a treat.

Cons: There's not much to pick at here in terms of weaknesses. If we're feeling fussy I suppose there may be a consideration, not a plot hole, that could have perhaps led the characters to a solution a bit more expediently than they pursued. Without spoiling major plot points it involves the reality jumping aspect of the film and having access to all possibilities. It seems that maybe certain avenues weren't explored that could have been in order to solve their problem. However, we as the audience have the benefit of sitting back and thinking up scenarios and solutions. Without Monday morning quarterbacking, a different (possibly better) solution may not have occurred to us in the moment either, which the characters must live through in real time and don't get to sit back from removed from the scenario. Especially in a movie like this with the adventure whizzing by at lightning speed. One other, more legitimate, quibble has to do with the Matrix-esque skill acquiring Evelyn is able to do. From what the movie tells us, that should be perfectly possible mentally. But physically, it doesn't perhaps make immediate sense why her body itself would gain or lose functionality (floppy hotdog fingers and hulked-out pinky fingers, alternately). Played more for laughs here, but still. Something to consider.

Bottom line: This is without a doubt one of the best movies of the year, as well as one of the best movies of the last few years. Genres are blended and transcended with astonishing finesse. The action comes fast and creatively shot, the drama is grounded and real, it's funny when it wants to be and it will freak you out when it wants to get freaky. It's one of those movies you just have to see to experience this strange but effective blend. It's a little bit of everything, that will take the audience everywhere, all at once. 9.5 out of 10 stars.

Title: Brilliant genre-blending cinema
Review:
A Chinese family in America is disintegrating over the stresses from a strained marriage, generational differences, and looming tax issues with their small business, all overshadowed by the spectre of unfulfilled dreams. When the boundaries keeping the multiverse apart begin to collapse, however, all possible narratives begin to not just bleed together, but collide with spectacular effect - both cinematically and narratively.

This film reminded me of all the great reasons for being a cinema reviewer - not least opportunities like this, to get to see wonderful cinema before almost everyone else - and then write and publish exhortations to SEE THIS FILM!!

Not just for the spectacle - which is considerable - but also for a wonderful, heart-warmingly, human story of love and misunderstanding, that will have tears in your eyes even while you are laughing in disbelief at some of the colossally humorous and wickedly painful pratfalls that populate this enigmatic sci-fi-slash-martial-arts flick.

The cast were absolutely splendid and I loved absolutely all of the characters - however I will make special mention of both Stephanie Hsu, who was able to demonstrate a massive yet seamless range all within the same shot - in multiple scenes - and Jamie Lee Curtis, who brilliantly pulls off what is without doubt the strangest character portrayal of her career.

This is the best film I've had the opportunity to review in quite some time and I'm very keen to see how it fares in the awards season.

Bottom line: I thoroughly recommend you see this film, so you can decide for yourself whether it's worth the second viewing I know I'll be making.

Title: Acid trip to multiverse of absurdity
Review:
So this is about a multiverse thats even more complex than comic movies' lol. I think this movie is not for everyone, though. Within the complex layers of trippy-ness and absurdity, the movie has really deep meaning.

With that said, for me, well, I got entertained on the first act, then it got REAALLY trippy and convoluted on second act, so at third act I just wanna see the closure and be done with it. Its so trippy that sometimes it gives me nausea effect, and the bizzareness and absurdity FAR outweigh the film's overall feel, even though I get what the film is trying to say.

So.. what's my final take on this film? All the actors played here gave great, ..no, superb performances. Film's message was great. Visuals and art direction were great. But it's still very hard to rate this movie. A part of me wants to rate it 9, but also wants to rate it 3 at the same time. I like it, but at the same time, not really. So.. at the end, I feel like this really isn't my jam, definitely wont ever rewatch it, even though I do like and appreciate some parts of it, especially the film's message.

Rate: not for everyone/10.

Title: NOT what I was told
Review: I was told by both reviewers here and professional critics that to GET "Everything Everywhere All at Once," I had to stick it out until the end. Even if you WANTED to turn it off after a half-hour or an hour, you couldn't, because you wouldn't understand the film's point. So, I sat through the ENTIRE film, credits included in case there was one of those little scenes at the end of them telling me that everything I'd just watched was a dream or something. But, no, there was nothing. I won't even go into the plot because umpteen reviewers here have already done that. But I will say that in the world of "over-hype," this film is in the Top Ten. If you feel like you HAVE to see it before "Oscar's Big Night," I suppose you must, but if you're reading this after the Oscars, even if this film wins Best Picture, don't bother. The "message" of the film is simplistic, and frankly, too little and too late. It will not change the world as much as the screenwriters and filmmakers may want it to. I'm giving it a 5 for Michelle Yeoh, Jamie Lee Curtis, and Ke Huy Quan. And James Wong is ALWAYS a welcome addition to any film, even one as overhyped and ultimately disappointing as this one. On to the next nominee...

Title: Not perfect, not for everyone, but definitely an experience!
Review:
This is a film unlike no other, it's up to you to decide if that's a good thing or a bad thing.

In my case I absolutely loved it, the humor landed with me every time there was a joke and the heartfelt moments were tastefully done in my opinion. The characters are there and they aren't just empty vessels for the action, the main characters all get fulfilling character arcs and even side characters get to have their own backstories developed a bit across the multiverse!

There are a ton of little cues, details and foreshadowing that pop up upon a rewatch and to someone like me who loves rewatching the movies I like, it adds a ton of value and makes for a better experience.

The movie is weird and convoluted, hard to follow at times and at some points I heard people near me in the theater say: "What are we even watching?" However if you're able to embrace this uniqueness and immense creativity, it becomes an experience like no other. So many things happen during the runtime of the film that there's always something to love, and you'll come out with several memorable moments to joke about.

The title Everything Everywhere All at Once describes the viewing experience perfectly. Some might hate it or feel overwhelmed, I loved it start to finish, nonetheless it is undeniable that its a unique experience and for this reason I consider it a must watch.

Title: The Multiverse We Needed, The Multiverse We Deserved
Review:
"Of All The Places I Could Be, I Just Want To Be Here With You"

I for one, generally refrain from using the phrase, the word, "Masterpiece" in my assessments of movies; simply cause it's a medium of artistic expressions, and therefore it is very much subjective, so using such a generalized term would pose a few questions against the very conception of having subjective viewpoints. However, in this case, I would like to make a rare exception by citing "Everything Everywhere All at Once" as a Chef-d'oeuvre, a Masterpiece.

Not only the concept but the entire demonstration is on a whole another level. Never in my wildest imaginations did I think something like this could ever possibly exist, let alone anticipate. It's just so terrifically done, almost too perfect to believe if any of this was real, or was It all a dream? With great characters, a magnificent screenplay, and scintillating technicalities; It has got everything a movie fanatic would wholeheartedly cherish, mark my words, in the time to come, this will eventually become a cult classic, that would have the power to inspire thousands of other movies.

I'm not even exaggerating when I tell that I can't point out any single flaw in it, let alone any kind of inadequacy. The whole movie is just so flawless, like an immaculate endeavor, fraught with the potions of perfection and grace. Matter of fact, I never seen a movie celebrating and taking full advantage of its peculiarities in such an imperial manner. This will mesmerize and bind your conscience until the very last frame. It is very difficult to explain in mere words, what my mind wants to convey at this moment, it is something you need to experience by yourself, only then you would be able to witness what peak filmmaking really is.

Title: Coulda Woulda Shoulda
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Oh My Godddd!
Review:
Everything Everywhere all at once is phenomenal. During my watch, the movie has surpassed my expectations multiple times. The movie has shown stuff beyond my imaginations but also holding a deep emotional core of a storyline. My mind is blown.

For comparison, Multiverse of Madness does not even come close by a mile to 'Everything Everywhere all at once'.

Title: Nothing. Anywhere. Ever
Review:
What an absolutely smelly pair of old pants on a stick. I'd love to be on the panel of judges that award the Oscars, because I'd whip them into shape. This film is boring, the characters are uninteresting and the story line a big yawn. The special effects are not even that special. The film is at least an hour too long (probably two if the truth be told). It's repetitive and not very clever. I love Jamie Lee Curtis, but she really didn't impress me in this. Is there a bias towards 'foreign' films as a backlash to all the 'me too' kind of sexism and racism? If so, then that might go some of the way towards explaining what happened here.

Title: Sometimes the hype is justified.
Review:
I haven't seen a movie with this much thought, heart, and reverence in a long time. Nor a movie actually do gay representation without it making feel like minstrel show. This was great. A little bloated hence the 8/10 rating. The acting seemed good, but not great. I feel like Evelyn was kind of week at the very end, everyone else was good.

In a movie that normally is bloated when they literally try to do everything and try 100 different genres/art-styles, it helps when you have one basic message to structure everything. SO in the end it kind of get repetitive when you get the "THEME" of the movie, but it's done in such an enjoyable way, that you forgive the fact that it treats you like a child and repeats the message like 15 times which is how long they say with rote learning it takes to memorize something.

Was a great movie, could easily recommend and A24 is really cementing themselves as the new powerhouse for indie. I can't even remember the previous champ, but I do remember there was one, it wasn't Miramax... HMM who was it. EITHER WAY great script, great message, no tokens, and managed to be orderly yet chaotic.

Title: Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022)
Review:
Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022)

(8/10):Before the year closes out I thought I'd see what all the hype is about and it's warranted,fantastic film.

It's visually stunning and filled with so much creativity that it's concept could be milked for endless sequels,yet I'd prefer it as a standalone film.

It's got a great cast in Michelle Yeoh,Jonathan Ke Quan (most famous for his child roles as Short Round and Data),Jamie Lee Curtis and James Hong, who I absolutely adore.

My biggest issue with it is it's pretty long,being almost two and a half hours, but it's proof that originality isn't dead as it has enough ideas for one or two dozen different movies.

The acting is solid and the comedy sometimes hits its mark sometimes not, but comedy is not this film's strong suit,it's purely its visuals and seemingly endless amounts of ideas.

The film is separated into three parts or chapters which does help break down the pacing a bit,which is nice but it still started to feel a bit sloggish as if you're not completely down for the length of it and completely invested then it feels very much it's length and begins to drag about halfway in.

It's pace feels fast yet it still feels long.

Issues aside I think it's a very well made film that still feels like an indie project despite it having some big names and a big budget.

The fight scenes are very interesting and well choreographed and the costumes are excellent.

I think out of every movie I've seen to come out this year I'd recommend this one the most as it's fun, creative, original and a visual treat.

Title: Laughed, cried, was amazed. This movie touched my soul
Review:
Saw this with my gf. Starts out simple enough, then things get crazy fast. Then things get hilarious. So much random stuff is thrown about, even R rated stuff. Yet despite all that, the core themes come across beautifully and masterfully. Family. Love. Forgiveness. Self Acceptance.

All the other stuff is dressing and entertaining as h*ll. Highly recommend this.

Title: Excruciating
Review:

Title: Loving each other and respecting each other's differences is not very difficult!
Review:
We have a saying in Persian language that "thorns turn into flowers by loving them" and this beautiful movie was It was like this sentence. And it had the same message.

The analysis and message of this movie was very beautiful and the timing for the broadcast was perfect. And how beautifully it showed that old and absurd ways of thinking make you unable to love even your own child because of his difference, but how beautiful everything becomes with a change of perspective.

Being human, being kind, empathizing and helping each other in this world that has become a dirty political game of some politicians, is the only salve we can put on our wounds, because none of us will live forever.

Title: One of the best films I've ever seen.
Review:
Don't listen to the negative reviews, most seem to be about length for some reason. I can see this not being everyone's cup of tea, a lot of people have bad taste, but to write a lengthy bad review for this is like criticising a solar eclipse.

I laughed, I cried, I left inspired. A cathartic and joyous experience unlike pretty much any other film you could see. The story is captivating, not a scene of hammy acting, stunning psychadelic effects, and it has perhaps the most heart of any sci-fi film ever made.

The only reason I would give this anything less than 10/10 would be to lower your expectations so that you were that little bit extra blown away by the experience.

I immediately started googling the directors/writers other work, and will be following their future releases keenly.

Do yourself a favour and watch this film. It's as close to a perfect movie as you can get.

Title: A must watch masterpiece
Review:
This movie had so many twists and turns, it was an absolute joy to watch, an emotional rollercoaster. The whole movie you felt as if you were the one living it.

The cinematography was breathtaking, every scene felt unique, every transition flawless, every moment special. The people who worked on this movie really put blood sweat and tears into it and you can feel it throughout the entire film.

The movie has so much more depth to than it seems at first, it takes you on a wonderful ride with great acting, a breathtaking story and all in all feels very complete and well planned.

The only negative in the movie was I'd say some of the humor, it felt slightly forced but still none the less it is a must watch movie which might just help you search for a way to relate to some situation in the movie.

The movie told a lot of small stories in a very well designed manner.

As a final note I would like to say that I went into this movie expecting a simple, generic comedy movie but I was extremely surprised by what it is.

Title: Clever with superb acting, though overly long if message isn't new
Review:
The plot develops slowly then picks up speed. The film feels overly long from a plot development perspective, complex as it is it could have been covered quicker. The length at least gives the actors to display their immense talents in making the crazy situations credible, and adding the right amount of humour and pathos. However, I prefer a story that needs the length rather than padding to display the actors and editor's skills I see how some find the film engrossing in how it's message develops and the characters' realisations of it, but I found myself distracted. Maybe I've heard the message before and admire the presentation but feel little impact. For others I can see it is revelationary. Whoever you are the first 15 minutes drag so don't be put off by them.

Title: Unique amazing movie that should win all the Oscars
Review:
This is one of the biggest surprises in Movie history for me. I had zero expectations, and I only watched this by coincidence but oh boy oh boy is this a marvellous piece of cinematic wonderfulness.

I only hand out 10s to the very best flawless movies and this is not that, however it comes darn close and this certainly deserves a 9/10. The main negative is that the production value is sometimes low, and a couple of times you can tell. Don't get me wrong, they do a fantastic job with a limited budget and this outshines all the superhero movies, but imagine what they could have done with double or tripple the budget? The only other "complaint" I have is that I want more. This should have been a 10 hours movie or a 10 seasons TV show and I would eat it all up. I feel a bit cheated that there is no more.

The movie is however pure brilliance. The acting is fantastic, the directing amazing, the story so unique and original that I hope all of Hollywood feel ashamed. Music and sound design is brilliant, and I cannot remember when I laughed and cried so much to a movie before. The emotions are strong with this one!

Fantastic movie that should win at least 5 Oscars, but I would not surprised if it wins more. Best movie of 2022 so far, and I hardly see any movie surpassing this. Absolutely stunning watch and I cannot recommend this enough. Go see! And see it again!

Title: This could have been a great movie
Review:
This could have been, and should have been, a great movie. It had all the right themes, a great cast, good direction but it fell down because of way too many fight scenes. Perhaps a movie with an underlying theme of the bond between a mother and daughter dosen't lend itself well to a Kung fu movie, perhaps it shouldn't be tackled by an all male team because the overabundance of fight scenes were really tiring if you're not a male comic book movie fan. I'm not but I thought I might like this movie anyway. I did like Black Panther, the action fit the movie, but this was trying to be all things to all people and it just didn't cut it. The one thing this movie reinforced was thar it might be better if women ruled the world as well as made more movies. There would be less superfluous fighting, more plot, and a shorter, but much better, movie.

Title: Fever Dream???????
Review:
What did I just watch? Listen, I grew up in the 80's and I love to see the underdog win. I cried like a baby during all the winner's speeches. Then I figured let me watch the movie. Horrible. It was literally a fever dream. I don't understand the high ratings. The acting was very good, I'm not saying it wasn't but the movie made no sense and had no order. I came on IMDB to see if it was just me. Clearly it is not just me. A giant bagel? Fighting with your feet? An eye glued to the forehead? Talking rocks? Hot dogs? Did the writer just write down his experience on LSD? I don't know. I thought I've seen it all but clearly I was mistaken.

Title: Matrix - meets Alice in Wonderland: Through the Looking Glass - meets A Wrinkle In Time - meets Loki - meets Turning Red - meets Waking Life
Review:
MY OVERALL TAKE: Overall #EverythingEverywhereAllAtOnce gives The Matrix - meets a matured Alice in Wonderland Through the Looking Glass- meets A Wrinkle in Time - meets the family relationship tension of Turning Red - meets Loki - meets Waking Life

I was excited for this film the moment I saw the trailer back in December (I believe), and it met the expectations I had for the most part..minus some of the comedic choices, which wasn't expected, but was much appreciated.

This is clearly one of the most unique and mentally stimulating films of the year (if not The most...), which means it probably already has award slots RSVP'd.

OTHER THOUGHTS:

Highlights: Where to begin! The visual effects and cinematography pairing was superb and genius for this story. I also loved the symbolism of the Evelyn and Waymond's relationship via Evelyn's uncertainty of the "Waymond" who was present at any given moment. The women all did an amazing job, but Stephanie Hsu was a standout.

Could've Been Better: Though easy to accept, I would've liked more space in Act One given to showcasing the tensions and traumas of the family, specifically between parent and child, and parent and parent. This could've strengthened some of the decisions of Acts Two and Three.

Title: Hard to describe..
Review:
I really don't know what I just watched, but it was so creativ, so original, so absurd, so funny and so serious. This movie lives up to its title, it really is everything, everywhere and all at once. Sometimes so much it was hard to proces it all, but I have never seen anything like it, and I don't know how a few people can come up with so many creative things at once. I mean a universe with hotdogfingers, fightscenes with large dildoes and a fanny bag, and all the other colorful stuff they managed to put in it.

This movie made me feel good, and I have a feeling that it's gonna be one I remember, thats why I gave it 10 stars.

Title: Comedy in class with Ferrell, Sandler, or Stiller, not much more
Review:
Simply a comedy in the likes of Zoolander, Waterboy, Dodgeball, Anchorman, Dumb and Dumber. Or maybe a fast action romp like John Wick. A digital fantasy as Freeguy. One could be generous and say it is Annie Hall in being a comedy that fits the times. Crew deserves credit for editing and special effects.

Yeoh's acting is superior and brings likability to the whole family. But Jamie Curtis? That is an average role at best. And of course too long and often too immature butt plugs, almost feels like an insult.

EEAAO is not best movie material and watching it expecting such will bring disappointment. Much easier to enjoy if you begin viewing without the 7 Oscar winner quality assumption.

Title: Absolute Trash
Review:
This pile of confusion, jumpcuts, and littered chaos doesnt have a single redeeming virtue that can qualify it to status of movie. The plot is a deadbeat trope of recycled conncepts and hacked notions scooped up by someone stepping out from 30 years of coma and having just finished watching a double feature of The Matrix and Multiverse of Madness.

It doesnt matter how many people pretend to like it or defend it by citing its nominations for awards, in truth we all know this fluff is bloated , poorly acted, unhinged, pretentious, uniteresting , bore, unwatchable and a complete waste of time and money.

Title: Whats Walts Watching
Review:
Thank god for subtitles in a universe where I don't speak Mandarin or Cantonese, but there is also plenty of English spoken.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" by the Daniels, Kwan and Scheinert is the most trippy movie I've ever seen and that's saying something.

I'm glad I was only on prescription drugs and multi-vitamins that night.

So many movies are referenced during the 2 hours and 19 minutes of screen time, including: Stanley Kubricks' "2001: A Space Odyssey", "The Matrix", "Groundhog Day" & "It's A Wonderful Life" and Anime.

Imagine that you alone could save the world, but you can barely do your taxes or save your marriage and family.

The movie plays out like a book divided into 3 chapters.

The first is "Everything" and starts after the initial set up.

It's a great excuse to film the most brilliant choreographed fight scenes since Tarantinos' "Kill Bill" & "Old Boy".

Don't be fooled by the fake end credits after the first chapter wraps.

The second chapter is "Everywhere" and the final chapter is, you guessed it "All At Once" which features the denouement.

IMDb's synopsis refers to the films star Michelle Yeohs "Evelyn Wang" as an ageing Chinese immigrant".

Fair suck of the sauce bottle IMDb we are all ageing, but this actor is only 2 years younger than this reviewer so please call her middle aged if you must!

Whereas the man who plays Evelyns father can wear that title of senior proudly.

James Hong as "Gong Gong" is one of the most prolific and well recognised Asian-American character actors of movies and television.

At 93, he is still actively working, mostly as a voice actor.

Essentially this film draws on a mother and daughters relationship/love which knows no boundaries.

Stephanie Tsu is perfect as Evelyns daughter "Joy"...even though rapper/actress Awkwafina was tipped for this role.

One of my fave visual moments is "the handshake" between mother and daughter.

It's really the ideal Mothers Day movie.

Evelyns husband "Waymond Wang", Ke Huy Kwan, is better known for his work as a child actor "Short Round" in "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom" and "Data" in "The Goonies".

In fact, its been over 20 years since he's appeared on the big screen and that was in "X-Men".

Jackie Chan was originally destined for this role.

Watchout for: Jamie Lee Curtis ("Halloween") as an IRS agent with a Buddah belly who gets her tax cheats.

She apparently was the funniest actor on the set...even though Curtis only got to deliver serious lines.

One of the best scenes is silent and involves no spoken aloud dialogue, just superimposed lines from the two central characters...brilliant cinema.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" is an insane, existential, comedic, adventure that is so close to perfect.

"Dr Strange" is going to have a lot of competition from the visual stimulation that's both funny and at times sad in this low budget Multiverse movie even though they have the power of MCU versus just 25 million dollars and a handful of geeky tech people.

This movie will help you see meaning in a universe where you sometimes feel nothing matters.

Title: you had me at everything bagle
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Only Made an IMDB Account to review this powerhouse of a movie....
Review:
I probably had the most fun in a theater ever watching this movie. The whole movie was just pure unadulterated joy and heart and it's safe to say that this is my nee favorite movie.

The Daniels keep pushing the boundaries in film making and you can tell that they have their own style by even comparing the movie to their previous endeavor, Swiss Army Man, which was also a solid film.

Easily one of the most unique, most innovative and the most thought provoking films I have seen in years.

The fact that it was an allegory of a family made it all the more powerful.

If this doesn't get all of the oscars there is something wrong with the film industry because MAN did this movie pack a punch. They wouldn't let you turn your head for a second, from the first plot twist to the final chaotic climax.

Please watch it in a theater!!!!

Title: I saw everything all at once in the trailer
Review:
If you saw the trailer you saw everything. There is not a single scene that is not in the trailer. I waited the whole movie to see something else, another form of her but nothing... sad.

The rest, it feels like 80% of the movie is talking about the gimmick and explaining what is going on. Show it and do not explain the whole movie!

I still had fun, but i wished it would have gone even more deeper and more mindfuck.

Title: Good Film but Trying too Hard
Review:
This is a good film, technically it is well made but also the story is funny, the characters loveable and the plot engaging. It does feel like it's trying to hard at points though. Without going into spoilers, there are moments where something weird is thrown in and while at times it is funny, every now and then it feels like the directors trying are trying to make me point at the screen and laugh at how wacky and original they are. It doesn't necessarily take away from the film but I think it does hold it back from being a perfect 10 for me.

I loved every performance, stand outs being Ke Huy Quan and Jamie Lee Curtis for me but Michelle Yeoh and Stephanie Hsu were good too. I was surprised at how technically inept everything was, the action all flowed really well and the special effects looked, especially impressive when you see that all VFX were done by the directors and a few friends.

This is a feel good film with some big laughs but not quite a 10/10 for me.

Title: Beautifully shot and good overall message but it falls flat
Review:
I did enjoy the movie kind of like how anyone enjoys a 6/10 movie. It started interesting but I left feeling dissatisfied and like they took it way too far. Without all the over the top actions scenes and sometimes cringeworthy comedy I think I would have loved it.

It feels like the movie doesn't take itself seriously. Therefore the viewer also has a hard time taking it seriously. This makes the message and the characters struggles feel trivial. Which really falls flat when it tries to bring fourth such a strong message. I understand it's supposed to be a movie about the meaning of life etc. Which was kind of interesting, at least how the mc resolves it. But as I said I really can't take it seriously.

Another thins is that the fight scenes are just way too long. I already know what's going to happen and dragging it out to 30 min makes me fall asleep.

To repeat what I wrote in the intro. If this movie just skipped out on the over the top "all the time" comedy and fight scenes, this would have been a really cool movie. Same messaging, same tropes but just a bit more serious and not so frivolous. And maybe left a bit more to interpretation.

If you like flashy fight scenes, slapstick comedy and you don't like when things become too real in movies. This is for you.

Title: The title says it all
Review:
This movie is truly amazing and covers so much. It is nevertheless not easy to grasp at first sight.

What starts as a video game, is in fact a deep reflexion on family relationship between mother and daughter or father and daughter, inter generation differences, married life, polarisation between people, so very true in the US. It covers the ability of every individual to make choices and become any body. The multiverse is not the one created by Facebook, but the one created by yourself where every choice you make creates 2 life's running in parallel. The additions of choices made by every individual over time then create a web of universes where all possible situations are real... And in the end, the movie leads you to the conclusion that every life is worth it whatever your choices, everyone is different and deserves respect, love and dignity. Other life's are not necessarily better, so stick to yours and enrich it with love and tolerance to others.

It is pretty deep and so surprising and unexpected in a Hollywood world used to superficiality, fashion, and short-termism... It is also incredibly creative, fun, and energetic. The actors are great, and you spend a very good time. I went with 3 other people, and 24h later, we continue to speak only about this movie and try to isolate all the ideas, thoughts, messages, references embedded in the scenario.

Congratulations to the author's, directors, actors,... You made my day!

Title: Confused?
Review:
We'll it is obviously a well made film but I didn't get it, I really have no idea what is going on. I'm currently halfway through but going to give up. It's hard to write a review because I really have no idea what I am reviewing. It started off half in English and half subtitled, within the same sentence, and from that point I was struggling. I guess it is about life but certainly not my life. I have read other reviews that people have recognised this film as the way their brains work, well I'm glad that I don't live in their heads, far to manic for me. I would recommend that you watch this and see what it means to you.

Title: All kinds of mad, epic, delightful, and gorgeous! [+87%]
Review:
Writer-director duo Dan Kwan & Daniel Scheinert take the simplest of premises (a woman doing her taxes) featuring the simplest of conflicts (the uneasy mom-daughter scenario) and spins a fascinatingly wacky tale out of it. Visually and audibly epic, the film is a near-perfect blend of sci-fi, action, comedy, drama, and fantasy, with the cast and crew entirely aboard the ship of idiosyncrasies. It's the multiverse of madness like you've never imagined, taking you through different circumstances featuring the same characters but managing to stay coherent and engaging. There's no doubt that the film offers a lot to take in a single watch, but this is one of those works that warrant multiple viewings. Michelle Yeoh is genuinely on fire here (be it in handling the drama or the action set-pieces), and so is the entire supporting cast featuring actors from various ethnicities.

Title: A magnificent work of art
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is as the title suggest, a buffet of Thought. A glimpse into the very being of humanity.

It captures the absurdism of Camus, the nihilism of Nietzsche, the existential angst from Kierkegaard to Dostoevsky. It contains the deepest of metaphysical science, with bleeding edge theories of quantum physics.

It has love. Conflict. Right and wrong. It taught me things I did not know, and it taught me things I did not know I did not know.

I laughed until it hurt. I cried tears of joy and sadness. But most of all, I thought. At times I felt I understood what this universe is. I got a glimpse of real meaning.

This movie should truly be designated as a Wonder of the World. My future children will learn more in 2 hours and 19 minutes than Master's students in philosophy. They will appreciate and digest more art than 200,000 years of humanity combined. They will see an eternal work of art, that will be treasured for centuries to come.

Everything Everywhere All at Once stands on the shoulders of giants such as 2001: A Space Odyssey, Schindler's List, and Fight Club. And it manages to overshadow them all. The magnitude of this feat can hardly be understood.

I am grateful to live in time and place to experience this work. It might just have been a statistical inevitability, but it's one I will treasure most of all.

Title: Where Soda Meets Sentiment; What?!
Review:
Entering the twilight of her underwhelming life, an exhausted laundromat owner finds an outlet. I'm not sure how much more of the plot I can give away, because the shock absurdity of it all is a big part of what makes Everything Everywhere All at Once tick. Suffice to say, it's every bit as oddly, magically confounding as the directors' previous film, Swiss Army Man, which featured a fart-propelled corpse skimming waves and dispensing profound life lessons.

Daniel Scheinert and Daniel Kwan, collectively known as "The Daniels," have carved themselves a distinct niche with these two films, alike in their polished visual excellence and strangely potent sense of sentimentality. After the sheer, gargantuan silliness of these concepts has essentially disarmed you, they posit, you're ripe for a deeper, more resonant message or two. In this case, the despondent store owner (Michelle Yeoh, who's fabulous) addresses the strain of a parent-child relationship from both perspectives and comes to terms with her own abundant, unrealistic aspirations and expectations. It's deep, powerful, universal stuff, which just so happens to be spread across a series of increasingly wacky, music-video kung-fu action scenes and random, contorted pop culture references.

Put simply, this movie is a trip. The first act is demanding, a dizzying rush of big exposition and long elaboration that whirls between English and several subtitled Chinese dialects, but that lengthy setup is essential to unlock the delightful insanity of the next hour. Once the real ride is underway, it's an uncontrollable snowball of fanny packs and razor blades. Riotously entertaining; you've gotta see this.

Overall very interesting, well made movie. It has some minor problems like being just a little bit too long but they're not enough to ruin it. Great acting, interesting concept, ordinary, but not bad story. Definitely worth seeing.

Title: Best movie of 2022
Review:
There's little to say when a movie so absurd manages to not break the fourth wall. So. Here's some bullet points: 1. The editing is crazy good, and so is the vfx(the latter having been made by only self taught people is just crazy to me) 2. The writing is very good. After someone said something and there was some silence, i thought "how would I write the rest of this conversation" and found it incredibly hard, but when the conversation actually went on, I was always surprised 3. This movie has let me give a definition of surrealism/absurdism: "saying real things with surreal events", and I think this movie is brilliant in this aspect: it tackles emotions (and philosophy, and love) without being sugary.

Title: Silly Matrix parody trip
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

Title: I Was Really Hoping To Like It. But ... !
Review:
EEAAO is likely to be the most overhyped movie I've encountered in a lifetime of watching movies. That this overlong, over imaginative, over indulgent, pastiche of a film managed to inveigle the Academy of Motion Picture Science into awarding it 7, yes 7, of the major Oscars is just beyond my comprehension.

Everyone (pun intended) seems to want to do multi - verse/ multi - dimensional films these days. Fine! But at least attempt to make them coherent enough to tell a story. The various Star Trek franchises have been doing this generally successfully for many years. The Matrix quadrilogy began with some genuinely original ideas on the concept, then later overcooked them. Marvel hopped on the bandwagon and don't look like jumping off for quite awhile. But at least the aforementioned generally had some sort of reasonably clear narrative, with which to tag along.

EEAAO has none of these attributes. Its multiverses exist as a means to an end, which believe you me, at 139 minutes is a very long time coming and indeed seemed much longer to this disappointed punter. The whole film seems like one great cinematic contradiction. It does have frenetic pace, but no suspense. It's marketed as a comedy. Yet, I found it best, as amusing in parts. It's full of dialogue, which is constantly repetitive and lacks any form of wit or cleverness. There are plenty of martial arts scenes which look almost deliberately over - choreographed, unrealistic and illusory. It does have a predictably (surprisingly brief in the context of the whole film) happy ending. It's just that it's irritatingly baffling, how we all get to it.

I've been a huge Michelle Yeo fan for many, many years. But to think that her albeit, zany, quirky, performance here, was considered superior to that of Cate Blanchett, who delivers one of the GREAT cinematic performances in Tar. Well to say I'm flabbergasted, is very much an understatement. Similarly, whilst Jamie Lee Curtis is a much admired actress, all she really does here is wear drab clothes, various wigs, prosthetics and shout a lot. This is deserving of an Oscar? Go figure.

EEAAO is a mediocre fantasy film with little grounding in actual reality. (Don't even get me started on bagels.) Its greatest attributes as far as I can see are that it looks, production wise, to be a bigger budgeted movie than it really is and its quick fire editing serves to disguise, one can only assume, its numerous deficiencies from its host of fawning admirers.

Title: Not confusing and fun to watch.
Review:
Lot's of people are saying that it's "confusing". Well to me these people don't know what good writing is, you're supposed to discover the story along the main character. If you can predict everything or understand everything in the first 10 min it's not good writing. This movie keeps the questions going for at least half the run time, you slowly start to pick up on details and in the final moment you're supposed to 100% understand how the power works and how she's able to do everything she does. I had lot's of fun watching this and i did have my doubts but everything from the choreography to the random humour moment to the absolutely stunning visuals, everything was great! Movie is long but i feel like it could've gone forever with many possibilities. And im glad they didn't leave some ambiguity in the end to tease a sequel because it truly doesn't need one. One of the better movies iv'e seen in the last years!

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Something for Everyone All at Once
Review:
So many things to love here. Female leads. Original, and made full use of the cinematic medium -- hard to have had the same impact in a book or on stage. Most importantly, the core messages. It doesnt matter what versions of life have passed us. It doesnt matter whether some may have left us wealthier or more successful. What matters is what we want in any given moment. What matters is what makes us happy in any given moment. What matters is family. And an extension of this is that familial relationships can be conplex and the key is acceptance. Acceptance of oneself and the other. With these basic ingredients, nothing else matters.

Whats also wonderful about the movie is that its not about what you think at the outset -- the story unfolds and unravels and emerges in a wonderfully engaging way. Highly recommend.

Title: This is the life

Everything Everywhere All at Once almost does not feel real in the sense of the traditional movie experience. As thousands of reviews have stated, it felt like an acid trip of a movie, one that bombards you with beautiful scenes, thrilling action, and genuine heartfelt sentiment that has but vanished from movies that reach a broad audience. While the film takes you through a whirlwind of universes and concepts, the heart of the story lies in its simplest and quietest moments, of a family understanding one another, of love and affection that transcends worlds, shown with an almost overwhelming amount of style, yet those concepts never leave the screen. With outstanding performances from all the cast, with Ke Huy Quan especially. As the song states, This is Our Life.

Title: excellent a staple in movie history
Review:
"Everything, Everywhere, All at Once" is a mind-bending and visually stunning masterpiece that defies genre categorization. Directed by Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, the film follows the journey of a Chinese-American woman named Evelyn wang (played brilliantly by Michelle Yeoh) as she discovers that she is connected to multiple parallel universes.

The film is a thrilling blend of science fiction, action, comedy, and drama, with each element seamlessly woven into the narrative. The action scenes are breathtaking, and the visual effects are nothing short of extraordinary especially when you consider the visual effects was made by three friends from YouTube tutorials. The filmmakers also inject a healthy dose of humor, providing much-needed levity amidst the mind-bending plot.

One of the film's greatest strengths is its ability to tackle complex themes such as identity, self-discovery, and the nature of reality, without losing sight of its entertaining and accessible storytelling. The script is cleverly written and keeps the audience engaged from start to finish, with several unexpected plot twists and turns.

In addition to Michelle Yeoh, the cast is superb, with standout performances from Stephanie Hsu, Jamie lee Curtis and Ke Huy Quan. The film also features a diverse and inclusive representation of characters, which is refreshing to see in a mainstream blockbuster.

Overall, "Everything, Everywhere, All at Once" is a tour de force of filmmaking and a must-see for fans of science fiction, action, and comedy. Its blend of dazzling visuals, inventive storytelling, and memorable characters make it a standout in movie history, and a testament to the limitless possibilities of cinema.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Title: Bonkers, brilliant, moving
Review:
There are a lot of multiverse movies recently. Many are full of inventive visual ideas and special effects. Most cost a fortune to make.

This one was cheap. But it beats the Marvel multiverse movies that cost 10 times more. And the reason is simple: the script is better. The characters have emotional arcs that mean something. You really don't know how the tension will resolve until the end. And the end is moving and profound. There is real feeling here and believable, imperfect characters.

The multiverse isn't just there for inventive, fun visual effects. It is there to allow us to explore character, motivation and, remarkably, deep philosophical choices. Somehow the characters explore deep issues of free will, choice, alternative paths for their lives and whether all those infinite choices mean absolutely nothing is meaningful. For a moment, the lead characters flirt with a nihilist resolution. But choose something different. Not a trivial resolution where good things happen and everyone lives happily ever after, but a realistic acceptance of the good things in a flawed, imperfect world.

The first time I watched it I thought it was a great movie. The second time I realised it was also a deeply moving story. The third time, I realised I had still missed a lot and it deserved an unequivocal top score.

It reminded me of some of my other favorite oddball movies. Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, Being John Malkovich are good company for it.

Any move that just keeps getting better after multiple viewings has got to deserve a top score. And this is one of those movies.

Title: Felt like an acid trip
Review:
When people ask me the best song, or movie, I usually dodge the question. On what basis could I possibly answer this? There are a million different ways to rank media, so every piece of art is interesting or flawed in their own way. Also, art is subjective. I can safely say however, "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is OBJECTIVELY the GREATEST movie of all time... by FAR. This movie is incredibly ambitious, juggling 7 different themes that somehow weave together and coalesce perfectly by the end of the movie. I actually cannot believe they managed to pull off this dangerous feat of beauty. It's a visually stunning psychedelic trip incorporating weighty philosophical ideas like existentialism and nihilism in a playful and humorous way. You will feel a combination of 4 different emotions "All at Once". The line between the metaphorical and literal is blurred. It is simultaneously very basic and accessible, but also esoteric and dense. Its both lowbrow and highbrow.

"Everything Everywhere all at Once" includes 6 different genres that are somehow done perfectly. Its a drama, comedy, matrix film, Jackie Chan film, and multiverse film all in one movie. I cant criticize this movie in any way. I'm actually disgusted by how good this movie is. The acting was perfect and the pacing was spot on. Its intense (like uncut gems) that is overwhelmingly stimulating (emotionally, visually, and mentally) in the best way possible.

The political/cultural parts of the movie are conveyed in an authentic and non-soy way. It includes an older immigrant woman, her gay daughter, and a message about acceptance and love yet there was no fake, overdone "GIRLPOWER!! LOOK STRONG WOMAN" cringe. "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a 10/10 film that excels above every film I have seen on all dimensions. Please watch this film. I sound like a crazy person right now, but I promise after watching the movie, you will understand my fanaticism and thank me for the recommendation.
