Title: I got bored one day and I put everything in a movie:
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: The True Multiverse of Madness
Review:
What a bonkers, insane, emotional and hilarious ride. This film proves that Disney may have all the money but that is nothing in the face of good writing. Disney's multiverse movie (Doctor Strange: ITMOM) had a budget $200 million yet is trounced in every aspect by Everything Everywhere which has a budget of $25 million. It's all in the writing.

The film seems to start off as a conventional family drama film, with a past-her-prime mother running a small business, who is struggling to make meets end, her husband who she becomes more distant from, the daughter discovering herself but moving away from her parents in the process and the grandfather whose views are dated. The film starts off like this, but then goes absolutely bonkers, delivering some insane action-sequences and dropping a ton of information on the audience. Yet it all makes sense. At no point are you lost in the madness. You're invested the whole way through with strong characters, excellent performances and excellent handling of themes such as nihilism, existentialism, regret, love and kindness.

The acting is top-notch across the board with particular praise going to Michelle Yeoh as Evelyn and Ke Huy Quan as Waymond. Their relationship is central to the movie and the actors give it their all and deliver some truly stunning, inventive and bonkers action sequences. The visuals are also fantastic, with excellent uses of colour, lighting and camera tricks to give the film its own unique style.

The biggest takeaways from this film are the lessons it teaches. You feel like a better human being for having watched it. Despite all the madness, the emotional moments still hit hard and by the end all the pieces fall into place, leaving you satisfied. This film doesn't need to lecture the audience on modern world problems, or explain that because of its diverse casting it is some cultural moment. No. All you need is good writing.

Overall, Everything Everywhere All At Once is best described as indescribable. It has to be seen to be fully appreciated. The characters are wonderful, the acting excellent, the visuals and action are wacky in all the best ways and the deeper emotional meaning of the film really shines through. If you have to watch one multiverse film this year, make it this one.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: I cried at the end (in a happy way)
Review:
Probably not for everyone but this movie reflects on life, and in particular relates to people with sore estranged relationships with their parents as they get older. The plot can be a bit all over the place but I think that's part of the movie's charm.

I think I would recommend it to those who are willing to experience a seriously life reflecting movie, that also doesn't take itself too seriously. You don't really know or have certainty on what is going to happen next. Except constantly expecting the most ludicrous scenarios like (a universe with people having hot dog fingers lmao), but it is an emotional theatrical masterpiece. Very well made special effects, lots of funny scenes and it's ultimately a movie about life and the choices we are too afraid to make.

Again probably not for everyone but I typically like action films and enjoyed the fight scenes. I really think this movie is underrated and an amazing job in making me feel deeply. Very few Hollywood movies are able to do that for me. And why it gets ten stars from me.

Title: A beautiful journey of awareness, love, and gratitude
Review:
This movie is exactly the kind of thing modern day formulaic big box office films and rush produced streaming movies are missing nowadays. A certain special mix of whimsical, unserious, and hilarious absurdity that aims to poke fun at the banality (and eventuality) of taxes and laundry.

All while celebrating the joy that can (and should) be derived from every moment of being alive; because we are all tiny insignificant beings in an incomprehensibly large galaxy.

This movie uses cultural references and ridiculous humor unexpectedly to provoke the audience to seek self awareness and to live in the moment. Which is precisely the reason why many of the negative reviews I've read here speak more about the viewer than the movie. If you can't find humor, warmth, empathy or just appreciation for the originality of this brilliantly written story - then you need to stick to marvel movies.

In short, it's nothing shy of brilliant and for sure one of the best movies of 2022. Worth all the praise.

Title: Absolutely Everything
Review:
I don't know what to say about this movie. It's bizonkers and I love it. So wonderfully wild, creative and deep. This is the kind of movie we're all asking for when we see the 100th Fast and Furious movie coming out doing the same old thing. Its original, its new, its fresh. It somehow makes hotdog fingers a potent metaphor for the diversity and inclusiveness of love. It makes a bagel ominous and sex toys dangerous while still being deeply moving in its meaning.

Lets just hope we're not inundated with clones that completely miss the point. Replicants that see the quirk but not the depth, the crazy but not the conversation.

Title: It was okay
Review:
This movie is... okay. Not the best, most profound thing ever. Not the most confusing mess of a story. Just okay.

It takes a while to get started, but by the end of Act 1, it *really* gets started. The climax of Act 1 is over-the-top in all the right ways, and had me in tears laughing at certain points. I figured that, although the start is very slow, now that we were in THE action, the rest of the movie would be just as good as everyone was telling me it was.

And... it wasn't. This is a movie that really peaks at the climax of Act 1. Everything is absurdist, over-the-top, yet comprehensible, hilarious, and tense. All the pieces were there for a great film. But Act 2... drops the ball. Not hard, but like a gentle fluttering towards the ground, where you watch the ball descending and try to convince yourself that the ball is not, in fact, descending, but at some point you have to admit to yourself that it's far lower than it was before. It goes on an excruciating amount of time, it throws up the husband's idea of fighting as "being nice to others" despite the fact that every alternate husband we've seen so far is essentially a combat master. And apparently that's the key to unlocking the villain's heart, the villain having turned from an over-the-top, enjoyable, yet still sympathetic and mysterious force of nature, to a whiny, depressed teenage girl whose only echoes of the character she used to be are her outlandish outfits in each scene. It wasn't fighting for survival it was just... being nice? I guess?

The movie gets unusually predictable from here to the end. The only unpredictable things are the different universes, which remain the most enjoyable part of the movie. But by the time Act 2 gets going, you will absolutely know how it ends: just like any other movie out there. And so it does. They also force a happy ending for one plot thread that seemingly comes out of nowhere. Given a huge message of the film is "nothing matters, but you might as well enjoy it", I feel like it would have been much more powerful to go the direction that plot thread was clearly heading, only for the character affected to be assured that the lack of acceptance she received means nothing as long as she, herself, could be proud of who she is. In a world where being LGBT is still seen by many, especially in traditional culture, as wrong, it is unrealistic -- and unhealthy -- to hope that everyone accepts you as you are. You need to find your own happiness and acceptance, because not everyone will be willing to give it to you.

I won't mention Act 3, because it's not even really an act.

So yeah, okay film. By the time the second credits started rolling, I didn't even stay to see if it was another fake-out. I was honestly just done with the film. I can't really recommend it. Maybe just look up the action scenes as they are easily the best part of the film.

Title: One of the movie that so amazing that have a big heart in it.
Review:
One of the best film that ever made, i love science fiction film, i love action film, i love romance film, i love family film, and these film combine all of that with grace and coolness, i never found a film like this, Everything Everywhere All at Once is very cool and heartwarming, i never cry so hard watching film except this film, i love how humanly message that daniels give and spread from this film, it's like they made a family movie with science fiction on it, the cast is perfectly complete each other, i never think michelle yeoh can be my favourite actress, and i love how jamie curtis bring her unique personality in this film. I know this film will be remembered in many many years after as a greatest family, scifi, fantasy, action, and mother film.

Title: mixed feelings over here
Review:
It's an exaggerated film.

My favorite part of the film was the leading actress. Her acting is great and she's very funny but brings a much needed subtlety and sort of more calm, less dramatic vibe to this very dramatic chaotic movie.

My least favorite part, the visuals. Just personally doesn't do it for me, feels draining and like it's trying to sell more or be different and original but just doesn't get there. Just a matter of the style i guess, feels very like "oh cool look at all these ideas and elements, let's use literally all of it". If this movie were a food it'd be one of those hamburgers but the buns are glazed donuts, with onion rings, two types of sauce and rainbow sprinkles. Not everyone would eat and enjoy but it will catch everyone's attention.

I felt like the other things i loved kind of became what i didn't like after sometime. Like how it's unexpected and you can't tell what's coming, but then this element gets tired and overused. Or how it's psychological and reaches for the character's depth and complexity of their relationship to each other, but then again kind of goes too far and gets repetitive. I loved how it tackled heavier issues like suicide ideation, mental health but again, as it went on and on and just got too stretched to the point it drained my energy and it didn't feel worth it.

To finish off i loved the idea, it had a lot of potential, it has its great moments, but just doesn't get there. My biggest personal bias is that i hate romance, not as in a couple in love but as in how a message is delivered in a very positive light way but with a lot of struggle before it. "nothing matters" but "i will always be here for you" and that kinda stuff. It's just too romantic for me when things go from relatable and simple to something aiming to be beautiful and extraordinary. I think we should be kind of past that at this point as humans, as time progresses and we see how effed up things really are as a whole and instead of being proactive we try to escape to a better, more digestible place where we can be comfortable again.

Title: An LGBT Pro movie with a pinch of humor
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

Title: Too much blinking effects
Review:
I could not endure this movie to the very end. Just could not bear the blinking effects and the fast changing of scenes. I see some ressemlence of a good story line, but there are a lot of plot wholes and ambiguities. It starts very slow and then it gets so fast paced and I could barely catch up with the plot. I liked the fighting shots, the arrangement and filming of the scnes, the acting was at a good level, but there should really be a less acid trip way of telling that story. I really hope that whoever caused himself the suffering to endure that movie to the very end will find it was worth it.

Title: The Oscars proves, yet again, that they live in alternate universe
Review:
There have been many occasions in the past where I've looked at movies the Oscars think are best picture (Birdman, Moonlight) and wondered what they were seeing that I wasn't. But not even close to the bewilderment I felt over this.

Apparently, there is some intergalactic conflict, and some hapless owner of a laundromat and her family are drawn into it. That sets the stage for an unrelenting, almost nauseating, set of colourful, hyperkinetic scenes that also manage to be rather boring.

I guess that buried deep in there is a message about accepting life and finding pleasure in the small things, and another message about accepting gay persons, which is fine, but it's been done better in so many movies. I guess the people who made this movie thought wrapping it inside some sci-fi adventure/acid trip would make more of an impact? I don't know.

In any case, this movie did not even come close to deserving the accolades it received. And it pains me to say this, but Jamie Lee Curtis getting an Oscar for this is absurd. Her part is tiny and took less talent than her role in the original Hallowe'en.

This movie proves my theory that you should wait several months for a movie to come out, read the most recent reviews, and you'll find the truth about a movie, not the early reviews whos objectivity is questionable.

This movie was a '2' but I am giving it a '3' for some of the visuals and a couple of interesting martial arts sequences.

Title: The best film of the year?
Review:
Well, I was really looking forward to this film and probably it was even my most anticipated film from this year. Because the Daniels delivered a great film with Swiss Army Man, which quickly became one of my favorite films. Well, and together with A24 and the creative trailers, this can only go well. Nevertheless, I also have my problems with the film.

But be that as it may, one thing is certain, because Everything Everywhere All at Once is undoubtedly the most creative film of the year. If not the most creative film of all time. This becomes clear in the first shot alone, in which you can see the family through a mirror in the film. And even if this shot is quite short, you already learn so much about the family. Well, and that also extends over the entire film, this incredible creativity. For example, when the characters talk and in the background you can see something that is actually much more important, but the characters don't notice it. And there are so many scenes that are brimming with creativity. But of course, this creativity comes to the climax when it comes to the multiverse. I mean, there are so many ideas that are simply unique and that you have never seen before. For example, if the characters want to gain access to another universe and then have to do something specific for it. The scene with the paper somehow hurts more than any fight scene and the same applies to the scene with the dildo. I mean, who comes up with such ideas? And then there are so many other ideas that you could talk about it for an eternity. Everything that has to do with Ratatouille is just so funny or the scene with the stones, with the pinatas. All this is just so great, so unique, so unforgettable and thus without a doubt probably the most creative thing I have ever seen.

By the way, someone else noticed that the melody from "It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia" appears. It may also sound similar, but I could swear it's the same melody.

Well, the fact that the film is so creative doesn't mean that the plot is good. In this case It does. Because Everything Everywhere All at Once is not a film about the multiverse, not an action film, not a typical hero's journey, it's a family film. About a family, for the family (even if some scenes are probably not suitable for everyone). I actually expected something different and rather a typical hero story in which Evelyn has to save the multiverse, but instead it's more about understanding what family really means, that you can overlook little manners, accept everyone as they are and should appreciate everyone who loves you. Well, there is so much more behind the creative facade. A damn multi-layered film that you won't soon forget.

Another great aspect of the film is also the characters and the actors who embody them. All the characters in the film are just fantastically written. This is because they all have their weaknesses and are not perfect. I hate these films in which the protagonist is just perfect in every way, masters everything immediately and has no weaknesses. But in this film, every character has any blemishes, weaknesses and bad qualities, as every real person has. Nevertheless, all characters are likeable. Evelyn, for example, is a great protagonist. On the one hand, she is quite a big asshole to her daughter because she is still stuck to old values, but we understand her more and more the better we get to know her. Well, and she is also sympathetic because she is a bit clumsy and dreamy. This also means that she cannot do everything immediately. When there are fight scenes, it takes time for her to master them and manage to enter other universes. At least on purpose. She is a multi-layered character with weaknesses, with strengths and a great character development. And the same applies to the rest of the characters.

But probably it's also due to the great actors who embody the fantastic characters. Michelle Yeoh is just great in the role and plays everything damn convincingly so that she could carry the film on her own shoulders. But fortunately she doesn't have to, because after all she also gets great support. Among others, of course, from Ke Huy Quan. Except for Indiana Jones and The Goonies, I didn't really know him, but he's probably the heart of the film. He is so naive and actually always in a good mood and always nice and he just plays a character you have to like. But Stepahnie Hsu is also great and always convincing in her role, even if I didn't really know her before. Well, and then of course there is Jamie Lee Curtis who can also be seen here in a completely different role than you are used to from her. Well, and what more can you say, except that she is also fantastic.

But as already mentioned, not everything is so perfect in my opinion. There is the first act, which I think takes too long. The characters are introduced, their relationships with each other and the film is built up, but the first act is clearly the weakest. Or then there are other little things. For example, I am bothered by the fact that in a multiverse full of different possibilities, the good and evil are mother and daughter. I know it's about family, but I still found it a bit too constructed. For example, I would have liked it better if the antagonist had been someone completely different or Evelyn herself.

Well, I'm just saying that the movie isn't perfect, but what's perfect? (Except Fight Club, of course) But even if something is not perfect, you can still love it and somehow that's probably the message of this film. Unconditional love.

Title: A modern masterpiece
Review:
Simply put, this is one of the best films of the 21st century. In my opinion, certainly top 10.

Michelle Yeoh is a tour de force playing multiple roles opposite the fantastic Ke Huy Quan, both of whom excel in the multi-faceted nature of their characters as they explore a complex, comedic and heartbreaking multiverse.

Jamie Lee Curtis is a fantastic addition, however it is Stephanie Hsu's performance that stole the show for me. She, more than any other character, excelled in the madness of the multiverse and was eye catching in every scene.

It is easy to get caught up in the visual effects, eccentric costumes and excellent fight scenes but the true brilliance of this film lies in the humanity of it all. At its very soul it is a film about family, love, loss and finding yourself. It has a great central message of acceptance and it is going to be a film we talk about for years to come.

Title: One of the greatest films I've ever watched
Review:
Wow, this film is truly magnificent. The meaningful messages it carries and the way they deliver them is brilliant. Even though the film runs for over 2 hours there isn't one moment where you as the viewer is bored or feels as though it is slogging along. 10/10, watched it once and I think it's already in my top 5 favourite films of all time.

Title: An honestly "okay" movie
Review:
The movie has undeniably good ratings. Having an above average rating, I was curious as to how the plot would go and transpire. I'm not really a sci-fi genre fan, nonetheless, I decided to give it a try.

Now, I genuinely don't know what others saw or felt throughout the film to think it deserved such high appraisal. It wasn't bad, it was just mediocre at best. Although it could be a fun and motivating experience to watch with your family, since the whole film revolved around the ideologies and difficulties of each member of the Wang family. Perhaps you can relate to some struggles and actually really enjoy the film. The characters are truly likeable in ways that you can feel the conflict within them- they make you understand their emptiness, like how they can be hopeless and hopeful all at once.

It generally depends on how you interpret the value of the movie. Joy's anguish and desperation to feel something- to find meaning in her otherwise pointless endeavor to live, the pain of feeling alone with nobody to understand you- even the closest to your heart, can be quite relatable to most people.

You should watch it, you might enjoy it- or not.

Title: A Trip.

Please give it a chance. You will not regret it.

Will be watching this again and again for a long time.

Title: Bagel
Review:
One of the most creative and revolutionary movies in years. Usually I am not the biggest fan of surreal or experimental movies that completely go wild. But this one worked brilliantly. It was the mix of dark humor and the film not taking itself too seriously in some dimensions(....) but taking it seriously in the right ones. Its a fantastic screenplay and one that will be hard to beat this year for sure. Seriously I dont know on what substances the writers were but it was the right mixture.

The acting was outstanding as well. Michelle Yeoh has never been better and for a veteran actress like her that says a lot. I really hope she gets her dues this year. A great discovery was Stephanie Hse, who surely will go her way after this film. A great supporting performance that is memorable on many different levels. It was great to see Ke Huy Quan return with to the movie world with a bang like this. Many remember him as Short Round or Data in some very famous 80s classics. He turns into a very versetaile and demanding performance as well and manages those challenges fantastically. Last but not least there is Jamie Lee Curtis who obvioulsy had a lot of fun playing her role and puts a lot of energy into it. She was great, as she played against character. Sometimes a bit too cartoonish, but then again... thats the character.

The cinematography, the score and especially the editing were top notch and make this a visual masterpiece. It works on so many layers and the re-watch factor is very high as well. I did not expect that I will love this movie is much as I did. Glad there is still braverty in the movie work to produce a wild ride of creativity like this.

Title: If part 1 wears you out, watch this in two parts
Review:
I have a suggestion for anyone thinking of watching this film. The film has a part 1 & 2 (and a part 3, but it's not relevant here). It can feel confusing and overwhelming to absorb everything happening, everywhere, all of the time. If you reach the end of part 1 (you'll know when that is), and you feel at that point that it's all just too (insert anything here), then pause it for another time. This is what I did, and I was glad. I returned later to watch part 2, and I can say that I was glad I did. But I don't know if I could have enjoyed part 2 if had not waited for another day. The ending pays off (unless you're a hardened cynic). A score of 7 from me is a good score. It's overhyped, but I still recommend it.

Title: Everything everywhere all at once, never more
Review:
I haven't watched a movie as bad as the one I just watched in a long time, called Everything everywhere all at once (2023)). The film has good actors who, unfortunately, due to the poorly told story, cut out, repeated, confused, etc..., do not contribute much to improve the film. Supposedly this movie is advertised as a comedy - there is absolutely nothing comic in it. The few attempts make already silly situations even sillier (e.g., the one where in a given universe people have sausages for fingers). There is no continuity in the 2 hours and 19 minutes of film - you can leave the room for lunch, for example, leave the film playing and, when you return, continue watching it; the unseen part (whatever it may be) will have very little importance in the 'understanding' of the film because parts are repeated with slight variations. Also, I think that about 2/3 of the film focuses on very well-choreographed kung-fu style fights that a lot of people like and that, perhaps, is one of the reasons it was nominated for an Oscar. I cannot see any other reason for the indication.

Title: I honestly don't know what to title this
Review:
Now, I don't know what I expected going in to this movie. All I know it was something about the multiverse and it looks like a B+ blockbuster film to me. I'm was so shock to see that this movie was more than that. As funny and weird this movie was, it had some heartfelt emotional moments in it with a believable message. At the end, my mind was all over the place (no pun intended) and as I'm typing this, I can't wrap around what movie I just watched and how incredible it is. I'm glad I got around the experience and it is up there as one of the best movies of all time...well, for me of course. That's all I have to say.

Title: Superb
Review:
A must watch. There is really nothing bad that can be said about this movie. Every scene is so deep and can be interpreted in numerous different ways for pretty much anyone to relate to and apply to their own life. It honestly has everything. Humor, heart, wisdom, amazing cinematography and score. The whole movie is rife with symbolism and philosophical concepts - yin/yang being the obvious ones. The existential nihilist concepts explored are unlike anything I've seen in any medium - some feel right out of the page of Schopenhauer. It's a superb film for all, but especially for those who lean toward pessimistic, misanthropic, and nihilistic worldviews, as it's a much needed reminder that there is always another way to look at things. It doesn't always have to be about the negative.

Title: So this is what an acid trip is like
Review:
I've never dropped acid, but I don't have to now. This movie has to be safer than psychedelics. What a crazy, wonderful trip. It's like Monty Python and a grown-up Alice In Wonderland had a baby, this movie. The genius is in how the creators comically weave the nonsensical, shattered pieces of a life into a beautiful mosaic. It's in how meaning takes shape stepping back to gape in wonder at the way chaos connects, or the way you choose to believe it connects. It's as much a poem as a movie.

Title: A beautiful thing I discovered
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Quirky at its best!
Review:
The movie begins by introducing a relatable protagonist dealing with everyday challenges. However, within the first 20 minutes, the plot takes an unexpected turn into the realm of parallel universes. While this concept has been extensively explored by Marvel and DC, it may not offer anything groundbreaking for audiences familiar with those franchises.

For viewers who are not well-versed in the concept of parallel universes, the movie might leave them feeling a bit bewildered as they try to comprehend what is happening on the screen. As the plot progresses, numerous elements are introduced, making it challenging for those who are not avid readers of comics or followers of recent science fiction films to keep track of everything.

Despite these complexities, the film remains an enjoyable experience for veterans of the genre and can be appreciated at least once. However, it's unclear how it won an Oscar, as there may have been other films with stronger merits.

I would still recommend 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' to individuals who already have a good understanding of parallel universes and are interested in scientific concepts intertwined with the narrative.

Title: This made me feel everything everywhere all at once
Review:
I laughed, I cried and I had an existential crisis. And now I am so very happy. This film enriched my life and I was incredibly insanely well done.

Whoever is debating watching, I highly recommend, don't hesitate for a moment longer!

Did it deserve all the Oscar's it won? I honestly don't care. The Oscar's haven't made sense to me in years. The Academy has its own ideas about what it wants to laud. Let them do it. You do you. I'll do me, maybe in several different dimensions., everywhere, all at once.

Title: Really Was Everything
Review:
Just got out from seeing this movie, and I've been scouring my brain trying to think of a film I've seen that made me laugh as hard as it made me cry. The cinematography, set design, and costuming are all so meticulous handled; you can feel the amount of love and attention every aspect was given. The different gags throughout upped the ante every time and rarely missed. The pain was so deep, personal, and specific and yet also so broadly human that it would be impossible not to be moved. I love this movie. I wish more movies were like this movie. Do yourself a favor and go see it.

Title: Trippy, entertaining and healing.
Review:
It turned out to be one of the most trippy movies that I've watched in recent times. Interesting that it came out of A24, that's usually known for indie-movies.

The trailer made it seem like it's a sci-fi "Shang Chi meets Dr. Strange & Wanda" kinda movie but nooo, faaar from it.

I'll admit that I had to do some reading/research after to movie to make complete sense of the the plot, people's interpretation and hidden meanings, but without all that, you can say that it's a movie a...family portrait (?) told in the context of a sci-fi multiverse in the form of an action-comedy-drama about self-reflection & healing.

That kept aside, the acting by everyone was really good. Michelle Yeoh finally gets a chance to do something in addition to just action and she delivered; comedy, drama, sadness, everything! So does Ke Huy Quan, but the standout IMO was Stephanie Hsu, the daughter. *slow claps*The cinematography, editing and sound design deserve special mentions.

I still have more reading to do about this lol but if you want to watch something totally out there and yet entertaining & moving, don't miss this one. Watch it in the theater to experience the trippy journey that this movie will take you on.

Title: What's all the hype about?
Review:
Did this movie deserve to be the phenomenon that it became? I would say it did, because of how much the filmmakers clearly put into it. You won't get any good reasons as to why this movie is special in the first few scenes, and even when things begin to unfold, it's still not entirely clear why so many have responded so strongly to it. Over the course of the runtime, however, you are bombarded with an endless series of unusual, unique moments that just keep coming, right through to the end. Just when you think this movie has gotten so off-the-wall that they can't possibly throw anything else that unexpected at you, they do. The main drawback is that during the final third of the movie, we get too many drawn-out, overly sentimental moments of reflection that really needed to be trimmed down to be effective. It gets a bit repetitive, to the point that I am hesitant to re-watch the film, even though there is so much to like. I still have to praise it, however--there haven't been very many movies that have gotten as bat-s%#$ crazy as EEAAO.

Title: Representing Asians
Review:
Going through all the reviews, I have to wonder how many people are white, who didn't like it. I say this because all my Asian friends rate this film 10/10 because for the first time in a very relatively western based film, we felt represented. The movie, as crazy as it was, didn't feel like it was meant for a white audience and therefore many people came away not understanding the real point of the film because they themselves have never experienced it in real life.

At the core of the film, the suffering of the daughter and the way she's treated by her mother was reflected so clearly in my own life. This film felt like it was made for me, to reflect my experiences as an Asian woman growing up and not a white woman. I've never seen that before. This film is brilliant and a must watch, but it also made me tear up because for the first time of elf seen. So I would ignore the people going in not truly understanding the point of the film - that it was never for their white experiences, but rather that it was aimed at those of us who rarely see our own life reflected in Hollywood-esque cinema.

Title: Plot is Disorganized & Too Much BDSM/Kink
Review:
I think the acting was phenomenal, and that the general storyline held a lot of promise and significance. I believe they chose a heroine and a storyline in general which provided a lot of social commentary about modern American life, and the overwhelming nature of our capitalist culture and how it punishes minorities the most.

Unfortunately, the film seems to lack an articulated or properly-maintained plot at points, and tries to juggle way too many different themes and directions at the same time to be comprehensible. I was very frustrated by how often the plot took off ramps onto another theme or action scene, without fully developing and explaining what was going on (descriptively or symbolically) in the previous scenes. I'm guessing this may have something to do with the average American's ever decreasing attention span and critical thinking skills, which seems to have negatively influenced Hollywood film directing over the years. Regardless of the real reason behind these directing decisions, it made it very difficult to absorb the material at times.

I was also disappointed with the character development of Jobu Tupaki/Joy. I never felt the audience got sufficient explanation or context behind /why/ she was so suicidal and hostile toward her mother, beyond some superficial information detailing typical parent/ teen child antagonism, or the story of split personalities due to too much multiverse switching. Someone who is going through complex suffering and struggles to develop into that character deserves a comprehensive backstory and contextual interpretation. Perhaps some of the explanations for her pain lie in inter-generational conflicts within Chinese American families, in which case that explanation may have been lost in cultural translation. But I also think aspects of her backstory and character may have also just been poorly written.

Also, there are far too many kink and BDSM material to make me feel comfortable. Perhaps, in another universe, these BDSM scenes are poorly-developed attempts at satire, and poking fun at sex-crazed American society. But I'm pretty sure the film was directly promoting a culture that for many people is often one of out-of-control consumerism, exploitation, and abuse. I get it, adding this material gives the illusion of adding prestige, exoticism, or 'intricacy' to a film. That's often the effect BDSM references have on general audiences, since that culture is taken at face value as a 'rebellion against normalcy'. Introducing BDSM themes out of context also has some kind of shock and awe effect, and can be injected in content that may not otherwise be sufficiently thought provoking. But that's just it, the real value of this material is illusive, and putting motifs of kinky practices in film to substitute more powerful messages or ideas can't fool everyone. That's not including how gross and disturbing a lot of the kink content was to begin with.

Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

Title: Deserved
Review:
Everything Everywhere All At Once , movie that bagged 7 Oscars out of 11 nominations . Actually tried to watch it on big screen but didn't got released in my region and then waited for official digital release in India , atlast got released on Sony Liv platform and finally watched it right before the night of Oscar event . Movie totally surprised me with almost everything , title actually suits for the quality of the movie too , Direction , Screenplay , Editing , Camera Work , Action set pieces , Casts Performance , etc , etc where just topnotch . Core concept of the movie is quite simple , an emotional family drama well narrated with multiversal concept . It's really inspiring and intriguing that Daniels pulled off this magic with such a low budget and small crew , as an aspiring filmmaker I'm really eager to study their process and behind the scenes of EEAAO . After Oscars there was sudden urge of hate towards EEAAO just because it won 7 awards , I truly believe it deserved each and every award it bagged . People who haven't watched , kindly watch it , I hope you like it and if you're aspiring filmmaker then definitely don't miss out .

( In a World where they assume only big budget movies can only deliver extravaganza visuals and actions , there came EEAAO a big indie film which was produced under budget of 15 million dollars with only crew of 9 people and shot within 38 days , still delivered a great visuals with intresting content comparing to so called high budget movies and not only bagged 7 oscars but also became most awarded film of all time . )

Title: Taking in the "Everything" and Understanding the "Everything"
Review:
Some of the most important ingredients needed to make a film possible are passion, determination and craft- but most importantly it takes an immeasurable amount of CREATIVITY! If it's one thing I've learned with seeing films from both A24 and The Daniels, creativity is a quality neither are short of when it comes to displaying it out to the world. With all that being said the latest venture from The Daniels, Everything Everywhere All at Once, is one of the most extraordinary and pleasantly psychotic pieces of entertainment I've ever seen on the silver screen!!! This film fires on all cylinders when it comes to displaying the abundant amount of originality and creativity behind its premise, which I something you don't see very often in movies today. It's a real rarity when finding films of this nature that not only succeeds in whacky & absurd entertainment (being action or what not), but also finding the time to deliver a meaningful & and complex story that you're unlikely to forget anytime soon.

Based on my observations from previous Daniels' productions, I came to expect the usual quirks and weirdness with their brand of humor but never did I expect for it to effectively blossom as it did on such a large scale. Tagging alongside the humor, there is a great amount of heart and feeling to further increase your emotional intake as you truly do feel just about 'everything'. The Daniels have found such a creative & moving method to demonstrate a vast array of emotions, which never feels like it will teeter too far in one direction. An immeasurable sense of fun stays with you all the way through- that's a feeling I rarely get to experience in such a consistent manner where it lingers onward after the screening. An experience like this one has managed to carefully and cleverly infuse so many emotions to feel when watching EEAAO, which can be easily trace back to the craftsmanship of this film's directing duo. All the plethora of feelings to experience here are attributed by the amazing direction & writing from Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, who allowed themselves to let their creative juices flow so openly and freely. Perhaps the only gripe I would have is that a few minutes could have been shaved off, which may not seem like a major deal at first but at times a few minutes more or less in a film can make a huge difference. As I've mentioned before, the majority of the time (practically 100%) I enjoyed myself during the screening, but it did feel ever-so-slightly longer than it needed to be. For me this was a very minor dent in the overall experience but it was not enough to damage the massive enjoyment and thrill ride this film was.

With this film still being more of an indie flick, you would think there'd more limitations as to what they are able to do here, yet the production teams utilize what's available to them and more in order to create the wild spectacle presented to you. Both practical and special effects are demonstrated throughout the film, which is a quality that may go unappreciated at first but later on you could look back it and applaud for what these filmmakers had to work with. Budgets and finances for a film of this type don't usually happen often, but for the instance of EEAAO the money was used adequately across all areas whether it be production design, costumes, visual effects or sound. As an audience member, it's a great feeling when you see filmmakers like The Daniels who seemed to have used their film's budget wisely without making it look like they deliberately cut corners to save a few bucks. It's a discouraging feeling to go see a movie nowadays and you see a blatantly incomplete product right in front of you, especially, when you see the big price tag attached to the film. In the case of EEAAO, it looks like every dollar was spent accordingly and it feels as complete as it a film should be when you see it in a theater. On both the narrative and technical levels, a film of this nature finds itself in a cozy little spot to fully display its colors in the upmost confidence without damaging itself by means of nonsensicalness & outlandishness.

Besides the filmmakers and rest of the crew, a cast makes up the other majority of creativity power behind a film. And this cast... is OUTSTANDING!!! We have here a lively and energetic group of performers that give their everything in terms of delivering dimensional performances, plus the energy behind their performances shows just how much fun they seemed to have tremendous fun while making this film. Michelle Yeoh & Ke Huy Quan are the major standouts among this cast, but it wouldn't be fair to not mention performances from Stephanie Hsu & Jamie Lee Curtis who also give some notable performances. The leading lady herself, Michele Yeoh, truly shines as an actress with her continuously impressive physicality and emotional range with a character like Evelyn Wang. Making leaps and bounds across the multiverse, Yeoh seamlessly jumps between comedic and dramatic moments with each of those showing her 110% devotion to those moments. Alongside Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan makes an explosive return to the silver screen as an optimistic hearted and fun-loving character that serves as so much of the soul among the whole cast. As to the antagonist here, Stephanie Hsu's Joy Wang acts as a good clashing figure to go up against Michele Yeoh's Evelyn. Joy's character is complicated and emotionally resonating as someone simply wanting to be accepted and loved while understanding the craziness of the multiverse, which Hsu does exceedingly well. Plus it's amazing to seeing actresses Michele Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis being given the opportunity to play characters like these at their ages and show off just how badass they can be.

Creating something like EEAAO is a once in a lifetime kind of film where you get a meaningful and humorous story as well as a wildly entertaining spectacle that brings nothing but fun to all who watch it. A24 has done it once again as a studio known for creating new and original pieces that truly standout among the mass collective of films coming out every year. The Daniels have placed themselves in a special place in people's consciousness as filmmakers that will surely blow their minds with the unexpected and wildly creative imagination to come out of any two people's brains. It's an exciting opportunity to see cast of this caliber and creative vision this distinctive to shine as bright as it has in this very cluttered world.

Title: It's not that confusing. Wholesome but no masterpiece.
Review:
I mean, it is. Barely comprehensible. The weird sci-fi-but-not-really plot with its multiverse mechanics is full of inconsistencies and at its core, does not make any sense. While other movies and shows that tackle this kind of multiverse at least try to make it plausible, this movie does not give a damn, but it doesn't feel like a failure of the creators, but a deliberate attempt to make it as nonsensical as possible.

The focus clearly was on making it visually stunning, it's essentially just a series of completely random visually interesting events happening for two hours, lot's of weird stuff happening with slow motion effects. I usually roll my eyes at snobby film critic-type people telling me to just shut my brain off and enjoy a movie because its too stupid to enjoy otherwise, just because it has some pretentious theme or was made by some overhyped auteur, while in the same breath telling me how dumb your average Marvel popcorn flick is if you turn your brain on. But this is one of the few cases where I would actually agree. It's easy to miss out on what makes this movie good if you don't leave behind your rational mind at the entrance of the theater.

Because what saves the movie in my eyes are the simple themes of nihilism, optimism and optimistic nihilism at its core ("nothing matters, so we are free to be happy"), that are nicely brought together at the end. These are not very deep philosophical concepts, mind you, but presented in a very empathic way with believable emotions by very good actors, and going out it leaves you with a very wholesome feeling that other movies tackling similar themes fail to achieve.

What I really don't get is why the movies is so overhyped. I have revived my years old IMDB account specifically to give a more balanced take to the loads of "best movie ever 10/10" and "didn't get it, too weird 2/10" reviews.

Title: Something different but is not a master piece
Review:
The movie starts with a good idea, the multiverse but from a simple human perspective, however is not going to be the most transcendental or philosophical movie although in some parts make you think about the universe. It's more something developed towards comedy, to enjoy with family or friends.

The comedy that shows is very entertaining, it's easy to digest some jokes are very funny like Raccoon-touille, which is kind of a tribute to ratatouille. But in some parts the comedy goes for the easy laugh, a lot of physical jokes like peeing and some sexual connotations, like in the universe where people have hands with sausages instead of fingers. That comedy is accompanied with great costumes for the villainess, which are very creative, flamboyant and weird, and help us to understand what is happening in her conflicted mind.

The whole movie consists in three acts, introduction, where the hero discovers her powers and access some universes with the help of another traveler of universes. The middle in which the conflict arises, and confronts the villainess. And the final act with a heartwarming resolution.

While all this take place, the movie has decent shots of different universes but gets a little short in picturing the concept of infinity -yeah, I know that's quite a difficult one- but it compensates that with a crucial question, if you see the infinity what would happen, everything would matter or nothing would? Which is the conundrum proposed by the movie.

In summary, if you want to see something different with a plot related to family and love, with some philosophy on the side, this movie is for you. Instead, if you want a movie that questions the very fabric of reality, then continue searching for another sci-fi movie.

Title: Hollywood has lost its mind
Review:
This movie could benevolently be described as an experiment in movie making. It has hardly any plot, copies from many different genres and is at times so hectic that it is hard to follow. In the end they try to tie it all together to a sentimental and nihilistic message about the value of relationships over accomplishments in life. As such, some people might enjoy it but my wife and I would have walked out if we had not been there with friends.

But I have a problem with all the accolades like the Oscars for best movie and for some of the actors. That used to mean something. But to call this the best of the year and to give Jamie Lee Curtis an award for this nothing of a performance shows how they have lost their way and the respect for their audience. They are mocking us. This movie is art in the sense that drawing a mustache on the Monas Lisa could be called art. Hollywood is hard at work of making itself irrelevant.

Title: An imaginative concept, brilliantly played
Review:
It's not perfect, being just marginally too long, slightly repetitive, very nearly dragging in the middle, and not entirely clear about whether we should care about all fates in all multiverses.

But there's an awful lot to like here. A brilliantly bold and original concept, decent cinematography and effects, a sharp , nuanced script that both sets up and pays off, featuring well realised and believable characters, with a strong supporting cast. Stephanie Hsu and Ke Huy Quan both have a blast playing various versions of their characters, and James Hong is always great value.

Above all though, this film is about the phenomenal, poignant, delightful and absolutely captivating performance from Michelle Yeoh.

It's impossible to overstate just how hypnotically watchable Yeoh is, anchoring rather than owning every scene with presence, grace and generosity. Her character act is perfect, and she makes every scene entirely believable, no matter how absurdist the movie gets.

The very slight flaws can all be forgiven because of Yeoh's magnificent performance - you'll be utterly spellbound by every look, every gesture, every word, whether she's saving the multiverse, or doing her taxes.

Title: This movie has become one of my all-time favourite movies. I deem it a must-watch!
Review:
It is long however, unlike many other movies, there are no parts I could pick to cut out. It keeps a brilliant balance between sci-fi/fantasy and being grounded in reality. Exploring the complex challenges of being an immigrant, family dynamics and that show kindness is not a weakness. The acting from all the actors is phenomenal, and trust me, these characters are no easy feat to achieve, yet these talented actors flowed through the roles, never making the illusion feel broken or disjointed. They take you through a roller coaster of emotions, making you want to cry, laugh, and re-evaluate your view on life in just the 2 hours it's on-screen. It is truly one of the most original, genuinely moving, and profoundly deep movies I have seen in a long time.

Title: Everything. Everywhere. All at Once even!
Review:
Directed by the duo of Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert--credited simply as "Daniels",--"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a masterpiece in distraction. It's like a magic trick which hides its shortcomings by overwhelming you with its originality-powered chaos. I could toss it aside by picking on its trickery, but that would be pique. I prefer to let myself go in its whimsical mish-mash creativity.

That being said, the movie's originality doesn't stand in it bringing anything new to the table, but rather in the way it mixes two aesthetic extremes. Michelle Yeoh start as Evelyn Wang, the owner of a laundromat living together with her husband Waymond (Ke Huy Quan), her father Gong Gong (James Hong) and her estranged daughter Joy (Stephaine Hsu). Their problems are as common as any small business owners: making ends meet and--guess what--taxes. Around the start of the movie, Michelle and her family heads over to the IRS office where she is confronted by Deirdre Beaubeirdre (Jamie Lee Curtis), an IRS inspector as bad as you would imagine. It is then when she is contacted by a different version of her husband from a parallel universe who briefs her about Jobu Tupaki, an evil spanning the multiverse who must be stopped at all costs. What? Did I lose you yet? No? Good. It's this steep curve in the plot which gives this movie its edge. It combines aesthetically modest and niche movies with sci-fi spectacle.

From there onwards, the movie revolves around themes of regret, love, tolerance and failure. Evelyn's familial issues continue except now she is also dealing with the new knowledge regarding the nature of reality. Still, there is no time to linger on deep philosophical questions; the fate of the entire universe--pardon me, multiverse--hangs in the balance. Chaos unfolds as the Daniels mercilessly make it rain with over-the-top action scenes and multiversal sequences which act as one of the funniest, over-the-top and original entertainment set-pieces I've seen in movies. Among all this chaos, Evelyn is the viewer's center. She quickly adapts to the conditions around her, something which depends on Yoeh's acting skills who is able to impose authority with a single look. She often pierces with a totalitarian gaze, cementing her as an A-list actress.

As for the aforementioned chaos, words would sell it short, but deep beneath its outlandish visuals, these action scenes are manifestations of large philosophical ideas involving the nature of chaos, the inevitability of destiny and what not--serious stuff.

But at the same time, the movie doesn't want you to linger on these larger-than-life ideas, and resisting its absurdism would be wrong. I am not going to resist pleasure; why should I, anyway?

Title: too much of everything, get ready for a headache
Review:
Someone thought of a concept but mistook it for a script. Instead of a plot, the focus is on making every single scene looks like a masterpiece, resulting in a mess of things that have no cohesion between them, and worst of all, it's boring beyond belief. It kinda reminded me of my adhd room, where finding place for everything is almost impossible, unless that place is garbage bin. That's how pleasant it was. It's like someone trying to be creative, but lacking creativity, so they just pile everything they can think of, on top of everything else, overstimulating and tiring

For similar story but much more pleasing to the senses, go watch short film "bao" - you can even find it on youtube. It tells the same story, but in far less pretentious way, and since it's significantly shorter, you won't end up bored out of your wits.

Thought it wouldn't be as simple as that in real life, taking the first step to improve our lifes will always be the best direction anyone can move towards.

Title: "An Unforgettable Journey Through Infinite Dimensions: 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' Delivers a Cinematic Triumph"
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is an extraordinary cinematic experience that effortlessly weaves together multiple genres to create a truly unique and captivating film. Directed by the talented duo Daniel Scheinert and Daniel Kwan, also known as the Daniels, this movie showcases their visionary storytelling and inventive filmmaking techniques.

At the heart of the film is an outstanding performance by Michelle Yeoh, who shines as Evelyn, a woman who discovers the existence of multiple dimensions during a mystical event. Yeoh's portrayal is both powerful and heartfelt, as she effortlessly transitions between different versions of herself, each with their own distinct personality and strengths. Her character's journey is not only an exhilarating adventure but also a deeply emotional exploration of family, identity, and the interconnectedness of our existence.

The visuals in "Everything Everywhere All at Once" are a true feast for the eyes. The Daniels have crafted a visually stunning universe that seamlessly blends reality with imaginative and otherworldly elements. From mind-bending action sequences to breathtaking cinematography, every frame is meticulously composed and brimming with creativity.

The film strikes an impressive balance between genres, effortlessly blending elements of science fiction, action, and comedy. It keeps the audience on the edge of their seats with its thrilling and imaginative sequences while also infusing the story with moments of genuine humor and heartwarming emotion. The script is clever and engaging, providing a thought-provoking exploration of the nature of existence while also delivering a highly entertaining and enjoyable experience.

Supported by a talented ensemble cast that includes Awkwafina and Jamie Lee Curtis, the performances throughout the film are exceptional. The chemistry between the actors is palpable, and their commitment to their roles brings an authenticity that further enhances the immersive experience.

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a testament to the power of cinema to transport us to new worlds and challenge our perceptions. With its dazzling visuals, brilliant performances, and a story that seamlessly blends genres, it is an absolute delight for moviegoers seeking a truly unique and mind-bending experience. Prepare to be swept away by this exceptional film that pushes boundaries and leaves a lasting impression.

Title: 8.5 is my actual score
Review:
Wow, this is a cinematic adventure to say the least! Being an A24 film is what initially intrigued me about this film bc other than SLICE and The Blackcoats Daughter, I've really enjoyed this film company's films. It's title is BEYOND appropriate because it encompasses soo much. This must've been an actors' dream job: showing so much range and wearing soo many different costumes. Yeoh is outrageously great, Hollywood should've put her in more varied roles previously. The humor could come off as juvenile at times (I'm personally not into anal play) and as others have said, the 3rd act is slightly long winded, but if you're open minded you definitely check this out!

Title: Michelle Yeoh and the Multiverse of Existentialism
Review:
Does anything that has happened, is happening now, will or might happen mean anything on this small speck of dust in the tapestry that is our universe? No. No it doesn't. And if it doesn't, then what's the point of it all? Why are we even here? What does it matter what we do with the time that we have?

Existential questions like this have been plaguing me since March of 2020, and they are at the very heart of Everything Everywhere All At Once-a whacky, over-the-top, surreal masterpiece of an action-adventure-it dares to ask these questions, it doesn't pull it's punches, and apologetically answers with a tale as old as time:

Love.

And that is the word I have for this marvel of a movie. And, like Marvel, the plot takes us into the Mulitverse, but not with grand spectacle and superheroes, but with the mother of a teenager.

I've said it before, and I'll repeat it now-Michelle Yeoh, isn't just a national treasure for those countries she holds citizenship in, she's simply a treasure and has delivered, probably the best performance of the year in this movie.

The Daniels (Dan Kwan & Daniel Scheinert) continue to hit project after project out of the park, and I can't wait for what they have in store for us next.

There's one last person I need to talk about, and that is Ke Huy Quan, who returned to acting after finding fame as a child star in movies like The Goonies, and Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom, and he is brilliant-and deserves all the awards as well.

On a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being "don't see this movie," and 10 being "you should buy stock in it," I give it a 15.

Title: Completely Lives up to the Title
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is precisely that, it is a film that defies genres, melts minds and breaks hearts.

At its core, the film is a stirring family drama about the potential destructive nature of the intergenerational divide, particularly in immigrant families. But it is also a laugh out loud comedy, jaw-dropping martial arts film and mind-bending multiverse sci fi (eat your heart out Dr. Strange).

Absolutely incredible performances from an instantly recognisable and brilliant cast, and a rousing, atmospheric score by Son Lux are the cherry on the cake of my favourite film of 2022.

A must watch for anyone, especially when shared with family, friends or loved ones. You will laugh, cry, and surge with adrenaline, and when it's all over you'll want to watch it again.

Give it a go, you will be exhausted by the experience. Its nowhere near what the smug critics say it is. Carry on like this and the Oscars will be meaningless.

Title: A perfect film!

Title: Just Excellent
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

It's humorous, wittingly constructed piece of beautiful and magical cinematography, to which I can relate on very deep level and which has moved me like maybe no other movie ever. It's cinema magic at its finest. I've never cried so much on a movie before, but it felt good, it felt cathartic. Though the actors and creators of this movie will never read this, I wanted to thank them, this movie has a soul of its own.

Title: Great job, Daniels
Review:
What an experience. Best movie I saw since 2019, with Parasite. I'm saying, this is cinema in its pure state. It's because of movies like this I love cinema.

Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert directed Swiss Army Man, one of the most creative movies of 2016, but in my opinion, it's limited by the need of explanations and very expository dialogues. But in Everything Everywhere All At Once, it's precisely proposed the lack of sense and logic, giving the gap to be debated philosophical questions and develop the relationship between the characters.

Evelyn is a tired, exhausted and unhappy woman because of the decisions she made and the life that these decisions resulted. She has many problems and you can understand these problems. And throughout the movie, when she is presented to the idea of multiverse, she realizes that even the worst version of us can be happy.

Michelle Yeoh. This person must win all possible acting awards. Yes, I'm talking about Oscar. His acting here is just the most perfect performance I saw in years. The scenes of kung fu, drama, comedy... She is just perfect in everything. With all due respect to Jessica Chastain and other Oscar winners, but THIS is an Oscar-worthy performance.

I want to highlight the work of editing, that's very important to organize all this multiversal mess and make that all these scenes in all these universes be fitted and connected by the message the movie wants to pass about identity, purpose, apprenticeship, family, to live the present, to forget the past, to not think about the future, to be satisfied by the life we have.

I don't know how someone can have the idea of making a movie like this. It's incredible how Daniels could make all these crazy parallels plots be so well-developed at the same time and pass so many lessons and messages all at once and that doesn't get tiresome (at least not for me). I think It's almost impossible what they make here, just a quite creative and genius mind could make this movie happen. It's because of guys like them that the cinema never dies.

A24, make this movie be in the Oscar!

Title: weird
Review: Few things in life are certain besides death, taxes, and maybe the never-ending task that is doing laundry. At least that's where the characters in writer/directors Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, collectively known as Daniels, new film "Everything Everywhere All at Once" find themselves initially. That is, until they take an emotional, philosophical, and deeply weird trip through the looking glass into the multiverse and discover metaphysical wisdom along the way. In this love letter to genre cinema, Michelle Yeoh gives a virtuoso performance as Evelyn Wang, a weary owner of a laundromat under IRS audit. We first meet her enjoying a happy moment with her husband Waymond (Ke Huy Quan) and their daughter Joy (Stephanie Hsu). We see their smiling faces reflected in a mirror on their living room wall. As the camera literally zooms through the mirror, Evelyn's smile fades, now seated at a table awash with business receipts. She's preparing for a meeting with an auditor while simultaneously trying to cook food for a Chinese New Year party that will live up to the high standards of her visiting father Gong Gong. On top of juggling her father's visit and the tax audit, Evelyn's sullen daughter Joy wants to bring her girlfriend Becky (Tallie Medel) to the party and her husband wants to talk about the state of their marriage. Just as Evelyn begins to feel overwhelmed by everything happening in her life she's visited by another version of Waymond from what he calls the Alpha verse. Here humans have learned to "verse jump" and are threatened by an omniverse agent of chaos known as Jobu Tupaki. Soon, Evelyn is thrust into a universe-hopping adventure that has her questioning everything she thought she knew about her life, her failures, and her love for her family. Most of the action is set in an IRS office building in Simi Valley (which, as a Californian, had me in stitches), where Evelyn must battle IRS agent Diedre (Jamie Lee Curtis, having the time of her life), a troop of security guards, and possibly everyone else she's ever met. Production designer Jason Kisvarday crafts a seemingly endless cubicle-filled office where everything from the blade of a paper trimmer to a butt plug shaped auditor of the year awards become fair game in a battle to save the universe. Moments of love and camaraderie. Sometimes they happen over time. Sometimes they happen all at once.

Definitely 10/10!

At times in the movie you will feel great, energetic, motivated about life and what not, but at the same time few dialogues or scenes would make you feel exact opposite of it. I am not saying its depressing but it brings up the question "nothing matters?" and it makes you feel hopeless, useless but in a good way. Yes you heard me right but how can someone feel hopeless in a good way. Hence watch the movie, you will know what I am saying. I didn't knew the cast or anything about the other crew but everything was perfect.

It's that movie when you get out of the theatre and wonder what just happened. Am I doing the right things I must do.

Title: No one can say it's not original
Review:
One thing that this movie can't be accused of is lack of originality, with the movie industry trend being to reuse content until it dries out, for sure a movie like this deserves credit.

It's a wild ride, prepare to be open minded during this trip and let yourself go with it in order to grasp the deeper message it conveys. Among all the crazy, it's clear there are some beautiful messages that I took from the film, do not stay stuck on thinking what your life could be and acknowledge its potential, in this mad Universe we are but tiny particles navigating through the cosmos in a rock, put things into perspective and realize that we do not matter that much to the Universe, be kind always and no matter how insane things get we can't help but stay close to the things and the people that truly matter.

So this for me was the movie strength, the powerful messages, the execution while original, amazingly well done and hats of to the whole cast, sometimes is just too weird. I get it, the possibilities are infinite in a multiverse concept but for humor purposes they showcase some really weird and nonsense stuff, which personally for me didn't quite work, but still most of the movie is highly engaging and as whole experience I really enjoyed it.

Thumbs up for having the guts of making the film partially spoken in a non-English language, we need more of that!

Title: Short Round's Redemption!

Title: Unexpectedly hilarious and an emotional roller coaster

The soundtrack is an ear massage. The visuals are good. The story is chaotic and strange; it's everything. The setting spans multiple alternate realities; it takes you everywhere. I imagine that people who prefer an "organized" movie may find this one difficult to watch and understand. The first 1/3 of the movie raises so many questions, but don't worry. Everything comes together at the end, all at once.

Title: Eccentric, exhausting and overwhelming adventure of sheer madness, but with a solid message at its core
Review:
An Asian woman who owns a laundromat that is dogged by tax auditors abruptly finds herself at the center of the most large-scale battle ever between good and evil spanning an infinite number of universes and alternate realities, one which ends up intertwining her meek husband, critical father and estranged, rebellious daughter. To go into too much detail about this extremely unusual plot would be unwise; it's best to go in cold and with no expectations. That way, you just might get the full effect.

For the most part, it's a fun film to watch, with surprising effects, jumping through different alternate realities coming together into one big plot. This movie keeps you on your toes with surprising ideas and sometimes unwanted or try-too-hard jokes, which can sometimes go too far for the average taste. The film's weirdness is its proud ethos; the mayhem and anarchy are the film's heart and soul. The meandering, unwieldy narrative actually fits in with the unstructured multiverse. But underneath the film's chaos, lack of logic and unapologetic absurdity, lies a twofold wholesome principle: believing in the strength of the mother-child bond and finding the good in every individual, in spite of the world's cruelty and insanity. For all the film's unruliness, there's nothing remotely misanthropic here. Far from being a grim morality tale, it's more along the lines of hard-earned wisdom. Once you understand it in that regard, it's safe to say it will stay with you.

Michelle Yeoh as the protagonist Evelyn just crushes it again; she has proven to be one of the most underrated actresses for quite some years now and with an incredibly vast range of acting. In this film, she turns an unremarkable, workaday character into a bona fide superhero whose abilities might have no limit whatsoever. Fair warning: This film will be an endurance test for some, but not without a hilarious and/or philosophical respite here and there. Recommended for everyone who wants to stretch their comfort zone of the familiar way of movies and is up for something truly different and off the beaten path.
