Title: Not sure what I just watched, but I liked it.
Review:
There aren't many movies that manage this level of absurdity. There are even fewer movies that manage to stay coherent throughout.

Everything Everywhere All at Once sure does manage both. It's hilarious yet touching. And so, so absurd.

There are pop culture references, but not too many of them; it most movies these terribly annoy me, but they were oddly fitting here.

The dialogues are often hilarious, making me laugh out loud.

The action is fun, the VFX are surprisingly good (even though apparently done by amateurs?), the props are... deliberately terrible, maybe?

I'd almost consider this a perfect movie, though there were a few times where the silliness was a bit much, and a few other times that felt a bit long. It's still a clear recommendation, though.

Not that I have any idea what I just watched. It's really quite weird.

Review:

Title: Nothing short of amazing
Review: I've watched a lot of good movies over the years. I have watched a decent amount of great movies as well. I have watched very few perfect movies, and this is one of them. From the opening scene I was hooked. The characters were so beautifully written that you fall in love with them instantly, especially Waymond. It starts out by introducing us to Evelyn, Waymond, their daughter Joy, and their laundromat. They have some issues with their taxes and have to report to an IRS examiner. From the moment they arrive at the examiners office and sit at the desk the movie changes genres completely. It goes from a movie about a small business owner and taxes to a fantastic sci-fi adventure. It's a lot to take in all at once, but that's what makes it even more interesting. We are thrown straight into the adventure just like Evelyn is. Boy, what an adventure. I won't go into detail, because honestly it's too much to explain. Behind all of the amazing special effects, action sequences, and hilarious jokes, this film is a wonderful story about family and appreciating the little things. Watching this film helped me to realize how much I have to be thankful for. It impacted me enough to make me reevaluate myself and I think that makes this a perfect film.

This is a singular, messy, fantastic, beautiful, human film. There are moments that are literally a dozen thing/feelings/thoughts/stories/histories all at once. The story is so universal and so essential with extraordinary performances by everyone in the cast.

Title: An All Time Classic... And Cinematic Miracle
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All At Once" is a cinematic miracle...

Its not only the best film of 2022 by far, its one of the greatest films of all time. This is the best original film IP, that I have seen or experienced, since the first Matrix film came out in 1999 ( for different reasons of course ). Now it shares a spot in my Top 5 films of all time ( right alonside The Matrix actually ).

I can't say the film is for everyone, as I've already seen some saying they "walked out" of the film or "The film sucks" or "its overrated" or "Its ass". These people are completely missing the incredible storytelling and social commentary of the film. Its a Multi generational family drama, that is placed inside of a euphoric, wild, insane, action packed, and visually stunning multiverse film.

The films deeper story and meaning, touches on real life subject matter and themes such as LGBT, Depression, the curse of comparison, family trauma/relationships, Existentialism, Nihilism, and Asian-American identity. Michelle Yeoh leads an incredible cast of people, who bring this storytelling masterpiece to life.

As someone that has been a fan/mark for Michelle Yeoh, since first watching her 1985 martial arts classic "Yes Madam", along eith all of her Hong Kong work in the 80s & 90s. This is the magnum opus performance of her career and that is saying alot! It would be the stunning robbery of the year, if she's not walking home with an Academy Award for Best Actress.

All in All this is all time great cinematic film, that deals with alot of real life subject matter and delivers one of the most insane and emotional trips in decades ( and for sure should win Best Picture ). An easy 5 Stars and then some...

Title: Amazing and beautiful, which received an Oscar as well
Review:
Firstly the acting is so fabulous by all actors, which keeps the movie so authentic and true.

The script is beautifully written with connecting the possibilities of a sci-fia in an completely normal world. It's a first of its kind so no wonder it won the Oscar. The directing is so on point that it just makes you wonder and appreciate the characters so much.

It's a very well executed movie in terms of story, dialogue, acting, comedy, tense, drama literally everything. The BGM is decent enough as well that connects well with the viewers.

Plus thing whole concept is created by the young generation directors and writers who deserve appreciation.

Title: Shang-Chi should hire this fight choreographer
Review:
Everything Everywhere is a chaotic multi-genre film. It is partly a family drama (mostly mother-daughter), partly sci-fi/fantasy (jumping between multiple parallel universes), and partly an action film. Fight scene weapons include folded chairs, weighted fanny packs, and office equipment. That brings to mind Shang-Chi (of the Ten Rings), who was supposed to have been taught a variety of fighting methods, but stuck to fairly traditional weapons.

Michelle Yeoh does wonderfully as a harried immigrant woman, running a laundry business, dealing with a tax audit, having her estranged father arrive (he never approved her marriage), while being dragged unwillingly into a situation where she found a universe-jumping technique (in a different universe) and created a monster that had to be stopped. The script has the mention-then-use rule. Inadmissible deductions in the audit foresee her alternate realities. A lot of fights in various universes happen in the audit office, and what appears to be butt plugs displayed there are also used later.

The problem I have is that the whirlwind of universes left me mentally breathless.

Title: Why this movie gets mixed reviews
Review:
The reason this movie is a masterpiece and won so many awards is because it pushes the boundaries of modern cinema. Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert have done something remarkable here but in order for you to get the wisdom, you have to surrender to the journey. You are not going to be able to make sense of this in your mind right away. But, if you try to stay in the moment and follow Evelyn through each scene and each experience as it unfolds, then you will find yourself laughing out loud at the absurdity. You will find yourself feeling regrets and remembering your own life as a series of choices and failures and could have beens. You will find yourself opening up to your own life and coming to terms with your own choices and ultimately realizing how important kindness and love really is. You will find yourself crying and wanting to hug your family. You will find yourself cherishing the moment.

The surrealism and utter wackiness is a device to help you surrender into the nothingness of everything. Because in the end, this life is a hot mess and we are all in some crazy vortex of limitless possibilities. And even though it doesn't make sense, we hold onto love. This movie IS a genuine modern day masterpiece. With a work of art this advanced it is almost certain that many people won't get it. Because true art pushes the boundaries of perception and most people are too comfortable in their box to let it in. But if you let go of what you think you know and surrender to this film, you will see what I mean, and it may change your life. Thanks for making this film. Thanks for being true artists.

Title: A feat of cinematography and storytelling
Review:
Great family-centered sci-fi with cool action sequences! Should watch if you like somewhat whimsical movies with positive undertones.

Also great for angsty young people who love, but struggle with, their parents.

In "Everything, Everywhere, All At Once" the Daniels accomplish an achievement akin to "Cloud Atlas" and the works of Christopher Nolan. Their film dauntlessly travels where few have gone before tackling life's hard what-ifs through manifesting different versions of self across an infinite multiverse in this reality-bending opus.

Michelle Yeoh's dynamic acting brilliantly captures the choice to face life's many questions with turmoil and love rather than frustration at lack of answers. Alongside Ke Hay Quan and Stephanie Hsu, the trio of lead actors provide inspiration for any family member faces growing pains.

Review:

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Title: Absurdly empyreal !!!
Review:
Nothing matters whether I review it or not maybe its just this cinema's magic that made me do it. EEAAO takes the viewers on a philosophical genre-blending ride through the multiverse.

The fiction of multiverse is crafted astoundingly as an allegory to our mind's absurdity and ambivalence. I am pretty sure it will amaze you, shock you, confuse you, irritate you, make you cry, laugh, and love all at once.

The film's introduction to multiple realities of life is in itself mind boggling albeit uncountable questions comes along with which the film answers with different abstract emotions making it more convincing.

"Maybe the meaning of life is kindness. Maybe we should cling to each other. Maybe we should learn to let go. Maybe it's all meaningless. Or rather... maybe it's everything, everywhere, all at once."

Title: Certainly unique, eye popping to the MAX, and a love child/letter to films past, but like many I can't understand all the Oscar wins
Review:
My quick two cents about this film. I didn't love it, but I really enjoyed it, does that make any sense? It has a bit of everything in it for someone to enjoy. A ton of inspiration taken from many films (The Matrix the most notable, little bit of Mr. Nobody maybe?, The superhero genre, 2001 for sure. Too many to name) and some really cool and normally not seen often quick brief flashes of other movies thrown about. Completely unexpected but relevant to what's happening.

Very difficult to describe this. Definitely a visual movie. An offbeat, original fantasy/reality blend, and surreal mind trip that plays out through the main story of one family's domestic troubles. A well drawn-out story that uses the multiverse to great effect and doesn't mind being more than a bit weird to take great advantage of this tool. It is a very WOKE movie, so if that's not your thing here is your warning now.

It starts really slow, almost to the point where you get a little impatient but after the first fifteen minutes, time to hit the fast forward button people literally. It loses a bit of steam towards the end but it leads to a satisfying conclusion.

Here's where I'm a bit lost, the academy awards domination. Michelle Yeoh is an amazing actress, truly enjoyed all the movies I've seen her in. I couldn't be more proud for her to win an academy award for Best Actress. The rest are head scratchers, I'm mostly unfamiliar with the other nominees other than The Banshees Of Inisherin honestly. Jamie Lee Curtis? She's hardly in this. Shocking! Stephanie Hsu got robbed. Ke Huy Quan? I don't know.... the directors, maybe? Best Picture? Really?? Best Original Screenplay and Film Editing, now that I would do all day.

A great cast selection, mixing in great veterans with some relative newcomers that have a great showcase for all their talents. Good soundtrack. As original and colorful as a movie can be, funny (Waymond and Jobu Chewbacca LOL), sad, emotional, touching and very self-aware. A very fun movie, definitely not for all tastes but perhaps the one that will be the most noteworthy release of 2022. And yes, this is one of those you have to watch more than once. Its just built that way.

Title: Hilarious, Terrifying, Painful, and Comforting
Review:
I do not want to go into too much as it really is worth viewing blind. I will say it gives me faith in fresh ideas and revamped concepts in new exciting ways. The amount of creativity is staggering, from the plot itself to the cinematography. It is worth seeing even if in the end you don't love it, you walk away with something to mull about in late night parking lots with friends eating leftover popcorn.

Title: How a complex concept should be portrayed
Review: This is one of the most interesting and complex movies I have ever seen. No other films have taken the idea of the multiverse head on and displayed it with accurately. You become immersed in the idea of an ever expanding multiverse each with its own side plot. It is not only the concept that is engaging but the directing and storytelling is peak. At first I thought the cast was mid but after this film perfectly characterized each person so well I actually came to really like them. The only thing that I would've liked/ preferred is if the film didn't act as a comedy so much as some of the jokes came off as cringe or unnecessary. I can not think of any other films to compare this to this is truly one of a kind and a much watch to anyone who can comprehend complex ideas such as this. In reality the concepts portrays are way more complicated than what was shown the film does its absolute best with the format its given to expand while staying consistent tot he main plot as possible. The film seems more as a summary since each alternate universe could be its own side story but the movie does. This can easily be a film series or a TV show on its own but compacting it all into one movie while also getting your message across is near to an impossible task for most people which is why I believe this movie should be made mandatory to watch by everyone.

Title: Pretentious Garbage
Review:
Simple: Just because something is overly complicated doesn't mean it is intellectual.

"An Intellectual is a man who says a simple thing in a difficult way; an artist is a man who says a difficult thing in a simple way". C. B.

Overrated. Way too long. Utter Nonsense. I haven't been this upset about an overrated movie since "Interstellar."

What nice things can I say? The acting was good, it was nice to see Quan and Hong again. There were some funny moments but not enough to hold my interest. The cinematography was so overwhelming that I couldn't wait for the film to end.

If this junk wins Best Picture I'll be as upset as I was when "Chicago" beat out "The Pianist" in 2003. Or when "Shakespeare in Love" beat "Saving Private Ryan" in 1999.

Title: A Unique and Interesting Movie that's Actually Quite Necessary
Review:
I didn't see this movie when it came out, but I remember it got the internet talking. It wasn't until it was nominated for the Oscars that I finally got to seeing it.

And honestly, I could see why the hype was there.

This is a very unique film filled with some excellent performances and really cool fight scenes. It also plays deep with certain topics like meaning, regret, nihilism, and multidimensional connection. All the while leaning in with a veneer of absurdism.

Michelle Yeoh plays Evelyn, an elderly mother struggling to keep her business afloat, her marriage together, and her daughter's sexual orientation a secret. There's a lot of tension and drama surrounding her family and the IRS agent that makes her very miserable. During her meeting, she learns that there are multiple universes that are at risk of destruction from an entity known as Jobu Topacky, and only she can save them. Evelyn learns how to tap into her alternate versions and learn different skills and lessons to survive.

I think a lot of the negative reviews so far come from people who couldn't get past the absurdism. I mean, there's an alternate dimension where everyone has hot-dog fingers. There are also dimensions where everyone's a rock. All this is meant to be silly. The metaverse is a motif for deeper lessons on finding value and meaning even when things look bleak. We all look back and wonder what our lives would be like if we made different decisions. We all wonder if we're truly living our best lives. We also wonder if we should simply accept our lives or demand something better.

Waymond is the true hero of this movie. Ke Huay Quan came out of retirement for this role and absolutely nails it. The sad, sweet husband tries so hard to bring out the best in Evelyn even when she won't listen and delivers I think the true message of the film: make the most out of the chaos. This runs in deep contrast with Jobu who simply believes that nothing truly matters. If everything is chaos, there's no point in us feeling anything.

I've often heard the term "cheerful nihilism" thrown out a couple of times. Rick and Morty come to my mind. So many of us have given into the cynicism being portrayed in our media. We've become "blackpilled" about a lot of things. So, to see a movie that tells us to make the most of our situations even if they don't seem ideal was a refreshing change of pace.

I've also learned to divorce the Academy Awards from the public consumption. Top Gun Maverick is my favorite film from 2022, but EEAAO was my pick for Best Picture at the Oscars. It's unique, filled with great performances, editing, direction, and a creative story.

I doubt people will forget this film in five years. There's too much in it for us to forget it. Compared to movies like Nomadland, The Shape of Water, and Argo, I'd say this is one of the most deserving of praise and Best Picture.

But that's my opinion.

Title: A fun and unique action movie with emotional underscoring
Review:
Stunning action sequences that are much more interesting than the typical action flick are the first that sticks out, but there's more to this movie than that. Each character sees the world in a very different, often conflicting, way. This sets up emotional drama and invited the viewer to actively consider their worldview. There are also some amazing creative decisions that tie this movie together and make it a unique and incredibly enjoyable experience.

Title: Original, stylistic and awesome.
Review:

Also the fact that the production had only a handful of VFX artists is absolutely mind blowing with how the effects were done.

Title: A very wild ride but not a perfect one
Review:
Can many brilliant moments in a movie compensate for lesser-than moments of significance? I was asking myself that question over and over as EEAaO kept astonishing me with inspired whimsy and outlandish sequences. So, what are the cinematic problems with EEAaO? First, the opening drags and drags. I know there's a goodly amount of setup / intro needed but there's actually too much setup for what's to come and the pace is glacial. This contrasts with many later moments of sublime stillness in the middle of manic action that make perfect sense for overall pacing. Second, there's a Disney-sized dollop of sentimentality and sui generis La Familia a la Chinoise that hits you over the head, particularly later on and it's 100% telegraphed. That said, the movie has jaw-dropping moments of cinematic bluster and choreography. If Michele Yeoh doesn't get an Academy nod for best actress there truly is no justice. So, if you like over-the-top movie moments and can tolerate the underlying family-centric group therapy session thrust upon you, get ready for an amazing ride.

Title: A classic from another timeline.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: A Breath of Fresh Air
Review:
Why movies are made to touch us in some way and entertain us and maybe make us feel less alone. The concept behind the film is fascinating but it's the execution that ultimately matters .There was a hundred way this could fail and maybe two that it could succeed .The Daniels and the cast and crew the assembled nailed the landing and gave us the most incredible experience. They found the heart and gave us an adventure .

Winning seven Oscars Best Actress for one of the best and most original wins for the category .Michelle Yeoh gives a performance that demands much from her and she delivers . Supporting Oscar wins along with wins in editing original screenplay and best directing and picture are much deserved. The Academy continues to expand on what is considered the finest achievements in film. But even without that this is one of the all time standouts .A mix of humor, adventure fantasy and just enough family drama. It's well worth your time.

Title: Out of Left Field
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is an experimental, fast and quirky fantasy movie with humorous elements featuring a balanced cast combining veteran actresses and actors such as Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan with young and talented newcomers such as Stephanie Hsu and Tallie Medel.

The movie revolves around laundry shop owner Evelyn Wang who faces quite a few challenges in her life. Her elderly father keeps criticizing her, she fails to show any affection to her delicate husband who wants to divorce her, her daughter feels misunderstood regarding her sexual identity and her poorly aged business is facing bankruptcy. Just as everything seems to be falling apart, Evelyn Wang gets the opportunity to experience different scenarios based upon important life choices she has made. The elderly woman experiences her career as a famous actress, as a martial artist or a lesbian with deformed fingers. However, all these alternative realities are menaced by the anger, deception and despair of her daughter. Evelyn Wang must find a way to connect with her daughter in order to find her way back to reality and solve her numerous problems.

On the positive side, this movie convinces with creative, fluid and unexpected storytelling. The different realities are colourful, exotic and funny. The movie comes around with multiple surprises out of left field that will keep the audience watching until the very end. The acting performances keep the movie together as especially the veteran actresses and actors convincingly play characters with depth, heart and soul.

On the negative side, the film's storytelling can at times be overwhelming and needs a lot of acceptance, focus and patience to be enjoyed to the fullest. The story itself is walking on thin ice and filled with quite a few stereotypes hidden by the bubbly characters and alternative realities.

At the end of the day, Everything Everywhere All at Once is a movie that will divide the masses. Some might call it pretentious nonsense offered at a headache-inducing speed while others will praise its unconventional storytelling and unique characters. No matter where you stand on the issue, one thing is undeniable: this movie is unlike any other you have ever watched and therefore worth everyone's attention. Personally, I'm glad to see that there are still movies that manage to surprise me and push cinematic experiences to a new level.

Title: Just embrace it
Review:
I feel compelled to counter all the negative and low scores on here with a positive review. Yes it was hectic and all over the place, but how awesome was that? The world needs more thinking well outside the box, and to stop taking ourselves so seriously all the time. When was the last time any of us just let out mind wander and see where it goes?

Under all the crazy shifts was a very relatable and emotional story about expectation, acceptance, love and the choices we make - This was painful, beautiful and moving. It is all of us wondering what else we could do or be - a mirror held up to us about how our biases and expectations limit our own potential.

It's a different way of thinking that isn't typical, it's beyond the binary black and white. In so many ways it's like the neurodiverse showing the neurotypical majority/norm what's inside our heads - an entirely different way of solving problems or telling a story that doesn't follow norms or a specified format or process. That Michelle Yeohs character's superpowers were hidden, she was hidden and made herself smaller to follow convention was the absolute kicker - because this is the experience of so many who are different and walk this world with our own multiverses going on inside our heads feeling like weirdos.

This was messy, frenetic, bonkers and painfully relatable and beautiful all at the time time. Just let go of your expectations and enjoy a fantastic ride!

Title: For God's Sake People, Open Your Gobs And Talk To Your Loved Ones.
Review:
Greetings And Salutations, and welcome to my review of Everything Everywhere All At Once; here's the breakdown of my ratings:

Story: 1.50 Direction: 1.75 Pace: 1.75 Acting: 1.25 Enjoyment: 1.25

TOTAL: 7.75 out of 10.00.

Here's the thing, this film isn't that brilliant. However, what's clever is how the writers and directors wrap up a simple moral premise within an outrageous and semi-entertaining narrative and movie. They then smack you around the head with two iron bars that hold the virtuosity inscribed upon them; just to drive it into your noggins.

The moral - Open Up And Fly: open your ears; open your eyes; open your hearts; open your mind; But, most of all, open your mouths and talk to one another, especially your loved ones. This process is your standard fundamental enlightenment, which many of us stupid humans fail at, myself included.

Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert wrap up this nugget of comprehension in the tale of a dysfunctional family living in America. The mother, Evelyn Wang, is teetering on the brink of a breakdown. She's overworked and overrun by everything in her life. Her sick and dying father has moved into their small apartment. He's an old-fashioned Chinese who always wanted a male heir; a daughter was never good enough. She's unsure of her feelings towards her husband, Waymond; he's changed over the years and is no longer the man she married. Her daughter, Joy appears to be stuck in the teenage angst years, moping about all day and pouting. Even though she's not unhappy about her daughter's sexual preferences, she can't bring herself to tell her old-fashioned father that his granddaughter is homosexual. And then the intimidating, iniquitous IRS decides it's an ideal time for an audit. So things are looking as bleak as they ever could be for poor, ageing Evelyn. And they're not going to get any brighter. Evidently, before enlightenment shines, you need to stand on the verge of, and stare into, the abyss of the obsidian bagel of everything everywhere all at once. To get Evelyn to this moment of realisation and change, the writers bring in a multiverse of other Evelyns and her family members. They brought each of these Evelyns into life by using her choices. For example, in one universe, she ignores her father when he tells her not to run so fast and ends up falling, head and eyes first, onto broken chopsticks, leaving her blind. In another, she chooses not to elope with Waymond, remaining at home with her parents, she becomes a top martial artist and finds fortune and fame in the Chinese movie industry. It's one of these other multiverse hubbies that tack this "Worst Life Ever" Evelyn down, hoping she can halt the disruption Jobu Topaki is wreaking across the multiverse. This initial meeting is the start of Evelyn's great-awakening journey. The two Dan's do a superb job of multiverse building, and though some of them are super-silly, you never feel confused about what is happening in the story. Another bonus is the strong character-building they achieve. Everyone in the tale feels real. Moreover, they come across as believable. I knew this when I began to get the niggling feeling that Joy and Jobu needed a good smack to set them straight in their miss-thinking ways. Getting me to feel this shows the strength of their creations. Well Done, Dan and Dan. However, it's not all light and joy for the double D's. They have a failing - Comedy. There are moments when it works and many when it doesn't. It comes down to one reason, puerility. The story is strong and mature, yet sadly, the buffoonery is adolescent toilet humour and pretty unfunny, neigh, I'll say cringe-worthy. Worst yet, it spoils all the fine work they'd done before and after. I'm talking about the buttplug power to fight better and the dildo slap of death. Both of these could have been funnier if handled better. One element this film displays is America's terrible at double entendres; or that Jamie Lee Curtis's comedic timing and punch are woefully lacking. But I'll put it firmly at the feet of the Double D's as they wrote the truly unamusing and lame "hotdogs as fingers" sketch.

That aside, they are entirely different animals behind the lens. And this juxtaposition makes the movie more entertaining and powerful. The two Dans dare to try both simple and tricky camera antics to intensify the viewers' excitement and hold their attention. The fight scenes are beautifully blended. They take the cutting to the next level as they utilise everything. What I admired most is how many fights had pauses dotted throughout them. Making them rollercoaster rides within the major coaster ride of the story. Jackie Chan used this feature a lot in his combat sequences. It allowed the director to add in extra human touches, like running out of breath, feeling pain, etc, which also added humour, before the incredibly breathtaking punches and kicks flew again. The Dans employ them to display a character's thoughts and realisation and multiverse flashes. In fact, the only place they stumble is with the puerile humour. For me, it's shot too crisply and cleanly, which diminished its power to make me giggle.

I've always been a fan of Michelle Yeoh, right from her early days when she starred alongside Jackie Chan in Twinkle Twinkle Lucky Stars. And though that movie had some cheesy moments, her performances never stunk. And neither does her portrayal of Evelyn. Everything Everywhere All At Once shows what a dynamite powerhouse she's become. But this movie wouldn't be so enjoyable if we didn't have Ke Huy Quan as Waymond. Quan superbly shifts from cuckold wimp to kick-arse hero mode flawlessly. If he'd been unable to sell the credibility of either character and the transition between them, the film would've bombed, and fast. And I can never say a bad word about the excellent James Hong. He's another stalwart actor who's seldom given a poor performance. The cast would've been perfect had Stephanie Hsu given her character more oomph. Even as Jobu, when she's all peacocked up, she's drab and dull. This fault may stem from the Double D's idea of her characters. However, more personality wouldn't have gone amiss. She's so tediously bland that she's nearly nonexistent - Jobu! The worst villain ever.

Remove the horrid humour, and you have an engaging and entertaining moralistic story and film. As such, I'd highly recommend it to both Martial Arts fans and Sci-Fi nuts. I'll be returning to it soon, though it'll just be to watch Michelle Yeoh kick arse. Just remember the moral and open up, speak out, but do it respectfully.

Now you've finished watching this self-help picture for the Department of Mental Health, sit down, take a deep breath, and please read my IMDb lists - Holding Out For A Hero, The Final Frontier, and Just For Laughs to see where I rated Everything Everywhere All At Once.

Take Care & Stay Well.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: One of the greatest films ever made
Review:
I have seen A LOT of movies in my life. A lot. I've laughed, I've cried, I've been scared. I've seen it all. No movie, and I mean NO movie, has ever made me feel the way this movie did. And it's a feeling I can't comprehend yet. But I'll get there, and it will be all that more rewarding. One of the greatest films ever made, and A24's best film to date. See this movie.

Title: Mind boggling!
Review:
This movie is not for everyone. Those viewers conditioned to accepting the usual fodder of simple plots with black & white cardboard cutout characters could be stretching their tiny peas towards potential brain aneurisms. But the imagination shown by the creators is simply astounding. Not since Ken Russell or Quentin Tarentino has there been such a unique, quirky universe as this one created by Dan Kwan & Daniel Scheinert. Is it a dream? - a hallucination? Maybe, but it's a philosophical roller coaster - with an extremely emotional conclusion! Every actor in it delivers their best performances. With the extraordinary Michelle Yeoh at the helm this movie offers a more spectacular ride than what Disney or the blockbuster franchises could ever hope to create.

Title: Cinematic crescendo!!!
Review:
By the end of this timeless classic, you are just left in awe gaping and wondering at the art you have witnessed. If you live life to the fullest, this movie will tug at all your heart strings. The ebb and flow will keep you invested and on the edge of your seat. All the elements add up to one big ending which is crescendo personified. The characters all portray something meaningful and worthwhile. You root for them and hope they come through. It is the humaneness in us that makes us want to see them victorious. The complexity of relationship. The empathy, kindness, and openness all come to the fore.

Title: A serious movie disguised as a silly movie:
Review:
Wow. I rarely leave reviews but this one absolutely deserved one. Kudos to the directors for writing such a stunning movie. I'm a 58 year old, white, grandmother of five and I could relate to every.single.character.

It's a story of parent/daughter relationships sprinkled with remorse for dreams not fulfilled, paths not taken, focusing on the wrong things in life, and, eventually, realizing that Be Kind/Accept People For Who They Are is what everyone should strive for in this blink of an eye existence we all have. Each and every actor was excellent. In my opinion EEAO should win all the awards.

Title: Acting and action were great, the Trippy, only so so
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

This was a fluke watch for me as I had not heard about it and sorta went into it blind. So glad I took a chance on it.

Title: Bizarre doesn't necessarily mean great!
Review:
Some quick impressions after coming out of the theater: This movie is highly overrated. It has some interesting ideas, but a lot of repetition and is often dragging and boring.

It is basically a bombardment of your senses, which doesn't leave a good impression/taste.

Too much stupid fight sequences (poor story). Once over, you do not wonder about its "deep" meanings (if you manage to watch it until the end).

The commanding room is kind of copy/paste of The Matrix.

Not a good choice for an intelligent viewer.

A waste of time, money and senses... 5/10 max.

Title: A Trip of a Movie!
Review:
Don't listen to the contrarians that are "nOt LiKe ThE oThEr GiRlS." Every time a movie is critically acclaimed or has a minority cast, you're going to get ignorant people that tank it. Disregard them! This movie is a great and bizarre watch!

Michelle Yeoh is fantastic as the lead. Her life is crumbling, she's lost all hope in her business endeavors, her marriage is ending, and her daughter barely speaks to her. If all that isn't enough, she's being audited by the IRS and is on the edge. When it seems like it's finally going to fall apart, she gets pulled into a world she didn't know existed and now has to save.

All of the actors in this movie are incredible. They don't just play one character; they play several.

Don't look for deep life lessons from Hollywood. Movies are meant to entertain and that's exactly what this movie does.

Title: I wasn't impressed... then I watched it!!!
Review:
I heard mixed reviews when this was released, with someone saying this was the best movie they have ever seen, which sounded ridiculous and my more balanced friends telling me it was absolute rubbish. It looked rubbish so I gave it a miss on the big screen. I couldn't understand the fuss and the reason it got so many oscar nominations until I watched it on a flight just, and it is absolutely...brilliant!!!!!!!! It is in fact a masterpiece... if you follow it, and understand it, and I guess if you understand human nature, human experience, heartache, frustrations and human experience. Which is what the movie is actually about. It's about one person's journey through all of this, which appears, and i use that word carefully - to take them through this multiverse of madness to bring them to a real life epiphany, a realisation of who and why they are. It is absolutely brilliant if you understand that. And probably very grotesque and annoying if you don't get it. I can see why some people hate it. You need to watch it again. It is such an emotional joy. Wow. Applause all round!!!!

Title: Superb Originality This is a 21st Century Classic
Review:
My Review - Everything Everywhere All at Once 2022

My Rating 10/10 Thank you to my friend Cherrie G if not for you I may have overlooked this amazing movie.

There is already much written about this movie as I have discovered some of it poles apart in appreciation or lack thereof .

All I can say really for me if asked to describe my reaction to this astonishing trip between altered states and universes is to quote a Buddhist word Maitri which means benevolence, loving-kindness, friendliness, amity, good will, and active interest in others.

I'm no intellectual scholar my literary heroes and life teachers lies more with Aesop's Fables , Shakespeare or the Brothers Grimm than the great Jean-Paul Sartre or Marcel Proust .

That's probably why I kept thinking of three great movies while watching Everything Everywhere All at Once .

They were Lewis Carol's Alice in Wonderland, The Matrix and L. Frank Baume's The Wizard of Oz .

There's the same zany We're All Mad crazy characters in Alice even a drink me eat me scene the Sci Fi film noir worlds of The Matrix and the No Place Like Home journeys end of Oz.

Which brings me to mention the humour in this movie featuring Pythonesque comedy fun with raccoons ,butt plugs, hot dog hands ,and pelting pooches and pet rocks.

The producers wanted to keep the plot to this film under wraps before release earlier this year so the description just read a woman tries to do her taxes.

The woman is Evelyn Wang played by the wonderful International star Michelle Yeoh . This film even features her red carpet glamorous catwalk scene in one of her other famous films Crazy Rich Asians when Evelyn experiences what fame can bring in another life choice.

Evelyn Wang is stressed to her limits with her laundromat under audit , her daughter Joy's lifestyle choice a problematic marriage to husband Waymond played by Ke Huy Quan her family woes also include her elderly demanding father Gong Gong played by Veteran actor James Hong.

Most of action of the first part titled Everything of this unique Fantasy Sci-Fi Comedy of the Absurd takes place in the Office of the Internal Revenue with Evelyn's stress increasing by the second as IRS Inspector Deirdre Beaubeirdre interrogates her . Deidre the IRS Inspector is played by the wonderful Jamie Lee Curtis in her greatest comedy role since her 1988 role in A Fish Called Wanda.

No spoilers from now on part 2 Everywhere takes us and our heroine Evelyn on a journey to an alternate universe to explore what her life may have been like .

This is a world where even her daughter is an alternate character Jobu Tupaki and her enemy also played by Stephanie Hsu giving a superb performance in this dual role .

I advise even if you don't like the frenetic first hour of this trip stay with this movie it's worth it. You wouldn't get off a train half way if you knew you were on your way to a beautiful destination would you?

Part 3 All at Once is a beautiful and emotional journeys end.

I'm so pleased the Daniels replaced the choice of Jackie Chan as the lead to Michelle Yeoh as I think a woman with family and life stresses has a vulnerability that a male character would have lacked.

I was very interested to read that the writers directors Daniel Scheinart and Daniel Kwan originally intended for Evelyn to have undiagnosed ADHD.

Daniel Kwan researched the condition and discovered that he himself had undiagnosed ADHD.

I really loved this movie as it has a strong message for me about the world we live in today where the pursuit of excellence and high achievement seem to have left the battlers and ordinary achievers behind making many doubt themselves and the life choices they've made in other words it's ok to fail we can always have another try . Kindness and empathy for each other are better qualities than prestige and power.

I can't wait to see it again hopefully on a Cinema Screen.

Title: a perfect representation of generational trauma and feeling unloveable.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Title: Excellent!!
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a unique and entertaining movie that combines elements of comedy and science fiction. However, it falls short of being a top-notch movie due to its not-so-serious nature and the way it mixes genres.

The movie describes its subtext very well, and there was not the slightest gap in the screenplay. The acting was successful, although it did not quite deserve an Oscar. The editing was done exceptionally well, which added to the overall quality of the film.

At times, the pacing of the film is so frenetic that it's easy to miss important details even if one is watching very carefully. The film moves from one scene to the next without giving the audience much time to catch their breath or fully absorb what's happening on screen.

This high tempo can be frustrating, as the movie has a lot of interesting ideas and concepts that it wants to explore. However, because of the breakneck pace, some of these ideas are not given the time and attention they deserve. Despite this, the movie is an original work that is sure to captivate audiences with its unique story and philosophical depth.

The philosophical depth of the movie is what sets it apart from other films in the genre. The themes of identity, choice, and the nature of reality are explored in a way that is both thought-provoking and entertaining.

Overall, "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a solid movie with an 88/100 rating. While it may not be a top-notch movie, it is still an enjoyable and unique film that is definitely worth watching.

It must have been some sort of token nod from the academy for all the awards because I'm at a complete loss to see anything positive or remotely interesting about this film.

It was simply dull and there's no excuse for that. Shame.

Title: Not sure I've ever seen anything quite like this
Review:
A highly original piece of film construction with an obscure title that ends up being quite appropriate because that is what happens. I loved Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan in the leads, was sort of amazed by the ninety something James Hong and Jamie Lee Curtis seems to be having a great time, much more than I did, though a lot of it is funny, some of it exhausting and nearly all of it is eye-popping non-stop happenings. Others may view it differently, but that's my take on this very unusual film.

Title: Violent, pretentious-- also original and wildly imaginative. But...
Review:
After having read many of the reviews here it seems that, well, some people get this movie, and some people don't. I'm in the latter group. There's no doubt that this is a movie unlike any other; the creativity is off the charts. The acting is superb. The direction terrific. But there's no substance outside of a feel good message about... something: hard to say what. Still, the most salient part of the movie, and something few people seem to be talking about, is that it's possibly the most violent movie of the year, if not the decade. Once the roller coaster begins it's one excruciating fight scene after another, all beautifully choreographed, and all bloody horrible. So if you like originality combined with imagination, constant bloodshed, and a completely incoherent plot, this is your movie.

Title: Well then...
Review:
If you are a fan of the movie Lamb, Gold, Pig, Prisoners of Ghostland, etc... then you probably would like this movie as well.

Sometimes I feel like Hollywood is experimenting with us or something and I agree with a lot of people's view that these movies are "Emperor's New Clothes," a lot of groupthink, people just afraid to be honest about it, they just want to be in the hype and jump on the bandwagon.

The story and plot is completely convoluted and makes little sense. It seems to be like a magic eight ball of unrelated events trying hard to mash together. The characters are typical in an American comedy, they act like they're on coke, always fidgeting, twitching, and talking very very fast in a sarcastic tone. I remember first seeing Shia popularize this in Transformers. Was never a fan.

That's all just from the film itself, adding in the woke indoctrination and preaching, this film scores an easy 1 for me.

Title: Psychology and philosophy of life.
Review:
Psychology and philosophy of life. Starting from the premise that God probably does not exist, we are ephemeral beings doomed to a brief, forgettable, and invisible existence for an overwhelming percentage of the universe. Nothing makes sense, nothing matters. Everything will cease to exist for you and me in a shorter time than we imagine. We are completely helpless beings, there is no sense in so much struggle, so much suffering. Neither joy nor pain, all of this will pass. But living what is good is the only thing that seems to make a little sense in this life. At least that's what we try to choose. That's what seems to make it worth it, just a little bit. We smile, we hug each other. That matters, at least in this brevity we call life. The rest is just nonsense and a waste of time. That is the message of the film, which used this crazy idea of parallel universes to draw our attention to this. And it worked. If they had tried to make a philosophical and psychological film to explain it, only a handful of people would have seen it.

Title: Absolutely amazing
Review:
I've been watching this movie again and again since it came out last year and it gets better every time. This is the first movie that gives me something more every time I rewatch it. There's a small thing that I see on a rewatch that I haven't seen earlier. It's such an overwhelming experience, it feels exactly like the title says. It's an exhausting movie that leaves you just thinking about it afterwards. You just want to sit back in silence and think about everything.

It's so many things all at once it definitely is not for everyone. But for me, it was exactly what I would want from a movie.

It might be the fresh afterglow of having just seen it and I might go back to same ol' life tomorrow morning but boy does it affect you! It FEELS like it's complicated but it's not. Title: Tries to be original and deep but ends up messy and cringy
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: A marvelous movie.
Review:
This is one of the best movies of 2022, and can go into one of the best movies of all time. It has a unique way to deliver its message, with scenes that mixed with action, drama and comedy. If I'm going to explain anything it will be complicated, but the movie actually is well explained, that's why I advice anyone to watch it without knowing anything about it. The writing, acting, directing and everything was so AMAZING , special thanks to everyone has worked on this great movie.

Title: Great
Review:
What can I say that hasn't been said before?

Just about everything in this movie is top-notch.

The acting - from every actor -, the directing - which I've only seen their Swiss Army Man when it came out and had a lot of fun with it-, the visuals and especially the editing is just amazing in this movie.

It has a really good story and it's funny as hell, like I didn't expect it to make me laugh this much. It's definitely one of the best movies of these past couple years.

I enjoyed it very much, but the only reason I'm giving it an 8 and not a 9, is because I didn't really have the emotional connection that people seem to have with the ending of this movie, and the ending, although great, I didn't find it mind-blowingly amazing to warrant it a 9.

I usually cringe when a conflict, especially a world-ending one, is solved by the power of "love"! And I really hate it when this trope is used to end a story. But in this case, it really worked for this movie and I have no complaint about that aspect of it. Just that I wasn't too emotionally invested in their relationship, or better to say that the mother-daughter relationship didn't resonate with me that much. I don't know, it probably would've worked for me better if it was a father and son. And I'm not saying that just because I'm a man, I'm saying that because I know that that worked better in a movie like About Time. Or maybe it's because they showed that father and son relationship just a teeny bit better that made me invest in their characters and relationships better.

I probably will change my mind on a second or multiple viewings, but for now, I think it's a solid 8. Although it's automatically a 9 since we hadn't have a movie this good in so many years. (Except for Parasite) And it looks like that a lot of people, understandably, compare this to Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness, but I don't think it's comparable. One is a stand-alone movie that wraps up its own story in the runtime it has, and the other is like an episode to a cinematic universe that should be watched like a tv show. So why not enjoy both?

And it's fair if you don't like how Marvel movies work and that you have to watch lots of other movies before a "sequel" to a movie that came out in 2016, it's your choice and opinion, you don't like the way they do movies or you don't like the movie at all. But let people who enjoy both movies enjoy both of them and don't start a war over it.

Although if we were to compare these two movies with each other, EEAAO is definitely the superior movie. It has better visuals and editing, and the story and how it is told is definitely better here.

But I enjoyed the horror and gothic aspect of Doctor Strange too and really had fun with it, and even though I gave that one an 8 too, it's actually a 7.5 for me and obviously lower than this movie, but I still enjoyed both of them for different reasons.

One thing I didn't really find that great in this movie though, was the score. Now, the music and the sound mixing was great in this movie. But for some scenes, especially the ending, I thought the music could've been used in a better way. It's the only thing I think this movie is lacking. And like I said, it might be become better on a second-viewing.

And although they did a good job of explaining how the multiverse jump work, I am still confused about somethings, especially with the Bluetooth headphones they have.

All in all, it's a great movie and definitely the best movie since 2019. (of the ones I've watched)

Title: All at once
Review:
Wow. It's been a while since a movie blew me away as much as this did. This has to be by far one of the best movies I've seen this year. And I wish I saw this in theaters but never went for it. Go into this as blind as you can, it's worth it.

The mix of adventure, drama and comedy is so well balanced, it's inspiring. The acting is phenomenal, the score and music is top tier, the vfx, the directing.. I could go on praising this movie and to be honest I guess I'm just on a high a.t.m. And can't so a lot of faults. But are there many? Besides the whole multiverse complexity, sure it becomes so complex at a point you have to really remove logic from the equation. At first you try, but it quickly tells you to just accept it.

The only negative I could notice whilst watching where some blatant ''telling the viewer what's going on'' moments. With the complexity it's understandable why they did it, but to me it felt like ''yes, I know already'' This was in the early part only though. But that's like... the only thing I could find and imo is nitpicking.

It's a 2+ hour movie and it feels like that but also doesn't feel like that. Because of it's unique moments and editing choices it will make you aware of the time. Which leads to it. I loved the choice, but it also had it's repercussions.

Special shoutout to the VFX work and directing/editing. It's so incredibly creative, the backstories, the methods of how they show things, the simple but brilliant scenes. Conceptually this movie ranks extremely high. The main story is touching and emotional, but the movie never forgets it's a comedy, but you'll hear tears in your eyes and laugh at the same time. It deals with Chinese parenting traditions/stereotypes in quite a obvious way but the dad made all the difference in it becoming repetitive.

I have yet to see other works from these directors but I'm acing to watch anything they come up with next. This movie truly felt like a work of art and passion.

This is a special movie, and up there to be watched again.

Title: "The multiverse is here only as a background to the main plan that the relationships between the characters of Evelyn's family and the search for her happiness."
Review:
"The multiverse is here only as a background to the main plan that the relationships between the characters of Evelyn's family and the search for her happiness." Everything Everywhere All at Once presents a vivid and dynamic multiverse that brims with life, accompanied by coherent explanations. The film seamlessly weaves in moralistic elements, bolstered by remarkable and outstanding performances. Although the visual effects may appear modest, they aptly align with the film's overall vision. Every aspect of the movie embarks on a profound journey, exploring themes of choice, happiness, parenthood, and existential crises. Among the exceptional performances, Ke Huy Quan stands out with his remarkable portrayal , to his lead role, he flawlessly executes several distinct characters, exhibiting brilliance in each portrayal ,notably, one particular performance shines extraordinarily, likely earning him well-deserved recognition by the film's conclusion Quan give an exceptional performance that surpasses the standards set in recent years."

Cast:4.5/5 Screenplay:4/5 Direction:4.5/5 Narrative:5/5 Acting:4/5 Effects and video editing:4/5 Key Huy Quan:5/5 Michelle Yeoh:4/5.

Review:
You get it or you don't! I think it's a marmite film, you either love it or you hate it. I'm the former, I love it; especially the rock scene.

Do I understand it, not a chance.. but I think that's a good thing. Bonkers, brilliant film with no solution.

Title: Aimless Mixed up Jumble
Review:
What a god awful movie. It was as if the producers/director/actors wanted to see if you would fall for complete garbage and call it art. And by the ratings, you did.

I have been reading and watching science fiction and fantasy since before most of you were born and this nonsense is near the bottom of my list. I'm amazed I watched to the end.

According to the ratings this movie is almost as good as "Lord of the Ring" or "The Martian".

Not even close!

As for the characters, it's hard to find one to empathize with. Maybe Evelyn, maybe Joy, but even that is pushing it.

The story itself is incomplete in every way. Nothing can be truly understood by the viewer and yes, I think that is deliberate. They want you confused and want you to enjoy that and call it artful, innovative and reflective of the current year. Dreck!

Sorry, no, I wasn't fooled. Try again with the aim of entertaining the audience.

Title: A heartfelt tale told in the most insane way
Review:
This film manages to balance out so many things that I think a multitude of people will appreciate. You've got a likeable cast with a creative concept that grabs you and doesn't let go for the duration of the viewing. I believe there is a high chance you will walk out of this film feeling good and find yourself pondering the type of lessons imbedded in the story. One gripe I had, which I guess you could call a nitpick, is that it felt just a little too long. Perhaps ten minutes could've been cut so we could get to certain points faster. In the end, Everything Everywhere All at Once is as down to earth as it is ambitiously creative and is a viewing experience where you may take away more than you thought. One of the best films of 2022 so far. Verdict: 9/10.

Title: #1 multiverse
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All At Once" is a mind-bending, genre-blending sci-fi comedy that takes viewers on a wild ride through multiple dimensions and timelines. Directed by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, the film stars Michelle Yeoh as a retired physicist who finds herself caught up in an interdimensional adventure involving a mysterious box, a quantum entanglement device, and a cast of eccentric characters.

One of the strengths of this film is its ability to seamlessly weave together elements of comedy, drama, action, and science fiction. The humor is often irreverent and absurd, but it never feels forced or out of place. The action scenes are inventive and thrilling, but they are also grounded in the characters' emotional journeys. And the sci-fi concepts are mind-bending and thought-provoking, but they are presented in a way that is both accessible and entertaining.

Another standout aspect of "Everything Everywhere All At Once" is its diverse and talented cast. Michelle Yeoh is a force to be reckoned with as the film's lead, and she is surrounded by a supporting cast that includes Stephanie Hsu, Jamie Lee Curtis, and James Hong. Each actor brings a unique energy and perspective to their role, making the ensemble feel like a true ensemble.

The film's visual style is also worth noting. The cinematography is colorful and dynamic, with clever use of camera angles and lighting to convey the film's many moods and tones. The visual effects are impressive as well, seamlessly blending practical and digital effects to create a world that feels both fantastical and real..

Title: Loved the twists
Review:
Directors Dan Kwan & Daniel Schienert masterfully co directed and co wrote this wonderful film of multiple realities melding several realms and creating a symbiotic finish. Tons of quirkiness filled with genuine inflection and introspection of inner and outer turmoil within each person and everyone they have a relationship with resulting in continual flux of the stories. Thoroughly enjoyed the story within a story within a storyline. Brava and bravo to the actors for their performances. They captivate us with all of the multiple personalities that come to the surface. Feeling the range of emotions that they express and many times throughout cause confusion. Thank you for this quirky multiple rearmed movie.

Title: It's everything, everywhere, all at once. And it's remarkable.
Review:
The Good: You know a movie is special when the impeccable action scenes, unmatched creativity, and incredible performances aren't what stands out. It's the deep, unapologetic humanity and character dynamics - so realistic and raw - that really puts Everything, Everywhere, All At Once over the top for me. It's also a film that reminds me of what science fiction is really about: using these out there concepts to comment upon the human experience. This film is really a metaphor for adult life; how we often have to juggle so many things pulling at us and lose sight of what really matters: people, relationships, and the time we have with them.

To say Michelle Yeoh is great here is an understatement. She's truly remarkable and excels in every role she plays in this movie: she's funny, she's a fantastic martial artist, she's glamorous, she's relatable. Maybe the Daniels had some fairy dust in their pockets or something, because almost every actor here - required to play multiple versions of themselves - are OUTSTANDING. Key Huy Quan's Waymond is perhaps my favourite character of the year so far; he's so effortlessly lovable and brings so much pathos to this role. I also want to shout Stephanie Hsu out; she's not getting a ton of attention but her performance is so good the scenes of her and Michelle Yeoh almost brought me to tears (I'll freely admit Quan and Yeoh's scenes LITERALLY brought me to tears).

But, of course none of this is what people are *really* talking about with this movie. This movie's energy is on another level, I've never seen anything quite like it. It's both quick and snappy, but makes complete sense. Just when I was getting a bit bored with the setting, the film transitions at the exact right moment. The ending feels earned and in line with the film's themes. Everything just clicks...everywhere and all at once.

The action is next level. This movie was apparently written for Jackie Chan and I have to say, Yeoh and Quan are amazing stand ins for him. The influence of Hong Kong action films is palpable and unmistakable. In an era where I usually go into passive mode watching action scenes, EEAO had my eyes glued to the screen. It has some of the funniest, most interesting, and dynamic action sequences I have ever seen. Every time I thought I knew what was gonna happen, something entirely different did.

And if this movie couldn't be even more intricate and well made, its very existence if reflective of the Asian American experience. You couldn't have this movie without China, yet it's still clearly a very American movie. God, I freakin' love this movie.

The Bad: Honestly, this is one of the movies that I'd be nitpicking if I had to go through what was "bad." Maybe one or two scenes i think didn't need to be there, maybe some dialog that's a bit on the nose. But nah, this thing rocks.

The Ugly: 2022 is shaping up to be a truly amazing year for film. I'm so happy that we've seen a new generation of visionaries take centre stage, and I can't wait to see what the Daniels' do next. If Swiss Army Man was the appetizer, Everything Everywhere All At Once feels like the main course, a statement film that (I hope) elevates audience expectations as to what mainstream film making can be. No scratch that, it elevates expectations as to what life can be. I felt myself just a little happier, just a little more appreciative of my life and the people who are a part of it.

With all the stuff happening in the world, I'm happy I'm in the universe where this film exists.

Title: Brilliantly bonkers
Review:
I read the blurb and watched the first few seconds of the trailer before deciding I'd probably be best to just dive right in. That was an excellent decision, even if I do say so myself.

I'm not really into action movies, and despite this being full of action sequences, it's not really an action movie.

I loved the fact that essentially this was a film about people and the expectations they put on themselves and others, how they think others see them and how they see others.

The importance of needing to stand up and fight, but to also be kind.

I started crying with bemused laughter at the hotdog sausages and I knew then I was watching one of the best films ever.

I loved it. Brilliant.

Title: perfectly named
Review:
This is a movie that can only come out in 2022.

A wild ride of LSD like trippyness in a family story.

Thats what is boils down to, a story of a family.

Watching interviews, the writers are not even totally sure what this is exactly about, but it doesnt matter.

When i saw this with my family, not a single one of them liked it or enjoyed it, but i thought it worked and the weirdness from the eccentric fighting to the hot dog fingers, that can only work today.

If im old and someone asks me what is was like in my time, this is what im going to show them. They might not understand, but the emotions displayed in this are what go through my mind a ton.

Most of this movie's problem is that while is does present these ideas well, it does dive a bit too deep into these wild ideas, which holds it back a little. It still leaves me thinking about it to this day.

Title: An unparalleled bizarre cinema masterpiece that approaches the multiverse in a fresh, new, ingenious way.
Review:
I have no idea what I just witnessed. Everything Everywhere All at Once is unlike anything anyone has ever seen before. This brilliant goofy, zany, ridiculous genius movie will fry your brain cells. This film instantly establishes itself as a necessity for any true cinema lover. Ground-breaking writing that feels like a Christopher Nolan script with no limits and some eccentricity mixed in. I'm not sure if I fully enjoyed the movie, but I also can't say I fully understand everything Everything Everywhere All at Once is. Not a film for everyone but an absolute must for movie fans or sci-fi enthusiasts.

Title: Masterpiece
Review:
You can expect everything in this movie.

The action scenes are really well done! The CGI is perfect. The acting is brilliant, the plot is surprisingly gripping considering how frequently movies these days just throw in the word "multiverse" and expect it to make sense, this movie respects that word and presents it in a way that makes sense within the movie's context.

The comedy is simply top level, I was laughing every time there was a joke or when humorous contexts came up. It doesn't go out of its way to be funny, the comedy is presented in a fluid way.

The other thing that this movie does excellently is presenting the female protagonist! They, not once, shove it in the audience's face that she's a woman, they simply present the character and their path towards strength. So many directors mess this up and use exposition or arrogance to make their point about a female character, but here, its characters are being portrayed perfectly, even the old people are portrayed well.

10/10.

Title: Tries very hard to be smart, but fails miserably
Review:
I wonder if people who are enthusiastic about this mess of a movie have seen The Matrix, Inception, Brazil, Mr. Nobody and other movies I am too bored to mention; these movies have come years before this one and are still a giant leap above this pretentious bunch of thrown-there ideas.

There are some precious moments, and the movie is highly imaginative, but it looks like there was noone in the cast who was entitled to say "ok guys, this is too much".

If this movie were aimed at smart people, it should have told far less than it does; it looks like it hardly tries to tell you how smart and unconventional the writers are, and they Keep the secret message of the movie for the end of the movie, except for there is no real secret, and the meaning behind the story is dull and oh-so-obvious.

It is not a terrible movie, but it is probably the most overhyped and overrated movie to win so much oscars in the movie history.

Title: This movie truly is everything everywhere all at once
Review:
It is hard to imagine a movie that is comical, funny, cool, chaotic, dark and refreshing all at once. Yet the creative minds behind the scenes was able to pack this majestic roller-coaster all into one movie.

This one-of-a-kind film is able to hold up to its ambition of paying homage to multiple genres across the mutiverse and delivering on multiple themes while not feeling disjointed, and the experience just gets better for the Chinese audience who understand the language. Although the movie crumbles slightly at the end under its own weight, and some themes could be developed more profoundly, with strong visuals, cleverly designed gigs, eccentric acting and immersive editing, this textbook version of cinema has excelled in all technical aspects of achievement that few other have achieved.

Title: Not Good
Review:
I don't get all the buzz around this film. It's a poorly conceived derivative idea that fails to tell a cogent story. It tries to be Scott Pilgrim vs The Matrix in a Marvel-like multiverse... but Everything Everywhere All at Once is just not very good. As a children's movie it's fine, and I suppose if it wasn't up for all these awards I would have just submitted an average review... but, it is up for a bunch of awards, and I felt a responsibility to balance out all of the nonsense. I tried watching it with several people from different genders, races, ages, and sexual orientations. Nobody liked Everything Everywhere All at Once, most wouldn't even finish it. Waste your time if you must see what all the "buzz" is about.... But don't say I didn't warn you.

Title: Read nothing but praise and wasn't let down
Review:
I watched the movie in cinemas twice, and didn't finish my snack on either occasion. Every moment and little detail was thought out. It was original, funny and touching at the same time. Title: Yeoh really don't want to miss this
Review:
Ten minutes into Everything, Everywhere All at Once you already know all you need to about Evelyn Wang and her life. She runs a struggling laundry mart and is in some way estranged from every member of her family. She is a dissapiontment to her visiting father, resents here carefree husband who's cheery outlook on life she sees as weakness and while she worries nothing she has done matters she struggles to connect with her daughter who worries nothing at all matters.

Broadly speaking the movies follows Evelyn working through her family issues via Kung Fu, universe hopping and confronting a reality threatening bagel. If that sounds crazy its only scratching the surface, the film packs in a lot. It also a masterpiece. From Uncut Gems style stress to melancholy to exhilaration, the directors make you feel whatever they want on a whim and while Michelle Yeoh is the undoubted star of the show every cast member is outstanding. Really saying anything more (other than everyone should see this film) could only spoil things.

It'll make you gasp, it'll make you laugh, it'll probably make you cry. It'll make you want to hug your kids. An instant all time classic.

Title: Out Of This World
Review:
Behind the incredibly imaginative visuals and the 'out of this world' editing, is a movie that knows what it wants to say/be from the beginning. It never loses its way. All this spectacle wraps beautifully around a simple yet touching story.

Title: A family drama disguised as everything else
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: A very fun take on the multiverse
Review:
Honestly with all the dirty jokes and how it all comes back full circle, movie could have used some more comedy. I noticed that there was a lot of dark scenes too, some more color would have been great as I do not own an oled or HDR monitor/tv.

Music was absolutely gorgeous.

Romance, if I were to compare it to Dr Strange multiverse of madness, is all the more present here than it was in MoM, really liked it.

The whole family theme was slightly odd but fit very well with the whole setting.
