Title: Everybody needs everyone to love everybody everywhere at all times!
Review:
There aren't many action films depicting the mother/daughter bond, so this welcome addition surpasses everybody's expectations. But that isn't even half the film's draw!

Finally back on screen, my personal favourite sidekick or comic relief in big action-adventure blockbusters, Data/Shortstop from the unique Goonies and fun Indy films comes back with a bang! His bag of tricks on show for all to awe at! He's the North to Michelle's Crouching housewife, Hidden talent in the Laundry, midlife wife-crisis. And it's not "just the taxes" that turn the struggling business owner into a force to be reckoned with! Without giving much away, one woman must traverse multiple timelines of her life where every choice she's ever made has created a new version of herself. As we are products of our society, each version of herself has different skills. Before time runs out, she must learn to use her skills to fight off evil doppelgangers of her friends and her IRS officer (a hilarious turn from True Lies' Jamie Lee Curtis) from other universes!

Doctor Strange could take a lesson or two from the mouth-dropping visuals this films throws at the viewer, with the CGI and SFX blended seemlessly between quick, witty and relevant dialogue, majestic fight scenes, and surprises behind every turn! A feast for the eyes!

The cast playfully carry this film on their comedic, dramatic and kung fu-trained shoulders, all at once! After so many father- son bonding films, or son looking for approval, this alternate view of a parent/child relationship may be foreign to many, but will hit home to those in the know! As a son of migrant parents, the critical parenting style sure rings true!

Title: Felt like my insides exploded on screen in a good way
Review:
LOVED EVERY BIT OF IT WITH EVERY FIBRE OF MY BEING üíõ

I didn't watch the trailer, I didn't know what it was about, the title sounded catchy and it just looked like something I would enjoy. So I went with no clue and zero expectations.

And this movie was such a revelation. It's all my depression and anxiety accumulated during many years which peaked during the pandemic expressed in a super expressive movie. It's hilarious, it's deep, it's sad, it's dark, it's annoying at times, it's colourful, it's relatable, it's hopeful, it's just everything. It allowed me to let some feelings and thoughts that had been buried deep down back to the surface again. It's given me some hope and comfort.

It's not just me and that's comforting. Maybe more people than I think are feeling like this. Maybe there's still hope of making some sense of this meaningless strange existence. Maybe there are no rules and we can embrace googly eyes.

I absolutely loved the message and the form and the actors, this movie touched me more than I can say. I will make everyone I care about watch it. We need more stuff like this in our lives!!!

Title: rollercoaster ride of images and ideas for five movies
Review:
This is what a Doctor Strange-Multiverse movie should have been like: complex, witty, intelligent script, excellent performances, hillariously strange humor.

This movie is like a orgy in storytelling containing a lot of themes and delivering at each of them.

The hero of this movie is Michelle Yeoh that gives the performance of her lifetime.

Another excellent actress that will we remembered: Jamie Lee Curtis. Just hillarious.

It's nearly impossible to describe this movie. You have to see and experience it.

Why not a rating higher than 8?

The movie gets exhausting after the first twothirds, it's a little bit overlong, confusing and loses its pace by the end.

But, nonetheless, it's one of the most visionary, entertaining, strange and hillarious movies of the past years, I just say 'the stones' and 'sausage fingers'. Wow!

Highly recommended.

Title: A triumph in big and small scale storytelling
Review:
One of my favourite films of 2022. The story is astonishingly well crafted managing to be both totally thrilling to watch on face value and also completely captivating to see the bigger themes unfold. A multi generation chinese-American family are struggling with their lives and relationships and get the chance to explore alternative realities where their lives have taken very different directions. The film is a triumph of both big and small scale story telling while never feeling trivial or pretentious. It was fun and action packed, showing off mind-blowing editing and filming techniques as well as spectacular martial arts amongst some truly surreal ideas. The ambition and expansiveness of this film is huge and somehow expertly woven together into something that not only makes sense but is a real wonder to behold. There is also a really powerful emotional core to the film, particularly with the mother daughter relationship as well as proper laugh out loud comedy moments. The cast do an incredible job with so much to do and multiple characters to play and I hope Oscar nominations are on the horizon.

Title: Family drama with universe story
Review:
A Chinese immigrant finds himself experiencing adventurers he cannot avoid and imagine, traveling to another universe that has a different storyline of life to himself.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a film that really features a story with a universe feel (this is because it is screened close to the Doctor Strange film). Everything Everywhere All at Once presents a family drama story wrapped in a fictional story of the journey of the universe. The family drama that was brought is a story related to how the life of a Chinese immigrant in the face of changes and cultural differences in the culture in which he lives. The plot of the story actually has a simple story. However, it is wrapped in such an intricate adventure. The conflict that occurs is also a family conflict that is being hit by a period of disharmony and lack of happiness. That's the point made in this film. This film wants to bring us to experience the conflict that occurs with some questions if only. With the depiction of the reality of life branching out becomes an affirmation to understand the conflict felt by the Mother in seeing her family's problems.

Everything Everywhere All at Once has a unique story. This film presents an adventure film with a combination of drama and comedy which becomes a unity of films that are fun and fun to watch. This film also does not forget to present good visual effects. The image of the formed universe appears with colorful and diverse visuals. The Cast lineup also has a nice charm. Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan and Stephanie Hsu performed amazingly and well.

Title: A wonderful and funny film that explores every possibility/outcome
Review:

I honestly loved it. I thought it would just be a plain old boring run of the mill time/dimension story but it turned out much MUCH better than I expected. The comedy was on point, the acting was superb, the plot was very intriguing and fun. I mean what was there not to love about this? Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert did a wonderful job directing this movie.

And usually with these type of movies, the ending is always open for interpretation and left very open but I thought "Everything Everywhere All at Once" did a perfect job wrapping it all up in a nice little box leaving us with a very satisfying ending.

Title: Magnificient, Insipiring, Tender, Daring, Fun... All at Once
Review:
First off, this is my first IMDB review. I've wondered many times when would I finally publish one but I always felt the movies spoke for themselves, and also that there are so many people around the world reviewing here that it would simply be 'a waste of time'. Not for this movie, it isn't.

Second of all, I am a fan of old school cinema, even though I enjoy a modern flick from time to time. However, in recent years I don't think I watched anything that really moved me or made me care. That means when I actually watch something beyond the year 2000, I go in with extremely low expectations, basically that I will be watching trash. I would definitely describe myself as a pretentious viewer, meaning I really need substance in a movie to really like it.

Third, this movie inspired me to a degree I literally feel I am just a bit better as a person after watching it. So this is more of a praise than an actual review. I won't go into detail about any facet of the movie; just go watch it. What I want to share is the overall impact it had on my as a viewer. So here it goes:

My first impression was basically boredom. I didn't really understand what the writers were getting at; it this a comedy, a superhero flick, or what? All I knew going in was the movie is supposed to be 'great'. The movie starts out slow, which in hindsight is good - the pacing is on point as the viewer is slowly eased into the characters and story. I don't watch trailers, so if you're like me, you're lucky to watch this not knowing what a wild ride you are in for. The whole 'multiverse' concept is simple, yet overused these days and I was very, very disappointed with how it was handled in, say, Dr. Strange: Multiverse of Madness (yep, truly maddening plotholes and zero logic in that one). It's also not so easy to pull off the visuals, SFX and the whole narrative around that sort of thing. However, in EEAaO, it's handled brilliantly, in my opinion. Without taking themselves or the movie too seriously, the writers and the director manage to masterfully engage you in an almost real-life scenario where endless possibilities exist. Most, if not all of the visuals are breathtaking and mesmerising, taking full advantage of the multiverse concept inside the confines of the story, without exaggerating too much or keeping it too low-key for such an ambitious idea. The kung-fu elements I felt where spot on, not relying on 'magic' or 'superpowers' (even though we get a taste of that too, at one point).

Smart and grown-up humour is all over the place too, adding a lighter tone yet not sacrificing the overall atmosphere which is still serious enough to get one thinking and feeling more deeply. The humour itself is definitely a breath of fresh air - it's weird and at times - even kinky, but it does not cross the line too much, it's just enough to be different and really funny at the same time. It's adult aspects are not hard to draw parallels to, say, Deadpool type humour, but of course Deadpool's is way over the top, which is a sort of trademark there, but not here, thankfully.

Speaking of depth, I felt this movie is not brilliant or profound, but still manages to pull intellectual and emotional strings enough to intrigue all types of audiences. It has everything for everyone (pun not intended), from teenagers to grownups, from the casual viewer who seeks only spectacle to the more refined one that needs a bit of flare and meaning in every scene. The overall message is so sweet and simple it can appeal to anyone - perhaps only the people looking for completely empty films would not understand or care what the movie is really about - which I feel is Love, Compassion, Connection.

Trying to dig a little deeper, in a world where metaphysics and now even science are bringing us ever closer to the idea of multiple, perhaps infinite universes and alternative dimensions, quantum fields and so forth, it's a really intriguing and interesting topic with a fresh spin to it. It also has very valid moral questions inserted into that, again, in a world where definitive moral and even existential values seem to be blurring more and more.

Now, about some key elements of the movie - plot (script), direction, dialogue, acting, Action/SFX, sound/music:



Overall judgement - this movie left me feeling inspired, refreshed, and most of all - entertained. I find all this to be rare in recent productions. The movie is certainly not perfect, but I think it's really close to perfection for it's genre and the message I felt it tries to convey. In a few words - go see it if you already didn't, it's worth every minute!!

Title: Entertaining but overrated
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All at Once", directed by the Daniels duo (they're both named Daniel get it?) is an interesting, if messy experiment that starts out promising but turns into a convoluted mess.

Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh) runs a laundromat with her husband Waymond (an excellent Ke Huy Quan) and has a distant relationship with her ironically named daughter Joy (Stephanie Hsu). They are about to be audited by an IRS agent (a saucy Jamie Lee Curtis) when all of the characters seemingly enter a nonsensical "multiverse".

The first 20 minutes are so solidly written and acted that I wonder what the final result would have been had if just abandoned the absurdist concept and presented a straightforward narrative instead. Of course, that's not what this filmmakers are trying to do, but at 140 minutes it wears it welcome quickly.

While I do admire the film for it's originality, it becomes so entrenched in its own over the top silliness you almost wonder what the point of any of this is.

Title: A fun, touching unexpected ride
Review:
I usually write these reviews the day I see the movie on Instagram. So I'm just going to repost it here.

I usually write these from the parking lot of the theater right after I see the movie. With this film I needed time to digest everything.........cause its a lot. On the drive home I was deep in thought wondering how I was going to write this.

First some background. Before Wednesday this week I didn't even know this film existed. I didn't see any trailers, I didn't know what it was about, I didn't even know who starred in it. I went into this movie COMPLETELY blind. A dude I work with invited me out to see it. (Thanks man)

#EverythingEverywhereallatOnce is the story of Evelyn, an over worked wife and mother who runs a failing Laundromat, while taking care of her elderly Father. Her life takes a sudden dramatic and unexpected (in every sense of the word) turn when while at the tax office she is contacted by her husband from an alternate universe.

This movie is Bonkers, balls to the wall insane, 0 to 100 in a millisecond, turned up to 11 crazy ride. It has the feel of a #EdgarWright film in some parts a Mark Neveldine and Brian Taylor film in others with some #WesAnderson sprinkled in. This movie is Hilarious, irreverent, touching, insane, hopeful, gross, confusing, and moving, throughout.

The performances from the Actors were all top notch most notably #MichelleYeoh, #KeHuyQuan and #StephanieHsu. I've never seen Michelle Yeoh in a film like this before and its so cool to see that she's still got it. Ke Huy Quan's character is easily my favourite of the three. The heart of this movie. It was also cool see #JamieLeeCurtis on screen again this time as a minor villan. Last movie I saw her in was #KnivesOut. Great performances all around.

While the story is hard to follow at first, and the transitions are very quick and jarring I have no problem recommending this movie. Its an gem of a film and I'm glad I got to see it. I enjoyed watching this and had a ton of fun. Movies like this remind me of why I like watching movies in the first place. High praises all around.

Title: A Masterpiece
Review:
This movie is like nothing you've ever seen before, but it's amazing. It's hilarious, it's awesome, and it made me cry. It is not a simple story, and it takes some patience, but this is the kind of storytelling that is truly masterful. To take all of these parts and weave them into such a compelling whole is so impressive. Before I watched it I thought, "140 minutes, really?" And 30 minutes in, honestly I was a bit bored. But I stuck with it, and when I finished I was basically just in shock. Like holy crap, I can't believe how much I enjoyed that insane ride.

It may not be for everyone, but from story, to acting, to score, to editing, it's just so well done. Whether or not you enjoy it, you have to at least admire it.

Title: Thank you to everyone who took part in creating this film
Review:
At the end of the day this is a simple and beautiful story about a mother and daughter in a divided, struggling relationship struggling trying to understand one another and failing resulting in their entire world falling apart (both figuratively and literally). The message and self-gratifying feeling this films delivers to its viewers has profoundly touched me, I loved every moment of it. Relationships in immigrant families especially with one's mother, even if filled with intentions of love and protection can be difficult and what a beautiful and unique way to tell it, even if I don't think one would will reallly ever understand or full accept the other at least not in our reality.

Analysis hat, on whats sets it apart is its ability to blend genres, were all now more than ever aware of the multiverse (in films, of course!) so the concept easy enough to grasp, but it allowed it brought a certain originality to this film that probably wont be replicable elsewhere, so a lot of people might called this a gimmick film I mean it certainly won't spawn any sequels or prequels or it's own original genre but I mean who even whats that am I right?

TL;DR

Title: Not out of good ideas just yet...
Review:
In the bevy of remakes, and remixes and sequels Hollywood pops out, there are still diamonds in that rough.

This movie is in everyway an absolute diamond. It is a brilliant story of finding the shine in an ordinary life. And yet, it's told in a way that is visually engaging and so original, you almost forget what the point was.

It's funny, it's weird, it's heartful, it's serious, it's amazing in that it strikes so many chords, and makes them all sing so wonderfully together. The casting, the script, and the performances simply make this a must watch for anyone dying to find something original to see.

Title: As weird as mainstream film can get
Review:
It may be a bad idea to do a brief review of a movie this nuanced and deep, but I'll give it a shot.

This Sci-Fi Comedy takes you on a journey of a Chinese family in America, jumping between alternate realities and timelines. Ke Huy Quan's character calls upon Michelle Yeoh's character to save the multiverse by defeating a dimension-hopping being hunting her down and attempting to destroy all of reality. Michelle's character might defeat this being by jumping between parallel realities - becoming different versions of herself in different timelines. And that's just the setup.

The first thing you'll notice is that this movie is filled with lovable actors playing endearing characters. Michelle and James Hong are legends of the screen and effortlessly pull off their action, comedy, and dramatic sequences. Ke Huy (the Asian kid, now adult, from The Goonies and Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom) oozes kindness and charm. Jamie Lee Curtis also brings her experience to this movie as her presence is always both ridiculous and intimidating throughout.

This is significant because these actors play at least 5 - 10 different characters in the movie, spanning every mainstream Hollywood genre. There were artistic liberties in some of these alternate dimensions Michelle goes into. I wish this fictional world had more rules so it isn't just "Anything can happen, so let's throw up whatever we want on the screen!". It's fun but also seemingly art for art's sake.

The real story is a family drama caught up in this dimension-hopping chaos. There is meaning in pondering what could have been if you had only made different choices earlier in life. This movie challenges you with accepting the choices you've made up to this point and enjoy your current life despite the mistakes you think you've made. Michelle's character is faced with this challenge multiple times, and it's truly a wonder to watch.

Enjoy the acting, the colorful visuals, the action, the comedy, and the philosophical and thought-provoking dialogue all at once. Or not. This isn't your all too familiar genre film. But I'll thoroughly enjoy watching all the awards this movie will inevitably get.

Title: Suspiciously overrated.
Review:
I watched the movie with high hopes, because of the after Oscar's publicity. I hate to tell you, but I do not see the Oscar's in this movie. I do not see the excellent acting. Or the brilliant script. The storyline is very vague and most of the time you do not understand what are the dialogues about. Apart from few photographically nice scenes, the whole movie is just absurd, like a bad joke. Do not see the art, neither the blockbuster. Even the action scenes are long and a bit dull. I would define not remember it tomorrow, and I would definitely not suggest it to anyone else. Overall, I am happy I saw it for free..

Title: This film was truly mind blowing!
Review:
This film was so visually stunning. The way they used lighting was phenomenal, the interchanging of lights shining on Evelyn as she looks at Waymond, showing her love is so cleverly done as well as giving you so much to think about in a film.

The way they balanced family, love, making the film gritty, using Kung Fu, bringing tears to my eyes and making me laugh out loud is something I've never seen attempted in a film. This is the true representation of 'Everything' and it works.

I loved how you could see Michelle Yeoh, really play the role of her character, Evelyn. Seeing all her thought processes. Starting off confused and slowly turning into a badass Kung Fu queen.

"I don't know... the only thing I do know... is that we have to be kind" and "Especially if we don't know what's going on" the way Key Huy Quan, Waymond, presents this line is so touching because it's true. With all this violence in this world today we are so quick to judge people who are confused, and don't know what they're doing that we forget to 'be kind' and patient with them.

I have a very short attention span so this film was perfect. Everything was fast paced and so bright and flashy that it forced me to stay engaged plus I wanted to so I didn't miss anything. This film was truly mind blowing.

Title: Just be a rock
Review:
The movie at times feels like it is written by 12 year olds that have taken the pills from limitless and have unlocked 100% of their brain. The whacky, strange beauty of this movie means the more and more you try and work out where you are narratively, the further away from the truth you'll find yourself. As the film states, you have to just be a rock and observe as it works its multiversal magic. Everything everywhere all at once is bombastic, beautiful and surgical in its precision, it will make you laugh, it will make you cry and it will make you question if you are the best or worst version of yourself in the vast multiverse of possibility. 10 stars. End of.

Title: Wonderful
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Must see movie - but there will be many who miss the detail
Review:

Another clever aspect was the use of subtitles and language...for most viewers that draws your attention. You cannot be distracted- you need to pay attention. Thoroughly recommended viewing - best movie to come out in decades - iI consider it to be must view...

Title: This Unbearable Campiness of Being
Review:
From the technical perspective, the techniques used to achieve the moving pictures we get to see on screen, CGI or practical, are all commendable. Now let's talk about the finished product.

The entire concept of a "multiverse" is open to interpretation. This is due to the fact that no one has ever ventured out of our universe if indeed this could be done. If there are infinite version of ourselves then surely nothing is impossible. Our creative minds may not even be capable of imagining all the possible versions of ourselves in existence. It's hard to wrap our brains around the concept itself to begin with. So when asked "What version of yourself, of our world, do you think is out there?", there are no wrong answers. All we need is an open mind.

An open mind is what I had when I sat down watch this film. I was open to accept the version of the multiverse this movie has to offer. There is, after all, no wrong answers. No wrong versions.

Then what is supposed to be a mindbogglingly vast and infinite multiverse has been reduced and forced to play inside a dimly lit, stuffy, cluttered, and claustrophobic little stage where a number of casts and characters are all trying to be significant and profound all at the same time. I tried my very best to keep an open mind, just be at awe of this supposed magnificent achievement in film making.

Then lesbians with sausage fingers and talking rocks says I'm taking myself way too seriously.

Title: Every feeling everywhere all at once
Review:
I don't get why people who watched the film for 20-45 minutes can come here and claim it was an unfunny, boring and chaotic movie and people shouldn't watch it.

You should watch it, I believe this is a masterpiece that will change how we see things, how we see each other, and most of all, how we see ourselves.

I can agree that the first half hour was a bit confusing, but after a while I began to see the connection, the emotions, the harsh reality of how this was so close to my own home. And once I got all of that, I saw a beautiful cinematic piece unfold into an incredible storyline. You must embrace the chaos to get the chaos.

So please watch until the very end, you'll like it. And you'll get it.

Title: America hits bottom
Review:
When such things are not only possible but moreover applauded and awarded, then you know something is really wrong. Not like the Vietnam years when actors would come and protest the war, but rather like the late '40s this dark era when a sword was suspended upon anyone's neck who would dare dissent. Of course censorship has many faces, and is best served when it lies inside people's hearts. America steadily tumbles in a long protracted decline. It is not just the wrong people, it is the institutions that are corrupted to the core. The day has come when we can see the '90s as a golden era compared to what has followed. Hypocrisy makes us proud to export democracy and human rights around the world while there is a crisis inside and when no one outside finds us convincing and truly committed any more.

Title: A truly Wonderful Comedy Movie
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is as the title already says a truly wonderful comedy Movie. Not only are the characters amazingly written, the cgi (that was made by the driector who just learned it btw) was on another level and the story just beautiful and deep. The Ending was also very interesting, because it let the viewers question, if everything that they just have seen actually happned or just a visualization of their situation was (I don't want to spoil anything so that might have been kinda weird written). The only point that I think wasn't perfect in this sense was the usage of the villain. The villain was way too soon revealed and with that took the mysterious flare that the movie had been building up at the start. Besides that, I really enjoyed watching this movie with my family and we all had something to laugh because of how incredible stupid (the actions in there not how they were made) some scenes were. The depth that the movie has been building up was also very promising to me and it left a truly emotional impact on me and my family.

9/10 A must watch!

Title: A Masterpiece, breath of fresh air
Review:
Einstein illustrated relativity with an example of a hot stove and that special girl.

In 2022, this concept is probably best illustrated by the comparison sitting through one agonizing episode of She-Hulk that factually lasts somewhere between 15 and 30 minutes but feels like an eternity that you are forcing yourself through.

And then there's this original movie that's not based on a franchise, objectively lasts 2h 19m and feels like it's barely been more than an hour after you're done.

And yet this movie didn't leave me desperate for more. I think this movie has accomplished a very rare feat, especially in the current day and age: Finding the perfect length for the story it is telling.

I'm for sure going to rewatch this movie many times, it's just such a joy ride and yet it managed to bring tears to my eyes. It's deeply meaningful and absolutely silly. It's original and raw, wild and meticulously crafted. It's literally everything everywhere all at once. Well, except for boring or predictable.

Best film of 2022, and it's not even close. This film deserves nothing less than Academy Awards for best picture and best original screenplay.

Seems like post Oscars lot's of criticism about the movie being overhyped, people are not actually enjoying the movie or appreciating it for what it is but only in comparison to others in the lineup that made them feel some way or another. Regardless of what awards this movie has won I would suggest taking yourself out of what the narrative you hear say and just go along for the ride.

Title: Never knew SciFi could take such a 'familiar' turn

Title: it's an everything bagel..
Review:
... cause there's pretty much a bit of everything. Everything Everywhere All At Once is a genre-bending multiverse film, it's a non-stop action, comedy, drama, fantasy, sci-fi, thriller and a little bit of romance. It's the kind of film that you're not really sure how describe it to your friends when they asks what it's about. It's definitely a fresh, eccentric out of the box film of its genre.

It has decent story and very well acted but what strike my attention is the visual. It's definitely has the most extravagantly colorful striking cinematography and editing. Especially with the little budget they had (from what i heard cmiiw). It's definitely a strong OSCAR contender.

But with all that being said, with all these overtly colorful strong visual and heavy drama, at times it feels a bit too...much(?) Don't get me wrong, it's still an extremely well made film, but it feels a bit overwhelming to watch, even with only 2hr19min runtime.

Anyway, definitely a must watch.

9/10.

Title: Hope: A Lesson on how Hope...
Review:
Let's be real, this movie ain't for everyone, and I get that. When I saw it with my family, I'd say 2/3's of us liked it, with my father being the biggest detractor. And to those of you out there who are realists in life, content with where things are for you, and just the quiet type of easy-going person that just rolls through life, than you can stop reading this review right here.

To everyone else, keep reading, I promise you'll be happy you did.

If like me, you aren't perfect, than sit down, turn your TV on, and give it a go. It starts off hectic, the first ten minutes are a whirlwind, and it keeps going. There are hints of something more until the twenty minute mark of so when stuff starts for real.

The first act is decently linear, a typical movie in many ways, but also does more to mess with your mind than almost any other film. For the casual viewer, you might think that it can't get any more crazy than this. It's somewhat depressing, but it's so fun to watch, as it keeps you on your toes at all times.

Than the act titled "Everywhere" starts, and in my view, this is truly where the film hits it's stride. It takes you on an emotional ride for the next hour, up and down, everything you could possibly feel rushing through you at all times. I was glued to the screen, and quite frankly I loved almost every second of it. Yeah sure, there are some little parts that are kinda stupid, some parts that are a little too much. But then, there are others that you thought were crazy, and they turn out to teach you something profound about life.

When the credits hit me, I learnt something about myself, I felt a feeling that I hadn't felt in ages... Hope. Sure, I'd felt hopeful, or excited, or absolutely lit at parties or practice whatnot, but I hadn't felt a real sense of hope in so long, a real sense of happiness in so long. It's liberating in a way to feel that, to realize that maybe you did get it all wrong, to realize that maybe there is more out there than what you'd expected life was gonna hand you.

Maybe my movie has just entered it's third act, or at least my personal journey of acceptance has done so, I can't really decide, but I do know this. Most things might not matter, but some things do, and that's what gives you hope in life, it's what gives me hope. While you may return to your point of normalcy later down the line, your "hedonic set point," the knowledge that your life can reach a sense of fulfillment is what drives you along.

This movie didn't give me that fulfillment, but it did make me realize that it's still possible, and it gave me...

Hope.

Title: Profound wisdom in an art form.
Review:
Very few titles have done justice to the theme of interconnectedness i.e., how everything is connected across time and space.

On a spectrum of complexity let's start with the simplest one first. Bullet Train, which is all about how lives of a few individuals in a city culminates and in the end comes together. Then comes Babel - an interlocking story about one single event and its impact on four families living across different countries. Third is Life Itself which is about the cumulative impact on two families spread over two generations and two continents. Most complex of all is Cloud Atlas. This one took it to another level and showed how the action of one individual life impacts one another in the past, present and future. All these titles have tried to explain that nothing is random and there are no coincidences.

But Everything Everywhere All at Once has done what all these titles plus a few others (put together) could not.

Everything: If you end up scratching your head after watching this movie, the title says it all. "Everything". Everything is The theory of the Infinite on a Cosmic Scale. That's exactly what Stephen Hawking has tried to tell us with his Magnum Opus "The Theory of Everything". Alice in Wonderland, 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Matrix, The Bhagavad Gita (the inner battle of Good vs Evil), The beginning & conflagration of cosmos, The Big Bang, Black Holes explained in term of Bagels, giant stars giving birth to elements and the subsequent evolution of life on Earth, reincarnations, debate on Atoms and Randomness vs Faith & Providence, Free-will vs Destiny. Phew! Simply put, everything about the Universe (which incidentally contains almost everything). And not just that also infinity and beyond - The Multiverse. All this is just too much to take in a span of a couple of hours.

Everywhere: And if everything wasn't too much to take in, in comes Everywhere. This is the theory of the sub-atomic - the infinitely small world of Particles. The Strange world of the Subatomic which is governed by a madhouse set of physical laws known as quantum mechanic. Here it is possible for a sub atomic particle like electron to be in two locations at the same - Quantum Superimposition.

All at Once: Everything Everywhere All at Once equals complexity raised to the power infinity. But that complexity, if seen differently is merely on a surface level. What it all boils down to is the present moment we all have and the choices we all make in the here and now. Simply put love is a "choice" we call can make in every moment and this has a profound impact on both here and now and also infinity which some call it as "destiny". If that sounded heavy, read the ancient Hindu Scriptures, the Abrahamic Religions, Greco Roman Philosophy & Persian Mysticism and you will get the same eternal message which has stood the test of time and space.

All is One. Love All.

Peace.

Title: Bonkers, charming and hilarious
Review:
This film was bonkers! But very good. Michelle Yeo plays Evelyn Wang, and hard working but disorganised owner of a laundromat with her husband, Waymond Wang (Ke Huy Quan). Their as-good-as estranged daughter, Joy (Stephanie Hsu) is struggling to deal with teenage girl emotions while having a white girlfriend and their parents' disdain of this. So basically a happy family film accept Evelyn is the key to the survival of the entire multiverse.

The best place to start is the acting, for which a have to give 10/10. Kudos to Sarah Finn as she superbly fuses elite Chinese actors with American Hollywood. I'll get to the main cast later, but my god Jamie Lee Curtis was exceptional. Playing a double entendre role, she provides hilarity, menace, authority and ferocity, all one one scene alone! She plays the tax auditor who threatens to close down the beloved laundromat, while playing a key role in the wider multiverse as well.

James Hong looked like he was having a lot of fun as the traditional, hard-nosed Chinese father who is old and disappointed in his daughter. He is allowed by director David Kwan to show a more youthful side to him as well.

But the whole film comes down to the holy trinity: Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan and Stephanie Hsu. The chemistry between them is electric, and they are able to effectively convey the struggles of immigrants coming over to make a living in the US, while trying to maintain being a family. Michelle Yeoh's Evelyn is the driving force behind the family, and shows her full array of talents, from excellent fighting skills to being a hilariously snappy mother, while having the weight the task she is facing. Quan is just so adorable. It is heartbreaking to see how innocent and puppy like he is, also being able to flex his martial arts. The standout for me however was Hsu's Joy, an ironic name considering you see her smile maybe 3 times (twice in an evil grin). Growing up with a failing mother, unaccepting grandfather, a useless father, AND being a gay Chinese girl, AND THEN being the literal centre of the multiverse, she is phenomenal. Raw, emotional, sassy and evil, she also shows that this is a front for the deep sadness she feels after all the circumstances I have just mentioned.

The direction of this film was 10/10 as they jump from filming style to filming style, with clear and obvious influences from the classic martial arts films to Groundhog Day, without it being overbearing. The interplay between each universe is unbelievable, and some of the characters are unparalleled (they manage to make two rocks poignant!).

I think it very slightly got lost in its confusion, but the underlying message of an appreciation of family and those who matter most, while bombarding you with hot dog fingers, dildos and Raccoonatouille makes this whacky, charming, hilarious and wholesome.

Title: Love it

Title: For 10 year olds. Puerile drivel.
Review:
EEAAO is the worst movie ever to win Oscars, 7 in all and none of them deserved.

In whose mind was it Best anything? I stuck with it until about 20 minutes from the end simply because it had won these awards and I still don't understand why. There was no story the viewer could follow other than some woke nonsense about being 'kind'. The acting showed no finesse because the actors had no intelligible lines to work with. There's a silly premise of a middle aged woman being able to jump about between different universes while she's in the throes of a divorce and doing her business tax returns.

Anyone over the age of 16 may well be praying for the end as I was, although I never got quite that far before jumping ship.

To show some balance here, the only other film I've seen in this year's Oscar race, is the far superior "Women Talking". I would challenge any of the performances in that film against Michelle Yeoh and company. EEAAO is in short, a car crash in terms of good film making and I really despair now of the Oscars if rubbish like this win. What is wrong with voters? Did they get their kids to vote in their place?

Title: The Better Multiverse Film?!
Review:
The characters are EVERYTHING!

The plot is EVERYWHERE!

As it happens ALL AT ONCE!

The main lead actress, Michelle Yeoh, steals the entire show, perhaps being my favorite role she's ever done right along side "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon", with a great supporting cast that at some points in the film, they take center stage along with Yeoh.

Speaking of supporting cast, Ke Huy Quan absolutely dominated with the screentime he was given and a wonderful and emotional triumph return, from "Indiana Jones" and "The Goonies" to a now Oscar Nominated feature film.

As this being a story about the multiverse, it succeeded far greater than "Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness". Which was overall a missed opportunity and a disappointment. The film brought more and clear understanding about the concept of the multiverse instead of complicating things to connect with a broader and wider universe like the MCU. The film also stands out more from other versions and takes of the concept of the multiverse due to its standalone nature and its own take on how the structure of the multiverse works.

To wrap this up, "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is an achievement in filmmaking from its cast of characters , story and its many themes and connections to the real world, to the shear insanity of weirdness that it gives, only to keep it contained, only pushing the boundaries when it needs to.

This is a MUST see for movie fans.

One of my favorite films of last year.

Title: Great movie without a doubt (for me)
Review:
I watched this movie, I liked it very much as you can guess by the 10/10, and I am sad to see people giving it negative reviews so I read some of them and summarized what most of the hate for the movie is about:

Most of the haters agree that the movie is creative, but seem to dislike the length and the beginning of the movie. The main reason is the old styled introduction that requires patience for the story to kick in. The time it takes to introduce the setting might seem a bit long for young or unprepared audiences but I don't think it would be a problem for patient people. The waiting in the beginning pays of greatly throughout the movie, especially to those patient enough to listen to the characters and dive into the story in the time given to them. I also noticed some people being mislead into thinking of it as a comedy movie, they were unsatisfied with it for not being funny, but luckily, they seem to be a minority. And the plot is coming next, people seem to miss the plot of the movie, which is understandable considering how complicated it is. The way multiverses were induced in the story is just perfect, I heard that this movie's idea for multiverses came from "Spider man: Into The Spider Verse" movie, but it is a misleading statement because this movie uses multiverses as a plot and art device much better than the Spider Man movie. In any case, the plot is very hard to follow for that exact reason, and that is why people didn't like the storytelling in my opinion, they just seem to miss the depth of the story. But that is only a problem for those who can't follow it's plot, because the plot itself is just perfect, I just can't explain how good the story is. The last one is the art, it's probably the best part of the movie, the way it ties to the plot, the abstract images, the different settings for each universe, SPOILERS FOR THE NEXT SENTENCE: I totally forgot the movie was taking it's place in a single building for the whole movie.

END OF SPOILERS watching it made me feel as if I visited each of those universes, they are memorable, interesting, each in it's own way. I am amazed at how the art represented such a bizarre idea for a plot, and excelled in it.

In conclusion, despite the movie clearly not being made for everyone, it has no flaws when it comes to writing and filming. The movie might not be as engaging at the beginning, but the moment it pulls you in will stay with you forever. Or in case these type of movies are not for you, you will never get to that moment.

Title: Mind Bending Experience
Review:
This movie was one of the most mind bending and original movies I've seen in a long time. The music, cinematography, and acting were all top notch. I recommend going into this movie with as little understanding of it as you possibly can, and be open minded. This movie made me laugh, had great action, and also had an emotional core. I love that this movie wasn't afraid to not take itself too seriously, allowing itself to play around with some completely absurd concepts, and having them work perfectly. I also think it's important to go out and watch creative and original movies like this to encourage more directors to follow suit. I'll end with my only criticism of this movie, which is that it did kinda start a little slow for me. Other than that, I highly recommend everyone go see this movie.

Title: Innovative, Fun, Insightful Stuff
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once, which stars Michelle Yeoh in a superb performance, lives up to its promise of being a magnificent sensory overload that is both profoundly disorienting and intellectually captivating. The film's distinctive fusion of genres, styles, and insights creates a wholly new immersive experience that is what makes it so original. In a style that is both visually magnificent and emotionally potent, the movie deftly combines aspects of drama, fantasy, and science fiction.

Although it is never explicitly mentioned, Everything Everywhere All At Once implies that what gives life purpose is the understanding that everything and every moment has equal value because there is no inherent meaning. It's a daring cinematic reflection on all the insignificant but essential things that give us and our life significance in an uncaring cosmos.

Title: Not the best film of 2022 in my opinion but still a masterpiece
Review: I love the creative, inventive and inspiring world building of all of these different universes and it kind of takes you to these different worlds. The mother and daughter conflict is done very well and is done much better than in Turning Red. What makes this a great conflict is the fact that you can understand from both points of view. The mother is a person who wants her daughter to have a simple but good life but doesn't want to confuse her father by telling him that her daughter is a lesbian. And the daughter wants her romance to bloom and wants her mother to accept that. And this makes great conflict because you can be on both sides. Turning Red didn't do that that much. The mother is just a person who doesn't want her daughter to use the panda power so that way she doesn't embarrass herself but the daughter wants to use it because it's making people happy and she wants people to stay happy and she also wants to see a concert. In Turning Red you're more on the daughter's side than the mother's side because of her being more unlikable and pretty douchey. Here yes the mother can go a little far through insulting her daughter but it's only done at least once at the 15 minute mark of the movie. What makes this movie work for me though is the acting. Michelle Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu and Jamie Lee Curtis are all fantastic but the standout for me and let's talk about the all time GOAT of the movie. Ke Huy Quan. Need I say more? Well yes. Ke Huy Quan started out well with Temple of Doom and Goonies but after those movies he hasn't had the best career. But here he gives in my opinion one of the best performances of the 21st century that I've seen. What makes this performance so perfect is mainly down to the two main elements he pulls off perfectly. One is the comedy. I love the way he portrays the quirky and goofy husband and he pulls off all of his comedic parts perfectly. The drama he also does perfectly. So much of his lines for the drama like the "be kind" monologue are simple yet very effective and make his performance pull it off perfectly. He's the heart of the movie and I can see why. Man, this feels like a huge comeback and it feels fantastic. I can see why this movie changed cinema simply because of it's writing, editing, directing, acting, comedy and the creativity and ingenuity in the world building. It feels like the last third of Turning Red. It takes something that is so funny and hilarious but yet perfectly transitions into something that's simple yet very powerful and emotional at the same time. A movie that I'd highly recommend.

Title: Everything Everywhere All At Once
Review:
1 - An absolute stinker of a film, with no redeeming features. It's unlikely that any film will receive this score.

2 - Oh, not great at all. Amongst the worst films ever made.

3 - I won't be back, and am less than pleased I've just spent time watching this.

4 - Very poor effort. Struggled through.

5 - Mediocre. Nothing special at all, but not completely unbearable.

6 - Tries hard. On its way to worthwhile.

7 - Solid viewing. Can't complain - would recommend.

8 - Cracking. Enjoyed immensely. But it takes a lot to get 9.

9 - It takes a lot to get 9.

10 - An absolute banger of a film. Couldn't be better. It's unlikely that any film will receive this score.

Home.

Title: The glass ceiling cracked, but...
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: It's a live story
Review:
The hype is one thing, but if you love film, this is for you. Sideways references to Kubrick and Hitchcock, wonderful cinematography sound like Zimmer. It's just excellent.

Trying to summarise it would be worthless, as the quality, depth and range of the script and acting would not be served justice.

I cannot comprehend the poor reviews of this, it is simply out of this world. It justifies everything it's been nominated for and I imagine the past masters of directing would wish this was there's.

Is it Scorsese grit, no but it possesses the speed of the Marrix with charm and wit of a Cornetto film. Watch it and walk away happy and inspired.

Title: It's Everywhere Alright
Review:
The film Everything Everywhere All at Once is the trippiest, most confusing movie I've ever watched in my life. There is so much bouncing around, and it requires a lot of thought and attention to understand it enough to enjoy it. And those are my only real cons. It's a great movie, and it does have a pretty depressing tone with a lot of scenes having a sense of hopelessness. There is still plenty of moments with a great sense of hope, but I wouldn't recommend to those who struggle mentally. Michelle Yeoh always nails her parts, especially as disapproving mothers for some reason. It's a bizarre film with a crazy new angle for the movie industry. I wouldn't mind seeing more like this, just maybe with a happier tone. A lot of visuals are really cool but also really trippy and hard to watch. The action is also really good, and the movie is full of it. So while it's a really depressive movie, it's also a whole new crazy A24 movie with lots of new, creative things brought to the table that I wouldn't mind seeing a whole lot more of in other films.

Title: Best movie ever
Review:
Well, I laughed, I cried, then I cried while laughing. I'm not sure how they managed to reach so many emotions, all at once (pun intended), but it definitely worked. I literally sent a message to my wife, who was travelling, after one scene where they were holding hands. I started watching this film without knowing exactly what I was getting into but was completely taken by the simplicity and complexity of this story. Every aspect of the characters serves a purpose to the story and moves the plot forward. The humour is so silly but amazingly funny. I guess funny doesn't need to be too complicated. What a masterpiece.

Title: Brilliant and great fun!
Review:
I loved it! Gives vibes of Kurt Vonnegut/David Lynch/Thomas Pynchon. This movie has a great mix of imagination, humor, and clever dialog. It has emotional appeal, but is in no way sappy. I think the filmmakers took a lot of chances in the making of this film, which comes gives it a freewheeling, unpredictable quality.

The only criticism I have is that it was a little too long, and some scenes could have been eliminated or shortened

I'm sure that many people will not like this film, because it transgresses many of the formulas of filmmaking and its effects are low-budget and silly. Some people will simply not want to stick with it, but those who do will be rewarded.

Title: It's okay people, you're not alone!
Review:
With regard to the hordes of people who have praised this film, I've abandoned the idea of the "Emperor's new clothes" or herd dynamics in favour of a medical disorder of epidemic proportions - this being Visual Agnosia. I have of course questioned whether it's a personal failing on my own behalf but dropped this idea following consultation with other likeminded individuals who seem tuned in to the here and now. Let's be clear, I like quirky, and I recognise and appreciate originality, and of course clever humour and emotional depth. These are all central components in my appreciation of a good film. However, I have to say that I recognised none of these characteristics in Everything Everywhere All at once. For me, it was simply a convoluted mess that encompassed some naive notions of "imaginary science" alongside trite everyday woes. As for humour! I guess that's subjective, but banana skin slapstick is hardly sharp-end comedy. And for budding screenwriters, the depth of the dialogue between two incongruous rocks might be an example not to follow.

Title: Give me more crazy multiversal films
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Beautiful explanation of a hundred different emotions. A piece of art.
Review:
This movie was definitely a metaphor for so many different emotions you could feel towards life and family: frustration, anger, depression, existentialism, love, kindness.... More than anything, I'm amazed that it was able to clearly express all of those things amidst a very chaotic way.

This movie is more of a piece of art than your typical beginning-middle-end stories where everything has to be explicitly stated for you. If you're having a hard time following or understanding the film, I urge you to at least finish the whole thing first and go through all of the emotions the movie makes you go through, no matter how lost you are, because it's part of the experience watching the film. I'm glad this got the recognition it deserved.

Like anything in life there will be people who hate this. Half of them just want to complain about something or perhaps this genre is not for them(why see it then?) Anwyays. Don't pay attention to the detractors. LIke I said. Go into the movie with an Open mind. Go for the experience. This movie may surprise some while for others you will get a lot out of this movie. Enjoy!!!!

Title: A Unique Cinematic Journey
Review:
This left an indelible impression with its originality and distinct narrative. Having watched it twice, my appreciation for the film's creative storytelling and unique structure only grew stronger. While I found some inconsistencies upon my second viewing, these minor flaws did not overshadow the innovative plot and execution. The movie's ability to seamlessly blend different dimensions and timelines showcases its ambition and daring. The intricate web of emotions and realities that the film weaves is both captivating and thought-provoking. Despite the discovered plot holes, the film's creativity remains unparalleled, elevating it to a level of distinctiveness that is rarely seen in contemporary cinema. Without delving into spoilers, I can attest that "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a testament to the power of imagination and unconventional storytelling, and it provides a viewing experience that stimulates the mind while pushing the boundaries of cinematic storytelling.

Title: A poor Matrix wannabe about a Mother Daughter relationship on the rocks and "what life could have been, if, but be happy with what you have"
Review:
The funny part is I hardly need to write more than that title. They tried too hard with this one, and like one of the very few critics who was right said, " it lacked finesse in its story-telling, " big time. They tried to make it into this deep moving story about the universe but it falls very very flat on every level.

The whole jumping universes was really really dumb and poorly executed, again it really reeked of trying to copy the Matrix concepts and ending up in epic failure. Just not captivating at all, NOT deep please, not even moving really no tears from me and it isn't hard to bring them from me. Best things I can say is it is somewhat unique (less my Matrix comment), there was decent action in the way of fighting scenes at times and there were some laugh at loud scenes for sure. The laughing scenes saved this getting a 1 from me.

Wanted to walk out of theater many times, wish I had even the end was stupid but thankfully part 3 was very short like 1 minute because I was really dreading it. Worst movie I have seen for a long time sorry. Now had I dropped Acid like one user suggests, yeah, it could be a 10 then perhaps.

Title: Did someone put drugs in my beer?
Review:
I'm still reeling from having seen EEAAO. There's almost certainly a parallel universe somewhere where Old McDonald had a film called EEAAO, as the old nursery rhyme has it. If I had ever taken mind-altering drugs before, I might have been on familiar ground, but as it was I think the film makers took those drugs for me. I don't know they were on something at the time, but how else do you explain this incredible concoction?

One of the things I liked best about it was the unashamed willingness to be a vehicle for monumental silliness. If you don't like ridiculous humour, this film might wear thin very quickly. Luckily, I do enjoy it when done well, and for much of the middle act of the story the ludicrous spectacle was relentless, and hilarious. You just never know what's coming next.

But happily for some there's much more to EEAAO than absurdity and comedy. It's also quite touching, and charming, and has a few serious points to make about life, which avoids being mawkish or overly sentimental (just), thanks in part to leavening with the aforementioned silliness.

It's also incredibly imaginative. To combine the mind-expanding elements with the utter mundanity of a woman struggling with her taxes, and make a coherent story that ultimately pulls all the loose threads together for a surprisingly satisfying conclusion, is quite an achievement.

There's also quite a lot of subtitled Chinese dialogue, which switches back and forth from Mandarin to English and back to Mandarin again, because the main characters are all Chinese living in America, and speak both languages. This can make it hard on the brain at times, but stick with it; it helps to expand the mind!

Oh god, I've just had another flashback! Excuse me while I try to explain why I'm pissing myself laughing out of the blue again.....

Title: Has everything you'd want

This movie is funny, action packed, trippy, deep, and uplifting. I don't think any movie has ever made me feel such a roller coaster of emotions.

Title: Absurd that makes sense
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Title: You here right now
Review:
Well, the movie of the year will not be a $100+ million budget movie, but a smart, funny, heartfelt, creative piece that will take you to other possible outcomes of our lives, teach about family relations and roles. Gosh I love this instant classic and makes me want to watch again and pay more attention.

It will make you wondering about "what ifs", your choices in your past and your future possibilities, trick you into believe that nothing means anything, but at the end, where everything comes together you realize that in life, it's really you and here and right now.

Title: I have been longing for this!
Review:
The multiverse theme, the humor - both sardonic and relieving while also absurd and therapeutic, the cinematic brilliance, the boldness and the superb acting, it all came together in this masterpiece that I will watch again and again. I can't think of any movie that stitched together such a complex storytelling with this many layers and aspects, and made it work. It is truly an achievement that will be studied for a long time. I am so happy for all the appraisals this movie got, which will inspire future directors and producers to go places they previously would not dare to go. I have been waiting for a movie like this a long time. It is like a blend of cinematic and storytelling aspects of "Being John Malkovich", "The Matrix", "A clockwork Orange", "Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon" and "Turning Red", and then multiply the chaotic mess with 10. It is brilliant!

Title: Awful
Review:
That's how I describe it, awful. When I asked my husband.what he thought about it he said "I don't know" I said I don't understand what that means and he said I don't know what to say about it, my mind is f'd from watching it and I can't process a thought at the moment.

We always try to watch all of the Oscar nominated movies each year. There have been several that we didn't really enjoy, but they were at least watchable. This movie is almost impossible to watch. We had to divide it in 3 nights because it was so awful. 20 minutes the first night then 30 minutes the second night, then finished it on the 3rd night, but had to take a break about 30 minutes into the 3rd night. I'm actually angry that we wasted our time on this garbage. We kept thinking and hoping that it would get better, but it didn't. We never would have watched this had it not won so many Oscars, I just don't understand how anyone could enjoy this migraine inducing mess.

Our advice is don't waste your time on this dumpster fire, it really is awful. I have no idea why it was even considered Oscar worthy much less all the nominations and wins.

Title: One of the best movie of the year.
Review:
Not only this is the ultimate movie on the multiverse, even better and more powerful than Marvel and Netflix movies and series on multiverse (Dr. Strange, Loki, Umbrella Academy, etc.). And I am a great fan of that fantastic stuff.

Not only this is the ultimate cinematic trip: visionary, crazy, with such a lot of creativity at its best and many ideas that you won't believe they belong to only a two-hour-and-a-half movie. You will leave the theater with the head upside down.

This is also a great, beautiful, inspired and inspiring movie. The Daniels are in a state of bliss. Someone gives an award to those writers and directors for this masterpiece.

Title: A new neighbour of Slaughterhouse-Five
Review:
I should say that I didn't really like Slaughterhouse-Five much, and while watching this movie I didn't like it much either. But while by the end of Slaughterhouse-Five I still didn't really like it, I did end up liking this movie by the end! They are similar in the sense that our main characters are faced with an entirely new view of the world as if they have ascended to a higher dimension they can freely traverse, and they must grapple with the idea that nothing truly matters. I feel both don't really reach their full potential mainly because they make themselves too chaotic to truly enjoy, but this movie certainly still worked. And so this review isn't just reviewing a movie and a book at the same time, the visuals were also spectacularly beautiful and the acting was quite great mainly from the Joy character(s). Overall glad I watched.

Title: Don't stop watching until the end!
Review:

I can see why some people would switch off prior to the end (I never do) and i was finding it all a bit tedious about three quarters of the way through but then it all started coming together in a most glorious and moving fashion that propelled the film to one of my watches of the year. Its like a giant, crazy, jigsaw puzzle and you only really see how beautiful the picture is when all the final pieces are in place. I get that one of the films themes was "what could have been" but for me it was more about the complexities of a mother daughter relationship.

Title: The Dissection of story by story
Review:
All stories are told in someone's perspective. Perspective is always limited. As a result, it becomes incomplete and factually incorrect.

In this film with the, common events and choices of daily life had been shown in multiverse theme .Already there are films which are made with similar theme. Like The Matrix, Mr. Nobody, Dr. Strange. But this absurd comedy film is more complex, chaotic and multi-dimensional.

Based on many variables, we come to the conclusion what happened with us either good or bad, right or wrong and so on. All such conclusions are irrelevant and don't matter in cosmic scale.

Philosopher Alan Watts said, The meaning of life is just to be alive.

It is so plain, obvious & so simple. And yet, everybody rushes around in a great panic as if it were necessary to achieve something beyond them.

Title: One of the worst movies I have ever seen
Review:
Although this movie does have some humorous and touching moments and some good action scenes they are drowned in an interminable morass of frenetic randomness. Nothing really connects with anything or means anything and the plot , such as it is , never really progresses. It's ultimately a huge and tedious mess, a sort of failed experiment.

In all fairness, the actors all give good performances, especially considering that they have to portray nany different characters. The sets and special effects are imaginative and evocative , creating an extremely multifaceted universe, some of it anchored in the past , some very mundane and some very futuristic. There is lots of fast and unoredictable action. Unfortunately, all the good qualities of this movie are completely sunk by the abysmal script , which totally fails to hold one's attention. You could walk out at any time during the running time and not miss out on anything.

Title: This slaps
Review:
Everything Everywhere All At Once" is an excellent film that is both visually stunning and intellectually engaging. The film's unique and creative use of colors and special effects creates a truly immersive experience for the viewer, drawing them into the multiverse and the adventures of the characters.

The acting in the film is also superb, with Michelle Yeoh, Stephanie Hsu, and Jamie Lee Curtis all delivering outstanding performances. Each actress brings a unique energy and perspective to their role, and their chemistry on screen is a joy to watch.

Beyond its technical and artistic merits, the film also succeeds in exploring complex ideas and themes. The nature of reality, the multiverse theory, and the interconnectedness of all things are just a few of the ideas that the film grapples with. The film's ability to balance these more profound concepts with humor and action makes it an enjoyable and thought-provoking watch.

Title: Quite simply the best movie ever made.
Review:
Maybe there are comedies funnier. Maybe there are dramas more emotional. Maybe there are sci-films more intriguing, or action films more thrilling. But no other film in existence does them "all at once" quite like this. If you've ever felt plagued by lack of meaning in your life, or burdened by existentialism - Daniel Kwan has blessed you with an antidote. Enjoy.

Title: Excellent
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: One of the best movies I've ever seen
Review:
I loved how smart, silly and moving this movie was. I laughed until my stomach hurt and cried until my eyes were red, and through it all I was contemplating the meaning of life while exploring the idea of the multiverse. This movie is truly Everything Everywhere all at once.

I believe it to be one of the greatest films of the past decade, without a doubt. It is an exciting mixture of emotional ups and downs, and every scene has a deeper meaning behind it.

This movie is a must-see for every film buff, especially if you enjoy delving into a variety of concepts and find the notion of the multiverse particularly intriguing.

Title: Absolutely insane movie that's unique in all the memorable ways
Review:
What a wild film, even by A24 standards. Despite reminding me of a lot of films and filming styles, I haven't really seen anything like this movie before. It feels like what A24 was born to make and reminds me of the energy in Swiss Army Man if that movie were good.

Movie's a wild mess and I think it's more confusing than some Nolan films, but it works. The colors are vibrant, alternate realities imaginative, and characters interesting. It's also way funnier than I expected, both in dialogue and physical action humor. Really brings the action comedy of Jackie Chan into a contemporary reimagining.

Cast is solid, with the actress for Joy being far better than I expected. She demonstrated a wide range in this role and nailed every end of her emotional spectrum. Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy. Quan, and Jaimie Lee Curtis also do an equally commendable job, but that's not as surprising coming from seasoned actors.

The movie's long and though there's little fat & all loose ends are tied up, you're still left wondering how far into the story you've gotten at every turn. There's not exactly a definite fix here, but it was one of the few things I think this film could have improved on.

It's a creative story even if it was confusing for me, solid action, great comedy, fantastic actors, and a reasonably compelling set of character arcs.

Title: Disappointed...
Review:

How could they give this movie an Oscar is beyond my understanding. I am happy for the actors, but since the movie was so crap, I really didn't feel the performances. I do hope the Oscars bounce back next year and award meaningful cinematic movies and not just blindly follow the diversity trend. However please give it a go and see if you can make any sense of the plot. Maybe I didn't get it, but someone else could relate better.
