Title: Very good
Review:
In Swiss Army Man, the debut film from Daniel Scheinert and Daniel Kwan (collectively and fitting known as Daniels), Hank (Paul Dano) and his corpse friend Manny (Daniel Radcliffe) shoot out of a river propelled on the power of Manny's farts. As they fly through the air, they sing a song to each other that goes: "You just have to remember that we're all here for a purpose, and the Universe picks its time. Everything, everywhere matters to everything." While Swiss Army Man only lightly touched on this idea, six years later, Daniels' second film Everything Everywhere All At Once almost makes this verse a mantra amongst a cavalcade of insane multiverses, unlimited possibilities, and endless creativity. Daniels has given audiences a wholly unique vision that literally feels like everything everywhere all at once.

Leading this trip is Evelyn Wang (Michelle Yeoh at maybe her all-time best), who runs a struggling laundromat with her overly-optimistic husband Waymond (an equally fantastic Ke Huy Quan). When we first meet Evelyn, she's surrounded by receipts, thanks to the laundromat getting audited, her husband is putting googly-eyes on bags of laundry, and it doesn't take long for Evelyn to embarrass her daughter, Joy (Stephanie Hsu) when introducing her girlfriend to Evelyn's father, Gong Gong (James Hong). To make matters worse, Evelyn doesn't know Waymond has divorce papers, and IRS inspector Diedre (a hilariously wild Jamie Lee Curtis) accuses the laundromat of fraud. As someone tells Evelyn later in the film, Evelyn is living her worst you.

But that's not to say Evelyn hasn't tried to escape her monotonous life. We learn she's wanted to be a singing coach and an author, amongst other interests that became hobbies instead of life-altering careers. But Evelyn's life irrevocably changes when a version of Waymond tells Evelyn that she is just one of many Evelyns, yet she's the only one that can defeat a powerful villain named Jobu Tupaki, who could destroy all the universes (and there are a lot of universes).

Title: Trifecta: Fun + Thoughtful + Oscar worthy script and acting
Review:
This movie is best gone into blind. This is a glowing review that promises 3 things: 1. Laugh-out-loud funny absurdist humour; 2. Thought provoking questions on life, existence, and purpose; 3. Fantastic performances plus a script that's sure to get some Oscar nods. You should stop reading and go watch it now, ideally avoiding a trailer as well.

For those that want to know more, such as why the script is Oscar worthy, to me this movie is a blend of all movie genres done very well. Similar to how Parasite was a nod to Hollywood stories with meaning and meaning told through film, this is a nod to Hollywood genres and all the ways you can tell a story.

The themes covered in this film match the title. It has all the themes. There is something for everyone, whether that is someone looking for slice of life family drama, musings on nihilism and the meaning of life, or how many absurd dick dildo props you can squeeze into a movie that shares scenes set as romantic film noir about missed connection lovers sporting $10,000 gowns and suits.

The acting is superb, from both Yeoh and her supporting actor Ke Huy Quan. The range of their performances is surely Oscar bait, but serves a purpose in the story. The protagonist's daughter (Stephanie Hsu) plays a very relatable struggling teen for younger viewers as well. I'm glad Awkwafina had to bow out of this role, it would have been hard to imagine her struggling and seeing her as anything but awkward.

Finally, and most importantly, this movie is fun and enjoyable. I avoided this for so long despite glowing peer reviews thinking it would land on either the two extreme ends of a dumb action movie (it's not, it's quite deep) or a way too heavy-handed dry philosophical painful slog (it's not, there is a lot of light hearted fun). Older British thoughtful comedy classics landed in this sweet spot for me; if you are a fan of Edgar Wright's mashing of genres you'll find something here for you.

Title: A cinematic marvel that proves kindness and hope can prevail against all
Review:
I'm ashamed that I waited so long to watch this film. What a beautiful, poignant, funny, emotional movie this is. Everything from the story, the themes, the writing, the acting, and the editing makes this movie a masterpiece of cinema. Michelle Yeoh put on a tour-de-force performance for the ages, and she deserved every award that she won. The same can be said of Ke Huy Quan. I've seen iconic movies from Citizen Kane, Vertigo, The Godfather, Goodfellas, Forrest Gump, Pulp Fiction, Schindler's List, The Shawshank Redemption, and Back to the Future. When we look back at this movie in ten years, I feel it will be given its place among those greats and regarded as such. It's a cinematic marvel and is one of the greatest movies ever made.

Title: Best of 2022 so far
Review:
Please make more movies like these. This is the most creative and plot innovative film I've seen in a long time. The movie perfectly balances the line between being a trippy, hyperactive, dimension-hopping sci-fi adventure and a surprisingly resonating comedy-drama centered around a dysfunctional family near perfectly. It takes concepts and tropes you've seen a million times in other movies and puts a real spin on it, often leading to unexpected twists and turns that keep the narrative engaging despite its somewhat perplexing universe jumping plot. This movie is not going to be for everyone but it deserves to be seen by everyone at least once. Also, please avoid spoilers for this movie if you can. Some movies are just meant to be seen going in completely blind. Trust me, you'll be setting yourself up for the best viewing experience.

Title: This is not a movie, this is an experience
Review:
I saw this movie twice in theaters, the experience was bar none, I would suggest watching it on a big screen or like you would in a movie theater, totally better that way ( I say this as I am rewatching this for the 3rd time on my PS4 on an old TV & it doesn't really make the cut as far as viewing experience wise), but it's still the brilliant movie I remember. Deep & vastly personal, funny & therapeutic, it's not a traditional film, and that's okay, and it's more than okay, but be prepared to ingest it & sit with it for awhile. Not for casual viewing. This is worth a number of rewatches and I plan to own this at some point.

Title: Postmodern but not Pretentious
Review:
It is sadly quite common for new movies nowadays to be politically correct in a forced manner. Token racial characters are inserted into movies without any real reason than to diversify the roster. This is not the case here. This movie has Asian culture and philosophy onboard not just token Asians. Furthermore, it is not politically correct, as it makes fun of stereotypes and in general it does not take itself too seriously. This makes for an entertaining watch, that is filled with funny action sequences and all kinds of dark humor.

In a multidimensional universe where everything and anything that can happen, will happen, is there a reason for morality? Is there even any kind of meaning? The simple answer is no. This kind of nihilism manifests in the postmodern world through the philosophy of existentialism. In its foundational premises the philosophy revolves around the fact that existence comes before essence, and thus no true meaning is a given for one's life but must be created through culture or other means. Nietzsche took this premise to question the nature of morality itself and how it is built artificially and can't be espoused rationally and universally. First, one character who grasps this lack of meaning and purpose struggles in mental anguish and adopts Albert Camus' absurdity ideals, just trying to enjoy the ridiculous nature of the universe. As this gets old though, the character begins to adopt Kierkegaard's idea of the abyss and despair in the form of the abyssal bagel. A multidimensional entity that acts as a black hole that swallows everything, created by the character to help end the suffering of the meaningless world and the hopelessness. In terms of overall message, it does not try to be subtle, the message is kindness and love. The way to best nihilism and answer the existential question, is not to answer it, but to dodge it entirely and focus on each other; the fellow humans that we can help ease their suffering through acts of kindness and compassion. Although a pretty standard good message, it is delivered in a captivating way and in an entertaining envelope.

The cinematography is quite intriguing and done in a very cool way. With striking visuals that capture the absurdity of multidimensional existence. The CGI here serves the movie, rather than take away from it. The cast is brilliant and really carries this movie in terms of humor delivery and emotional release. That is except for the daughter, Joy, who I personally found irritating and too clich√© in terms of her character design (the teenager trope is really overused). Other than that the movie is quite solid and I would definitely recommend for others.

Title: Nolan's level of storytelling just marvelous
Review:
Everything everywhere is just.....there's no word to describe it, it just felt like a Nolan as great of a ride and as complex to understand but you can't take your eyes off the screen no matter how long...I couldn't believe it was a 2h movie cause it surely didn't feel like it.

It's by far the best screenplay of 2022, the best in developing the multiverse since Spider-Man into the spider verse and yes I've seen Spider-Man no way home and Dr Strange in the multiverse of madness both of them weren't even close to be as good as those 2.

The cast in general was just perfect, you could see all the shades of Michelle over the years she was just perfect for the role, best I've ever seen her.

This movie deserves everything everywhere all at once üòâ....should be at least nominated and win for best screenplay at every award show next year, literally the only movie of 2022 I was proud to watch on the big screen...it's been a long time since I've worked out of a theater feeling I've seen something great something that I'm gonna think about all night until I fall asleep.

Title: Best movie ever!
Review:
It's not lime anything you've seen before.

Some will love it and some will definitely won't.

But it had such a profound emotional and intellectual impact on me!

Wow!

I watched it seven times already and it just hits every note. Every time.

So moving, so intense.

It has everything, just like life.

It's brilliant writing and directing, and the cast sooo good!

Such an amazing artistic way to tell a family's story, everyone's story. Our story.

It's mind blowing when you realised that every choice in life a different path and how much love was needed all the time to heal the hurt.

Love is all. Be kind , fight different.

Just forgive and embrace change. Well I'm sold It should take each Oscar ! It deserves it.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: You either get it or you don't. I'm glad I did.
Review:
If you don't get it, you'll hate it and you won't understand why anyone would love it. That's okay. It happens. Not everyone understands subtext or allegory.

If you do get it, you're in for a masterpiece of absurdity, surrealism, existentialism, comedy and ultimately, humanism.

This is one of the most insightful and realistic depictions of ADHD, depression and anxiety I've ever seen. Yes, I used the word realistic about a film where characters may have hotdogs for fingers, or they may be a cartoon or a rock. Because it's not supposed to be taken literally. Everything is subtext. Everything is a metaphor. Everything is an illustration of absurdity to make a point.

The way this film handles the subject matter and delivers its message is a masterclass in using over the top silliness as a way to convey something subtle and nuanced.

It's insanely creative and beautiful. It's one of the best films I've ever seen.

Title: A humbling experience

At first i did not get the hype or the idea an hour in i was having fun and as soon as we got to the middle of it i realized what the art behind is,

Its that no matter how many times we regret things or wish we done things differently it does not matter,

We are in the best verse possible and have limited time so we shouldn't care that much and take it easy.

Title: A Bottle of Human Experience
Review:
There are few films that capture the breadth and diversity of human experience. Many of those that do make use of large casts, budgets, and show many storylines occuring at once or converging together. Some are anthologies. This film didn't need any of that. Touching, comedic, and exciting, this film displays what could be considered a slice of life buried under an extremely entertaining science fiction action story. Credit to the actors, of course, but there are also scenes without acting that elicit a genuine emotional response. Just watch it. And to all who think that the newest Top Gun sequel should have won more Oscars... this movie isn't for you.

You have no time to process any sort of emotions, one moment you're sad, one moment you're happy; one moment you're relieved, one moment you're angry.

Title: It truly is everything, everywhere all at once
Review:
I've been excited for this film as it's gotten great reviews. Whilst the plot is hard to describe, it's the type of film where you just have to trust that it's going to be good and enjoy the madness as it happens.

It's a film that manages to cover every genre there is, which is something i don't think I've seen before.

I admit that it was very confusing, but I think that's intentional and it's so wild that it makes it that much cooler.

Michelle Yeoh is a great lead and there were some minor roles and cameos that would have been fun for the actors to be involved in.

The action scenes were amazing, which were reminiscent of films like Kill Bill and The Matrix (minus the butt plugs of course). Top marks for visuals, music and costuming too.

An extremely imaginative film that is both quiet and chaotic, interesting and entertaining, it's all of those things, everything at once.

Title: Don't focus on means of expression
Review:
You don't have to try to understand this movie. I see a lot of people here commenting they are not smart enough to understand it. You don't have to be smart and you don't have to try to understand anything. You need to forward this movie from your eyes to the abstract part of your brain. This is a movie of ideas. This movie asks questions, it doesn't give answers. It doesn't try to set rules, it doesn't tell you what is truth, good or bad. That's why people are confused after watching it.

The current capabilities of visual art and the usual ways to express ideas in cinema are not at the required level to represent such abstract ideas, that's why some episodes look ridiculous. When you look at the ideas and you don't focus that much on the means of expression, all makes totally sense..

Title: Major Disappointment at Every Turn
Review:
I was so looking forward to seeing this movie. I'm a big fan of Michelle Yeoh (I love her in Star Trek Discovery, and I anxiously await her own Star Trek Section 31 show), plus, I love shows that deal with the multiverse.

Somehow, this show let me down, completely, thoroughly (and all at once). It literally looks like it was made for young children. The acting was sub-par in many cases, the characters were almost all caricatures, the special effects were uninspiring and the plot was like that of a basic Saturday morning cartoon.

I tried sitting through this movie, but after two attempts, I still only made it through 1 hrs and 12 minutes. It was that annoying.

How this garnered an 8.1 IMDB score is beyond me.

Title: If Edgar Wright and Charlie Kaufman made a Multiverse film...
Review:
As someone else commented, the most comparable film to this very original experience is Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind...or if Edgar Wright directed a script from Charlie Kaufman. That's how crazy and original this film is.

I do get some of the negative reviews, as this film isn't for everyone. But, if you're into multiverse type films, it's easily one of the best. There are so many Multiverse ideas packed into this film, it will be hard to catch them all in the first viewing.

I've been a film buff since a child so have pretty much seen everything there is. This is one of those films that will blow you away with its originality similar to Eternal Sunshine, Her, Being John Malkovich, Mr. Nobody or other films of that ilk. Easily a 9/10 and will watch again to catch everything missed on the first viewing.

P. S. For other films about the Multiverse and alternate realities, there's a good list of films at kneelbeforezod.io/tag/sci-fi-alternate-history-films/

Title: WELL.. Possibly the greatest dream I ever had!!
Review:
I will always try and watch anything with Michelle Yeoh in..and this has to be up there with her finest work! No spoilers here.

It was Beautiful, sad, crazy, deep, funny, polished, euphoric, dreamy, .. but most of all an epic story about the loves we have.

To quote the great Ke Huy Quan. ." He who loves the most, regrets the most ".

This really really resonated with me.

The editors and costume need a massive congrats on their work. The director also really deserves a pat on the back for holding this all together...because it must have been a tough job.

I always score as honestly as I can ... unlike the political or fan girl/boy reviewers who score their favourite actors/political motive movies 10/10 even when its a terrible movie.. But this IS a genuinely solid 9/10.. sit back, put your phone down and watch this crazy masterpiece before the USA makes a mainstream copy as per....

Title: Too good to put into words.
Review:

To me, this film was a masterpiece. After a semi slow first 10-15 minutes I was on the edge of my seat the entire time completely engrossed in this film. I was hysterically laughing and crying often.

After the movie, we sat through the credits unwilling to even move as the profound messages, insanely creative visuals and hilarious comedy were digested. Instantly one of my favorite movies ever as it had so much soul. I question if those who rate this a bad movie have a soul and brain. This absolutely deserves well over an 8 on IMDb and I encourage anyone and every adult to go see it.

PS - kudos to the amazing cast, crew, writers and directors. They all had to be at the top of their game to make such an amazing movie.

Title: Millions of times better than any movie has any right to be
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Wow....................
Review:
I can't believe the amazing and mind bending story I just experienced. I am just blown away by the story telling and cinematography this effortlessly life changing movie made me question my own reality. It was flawless from the characters to the plot. Everything I have been waiting for and wanting in a movie for so long. It breaks all aspects of how a movie should go from this unassuming relatable family in its own problems and culture, to this unbelievable story that's ripped across all realities past present and future all at the same time.

This has the Matrix (the original) feel to it but at the same time Total Rdecall (the arnold version) vibes, with a little new once to make it its own. The character development is standing ovation worthy and keeps you on the back of your seat in fear of what comes next. But leans you forward to hold on for more. I can't believe this is what this movie was. I was expecting a mediocre seen it before tale that had some new twist, but I was pleasantly surprised that I was taken on an original journey through mind altering thought to the point where I was questioning whether I was in the movie or some spin off of reality waiting for my own body to be tagged in and fight.

All I can say is it is a must see for everyone who wants a new original thinking journey to ride along with and not think about awards or criticism. Just to take a ride on another state of mind all together. I commend you for reading this but can't wait for you to realize what you are in for within the hours to come in this unbelievable joy ride you are about to partake.

Enjoy the ride and please open your mind to what is coming!!!

Title: This film is way better than everyone makes it out to be
Review:
It seems as though this film has gotten a lesser response from audiences than critics. I think this film knew that it wouldn't appeal to everyone.

With all films of recent being sci-fi, action-packed blockbusters, it seems as though audiences today can't connect with a deep message.

The films score, screenplay, and acting create an eerie, thought provoking experience for some viewers, while other consider it a disorganized mess.

While I wouldn't consider it a masterpiece by any means, I don't think it was trying to be one. It was trying to push a profound message onto these ADHD filled audiences that won't be contempt without an action scene every five minutes.

And, for me, it succeeded. It felt like a mix of Doctor Strange and Eternal Sunshine. Grabbing some of the best and most thought provoking elements from both.

Although it's not the best film, and sure, it does lack in certain areas, I consider this to be the best film of 2022, not my favorite per say, but the best.

Title: A true masterpiece
Review:
"Everything, Everywhere, All at Once" is a mind-bending cinematic experience that effortlessly transcends boundaries and immerses viewers in a multidimensional journey of self-discovery and enlightenment. Written and directed by visionary filmmakers, this ambitious masterpiece challenges conventional storytelling norms while igniting the imagination with its boundless creativity.

At its core, "Everything, Everywhere, All at Once" explores the intricate tapestry of human existence across parallel dimensions. The film weaves together a complex narrative that demands intellectual acuity and an open mind to fully appreciate its profound themes and symbolic representations. It invites the audience to dive deep into the metaphysical realm, provoking introspection and questioning the nature of reality itself.

Some viewers who rated this film below a perfect score may have found themselves overwhelmed by its intricate storytelling and unconventional structure. The movie challenges traditional linear narratives, opting for a kaleidoscopic approach that effortlessly blends genres and blurs the boundaries between past, present, and future. Consequently, those who prefer a more straightforward plot may have struggled to navigate its depths and fully engage with its complexities.

However, it is important to recognize that this film's brilliance lies precisely in its ability to provoke such diverse reactions. While some may find themselves momentarily lost in its labyrinthine corridors, those who possess the intellectual acuity to embrace its multidimensional nature will be richly rewarded with an awe-inspiring experience like no other.

The cinematography and visual effects in "Everything, Everywhere, All at Once" are nothing short of breathtaking. Each frame is meticulously crafted, offering a visually stunning feast for the eyes. From ethereal landscapes to intricately choreographed action sequences, every scene is a testament to the creative prowess of the filmmaking team. The expert use of color palettes and innovative camera techniques further enhance the immersive nature of the film, enveloping viewers in a captivating visual symphony.

The performances in this film are nothing short of extraordinary. The ensemble cast, led by a magnetic and versatile lead actress, delivers performances that seamlessly blend vulnerability, strength, and emotional depth. Their portrayals bring authenticity to the multidimensional characters, allowing audiences to form a deep connection and empathy with their struggles and triumphs. It is a testament to the director's skill in guiding the actors and extracting nuanced performances that resonate long after the credits roll.

One of the film's most notable achievements is its ability to provoke philosophical and existential contemplation. Through its intricate narrative layers, "Everything, Everywhere, All at Once" explores themes of identity, interconnectedness, and the fluidity of time. It challenges viewers to reflect on their own place in the universe and the impact of their choices on the fabric of existence. This thought-provoking journey transcends the boundaries of traditional cinema and becomes a transformative experience for those willing to delve into its depths.

In conclusion, "Everything, Everywhere, All at Once" is an intellectually stimulating and visually captivating cinematic triumph. While it may require a certain level of mental agility to fully appreciate its multidimensional storytelling, those who embrace its complexities will be rewarded with a cinematic experience that transcends traditional boundaries. This is a film that invites viewers to reflect, question, and explore the very essence of their existence. It stands as a testament to the boundless potential of cinema to challenge, inspire, and expand our understanding of the world.

Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Lamentable
Review:
I was looking forward to this one after all the rave reviews, but I somehow missed the fact that it was directed by the jokers behind SWISS ARMY MAN. Sure enough, it turns out to be a cheesy, repetitive, scatological mess of a comedy with a multiverse hook that goes nowhere and does nothing, other than copying previous sci-fi flicks like THE MATRIX. The action is nondescript; the whole thing turns out to be a simplistic family drama, the ending entirely predictable. Michelle Yeoh is an old favourite of mine but I felt embarrassed for her here, and I'm not even going into what Jamie Lee Curtis is made to do. This film's a good example of why I avoid modern Hollywood comedies like the plague.

Title: The main cast shine in this multiverse comedy
Review:
I have heard so much hype coming from this film even before its release. As I have finally gotten to watch it on the big screen, there are so many words that I can use to describe my experience towards the movie. And that is mostly positive things that are hard to be put into words due to how Everything Everywhere All at Once is a confusing yet a thrilling and entertaining film that I will never forget. To A24 pictures, this is probably the best that I have seen from you yet and here is why I loved it.

Michelle Yeoh, who is best known for her role in Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, is an absolute blast to watch. She is by far the most standout but even the whole cast as well delivered when they are given screen time throughout the film. I love the fact that her bickering and being confusing makes a whole lot of sense to her because I too, as an audience member, was very confused at what's really going on. But by the time she eventually learns to acknowledge her problems and flaws towards herself and her family, she becomes a lot more relatable.

And yes, as I have stated before in the previous paragraphs, the film is absolutely confusing. In addition to this, it was a non-stop rollercoaster of craziness and off-the-top humor, particularly sexual jokes, that added more fuel to the fire of confusion that I am getting. The action sequences though are also cool and not to mention how funny the jokes delivered by everyone in the cast, in particular is Jamie Lee Curtis who I was surprised was part of this movie.

I am also happy that this is one of those films that does feature the element of the what-if routes. Seeing what Michelle Yeoh's protagonist could have been in other universes is a great and also relatable way to the audience because we also imagined what our lives would have been if we took the other choices in life.

Remember the iconic quote of Spike Spiegel from Cowboy Bebop "whatever happens, happens" - this basically sums up my love for the movie and interpretation to reality. Just like the movie, sometimes there we always be moments that you will face a difficult situation and as you start to think that it would have been better if I lived another life, always remember that sometimes, living your life to the fullest in all the mishaps you experienced with the people you are stuck with is better than regretting everything that made you come to this point of your life.

So basically, even though I said Hustle was my favorite movie of 2022, it seems like Everything Everywhere All at Once has just topped my list. Please Oscar, nominate this film for Best Picture and give Michelle Yeoh her very first Best Actress nomination because she literally carried the film the entire way through. Yes, there is more to come in the second half of the year but I bet no film can be as standout as what the Kwans did. If you haven't seen this film, I would be very jealous of you because you are going to have an exhilarating yet memorable ride with the movie.

Title: You don't watch this movie, you experience it.
Review:
You don't watch this movie, you experience it.

I watched this movie on Friday and was completely stunned. It was like for the first time in my life, I was seeing a real movie. Everything else, from the Godfather to the Titanic had been a nice story, but at the end of the day, just a story..about people often very different from me.

This on the other hand, was something deeper, some more real. It perfectly brought to life one of the deepest, most personal questions we ponder in life: am I living my best life...or wasting it?

It is the first movie I've been to where when the lights came up at the end, no one got up to leave. People just immediately started excitedly talking about what they had just experienced.

Image if Picasso made a film that combined the Matrix with Cloud Atlas. It tells a very profound but relatable story about the importance in a seemingly meaningless world of valuing kindness and family/friends over all else, even if it doesn't always make sense.

It does this by shooting a firehouse of storytelling twists and visual imagery at you for 2.5 hours that at times starts to feel exhausting but in the end...you realize was a necessary metaphor for the complexity of life and the infinite set of choices we make in life.

This is a kind of movie that comes along once every 20 years. Go see it folks.

First of all the acting was superb and i found every character likable in different ways. The strange and wacky humor just made it that much better. Overall i would give it 10/10 hot dogs.

As so often in life it turns out to be a different thing and i need to accept i wasn't aware and in addition to that i fell for the 'don't judge a book by its cover' hokuspokus..again.

Not only the cover is leading you in a wrong direction even the movie will if you don't look with an open eye or mind in this case. Flashy on the outside, philosophical challenging and more than once not easy to accept on the inside. Talking about the movie here and not life, i think.

You will get yourself into a spectacular hilarious ride full of up and downs with multiple layers of Interpretation. Its on you how far you go.

Title: Mind-Bending and Visually Stunning Journey Through Parallel Universes"
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is a mind-bending and visually stunning movie that takes viewers on a journey through parallel universes and alternate realities. The movie follows a middle-aged woman named Ling, played brilliantly by Michelle Yeoh, who discovers that she has the power to access multiple dimensions and parallel universes. Ling is forced to confront different versions of herself, including a ruthless and powerful version who seeks to take over all the universes.

The concept of the movie is both intriguing and complex, and it may take some time for viewers to fully grasp the different realities and timelines. However, the strong performances by the cast, especially Yeoh, keep the audience engaged and invested in the story. The movie also features stunning visual effects and a captivating score that enhance the viewing experience.

While the movie can be confusing at times, the unique storyline and themes of identity and self-discovery make it a worthwhile watch. Overall, Everything Everywhere All at Once is a thought-provoking and entertaining movie that pushes the boundaries of science fiction and leaves a lasting impression on its viewers. I would highly recommend this movie to fans of mind-bending sci-fi films who are looking for something fresh and innovative.

Title: A gems like few others
Review:
It is difficult for me to overstate what I think of this film. The script is creative, fun and original. The direction is energetic, clever and tight. The cast is too notch.

I mean Michelle Yeoh is a fantastic actress but the rest of the cast (special mention to james hong) is on par with her.

A must see. For me the best of 2022 without a doubt and possibly one of the best for a very long time...

Title: This gave me Everything all at Once
Review:
This is one of the most creative fun movies I have seen in a LONG TIME. There were moments that made me laugh out loud and cry out loud. The story has heart and is rich with creativity (in cinematography and writing), you can tell the writers had a blast making this. It is such a fun rollercoaster of a movie that makes you want to get back in line and enjoy the ride again immediately after watching it.

To compare to a movie like Christopher Nolan's Tenent where it is 100% based on ideas and plot and completely forgets heart or soul this movie has so much plot and so much heart leaving nothing behind.

This movie is so dense with amazing ingredients. I have seen it multiple times and I'm still picking up new things to talk about and discover. It is sad to say that I felt more in this stand alone movie than I have with many saga movies or tv shows.

It is true not everyone will like the same movies but if you enjoy movies with meaning, heart, creativity, action, comedy and everything else then Everything everywhere all at once is a movie absolutely worth giving a shot.

Title: Phantasms, metaverse and chaos
Review:
There are so many opportunities to fantasize (daydream) in everyday life (when you are working, when you are driving, when you talk to a friend or a colleague, when you watch tv, and so on) that if you allow yourself to be overwhelmed and invaded by phantasms, it can become complete chaos in your existence. And with the metaverse, it's worse. Congratulations to the scriptwriters, directors and actors for translating that chaos into a seething and swirling movie. More than ever, we must follow the Latin advice of Ignatius of Loyola (founder of the Jesuit order): "Age quod agis": = do what you do. And stay focused on every task, even the smallest and simplest. This is the only way to avoid chaos.

Title: Can't run, can't hide: Can't escape myself.
Review: None of us can. Daniels and the Russo Brothers collaborate in a mind-bending film bringing together the legends Michelle Yeoh and that one kid from The Goonies and Indiana Jones all grown up. Polarizing forces in the life of their daughter. Movie is really existentialist and nihilistic at times, and I love it! Does any of this life actually matter or is it just what you choose to do with your time? Is there any innate reason for us being here or do we just make it up as we go along? I understand exactly how the daughter was feeling as if she was just so tired of going on and on in a box, all for it to end with so little having been accomplished. The visuals in this movie are eye-popping, and this was a fun adventure with parallels to The Matrix, but way cooler! Made me wish I could escape from my life and hop into another me in another universe. I guess we just need to understand and love the people in our lives for who they are. Take it or leave it, all or nothing. Use what little time you have together and make the best of it while you can. What else is life besides what we make it? Put everything on your bagel, or eat a plain one if you wish, nobody can tell you how to eat it. Superb acting and an overall beautiful movie that is a definite rewatch for me.

Title: The blue/black white/gold dress of a movie
Review:
The blue/black white/gold dress of a movie: inexplicably, some people love this movie; others hate it. If you enjoy "kung fu meets potty humor", and like your movies low brow and juvenile, you'll love it. If you go in expecting profound and meaningful, with something to say about existence, multiverses, or achievement in life, you'll be disappointed. It's a chaotic mess of a movie that tries too hard to shock and bewilder, while missing any opportunity to use that shock to get more than surface level with its premise. It's like someone saw The Matrix, then decided to remove the philosophical ideas and change the fight scenes from visceral to silly. It's no fault of the actors, the costume makers, or photographers: the blame lies squarely on the writers whose convoluted experiment in simulating ADHD on screen is a self-indulgent mess.

Title: It grew on me
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Watch While Baked
Review:
111 out of 10 stars

Everything Everywhere All At Once feels like a mind-blowing combination of a kung-fu movie, kung-fu movie parody, soap opera, dramedy, live from the Lincoln Center opera, & Sci fi with an emotionally deep culture clashing family written by someone with ADHD doing acid listening to some Darkside Of The Moon, while Heavy Metal the movie is playing in the background, staring comic con favorite celebs, being aimed at for an Academy award based on a book by Phillip K Dick, remade by James Gunn, the Snyder cut version, choreographed by Sammo Hung, produced by Eli Roth, stunt coordinator Zoe Bell, anime, anime adaptation.

Imagine if the comic con people started their own movie studio & had it run by cosplayers: Ivy Doomkitty, Jessica Nigri, & Animia. That studio would have made this movie.

The storytelling feels like you're just flipping through channels & getting one big story from the channels being combined cohesively.

None of the people named are involved, it just feels like if they were is what I'm trying to convey.

Title: Next Year's Oscar Winner !
Review:
I simply can not rate this film highly enough. From the bizarre, yet hilarious, sense of humor to the exquisite over the top action scenes this film simply excels in everything it attempts. It's difficult to categorize just what this film is exactly about: Is it about American-Asian mother daughter interpersonal relationships? Is it about how we handle our own trauma and pass it along to our children? It is about hilarious riffs on a variety of genre movies?

Yes. It is about all of the above and so very much more. In an age where Marvel comic book movies seem to define the big screens, this movie stands out as a reminder of whet the media used to be and could be still. The movie quite literally made me laugh and made me cry. I can't recall the last time a movie did that.

Just be kind to yourself and go see this movie.

Title: I've never laughed and cried so much in one movie
Review:
I adored this movie. This movie plays with the viewers. It jumps back and forth between so many scenes and genres and amazingly it works nearly flawlessly! It spoofs the Matrix and ratatouille (LOL!) some other movies, but simultaneously pays homage to them. The movie touches on almost every genre and plays into them. And just when you think the silliness is over the top, it grounds itself in some seriously profound philosophy. What blows my mind is that as big as the movie gets, it then becomes very intimate and is centered on familial relationships and what it means to love those closest to us and life in general.

Title: Fun and wholesome
Review:
This film is the perfect mix of heartbreaking, hilarious and mysterious. Full of convincing performances, it carries a heart through the whole thing which you don't see in many films these days.

The first time I watched it I was slightly confused but now I see how that makes sense to reflect Evelyn's (Yeoh's) position in it. The second time made more sense and I picked up on more, which is what a lot of directors want from their movies so well done to the Daniels!

Definitely one of the best movies of the year and I am sure that I will be watching it again in the future. I highly recommend it, and it's also a good film to watch in a group of friends/with your family.

Title: This is... MADNESS- Everything Everywhere All At Once Review
Review:
I literally just got out of seeing Everything Everywhere All At Once, and this might be one of the most underrated movies ever! Michelle Yeoh crushes it as the lead star in this movie, and has a performance that is super memorable. Now, let's get to the main part of this review because DANG!!!!!!!!!! This film is Madness, and it's bonkers! Depending on how Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness goes, this might be the most bonkers multiverse film of the year! It goes into many spots which are weird, and that's this movie in one word: Weird. And not only is it a great multiversal superhero story, it's a family movie, an adventure movie, a thriller movie, and a emotional movie. It packs a punch on what it does with the plot and villain and characters, and the surprises this movie has in line for the audience is so worth it!

I know you probably didn't have Everything Everywhere All At Once on your movie radar to go watch, but your going to be doing yourself a MASSIVE favour if you buy a ticket and go see this masterpiece!

8.5/10.

Title: Entertaining, ragged, way too long
Review:
Well acted, indifferently written screenplay, alternately intricate and shabby production. Difficult to understand this movie's high ratings.

Don't get your hopes up. The cast does the very best possible job with a screenplay that feels like it was written stoned by amateurs with good imaginations and too much time on their hands.

You don't need to see this one in the theater. Watch it at home, stoned out of your gourd. Take breaks when you need them; things will be much the same by the time you get back.

Title: You could be anything, anywhere, why here?
Review:
Where cinema, feels wonky and lacks heart, everything everywhere all at once, comes to the party crashing its doors.

At first you feel like the film is all jumbled and not making any sense, you feel lost, little did you know, thats how you should feel, at this age almost everyone of us is lost and cannot figure his way out, dug down deep in a pit with no way out.

Every possibility you made, could have made and going to make is a life changing event,, but really were just little specs living on a floating rock, why should we dwell on it,

Title: An uexpectedly awesome journey.
Review:
I had the urge to resist the movie at the beginning because it was hitting too close to reality. I forced myself to work through the inital dread and anxiety and found myself immersed in an exercise in finding acceptance. The overall theme of the film is an important one we need to face as people and as a society overall. Can we just be ok with being ordinary? Can we heal and let go of our regrets and past mistakes to live for now? I found this movie wildly thought provoking and emotionally exhausting. Great fight sequences are always a plus for me, and there was some good ones here. Even the multiverse aspect which is overused lately was used in an inventive way. I wasn't into some of the crude and juvenile humor though which is why it doesn't get higher marks from me. (And there is A LOT of that.) Still a great film that demands a watch even with the step down humor included.

Title: This is a Multiverse movie well done!
Review:
The movie itself doesn't take itself too seriously and neither should you! It has plenty of absurd jokes and moments and some of these might turn you off. But please, don't let those ruin the movie for you! Do watch it with an open mind. This is really a great movie! I really can't say anything about it without spoiling for you but you should give it a watch!

Also compared to the Multiverse of Madness, this movie shows that if you know how to spend your money, a great movie can be made! Obviously there's more to that but this shows that you can spend alot of money and your movie can still turn out to be mediocre at best.

Like I said in the title, this is how a Multiverse movie should look like! They really captured really well the essence of each universe shown in the movie and this is exactly how Marvel should have done it!

Again, words are few to actually appreciate this movie!

Title: Fantastic
Review:
This movie is absolutely brilliant. It's pretty rare for a movie to be able to leave me speechless, in thought, belly laughing, and wanting to tear up all in one sitting, but this one did it.

This movie is ALL about symbolism. If you just take the movie at face value and try to piece it together literally, it doesn't make a ton of sense. And I see a lot of reviews point that out. If you're that kind of person, this probably isn't gonna be the one for you.

But if you can view it in the abstract, for the story it's telling, it's absolutely relatable and heartwrenching. Regret, missed opportunities, marriage, family, kids, everything. It makes you reflect on your own life even.

If I could change anything about the movie at all, I'd probably have trimmed some of the fight scenes. They weren't bad at all, but seemed more added for comedic effect, and pushed the runtime up just a little more than I'd have liked I think.

Title: Absolutely Loved This Movie.
Review:
Entered straight into the pantheon of my favorites - and that's high praise. Love, love, love the fact that two middle-aged women get to kick ass in it, to boot. And that it passes the Bechdel test with flying colors. And, most importantly, that in the end it's about love of family & that twisted, prickly, yet somehow unbreakable bond between mothers & daughters. Kudos to the Daniels for figuring this out.

I was glued to the screen the entire time. Acting, production design, editing, music, VFX, costumes (Stephanie Hsu's outfits & James Hong's chair!) - everything was spot on - and delivered with a sensibility that both honored & skewered movie tropes with heart and humor. Deserves every award it gets.

Title: A Masterpiece of a Hidden Gem
Review:
Where do I begin? There's just so much to talk about this absolute masterpiece of a movie. The action, the drama, the humour, the subtext, the cinematography, the emotions-and most of all, the weirdness.

I will try my best to put into words how beautifully this movie was brought together with a neatly wrapped ribbon on top. I don't do movie reviews but this is something I just cannot resist writing at 4 AM because the pure adrenaline will not let me.

Intro

I will admit that I need to watch it 2-3 more times to fully grasp every drop of what the directors poured into the 2+ hour runtime of the movie.

When I started watching it, I was so confused as to why this movie came highly recommended as it seemed very crude and bare at face value.

But the more I watched it, the more I delved into the multiple realities the movie takes you through. It just draws you in and you cannot stop watching with every obscenity, every chaotic scene and every inexplicable moment that passes. It's a steadily meandering curve of insanity and chaos from start to end.

Action and Choreography

Violence is usually depicted as a raw amalgamation of gore and barbaric roughness. This movie polishes a scintillating diamond through the beautifully choreographed fight scenes. Creativity knows no bounds and nothing is repetitive in any of the confrontation scenes as people are killed off in the most elegant ways imaginable with the help of colourful visual effects.

The movie somehow manages to antithetically depict the other side of the coin, addressing violence with kindness and compassion in a truly unique way.

Writing & Characters

There is a perfect balance of comedy, action and heartwarming poignance.

At the start, you are introduced to characters and plot points seemingly unrelated to each other. Right until the end, all of these characters are thrust into each other's lives in the most unfathomable ways and each character plays a vital role, no matter how small.

The overarching plot seems somewhat fundamental at the surface level. It's the plethora of underlying plotlines and abstract messages that really form the core of the movie. The science fiction aspect takes a backseat to the more pertinent themes that are constantly overlapping sporadically.

To put that on a scale, Doctor Strange is a 6-year-old's art homework.

Emotions

The story explores the lives of 3 separate generations of a family who hate as much as they love each other. The generational gap is evident right from the start, with each one having nuances in stark contrast to the others. These various relations burgeon into something indescribaby wholesome across their shared experiences.

Coming to the quirkiness aspect of it, I have no words. I am inexplicably drawn towards zany and quirky plots and sequences that make superficial sense to the common viewer. I found myself uncontrollably laughing every 2 minutes while simultaneously being absolutely bewildered at the nonsensical shenanigans transpiring in front of me.

Cinematography & Direction

The director duo of the Daniels, responsible for another one of my all-time favourites-Swiss Army Man, absolutely smashed it out of the park yet again. The way one scene shifted to another while my brain was stuck processing the earlier one really captivated my full attention. They've also thrown in a little treat for fans of fourth-wall breaking, completely novel and never seen before.

There are also a few segments within the movie that give you a breather to take in everything and contemplate the meaning of life along with the characters themselves.

I would be gravely remiss if I did not mention that the VFX team was comprised of only SEVEN people entirely, an outstanding feat for what they've achieved.

For simple-minded Marvel fans, this is produced by the Russo Brothers. Do with that information what you will.

Shoutout to the Actors

The acting, on the other hand, felt a little less than organic, if I had to criticise just one thing about an otherwise flawless production.

For Asians to have such brilliant interaction on an English medium is remarkable on its own, as seen with Crazy Rich Asians. It is with that same energy that Michelle Yeoh brought her A-game and really flourished. The other cast members also carried their role to their fullest in their own idiosyncratic ways.

The Verdict

This movie had me at the edge of my seat, processing several emotions at the same time. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a completely new experience that pretty much condenses an entire cinematic universe in just 2 hours. It's a refreshing change of pace from today's hackneyed Hollywood industry that seems to care more about profits than quality, and offers a hidden gem unlike anything you've ever seen before.

It was wholesome. It was thought-provoking. It was alluring. It was insanely mind-bending. It was everything, everywhere, all at once.

If you actually read all of that, I appreciate it. If you just skipped to this part, shame on you. Either way, go see it asap. It's a must-watch masterpiece that I'm definitely gonna find myself re-watching over and over again.

Title: This is a movie about being a bored God who is done.
Review:
Imagine if you were a God that could make anything happen (more or less), you could travel to any instance in time at will to any part of the multiverse do anything you wanted. Yet you felt unfulfilled by these powers and you became destructive, not having anyone around to share in your powers.

It would become terribly frustrating, this movie is about a version of a person who becomes a God and has decided that enough is enough, she is checking out into the void but wants someone to share this experience with her. But in embarking on this journey to find 'another Godlike being' to share this new desire for oblivion she finds that the other Godlike being doesn't believe in destruction and the futility of it all, quite the opposite.

This is an incredible movie and for me at the end was quite moving. I've not seen anything so good and inspiring in quite a few decades to be honest.

Title: Love is never the answer for Asian family issues. Twinge is.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Forgettable.
Review:
So much hype. Yet after 6 months I barely remember anything about this movie, which says it all really.

If you want to waste 3 hours of your life on a film none of your friends will remember, or ever talk about or ever want to watch again, then this is it.

The production quality is pretty good, and the pretence different and potentially interesting, but the film undermines itself by continuing longer than 60 minutes. It actually becomes obnoxious in the end as you're forced to sit through a relentless durectionless assualt on the senses. You give up assuming that there must be some sort of point to it all, and just hope it ends.

It's a shane, I feel it could have been a lot better.

Title: Remarkable film with stunning acting and visuals
Review:
This really was one of those films that sit with you for a few days and make you think about its premise in your own life. Such a thought-provoking and original story, with deep characters brought to life by the brilliant cast. Michelle Yeoh's performance showcased wonderful character development, alongside Ke Huy Quan's effortless ability to portray the many lives of Waymond.

The visuals of the film are absolutely stunning. Some have described it as "an assault on the senses", which I certainly agree, though it is coherently done so that the audience is not feeling confused or left behind. Colours and slow-motion, among other special effects, are used to create sequences that may read as "ridiculous" on paper but are visually fantastic.

A masterpiece in writing, acting, and visuals - 10/10.

Title: I created my IMDb just to give 10/10
Review:
This movie was absolutely fantastic.

The comedic aspect was absolutely nailed, it kept the movie feel very light and funny while having actually quite deep message.

The plot was well thought through and made perfect sense (even while being crazy) which is very rare to see in modern movies, especially comedic ones. The characters seemed very natural and fitting, nothing felt forced in any way.

My personal taste is that I usually don't like comedy movies from China because they tend to be over the top crazy and not make that much sense but this one really changed my opinion. It is crazy, yes, but in a good way, I would say really on the line of being too crazy but not yet. Most importantly the plot wasn't hurt by the craziness in any way so it is still briliant movie story-wise.

As critical as I usually am to movies, I am honestly giving this movie 10/10 and ranking it among my Top 5 movies while being the Top 2022 movie (and I watch a lot of movies).

Title: Well, I don't get it
Review:

Title: The best film of 2022 so far.
Review:
This film is everything.

It's Ejzenstejn, it's Kubrick, it's Godard, it's Fellini, it's Wong Kar-wai, it's Kurosawa, it's Kobayashi, it's Lucas, it's Spielberg, it's the Wachowski sisters, it's Anno, it's Miyazaki, it's Kon, it's Bong Joon-ho, it's Wright, it's Nolan, it's Tarantino.

It's Daniel Kwan, it's Daniel Scheinert.

And it's also Marvel, but better.

It's really the film about the multiverse, the one of the weight of choices.

Through such an absurd and surreal story, life is told in its most realistic nuances.

Through the regret of not having lived a life that for a single, different deviation does not belong to us.

Believing that absolute nothingness, being stone, is the solution. A simple and appetizing solution, like the Bagel.

The absolute nothing to avoid the suffering of appearances, or the frustration of our present.

Making the mistake of not being grateful for the here and now, the present, which along with feelings are the only things that matter.

You just need to be kind in this life or in the other one.

It's the only way.

One of the most beautiful and important experiences of my life.

Just to start this off I want to say that this is for sure the best movie of 2022, I have two problems with this movie one of them being the beginning starts off a bit slow but it was quickly paced much better. The cinemaphotography is amazing, comedy was great and perfectly timed, and the action scenes were near perfect. The actors were chosen well but the character writing made the movie 10x better. The plot was tackled beautifully, almost better form than an NFL player. Another complaint was the ending was a tiny bit drawn out and they should've ended it right when they hugged before all the sentimental talking, but of course it is my opinion and you are entitled to your own. 9.4/10, a24 did an amazing job once again.

Title: Troubling but passionate, existential in its message
Review:
I found this film to be very anti or strange in its message. It evolves around nihilism or at least existentialism on how nothing matters but we still choose kindness in the midst of 'not having all the answers.' This type of thought leads me to believe that the film makers believe in a worldview of 'nothing matters' which irked me as I don't believe in the same way.

I think that we should choose love and kindness because we do matter and life does matter and the choices we make have lasting effects on higher powers or a God in place. It's a disappointing final message and I wish no one would come to appreciate or believe in its nihilistic approach, it's devastating.

The film is original, masterful, perfectly edited and incredibly engaging. It's an acid trip and it feels as if you're exploring through many different portals of life. It's grand and I believe its a mind dazzling, complicated and pretty fun experience. I can't give it a higher score because I'm saddened by its poor depiction on life and how we should value it. I just wish this film wasn't a message to allow more LGBTQ privilege to flood through our heads thinking that's okay.

In summary, it's a film about human liberalism and the allowance of mutual sin and spreading sin, it's about universal love but it's human centred and it idolizes our place infront of God. The reason I'm being religious is because the film explores so many ideas of life and the meaning of it. As a Christian I don't believe life is meaningless and I don't believe that lesbian gay rights should be pushed ever so bluntly they did here. I believe that life is full of grace, and lesbians should have equal rights but not in the way of outright blasphemy of Christian tradition. It's this kind of liberalism which angers me because if you don't have a fear of God, you'll unleash human anger and rage everywhere.

Instead of being kind because life is meaningless which is a stupid message, think about how God loves us so much and made you so valuable and you are loved no matter what race, status or sexuality, so then be loving and kind because we are all eternal people and we shouldn't misplace the love and message of Christianity for something trippy, ethereal and demonic.

Title: I want a husband like Waymond
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: A movie that is a visceral experience in a cognitive shell and it works
Review: This more than 2 hour movie is the length of a War and Peace novel. Many of the actors are recognizable from other roles and are true dynamos and professionals in their field. The movie initally appears quite disjointed and confusing but as it progresses the emotional connection takes over and the inticacies of each character in each timeline becomes part of the whole and one processes it as such. I really enjoyed this movie and would highly recommend it. Truly excellent! Michelle Yeoh as the main character is a "shape shifter" in the sense that she can change her demeanor and physical actions as she progresses on her journey. James Hong seems to have been around for ever as an actor and he adds a familiar face to the scene which incorporates drama and comedy in a seamless fashion always taking you to another level. Jamie Lee Curtis is magnificent in a role that you would never expect her to play yet she pulls it off with a memorable performance. Ke Huy Quan who plays the husband from different timelines also brings a believability to the movie and Stephanie Ann Hsu who plays the daughter is able to morph personality and bring shock and awe to the situation. I highly recommend this movie.

Title: Not for me sorry
Review:
I don't get the high reviews, i like Michelle Yeoh and the actors were great but it was a chaotic mess, not for me and i struggled to finish, bleh. I'm struggling to find anything else to say to be honest as i need a certain number of characters to post this and a 5 is generous, it was not for me, it was trying to be serious an silly at the same time an left me not caring at all, but hey, other people seemed to like it from the overall score so make up your own mind. My review is still short so ill add i cringed at getting a papercut and Jamie Lee Curtis is fab as always. Had to skip 10 seconds to fast forward many times in this, a silly mess of nonsensical drivel.

Title: "Everything everywhere all at once" is a great example of movie playing with ramifiend timeline concept while being story about importance of love in us.
Review:
"Everything everywhere all at once" is a great example of movie playing with ramifiend timeline concept while being story about importance of love in us.

The movie introduces concept of traveling through different life scenarios that vary by any, even smallest decisions. Unlike typical blockbusters, this work uses it not to create a plot, rather to highlight problems and challenges characters already had.

The main idea and concept is all kinds of love: love in family, to the stranger and to the partner. With that being covered, almost every aspect of love finds its place here too: lack of love, struggle to show love, need to get one and so on.

It's gorgeous movie that doesn't have weaknesses, covers the topic and takes viewer to an exciting journey which easily deserves 9/10.

Title: Drop Acid Before You Sit Down To Watch
Review:
Would be one way to watch this movie then again dropping acid as I remember slows time down and this was long enough.

Rather difficult to watch to say the least but a gold star for originality.

It will not everyone's cup of tea as you will see in the reviews but if you are looking for something totally out there and like the idea of an experimental experience at the movies give it a shot.

When the final credits did role I was thankful yet smiling, I do not think the reviews do the film justice.

Yes the fight scenes are very "Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon" in there execution but that was all part of the fun in how the film was written.

This is a film that you should make an effort to go see just because it a film that is worth discussion as you are walking out of the theater.

If nothing else, one that will stand the test of time.

Title: What a glorious, entertaining, profound and enjoyable mess!
Review:
I will be extremely short, I don't have too much time but I just wanted to tell people: just watch this movie. Nothing like this ever existed before, it is the most original movie I've watched in years of repetitive plots.

It also manages to be a movie that touches the LGTBQ+ in a purposeful way - and this is coming from someone who hates the recent wave of wokeness.

It's just a GREAT GREAT movie and super fun to watch.

Unfortunately it's not kid's friendly, although I can't wait my kids to be adult enough to watch it because it's too funny. :)

Title: Worth checking out
Review:
This movie, which claims to deal with the multiverse, as the name suggests, but uses this factor to create a truly moving and entertaining story to watch for 2 hours and 20 minutes. The multiverse has been explored on the cinema screens for a few years now, but this may have been the first to show it with mastery. From the performances (which also won an Oscar) to the direction of the scenes.

A movie that can be watched with family, with a comedic tone at certain moments and a really cool message to be conveyed. A movie that is definitely worth watching.

Despite all of this, I don't think it's super innovative, as some reviews suggest, being something outside the box. It's just good at what it set out to do.

Title: Remarkable once you get the rhythm of it
Review:
At first I was thrown off by the frenetic pace, but once I understood and settled into the rhythm I appreciated where the film was taking me. It touches on many issues such as family estrangement, the plight of immigrants who struggle with the rules & laws of their adopted country, and in particular how we view and judge our past choices and contemplate "what ifs". This is not the film for when you want something easy and relaxing. It's a wild ride with a purpose and an ultimately satisfying ending. Congrats to Michelle Yeoh who still has her martial arts chops and all the supporting cast (shoutout to Stephanie Hsu). I recommend this to those viewers looking for an adventure and willing to put up with a little confusion until the movie reveals itself.

Title: Imaginative Fast Paced Multiversal Drama
Review:
Very ambitious multiversal drama. I honestly was not expecting this movie to be built around a family delivered through a multiverse of astounding scenes and imagery but I was pleasantly surprised and intrigued by it. Particularly impressed by the brilliant Michelle Yeoh and the underhyped performance of Ke Huy Quan.

However, considering the high standards the movie sets for itself - despite the brilliance of its characters, how the story is told, and how the movie's plot unfolds, and - if Everything, Everywhere, All at Once is perceived as the fast-paced drama it is albeit set across a multiverse: The movie underdelivers. To be clear, yes, the movie borrows a lot from multiple genres but at its core it is mostly a drama.

In that light, it struggles to provide sufficient emotional fulfillment by the end of the movie and all the brilliance of the movie's methodology amounts to little. It also fails to deliver anything new or unique to match its multiversal ambitions, undermining its brilliance with a bagel. Point being: The movie shows that it can tell its story across a multiverse but ultimately does not prove that it has a reason to do so.

Also, while Stephanie Hsu was good for the most part, I think she perhaps lacked a functional range to portray the varieties of her character. Thus contributing to the emotional gap at the end of the movie.

Overall, it's a mostly superb movie, seriously original and put together with Oscar worthy editing. If there was one Oscar this movie would easily win, it would have to be for the editing work.

From the cinematography to the visuals, and even to the acting it was top notch. It depicted what could be so well. The notion that we live in alternate realities, and can change all of them was extremely well done. I really hope this film gets the admiration and accolades that it deserves.

Title: A masterpiece
Review:

Title: it really is everything everywhere all at once
Review:
If you're reading this before seeing the film, go in as blind as possible. You *need* to see this movie. It will make you laugh, it will make you cry, it will make a confusing arrangement of both come out of you at the same time. It will feel personally tailored to do this to YOU ALONE. It contains a little of every story, every conflict, every problem you yourself are facing, and addresses all of them from a place of empathy and love.

Don't expect anything specific. It won't matter, though. You won't expect any of it. I've seen this film 4 times, once in Finnish, and each time it made me cry in a different way for different reasons. It will require multiple viewings, and it will feel like about 20 movies at once. And it is. It's a beautiful amalgam of so, so, much. It's a story about a laundromat owner doing her taxes. And much, much more.

This is a beautiful film. It's the best film i've ever seen. In addition to the important emotional stuff, it's also a pretty movie, with wonderful cinematography, lighting choices, vfx, all that stuff. That's not why you'll watch it so many times, though. You'll be peeling back layers, both of the film and of yourself, learning more and more about how to live empathetically and be the best possible version of yourself (or, as it may be, live with being the worst). You will find yourself in this film. And it knows that. Knows you. Let it in.
