Title: Best movie ever made
Review:
Some people will laugh and ignore this movie, others will simply call it best movie ever made.

I haven't done research on the "Daniels" but they might have tapped into something profound here.

There are way too many references to the mystics and eastern spiritual philosofies. Like "Mr Nobody" the movie puts the viewer in whats like to be in the 5th plane where we are not prisioners of time instead we have access to timelines, but goes beyound reaching the 6th (choices) and 7th (physical properties), ultimately lands in the realm of empathy and compassion through understanding of others perspectives to prevail in unity of the present moment.

There are many alternative lives out there but them all find beauty in the simple things.

Title: The title resume everything
Review:
The movie title literary resume everything, both in it form and content.

Everything everywhere all at once will be an iconic movie for this generation just like the graduate was for the older one.

First, It carry important messages, such as depression, the meaning of the life we live in etc.. it really hit late millennials and early gen z. In a world where everything fall apart it's hard to take place and find goals that make sense, it's hard for us to leave a print where everything and anything has already been made. (up to you to interpret the others) also it's the best meaning of "it's bad to be bad" because it said that if nothing matter, nothing count then why lost your time to be something else than being good?, It's not naive to be optimistic, it's vital and strategic.

The movie in is absurdity is incredibly well because the absurdity make sense and it's important for the story, that's why it works and also because there is no side character to remind us that it's not normal. This is the key to make absurdity work. This comics scenes was also taken really seriously during the shooting of this film and was meticulously thinked, exactly like a "normal" one they wasn't acting like "it's funny and absurd so it's okay if it's a mess".

The actors choice is perfect, sound design, perfect. And I would like to salute the video montage team because it must have been hard to build up this movie but they did it extremely well.

Im sorry if my critics hits all topics quite randomly but it's hard to give a correctly build advice when this movie put your mind in everything everywhere all at once...

Title: The best movie I have ever seen
Review:
The title is not hyperbole. I don't think anything tops this masterpiece. Art films get too boring, and blockbusters get lazy. This is maybe the most entertaining but excellently written movie that I'll ever see. The humor is great, combining both slapstick and observational comedy. The action scenes are just standalone masterpieces. The cinematography is just refreshingly good. But I wanted to basically talk about two things here, the acting and the message.

First, the cast is just plain awesome. Everybody has already heaped praise on Michelle Yeoh's outstanding performance, but I was more engrossed in Stephanie Hsu's Joy. She has easily secured her place as the best antagonist I've ever watched. Not only is she brilliantly written and acted, I just found her way too relatable. She is maybe one of the best teenage/Gen Z antagonists I have seen, and I was honestly rooting for her the entire movie. Also, they make a very adorable couple(her and Becky).

Finally, the message. The movie does something most movies don't even think about. It works hard to resolve it's conflict, which is basically existentialism. It somehow manages to put a optimistic spin on such a nihilistic concept, and makes it satisfying.

Also, this movie made me laugh and cry with just two rocks. No dialogue, no music, just two rocks at the edge of a cliff. So if you haven't watched this yet, just go see it. Pirate it, buy it, idc, just see it.

This is the true Multiverse of Madness. The 1 minute shot of Evelyn across thousands of multiverses is the best shot in entertainment history. THE BEST!

Title: A blend of "Pulp Fiction", "Terminator" and "Sanford &Son"
Review:
Title says it all.

I feel that you have to watch this movie twice to appreciate the full mastery of this movie.

First time watching it I was having difficulties following the story line.

(Editors had a major job putting this film together)

Full of twists and turns...... but stick with it.

Second time, It blew me away.

Jamie Lee Curtis pulled off a great character.

Michelle Yeoh jumped from so many roles.

Ke Hu Quan kept things connected Stephanie Hu and all others were instrumental to the film.

It was great to see legendary James Hong in this movie.

He always been an extraordinary actor.

Title: Surreal action-comedy
Review:
I hardly know what to think about this. It was surreal, it was science fiction with time travel, it was a martial arts film in the comedic style of Jackie Chan, it was a romance, it was a story about a mother and daughter. I liked the film, but I didn't always know what was going on. I cared about the characters (in some timelines) and wanted things to work out well for them.

One complaint I have is that the science fiction part is never resolved. People from the future(?) or at least a different timeline are trying to get Evelyn to help them, and they are important in the first part of the film but not later. That part of the story just ends, and maybe we're supposed to conclude that their timeline is fixed by what happens to Evelyn, but I would have liked more clarity on that.

Title: I was hoping my power would go out!
Review:
I was hoping my power would go out after 40 minutes ! It did not go out so I got up and left the room with the rest of my family watching I mean three dogs watching. Speaking of dogs, this is a pile of heaping steaming crud. Horrible. Pretentious, overhyped, they stole the awards, it is a juxtaposition of nothingness. Do you want to be so bored that you are writing a review of the movie when it is only half over, then join the club because that's what I'm doing. No story, no plot, pointless, just a huge disappointment after watching the awards show last night. All quiet on the Western front was the best movie of all of them. Someone hand me a fork I want to stick it in my ear to end this pain. Thank you to the Academy ! Not.

Title: I KNOW KUNG FU
Review:
This is the best movie of 2022 for me so far. I'm saying that and I've watched Multiverse of Madness, The Northman, X, The Bad Guys, Sonic 2, and some good ones. From the first minute it hooked me and it just keeps getting better and better. I feel interested and mesmerized each time. I love the incredible acting of each of the cast especially the daughter and the father.

I just don't like some of the sexual jokes as it felt off. The movie also should have been shorter. The movie dragged on near the end and my enthusiasm since the beginning of the movie vanished.

Overall it was an amazing experience. Amazing visual effects and I'm glad that it didn't flop at the box office.

Title: Hysterical
Review:
I love it when a writer takes an idea, considers the many and varied consequences of it and weaves a story around it that captures the imagination of its audiences and forces you to watch it through to a conclusion

For me that's what Everything Everywhere, All at once does.

When you can get over the absurdity of the premise, which is served up piecemeal as the seemingly banal scenario of a failing launderette plays out in the beginning you'll be rewarded by the beauty of its execution, the hysterical outcomes and finally, the deep, deep, deeeep phylosophy its grounded in

Absolutely brilliant.

Title: After careful consideration, this is the best film of all time
Review:
After having watched it multiple times and thought about it for months, this is my conclusion: Everything Everywhere All At Once is the best film of all time. Cinema peaked right here.

Every turn is unexpected, the script is original, the cast is perfect. One moment you're almost dying from laughter, and the next, from emotional pain. The final message, however, somehow seems to have permanently boosted my well-being and happiness in life. Safe to say I have never had a similar experience in the cinema, and certainly, no movie has ever stayed with me like this. Deserves every possible Oscar next year!

Title: My opinion
Review:
Keep in mind that english is not my first language.

The name of the movie fits perfectly with everything the movie throws at you. The actors gave everything they had in them for this movie. The effects, scenery and camera posistions are all brilliant in terms of everything that is happening throughout the movie.

Personally I think there was a bit too much fighting scenes and the comedy choice isn't my type of commedy. Also way to much slow motion and use of music etc... however, that's just my opinion and I won't let that interfer with the movie itself, like many do in their reviews.

Not every movie needs a structure, just like evry song dosen't need a structure. Do you know why old music and movies were generally "better" than newer movies and music? It's because everything was original and new. Nowdays almost every movie and song tries to stick with these rules, guidelines and structure etc which leads to everything feeling THE SAME. That's why the older we get the less we can take of the pop songs that the younger people seems to love. All I knew when going into this movie was that it had something to do with multiple universes, and so much happend throughout the movie and I was unable to predict the majority of scenes and if that's not a good thing then I don't know what is?! The underlying meaning I felt after the movie actually hit me and I feel like it was the point from the directors and writers as well cause those parts of the movie had the longest scenes. I'm talking about everyday feelings that I'm sure 99% of humans will feel at least once in their life, which is wondering what their lives would/could have been like and what lives they want/wish they had. Especially impactful in the world we live in today were people literally have access to everyone, everywhere all at once through their phones and computers, young and old minds seeing both poor and rich people everyday all across the globe... the movie has moments where two completely different realities want what the other reality has, something that is also true in the world we live in. So many wanna be famous and many are jealous of the rich and famous and yet so many of the rich and famous are jealous of the people living normal lives... it goes both ways and every person on this planet has ups and downs and moments were they question their lives and everything that they wish or could go differently. This is not a bad movie and Ive seen reviews by people with thousands of ratings giving this a 1 star and I can't belive it... unless you are a fan of slow pased black and white jazz movies I highly recommend that you give this movie a shot.

Title: All over the place but I liked it. :)
Review:
It's a very thought provoking original movie and for much of it - I don't really understand what is going on with the multiple universes and where the plot is all going.

You are somewhat just as deeply confused as the protagonist yet at the same time, that is what is so amazing about this movie. It makes you both confused yet engaged with the movie every step of the way in a beautifully emotional yet ego-confronting , and at times, humourous way.

Some of the fight scenes are fairly funny and odd. It reminds me of a classic (life reflecting) supernatural film where it takes somewhat supernatural powers and experiences, for one to learn ab ultimate fact about life. I find this movie both well made, with obviously high quality production for the elaborate special effects and the plot is so original, that it's out of this world. I really enjoyed watching this from beginning to the end, and glad to have seen it.

Title: The real "Multiverse of Madness"
Review:
I've been watch those two "Multiverse" genre movies and this one is the true multiverse of madness. Visually pleasing, great acting from all actors, great concept, great choreography, simple yet great storyline, packed in one of the greatest movie ever made.

It's like a huge portion of sandwich, but they didn't put with what it left, THEY PUT EVERYTHING WITH WHAT THEY HAVE yet still managed to make it look like sandwich and taste like a good sandwich.

The multiverse itself might be a huge distraction for a simple storyline, but it's the essential part to make a great world building unlike *cough* Strange *cough* that's just passing by and gone.

Overall, best movie in 2022.

Anyway, I do respect what the movie was trying to say, as chaotic as it was presented. The flipping around between multiverses reminded me most of "Cloud Atlas", but magnified tenfold.

Title: Lunacy. Brilliant lunacy.
Review:
At the heart of this film is a simple and fairly well-worn story about a mother (Michelle Yeoh) - she of conservative upbringing and strong work ethic - trying to understand her liberal and slightly rudderless daughter (Stephanie Hsu).

But how this story is told is a bit bonkers. The daughter manifests as an inter-dimensional being of unimaginable terror, bent on the destruction of the multiverse - and the mother is required to tap into the powers of her various alter egos from across the same multiverse in order to defeat her. Along the way we plumb the depths of the daughter's chaotic psyche and the writers' imaginations, as Yeoh taps into different universes featuring sausage-fingered humans, talking racoon chefs, robot grandfathers and a version of her movie star self. There are numerous homages to different movie genres, from fight scenes straight out of the Jackie Chan school of choreography to extensive comic-book superhero pastiches.

The concept is brilliant lunacy and the execution is almost flawless. Yeoh and Hsu are perfectly cast, Ke Huy Quan is a revelation as he switches apparently without effort between his completely bi-polar alter egos, and Jamie Lee Curtis is in equal parts terrifying and hilarious. Surprisingly, for a fantasy film, the cast is able to dictate proceedings without being dominated by CGI and special effects.

As is the way of cinema these days, the film is over-long and does drag slightly in the last quarter. But that doesn't undermine what is a funny, imaginative, thought-provoking and intelligent film.

Title: A poor man's Matrix - don't bother
Review:
This is a poor man's 'Matrix meets Inception', and is not even as well thought out.

I knew it was in trouble when it was still setting up the premise of what was going on one hour into the film.

It certainly didn't deserve all the Oscars it got, and I can't understand why it has been so hyped.

Some of the visual effects are decent, but the film itself could be a low-budget B-movie.

Towards the mid-point, I didn't even care what was going on in the storyline. Nearer the end I was just waiting for the credits to roll.

I'm just glad I streamed it, instead of paying to see it in the cinema.

Very disappointing and nothing special.

Title: A beautiful celebration of what it means to be alive
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Cinematic Masterpiece
Review: Once a decade, a film comes out that redefines cinema for that era. Everything Everywhere All At Once will be that film for the 2020s. The use of absurdist filmmaking is the perfect vehicle for addressing heavy themes like existential dread and generational trauma at a time when a film like this is needed more than ever. Not once does this film feel heavy-handed in its approach, but it also respects its subject matter and does not shy away from it. You'll belly laugh for half of this film and sob for the other. This beast of a film tackles its themes flawlessly and does not miss an emotional beat while simultaneously being a technical marvel. The performances, directing, editing, screenplay, sound, makeup and hairstyling, costume design, and score are all achievements of their own within this film. Everything about Everything Everywhere All At Once should not work on paper, but it does and it knocks it out of the park. All types of movie fans will find something to sink their teeth into with this film, there really is something for everyone. Go see this one in a packed theater, you might just walk out feeling like you experienced something transcendental with a bunch of strangers. Everything Everywhere All At Once is a warm hug to remind you that all of that everything might just be your superpower.

Title: This film is pure art
Review:
This film is pure art. Michelle Yeoh is incredibly wonderful, and I believe she should be nominated for Best Actress for her portrayal. You will be amazed, you will chuckle, and you may even drop a tear or two. The action is also excellent. In a world when you believe you've seen it all, this utterly off the rails treasure shows you that there is still some creativity left in the world. Michelle Yeoh, the writers, the director, and the rest of the actors have a lot to be proud of with this film.

One of the oddest films to begin with, but the three-part act of everything everywhere at once is one of the most authentic, original, and heartfelt films of the year, if not ever. The supporting cast is fantastic, but no one can compete with Michelle Yeoh as the powerhouse that she is. As a sci-fi lover, it is unusual to come across such a mind-bending premise paired with such an emotionally gripping tale. I couldn't get a certain timeline- noir-esque, fuzzy, rainy- out of my thoughts for weeks after watching. Laundry doesn't seem so horrible now.

Title: Brilliant roller-coaster of emotions
Review:
This one of these movies that explaining or trying would do just damage to whoever is watching it for the first time. Instead I will give the same advice that was given me, hold tight, pay attention, and you'll have a an amazing experience.

I read a couple of the bad reviews here and as expected they are mostly from people who could not understand some principles that might be important for a movie touching the multiverse topic. So if you are not familiar with it, or the idea of philosophy or even rejecting the reality we live in, you will have issues following the plot. There's no such thing as "too silly" to be possible kind of reality, our universe itself is as ridiculous as it can be, we would look just as silly from the perspective of minds from a universe where ppl walk upside down or just the fact the walk at all.

More importantly this movie send me to a journey through most emotions. It felt like action at times, suspense n horrors, but really a lot of really funny times filled the will of humans to feel complete and the power of loving and being resilient to the adversities of life.

Title: Dumb and unwatchable
Review:
I decided I finally needed to watch this movie after all the Oscar nominations it got. After 30 minutes, I almost caught myself falling asleep. After about 1 hour I turned it off. It was truly unwatchable. The movie (at least up until the point that I watched it) seems to have no plot at all. The multiverse theme seems to have been done without any proper theoretical backing or any philosophy behind it whatsoever. In any case, if there is any theory or philosophy, it's completely unintelligible. Everything indeeds happens everywhere, all at once, but I wouldn't say this is a good thing. Maybe I'm just not on the right drugs (no drugs at all) or I didn't understand the movie, but I highly doubt anyone will be able to explain it to me.

Title: Profound exploration of exsistence.
Review:
Sorry it's kind of a long review I apologize in advance.

I'm not really sure how to get into explaining the deep thought put into the movie. The way I interpreted it may vary from your opinion of it. There are some parts that seem a little far fetched but the main idea behind the movie in my opinion more than makes up for the parts that seem to drift. It probably could have been delivered a little better in parts.

A little more in-depth on my idea of the meaning of the movie.

In my opinion the idea of the multiverse that exsists in this movie is something that differs from our current idea of the multiverse from Marvel as an example. I believe it's more of an idea of what you could have become had things been different in life and a way to connect with those lives, where things played out different. Just the idea behind that is intriguing to me.

Overall a movie I would recommend you watch. But also go into it with an open mind and allow yourself to enjoy it.

Thanks for taking the time to read my review....

Title: completly overrated - what a waste if time
Review:
I really don't know why this film was hyped so much. The film is a seemingly never-ending martial arts composition with the pretence of somehow being a science fiction film. Maybe numerous people like the craziness, which, of course, could also be seen as an artistic achievement, but all the film really has to offer is a trivial, cheesy story that culminates in some nonsense and absurdities and, as I said, brutal fighting, fighting and again fighting. I waited a long time while watching the film for something to come along that would somehow captivate me, but nothing.

I have rarely struggled through a film as much as I did through this one, and it is probably the first and only film where I am completely at a loss as to why this film doesn't inspire me, despite the good reviews of others. Maybe I should have smoked a bit pot or taken acid to get some entertainment out of this never-ending nonsense ...

I found this film to be 140 minutes of wasted life (plus 5 Euro rental fee).

Title: You just know the Daniels are going to give us something unexpected
Review:
I really enjoyed this and wasn't necesarily expecting too. A very clever film about our emotional pain and the power of kindness- I found it fantastic. The film touches on so many bases and had me thinking about it in the days to follow. You know the Daniels are going to give us something unexpected and incredibly entertaining. While I hear Awkwafina didn't make the final cut due to scheduling conflicts, the cast still boasts Michelle Yeoh, Jenny Slate, and Jamie Lee Curtis. So you just know there are going to be some comical moments as well as incredible fight scenes. And there are. Well worth checking out, I think one of the top ten indie films of recent time, without a doubt. Check it out and tell your friends- you and they won't regret it.

Title: Really, Just Everything
Review:
You would have to be a secret shifu to foresee that Evelyn, the middle-aged laundry woman, was about to be launched on a hero's journey arc in this kung fu-magical realism comedy. Everything, et.al. Is genius in defying expectations. Evelyn's is a journey of constant time leaps, martial arts spectacles, tasteless comedy, characters with alternating personalities, and uncountable weird planes of reality where our hero discovers and hones her unknown ability to master the multi-verse. Merging multi-genres, this unique movie has something for EVERYbody, sometimes to the point of exhaustion. By the end what glues the whole frantic mosaic together is its unexpectedly poignant message on the need to prioritize relationships and family.

Title: Has everything
Review:
Sums up life's pointlessness and why it's so precious, accompanied by thrilling pictures and seasoned with the salt and pepper of life - humour and play.

This Sci-fi movie presents a mind-boggling idea of a multiverse, puts everyday people in the center of it, which leads to a very everyday take on the big question of life: whats the point? If everything happens everywhere all at once all the time, why dont we just surrender to random and give up? A challenging question which through hilarious frames is being answered in the most everyday way I can imagine: You cherish what you have and seek the point yourself, in this case to practice love.

The story of love that stretches beyond time and space will never grow old to me. Give yourself a reminder on how to enjoy life while it lasts by watching this movie and remember: DON'T PANIC.

Title: Really, really, really awful. And boring.
Review:
I think I spent at least 2 hours of the 2 hour and 20 minute movie wishing it would end, not wanting to say anything in case the people I was with were enjoying it. It is a giant mess, makes no sense, the sci-fi aspects are just dumb, the main character is almost likeable but no one else is, I felt like it must have been 4 hours long, but didn't want to look at my ticket or my phone to see the time so as not to annoy the people around me. The quality of effects and the acting are fine, but the story is just so near non-existent and stupid. I did think during the movie that the great reviews and ratings (the reason I chose it) were like an art critic praising a banana taped to a wall - because they don't want to admit the don't understand it - when there is nothing to understand. Staring at a banana taped to the wall would be about as boring, but not the same awful assault on the senses.

Title: Felt levitating watching it and had an amazing euphoric experience
Review:
I am too lazy to write reviews on every good movie that I watch, but this one is the very few that deserves to write a review about. First off, this movie is a perfectly timed release; a blessing gift for the post-pandemic era. This movie was damn brilliant; one of the most unique, complex and beautifully crafted movies I've watched in a very long time. On a technical level, this movie is a masterpiece; I felt levitating watching it and had an amazing euphoric experience.

It has a phenomenal screenplay, embodies multiple genres and it balances everything. It was overwhelming from the beginning, moving, had a ridiculous twisting plot and it was terrific, beautiful, funny, emotional and deep with a perfect ending.

As soon as it ended, I told my movies buddy I needed to take a break to have it sink in before we talk about it. Then, we started talking and found it very complicated at the beginning but simple at the end, detailed and scattered at the beginning but wisely connecting the dots at the end and as we kept thinking, we soon noticed the depth of the message this movie conveys. It kept us engaged at every scene, we were laughing, we were crying, and thinking and it had incredible levels of emotions with some heart-warming moments. Michele Yeoh has delivered an Oscar-deserving act and the supporting cast has done an amazing job.

It is my top 2022 recommendation, go watch and you will thank me.

Title: Cried happy tears which has never happened to me
Review:
This movie is truly original I haven't seen any movies like this and I think it's probably one of the greats of the decade with only Parasite coming to mind as potentially as good or better. A lot of the negative reviews seem to say it's hard to understand or pretentious, but I don't think either are true. I'm not going to say if you don't get it you are stupid because that's a stupid and rude thing to say, it is weird and has a lot going on but I think really if you focus on the partner and daughter relationships you'll recognise this as just a really sweet and sincere story about family. Which is also why I don't think it's pretentious it is far too sweet and caring a story to be pretentious.

Title: A Must
Review:
It has been a while since I have come out of a cinema feeling different. I am always worried about any type of content that tries to tackle multi-verse or time travel because I feel like it often leads to paradoxes that disconnect you from the story. In Everything Everywhere All at Once I did not feel any of that, even though there are plenty of plot holes and inconsistencies to point out.

Part of it is, of course, the comedy aspect of the movie. But beneath this layer there's a very well told, and surprisingly consistent message of "no self". For me, it reminds me of 2 books combined, namely "Man's Search for Meaning" and "No Self, No Problem".

It is an incredibly powerful message, told in a very dorky yet incredibly effective way. I was hooked from start to finish and I feel like the movie's message will linger in my mind forever. I feel humbled and empowered at the same time.

Title: Everything Awesome In One Place...
Review:
The most original, intelligent, inspiring and beautifully crafted / acted film I have seen in 20 years.

It deserved all the Oscars that it got and more besides. This is a story that was as emotional as it was unexpected and it's hard to imagine that this could ever be emulated by the Daniels, although I'm excited to see what they come up with next.

Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan lead an impeccable cast, beautifully supported by Stephanie Hsu and Jamie Lee Curtis. We are treated to every genre under the sun that ultimately leads to a beautiful reflection on relationships and family. I'll never look at rocks the same way again....

Title: A Fever Dream on Acid...with a Crystal Meth Chaser
Review:
If you've never experienced the mindblowing, sweat drenching, intensity and total derangement of a fever dream strap-in and look no further than this sphincter-puckering, multidimensional rollercoaster ride. The title says it all...but doesn't even scratch the surface. I literally had to hit pause to allow my head to catch up, my heart to slow down, and my bunghole not to give out. As crazy as it was watching this story the thought of writing it made me sick to my stomach. Few films dare to go this gigantic and manic. And when they do they rarely succeed. Not so of EEAO. It is disorientingly heartwarming. And it is a film you will never forget. But watch it with a friend. Not only will you need someone to grab onto, but because if watch it alone, you might not be able to convince yourself it wasn't just a dream.

Title: Unexpectedly touching film.
Review:
I watched the trailer months ago and thought it was interesting but that was it; ok, a sci-fi comedy with a twist, something different from Marvel/DC/Disney..., will watch it, then, sadly, I missed it on the theatre. Luckily, they put it on stream.

Never would had I thought this one was one of those films I'd treasure for the rest of my life.

At first (very quickly) it may be too strange and fast, but once you set your mind to its pace, it's a joyride.

Every performer is on point but Stephanie Hsu and Michelle Yeoh as main characters and Jamie Lee Curtis' supporting role are amazing. Very deep, touching, tender, funny deliveries.

Reading that the FXs were made by a small group of friends (9) including the Daniels (Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, writers and directors) is astonishing and they learned through tutorials, impressive.

I imagine the script as a mixture of the Wachowskis, Terry Gilliam (edit: there's a photo of him and Yeoh together in his IMDB page, maybe in another universe, hahaha) and Charlie Kaufman; a total chaos that leads to something deep and beautiful.

It deserves to be re watched several times to get all the small details. Being a Wong Kar-wai fan I recognised the homage straight away, it made me cry.

This is the way, at least I, expect one of today movies industry's favorite topic to be treated, won't tell wich not to spoil anything, you'll find it. Seriously, with respect, with a sense, not just because it sells better or to catch up with some agenda.

I think in this case editor and cinematographer not should but MUST be credited right next to the writers/directors, incredible work.

Title: Almost unique
Review:
No, 10 is not a wrong score...I would give it 11 if I could.

I cried, I laughed, I thought about my fathers death, I smiled because I have wonderful people in my life, felt love because of a wonderful woman in my life. It has nothing to with the movie but as a person with less emotion on the outside - this movie brought it all out of me. All my emotions simply spilled out.. I felt what actors and writers meant for me (audience) to feel it and felt a bit more...it really was everything, everywhere all at once.

Move is definately unique, worth the watch. I really can't say anything without spoiling it but for anyone that ever reads this review - enrichen your lives with a bit of silly with a side dish of what really matters in life.

Title: Absolutely mind blowing.
Review:
I could easily reach the text limit talking about good EVERY single aspect of this film is, because it is absolutely brilliant in every aspect. It is beyond a visual treat (if intense in some of the flashing parts) that will have you in a trance like state of "whoa". The entire cast is incredibly strong as well and their character shifts are quite impressive.

As a huge film buff who has watched basically everything I can, about halfway through I was already placing it in my top 5, and after that mark, where the emotion and hope and fear of the writing all comes into play...just wow. I'm sure some of the more physical humor (dildos) won't be for everyone and the general wackyness of it all could put some off, but I was mesmerized by it. Never before have I gone from crying from a mixture of love/fear/sadness/hope/loneliness/togetherness ALL AT ONCE to laughing hard while the tears were still coming. This movie is an EXPERIENCE and not just a movie. Thank you to everyone involved for making this.

Title: Hilarious, Heartfelt, Relatable, ALL AT ONCE!
Review:
A truly incredible piece. Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert absolutely knock it out of the park with superb writing and fantastic direction and action that is just bonkers enough to make sense and yet imaginative enough to keep you thoroughly entertained.

The movie is a fresh breath of air amongst the recently developing crowd of multiverse flicks. Never does it shy away from the weirdness or trying to offer complicated explanations which gives room to explore the core characters and the underlying story. This movie will leave you playing out your own What If scenarios in your head, and how the slightest decision can lead to drastic differences in life. Its not a new concept but never has it been explored from the perspective of a relatable story of an ordinary household with common problems which are very much at the heart of it all.

The performances explore the widest range of emotions I have ever seen. Michelle Yeoh gives a career best performance in the role of Evelyn, who is trying to be a good Wife, Mother, Daughter and laundromat owner. Trying to be Everywhere, do Everything all on her own which later ties very well into the multiverse concepts. This is a character she plays to perfection and in my humble opinion is definitely worthy of an Oscar nomination at the very least if not a win. The support cast Stephanie Hsu (Joy) also gives a well layered performance. She flushes out the nuances of being different in a conservative family very well and beautifully channels the frustrations. Ke Huy Quan is also a great support.

To sum it all up, the movie is Hilarious, Heartfelt and Relatable, ALL AT ONCE.

Title: Biggest Surprise since Parasite (at least)
Review:
This is the first time a movie has made me leave a review... and I've been on IMDB for more than 10 years (that alone means a lot).

This movie has it all: action, suspense, humor, emotion... everything! At the same time, the movie is so well written that I never felt "helpless" but was able to follow along well. The story is complex, but you are taken by the hand, so you never get lost.

I don't want to go into too much detail about the story, but you don't leave the theater with question marks (regarding plotholes).

Furthermore, the film scores with ingenious acting of all involved without exception and ingenious animation and sound.

I cried, laughed and completely lost myself in the film... the film made me think and I will certainly see it a few more times in the cinema.

This is cinema. This is art.

10/10!

Title: Nonsensical Drivel
Review:
If there is a message in this movie, it's beyond my ability to see it. I read numerous synopses and recaps, and the pseudo-intellectual explanations seem to be author's attempts to appear intelligent and aware. If you watch this movie with a preconceived opinion of what its 'message' is, you are likely to see it. There's so much going on, that I think you can probably see many 'messages' depending on what you expect. In other words, you can make anything you want out of this movie as it's such a mess of disjointed images and sounds as to be incoherent by the end. Definitely not my cup of tea. I imagine that opinions will be sharply divided on this movie. Viewers like me get nothing from the chaos, while others will see some deep meaning in it.

Title: I'm definitely going to watch this again!

Title: Must be high to watch or worst movie ever
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: I laughed; I cried; are you not entertained?
Review:
It's a remarkable flick.

Cloud Atlas meets The Matrix meets The Fall meets Nietzsche meets existentialism.

A heady experience, fraught with the emptiness of being, punctuated often by absurdity, levity, playfulness, sorrow, compassion, and hope. You never get to wallow in the fact that nothing matters; you're having too much fun.

I realized long ago that anything is better than nothing.

This film imports a lot of meaning from familiar places, like the love between a mother and child (not questioning the ultimate meaninglessness of kin altruism), so it only skims lightly on the implications of nihilism, but it speaks to us in ways we can understand., and if nothing matters, then why not choose to smile about it? Your sadness is just another petulant mythology.

I choose to enjoy the ride. What a neat film to remind us all of the possibilities to experience, and the privilege that it is.

Title: Funny and entertaining!
Review:
This is a very silly and entertaining tail. Its makes me wish that it had a sequel already. Get ready to shake your head and laugh, this movie is full of random silliness and non sequiturs. Good acting and a good script, i am very impressed, I haven't giggled this much in a long time. Most of the movie doesn't make sense yet it is highly entertaining and leaves you wanting more. Im not sure what inspired this film because it is really crazy yet well done. If this one is not nominated for an Oscar than they are crazy. I am impressed at how serious the actors are as they deliver the outrageous lines that have been written. This one is an instant classic and one of my personal facorites.

Title: Heartwarming, Soothing, hilarious
Review:
Everything everywhere all at once is a unique film, blending kung fu action, science fiction, family drama, comedy and heavy existential dread all in one big pot of soup.

It explores some of the heaviest parts of the human experience like failure, unmet expectations, regret, the possibilities that we passed on, what we can and cannot control.

It tries to navigate the pain of living a seemingly unfulfilling life and the thought of "what we could have been" but it never gets boring or pretentious as it is always self aware and humorous.

Ultimately it is heartwarming feeling that you get when a film articulates so much of your worries and reminds you why what matters is what you have right now.

Also I cried for 45' watching it.

Title: Wow!!
Review:
Just incredible movie!

Several bad reviews, not that i think they haters, I imaging their little brains can take that much of what went in to so much effort, thought, arrangements, development and art!!

Just feel sorry for them!

I will just post what other reviewer wrote!

Gbill-74877

"Be kind, especially when you don't know what's going on."

If only we could recognize that those who combat us in life do so out of hidden pain, and fight them with kindness. If only we could accept our kids for who they are, and say supportive things from the heart instead of trying to mold them. If only we could be content with the life we have, and set aside the idea of the countless other lives we might have led, had we made different decisions along the way. If only we could see that the flipside to life being meaningless and everything ultimately being sucked into the abyss is the freedom that comes from that, that we can do anything with the time we've got.

Like the first word in its title, this film feels like everything. While watching it I thought Stephanie Hsu was everything too, but then again, so was Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis. The homage to Wong Kar-Wai with Ke Huy Quan making his enlightened speech is extraordinary, and the fact that James Hong was still getting it done at age 93 was wonderful. I also loved how both mother and daughter, troubled as they were with their upbringing, each found comfort in a kind and patient partner, and Tallie Medel's character was a nice touch.

The film threatens to go off the rails with its madcap multiverse hopping in the first part, but it's all a setup for the second part, which is incredibly powerful. It was impressive that it managed to be so entertaining along the way, with its fast-paced action and the wild ride it takes us on. It's one that rewards a rewatch to, as its full of little details and references. Just a great film, lots of fun, and from the heart.

Title: Top 5 favorite films of all time
Review:
I absolutely loved watching a film that's as simple yet complex as this one. There's beauty in a film that caters for multiple audiences and their watch styles; for example, those who need a little more hand holding for the plot and those who don't. There are obvious themes like, love and navigating relationships with others and yourself, and concepts a little more subliminal / complex like the multiverse itself, chain reactions, life purpose. There's an insane amount of symbolism in this film worth thinking about. From the IRS (and the trophies...I won't spoilt it but) etc... I promise the trailers really don't clue you in to the film genuinely, I was totally taken for a ride in the best way possible. I was just a huge fan of Michelle and that was my main reason for going, so this was the most rewarding and unexpected experience. A film that had me crying, then laugh crying, to feeling changed! Surely you can find some some story line to relate to in this film. Refreshing to see a story like this when cinema seems slower at turning our original content anymore.

Title: How did it win 7 oscars?
Review:
I wanted to throw up while watching this disgusting movie.

It stared off well, but the more I watched the more I wanted to gauge out my eyeballs after seeing the most disgusting scenes.

I understand they are meant to be comedic, but what the heck did I watch? Especially at the end when I saw them eating there hot dog fingers, I felt so sick I could vomit all my organs out.

I am rating this 3 stars of 3 reasons -

1) Although VFX is used for disgusting scenes, does not mean it is bad. In fact I was amazed finding out the VFX-team consisted of amateurs.

2) Acting is good. Weird, but good. The actors did a great job getting into their roles. All of them had to play multiple different versions of their characters, and they did it good.

3 Concept of the movie is good. The multiverse is presented well.

Regardless, I would not recommend to watch the movies for the following reasons -

1) It is stretched alot, most of the plot feels so out of place and just filler. Does not add to the characters or anything.

2) Plot is terrible, and the execution is worse. The plot is all over the place and most of the things just feels like a waste of time while watching.

3) The scenes are disgusting. All the fight scenes feel out of place. One simple word to describe it - YUCKY

4) Mainly because it is boring. Watch something else. Anything else

Also just a warning, do not eat food while watching this.

Title: One of the best movies of the year
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Absolutely Amazing
Review:
This movie is absolutely amazing. Watched it tonight with my friend and we were absolutely amazed at how perfect it was. It contains the perfect mix of comedy without undermining the serious tones and messages in the movie. It's a ride, and a very good one at that. Definitely one of my favorite, if not my new number one favorite, films I have ever seen. 10/10 would recommend, and I do recommend.

I hope that it receives the recognition that it deserves, this is truly a masterpiece.

Title: Simply amazing
Review:
I've never had my entire family sobbing in a room together unless some unthinkable tragedy had just taken place - until Everything Everywhere All at Once came out.

This movie is a wonderful story about family, and family's expectations, told through an absolutely strange story. The performances were great, the script is amazing (don't listen to the haters), and the message came through clearly.

Plus who doesn't want to see Jaime Lee Curtis summon her inner Sumo-Wrestler??

Perfect blend of comedy/action/comedy-action/drama/visuals.

Overall I can't think of a better movie to come out of 2022. I was already a fan of A24, but now I'm a fanatic.

Title: Lost for Words
Review:
I feel compelled to write a review after watching this. I am not going to be saying anything that hasn't already been said, but honestly, this is probably the best ever film I've seen in the past 10 years.

I laughed, I cried, I was entertained, I was sad and I was happy. It was a roller coaster of emotions and that is what separates good films and great films, something that makes you feel. I would understand why some would not like this because it will honestly be the strangest movie you'll ever watch, but for me thats what makes it better.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a masterpiece that is WAY ahead of its time.

Title: Diverging and converging. Iconic
Review:
The movie is an 8 for me.

It talks about self love and self harm, depression, how hard it is to accept love when you believe you don't deserve it, how difficult relationships are, and how we all try our best everyday.

Why an 8 and not a 10?

1) There's this moment when you think "what am I watching!?" which lasts a bit too much 2) Sometimes I wanted it to be close to the end as it felt like it was a 10-hour movie

However I loved the genius! The ability to talk about such topics in an unconventional way.

I loved the costumes, the use of colours and the acting.

Iconic! One of those movies you want to keep on talking about.

Title: Not the worst movie I have watched
Review:
Not the worst movie I have watched, I just can't remember what movie was worse.

I gave it 90 minutes and that was torturous and I am baffled how people are rating it 9's and 10's.

I was excited to watch this movie and did not laugh once.

Title: More than a Movie...
Review:
Love the main actress Michelle Yeoh and this movie is Awesome.

An Action, Fantasy SciFi Comedy that blew my mind. The metaphors are mind bendingly charged. At times I needed to catch up to my brain, other times it was so ironically obvious. It has an artistic quality to it very few movies attempt... Thinking of "Being John Malkovich" or "Crash".

At times I laughed out load and others I cried long. A very powerful movie.

I watched this because Michelle was in it (I didn't expect it to be a Kung Fu flick). It had some chops but it is sooo much more than that. This is a thinking person's movie. A once in a decade awesome movie.

Michelle Yeoh is speculated to be an Oscar nominee (winner?).... this should extend to Ke Huy Quan and screenwriters, cinematography director.

Caveat... you'll either love it or not. If you think you might be liking it - stick with it... 10/10 for me.

Title: Holy sht was this a good movie
Review:
This is one of my favorite movies of all time. I like how experimental it is. It's such an amazing film. The way everything is filmed and the way the story plays out. It also includes a nice at the end. This is a spectacular film that I have greatly enjoyed watching. The acting is amazing and I am very happy that some of the actors won Oscar's for this wonderful performance. This is a movie that I can watch time and time again and still find enjoyment in. It is a movie that will live with me forever. I am very glad I watched it and happy to recommend it to friends of mine or anyone who wants to watch a beautifully made movie.

Review:
A good mixture of sci-fi, drama, comedy and action. Good story line may even make you think about your own life; it can be a bit complex but not hard to follow. It was able get a good laugh out of the audience without ruining the intensity of the moment. Overall, its the best one so far this year.

Title: An Utterly Perfect Film
Review:
This movie of genre bending madness is probably the most life changing movie I've ever seen. The visuals, beautiful, the score and sound design, fantastic, the acting, phenomenal, and by god the perfect writing. This is a movie that is utterly hilarious, with extraordinary action, and thematically it's one of if not the most beautiful film ever. It's messages about life are so powerful, that love and joy is the thing persevering throughout all universes, and that sometimes a meaningless life is what gives life meaning. It's not just about the meaning of life but also the meaning of living. It's acing the messiness of life and man it's just a perfect film. It is not for everyone I will say, it is dirty, fast paced, and very flashy. But nothing will takeaway from the fact that this movie is utterly amazing.

Title: An attack on philosophical nihlism
Review:
"When I choose to see the good side of things, I'm not being naive. It's strategic and necessary."

I believe this line carries the entire message of the movie - optimism does not equal naivity.

This movie does more than just giving us thrills and laughts. It also teaches us how we should think of our lives. You may believe that alternate universes do exist. You may think that our lives are pointless because we could have lived in any of these universes and lived through all the ups and downs. The movie tells you that you are wrong.

We humans possess a natural instinct to render positive meaning to what we sense. That is why everything we have experienced seems to be real. Think about dreams. When you are having a dream, you never realize that you are dreaming regardless of what you see inside the dream. It is this very instinct that makes life possible. We take our life seriously and try to make the best of it because we believe it to be positive, real, and worth-living, otherwise there is no way we can survive.

It does not really matter whether the world we live in is actually real. In a Matrix-sense way of thinking, we may all live in a virtual reality and everything we feel is nothing more than electrical signals in the brain. What matters is that even inside this virtual reality we can render meaning to our lives and treat it as if it is real. This is the persistence of the survival instinct - it drives us to secure the best ourcome in whatever circumstances we find ourselves. It is this spirit that makes us human beings.

Next time when someone calls you naive because your are being optimistic, tell them you are not being naive.

Title: The Matrix on acid
Review:
I'll keep this short at to the point without any spoilers.

The movie was so good it compelled me to write this review when I should be working, but this was good enough to impart a small reflection of this classic to be.

This movie is a work of genius, a true masterpiece with a brilliant core message of the power of imparting kindness over violence. Of listening and understanding our place in the cosmos.

The acting is flawless as is the casting. The visuals are absolutely mind blowing.

As my review title states, the movie reminded me in part of the Matrix but better and yes, on an acid trip. I loved the action scenes and the humor throughout. It would be cool if they created a 3D version as well, but it's not needed.

One of the best movies ever made in my opinion. Kudos to all involved. This is the pinnacle of cinema.

Title: An Ambitious Yet Disjointed Journey
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All at Once" starts off on a promising note, offering an intriguing premise that captivates the audience. However, as the film progresses, it transforms into a chaotic whirlwind, attempting to depict "everything everywhere all at once" in a manner that mirrors the confusion experienced by the protagonist and her daughter. While the initial setup held promise, the narrative soon loses its grip, leaving viewers struggling to comprehend the multitude of scenarios presented. The narration lacks the necessary clarity, making it challenging to grasp the logic behind various scenes and understand why events unfold as they do.

Despite its narrative shortcomings, the film benefits from convincing and above-par performances from its cast. The actors succeed in bringing authenticity to their roles, elevating the overall viewing experience. The direction also exhibits skill, with the filmmaker's ability to handle the complexity of the story and guide the actors effectively. However, even with these strengths, the story fails to maintain a tight hold on the audience's attention as the film progresses. Repetitiveness and a sense of endlessness start to seep in, detracting from the initial intrigue and preventing a fully satisfying experience.

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" ventures into the comedy and sci-fi genres, with varying degrees of success. The comedic elements, unfortunately, fall below par, failing to deliver the expected laughs and lacking the impact needed to enhance the storytelling. On the other hand, the film manages to justify its inclusion in the sci-fi genre, exploring parallel universes and delving into thought-provoking concepts. However, the overall premise does not entirely convince, leaving some doubts lingering in the minds of the audience.

The film concludes with an ending that fails to convincingly resolve the chaos within the protagonist's mind or satisfy the audience's desire for closure. The overwhelming abundance of not-so-interesting sci-fi parallel universes contributes to a flat and unsatisfying conclusion. The ambitious nature of the film's concept, while commendable, ultimately becomes its downfall, as it struggles to maintain a cohesive narrative thread.

In conclusion, "Everything Everywhere All at Once" sets out on an ambitious and thought-provoking journey. Despite commendable performances and competent direction, the film falters in its execution, succumbing to confusion and a lack of narrative clarity. While the sci-fi elements are justified, the comedy falls short, and the story loses its grip, leaving the audience wanting for a more engaging and satisfying experience. With a promising start but a flat ending overshadowed by the abundance of parallel universes, "Everything Everywhere All at Once" receives a four-star rating.

Title: The people who get it, get it. The people who don't, don't.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Now this is how cinema should be!
Review:
Like it's own Chinese name: "horses flying in the sky". Which is a mandarin idiom that shows unlimited imaginations and absurdity, so is this film.

It's been a long time I had ever watch a film with like pure talent of imaginations, not just in settings or plot, but also in cinematography and the use of sound! After watching so many mainstream films nowdays, I had already forgot that cinema is actually a form of art. And this film, it shows us how creative cinema should be.

However, after the unlimited amount of hustle and bustle in the film, the main theme of the story root into the theme that most commonly talk, but everyone has been missing out in normal life: love.

The main character is a pure loser in the start of the film, in crisis of divorce with her husband, having a rebel daughter, a father who disappointed in her, and of course: unlimited amount of taxes.... If you ever live in this kind of world, you might be wonder what's it like to live in the other live, where you can make a different decision that might lead you to a better life.

But what if all you can do is just loving what you had now? Like take a good care to people surround you? Take a good look at the washing machines that you had been bothered to see everyday? Instead of wasting time to regret your decisions in life, which lead to a more regretful life.

This is definitely a film you should watch as early in your life as possible.

Title: philosophically great, but partially a hard watch
Review:
So, as someone who is deeply interested in philosophical questions, questions of depression and anxiety, this film should have been perfect for me. It actually is, in terms of asking and answering the big questions of humanity: Where are we ? Who are we ? Are we alone ? How can we go through this ? Alone ? As a family ? What are feelings ?

I think the Daniels answer these question very easily, not cheeky at all, we are humans and we've got emotions, desires and wishes. It's what makes us human, our feelings, and we can live through these emotions and make connections to other people. It's how we can overcome anxiety, madness and desperation. It's a beautiful message and the film explores these themes with undeniable power and maturity.

In addition, the film is a great production, it has some of the best fighting scenes I've seen in recent years, strong acting by its lead cast. It comes with clever dialogue, with beautiful pictures (as I'm referring to two stones talking to one another right next to a cliff), costumes, design, special effects - it's all there. A beautiful piece of art - and that what it really is in the end - a piece of art.

But this piece of art comes with some cost. Really, I love the messages behind the movie. But I think that in the end it, of course, it can be an artwork, but it's also still a movie. And in-between all these multiverses, we sometimes don't know where we are. Humans, or as I should say -especially myself - still have the desire to know where we are and to hold on to that world we are living in right now. The film floods you with pictures, images, changes, fights, explosions, madness. Of course, this whole thing here is madness, our life is absurd. But in the end I watched a movie of which I expected to be entertained. And I was entertained, but it felt stressful. Almost exhausting. It was just too much. The pacing was too fast in my opinion. I would've needed more time to take a deep breath and ask myself what the hell I just saw. I also feel that the 140 minutes are too much. Don't get me wrong. I liked this, but I didn't enjoy the watch as much as I did it with other masterpieces or artworks, because there is still an opportunity to create these kinds of movies AND deliver an easier watch.

I also want to mention, that I cried multiple times, especially in the end, where I think the film rewards the viewer brilliantly. But that reward was not enough in comparison to the demanding but also tiring parts in it.

Title: It really blows my mind
Review:
This movie is a great masterpiece that offers a profound experience. It develops something wholly original and mind-blowing by breaking the rules of conventional filmmaking. You are always surprised and on the edge of your seat. The movie finishes with awe, making you wonder about your perception of life. You shouldn't miss it since it's engaging, thought-provoking, and an unforgettable experience. Everything Everywhere All at Oncenis a movie to make you feel, think, and just have a fantastic time. It's an opportunity of a lifetime that you won't forget long after the final credits have rolled.

Review:

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. Title: Not everyone get every thing all the time.
Review:
I can see why you either loved it or hated it.

It either struck a cord with you and was the greatest thing ever, or you didn't get it and it was a chaotic mess.

I got it by its display of living with a nihilistic view, yet the importance of being kind and kindness being the only way forward when you don't know what is happening.

Maybe someone got it for another reason entirely.

However movies that take risks like this deserve the praise and if you don't get it now, circle back in a few years. Maybe you can feel the way I feel now after watching this masterpiece.

Maybe you will never get it, but get this, you are just a little dumb spec, we all are and nothing really matters, so just be nice if you are going to be anything.

Title: The indomitable bond
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a poignant cinematic masterpiece that beautifully delves into the complexities of mother-daughter relationships. With mesmerizing performances from Jamie Lee Curtis and Michelle Yeoh, the film's enchanting dance of love, conflict, and shared history leaves a deep emotional impact. Tenderly exploring the joys and sorrows of motherhood, it celebrates the unbreakable familial bond. The breathtaking visual storytelling mirrors the ethereal nature of this unique connection, enhancing the emotional journey in ways words cannot describe. A tribute to the resilience of the human spirit and the power of love, this film invites reflection on our own connections with loved ones. Embracing the joys and heartaches of the human experience, "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a rare gem that resonates with profound tenderness and genuine emotion. Prepare to be moved, to laugh, and to shed tears of both joy and sorrow in this heartwarming and emotionally resonant cinematic journey.

Title: Simply Amazing storytelling

Title: A Heartfelt, Multiversal Roller Coaster of Emotions and Adventure
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a masterfully crafted sci-fi comedy that takes a deeply relatable story of a family struggling with an impending divorce, tax debts, and a strained mother-daughter relationship, and turns it into a wildly imaginative adventure through multiple universes. The Daniels duo expertly weaves these seemingly disparate threads together, creating a cohesive and emotionally resonant narrative.

The film's unique blend of heart, humor, and mind-bending visuals offers a fresh take on the multiverse concept. Michelle Yeoh delivers a captivating performance as the beleaguered housewife, whose journey through the multiverse brings her face-to-face with the many facets of her own character. This exploration ultimately helps her to address the challenges in her life and mend her relationships.

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a must-see for those seeking a cinematic experience that is equal parts entertaining, thought-provoking, and genuinely moving. This film is a testament to the power of storytelling, reminding us that even the most outlandish adventures can be rooted in universal themes of love, family, and self-discovery.

Title: Scott Pilgrim + Neo + Dr. Strange
Review:
After taking Existentialism in high school, I would never have dreamed a movie about "life is meaningless" would have me laugh-crying at the end.

The genre bending of the Matrix mixed with the multiverse of Marvel and then layered with the most exquisite humor of Scott Pilgrim, this movie was incredible.

I cannot imagine how the screenwriter conveyed such absurd concepts (hot dog fingers, talking rocks, not to mention a beautiful raccoon riff) to a director who "had a vision for what they wanted on the screen (?)" who was able to get the actors to so convincingly amp up the nuanced acting as we flit back and forth to the same universes where the continuity manager's head must have popped. The white board for this concept must have dwarfed any previous movie and the editor had so many cuts that had to sync up. Just wow.

Hats off to the entire cast. Well done and beautiful. The ending was not at all what I expected and I cried (?) several times as it wrapped up. And the ratatouille references made me laugh. Thank you Hollywood for this one of a kind movie and Yeoh you are the best. I cannot believe a woman so versatile, beautiful, and physical can be in her sixties. You the best!

Title: A therapeutic psychedelic trip that might change you forever
Review: Honestly, I never write reviews for any films but this one might stay in my mind for a long time. This is what aliens should see if they come visit us, or what people will watch in 100 years from now to understand the origins of our culture. Being the closest I've ever experienced to a psychedelic trip, the film immortalizes how it feels to live right now, at this exact moment, in such an entropic world like ours. I have questioned countless times the meaning of life, been close to suicide, suffered from constant depressions, and wondered how life would be if I had chosen the other path, or any path at all. But nothing hits deeper than the sense of nothingness that comes up when you get a glimpse of all the alternate universes you could've experienced, which is also a real math principle given the infinite size of the one we live in. Everything, Everywhere, All at Once will relate to each of your life memories and draw a picture to the frightening feelings the anxious, unstoppable and unforgivable world has put you through, but to say CHILL, LOVE and DONT WORRY TOO MUCH. Because nothing matters, nothing can stop you. Nothing is too important to prevent you from enjoying this one shot you get that's called life.

Title: It's all about Michelle Yeoh
Review:
While the movie is very fun, cutting 20 minutes and refraining from this overdose of dialogue and resolutions could have helped a lot. Some images would have been enough to explain - or make you feel - the multiverse and all its facets.

Truth is : "Everything, everywhere, all at once" is fantastic because of Michelle Yeoh. She shows an ability to habit emotions that you cannot rehearse, to frame silent emotions as if in her right true life, portraying a character who would not grasp the wild stakes of these events. She made me feel like truth was achievable by an actor with a very deep control of emotions. Her kung-fu education in martial arts surely is no stranger to that ability.

I don't think we will remember the movie as much in the future, but we will remember Michelle Yeoh. There is no Oscar night without her kicking Chris Rock on stage in 2023. And if she doesn't win then they haven't understood anything about acting.

Title: One of the best movies I have ever seen
Review:
This is easily one of the best movies I have ever seen, definitely the best movie I have seen in the past few years.

I try not to go into movies anymore with any sort of expectations as I've been let down quite a lot recently. I heard great things and decided that this would be a movie for me. I have never been so engaged in a movie as i was to Everything Everywhere All at Once.

This movie should be regarded as art. It is so well done as a comedy with a sincere message that had me nearly sobbing at the end. Movies don't make me cry.

I will forever cherish this movie and I recommend everyone give it a shot, even if the message doesn't come through to you, it's still a fun ride!

Title: First time I disagree so much with the average rating!
Review:
Worst movie I've ever watched! Yet, the average rating on imdb stands at 8.0. This is so surprising. I usually am not hard to be satisfied by movies, and I had always agreed broadly with the imdb average rating (by a point or 2 at most). But it's the first time I disagree so much with the imdb average, and with reviews in general. I really felt like I lost 2 hours and a half of my Saturday because of this movie. The message shared at the end is a message I agree with, the plot sounds interesting, the actors are amazing actors, and it's great to have some changes in the typical cast of Hollywood movies... but the movie's jokes and comedy scenes felt like they were aimed at teenagers (particularly a few scenes that I would definitely had laughed about with some of my friends when I was in high school). I would recommend to stay away from this movie, despite the amazing reviews you will find and the nominations it has received.

Title: Not just any movie. It's why I watch movies.
Review:
Plenty of cynics today like to play this one angle, "We can't make movies today like we used to!" And to that I would retort, well there are plenty movies being made today that couldn't have even been imagined decades prior, for reasons of special effects capabilities and subject matter.

Here is a movie that falls into both categories.

A multiverse plot can be like a time travel plot. It can make your head spin. Our main character Evelyn, portrayed to perfection by Michelle Yeon, learns that much for herself in quite literally the most overwhelming manner possible, when she is suddenly sucked out of her mundane life by an alternate version of her husband who claims that the fate of all existence rests is in her hands. No pressure there.

It's as weird a movie as you can possibly imagine, which has become the trademark of the Daniels directors. What else can you expect when you are transported to realities where people have hot dogs for fingers, or rocks make up the human population, or where the physical laws of Pixar's "Ratatouille" are a thing?

But like "Ratatouille" taught us, "the new needs friends." This is the kind of movie that encourages you to push your levels of acceptance along with Evelyn herself.

If you can bring yourself to look beyond the nigh unfathomable chaos, you might see that it only serves to benefit Evelyn for the better.

It takes meeting an alternate version of Evelyn's husband Waymond, in a verse where they never married, to help her realize, maybe a lifetime of laundry and taxes isn't so bad if you're sharing it with someone special.

It takes encountering a dark, misguided version of Evelyn's daughter Joy to make her ponder, maybe I've been pushing her too hard as a mother.

After the most mind-bending and convoluted of trips, it all boils down to this one timeless reminder. How did that Kansas farm girl put it? Ah, yes.

"There's no place like home."

What else can I even say about Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan, Stephanie Hsu, Jamie Lee Curtis, and of course James Hong that hasn't already been said by everyone else on Earth? They are all nothing short of phenomenal in every variation of their characters we see.

Ke Huy Quan, aka Short Round, shines like a star as Waymond after decades away from movies.

Stephanie Hsu as Joy shows fantastic range from joyful (no pun intended) to sinister. I look forward to seeing her in more stuff.

Jamie Lee Curtis...she's terrific as always.

And James Hong, of course, continues to be a legend.

From a technical standpoint, if you can believe it, only 5 people made up the bulk of the movie's post-production work. You read right. 5 people! At a time where major blockbusters have a small army of folks in the Post-Prod credits scroll. And yet this film actually stands out more visually and creativity next to the majority of them. Coupled with some of the most ludicrously bad-ass action sequences I can recall of late in cinema.

Impressive is not an adequate enough word.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" is not just any movie. It's why I watch movies.

Its success makes me happy.

Its continuously growing following makes me happy.

It's best Picture win gave me the happiest surprise I had in ages at the Oscars.

And somewhere, in every verse, there's a variant of me being asked "Are you Happy?" And my alternate selves answer, "well...movies like this definitely help."

I can't wait to see it again.

Title: For people who like to think -- Ignore the bad reviews from people who want movies to be easy
Review:
In many places, the film confuses -- but only if you aren't paying attention. I'll grant that the one impediment for me was the broken English; it was hard to follow at times and I missed things.

But the script was innovative and, yes, derivative (as some have complained), but derivative in that it points out its references, such as The Matrix, 2001: A Space Odyssey, Rick and Morty, amongst others. It's a lot of fun if you stick with it.

A few things could be improved/changed, such as the butt plug scene, which made no sense; and some editing was needed for the bagel scenario, which went on too long. The "message" was a bit heavy-handed, and should have been handled in a manner more befitting the zaniness of the film.

I'm going to watch it again, to see what I missed, this time with closed captions.

Not perfect, but definitely one of the better films of the year. If you like being spoon-fed sentimentality and simple plots, like that found in The Shawshank Redemption, this is not your movie.

Title: Complex and profound without taking itself too seriously.
Review:
A farce roller coaster ride with countless awkward unexpected turns around each infinite corner.

Original as it is deliberately random, this deeply philosophical journey feels a bit like The Matrix got an "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" makeover.

The Meticulously planned storytelling is done with both precision, and sporadic slapstick humor.

But above all...This movie may be one of the most brutally honest stories about love and family that exists in modern film.
