Title: Whole Lotta Cringe
Review:
The funniest pattern in these reviews is the number of ravers condescending to everyone who disliked this mess, 'You obviously didn't get it.'

Uh-huh. That's it. Went straight over our heads...

Three out of four of the main actors were excellent (sorry, Stephanie Hsu). Portions of the film were quite moving; I cried more than a bit.

But, god, my kingdom for rewrites and some ruthless editing! The film was so repetitive and overlong I wondered how the directors and producers could possibly believe the story played as is. Much of the visual humor was overused to an embarrassing degree. The IRS audit evoked more suspense and tension than the super villain/end-of-the-world plot, which was entirely unconvincing.

The film's ultimate Message, the love and kindness offered as an antidote to...well, everything, would have carried more weight if it weren't undermined by the protagonist almost immediately.

How 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' got so overhyped is a mystery, beyond the obvious appeal of a feel-good Hollywood underdog(s) tale. Love me some underdogs! And weird is *always* more interesting than tentpole flicks. But when people first touted EEAAO as a potential Best Picture nominee, I thought they were joking. Now it's the odds-on favorite? Are films where you could sleep through 45 minutes and not miss anything essential really something to aspire to?

Title: A beautifully brilliant existential crisis
Review:
If you have never had an existential crisis that comes with or immediately precedes a Great Depression where nothing makes sense, everything hurts, you're confused and fighting the unrelenting urge to throw yourself into the void, sorry bagel, of doom, then you are unlikely to understand any of this.

It has been a very long time since a movie has forced me to focus all of my attention on it, by barraging my senses, making me read AND watch AND pay attention, I was not half on my phone, wondering where I'd seen the actors before, making mental lists of what I needed to do after it ended. I was fully immersed in the experience, even when I didn't understand what was going on, I was invested, I wanted to understand.

What I got was a story about family and love and that ability it has to pull you back from the edge even when it all feels too much, when you feel everything, everywhere, all at once and question why we are even here and what the point of it all is. We often don't need answers, we need the person who stands beside us, holds our hand, says 'I'm confused too but I love you and I'm here'. I think this was a truly wacky, beautiful story and I loved it.

Title: Unexpectedly brilliant!
Review:
I avoided to watch it as I am not a fan of absurdistic parodies... until Curtis got the Oscar, which made me curious . Armed with new patience I turned it on, it is on Prime TV.

I didn't expect to last the full 140 minutes and the first 20 something were... challenging as I couldn't place it anywhere.

But slowly it opened up, and the brilliant acting only helped me to navigate through this circus of emotions, depth, superficiality, human nature, clich√©s, philosophy, comedy, costumes, caricature and even real tears (I'm human after all:). The world in a nutshell with us, humble beings as observers. Incomprehensible, incommensurable, impressive, unpredictable, entropic.

The title says it all.

Warning: you will either hate it of find it genial.

Title: Absurd masterpiece we never knew we needed
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Simply perfect
Review:
Upon first view I instantly thought "wow this is one of the best movies I've seen in the last 10 years."

Upon second view i think, "wow this is the best movie I've seen in the last 20 years"

After the third view.... I can squarely place this in my top 10 (personal favorite) films of all time.

It just has everything.....a beautifully woven story from SUCH a complex plot. I kept thinking to myself "how the hell could a writer pitch this coherently???"

As usual....glad A24 was able to answer the call.

It's just such a beautiful family film....with superhero/super natural elements that has so much heart, humor and a great message. Entirely unique and unlike anything I can possibly compare it to. I simply can't endorse this movie enough.

Title: Easiest 10 Stars Ever.

With exciting, tense scenes, ridiculous situations, and hard-hitting emotional exchanges, it has it all without feeling cheap. I'm not even afraid to over-hype this movie because I hyped it up for some of my friends, and they still loved it.

Be warned though: This movie doesn't really fit into any genre, and will be wildly different from almost all other movies out there. It's like an art movie that also has an intensely heavy-hitting story line(s?). So good, if you get a chance you have to watch it.

Title: A magnificent cinematic trip.
Review:
I've seen this movie 5 times now, and I still don't know how to sum it up. But I'll briefly try, just enough to meet the length requirement üòâ.

This movie is about despair, love, faith, nihilism, and the unrelenting human spirit... but it's also gag comedy, unflinching absurdity, and visual cotton candy. It's a lot (hence the title), but it somehow works.

And it really gets better each time you watch it - for me, the 5th watch was the best so far. I don't think I can say that about any other movie.

One last thing: you ought to watch this movie with friends or family - if not on your first watch, then the next time you watch it. Trust me. It's a conversation starter.

Title: A Good Film About Family, Non-Political
Review:
I'm Asian. I'm politically right-wing. I saw this film over a year ago. I enjoyed it. The movie is about an immigrant woman whose hopes and dreams were repeatedly beaten and destroyed, but it is her love for her family that keeps her going. It reminded me of my immigrants parents, who worked so hard, and their dreams shattered, just to provide for the family. It's a genuinely good film. The action and the multi-universe, and the questionable but hilarious props and scenes, it's entertaining.

Some people are making this into a political thing, like as if this is a leftist agenda. It's not at all. It has nothing to do with Asian agenda, or whatever it is. This film was highly rated even a year ago. We're seeing a bunch of negative reviews from salty people.

Title: Multiversal yet Universal
Review:
It's a low budget independent production from the wonderful A24 Films. It's also a creative powerhouse about the multiverse that can make Marvel jealous. It uses the most cheap and shallow forms of humour you can think of, while offering a symbolism extravaganza that reaches deeper every time you think about it. Hard to classify, hard to describe... but let's try.

In one sentence, it is a film with a multiverse clothing over a core of family relationships. In its essence, it's a mother/daughter, wife/husband story.

The contrast between a complex sci-fi theme and something so human, with which we deal since the beginning of times, makes it layered and easy to relate to.

It's multiversal, but it's universal.

Also, as an underlying theme, it presents a philosophical confrontation of Jobu Tupaki's (daughter) nihilism and Waymond's (father) optimism. Bagel vs. Googly Eye.

As a visual metaphor, one is the inversion of the other: a black symmetrical donut with hollow center, a white asymmetrical eye with black center. Both circles having similar geometric properties but indicating opposite approaches to life.

The literal "Everything Bagel" was made by Jobu Tupaki. With her godlike powers (acquired from being split across infinite universes), she compresses all that exists in a donut-shaped singularity. When you experience everything, she says, nothing matters. Life is hollow.

On the other hand, Waymond uses googly eye's stickers to attach joy and kindness to everything. For him, even dull things can be seen as worth of appreciation, happiness can dwell in enjoyable little moments. Life has substance.

Throughout the movie, the Daniels use several round shapes to address and reinforce this duality.

At first, in images as the washing machine's doors or in the way Deirdre (IRS auditor) draws a messy circle on Evelyn's (mother) papers, they refer to the bagel. Inevitability, lack of finality, monotony. Evelyn is trapped in her cyclic routine, in a tedious laundry business, dealing with the IRS. What is the point? It could easily drive her towards nihilism.

By the end, the circular shapes become more asymmetrical and colourful. The chinese decorative lights are framed more instead of the machine's doors in the laundry scenes, Deirdre's pencil (the same she used to circle Evelyn's papers) shows a colourful ball attached to its top. It's optimism taking front.

Evelyn makes a journey of getting out of her inertia and self-absorption, experiencing instead her daughter's and her husband's views about life. Thus, comprehending them truly and loving them honestly. The circle now represents connection.

Camus said: "What gives value to travel is fear." Perhaps we can conclude that Evelyn's journey was full of fear, full of wanting to get back to what was, but ultimately fear shook her up and she was ready to see value on Waymond's way. His kind way of fighting. She realized that keeping their customers coming and having Deirdre give them more time were Waymond's merits, that past victories were not because of her, but in spite of her.

At the moment she wears the googly eye as a third eye, she is enlightened. And then, having traveled from nihilism to existentialism, she is able to guide her daughter through the same path. Empathy.

I also love the recurrent use of irony. This is an exhilarating movie about laundry and taxes. The name of the daughter is Joy. The very fact that the worst version of Evelyn is the best fitted to save the multiverse is hilarious.

Being always just one decision away from a better version of herself, Evelyn is able to connect more easily to all her better universes. As she chose always the worst path, several better paths, and it's acquired skills, are now uniquely close to her. There is a lesson the movie wants to teach us here.

Even the most ridiculous universes are capable of carrying deeper and valuable meaning. In fact, the Daniels seem to dedicate themselves to come up with the most extravagant, nonsensical, absurd ideas, and commit to them, just to reinforce the argument that it is possible to find the best in the worst. The hotdog fingers could have been just a brief visual gag, but became a full arc, as did Raccacoonie, and contributed decisively to the final resolution.

It adds to this approach that the most violent scenes are filled with comedy and feel frivolous. And that the most laughable settings or visually empty parts carry an emotional punch. The rocks, how do not cry with them!

The film is named Everything Everywhere All at Once and hardly I've seen any movie edited and composed so fittingly to its name. It's remarkable that it can be so cohesive with such a wide range of subjects, genres, techniques.

Is it sci-fi, comedy, coming of age story, martial arts, romance, thriller, drama, musical? Everything at once. The mix of genres make it impossible to classify.

Is it spoken in english, mandarin, cantonese? Everything at once. Grandpa speaks cantonese, daughter english, husband mandarin, and Evelyn has to mix it up. At first, the cultural and language differences within the family act as barriers to deeper relationships. At the end, the mutual acceptance, empathy and the realisation of their connecting lines bring the family together, and they are richer because of their diversity.

Is it 1.33:1, 1.85:1, 2:1, 2.33:1? All aspect ratios at once. It changes constantly. 1.33 (4:3), reminiscent of old TV screen proportions, used in flashbacks. 1.85, an aspect that can fill the entire movie screen without pillar boxes, used on dialogues, romantic moments and other situations were realism is needed. 2.33, the widest of them all, in cinematic fight scenes or large scope shots. 2:1, an odd and uncommon aspect ratio, in the sausage fingers' universe.

Each universe is also shot and colour-graded in different ways. Anamorphic vs Spherical lenses, flatter/colourful/greener gradings... these all are used and yet the final result is cohesive. To achieve that the editing here is nothing short of spectacular. Wow, those transitions!

There are also a plethora of references, homages. The most obvious ones: Kubrick's 2001, Tarantino's Kill Bill, Pixar's Ratatouille, Wong Kar-Wai's In The Mood for Love. Also, Matrix, Hong Kong kung fu movies, and several others influences can be spotted. A multiverse of movies within this one.

The soundtrack is a masterpiece. We also have everything at once here. Classical music, pop songs, ethnic, circus and western themes... dozens of small motives, arranged differently according to the context. Each one helping us identify a universe, a character relationship. For instance, Clair de Lune appears for the first time in a fight scene between Evelyn and Deirdre. When Evelyn can finally say "I Love You" in a truthful manner, it plays. Afterwards, we find out that there is a universe where both are lovers, and Clair de Lune is the soundtrack of this relationship.

Another example: Waymond says: "Your clothes never wear as well the next day, your hair never falls quite the same way", describing the multiverse. This is from the 2000's song "Story of a Girl" by the one-hit wonder band Nine Days. When he says it, many of us possibly sensed something familiar about those words, but not quite sure what. A very parallel universe/deja vu kind of feeling. Afterwards, the song plays in the movie, including different versions of the lyrics and arrangements, made by the original band, according to each universe.

Add to all that the superb acting from all 4 main actors. They are mesmerizing. Michelle Yeoh delivers a wide range of several versions of herself. And among all that, she conveys the stages of fatalism, self denial, enlightenment and acceptance Evelyn has to pass through.

Ke Huy Quan transforms from kind and naive to confident and experienced with just a flick of his expressions and body language. We are never confused about what version of Waymond is on screen.

Stephanie Hsu is as big as Jobu Tupaki is, and not every actor can pull it off. The hopelessness, the solitude, the sense of inadequacy, all there in her eyes and with a crazy costume design that she tames as a horse whisperer.

Jamie Lee Curtis was never freer, exposing a vulnerability I'd not yet seen in her past roles. Laying all on the table: being a stern and judgemental auditor, a delicate and compassionate partner, a monstrous and menacing villain. A bravura acting.

At the end of the 3 acts, all this ridiculous amount of everything imaginable surprisingly showcase a cohesive work. How could the Daniels put everything in this bagel and come up with something as tight as this marvels me. It is another testament to the recurring theme: connection. Emotional, visual, thematic.

All connects as in a circle.

Title: Everything we needed all at once

Title: Tour-de-force in every department.
Review:
This is what happens when you get extremely creative directors and writers together with super talented actors, and give them a project that allows all of them to make career-defining work. Every single aspect of this film is as close to perfect as I've seen. The images on screen are lush and saturated with color and texture, the camera work is kinetic and puts you right in the middle of all the action, the ensemble cast is fantastic (more below), the stunts are mind-blowing (and hilarious), the story is totally weird and original (and a bit mind-bending, but don't worry it all makes sense in the end), the special effects make you scratch your head and wonder: "how did they do that???"

A quick moment of focus on the acting in "Everything Everywhere...". The role of Evelyn is very difficult as it carries the weight of the entire film, which is told almost entirely from her perspective. She has to go from a tired, end-of-her rope, slightly downtrodden immigrant woman whose hopes have been dashed by harsh reality, to the saviour of not only our universe, but countless others as well, realizing along the way that the little daily events and love of her family, is what will save her. Michelle Yeoh pulls this off masterfully, letting us see in her face (and whole being) the transitions she's undergoing, at great peril to her own sanity. But she in no way does this feat on her own. The talent arrayed around her is so powerful: an almost unrecognizable Jamie Lee Curtis portrays her nemesis IRS agent; Ke Hui Kwan (known from Indiana Jones and The Goonies) in his first major film role in over 20 years portrays Evelyn's husband Waymond, at once both the ass-kicking protagonist and tender beating heart of the family; the radiant Stephanie Hsu plays Joy, Evelyn's daughter and unexpected antagonist. Even the minor parts (James Hong, Tallie Medel,and. Jenny Slate) are fleshed-out and contribute greatly to the film.

The result, is a film that feels holistic, that presses all the buttons. It's by turns hilarious, balls-to-the-wall exciting, devastatingly sad, and ultimately life-affirming and uplifting. One of the best films I've seen in the last 10 years.

Title: Why the love for such a bad movie?
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: A great movie that gets better the second time you watch it
Review:

I was captivated by the film's exploration of immigration issues and cultural identity, as well as the emotional storyline between mom and daughter. The exceptional performances of the cast and stunning visuals made this movie an unforgettable experience.

So if you've already seen "Everything Everywhere All at Once," I highly recommend giving it another watch. You'll be surprised at how much more you can discover and enjoy. And if you haven't seen it yet, get ready for a wild ride that's sure to leave you wanting more."

Title: Creative, funny, relatable
Review:
I went to Everyman cinema to watch this movie and let me get this straight, I slept for about 20 minutes at some point because it was feeling endless and boring as they were building up the story but after waking up, THE MOVIE WAS BOMB. Made me laugh (a lot) made me cry too. Motherhood is explored and you can see how experiences create different emotions on the mother's side and on the daughter's side. I really appreciated that relationship explored. The relationship with the husband too made me put a lot into perspective: we always want things to be different, we want the people we love to act a certain type of way towards us and sometimes even blame them for the who we are and who we are not. But at the end of the day we need to make the best of every situation, appreciate where we are. She had several lives lived in different spaces where she felt more accomplished but the actual her in her universe was the best and the most fulfilled at the end of the day. The scene with the rocks, one of my favorite too.

Great movie, a lot of cognitive capacities where awake due the multiple colors, scenes, jokes. The Oscar was very well deserved. Good actors, good script, good story build up.

Title: 9 stars from me
Review:

Title: A modern classic. Best movie to release in years
Review:
In a time where most popular movies are marvel movies or remakes of old films, EEAAO is a truly unique, creative, emotional and brilliant film. It is a mind opening, sometimes uncomfortable, challenging, deeply emotional journey that you need to embrace to fully enjoy.

First off I want to say that there are a ton of negative and 1 star reviews coming in, and if you read them or look at the demographics they are mostly from people who admit they did not watch the entire thing or did not get it, and are often older folks giving bad reviews. Not that you need to be younger to enjoy, it just uses a lot of things that are easier for people under 50-60 to understand.

This movie is truly incredible and touching. The performances are incredible, especially from the leads. It will make you laugh, cry, and wow at how crazy the action and editing is.

The only valid criticisms in my mind, is that it is a long watch that can be laboring on the first watch bc you are trying to keep up with everything and figure the story out completely. There were maybe a few fighting scenes and extras they could have cut out. I really liked it the first time i watched. It became one of my all time favorites the second. Blows my mind that some did not connect to the story. Me and many others cry like a baby at the ending.

If you are in the mood to commit time and emotion to a great film, and you have an open mind about how they get you there, then this movie is for you and you will love it as much as myself and many others have!

Title: Simply touching movie
Review:
Kindness can change world.

One action by action of our generousity, we all start from there.

I was extremely shocked when I first watched this movie. Even though life might be tough, you want to give up everything and just lay down, this movie gives me lesson to stand up again.

We are so small existence in absolutely gigantic cosmos. This movie taught me we should love and encourage each other.

Michelle Yeoh, who is the main character of this movie, was completely amazing that I was totally absorbed in the film every second.

The CGI was absolutely amazing and so was the soundtrack.

I highly recommend this movie when you feel you are in a rut in your life. We can feel how surprisingly valuable every moment is.

Title: Best movie I've seen in a long time...
Review:
A fantastic film that was brilliantly written and thankfully the direction was executed perfectly to do the story justice.

While it won't be to everyone's taste, for those who can appreciate (and see) the nuance beyond the ridiculous (and hilarious) elements, it is an incredible end product. The way it ties universal themes and emotions together through a complex yet understandable storyline warrants a lot of praise.

The acting is, for the most part, right on point. The ability to switch between characters so seemlessly can be hard to master but how it was done here was as good as it gets.

Ultimately, this is a film you will either love or hate, there can be no in-between.

Title: Mostly Bonkers
Review:
While it can be a bit slow to get started and a bit slow in places, many parts are downright bonkers and quite funny. It's worth giving it a bit of a chance. If you got to the first bit of proper action and didn't warm to it, then probably not worth persevering.

That said it could easily have had a bit of trimming and towards the end I did feel like I'd been duped a little, as this seems to end as a wholesome "family" story.

While the core story uses the same couple of locations many of the extra cut scenes made it less samey.

Acting was top notch, with everyone as you'd expect and more.

Give it a chance.

Title: The title is fitting
Review:

Title: EVERYTHING CRAP ALL AT ONCE
Review:
What a dreadful movie.

I wanted to leave before the hour mark but stayed because of partner & 24 year old, movie fanatic, Autistic son, who always has to stay until the end, but, I couldn't stay any longer than 80 mins. When we met afterwards, she said she wanted to leave too & he even admitted "it wasn't very good", & he likes 99.9% of films.

Hollywood. Please stop with these multiverse movies. If they're not done well, they're too complicated to follow & bore us folk, who want to support cinema but you guys are testing our patience.

1/10.

Title: Great modern movie; times are changing
Review:
The fact that this movie sweeped the oscars is a good sign in my eyes.

Over are the days when only hyper-story focused movies got a chance. Make way for more chaotic storylines, more chaotic concepts, more chaotic everything.

Pros:
Great acting by pretty much everyone on cast
Fantastic concept art
Fantastic levels of creativity
Great gags...


Cons:






I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It didn't try to cater to the blockbuster crowd, didn't try to cater to the arthouse crowd and somehow managed to impress both.

If you don't like concept driven movies, I would strongly suggest skipping this one. If you're open to experience something different WATCH THIS.

And if you liked this, go watch something even MORE different and put in Tarkovsky's Mirrors.

Title: Uniquely Brillient Sci Fi
Review:
It's weird, it's quirky, yet it is one of the most uniquely interesting sci fi movie ever made. Hats off to Michelle Yeoh's performance, her delivery of diverse acting is a masterpiece. Story was very integrating; directing, camera work, action sequences, set and costume designs are all top notch. It was a real visual treat.

My one criticism is later part of the film felt a bit slow for me.

Title: What is the meaning of life? This movie is you answer!
Review:
When I walked out the theatre after watching this film I was in absolute awe. Such amazing cinematography as well as great acting.

This movie thought me that love is the most important thing to have in life and that nothing else matter except surrounding yourself with the people you love. It's as such a complex film with such a simple and core meaning.

The colours In the film are so vibrant and dull at the same time. This movie is (imo) the perfect depiction of what a person should get out of watching a movie. Feelings of both happiness, sadness, confusion, but at the end walking out having learnt something that can benefit your life as well as feeling like you have wasted 3 hours of your life.

Absolutely in love with the movie and is one of those film you always think back in and say "what I would do to watch that again"!

10/10.

Title: Is it really oscar worthy?
Review:
I really liked this movie, the plot or more like, the way they handled the plot was kinda unique, which is great cuz even tho this subject of the multi-universes it's kinda being overused right now, the story still feels fresh BUT it didn't convinced me enough, i had big expectations since it's an oscar winner film but it disappointed me a little. The cast though, was amazing !!!! Ke Huy Quan and Stephanie Hsu were my favorite, she totally deserved that "best actress in a supporting role" oscar by the way, i love Jaime Lee Curtis and her acting in this film is great but c'mon... anyways still a enjoyable movie lol.

Title: Utterly Absurd. Masterfully Grounded.
Review:
I watched this movie late last night on the back of the numerous oscar wins and haven't stopped thinking about it since. This film absolutely floored me. Who knew a concept so utterly absurd could be so masterfully grounded.

For me, and from many reviews I have read and seen this is a very polarizing movie. I will go on a whim and say some people will perceive this as pretentious nonsense, naive, utterly absurd and therefore write it off. Although that is why the movie is utterly brilliant.

What the directors, referred to as 'Daniels', have managed here is a beautiful commentary on the philosophy of life, the importance of those around us and a masterful telling of relationships between generations. It is a rollercoaster of emotions, I found myself laughing hysterically and sobbing uncontrollably whilst watching throughout.

The first part, "Everything" lays the foundation work for the movie, sets up the concepts and launches the viewer headfirst into the narrative. It sets it up like an a-typical villain movie, you side with one team and it almost seems like your a-typical action film with great comic relief and fantastic fight sequences. The movie however truly begins with part 2, "Everywhere".

The second part is where this movie masterfully paints it's narrative. Interlinking ideas of relationships, love, kindness, empathy, masculinity and trauma on the basis of what was set up by part 1 in "Everything". Whilst in a typical movie the characters tend to go through their own 'arcs' this movie puts the audience through one. It questions at the meaning of life and provides it's own answer. Whether or not you agree with it is up to you, although I found myself suitably moved at the message this film delivered.

Part 3, "All at Once" serves as a beautiful, emotional conclusion.

The acting performances were also masterful. In a movie as utterly absurd as this it takes something really special to make it feel so grounded. Kudus to Ke Huy Quan, he is one of the main reasons this movie works so well.

I cannot recommend this movie enough, I wish more people "got it" and took the humanitarian messages it offers. Hollywood needs more films like Everything Everywhere All at Once. I will never forget how this film made me feel.

Title: Oscars Awards are apsurd!
Review:
I've watched hundreds and hundreds of movies in my life, and rarely did I have to stop the movie halfway through because it's stupid for some reason... this movie is stupid for many reasons, and I was happy to stop it and save an hour of my life. The American Film Academy has shown for the umpteenth time that the Oscar awards have become absurd... films like these do not deserve to be nominated at all, let alone be declared the best. I'm glad that every now and then a movie like "Parasite" or "Coda" wins an Oscar, they deserve awards because of the incredible story, acting and impact they leave on the viewer... unlike this movie. Everything, everywhere all at Once is a pale attempt at a combination of superhero movies, sci-fi, and comedy, and unfortunately, it fails in any of them.

Title: An acid trip-like cinematic experience
Review:
I admit that I had to do a second viewing to understand the film better and I'm glad I did. Everything Everywhere All at Once is a true masterpiece. It's not common to see a film that incorporates elements from a number of genres and film mediums and executes it flawlessly. But even with its twisted and true swirl of genre anarchy, the film is simply a drama about a family trying to work their issues out.

Like many other people say, Everything Everywhere All at Once is one of the most original films ever made. The writing and the execution were near perfect. Michelle Yeoh's performance was superb and Ke Huy Quan was just fun. The visuals, the cinematography, the editing, and the music were outstanding. It's a hard watch and definitely not for everyone, but for those who enjoyed this acid trip-like cinematic experience, we could agree that this is one of this year's best.

Title: A modern day classic!
Review:
Visually stunning, surprisingly small in scale, with both inventive and silly jokes, jaw-dropping action scenes, dramatic twists...

That alone would qualify it for an enjoyable time, but no...this movie doesn't stop there. It goes all in with its underlying message and holds nothing back. Themes, plots and meanings that will be spoken of for years to come.

All held up thanks to an amazing cast. Every single one doing their absolute best: Michelle Yeoh has to do much lifting, succeeds at everything she does and perhaps delivered the best performance of her career.

But man, do I have to point out Ke Huy Quan, who almost has to do just as much as Yeoh and he chose one hell of a role to come back to acting. I can only hope it will encourage him to stick around.

Title: Stick with it... Mom
Review:
Everything everywhere all at once is a story about being a mother, letting go, fear, and love. With a whole bunch of real and not so real nightmares thrown into the mix. Oh, and king fu. Lots. Of. Kung Fu!

It's an existential dip into the nature of reality. Of life. Of living. Of being alive. Of being human through multiple universes of possibility and potential.

It doesn't make any sense: until it does.

Stick with it.

Right until just before the end... (no spoiler alert).

Because if you follow it - and you can 'get it'... It'll pop you out the other side into a wonderful dimension, where being a Mom actually makes sense.

And it rocks.

Title: Not as advertised!
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Yo-Yo-Yeoh!
Review:
Admittedly, I tuned in because of the talented headliners, Michelle Yeoh and J. L Curtis............I was not let down; what a brilliant, beautiful film (seriously funny too).

This movie blends, and bends, time effortlessly. The chaotic streaking of time with each universes' character is a delight to witness.

The humour in this film is unexpected at times making the jokes/situations all the more funny.

All of the cast was brilliant...... it was cool to see "Data" back in action, and James Hong too - so good! Stephanie Hsu nailed her character(s) and the coutume and make-up department deserve serious accolades.

This is probably the best movie I've seen in 2022 - I loved it! 10/10.

Title: Ego Death
Review:
Everything Everywhere All At Once is one of the best movies/experiences I've ever encountered. It's sad that there are so many people not "relating" to or letting go and giving themselves into the story and relating to this masterpiece. It made me think and feel deeper than I can ever recall from a film.

There are some moments that I can see some people would roll their eyes at, but I cherish the playful scenes that add to the complexity and break the ice with an assumed lol or wtf moment to some... Overall, I laughed and cried (more than once!). This one challenged my mind and opened up so many memories I thought I'd lost!

Title: Weird in the best way
Review:
Dont go into it with details, the less you know the more entertaining it is , but that being said heres my review. The movie is straight up weird, it takes so many random turns thats compile upon each other and the genius is the plot that unravels in way that pulls them all together into cohesion. Theres so many details to the movie that they didnt breeze past and i think thats what makes it one of a kind. The raccoon ratatouille, the outfit changes the outrageous fights, etc. They took a general plot concept and gave it authenticity and Alice in wonderland details. They did what so many low budgets films try to do and thats pull off weird in a way that isnt cringey and unrealistic. This movie was alot funnier then I thought it would be , I absolutely loved the rock scenes. There's something so refreshing about seeing something completely new AND good, and this was it. Its got great shots of aesthetic fights, funny unexpected laughs, clues and puzzles and attention to detail like no other, definitely worth watching once !

Title: Oscar must have eaten the bagel
Review:
If you want an intelligent film about the 'what ifs' of life, watch Krzysztof Kieslowski's excellent 'Przypadek' or Tom Tykwer's 'Lola Rennt', but whatever you do stay well clear of this nonsense. At 140 minutes it is at least an hour overlong and suffers from the worst crime in cinema of being boring. Puerile humour, action pieces straight out of the Marvel playbook and inane dialogue all contributed to making this a very poor effort.

Many reviewers have stated that the central premise is original, which just shows how little science fiction writing they are familiar with. Even 'Family Guy' did a much funnier job with Stewie and Brian's interdimensional antics.

How this mess was worthy of 7 Oscars is beyond me. I'm off to watch 'Lawrence of Arabia', 'The Godfather' and 'One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest' to remind myself that there was a time the Academy recognised craft and talent.

One last thing, this film needs a warning for people with photosensitivity, which was not on Amazon. There are several almost subliminal sequences which could easily trigger a seizure.

Title: Infinitely brilliant and infinitely flawed
Review:
This is the closest film I have seen that explains reality, infinity and all that.

As the narrator in Fight Club says, You met me at a very strange time in my life... I want to go and visit the sausage finger universe... I might head over there now once I've written this on my iPhone, or I'll get ketchup all over the screen!

It's missing the concept of black swans, and unknown unknowns - but that is impossible to describe. It's impossible to describe an unknown unknown - because as soon as it is known, it changes state, it exists, like Schroeders cat, or light that is both a particle or a wave, and changes once observed.

If you watch this thinking it's a wierd multiverse movie, like The Matrix or Fight Club, with characters with mental health issues that need therapy, oh dear... you've missed it...

Love it, I need to watch again and again... I wonder what movies are showing over on the rock universe?

Title: Great Film... To watch
Review:
This was really a joy to watch. I have to say I did non expect something like this at all: Crazy and emotional at the same time. I've watched the film after seeing all the attention and nominations that it received at this year's Oscars and my expectations weren't the highest. I was completely wrong. The movie is kind of intricate (in a way like tenet and inception) but it has also a great emotional story and somewhat of crazy. All the actors and actresses are AMAZING and of course Michelle Yeoh and Stephanie HSU are superbe. Also if I don't know if everyone would love this film for sure, i would definitely suggest it.

Title: So surprising
Review:
My friends and I had no preconceived notions about this film and its cast. I still can't believe it! I recommend this exceptional film, from the great and amazing actresses. A film that we will not forget!

A real UFO in the movies industry ! A very creative visual slap much more subtle than it seems to the closed brains that did not appreciate.

A certain level of culture and humor is required to understand the points.

In all this madness, there is however a great lesson of life in each of the characters, of a great delicacy.

Of an audacious mix of genres (social chronicle, science fiction and action), a strong cast (Michelle Yeoh, Jamie Lee Curtis) and original ideas.

Title: Beautiful, beautiful movie.
Review:
I don't understand the negative reviews, maybe they're just not thinking deeply enough about this movie, or maybe they can't relate with the family's story. I personally found it SO relatable and accurate of most middle-aged couples with teen/young adult children. I ugly cried through the whole thing, while at the same time laughing through the whole thing. To me, I felt that the multiverse plot was just an avenue to tell us a story of acceptance. Don't get me wrong, it was such an imaginative use of multiverse theories and it was done in such a cool way. But regardless of the multiverse I think this is so worth watching. Most of us, like myself, often feel unaccomplished in life and this movie really gives those people the spotlight. You don't have to lead an extraordinary life to lead a happy life. I think that is the most important lesson this movie teaches us.

Title: Imagery for a decade
Review:
When you think back to images that define an era, this film provides an endless stream of them. Each filled with something unique, hysterical, sad, identifiable, strange, bonkers, creative, and beautiful.

Finally! Something I haven't seen before!

A film about generational acceptance layered within a story about a family in need of some deep emotional catharsis, while dealing with a tax audit, involving a multiversal war.

You could explain every detail to someone and they'd never quite be able to visualize this mashup of every genre.

Deservedly winning its 7 Oscars, its easy to agree that it's the best picture of 2022.

Title: I can't believe it had so many awards and nomination
Review:
The cinematic interpretation of multiple universe concept appears to be quite challenging. I thought Dr. Strange and his confusing multiverse experience was pretty bad until I saw how it could go worse with this flick. My expectations and standards are low when I watch movies on the plane but I could not stand more than 30 min of this nonsense. I am giving it two stars because of Michelle Yeoh. She is an awesome talent indeed. Everything else was horrible, not entertaining at all, and very difficult to watch. I do not understand the positive critic reviews and the hype. I would rather strongly discourage everyone from wasting their time on this ridiculousness. Oh, and please do not give it Oscar for best picture! It would be an utter insult for all the great filmmakers out there.

Title: A mixed bag, but excellently made
Review:
I thoroughly enjoyed the first half of this film but felt that the second half dragged a bit. As a cinematic experience this film is stunningly well made. It's funny, heartwarming, has some great action scenes and is very, very weird.

The performances from all the main actors are brilliant and for the first half at least I felt like I was was watching something very special. Possibly my favourite film of the year so far.

However, the second half is where I started to lose a bit of interest. I don't mind a film being a bit odd as that is what makes films original - especially in this world where Hollywood churns out lifeless crap like Uncharted and The Contractor (just happen to be the last two turkey's I've watched) but I felt like the story started to drag towards the end. I started to lose track. Again, I don't mind being confused by films because this just means it's worthy of repeat viewings to pick little bits up you missed the first time - but when it is SO confusing you barely have a clue what's going on, it becomes disengaging and hampers your enjoyment. It could have done with being about 20-30 mins shorter to be honest. After such a brilliant assault on the senses over the first hour, making this over 2 hours just felt a tad too long.

Overall this was original, well acted and entertaining so it's worthy of the high praise it's getting, but I can see why it has such diverse scores. It won't be for everyone due to the madness of the last 50 mins.

Title: What a movie!!
Review:
Its been a while since I've watched a film that has had such a profound impact. There are times when you question every little decision you've ever made, and wondered what would've happened if.... and this film addresses this head on. The complexities of life lye in the everyday choices we make and the impact they may have on our lives, and those closest to us. A simple concept, yet the reprocussions of these decisions can be life altering as portrayed so beautifully in this film.

What if????

Title: great cast in a plot that is sometimes complex to follow
Review:
The movie's exploration of the multiverse is both visually stunning and thought-provoking, weaving together complex scientific concepts with inventive storytelling techniques that keep the audience engaged from beginning to end. The film's special effects are particularly impressive, adding an extra layer of immersion to the already captivating story.

The performances are generally strong, with Michelle Yeoh delivering an outstanding performance as Mei. Her character brings a relatable and emotional core to the film, balancing out the more abstract and philosophical aspects of the story. The rest of the cast, including Stephanie Hsu and Jamie Lee Curtis, also do an excellent job of bringing their characters to life, adding depth and nuance to the overall narrative.

Title: Exciting, Charismatic, and highly Innovative
Review:
Never let it be said that innovation is dead in movies. Sure all that need be said may have already been said in a thousand movies, or books that are as old as the Bible. But that is no reason for us to be lazy and rehash everything exactly the same way. It's possible to say the same thing in a different manner. And that's exactly what this movie does. It's basically a family drama, and the symbolism are way too clear for anyone to miss. A lesser movie would've made the mistake of underestimating its audience by spoon feeding them rubbish information that's clearly way too easy to understand, in an attempt to make themselves look smarter. On the other hand, if a pretentious filmmaker had taken the movie, it would've ended up being too ambiguous and self serious. Thank God that was not the case. This movie is fun, light hearted and extremely well paced. The action scenes are so energetic that they keep you on the edge of your seat and the comedy is too idiotic that you can't help but laugh. It's an emotional drama that is disguised as an action, scifi and comedy. Hats off to the writers/directors. This is only their second film if you can believe it. And their first one is a masterpiece of it's own, a little movie called swiss army man.

Goddamn, the level of genius is mind blowing. If only others can learn to duplicate such an art, we would've been able to watch more than 3 great movies a year.

Title: Amazing
Review:
The Kung fu is great. The acting is great. The plot is great! This movie is really crazy and intense!! Omg! I can't believe how far this movie pushes the envelope. It really makes you question your own life choices. This movie really has it all. I cannot recommend it enough. Now, the only people I can't recommend it to are people with epilepsy. This movie does have a lot of flashing lights and fast moving images, so that's something that should be considered, but I think if you don't have epilepsy then you should definitely check it out. This movie has made me excited to see the Oscars again, and I haven't been excited for the Oscars in a long time.

Title: Made an account just to rate this movie
Review:
I love movies, but rarely have I found a movie that didn't feel like Hollywood's cash grab or formulaic. The trailer for EEAAO piqued my interest because of the mention of multiverses and I thought how bad could it be.

I am so glad I saw it in theaters. I enjoyed the movie so much I have seen it in theaters about 5 times bringing different people who have never heard of the movie and left the theater in love with it.

This movie had a lot of passion, talent, and feelings. A visually, character, and plot engaging movie putting you on an emotional rollercoaster.

Ignore the fact that this was partially filmed during the pandemic, and ignore the fact that their budget was only $14 million (average is $50 million) This movie felt real, genuine, and I am so glad that I am part of the universe that gets to experience this movie.

For the best experience, watch the movie knowing as little as you can.

Title: Amazing!
Review:
I do not even know how I like this movie, but I absolutely love it and want to put it up there with my favourites. I will be the n-th person to say this, but this movie really is Everything, Everywhere All at Once. I really do not know how this movie does it, but it has so many things that I think I normally find extremely frustrating, unrealistic or not funny at all, but with this movie I appreciate it, love it and absolutely crack up at it. Of course I have seen movies that made me go through a lot of emotions but this movie is so different. I had so many emotions, and they all felt so complete and separate, it was like I watched 5 movies that all gave me a different emotion.

I think I love how this movie gives you so many options to feel about it. You can think it is a great comedy or action movie, but you can also spend a lot of time analysing all the subliminal messages of the movie and find it an incredibly deep movie. It somehow succeeds at all of it.

I saw someone make the comparison with The French Dispatch (in a negative way). I absolutely hated The French Dispatch (sorry), I found it so boring, it made me go and study. But in a way, I do understand the comparison. I (an absolute layman) think The French Dispatch also tries a lot and tries to make people connect with and get into an absurd movie. To me, The French Dispatch just totally failed at connecting and well, everything.

This review is probably chaotic and all over the place, I apologise, but that kind of is how this movie was for me. And I absolutely loved it! Wow!

Title: Everything Everywhere it was all at once
Review:
Best ADHD representation ever. I cried and I laugh all at the same time.

I get why some of the comedy could be perceive as cheap but in retrospective that is what happen to some brains when they are bored and they try to make sense of mundane situations. Yes is like using apples to do maths but it's an ADHD brain using the most basic language to explain how it works.

Just sit, relax and don't try to make it into the masterpiece that it already is, because you might not get it.

It is brilliant!

Title: The best movie of the year?
Review:
After some time and many recommendations, I have finally seen the film and now understand why it is so positively received.

Well, the film is very emotional, its concept is absolutely bizarre, it plays with several genres and above all it is also crazy, even a bit punk.

Ah, and Michelle Yeah is simply fantastic!

And when do we see crazy things anymore?

You see, too rarely.

But it's also, above all, a family drama that focuses on a mother's relationship with her daughter in an incredible way.

And the film is a great philosophical work about how to be your best self.

So, it's worth seeing.

Go and watch it in a movie theatre.

Title: It's the best movie this year
Review:
Any movie that beats this movie this year should be this movie which is 1 minute longer, I have never hungered to rate a movie 10 as this, please watch it, if you don't like it watch it again, you might have missed something, it's undeniably good. I enjoyed the way they presented the concept of the multiverse; funny, crazy and amusing. I don't know a good person with good judgment that can rate this movie lower than 8. I really wish this movie would get more attention and probably win an Oscar.

Title: A Brutally Honest Review.
Review:
I am a middle-aged male cinephile. I've seen my share of movies. This one made my fingers itch to write a review, halfway into the film. I managed to see the whole of it and oh boy I am pissed off! And let me tell you why.

There are some things that bother me but I will gladly give them a pass, like:
The script is a deliberate mess, it is supposed to be, fine I get it!


The style is like Kung Fu Hustle, with a hidden "serious" meaning. Sometimes silly, sometimes rude, sometimes even offensive to the eyes, mixed with some "forced" drama to make an impact, give a touch of superficial reasoning to the story. Sure, I can live with that.


But seven freaking Oscars?











And now for the cherry on top!



Three Oscars for acting! For Best Female Lead, and both supporting actor and actress? Seriously? It makes no sense! I mean the script is so ridiculous that almost anyone could recite the lines and do the gestures and the funny faces. And even when the cast has a chance to connect with the audience, the script being so over the top surreal, deprives them of this opportunity and get lost again.

Please, the Oscars have become a joke. I have nothing against the actors, but did they deserve Oscars? No! Why? Because using the Academy's current logic Jamie Lee Curtis could have gotten an award for Halloween, Ke Huy Quan for Goonies, and Michelle Yeoh for Crouching Tiger, or even James Bond for all I care, it would make so much more sense than winning for their work in this production. Stephanie Hsu who was also nominated for best female support role, was the only one that brought some consistant acting skills to this movie.

Seasons change, trends come and go, the world changes, but for this movie to be considered the best Hollywood has to offer right now, that is simply ludacrous and it tells you a lot about the state of the Arts in general.

Promoting this movie as the best of the best, it shows you how much Hollywood care about quality, which is not at all! It only cares about things like being "inclusive" and "open minded", and that's another reason why people don't watch movies in the theaters anymore. Why would a family of 3 paying tickets for this movie... They would feel ripped off, of their money and their time they could have spent elsewhere having actual fun, I do.

Concluding, I don't know how to rate this. A 5 out of 10 is the best I can do, just because the movie is supposed to be weird and it suceeds in that.

Review:
Underneath all the multiverse romping, martial arts and VFX is a very deep story about how the buildup of daily emotional clutter can blind the relationship between kindred souls.

This is the Matrix, but it is also something else deeply interesting.

I didn't know Hollywood could still make movies like this.

Title: Actually Everything
Review:
Everything that could ever be said about this movie has probably already been said, but I think this is an amazing change of pace for Action as a genre and as a whole. It's a genre that has been, in my opinion, dying for many years, run into the ground with the last 20 generic marvel releases, but this is something new, refreshing, and a poignant breath of life brought back into the genre. Title: A foooking masterpiece
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Fresh Approach to the Multiverse
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a fresh take on the quickly staleing multiverse idea that is now commonplace in the cinematic world. It follows Evelyn Wang, a mediocre woman who is capable of extraordinary things, and her journey through the multiverses. In exploring who she truly is, she must go on a journey of self- discovery, acceptance and pure unadulterated adventure.

Title: The perfect movie exists?
Review:
I don't ever review movies but this one is dear to me.

It is all at once the chaos_and_ order of what genius looks like. It makes me feel emotions I can hardly describe, ranging from joy and wonder of discovery and comedy to the deep human connection where I am crying my heart out at recognising the familial connection between the main characters and their complex emotions.

Yes, I am a grown man, in fact often robotic in not showing emotions openly as society has designed me, but present me with the perfection of emotional range that is this movie and you remind me who I truly am (somewhere).

To the directors, thank you for this incredible gift to humanity. I cannot wait to see what you create next.

Title: Worst movie ever
Review:
No clue why this movie got so many Oscars.

It's one of the few I actually walked out of.

So, arguably I shouldn't review it, because I didn't see the whole movie.

But with so many 9/10 and 10/10 reviews, this should have been the movie you want to watch over and over again. Well, absolutely not.

I can only conclude that people didn't understand the movie. But if the critics say it's brilliant, it must be brilliant...

Does Michelle Yeoh deserve an Oscar? Oh, definitely. But it would have been much better if she had received it for one of her really good movies instead of this one.

Waste of time.

Title: Unique, Thrilling and Heartwarming
Review:
Everything, Everywhere, All at Once tackles a very extensively done trope of time/dimension travel however it does it in such a unique way that feels extremely fresh. There is no other movie like this, and the plot; while not shakespearian does a great job of capturing the audience. The film is packed to the brim with comedy, action, adventure and even heartwarming familial bonding moments, it has a little bit of everything. While some parts feel weaker and less focused, the movie as a whole does an excellent job and is definitely worth the watch. Subsequent watches also reveal many things you don't get on the first viewing so that is recommended. While it can be hard to follow along with at times, if you are able to it is one of the best movie experiences of the year.

Title: I assume acid is like this.
Review:
I loved this film. It was so stupid and so clever. So deep and so silly. It takes a decent amount of time, but what starts out as a comedy, then kung fu flick, turns into a lesson in life which will leave you in tears at its profundity.

The action and comedy serve their own purpose and would be enough to get a decent movie together. This film weaves them seamlessly into a solid and novel plot, though.

A multitude of concepts I've never seen mentioned, let alone explored in movies, are swirled together into something really special.

I really have no idea how a human can imagine this and then film it into reality. A visual and emotional masterpiece like you have never seen, guaranteed.

What a thing to make.

Title: Another baffling movie that makes you wonder why it won anything
Review:
To think this rubbish film won an Oscar is crazy. I felt like the movie couldn't have ended soon enough and to make it worse its 2 hours + long and broken into 3 parts. Like many "Hollywood hype" movies they are rightfully forgotten over time. This movie will be known for "Hot dog fingers". There is nothing else in this movie that is worthy of even remembering beyond that. I can't imagine anyone wanting to see this movie more than once I sitting down to talk about their favorite scene. This movie is all over the place. The plot goes off into too many directions. It doesn't seem to know what it wants to be or what the message is because it has several and none of them are enough to keep you awake and watching.

This could have been a much better movie just like "Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon" a movie that no one liked and only remember because it wasn't a Kung Fu film but was marketed as one. Instead it was a love story people who wanted to see a Kung Fu film got tricked into watching.

We'll that about it on my thoughts for this film. I can't wait to forget it and mostly I already did after watching it. It was boring.

Title: Best move ever filmed?
Review:
This may be the best movie I have seen in my 40 year old life. I didnt expect much of it and just put it on because the trailer seemed interesting.

It started little slow and I thought it will be an okay movie to see before sleep. I was so wrong.

There was wonderfull after wonderfull scenes that my eyes couldnt believe. And then the dialogue and story, my brain was working overtime with processing it all.

When the movie ended I was just sat there with my mouth open. I had a hard time sleeping that night and just was processing the movie in my mind.

This is the greatest thing I have ever seen on the screen and I am thankful to be alive in a time to see something so incredible.

This took my top 1 movie of all time and Donnie darko got pushed to nr 2.

Review:

Masterfully assembled set pieces come together in a way where the end result is greater than the sum of its parts. Feels a little longer than it needs to be since the message being conveyed is shallow. Worth the price of a matinee ticket.

Title: Best Form of Any Storytelling Ever!
Review:
When I first watched Everything Everywhere All at Once, I thought it was one of the best movies I've ever seen. But after rewatching it after some time, I am convinced that it is the best form of any storytelling I have ever come across. Granted, I haven't watched, read or played every movie/show/play, book or game ever created in the many languages that exist. But of the significant portion of my life I have spent experiencing stories and my subjective & biased parameters for what an exceptional form of storytelling should ideally be based on, I am certain that this movie is the best I've come across yet.

Why do I think that?

Because it combines the most investigated philosophical question of the purpose of life, the most complex metaphysical theory of multiverses and the most consistently prevalent emotions of hope & despair, all together, in 150 minutes that span almost every storytelling genre there is.

And it does this with a series of truly extraordinary & powerful acting performances, elegantly simple yet extremely compelling dialogues, absurdist yet coherent editing & transitions and one of the most narratively complementary cinematography ever.

Furthermore, the exceptionally intelligent use of various styles of humour, balanced with a metaphorical yet deeply compassionate use of relationships, to construct a narrative that - though may appear comically-absurd & entertaining on a casual first-watch - is actually so much more; being consistently deliberate, methodical & profound on a second viewing.

All this coalesces into a unique emotional journey - with an abundance of excellent humour - that inevitably transitions to a rollercoaster ride of hope crescendos & despair diminuendos, while offering convincing justifications for these ebbs and flows, concluding in an extremely cathartic & appropriate ending.

Everything Everywhere All at Once - as the title suggests - is truly a story about everything, everywhere, told all at once. It's the most conclusive story of existence. And as cliched and inaccurate its ultimate moral may seem, it ingeniously conveys it in the single most hopeful & captivating manner possible.

And that's why it is the best form of any storytelling I have ever come across.

Title: Nothing Nowhere Never
Review:
Watching this movie was an experience I would have rather not had. Sometimes we see, read, or experience something that just does not resonate. Because we are individuals, we will respond to art differently. There will be some kinds of art that some of us will love and some of us will hate. This is an example of art that was destined to be devisive. Taste and sensibility are everything.

I think it would be very difficult to be neutral about this film, or give it a 5. It's either a 10 or a zero. Was it made well? Yes. Was it well acted? Yes. Were the music and special effects well crafted? Yes. On these elements we can be objective, and positive, and probably agree.

But without being judgmental, and only subjective, was it interesting? No. Was it funny? No. Was it clever? No. Is it worth describing? No. Is it worth a second viewing, or even a second thought? No.

But that's just my opinion, as a sentient individual.

So, for me, It was two+ hours of my life I will not get back.

Title: Strange film, but can't turn my eye's away.
Review:
This is a very strange film, but I can't seem to turn my eye's away for fear I'll miss something important or well, strange. But, stick with it, it will begin to make sense toward the end in the last quarter.

Great casting and I was super surprised and pleased to see Ke Huy Quan in one of the primary roles; always considered him an interesting child actor but then he seemed to disappear from the screen. As he has been reported to have said that after his childhood roles, there just didn't seem to be any opportunities for him again in acting, so he turned to behind the scenes. Would be really interesting to see him reprise his role as 'Short Round' in the next Indiana Jones film, but now as an adult.

Michelle Yeoh is of course impeccable in anything she's in, and Jamie Lee Curtis is a hoot as a government IRS agent. Story line with so many costumes and scenery changes must have been as confusing to keep up with as it was to watch it all. Expect I'll be seeing different scenes of the film in my memory again and again for a few days.

It's an odd film, might even consider Art House worthy, but I'm hoping you will also think it was worth sticking through all the crazy scenes and costumes till you get to the end and the purpose of the film. Best quote is 'Be kind, especially when you don't know what's going on. '

Title: A Breath of Fresh Air
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Title: This is THE multiverse movie
Review:
This is everything I expect from a "multiverse" movie. It is everywhere all at once. I expected nothing more and nothing less. It gave me what I wanted from it.

Title: A Multiverse of Madness
Review:
I give this 8 out of 10, because it dares to wrestle with the nature of our existence. Kudos for that! But it doesn't leave you in a good place. Here is its worldview: Everything, Everywhere, All at Once; Multiverse of madness; Infinite options; Nothing matters; Be kind; Self-loathing: We are little pieces of (trash), Each new discovery makes us realize how insignificant and small we are; What matters most is human connection; A renewed appreciation for your place in the universe through nihilism; Appreciate the few good moments of your life because when you die you won't exist; A little apartment above a failing laundromat means you have somehow failed, are miserable, and have not experienced life.

Question: How do people stand to live with such a depressing, unnecessary worldview? No wonder people are out of their minds with despair.

Another worldview: A Few Things, Right Here, At this Moment; Universe of reality; One unifying loving purpose; Everything matters; Be humble; Self-respect: We are the crown of creation and made in the image of God; Each new discovery makes us realize how wondrous God's creation is (marvel at the wonders of this vast universe) and how special we are; What matters most is our connection with God and how that allows us to connect with other people; A renewed appreciation for your place in the universe through faith (positive expectation); Appreciate the good moments of your life because they are a foretaste of eternity; A little apartment above a failing laundromat means you have experienced most what if means to be alive and in no way limits your capacity for joy.

In commenting on life and the nature of existence, "It's a Wonderful Life" (1946) does a much better and more life-affirming job. If that is too sweet for you, the on-target satire "Don't Look Up" (2021) achieves a similar but less cynical epiphany than EEAAW, when Dr. Mindy says, "We really did have everything, didn't we? I mean, when you think about it." Well said!

Title: Must watch for parents who feel disconnected from their kids
Review:
Everything everywhere all at once is jaw dropping amazing. It's funny, it's smart and it's emotional. First, the outfits just blew me away. It was all so well done and beautifully made. You had these ridiculous scenes where you're staring at the screen and going 'what the hell is going on??' and then the next minute you're in tears. It's bittersweet. It reminds you that we're all just people on a rock in a large universe trying our best.

I especially loved how different it is than most main stream movies. The main character is a middle aged asian mom who's struggling with her taxes and daughter. She's an immigrant and culture shock still hits her hard 20 years later. Her daughter is gay and rebellious and nothing like she'd ever seen back home.

I highly recommend watching this if you're Asian American as it definitely hits very close to home. I recommend it to parents of LGBTQ+ children who are struggling to understand their kids.

Title: From don t Look up is the best move seen till now
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: I am in the thumbs down brigade.
Review:
I do not need to work this hard.

Firstly; continually switching between English and subtitles is tiresome, and makes it hard to focus on the film.

Some of the situations felt a bit silly.

The rapid switching between scenes is jarring, and there is a general air of incoherence about the whole film; in an irritating way, not one that endears.

Title: Every decision you make can create a different reality!
Review: As the teachings of Albert Einstein show us how we can create our own reality, this movie gives us an amazing insight into the cause and effect our actions can have within our own lives and the entire multiverse. If you've explored the possibility of how every decision we make can take you in a different direction and create an alternate version of yourself, then you'll love it. Michelle Yeoh does an amazing job of playing a stressed out wife running round on the hamster wheel of life barely catching her breath. She is presented with another version of her husband that takes her on a journey of her other selves whilst he teaches her how to switch realities and draw in the gifts and talents from other versions of herself to change the reality she is living. It really is very enlightening! A mix of sci fi, comedy, romance and some great psychological insights as it explores the relationship with her family and how she came to be at the crossroads in her life that wakes her up and explores what's 'out there'. Sometimes it feels completely crackers but I found myself laughing out load and totally aligning with those moments. A treat if you like to stretch your mind and think outside the box!

Title: Action packed every moment.

This movie tells the story of an immigrant couple and their adult first-generation daughter as they navigate the balance between tradition and acceptance, all while dealing with inter-dimensional time travel. There were touching moments, nonsensical moments, happy moments, and moments that made me sad. It was all about growing and letting go of the past. As always A24 does a fantastic job. A.

Title: We ALL Know Why This is Getting Raves
Review:
Hollywood is imploding - their business model of creating good movies to lead viewers to theaters has been crushed and replaced with streaming television.

In their struggle to remain relevant, they have also found that their "old white boy" setup has come under fire. In their quest to reverse that stigma, it has been declared that every film made by, starring, directed by, or produced by minorities MUST be hailed as the next Citizen Kane.

Everything Everywhere All At Once is not Citizen Kane by any stretch of the imagination. It's not the worst movie I have ever seen, but it certainly wasn't deserving of the hype that has been placed upon it. I have little to add to the other reviewers who gave this movie around 3-4 stars, so I'll let those reviews speak for me.

To be honest, I wouldn't care if every single movie nominated for an Academy Award was done by minorities - more power to them, I say. However, race alone should bear no weight in deciding what is considered outstanding. As much as I hate to say it, this is clearly what has happened here.

Three stars for originality, and that's being quite generous.

Everything Everywhere All At Once is a euphoric experience that should not be missed. The morals are clear and so simple that this movie meddles in your mind for a long time. You start to think about what actions could've been taken to make another person feel better.

In conclusion, this movie is a must-watch, surreal experience that will change your perspective on what we call life, and others around us.

10/10.
