Title: One of the most original films of the decade
Review:
I was getting tired of movies trying to be overly serious and intellectual. So when I saw Everything Everywhere All At Once, I was pleasantly surprised to find a film that blended humor, action, love, and insanity in a way that kept me thoroughly entertained.

What sets this movie apart is its unique take on the "parallel universe" genre. While this type of storytelling isn't necessarily new, Everything Everywhere All At Once exemplifies the chaos that it creates in the most captivating way possible. The film's creative use of parallel universes adds a fresh and exciting perspective to the genre, making it stand out from other similar movies.

Another great thing about this film is that it constantly keeps you on the edge with its non-stop action and unexpected twists. At the same time, it manages to seamlessly integrate moments of heartwarming romance and comedy, creating a well-rounded viewing experience.

I'm thrilled that Everything Everywhere All At Once won the Oscar's. This film is a true gem and deserves all the recognition it has received. If you're in the mood for an entertaining and thought-provoking movie that's unlike anything you've seen before, then this is definitely one to watch, if you are over 45 years old then probably you are not going to like it.

Title: Far less than I hoped for
Review:
I went in to watch this film after reading good reviews, apparently it was the film of 2020. It was disappointing, repetitive and felt like another trip down the worn out Marvel lane. I cannot believe it won an Oscar.

Perhaps the acting was good, maybe, I just can't get my head around how disappointed I was in it. I felt like I had seen it all before, which in many ways I had but was told it was original and fun. The dialogue was ridiculous, the plot was all over the show and I need to repeat, how on earth did it win the big prize and the Oscars. It's the first film in my 50 years of watching Oscars I just can't wrap my head around what made it good.

Title: Crazy and wholesome
Review:
Overall great film with beautiful cinematography. Insane special effects and captivating lighting made the film enthralling.

I gave it an 8 for overall delivery, however I have many critiques.

The film went for about an hour too long, lots of repetitive and strung out scenes.

Lots of childish humour that took away from the important emotional scenes.

Too many pop culture references that made the plot almost "silly" for example the bagel concept. Kinda feels like it was written by a grandma who's spent too much time on facebook.

The apparent "life changing" messages the film tried to communicate were very obvious and nothing groundbreaking.

The ending was really nice and pulled everything together. The film was beautifully chaotic, and enjoyable watch, but I don't need to see it again.

Title: Confused halfway, released by the end

Another thing I learn from this film is that we're fluid, it's kind of like the queer theory, you could be any identity if you want. I was stunned especially when I see the two of them become rocks. This is EXACTLY what I want my identity to be in the afterlife, or at least it shows my imagenary self-identity, that I can be EVERYTHING.

Title: Multi-layered experimental piece of art
Review:
As human beings, we are taught that we are the only species with the power of choosing. This movie probes into our very complex feelings. We have multiple layers in our dark side. But only one layer to overshine everything about the darkness. The movie offers a very simple solution to our empirical pains.

It's easy to neglect the ones around us and wish for ideal people to have around to fulfill what we lack. However, it takes a lot of courage and sacrifice to stand up for our loved ones. Optimism, not giving up and living all kinds of feelings, good and bad, in a balance. In the end, it's what we are made of; the good and the evil. As a complex species, we are not entitled to be trapped in small boxes. We all have the capacity to have mutual acceptance, tolerance, and understanding. It just takes a bit of courage to risk it and set a foot forward.

It's a movie anyone would connect to and enjoy. But remember to keep your heart open before entering the theatre salon or pressing the play button.

Title: Multiverse of madness...
Review:
This film is weird, really really weird. At many points it feels like it contains all the ideas from pitch meetings that get thrown out when the boss says 'there are no bad ideas'. Though when most would immediately shoot these down and judge the life of whoever blurted them out, this film uses them in a chaotic, almost beautiful way.

While the concept of a multiverse has been beaten to death a bit recently (particularly with Marvel), this film commits like it had nothing to loose. It explores so many different aspects of multiple realities and existence to the max that it's painful to try to take it all in. It builds and builds and builds into more and more unthinkable scenarios but keeps a personal, meaningful core throughout. Where certain (marvel) movies would keep building the stakes to a destructive cgi monster fight this never looses touch with what story it's actually trying to tell.

This is a remarkable film with a unique take on an idea, incredible visuals, elaborate stunts, perfect performances, and a touching story to follow through.

(You need to be in a very particular mood to really enjoy this film. I wasn't lying about the weirdness but it does have purpose and charm if your up for it. If not maybe try it again another time or look into the work behind it or maybe it's not for you. All good options) :)

Review:

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Incredible

A random bong rip from a gun, random ketchup bottle, then huge dildos used as weapons, and then finally the ridiculous sausage fingers and mustard scene among so much other garbage. Title: Embracing the Eclectic Brilliance of "Everything Everywhere All at Once
Review:
As a movie enthusiast who eagerly explores the vast array of cinematic offerings, it never fails to surprise me when people fail to appreciate a film as magnificent as "Everything Everywhere All at Once." To those who find fault with this extraordinary piece of artistry and fail to grasp its brilliance, I can only assume they either lack the capacity to appreciate true cinematic genius or simply have not encountered a film that has left such an indelible mark on their hearts and minds.

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is an audacious cinematic marvel that defies traditional narrative conventions and immerses viewers in a kaleidoscopic tapestry of emotions, ideas, and visual grandeur. Its unapologetic commitment to pushing boundaries and challenging the norms of storytelling elevates it to a realm of artistic excellence that few films dare to tread.

One cannot begin to dissect the remarkable impact of this film without acknowledging the breathtaking performance of its lead actress. Michelle Yeoh's portrayal of Ma, an ordinary woman thrust into extraordinary circumstances, is an acting tour de force. Her ability to seamlessly transition between multiple dimensions and personas is nothing short of remarkable, displaying a depth and range that is awe-inspiring. Yeoh's captivating presence on screen is alone worth the price of admission.

Furthermore, the film's non-linear narrative structure is a stroke of storytelling genius. It weaves together disparate threads of reality and imagination, blurring the lines between past, present, and future. This nonlinear approach immerses viewers in a mind-bending journey that challenges conventional notions of time and space, inviting us to question the very fabric of our existence.

The visual effects in "Everything Everywhere All at Once" are nothing short of mesmerizing. The seamless integration of practical effects and computer-generated imagery transports the audience to realms of imagination that feel tangibly real. From gravity-defying action sequences to mind-bending cosmic landscapes, the film delivers a visual spectacle that ignites the imagination and leaves a lasting impression.

But perhaps the most profound aspect of this film is its exploration of universal themes. Through the lens of a middle-aged woman thrust into a multiverse of infinite possibilities, the film tackles profound questions about identity, purpose, and the interconnectedness of all things. It serves as a potent reminder that, despite our seemingly ordinary lives, each of us possesses the potential to be a catalyst for change and the hero of our own stories.

To dismiss "Everything Everywhere All at Once" as anything less than a masterpiece would be a disservice to the art of cinema. Its innovative approach to storytelling, remarkable performances, and visual splendor set it apart as a groundbreaking work of art that deserves all the accolades it has received. This film pushes boundaries, challenges perceptions, and expands the horizons of what cinema can achieve.

In conclusion, for those who cannot see the brilliance in "Everything Everywhere All at Once," I implore them to open their minds and embrace the sheer audacity and beauty of this cinematic gem. It is a testament to the boundless creativity of human imagination and a reminder of the transformative power of art. To truly appreciate this film requires an open heart and a willingness to embrace the extraordinary.

The subtle respect for sexual expression is probably necessary considering Chinese culture and family values and my sharing their woes in terms of change in the context of billions of people. Title: Kung Fu Hustle + a Hallmark movie about a frustrated teen finding reconciliation with her parents
Review:
At its core, it's a simple, vague feel-good movie plot with a helluva lot of spectacle thrown on it. That spectacle is some of the most imaginative and wild and entertaining spectacle I've seen in years.

It never reaches the emotional depths or peaks of a similarly surreal dramas (Being John Malkovich, Sorry to Bother You, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind), and it doesn't have enough combat choreography to be what most wushu fans would consider to be a martial arts movie, but it sits nicely in its unique space as a wild and unforgettable movie.

Title: I didn't realise how many things I disliked about this film...
Review:
It's the film version of that 'whacky' cringe-inducing office poster: "You don't have to be crazy to work here, but it helps!" Some personal gripes: The name 'Waymond' which comes over as a 'Chinglish' mispronunciation of Raymond. Why did people not find this offensive?

Michele Yeoh's limited emotional expression, or so it felt to me.

The excessive fight stuff, a lot of it in this film felt so unnecessary, repetitive and boring.

Not an issue for most I guess, but crude body humour is a turn-off for me, it's hard for me to get past my disgust. Don't put things in your arses, people! Modern obsession with sex toys gives me pause. Seems juvenile.

And having considered possible reasons why I disliked the film so much I *takes deep breath* don't think the acting was very good. There was something lacking. Also and I suppose this makes me shallow, but everyone seemed so unattractive, bland at the very least. I expect that was to emphasize that they were 'ordinary people' but being 'ordinary' does not preclude being attractive, and I think you need that element in a feature film.

I don't tend to agree with modern Academy Awards in the main, so I suppose this is just an ongoing example of how out of synch I am with the values of that institution.

Is it nitpicking to assert that a species that evolved with hot dog fingers could never have reached the level of technological civilisation portrayed in that 'skit'?

Ke Huy Quan is no Tony Leung. I got second hand embarassment from that part. Anything attempting to match the subtlety of 'In The Mood' is doomed to be cast as parody, not homage. Films like that should be out of bounds, it's rather arrogant to think you can replicate them in such a superficial way.

Title: One of the main contender for oscars
Review:
What can I say about this movie? Many many....people have already praised enough so I cannot add much more in terms of reviewing the movie. But one things is for sure IMO that no other movie is going to stop this movie from winning at least 3-4.oscars if not more. There is a (strong) possibility James Cameron's Avatar: The Way of Water, if released this year, can beat this movie in the race for Oscars.

Oh, now something about the movie. From 2:03:56 to 2:08:57, movie is laced with such emotions and beautiful scenes that one can't stop crying.

If you cares about your loved ones, see this movie. You will definitely enjoy the journey of the characters involved in complexed relationships. But if you somehow don't believe much in building relationships, then this movie is must watch for you to learn a thing or two about the kindness, love and empathy towards your close ones, loved ones and common persons.

Title: Incredible Journey
Review:
Some of the goofiest visual effects, stuntwork, and storytelling I've ever experienced in a film. I'm loosely reminded of the feeling that I had watching movies like Kung Fu Hustle, Shaolin Soccer, and films of the sort. The direction playfully explores a composition of profound themes while simultaneously cutting the tension with orchestrated silliness and mystery. One moment you're trying to link the narratives together as you're frantically following a chaotic story progression, and immediately after you're holding your sides from laughter. By the end of the movie, you cannot help but appreciate the underlying message being told. I would call this film nothing short of a masterpiece, and you would be doing your friends and family a favor by recommending it.

Title: Omnia Vincit Amor
Review:
So funny, so precise. A perfect mix of everything, everywhere and All at Once. Quirky and yet precise. Kung Fu meets Love Story. Crazy meets perfection.

The actors have really met up to their characters in a way that I haven't seen in a long while. So worth all the Oscars and all the other awards they have been given. If you ask me - a must see. Also to see actors like Ke Huy Quan and Jamie Lee Curtis, childhood stars, on the screen again - making such a fantastic appearance makes me smile. Best movie, best film, best story in like a very, very LONG time!

Thank you, please make more movies like this. It will make the world a better place,

Peace!

Title: speachless
Review:
This movie came out a few months ago, but i only had the time to watch now and damn! Did i lose quite a experience.

The cinematography, choreography and the writing in general is top-notch.

A movie made by quite a small cry with an even smaller budget, but it manages to surprise you with the quality of itself!

The history is fantastic and the imagery very trippy! Funny when it has to be then suddenly serious all over. It makes you cry at the end with tears of joy and sadness altogether. Just seeing Evelyn and Joy fight the whole movie while feeling bad for everyone especially Waymond, i just can't describe everything i felt.

10/10 movie for me, might not be for you, but an amazing movie nonetheless. Best of 2022.

Title: What a bore
Review:

How anyone gave this more than two stars - how I managed to sit through the whole thing - I'll never understand.

Also it's completely unfunny despite the desperate, relentless attempts at humour almost all the way through. Seriously tedious. Watch at your own peril.

Title: Original, funny and clever
Review:
In a raft of franchise films and formula moving designed for a focus group this stands out as one or the weirdest, cleverest, funniest films I have seen in long time.

Not saying it's always easy, but that's because it does follow the pack.

The effort and detail that goes in is staggering for something (I'm guessing) without a massive budget. Some scenes probably 1/10 second long with intricate detail, some great gags, funny, sad exciting

Not often an emotional scene with stones in a film, or the answer to a long standing philosophical question, or understanding of the potential violent uses of office equipment

Loved it.

Title: Probably the best movie I've ever seen
Review:
The visuals in this movie took my breath away, with every scene having dynamic lighting and the costumes were just fantastic. The sound effects were creative and added to the immersion, and the score was beautiful.

This movie was also the funniest I've ever seen. I had tears running down my face for the entire first half, although the second half was a bit more serious. The plot was easy to follow yet engaging, and told a beautiful messages of life without regrets, love, forgiveness, communication, etc.

This movie was beyond enjoyable, and there wasn't a single moment I was bored or confused. Although I've read some contradictory reviews, I think Everything Everywhere All at Once was cinematic perfection and I would watch it a thousand times over. I highly recommend this movie to everybody everywhere :)

Edit: since writing this Ive watched it three more times and my opinion remains unchanged.

The editing was extraordinary, as well as the acting and soundtrack. Daniels did such a great job with the script and symbolism and the whole cast was phenomenal! Michelle Yeoh was outstanding! Go watch it now! It's one of the films you can't stop thinking about or talking about when you leave the theater... it's THAT good. It's Oscar worthy for so many categories and it's bonkers, but when you watch it a second time, it will capture your heart even more. Be kind and love one another because we don't know what is going on sometimes.

Title: Original, witty, funny and a roller coaster of a ride.
Review:
Clever idea with a unique interpretation of the multiverse that dwelled into human goals, tribulations, failures, second chances and many others including what could have been etc. Highly entertaining and it did create some confusion of the various dimensions and timing but you get it the jest of it after a while. Title: A bad dream
Review:
Though the production value was high and the acting and choreography was quality, the movie as a whole left me, by the 45 minute mark, wanting to shut it off. It felt like a really bad dream that you wanted to stop and forget. The plot's flavor got lost in the seasonings and I just wanted to spit it out. There were some charming parts at the beginning and I did get a chuckle, but when the sci-fi kicked in it became redundant and ridiculous. My daughter left the room 70 minutes in and I stayed with the hope that it would get better. It got worse. Though there was redemption at the end, again, it got lost in the chaos.

Title: Amazing movie!
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Dr.Strange, Fun, Abstract, Action, Schwarzschild radius and Empathy
Review:
EEAAO, From funny moment to badass action to heartbreaking moment each and every moment perfectly grasped the gist of entire story.

Michelle Yeoh & Stephanie Hsu was absolutely phenomenal in thus movie, probably the best acting performance in her career.

Team of five people to complete 500 visual effects.

Cinematography and Editing is fantastic, stitching the scenes perfectly, no bland shots. The action is innovative and fun. Music score helps convey internal emotion

Master minds of the Daniel's (Directors Daniel Kwan & Scheinert).

Special mention to Raccacoonie, Rocks, Pinky Finger, Googly eyes, Bagel, and Hot dog.

Title: An unique experience
Review:
If you want to watch this movie, you have to grab all the movies, cartoons, or whatever you ever saw in your life, and put it aside. Because this film is different from all of them.

I discovered it through social media and when I saw the trailer, I choose to give it a try. Honestly, I was expecting the usual plot: great evil, wants to destroy the multiverse, then there's the hero and blah blah blah. And you know what? That's what I kinda saw. But the way this story was narrated, showed, expressed... I was not ready. During the 2 hours of this movie I laughed, I cried, I felt enthusiastic and so on: everything mixed together.

I was so happy after finishing the movie, finally something that was different, that doesn't copy and paste the main plot and just changes some details but that changes everything and create something else, that doesn't follow the mass: that it's special is own way.

This isn't a story about Evelyn saving everyone, is a story of acceptance, personal growth, regrets, success, mistakes, obstacles and most importantly love.

It makes you learn to cherish what you have, be happy about who you are, to learn from experience and to just live the life, because the truth it's that we're just little and insignificant compared to everything else.

Also I think that the technical part was so good, the music, scenography, acting, costumes, lights: all of those were *chef kiss*

So yeah, I really recommend spending 2 hours of your so insignificant life and just... enjoy everything about it, everywhere you want and maybe with all your friends all at once?

Title: One of the best films I've ever seen!
Review:

Title: quantum mechanics meets sausage fingers!
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All At Once" tells the story of a insecure mother who looks down on her husband and considers him useless, while constantly trying to make her father proud and prove herself to him. She has a strained relationship with her daughter who is on the brink of suicide. The movie explores these relationships through multiple universes and the absurdities that come with them.

While all these bonkers can make it difficult for some viewers to watch and follow, it is a wonderful film that questions what success means in life and even delves into the meaning (or meaninglessness) of life itself. It shows us that happiness can sometimes be found in the small, boring and even mundane things in our lives.

For those who are not familiar with comedy-action films like "Kung Fu Hustle," the bizarre elements such as sausage fingers, police officers jumping on dildos, and talking rocks may be too much to handle, and may even leave viewers wondering, "What am I watching now?" But if you can see past the absurdities, you will find a beautiful movie that can make even those who do not typically enjoy Far East films contemplate philosophy.

As someone interested in theoretical physics, I also appreciated the references to quantum mechanics and wave functions when explaining multiple universes. The screenwriters and directors did an excellent job in crafting this film.

In short, "Everything Everywhere All At Once" may be weird, but it is definitely enjoyable.

Title: Diaper Deposit
Review:
Once upon a time in Hollywood, a screenwriter had a role to play in crafting a feature film. But screenwriters have been replaced by "special effects" and "visual effects" personnel. Here, instead of looking at a picture, we're offered a kaleidoscope. In this age of disorder and decay, a potpourri of fractured imagery is offered for the audience's delectation. In the minds of the filmmakers, some sort of story with some sort of theme is being suggested for the cognoscenti. It is the obligation of the non-judgmental public to put it all together, to craft some sort of coherence out of the visual jigsaw puzzle. Well, I, for one, require payment for my work. On TV, there are plenty of good movies to enjoy again....

Title: This movie is for everyone to watch. The message is live our life with love, compassion, understanding, kindness, forgiveness, peace, harmony and joy!
Review:
This movie is not really just about one particular person story.

It is the story of everyone.

The message is that we are our own hero, savor, healer.

And the fighting or battle is not about kill the bad guys, as no such thing as bad guys or evil, devil or monster.

It is about fighting to the darkness or negative energy within ourselves, which we have mistakenly absorbed from this 3D world.

And I love the end solution. It is a very profound wisdom. Learn to understand ourselves and others, instead of criticise or judging others and ourselves. We need to relax, live simple as we can and enjoy life.

I am 62 and watched this with my 29 year old son. We both loved the movie, but he loved it more. It is a visual feast and, without being too heavy handed, it has a really great message.

Title: Everything I wanted, Everywhere in this movie, more or less all at once.
Review:
One of my patreon subscribers hipped me to this last week and last night I saw it. Absolutely f'ing loved it. Talk about a movie that has everything - an emotional core, something to say, comedy, action, pathos, lots of solid performances with great acting, and yes, it's close enough to how the omniverse in Splinters is laid out to be kissing cousins.

Clocks in at about two hours, the violence is never gratuitous, there is no hate speech or harsh language, though it is quite INTENSE in places. Pacing wise not nec. A movie suitable for many children but some will get a lot more out of it than others.

Four out of Four Stars, Gwen D. Says Check It Out if you haven't seen it.

Title: Love everything about it
Review:
The film is great. The visuals, the acting, the OST, the atmosphere, the uniqueness (god, the humour), the morals, the symbolism, and the everything about it is a gift from the creative minds to the world.

Some people may find it as a 0/10. But I love everything about it, personally. From the crowded atmostphere of repsonsiblites to the morals (don't wanna spoil anything here). It got me emotional there ha ha. It's actually rare for me to get emotional from a product made by any entertainment industries.

I love it so much that I made myself am IMDB account to write this review.

After I watched the film, I felt like I'm back being a kid after watching a great film from a cinema. It's so original! I haven't felt like this for years now (not many. I'm still a teen hehe) and I didn't even watch this film in a fancy ancy cinema. It really got me hooked. Yeah, I found it 'that' (in italic) great.

10/10, but not for everyone.

Title: Nothing Nowhere None at once
Review:
It's a conspiracy.

Hollywood and the critics have placed a bet.

Let's give 7 Oscars to a totally absurd movie and check how the brainwashed audience will react.

Will they go to see the movie?

Will they share the excitement?

Guess what. It worked...

Can't remember the last time I've seen such a terrible movie. The flow, the characters, the scenario.

Omg.

It hurts.

Don't waste your time with that movie. You're better off watching a black screen instead.

P. S.: once upon a time movies like The Godfather were winning the best movie award. Now we have Everything Everywhere all at once. As sad as it gets.

Title: Truly Everything Everywhere All At Once
Review:
This movie is truly an immersive experience where you follow the main character Evelyn played by an excellent Michelle Yeoh through the multiverse to defeat an unknown force. This movie skillfully utilises symbolism and humour to address themes of nihilism, sacrifice, depression and intergenerational trauma. Uniquely, this film could also be titled Truly All Genres All At Once as it incorporates comedy, drama and action into its core identify as a sci-fi film. There is bound to be many laugh out loud moment as well as many moments of introspections which makes it a cognitive experience as well.

Adding to a mind blowing plot, is the artful directing, sound score and costume design which adds vibrancy to the message being conveyed. This aspect of the film truly makes it a sensory experience. Your brain will undoubtedly be stimulated.

Overall verdict: a cinematic experience once must experience in the cinemas. This will undoubtedly one of the front runners for Best Picture.

Title: Mesmerizing - Covid-19 dose
Review:
You can link this movie with everything everywhere, all at once. This movie has all the ingredients for almost everyone. And has lot of life lessons as well. We can relate it to the Covid-19 as well.

Title: The most beautiful mess
Review:
An incredible film that touches you profoundly, but also has a way to entertain you by introducing so much novelty and dynamic energy. The movie brings so much freshness to the screens and leaves you feeling like everything is possible.

A powerful message of healing family trauma and realizing that truths coexist: everything matters and nothing really matters at the same time.

As the movie starts, it feels like it's gonna be like every other Sci-Fi movie you've ever seen, but do not be mistaken. You are bound to be taken on a journey that you don't know how it will end.

What EEAAO manages to do different than other Sci-Fi movies and also the reason why it replays in your brain long after you're out of the theatre, is because it manages to play with your emotions and reflect deeply about your life. Are we living out our highest timeline? Who knows. At the end, we see that even what we think is a merely boring life could have so many silver linings.

This was by far one of my Top 5 favorite movies. Thank you to the Daniels and the incredible crew for your great work!

Title: Greatest use of multiverses
Review:
Very good film, fast pace maybe sometimes too fast for my taste, but nevertheless very interesting concept and in my opinion the best use of the multiverses as it tries to use its full potential. Funny, adventurous and meaningful. Definately, you will miss a lot if you don't watch it.

Title: I love this movie here is why
Review:
This movie was genuinely enjoyable, it was strange yes but that is my style for the most part. This movie is full of overloaded scenes and can make you feel overwhelmed at some points but this adds a lot to the storytelling and gives you a closer connection to the characters.

I love this movie for all of its metaphors and symbolisms, when you look past all of the big in your face stuff the story and meaning is actually quite simple and I think a lot of people overlook that fact.

The acting was phenomenal as well as the rest of the elements of the movie like costume and cinematography, so 7 Oscars wasn't surprising to me, i think this movie was amazing and it lives up to the hype. Which is why I am confused as to why it only got 7.3/10 this movie deserves at least a 9.

I recommend you watch this movie.

Title: Thought it was a Dr Strange knock off but totally different.
Review:
I just watched a movie wondering what it would be about, but was not only, funny, action pack, insightful and beautifully filmed and acted. The underlying story is one of the best examples of this kind of movie I have seen. Worth a watch with a family member or bestie that you love and care for warning at some point in writing the script I believe drugs could have been involved.

Will have to go back and watch it again as I suspect there will be many Easter eggs that I missed first time around.

The acting is really good especially the range that the actors have to express throughout the storyline.

Title: Pure Creative Genius
Review:
What an absolute masterpiece. Brilliant creative genius. No words can describe it. All Dharma Realms = Mind = All beings. Grandpa is the traditional value and hierarchy. It's judgmental and impossible to please. Daughter is rebellion against the hierarchy and find liberation in emptiness/nihilism. Father is trying to please everyone, suppress himself to take care others first as a way to cope. Mother realized the middle way. Letting go and embrace are the same thing. Suffering and happiness are the same. Everything and everywhere, we are all in it together.

Title: This movie is equivalent of the emperor's new clothes
Review:
Because inside Hollywood is saying this movie is "genius", no one inside Hollywood wants to admit it may be the worse film ever made for fear of looking stupid. But I got it - millions of parallel universes where so many possible outcomes exist and where kindness wins out over evil. But it was so over the top bizarre just for bizarre sake, an endless string of boring fight scenes, tediously dragged on for about 2 hours too long, and a total waste of good actors, it is 2 hours I will never get back. How could this win so many awards? I think the academy has gone insane Or this was a big joke. I feel betrayed. Don't waste your time.

Title: Absolutely worth it, the story is a maximalistic dive into something beautiful
Review:
No, this movie doesn't have a multiverse just for the sake of it. On paper this story is overcomplicated and convoluted but the beautiful part is the movie, the visuals guide you completely in roughly 2 and a half hours. If you gave someone inexperienced the task to produce the same story it would be a 4 hour boring mess. The risks Daniels took on this movie is way too underappreciated. The non linear storyline, multiple plot lines merging as one, the hidden symbolism in the first act and which is later displayed in a whole lotta multiverse action is well done.

What really sticks out is the acting. The emotions this cast shows is hard to connect with, as it's just an average chinese family with unrelatable middle aged evelyn, her husband, her father and queer daughter but somehow they capture emotions enough to make it relatable

I think the multiverse concept really helps explore the mind boggling nature of human conflict, love and confusion. There's so much that goes on in ones mind when you fall in problems with your loved ones. Even how the story explores non-openmindedness should be studied. Even the humor in this movie is ON POINT.

If you're a big fan of acid trip esque adventure movies trust this one, its captured all essence of it. Only flaw possibly is that you need to be willing to appreciate before criticize. This might be messy, but its the good type of messy.

Title: Heartfelt, funny, fantastical and relatable.
Review:
The base storyline takes a mundane life, and weaves it into this wonderful, fantastical multiverse.

I laughed so many times throughout, and also cried at the incredibly human moments that are also there in bounds.

Title: Where to begin?
Review:
I didn't quite know what I was getting myself into. I've been waiting to watch this until it hit streaming for free cause I'm frugal, but my god, it was worth the wait! I'll save you all the existential hullabaloo and just tell you this. This movie is something like you've NEVER seen before. At the very center of this acid trip is a story about us. About you. We're all struggling every day to figure out this crazy thing called life. We'll never figure that out completely, but what we will do is continue making masterpieces of film like this one to cope with how it's going. I'm going to rewatch this one a handful of hot dog fingered times.

Title: I don't normally review movies
Review:
But I had to say something about this one. I feel like I've watched something special. I just left the cinema 2 hours ago, and it hasn't really set in yet. But I feel like this has the potential to become a true classic of the modern times. It's the sort of movie, that I can't imagine anyone not at least finding some sort of resonance with. The message it contains is universal and the way it delivers it is truly original and even somewhat unique. It operates under the modus of "more is more" and that might be the only reason that I wouldn't give this movie a 10 out of 10.

At the same time, if it wasn't for the willingness of the writers to explore every possible idea they (and their team I presume...) could come up with, the movie wouldn't be what it is - and in some weird way I wouldn't want it to be perfect anyway - the overwhelmed feeling that I'm left with now, is part of what makes the movie such a masterpiece. And, maybe one day, when I've rewatched this a handful of times, I'll come back and bump my review up to a ten.

Title: More A Work Of Art Than A Movie
Review:
The first time I saw this masterpiece, I was cross and upset. I wanted to ENJOY it - but I tried too hard to UNDERSTAND it.

I was left wanting to feel more. You can't go in to it with any specific expectations in your mind as it is truly an unrelenting stream of thought and ideas that don't really seem fit for existence.

The whole piece feels like a joke - but one that was excellently carried out.

The second time I experienced it, a whole new story arose. I relaxed and let myself feel the art. I don't believe there is a better thing out there.

I would 100% recommend to anybody who wants to discover a completely different genre of film.

Title: Spectacular, Magical, Unique
Review:
I have never felt anything like this in a cinema. It started off slow and I had a hard time getting the hang of it, but the last hour is so good... I went to see it with friends and we usually comment on some things during the movie, but this time we were quiet, without moving, absorbed in the screen trying to assimilate what we were seeing and enjoying every second.

It may not be for everyone, it certainly is nothing like the rest of the films that usually come out in theaters. But in this era of reboots and remakes, original ideas like this are always welcome. I hope to feel something like that again in future films, I need it.

100% recommended.

Title: I love this movie

Title: More Madness than the Multiverse of Madness!
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Collective Consciousness
Review:
This film is extraordinary in every way. The creativity of the Daniels in this storytelling of the multiverse. It blows my mind. I felt the whole spectrum of emotions from this film. The family dynamic, asian culture dynamic, sexuality, and the action? Yas.

I feel very connected to the universe when I watch things that highlight such human experiences. The what ifs, the butterfly effect, timeline jumping. I've always been a Michelle Yeoh fan and grew up watching her films. Her performance was absolutely outstanding. The entire ensemble were captivating in their characters. Just a beautiful work of art.

Title: Didn't get it.
Review:
I watch and enjoy enough deep or artistic movies. Hell, I studied film and media for years so I've been exposed to the strangest things ever produced.

I decided to watch this based purely on the amount of positive reviews it was getting but I just don't get it. You know those paintings that people say are masterpieces and then you see it and it looks like something a child made? This is how I feel about this movie. Seems like it's just weird for the sake of being weird and it's getting a lot of extra credit for being quite unique. The comedy was either crude or childish so that didn't do much for me either.

I'll give a middle rating purely because you've probably never seen anything like this before. Loads of people love it so you might too. Either way, you're going to experience something different for a change.

Title: Absolutely loved it!!!
Review:
"Every rejection, every disappointment has led you here to this moment."

There comes a time in life you think about the Shoudda,Coudda, Woulddas... But what if we can be content with the life we have? The thoughts of the countless other lives we might have led, had we made different decisions along the way... But what if you see that the flipside to life being meaningless is in fact the freedom that comes from the fact that you can do anything and that you did your best with the time you've got???

This film is a crazy ride... I laughed, I screamed WTF several times, I cried; oh boy I cried... I absolutely loved it...

By the end I saw my nervous anxiety ridden self with all my quirks and strengths and understood that all decisions good and bad I've made in life have brought me here and its exactly where I need to be.

Title: Nothing Nowhere Oh Good God
Review:

Annoying to watch, but let's give it a Best Picture. The deluded Academy that gives this award is embarrassing. I can only hope they're selling themselves out for a shot to work on next year's Best Crap Picture. I liked Jaime Lee though. After multiple Halloweening, she at least thru in an acting twist.

Title: Beautiful! One fir Rick and Morty Fans
Review:
Multiverse is very on trend at the minute, but where Dr Strange was lacking, this made up for it.

Where science and philosophy let your mind wander in and beyond the 'What If's.....

Yes, its not a new concept, but it was just mental, and so much fun to watch (and feel).

Title: I still didn't really know what that movie was but I'm sure of one thing, it was amazing
Review: I went to see this movie because a friend of mine told me it looked fun. Before I went to the cinema, I knew nothing about the film, neither the genre nor the directors. When the movie ended, I still didn't really know what it was but I was sure of one thing, it was amazing. The more I think about it, the more I realize that this film has no real flaw. The action scenes are very beautiful and we feel all the love of the directors for the films of Bruce Lee and Jackie Chan. The editing is very fluid and pleasant. The film is well rhythmic, you never get bored. The writing is as touching as it is funny. This film is really impressive, it surprises us every second. You never really know what you're watching, you alternate between sf and family drama. This film is really a new breath in the current film industry, an author's blockbuster that never suffers from its low budget and that could become for the next generation of filmmakers a revolutionary film as was the first Matrix (whose film is a bit inspired ) by its positivity, its universal message, and its cinematic qualities.

Title: A fun if formulaic take on identity and "what if"?!
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

Title: Incredibly Emotional and Life-Affirming
Review: This movie blends concepts and certain stylistic elements from The Matrix (though it is tonally and thematically very different) with the kind of absurd humor you'd find in something like Kung Fury (though without quite as much self-aware tropeyness). This movie genuinely surprised me; I don't typically think of comedies as great media, especially not comedic movies, but this movie is so emotionally resonant while also being funny that I cannot but give it a 10. To be clear, this movie is not perfect. It's not particularly deep, intellectual or cerebral. Though its first part, Everything, is funny, the movie takes its time getting to its absolute highest. The comedy doesn't always hit, particularly some of the sexual humor or scenes where the protagonist pees herself or inhales a fly. It's not particularly hard to find a few holes in the movie's logic. To my mind, however, none of that detracts from how great this movie is. This movie is raw emotion, and if you've experienced the emotions it puts on display, I think you can get something out of it. Its representation of an American immigrant family might get nods or smiles from those who come from such a background, and its almost psychedelic representation of what it's like to feel overwhelmed by life can speak powerfully to those who've felt that way. Combine that with comedy that, to me at least, hits far harder than it misses and even plays into the more poignant aspects of the story, genuinely good action, and beautiful, surreal visuals, and you get, without exaggeration, the best movie I've ever seen. This movie looks at life in all its insanity, suffering, tedium, and regrets and says yes. And that, I think, is something a lot of people can get value out of.

Title: When you try so hard to be original
Review:
My experience was going from "what's going on" and the occasional giggle, to "ok that's a cool idea" to i can't stand this anymore.

It's an unnecessarily overly complex movie to convey a very simple idea. I get the appeal of the stylistic choices and the creativity involved, but it's not my cup of tea. It looks good and promising on the first 30 minutes, but after that it's actually more and more painful to watch and not funny anymore.

Speaking about the creativity, i never thought I'd say this ever, but it's too much. Just too silly, too ridiculous and off putting. Like the people behind it did everything they could to do something they deem "original", very forcefully, in a very unnatural way.

In a way, it kind of reminds me of Tenet by Christopher Nolan, which was much better than this one, but still has that extra degree of complexity just for the sake of trying to be original. It doesn't work in that film either. A good example where this was done flawlessly is The Matrix.

I'd say this movie is the representation of the exact theme the movie tries to present a solution to, Nihilism. The world is so devoid of values, people are so confused, original work and ideas are thrown out the window in Hollywood in favour of money-making dumbed down movies, they don't know what else to make to be original, the desperation is very clear when they awarded this the Oscar for best picture.

I will never forget this movie, but will try to, and will never revisit it again. Not worth the watch not even to satisfy curiosity. Skip it entirely.

Title: Insanely inventive
Review:
The less you know going into this movie, the better. Full stop. Do not read reviews. Do not let people tell you about it. Just go and see it with an open mind. It will start with you wondering whether you're watching a family drama, but buckle in. You're in for a ride. It's clever, emotional, hysterical, thoughtful and you walk out elated and happy you saw the movie. It's deep, if you want it to be, and fun regardless. Ambitious as heck, it successful pulls off its ambitions and joins my top ten list movies that i have enjoyed of all time, and i have conservatively seen 5000 movies. And if you don't like it? Too much for you? Well, at least you saw it and now have an opinion.

Title: A Horrible Waste of Time
Review:
Months ago, I fell asleep during "Everything, Everywhere All At Once," finding it horrible, but after it won so many awards, including the Best Picture Oscar and three acting awards, plus writing and direction, I thought that perhaps I was too tired originally and decided this evening to give it another chance.

I fell asleep twice, rewound the DVD to where I'd conked out and essentially forced myself to sit through one of the worst, if not pointless, movies I have ever seen in my life.

Visually, it's intriguing, though it gets to a point where the countless and tiresome cuts all over the place become increasingly dreary. It's like the filmmakers had visual computer film toys which, due to their expense, they were insistent upon using

I cannot understand its presumed esteem and perhaps what I might have missed, though I cannot believe there are not many others who feel likewise. What a waste of over two hours of my life!

Review:
Emotionally packed movie carrying more than one message, from mastering an existential crisis over realising which people matter most in your life, to being more open and/or tolerant to a different sexual orientation. But most of all, nothing really matters . . .

Title: Evelyn & Sisyphus
Review:
As a film entirely devoted to Albert Camus, it impressed me a lot. It seems to have been the philosophical reflection of the books 'The Stranger' and 'The Myth of Sisyphus'. If you are interested in the philosophy of existentialism, it will make you think a lot. The main theme is based on the problematic of whether life is worth living or not. Of course, since this is a very heavy and depressing subject, they decorated the movie with absurdly funny scenes and good enough fight scenes. If they had not done this, they would have dragged the audience into that 'Black Hole'. In short, the score in your head is constantly changing from 1 to 10 in every minute of this two-hour movie, until you end up feeling bored and sometimes stunned. The acting, visual effects, music are very good, I can say that it is the unexpected movie of the year.

Albert Camus' book 'The Myth of Sisyphus' begins with this sentence; "There is only one philosophical problem that really matters, suicide. To judge whether life is worth living is to answer the fundamental question of philosophy." Here is the 'Jobu Tupaki' character, after all the endless lives she has experienced in the parallel universe; She decides that the truth, the meaning of life, is nothing. She also wants to share this nothingness with her mother 'Evelyn Wang'. Her mother's experience of all these other lifetimes by following her daughter and eventually turning into stone and then rolling off the mountainside turns into a life's unchanging cycle of hope and frustration. The punishment given to Sisyphus by the gods, the burden he will carry forever, is just that. In the end, Evelyn decides that instead of getting rid of this burden placed on everyone, she should accept it and just be 'kind' in life. This is how she fights her daughter's thoughts. Your goals, your desires, everything we do may be empty and meaningless, nowhere to be found. What matters is the path itself and with whom you share it. Therefore, Sisyphus and Evelyn can find happiness in every collapse and disappointment, and such happy people spread happiness around them.

Title: A Poignant Portrail of an Inperfect family
Review:
Love can be fought for, spoken, shown in gesture, or action.

One of the first things that came across onscreen was the love language of each character and how they operated within their world. People can be flawed and hateful, but still care for the ones they cherish. The world can come crashing down an yet you can look to that one person to hope and shield.

This was evident and why i was in tears for nearly the whole movie. The "Daniels" were able to weave a thoughtful sentiment into a chaotic world bending narrative that came alive for each and every viewer. If there was a movie going experience that truly showed the capability to impact, This was it.

"Of all the places i could be, I just want to be here with you."

Title: Topic and LGBTQ+
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: The most touching movie for me since the Matrix.
Review:
There are so many excellent movies, depending on one's taste, it is hard to say which one is better than one another. But among the best movies, there are ones that inspire a whole genre and a generation.

For me, the matrix is that kind of movie. Within which there is a fascinating, realistic world with its unique physics laws, culture, hierarchy, and characters. And the creators are at their premiere era of creation, and ideas are so overflowing that they try hard to push them into their works like cramping a feast into a tightening tin can. And when you open it, it just blows everything right in your face. Compared to Avatar, another one of my favorites, Avatar is the feast, much more mature, presented to you in a Michelin dining room, and you're well-acquainted that it must be dame good before tasting, without some specific feeling of surprise.

I don't need to comment on the details or philosophy of the movie. There are tons of them. Instead, I want to express that you have to watch it and break your mind. It should be a movie you need to watch in your lifetime. PS, any rating less than 8/10 is not fair.

Title: Currently questioning my existence
Review:
Some of the best visuals I've ever seen. Acting was pretty phenomenal as well. I think this is a movie everyone should see.

Every action I take leads to a different possibility, this review I'm writing is creating an entirely different present to if I were to do something else. Just a thought that this film provoked for me.

I think it'll stick with me for a long while, ya know life really aint that deep, everyone else is living their own different reality right at this moment, all that shi.

Title: Unwatchable, hyperactive nonsense...
Review:
...and the usual over-exaggerated ratings that paint it as a work of genius!

I like honest reviews, they're helpful in deciding what to watch.

The problem with dishonest reviews is they make people more cautious about watching new things and - in the end - producers & the industry itself will be less inclined to fund potential new things.

That being said:

This was not very entertaining, it was quite annoying.

The slow, unnecessarily long scenes that tried to put an artsy edge to the movie just came across as tedious and over-cooked.

If the first 30 minutes don't give the viewer some interest or curiosity about watching the rest then you've failed as a big budget film maker.

I give it a 4 for effort, but my true feeling is probably negative 4 just because of the hype and lies surrounding it.

Title: Watch this movie immediately
Review:
This is single handedly the best movie I've ever watched. If you want to experience every possible emotion all while being absorbed in amazing visuals and incredible acting performances then this is the movie for you. I have thought about it everyday since watching it and have recommended/required everyone I know to watch it:). The movie encompasses multiple significant and relavent topics while still finding space for humour and action. If there were ever a movie I wished I could see for the first time again it would be this one. Everything, Everywhere, All at Once is incomparable to any other film.

Title: A beautiful, wonderful, and meaningul chaos
Review:
If you are tired of films speaking about the importance of love, kindness and family, go watch this film, it's all about that. But better.

This film is the perfect balance between action, sci-fi, auteur and so many other genres. You never expect what is coming next. You sometimes laugh or cry, and you often do both.

I still cannot describe how this film made me feel, and how (almost) perfect it is. Not one second did I get bored. And the most surprising for a 2022 movie for me : I can't stop thinking about it.

The editing, the lights, the acting, the camera movements, the music, the sound, and so many more things are simply beautifully mixed together in wonderful, meaningful chaos.

I could talk about this film in more details, and for way too long, but I'll stop here and tell you something everybody must have told you : go watch it, immediately.

Title: An excellent ride throughout. Just go ahead & watch!
Review:
The film starts so simple & gets to open up in many layers after the first 15 minutes. It starts your ride with the concept of multiverse which is Sci-Fi later turn into action & ends on an emotional note.

The film is a complete package of "everything" spread out "everywhere" "all at once" in a single film. I felt I had watched something so good at the end of the film. The performances of the leads, especially Michelle Yeoh as 'Evelyn', Stephanie Hsu as 'Joy' & Kay Huy Quan as 'Waymond' were extraordinary! Kay Huy's variations in his performance totally grabbed my eyes onto him. It was a delight watching his performance.

No words to say about the technical department. Just hands down for the output.

Title: Interesting but complex movie
Review:
Not since Inside John Malkovich has a movie had so many threads that come together by the end of the movie. The movie had so many transitions and with each transition a new story involves the main characters. But yet by the end of the movie, all of these transitions come together and proclaim a simple lesson about family and acceptance of one another. Excellent acting and definitely one of the best movies of 2022.

Definitely a contender for Best Picture. A definite reminder of Terry Gilliam's Brazil and a very creative experience of movie making. Do not try to analyze it just sit back and enjoy the creative experience.

Title: Beautiful written, touching and hilarious
Review:
I went into this movie not expecting more than a small little movie that i will watch once and forget about in a day, i can confidently say that i was hugely mistaken this movie was so captivating that its 2 hour 19 minute run-time felt like only 30 minutes. It is beautiful in so many ways to avoid spoilers one of the characters constant outfit changes was so creative, Michelle Yeoh is fantastic as the protagonist, ke huy quan was perfect at changing his voice and mannerisms to match his personality, oh and his moment at the end really was so well done and touching. This movie was also hilarious (Jamie Lee Curtis adds a lot of humor) i loved the comedy style and its wacky shenanigans ( For context i am 12 ). So overall i think this movie easily gets a 9 out of 10, any doubts you have about this movie should be cleared go watch it now.

Title: Quantum Entanglement simplified
Review: "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a visually captivating and intellectually stimulating film. The film's nonlinear storytelling may prove challenging for some viewers, as it constantly shifts between different timelines and realities. However, this approach adds depth and intrigue to the narrative, allowing audiences to piece together the puzzle and contemplate the underlying themes. Its complex narrative and abstract concepts require an open mind and a willingness to embrace ambiguity. Some viewers might find the film's philosophical and metaphysical elements overwhelming or hard to grasp. With its stellar performances from Stephanie Hsu, Ke Huy Quan, Jamie Lee Curtis and with thought-provoking themes, this film offers a cinematic experience that challenges our understanding of reality and the interconnectedness of the universe. Michelle Yeoh is outstanding and truly deserves the academy award for best actress. A path breaking effort from writer-directors duo Daniel Kwan& Daniel Scheinert to offer a scientific theme to a captivating metaphor of interconnectedness, destiny, and the infinite possibilities that exist in the fabric of reality. The movie is a daring exploration of quantum entanglement that pushes the boundaries of traditional storytelling.

Title: Beautiful Madness
Review:
Incredible film-making and storytelling without the crutch of a domineering plot. Gets to the heart of the human condition through its characters... our passions, our fears, our heartaches and our joys. A beautiful work of art infused with the thrilling madness of our world.

Loved seeing it at Alamo Drafthouse for interviews with the indomitable, incomparable Michelle Yeoh and some pretty awesome Daniels.

Title: This movie is life
Review:
Perhaps this movie beats all my favorites like the Matrix or Limitless.

The movie is about every stage of life and how to deal with it. It goes deep into human nature and figures out that ultimately, there is no "trick" to enlightenment, but it's all the things in your life being in tune with each other.

The whole idea of this movie essentially is to create a vibe that comes as close as possible to sense perception and the potentially extreme chaos implied by that. Life is absolutely chaotic, it is extremely hard to solve if we get engaged with the logic of our environment. The environment can potentially be hell and the mind will run away from it. Evelyn is the personification of exactly that, she runs away from the immanent facts that actually rule her life and she gets very upset whenever anyone tries to show her the vastness of reality. Having done LSD, this reminded me of certain stages during the life altering experience during the trip. It's a memory that returns periodically.

Obviously the movie can have any effect on anyone, it's like drugs. Whatever you want from the drug you can achieve, if it's just fun or wisdom. There can never be consensus of things like this, it's like life itself.

Title: A chaotic but still coherent journey
Review:
I had not heard of this film nor seen a trailer and while browsing the new released films on TV, I found the title and the cover extremely appealing. So I just blindly started the movie.

And oh boy, I was in for a treat.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is an original, funny, but also moving film with an impactful message. It's been a long time since I've seen a movie so brilliant with such amazing concepts and ideas. Everything Everywhere All At Once is a chaotic but still coherent journey. It's a metaverse that tells the essence of human relationships through many different film genres, connected in unique and spectacular ways.

Every formal aspect, from the direction to the editing to the fight choreography, is meticulously executed as well as functional in holding together and developing neatly a complex plot.

I also cannot stress enough how much the duality of a simple phrase like "Nothing matters" touched me personally.

I highly recommend it.

Title: Blown Away
Review:
Just a completely unique movie experience I'll be thinking about for years to come. The acting was amazing-Michelle Yeoh especially of course, but I also thought Jamie Lee Curtis, Ke Huy Quan and Stephanie Hsu gave layered, incredible performances. I was constantly impressed by the costuming and makeup; every outfit Jobu Tupaki put together had SO much detail and care. The score was powerful, and did a great job of adding to the film without overpowering it. I loved to see this core story of a mother and daughter at the center of an epic sci-fi with such well-done world building. Plus the sense of humor scattered throughout heavy moments was consistently unexpected and delightful. Overall, a film entirely worth watching.

Title: I love this movie, and the lesson it teaches.
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once.... What can I say?

This movie is an amazing movie, it goes deep into topics such as Existential Crisis, Depression, and about life in general. I am a teenager who has yet to experience a life of my own, cooped up in my parents home.

However, this movie pertained to me because I feel like it represents me, the characters feel are relatable, parents who fear for the next generation, others who just reject it entirely. Teenagers who are scared, and dealing with mental issues.

This movie despite the craziness and sci-fi, feels...real...it feels like life......

Title: So bad and overrated I made an IMDB account to write a review
Review:
I was talking to a friend a few days ago, who is passionate about quantic physics, that it's about time some movie will come up with Hugh Everett's many world's interpretation of quantum mechanics. Sadly, this crap got to it in a main stream way first. It's hugely overrated and can't remember having to watch a movie with such a big discrepancy vs imdb score. Maybe the idea seems revolutionary to some, and that's why it got the big acclaims. But no matter how you look at it, it's a huge waste of time. I will definitely remember this movie for being the worst I've seen in a very long time. Don't skip science class, when you see crap you'll be less impressed.

Title: A Rollercoaster of Emotions Inside Us All
Review:
This film will not be for everyone.

Every now and then, we get an absolutely golden film with deeper messages and themes that resonate with moments in our lives

There are a lot of low score reviews, who could only process the action in front of them. The action and goofyness is only the cosmetics in front of you. A pillow for what would actually be quite serious and heavy without.

The deeper messages appear to you from each character. And if you have been through some of these hardships/challenges, you start to follow where this film is going.

Everyone cast are absolutely perfect in their roles. And the ending is a truly feel good one. The occurrence in each multiverse are both impressive and hilarious.

If you enjoyed films like The Joker, Parasite, District 9 or Cloud Atlas, this is very much in your ball park.

Never had a film make me cry, but there is a moment (also quoted in the Quotes section) that made me think of my life with my wife and it was tears of love and joy.

Life may not be perfect, but if we each try to make it better, we will succeed :)

Title: Incredible experience
Review:
To begin, it must be known that prior to watching this film I got blown. I went into this experience with basically no knowledge about what I was about to watch. The first 10 minutes were a little slow and confusing, but once the ball got rolling, things got wild.

The sheer number of details in this movie will leave me coming back to discover new things about it every time I watch it. I mean it when I tell you that I never expected the next thing to happen. EEAAO constantly made me think the plot would go one direction but then everything would hit a 180 and I'd be watching hotdog-finger porn. The costume designs, the acting, the lighting, (almost) everything about this movie was phenomenal. This movie, which I thought was purely sci-fi before watching, made me crack up, almost cry, and left my jaw on the floor. EEAAO was everything I could have ever wanted in a movie and more. A true work of art, and a must-watch for stoners.

Title: The Movie That Forced Me To Review It
Review:
I do not write reviews. I do not go out of my way to write good or bad reviews. I simply can't be bothered.

However, this movie is so incredible that it would feel wrong not to do so. It is one of a kind and something that will be studied in filmography in some years.

Having watched it 4 times, it only gets better and better. Each time you watch there is something new to enjoy. I don't think I have ever watched a film that so perfectly puts together everything it is trying to do and I don't think there will ever be a film that can manage what this one did.

It is truly an incredible journey.

Title: Groundbreaking and unequivocally fresh
Review:
This film is a completely new experience and it was absolutely mildblowing to watch in theatres. Handling very serious topics and gut wrenching scenes in a comedic way, while still supplying intense action and brillant fight choreography. It is so nice to see a film these days that isn't a remake or a sequel in a franchise, Michelle Yeoh does beautiful job showing the realness of her character and the conflict. Jamie Lee Curtis is also a gem for this project, mixing it up opposite Yeoh. Stephanie Hsu might be my favorite part of this movie, her dedication to her character is remarkable. I highly recommend this film and I cannot wait to see how it does at the oscar's.

Title: I want to love this, but I'm left confused
Review:
I really really wanted to love this movie. It is a spectacle, visually interesting and it has a nice ending, but for a majority of the time I was just so confused with what was happening. All the multiverses, the weird jumps in time, the plot that escalated quickly and weirdly. The first 45 minutes I was waiting for something to make more sense or for the movie to pick up some speed. I don't know, I honestly feel a bit sad because my partner really loved the movie and was touched by it!

Maybe I have to watch it another time to grasp the magnificent feeling it gave many people. The ending was nice though.
