Title: Don't read further unless you choose the red pill! Or you're a parent. Or you're obsessed with bagels and black holes.
Review:
This movie was extraordinarily creative, with caveats.

The trailers are absolute eye candy. They include Matrix-like action scenes with high contrast and slow motion martial arts. There are mentions of the multiverse, and one headline online suggested the film was an intro into quantum mechanics and alternate dimensions. The hype is so intense for this production that I tossed my conventional thriftiness out the window to wait until the next discount day at the local theater. Instead I pre-ordered an expensive ticket for the best seat at a luxury cinema that has huge reclining leather seats with lots of leg room. I was ready to shortcut years of college physics classes for the two and a half hour long visual treat.

As the movie began I skipped attention at the early scenes while organizing boxes of candy and drinks. When the tax office scene started I knew from the trailers it's time to focus. As the movie progressed it was delightful, a comedic parody merging The Matrix with The Lego Movie. So far so good. Unlike the Matrix, it's actually hilariously funny and the production team here invested in lighting so you actually can see what's going on during the movie.

(Opinion ahead!)

Yet, midway through the film, all of sudden realized I had been shamboozled, as scenes with the hidden meaning started illuminating through the smoke and mirrors of the parody.

There's two main perspectives on where you're coming from when you watch this movie. If you're a parent of a teenager or young adult, then long story short, this film is a colorful fun metaphor for why you should always make kindness and unconditional love the number one important theme for your communication with your kid, even through the rough times. Honestly from this view it is a brilliantly wonderful modern parenting guide presented on the big screen.

If you're a parent, once you get to this realization in the movie, turn on your phone, and send a text to your kid, "Hi, how are you doing, wish you were here, it's a great movie, just reminding you that I love you." Then continue watching the movie, occasionally laughing aloud, which you will many times, and saying to yourself, "Hahaha oh yeah I can relate to that conversation... and that one... and that one too". The dramatic interaction scenes are spot on indeed.

(Alternate perspective for the rest of you)

However, if you don't have kids then just pretend this movie is an updated Matrix, but with lots of humor and comedy and with better lighting. Just like in The Lego Movie, we are presented a story line in which a 'nobody' can be special and save the world, or in this case all the infinite possible universes too.

The Everywhere movie has a tasty recipe. Combine the somber serious overtone of The Matrix with the happier smiling vibe of The Lego Movie. Now give the chef some magic mushrooms to snack on while heating up the sauce and sprinkle some of those peyote stems in the pot and go really wild with the absurdity. For atmosphere stir in the maximum amount of layers possible. Toss in every seasoning and spice in the kitchen and let them sort out their taste buds in between chomping on popcorn.

Forget using antique pay phone booths to travel! Although sniffing the Kragle might do something. Snort a bug up your nose, sit on a trophy, or chew some of that sticky gum on the bottom of your shoe. The more insane the action, the better the slingshot connecting to a wackier dimension. The visuals are so mind opening that you don't have to drive to New Jersey and get high before watching this film.

(Skipping lots of specific scenes because you'll have to see for yourself, including the rubber...)

Just know that when the movie ends you'll have the thought that there could be billions or trillions of versions of you, and that you could very well be living in the worst possible scenario of all of them. It's likely that every choice and decision you have ever made were the wrong ones. But take comfort in that although your life might suck, there's potentially trillions of happier versions of you and many are rich superstars. Yes you might be a failure and a nobody, but in the event of an actual multiverse emergency you might be the first one they call.

Don't forget the movie's sub-sub note here. If you're with a partner, guess what, just like you they are probably the worst version of themselves too. However, since you may have just watched the movie with them, right now they might be thinking the same about you. So now's a great time to give each other a hug and kiss.

(What's the real reveal?)

Saving the best topic for last, who's the villain in this movie? Pay attention, because it's the only way to save the multiverse. No it's not a computer machine monster army, nor even the holder of the Kragle. It's you. Yes really it's you. Well, it's simultaneously you and most everyone else in the multiverse. So you're not alone. For the villain role Everywhere, Everything All at Once deals the most realistic aspect of the movie and of life, the typical overall lack of human kindness. In addition to making bad choices you likely have a lack of appreciation, a lack of empathy, a lack of acceptance, a lack of openness, a lack of love, a lack of communication, etc.

However the solution to fixing everything that is wrong in the multiverse is actually super easy, barely an inconvenience. No it's not EMP's, nor virus codes, nor armies. The answer is kindness and love. It's here where I give the movie the highest review possible, for the truth of this simplicity should be in every movie, every play, every book, every story, every spoken dialogue, every action, every thought. Just like it is in real life, the answer to fixing everything, everywhere all at once is kindness and love.

See, you gotta love a movie with a happy ending.

After you leave the cinema, you might be tempted to go get a bagel with everything on it. Skip it. Go get a cookie instead. When you're there at the counter buy a few cookies for those around you and tell the person behind the counter thank you and smile, and leave a tip. While you're nibbling away, send texts to everyone you know saying "Thanks for being you, you're amazing."

By the time you finish and walk outside, you'll feel right as rain again.

Title: Perfect in nearly every way
Review:
This movie is wonderful in every aspect of the word. A heartfelt tribute to life and existence in a time where everything seems surrounded by darkness. When you look up at the stars and believe that nothing matters or everything is pointless, this film reminds you to find everything in life to love.

Michelle Yeoh's performance is Oscar worthy, Stephanie Hsu as Joy has one of the most relatable and captivating performances in any movie, the editing of this film is some of the best I've ever seen, and the script is absolutely heart wrenching. If this movie doesn't sweep at the Oscars I will be very genuinely surprised.

100/10 would recommend.

Title: Ref:help
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: What it is to be HUMAN.
Review:
All I can stay is that, at the end of this move, I said, "I can't believe this movie made me cry." Totally unexpected. A unique and creative way to send an emotional message about human fragility, ignorance, fear, all the things about what it is to be human. Be emotionally prepared, expect a lot of strange and unexpected humor. Watch with an open mind.

This movie is visually creative in many scenes as well as bizarre and extreme. The performances are amazing. The story is heartfelt despite in all its weirdness.

An emotional roller coaster half way through this movie. Laughter, disgust, appalled, sensitive, anxiety. A movie to touch you like this as weird as it was....deserves an Academy Award.

Title: Best Movie I've seen in years.
Review:
I have my favourite movies obviously. There are movies that I will go back and watch again and again regardless of them being technically good or not. Sometimes movies just resonate with you because of nostelgia, or because they're relatable, or because they play with your imagination and emotions. I'm approaching middle age now so that kind of thing doesn't really happen to me anymore. I'll enjoy a movie sure, but I won't be blown away by many. Everything Everywhere All at Once is the exception to this rule. Everything Everywhere All at Once is an exceptional movie and one that I have not enjoyed this much in probably a decade or more. It might be my favorite film now. A second watch may confirm or deny this but it's easily the best movie of 2022. It's a perfect film. Perfectly shot, perfectly paced, perfectly timed. Even if you ignore the profound story linez, the hilarious jokes, the intense sci-fi action and the emotional drama, it is a film that could not have been made better. I don't know if this is a one off fluke or if these dorectiors are actually geniuses. Only time will tell.

To all the haters, I'm just going to have to assume they have a completely different idea of what makes a good movie and that we would never actually agree with eachother about anything. These people should probably be ousted from society to be perfectly honest.

I pray that other directors take note of this charmingly dazzling film. Thank the Lord for A24. GO AND WATCH IT RIGHT NOW.

Title: Bewildering nonsense
Review:
Bizarre, chaotic, directionless nonsense. I saw Jamie Lee Curtis on TV say she didn't understand the story when she took the role but now believes it's about love. I think it's about the director trying to create as many meaningless, violent and unfathomable scenes as possible within the budget available.

I confess I only managed to watch half the movie up to the point when I was cringing at what was purporting to happen to a guy with no pants on. Nothing in this scene was progressing the story. It was just the production staff trying to see how gross they could make the scene and still get the movie shown in mainstream cinema.

Just an horrendous movie.

Title: Wow
Review:
I really really don't ever do reviews for anything. But this movie has me wanting to encourage the world to give it a try. I almost instantly fell in love. I threw it on after all the hype with the Oscar winning and what not. I'm no movie critic. I'm not one to make a point of watching Oscar nominated, or winning films. I put it on for background but very soon after it had my full attention. I was asked to describe what it was about and I said everything. The title speaks for itself. I cried for the last 30mins. Ugly cried. Like I said I'm no critic, maybe others think this movie sucked or didn't get it. Maybe I'm being biased with the Asian family narrative hitting too close to home. But I thought it was lovely and beautiful and epic. I cant stop thinking about it since it ended. Ready for a rewatch already. I think I could write an essay about it so I'll wrap it up here but moral of the story, this movie has become an immediate new favorite and I will sing its praises until the end of time. Check it out.

Title: Transcendental Multiverse
Review:
First 20 minutes of the movie may be a hard nut to crack but give it a chance and try to look at it from a distance. Try to open your mind and look for a deeper sense. Don't focus on the picture itself but on what the director is trying to convey through it.

If you are interested in multiverse/quantum physics topics you will be delighted. I have never seen so well depicted interpretation of a multiverse concept. It will take you far beyond the limits of your perception. Will not only show you the 'out the box' thinking - it will totally destroy all the walls of that box, showing you all the possible ways the atoms your body consists of could ever turn into. All other concepts of the multiverse like the one in the Marvel's Universe are somehow limited - they present other worlds but with the same structure - there are humanoid creatures living their lives as we are - but with differencies being the outcome of different life decisions etc. The movie here is showing all the abstract versions of ourselves which will push some of it's audience away - which is understandable as not everyone is imaginative enough to grasp it.

It was a mind boggling experience full of moral principles which we tend to ignore in our daily life. If nothing matters after all - what will you value the most?

Title: Why some people don't understand this movie
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Great movie
Review:
This movie made me extremely happy and hopeful. It's an amazing philosophical examination and a family drama masquerading as an action movie to appeal to wider audiences. This movie is funny, bold, creative, maybe cheesy at times, but overall it's a profound movie.

The central theme of the movie is the battle between nihilism and absurdism (or existentialism). Nihilists say that the universe is meaningless and our lives are pointless. The antagonist of this story is a nihilist and wants to wallow in sadness and gloom. Existentialists and absurdists both attempt to solve the problems created by nihilism. Existentialists believe that since the universe is meaningless we are free create meaning of our own, and that is a beautiful thing. Absurdists argue that the universe is absurd and meaningless and one must find happiness in the absurd.

This movie presents all of these philosophical ideologies and does justice to them in my opinion.

Title: Everything. Literally everything.
Review:
Self-referentially, this movie has everything, including a bagel with literally everything on it. It's an edge-of-your seat thriller, a side-splitting comedy, a tender love story, a tear jerker, a horror movie, a sci-fi, an action pic. It's about life, infinite universes, and everything. It's both an emotional roller coaster and a deeply thought-provoking meditation on the meaning of life. At its heart, though, is a simple tale of love mislaid and found again. The acting is perfect, the writing is perfect, the direction is perfect; even the music is wonderful. Thankfully it is not actually all at once, but its 140 minutes of undiluted delight fly by way too fast. It's worth a second viewing. Or a third.

Title: Best film I've ever seen, yet I understand why others don't like it.
Review:
This film was really incredible. It literally changed my view on life. I started to look at my things in life differently and appreciate them differently. I used to get lost in the smallest things before the film and was afraid of what I would become. In the end, I'm just a small dot in an infinitely big universe anyway, what's the point of worrying about small things? Besides, the film showed me that there is beauty in everything, and you don't need a perfect life to be happy, even the worst version of yourself can find love and happiness. I know the film is not for everyone and everyone has a different opinion of the film. I personally loved it without question. I've never seen a film that took me away like that, but everyone is different, so I can completely understand why the film was too chaotic or crazy for some people.

Title: A shot of life into your soul
Review:
I don't know how to express how beautiful this movie is. It has everything on it, and every part of it is put together so perfectly. It's inevitable to feel all kind of emotions, and all the things you feel are very different from each other. Love, sadness, joy, laugh, fear... you have comedy, drama, absurdity, martial arts, romance, science fiction, and more, all at once while the story is unfolding perfectly. The music, the photography, the dialogues, nothing feels repetitive and you have the perfect amount of information to live every scene as you should and prepare you, at the same time, for what's next.

It probably sounds like I loved the movie so much and I'm a 'fan' and I'm not being objective on other aspects of the film. I don't know about the flaws that it may have because it doesn't matter at the end. At the end you are a creature that just got off of a rollercoaster of emotions and probable you are already seeing your life with different eyes. Maybe I am a fan. Maybe this is the only thing that I am a fan of.

This is my very first review here in IMDB because I couldn't help it. I couldn't not say anything about this beautiful movie. I don't know hoy many of you will read this, and I'm sure a lot of you will disagree with me, it would be very understandable. I can just say about what the movie made me feel to me, with my baggage, with my mind.

Thank you to all the people that made this movie.

Title: Closest thing to an acid trip
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: I would say it's like a fancy dreaming , it's chaos but inspired , I awoke with a smile on my face!
Review:
This film is completely beyond my expectations , I mean both of production and story telling makes me eyes opening , this is a fresh topic for film makers for sure , less people would willing to using a western comedy way to tell a eastern family's struggle , In my opinion , a word form Latin called " modus vivendi " are totally described how I understand a most Chinese family style , they accommodate and blame each other and depend on each other , therefore, it is kind of symbiosis relationship.

I am enjoyable of what present on screen , no matter character setting,camera language,art design and acting is great and creative, love to see different Asian culture been shown but not overused. In addition, philosophy discussed is make people thought-provoking , when I saw this movie , it make me remind a famous sentence "There is only one heroism in the world: to see the world as it is and to love it." Even I seen thousand of possible future , I still chose to live my life and love you.

In the last , I wanna shout out to Michelle Yeoh , first time I know about her is cause the film "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" by Ang Lee (my respectful director btw :) , I never thought in 2022 I can see astonishing new image from her , Thanks for her contribute , this movie just like tailored for her .

Thanks Daniels and all the crew members to create this amazing gift to audience , I can promise this will be my favorite in this 2022 .

Title: Touching- and that's the Asian bro from the "Goonies"
Review:
Open your mind and enjoy this loving, touching movie. You will be smiling at the end. Very original. The cast does a great job. A couple scenes were defiantly odd- but whatever. This movie had everything. Didn't want to stop watching. You will love Joy's outfits. Not only is that the bro from the "Goonies"- but there is also another bro that was the bad guy in "Big Trouble in Little China". AND the lady from the bowel yogurt commercials does an epic job as well. Very cool premise for a movie that you can watch by yourself or with people you care about. I spend like 45 minutes of my life searching for movies some nights- on the 10 different apps we have and rarely end up this satisfied with my choices. This was a pleasant surprise. It's a feel good movie. Promise.

Title: I tried to get into it but gave up halfway through
Review:
I tried to get into this movie. I gave up halfway through. It has got to be the most uninteresting film I've seen in a long time. Frenetic, disjointed, and irritating. I doubt that I would have felt differently had I watched it until the end. I'm surprised that it won so many Oscars. Critics have raved about it and usually there is a glimmer of truth in what they report. Not for this movie, at least not for me. The opening scenes were fine, and I wish the movie could have continued along in that manner. But it moved into bizarre territory and stayed there. Bizarre can be ok, but in this movie, it wasn't. I couldn't make sense of most of what happened nor did I care to. I agree with other users here who said that there are better films to watch if one wants to find out what life may have been like if one had made different life choices.

Title: The perfect movie for right now
Review:
I am blown away by this movie. It feels inspired in all its aspects, as heavy and profoundly tapped in to the human expirience as possible, and still fun actionpacked and visually stunning. Its hard to say what is best about this whole excersice in movie magic. But one of the thing is deffinitly Michelle Yoeh. In many ways this was a part only she could do, and then to play it in this way, it makes you just be happy to be living in this particular universe.

In a time where diverse casting and the wokeness culture sometimes seems to be a mold growing on the movie business, this movie seems to be getting it all right. Giving a loving insight in an asian immigrant familie, handeling the struggles of LGBTQ stuff in a way that speaks to all with a heart. And all this as a sidenote to a story on depression, family, love and the depth of human expirience, wich it also hits out of the park.

Cannot recommend enough. Don't be forced to slap yourself in a few years when you see it and could have seen it in the cinema today.

Title: Drugs via cinema
Review:
I would like to start by saying please make sure you see this in the cinema to get the full experience.

I believe the film is about depression or at least existentialism.

This movie touched me deeply, writing this review makes me want to cry but in a good way. I really connected with the films values, the daughters view on the world and relationship with her mother.

I think like a lot of people, we have all been really questioning the meaning and purpose of our lives the past couple of years and it can all get quite dark and lonely and confusing.

This film depicts these thoughts but in a funny and uplifting way. I felt like a child again, there are the most random and ridiculous and silly scenes that had me and the rest of the cinema belly laughing.

There was also scenes which had me in floods of tears.

I came out feeling like I'd had 5 tabs of acid I still feel different and can't help thinking of this film and will do for a long time I need to see it again.

Title: A Visual and Emotional Masterpiece!
Review:
From start to finish, this film takes you through a roller coaster of emotions whilst leaving you breathless as to how each scene was pieced together. Rarely am I on the floor crying tears of laughter, sadness, and joy in the same film.

There are many moving parts to this film... From the way the actors (especially Michelle Yeoh) draw you into the screen, to the Daniel's expert directing, this film has it all, well almost all.

The one thing that will prevent you from enjoying this masterpiece, is by getting hung up and clashing with the point that it is trying to make. This film offers a take on nihilism and lifestyle choices that will be distasteful to some. This however is in no way an attack on the film itself. Among many other things, film is a storytelling medium, and when a story is told well and in a compelling way anyone can enjoy it even when they disagree with the point that it is trying to make.

All in all, this film is definitely worth seeing!

Title: Absolutely the worst!

I hesitated writing a review because I don't enjoy being negative. However this is the worse movie I've ever seen! Attack of the Killer Tomatoes was a better film than this one!

Don't get me wrong, I love Michelle Yeoh and I can think of at least 2 of her movies that greatly deserved awards but had been shunned by the Academy. I loved all the main actors in this movie but they really must be embarrassed by how bad this movie is, I feel sorry for them.

Title: Amazing

The decisions we make and the people we choose to become affects our lives and everyone around us.

The performances were very real and heartfelt and the film is also visually stunning.

Please give this film a chance.

Title: Existential breakthrough

It's for though who are on a spiritual enlightenment journey who see how deep films like Star Wars and Interstellar and Inception are - this film is your breakthrough. It was so insightful and mind blowing, you should definitely get high for this one but if that's not for you, it's still good. It has a heartwarming ending that really solidifies that 'only love is real' - it is the most powerful force.

Title: What a ride
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: stupid, over rated, dumb
Review:
I watched this after all the hype with awards.

So outlandishly stupid and dumb and yes, overrated. How the f does it deserve oscars is beyond me. The judges were probably filling their diversity/representation quota.

This movie is an absolute mess! "Everything Everywhere All At Once" tries to be clever and profound, but it only ends up being convoluted and nonsensical. The plot is confusing, the characters are one-dimensional, and the humor is cringe-worthy. I cannot believe I wasted two hours of my life watching this garbage.

The filmmakers seem to think that throwing together random elements from different genres and cultures will make for an intriguing and original story, but all they achieved is a jumbled and chaotic mess. The special effects and action scenes are not enough to save this train wreck of a movie.

The worst part is that the film pretends to have a deeper message about identity and universality, but it's all superficial and unconvincing. The dialogue is filled with pseudo-philosophical gibberish that tries to sound profound but comes across as pretentious and meaningless.

Title: Meaningful and entertaining
Review:
Every aspect of life is a universe. The paradigm / governing thought controls how a person acts in a particular universe. Conflicting ideas fight each other in its own universe.

Everything: Our life consists of a lot of universes: meaning of life, sextual orientation, parents and children's needs, wants, and expectation of each other, dealing with other humans, dealing with laws, dealing with nature.... There are lots and lots of them. Hence, lots of universes.

Everywhere: Our mind and body thinks about and act in each of the universe in fractional seconds. So as we think or act, we are jumping among universes. Even though we do not see it physically, our minds are fighting each other in a particular universe just by thinking about it.

All at once: many meaningful ways to look at it. 1. All this is happening at all times in each person's life. 2. Explodes when conflicting thoughts materialize into action. Ex. Two people thought about how much they hate each other. Arguments/Fights will happen when they meet and discuss how much they hate each other. 3. When involved people CSIPed (Processed with Complete and Successful Intellectual Process) their thoughts about all of their conflicting thoughts in each universe. Their minds and souls converge and become harmonious in the corresponding universe.

Great movie. As good as Forrest Gump if not better.

Title: Mirror of My Mind

Even if you just absorb the absurdity and laugh at the comedic parts, it is worthwhile and entertaining. I highly recommend this movie.

Title: I have never written a review on here before, but I just had to for this one
Review:
This film was easily one of my favorites of all time, and I hardly ever like films. It was quite literally "everything, everywhere, all at once". I laughed. I pondered. I sobbed. If you felt this movie was messy, and didn't like it, and decided to leave a bad rating, you didn't understand it, and you never will, unfortunately, because it is a beautiful film with a powerful message that brought me to the most tears I have ever cried in one sitting. This film is moving, powerful, emotional, a good laugh, a great visual, and an original concept that was well put together. DEFINITELY go watch. You won't regret it.

Title: I couldn't help but crying
Review:
This movie is certainly not flawless, but still it's my favorite movie of the year. I am fully impressed by the imagination, the power of emotion and the unique way of intepreting family relationship. In some way we are all ordinary heroes of our daily routine life that seems to repeat endlessly. It's time to change the way of our way of perceiving our lives, our beloved ones and of course, a change of mindset is the most important thing of all. Let's start to think out of the box, and see little things in our lives in a new perspective, we will find out how many possibilities our life could hold. My appreciation to all the actors, actress and the whole team working behind the scene, a beautifully told story, a masterpiece.

Title: Amazingly overrated
Review:
I can't believe this film won so many Oscars, goes to show the academy has truly lost their sense of what great cinema is.

Mildly funny, and often forced, 5th grade humor and mostly slapstick comedy is considered genius now?

Also blatantly and shamelessly ripped multiple things off from The Matrix including bullet time and the concept of a savior character who needs to unlock her powers, "downloading" knowledge - this movie is far from original or inventive.

Yes it's entertaining, a little trippy at times, nothing mind blowing if you're familiar with the concept of a multi dimension universe - this take on it is far from believable by any means even with suspended disbelief and wasn't very entertaining, Spider-Man did the concept 10x better.

Title: Magical, surprising, and bizarre
Review:
This movie was a real exception! With the creative plot, it's lovely characters, various mix from humor, suspense and great fighting scenes, it doesn't fit to any box, but to its very own one!

The story starts with the Chinese women Evelyn, who is the owner of a laundromat and lives a very normal life. The daily struggle of clients, family problems and a tax review is suddenly broken when somebody from a different universe enters her life.

Suddenly an exciting adventure starts for her, where she slips in many others versions of herself to fight for nothing less than saving all connected universes.

10 stars for this wonderful pieces of movie art!

Title: MIndblowing!!
Review:
Everything at once everywhere is a film that will not leave you indifferent. It is an accumulation of action, effects and a lot of humor. No doubt I would say that it is one of those films that mark you in one way or another, to me in this case for its photography and special effects.

It lasts 2h 20', maybe at the beginning it can be a bit heavy until it starts to develop. However, it is worth watching it until the end because it improves at times although from the first minute it surprises you in a very spectacular way audiovisually speaking. There is no scene that is the same as the previous one.

I wanted to highlight the performance of Jonathan Ke Quan, who plays the husband of the protagonist. He's a super charismatic character and it's partly why the film works so well because of the duo that the leading lady (Michelle Yeoh) plays.

The film is divided into two acts, which is something different from what is commonly. Seen in mainstream cinema.

Besides being a movie full of visual effects and fights, there is also time to get reflective, something that is appreciated.

Undoubtedly, highly recommended.

Title: Best movie of the decade.
Review:
When I first heard of the new sci fi movie, meant to be for best movie of the decade I was skeptical. I knew I had to watch it for myself and it delivered. Truly one of the greatest movies this decade, if not ever. Hands down the most original premise with near flawless executions. The way they can address such mature topics in new insightful ways is something far more movies should aim to do.

Truly a modern masterpiece of cinema.

Title: Made me cry happy tears
Review:
I made an IMDb account just to talk about this movie. I really needed something like this, especially after all the stress and chaos that's been the last couple of years. It's so refreshing to see a movie that's just so unabashedly weird and chaotic and fun. It's so refreshing to see a movie with style and passion. You could tell, from the acting to the cinematography to the script, that there was so much passion poured into EEAAO. And the message that it isn't shameful or weak to be kind? That being hopeful is a valid way to survive in this universe? That things can change for the better? It's wonderful to see a message like that on the big screen. This was a true gem of a movie and I'm not going to shut up about it for a while.

Title: Nothing Nowhere All at the Same Time
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: I Gave it One Star Because I couldn't give 0 stars
Review:
This is the worst movie I've ever watched. It reminds me of Springtime For Hitler, a play created to bomb that somehow becomes a success. I have no idea what the Academy saw in this movie vs Tar, All Quiet on The Western Front, or any of the other contenders. Similarly, I have no idea how these actors won Best Actress, Best Supporting Actor, and Best Supporting Actress. If the Academy wants to reward ethnic actors and give Jamie Lee Curtis a Lifetime Achievement Award, then just do it. Don't clog up the awards with manufactured winners. This movie is a piece of garbage with no redeeming qualities. I read that it was made for only $20mm, given what I've seen, it probably could have been made for $1.50...and even that would be a stretch. Do yourself a favor and skip it.

Title: The research they undertook shows!
Review:
After hearing that the creators of this movie did multiple years of research into the possibility of a multiverse, I thought the idea sounded like a piece of art.

What amazed me was the way that the complexity of the subject which amazes so many of us (real or not) was conveyed in an understandable but artistic way. The film hit incredibly with all friends I've watched with and has been the first film in the last couple of years which has left an impact on my mind, the way I think and my interest in scientific theories. The weight of the film was tangible and I was lost in the story (although confusing but in the way I believe it was intended for the average viewer). It is a true stand alone classic and I will come back to watch for many years.

Title: Perfection

But I'd like to add what I felt watching this movie. This movie dropped at the right time in this universe for people like me whose family is going through times, barely hanging onto by a thread. It's an every household story, but with the help of the concept of multiverse.

Themes of family, kindness, selfishness & selflessness, unending commitment to love, etc echoes loud throught the whole journey.

This movie is a case study and will be studied by film schools for generations.

Title: Massively over rated.
Review:
I haven't reviewed a film on here for years but was compelled to do so after having been subjected to this mess.

Although it was very ambitious and occasionally funny in a slightly campy way, I'm flabbergasted at the positivity about this ill thought out, hotchpotch of disparate cinema genres.

The idea of exploring the multiverse through the prism of Kung-fu fighting and kinky sex is ludicrous.

Maybe it will become a cult film best watched while tripping but definitely not the 'profound' experience people are describing here...

Title: A film for broken Asian kids
Review:
I am curious if a viewer from a completely different culture background could relate to the feelings in this movie. From what I can see, it's not only about to love, to be kind, rather a first generation immigrant trying fo fix herself. She's in between of a traditional Asian family, and a daughter born in the west. She's the one character in this movie struggled the most, and put in the most effort into everything. She's never good enough for her parents, and never good enough for her daughter.

I am happy there's a movie out there touching this part of the world. The feeling it brought me can't be simply rated.

Title: Groundbreaking Masterpiece
Review:

Title: WOW.
Review:
"Everything Everywhere All At Once... or more like "The Matrix meets The Multiverse of Madness meets Lucy meets Kung Pao all At Once"!!!!

And I mean that in a good way. They took the best of those and made their own masterpiece.

The title suits it very well. The plot was ambitious and at any point could have been a chance to mess up. But it didn't.

Cast is awesome. And it had everything!

Humor, Action, Special effects and Heart.

One second you're watching an impressive fight scene, the next you're LOLing, then you'd get teary eyed.

At times cheeky but not corny.. heartwarming but not melodramatic.

It has a love story embedded in it without being the typical unnecessary cheesy stuff.

Romantic love, love for family, love of a parent, love for others. Generational curse.

This puts Doctor Strange's effort at depicting a "Multiverse" to shame.

This may very well be the best film of 2022. So far, it is for me.

Title: Thank you.
Review:
Just. Yeah. Exceeded any expectations. Then kept going. Amazing. Best movie I have seen in the last four years. If you want to escape your reality, this is a must watch. Really turns the whole genre of alternate universes on its head and brings it straight back home. Forget your Marvel way of looking at things and, instead go for what's important in your universe. Cinematically outstanding, a top notch casting. Although I will say it most definitely has put me off hotdogs for a very loooong time!!!!!

Watch this movie. Unless you sell hot dogs for a living. In that case maybe you've made the wrong choice in this universe. Lol.

Title: Don't watch even 2 minutes
Review:
The most ridiculous movie I've ever seen in my life. A bad movie that has nothing to do with logic and morality. Don't even watch this 2 hour movie for 2 minutes. Getting an Oscar doesn't make a movie good. There are hundreds of non-reward films that touch the hearts of the audience.

What does good movie mean? Beautiful movie is love movies between Man and woman. Like the "Titanic". Good movies are action movies, like "Die Hard". Good movies are detective crime movies, like "Se7en". Good movies are family movies, like a "Everybody's Fine".

This movie is too bad. This bad movie has nothing to do with family, morality, or love between man and woman. If I had 500 years to live, I would not watch such immoral films even for 5 minutes.

Title: beyond imagination, a movie who celebrate creativity and the Joy of Existence
Review:
Everything about this movie is good, the actor, the humour, the story, the vfx. This movie is one of the most original and entertaining i have seen. Its one of the very few movie that i can give a 10/10 without a hesitation. The actors are very well written and relatable, its also a very big come back for the actor Ke Huy Quan. But what make this movie very different and unique from the other one is the Originality of the story, and the capacity to make such a good movie with such low budget and low number of people ¬®for example 5 artists working on the vfx¬®. If you are looking for a movie that will make you cry, laugh and deeply think about the meaning of life, existence and consciousness, its for you.

Title: This movie pulled so many emotions out of me.
Review:
The range and intensity of emotions this film elicited from me was nothing short of stunning. Laughter, tears, curiosity, anxiety, awe, dismay, and more. At times it feels like pure information overload, and and other parts, time slows to a crawl as you savor one particular scene, moment, feeling. I cannot recommend this movie enough. People look for different things in a film: perhaps to see something visually appealing, perhaps to escape from reality for a while, perhaps to learn some important life lessons, or perhaps just to experience something new. This film has all of that. Give it a watch: whether you end up liking it or not, you will definitely experience something you've definitely never experienced before, intensely. 10/10.

Title: The ultimate in film versatility.
Review:
Everything everywhere all at once rides this fine line between being humorous and heartfelt, complicated and sincere, and meaningful but not preachy. Great acting is combined with the most innovative direction of the decade turns this silly multiverse-action-comedy-drama into a near masterpiece.

The movie is not meant for all, however. About as many walked out weeping by the touching ending as did disturbed by alternate universe antics mid way through. The movie is packed, and a little hard digest given it's breakneck speed over an above average run time. Some might find it hard to reconcile excellent, introspective dialogue bookended by crude slapstick gags.

Despite some minor flaws, Everything Everywhere all at Once is a shoe-in for best direction and best cinematography, and very well may be the best movie of 2022.

Title: Delightfully chaotic!!!
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Avalanche of silliness. Lasts 45 minutes too long. Should have had more breathers with real life acting in between all the silliness.
Review:
The bad: it lasts way too long. 45 minutes should have been cut out of it, because there is a limit to how much silliness I can stumach non-stop.

More bad: this story CONSTANTLY shifts between reality and fantasy, up to a point that it gets REALLY ANNOYING to watch. But perhaps game marinated teenager brains wont mind that at all?

Not any good then? It's really a wonderfully creative movie, with excellent photography, excellent choreography. It's definitely something else...

There is also a great role by Jamie Lee Curtis as some kind of psychopathic old IRS lady for which she even won an Oscar!

This movie is simply not my cup of tea, because this movie does not know when to breath, when to have a pause and let REAL characters interact with each other, instead of fantasy ones.

It's too much of a gimmick for me. It could have been a lot better if there had been a better tightknit direction, because in it's core it is a fascinating magical story...

Suited for who? I honestly do not know, because this is one of the weirdest Oscar winners in history...

Title: Knock ... Knock ... Who is there?
Review:
I'll tell you whose not there. There's no film producer. There's no film director. There's DEFINITELY no film editor because this supposedly highly acclaimed film that has suspiciously garnered eleven (11) Academy Award nominations in March 2023 left me and Mrs. Shullivan at our open front door looking around for what the heck all the buzz was about this piece of garbage?

I cannot emphasize enough how disappointed that Mrs. Shullivan and I were after investing some $40 for a 4K copy of this film when it was initially released which I rarely do but I proceeded with my advance copy of the film based solely on the eleven (11) Academy Award 2023 nominations that the film attained.

I am using the analogy of a "Knock Knock" joke because this film is delivered in three (3) chapters (just like a Knock ... Knock .... Knock joke) all which were basically a mirror image of each other with total chaos being the premise and an underlying theme of the strained relationship between the Laundy Mat owner and mother Evelyn Wang (Michelle Yeoh) and her daughter Joy Wang (Stephanie Hsu).

Mrs. Shullivan and I kept waiting for the tempo to slow down but instead the Chinese western theme continued throughout with fight, after fight after fight through the Disneyland eyes of a poor copy of the 1940 Fantasia film.

Hey my wife and I are senior citizens and our days of experimenting with hallucinatory drugs are decades behind us. Maybe, just maybe the film critics who are praising this piece of garbage went to a screening and instead of chomping on M&M's and Caramel popcorn they were fed some potent hallucinatory drugs and spiked Kool-Aid and then attended a big after party afterwards. Otherwise I cannot in my wildest dreams comprehend how this film pulled off such a big scam on the general public.

I hope the general public isn't drinking their Kool-Aid and I also suggest if this film comes knocking at your door ..... DON'T ANSWER IT!

I give the film a very disappointing 3 out of 10 IMDb rating.

Title: Oscar Self-Destructs
Review:
The movie has everything everywhere all at once that today's younger audience might want from movies: it's frantically paced, crazily plotted and doesn't follow any of the traditional notions of clarity or coherence. As science fiction, it makes Star Wars and Star Trek seem like outdated museum pieces. It has the feel and look of an endless video game - a movie where rules don't apply and there are no real consequences for anyone, anywhere.

The only ingredient that registers with any brain that might be in the audience is the talent of the performers who, as professional actors, remind us of what better movie roles hopefully wait for them in the future.

Try to imagine trivial, mindless entertainments from the past, like Blazing Saddles or Animal House, winning the Best Picture Oscar; or even higher quality sci-fy movies like Alien or Zardoz - once upon a time, it seems, there were standards. The votes this received for Best Picture must surely have been cast by members who think the Academy has reached the end of the line.

Sadly, maybe it has.

Title: What did I just watch...
Review:
I just watched this film by virtue of it being a multi-Oscar winner. I was well rested and of clear mind but still found the film difficult to follow.

It's a film that focuses on a migrant laundromat owner who in essence, I can only deduce, is trying to patch up the relationship with her daughter while also experiencing a faltering relationship with her husband.

The core of this film is sweet and well-intentioned but the way it is filmed is nauseating and difficult to follow. Some might say the special effects are part of the appeal, but personally I did not find the experience pleasant at all. The film is also far too long for what it aims to deliver.

Title: Interesting but boring and extremely over-hyped
Review:
I stated once and stopped after 15 mins , then gave it another try as a result of all the hype . What was that? Seemed like a cheap video tape of the 80s. Overly simplistic, amateurish special effects (pretentiously intentional). What was the hype all about? What were the Oscars for except for making up for the past guilt on the Asian American community? I watched Tetris on the same day and there was no comparison between the 2 movies . If they idea is to create a mess in the name of art, then yes , the movie achieved it . Imagine an Asian version of the guardians of the Galaxy mixed up with some more non- sense and this is it .

Title: 3 attempts ...
Review:
... and I still can't force myself to watch till the end this 'Oscar Winner'.

NO, NO & NO ..... The Golden Raspberry Awards at most!

The Godfather, Forest Gump, Gladiator, Titanic, Braveheart, Schindler's List, The Silence of the lambs, Dances with wolfes, Rain man, Platoon, Rocky, etc,

is this really in the line with these Oscar Winners?

And it is not that I judge by american, non-american, chiniese, non-chiniese, politically driven, non-politically driven, lgbt driven, non-lgbt driven ... but HOW on earth the makers of this movie pulled the wool over the eyes of the Accademy members (sic!)

The art, the story, the moral, the performance, SFX, ... all of these factors should came over.

I'm sorry but in this case (my opinion) i didn't.

3rd attempt not to watch TheOscars during the last 3 years - succeed! I drop.

Title: Well Acted Pandering
Review:
I love Michelle Yeoh, and movies that show loving what you have but this? This was idiotic.

Albeit the acting and action was very well done (Is that Data from Goonies kicking butt?!) this brain vomit of mixed signals doesn't deserve them.

Jamie Lee acurtis shows up to be, fat Jamie Lee Curtis and tries to demand we find her charming. She isn't nor are her disgustingly bad scenes.

Moreover the real message pressed is; 'Dammit you dumb old people, stop being old, and make grandpa be excited about lesbians!' Also, enough whinging and you can break the universe.

A wildly overworked mother gets smacked around by all the whiney brats desperate for her attention, RIGHT NOW! ... Could her husband really not wait until dinner, at least, to drop a bomb on her? Daughter is mad because her family is out right screaming with joy she's gay, they're ONLY accepting. The nerve! Her father is apparently an ass, but we never actually see that.

Oh, and be careful who you watch this with, or you may end up in uncomfortable, wildly unexpected, conversations about sex toys... What was the point of that, movie? Seriously, how did this move the story along?

Although I found the things needed for travel funny most times, it got really stupid, really quickly. It's somewhat like a small child trying to show you how gross they can be, passing gas in a tub and hoping you'll laugh. This doesn't fit with the 'message' or rhythm of the movie in any congruent way.

Watch it, if you must, but this is a wildly overhyped piece of junk with amazing actors doing incredible things to carry it.

Title: 7 oscars is this r√©al?
Review:
This is my first review so my misunderstanding is great.

7 Oscars is huge and it will change cinema forever the film is not bad far from it but this consecration is not timely.

I'm a big fan of movies and when a movie motivates me I watch it in one go, this one on the other hand I stopped halfway a few months ago and never watched the end. It started well but then it became a series of shots seen and reviewed.

The Oscars are no more than a masquerade from now on. I'm not saying that the film is bad, but it's impossible for it to garner so many. I am even less motivated to finish it and unfortunately to understand what could have motivated so many prices.

Title: Major disappointment, Not award worthy by any category except for costume design
Review:
Based on the award nominations and general hype there were some serious high expectations for this movie. Clearly it didn't live up to it

You can tell from trailers this is more of a light, action drama. But if it wasn't for the fast unnecessary graphic edits or bizarre side scenes that didn't make any logical sense, it might've actually been an average ok film.

Still, no actors deserved any recognition for their roles. The acting was flat without real emotion. The script was stereotypical and predictable. The editing was nonstop and migraine inducing.

I couldn't wait to finish it. What a waste of time.

Title: B movie
Review:
Another poor story about Muli-Verse. This Multi-verse story was written poorly and tried to teach us a lesson about war and bad manners, but just fell on its face. Acting was up to par with a B movie. The main characters seemed to have chemistry, but the supporting cast, (Jamie Lee Curtis included) really seemed to be afterthoughts that the Directors tried to fit into the story. The music and cinematography were adequate, but the costumes and make-up were very remedial. The special effects were average at best. One of the worst written movies I have ever seen. I would not recommend this movie.

Title: Like Downsizing in that it's ambitious and hard to finish
Review:
I also don't get the hype. It doesn't deserve the acclaim. It's a mess in every way. Reminds me of Alexander Payne's Downsizing because that has an interesting idea so poorly executed that it took me forever to finish. I tried and tried but just couldn't see the point. Like Greenbook, Driving Miss Daisy, Shakespeare in Love, and Crash, it proves that the Oscars miss more often than not. Probably going to win best picture but not deserving of it. When even positive reviews call the acting over the top but it still yields 4 acting nominations, that means something is broken. This will do nothing but perpetuate Hollywood pandering generalizations.

Title: Too self indulgent to be called an epic
Review:
What could had been a sweeping adventure like back to the future or zathura, is reduced to same thing happening over and over and over again for more than 2 hours. Its not as complex as it aims to be, neither its as engaging. To please the me-she-you audience, it throws some propaganda and lgbt gimmicks too, which adds nothing to the fray. Michelle Yeo and Ke Huay Quan are wasted. This is neither a time travel adventure, neither a time loop incident, and neither it is a miltiverse movie. Its too self-indulgent to be called any of these. Maybe someone from the team of jumanji or zathura or goosebumps or night at the museum should have handled this.

Title: Unwatchable
Review:
Disclaimer: I only got thru an hour of this mess before I said: enough! What the hell am I doing??

Just because someone else thought this up doesn't make it good. This movie is a combination of the Joy Luck Club with Tron and the final result is horrible! Trying to follow the plot is not only impossible (maybe after 2:20hrs it makes sense but I wasn't going to find out) but also migraine inducing. There are tons of Kung Fu fighting scenes woven into "seize the day" life lessons with a horrible looking Jaime Lee Curtis playing a zombie apocalypse / terminator type killer while three people in a control room try to make life changing decisions for a mid fifties lady on the fly. If what I just wrote makes no sense, it's because it doesn't. And neither does this movie. Definitely the worst supposed plot and execution I've tried to watch in years, maybe ever.

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Two Directors and No Professional VFX Artists...Telling
Review:
I know, I know...this was yet another film that was aboard the "hype train" in recent times, and it got all these awards and blah blah blah...

Well Too bad, folks. This film was a nightmare.

It began with the most drawn out, boring, monotonous and headache inducing drivel I have seen in an art form in YEARS. I was honestly in pain trying to watch thing and after 35 minutes, my family and I gave up. What a mess this was.

At least its nice that James Hong is still around, cause hes cool, and of course the main actress used to be in tons of martial arts movies, so she WAS cool. But this film was a dud and unworth continuing a third of the way through. Avoid at all costs unless you are heavily medicated or intoxicated. Which, im sure, this film is geared towards folks under the influence. Many films are.

Title: Boring, confusing and annoying
Review:
This movie starts so chaotic, I almost could not bear to keep watching. After 40 minutes I stopped. I was thinking every character in the movie has a serious form of ADHD. The first 30 minutes you don't have a clue what you are watching. I don't like that, within 10 minutes after the start of a movie I want to know what it is about. 2 instead of 1 star for. Michelle Yeoh ("Philippa Georgiou").

Title: Not "everything" to everyone
Review:
This movie was an absolute chore to sit through. Some might call its flourishes creative; i found them tedious and undisciplined. Also, behind all the gimmickry, I found the family story pretty banal and conventional. Lesbian daughter/disapproving mom drama? What year is it? This is tired stuff. The awards season run for this is just baffling. Jamie Lee Curtis has done some consistently good work but her performance here as, essentially, "bad white woman" is kind of cheap and grotesque. Michelle was fine but I've preferred her elsewhere (Shang Chi, Crazy Rich Asians, Crouching Tiger). I'm really only here for the Key Huy Quan comeback.

Permalink

Title: Incomprehensible Gibberish
Review:
This movie would have been a mega-smash in the drug-soaked 1960s when anything that made no sense at all was considered "deep". By the time this garbage was over, it had found a permanent niche in my "Worst Movies Of All Time" list.

It seemed like they hired a bunch of actors and told them to say the first thing that came into their minds. It certainly didn't help that the dialog kept switching between English and Chinese. Aside from the language, it (I hesitate to call it a "plot") bounces all over the place with little rhyme or reason. There wasn't a single character that I cared about in the least.

I'm sure that, if there really are alternate universes, the finished copies of the film were burned in all of them (except, sadly, ours).

May all their fingers turn to hot dogs. The one star was only because I liked the raccoon.

Title: Awful.
Review:
I turned it off after 35 minutes. Couldn't take the stupidity of it any longer. How in their right mind could the Oscar's award this pile of trash such a prestigious award is beyond me. It didn't have any type of plot. The movie was all over the place. Every Oscar nominated movie this year was better than this. I can't really make sense of all the critics positive and glowing reviews. Seems like the vast majority of the regular public truly sees this movie for what it is. An overhyped production that wasn't even worthy of a nomination. Let alone be the winner. It's a shame bad movies win Oscar's.
78 out of 113 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: Absolute garbage of a movie
Review:
The movie started off well by introducing the main protagonists who were likeable and relatable at first. And then the entire movie turned into a complete mess and was all over the place. What followed was a very boring and dumb plotline, utter randomness of events, cringe-worthy acting, and humour that wouldn't count as funny or hilarious.

I am grateful I didn't listen to any of the degenerates who enjoyed the movie and gave it very high ratings as clearly, the movie neither deserved the high ratings, nor did it deserve those rigged Oscar awards.

I personally enjoy multiverse stories, but this one was nothing but a joke and is a waste of time. Clearly an overrated movie that is garbage and probably written by a bunch of 13-year old kids on crack.

Title: Just didn't enjoy it!
Review:
I hate leaving low rating reviews but I was just do disappointed with this movie. I thought after winning all those Oscars I was in for a treat when I rented this movie, I got that wrong. I couldn't even bring myself to finishing it, I actually turned it off just after an hour which is really unlike me, I hate starting movies and not seeing them through but I just couldn't take it anymore. Stupid is a word I would use for it. Maybe messy too. Yes, a stupid messy movie. I don't know, perhaps it's me but I really don't recommend it. One good thing that drew me to it as well as the Oscars was ShortRound being in it but unfortunately that didn't improve it for me although his acting is good, so it's just the one star I'm afraid. Sorry to those that love it, but not me.

Title: Save 2 hours of your life and something else
Review:
I start watching this film without any idea about what it is and without seeing any reviews. I just knew it won some awards.i thought that in the first 20 minutes the director had in mind to portray how first/second generation of Chinese Americans are struggling between native traditions and American way of life, grasping with daughter's homosexuality, trying to deal with issues in their relationship. And the performance of the actors was good. Then, they asked a 19 old art student to replace the director and he/she decided that the best way to move forward with this film is to make a film taramosalata with a hundred different ingredients, all mixed up very quickly in a fancy mixer and serve it in fancy plates. The result is an incoherent, distasteful, not funny end product that the only people that may enjoy it are those who don't want to be considered "not cool".
8 out of 11 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: OVERWHELMING, TOO WEIRD, CHAOTIC & ALL OVER THE PLACE!
Review:
From a cinematographic/visual point of view, the film is something we have never seen before, combined with the concept of the multiverse, and it's true that the film was humorous at times. However it was very gross and utterly absurd and the constant frantic & chaotic fast-paced images/cinematography thrown at us combined with a mishmash of OTT Kung-Fu scenes and ridiculous, vulgar scenes (for a movie that lasted well over 2 hours) proved far too overwhelming, too absurd and weird to my taste!

I didn't enjoy this movie (my friend felt the same and even left the room 1 hour before the end of the film as she absolutely hated it!). I felt I couldn't connect emotionally with any of the characters, there wasn't much in terms of character depth... and it was hard and particularly exhausting to keep watching this film which was far too long... All I wanted to do is for it to be over...! I felt this film was all over the place... It didn't make much sense, and you certainly realise this even more so when the film comes to the conclusion that "Nothing matters"... Needless to say, this movie left me empty and drained... - It just wasn't for me!

Title: How could it get 7.8, and 11 Oscars?
Review:
All the reviews I've read so far seem to agree with my reaction: way overrated, more style than substance, no new profound message here and yes, it took great fortitude and forbearance to see it through to the end. My head is still ringing from the endless meaningless action and special effects sequences. I do not feel the slightest bit informed nor uplifted from having watched it through to the end. I will not be recommending it. Yes, I picked up on the message loud and clear about being kind and that it's ok to be gay and that parents need to let go but never stop loving their kids. But how is that profound or new?

Title: Chaotic and Annoying
Review:
I found Everything Everywhere All At Once to be a very ambitious but ultimately disappointing film. The concept is certainly original, and the film is full of creativity and visual flair. However, the story is very convoluted and at times, annoying, and the characters are not very likable. I also found the film to be very long and self-indulgent.

Overall, I would give Everything Everywhere All At Once a 3/10. It is a film that is worth watching for its originality and creativity, but it is not a film that I would recommend to everyone.

Not sure how it's received rave reviews, and I certainly don't think it worthy of an Oscar.

Title: Absolute rubbish, don't waste your time!
Review:
I watched most of this film, before finally giving up the hope that it might somehow improve, it didn't! It was just a ridiculous meandering load if nothingness! How this film won 7 Oscar's is totally beyond me. There must have been at least hundreds of far better films made in 2022 who were far more worthy of such awards. The film bears a slight resemblance to the Matrix, in that what appears to be real, isn't. However thats where the similarity ends. Some of the acting was reasonable, but the storyline was meaningless dribble, backed up by Jackie Chan like martial arts fighting that had little or no point. If you have 2+ hours to spare, I suggest that you watch some paint dry, it will be a far better option!

Title: This movie can't make up it's mind
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Most unoriginal film ever made.
Review:
Dreadful. Absolutely tedious dull nonsense. Everything everywhere all at once sucks in this film (pun intended). Really, everything about it is awful. At first, it's way too fast-paced that it's difficult to follow the events, yet later it gets way too slow-paced that it just gets so boring. The acting is terrible, none of the performances looks realistic nor does any of the characters believable. Actually, I hated all the characters, they're so uninspired and bland. Most of the film it's just so stressful and messed up that it's just beyond annoying. The film is full of immature childish humour that is so lame.

But the worst of all is that this film doesn't have any kind of originality at all. We got so many multiverse and meta films at this point already and this seems to be the most generic of them all. None of the other universes plays an important role in the film and there are so few, to begin with. The structure of the film is just like any kind of generic blockbuster following the same 20 rules of the generic "The Hero's Journey" film. It's full of cliches and doesn't bring anything new to the table, possibly one of the weakest screenplays I have ever seen. It overexplains everything and is repetitive to its core in doing the same events over and over again. Mindless fights and brainless arcs. The messages are so basic and dated that we learned them all 50 years ago in much more complex and subtle ways already, how does this film even dare to be so bare-bones in its execution, I cannot even imagine. Completely empty dumb trainwreck.

Title: Too much of the Surreal for me
Review:
Sorry, AMPAS. This movie is too wierd for me. Sort of like a Dali or Pollock painting. So much doesnt makes any sense. Obviously this is intended, just much too much. The starting poiint is fairly normal, but it gets progressively incomprehensible with characters working out their conflicts in bizarre ways. These are sandwiched between occasional scenes with affection and words. Mid-movie is dominated by multiple representations of each character and the story becomes overly complicated with the multiverse. The use of butt plugs is over-the-top weird, even in a porno film. Alot of kung fu for action - this violence wears thin after about an hour. Hot dog fingers, a bagel religon, Chef with a raccoon on his head? Apparently some of it intended as a satire on Chinese families, supernatural, and kung fu. It is unique, but that doesn't make it entertaining or insightful. I am okay with two rocks talking with each other in a barren landscape, but a film mostly devoted to making things in overly complicated and impossible to understand much of the time - no thanks.

Title: The Emperor has no clothes
Review:
How this movie got even near an Oscar nomination beats me. It's a confusing and pointless salad of ideas and images just thrown together. The acting which won awards seems wooden and second rate - although since the whole human situation is totally unintelligible it's hard to really say what they should be feeling and how they should be behaving. You certainly don't care what happens to anyone - there's no one to believe in sufficiently. Emotional moments fall flat as do attempts at humour which come over as in jokes. On the plus side, some of the imagery is interesting. But I guess it's fooled a lot of people. Overall it'll be forgotten in weeks and history will remember it as a B movie which mysteriously trended.

Title: NOT WORTH ALL OF THE OSCARDS
Review:
Alright, I am going to be brutally honest. I didn't enjoy this movie as much as everyone else did. I didn't end up watching this movie for the longest time just because everyone was raving about it so much.

Petty I know.

But when I finally got around to watching it, I had such high expectations, and then they were crushed. Hard. I also previously watched the Oscars and I don't believe that they deserved everyone that they won.

Was it entertaining? Yes. Was it funny at times? Yes. Was it weird and random? Yes. Will I probably watch it ever again? No.

It does have a sweet message about always choosing your loved ones over any other opportunity in the world, which I think is sweet. And Ke Huy Quan nailed his part and I think 1000% deserved his Oscar.

Other than that, to me, there is no other reason to watch this movie. I will give it 3/5 stars, and probably recommend it to no one.

Title: Pair of earphones and chewing gum
Review:
140 minutes of nonsense. And I saw a movie with people suffering from hallucinations. You can go from this universe to another by a pair of earphones and chewing gum. I would rather hear some good music. This movie is a nothing but a cheap stupid Chinese version of Inception. And over rated.
