Title: There must be a prank behind this!
Review:
A scriptwriter, a producer and their close associates one day met in a in a BAR at downtown LA where they developed an idea of making a multi-dimensional film, involving science fiction, comedy, horror and you name it. Throw in in a celebrity or two, some "Dr. WHO" and "Dumb and dumper" flavours associated with idiotic multicultural characters and lots of color, and make a movie.

Just like a painting where you throw in all the colors in a bucket and spill it on a canvas and do nothing else.

Use some influencers to get some awards and voi la!

They rightfully anticipated that a lot of the people will say that the movie is worthless, but so what! Majority will talk highly of it because of the awards, artists and that the average person will go like "oh, I think this is a complex art piece containing important messages for humanity" pretending he understands art.

They must be loughing their asses off now! One of the biggest pranks in cinema industry.

BTW sorry folks, for my overrating as there was no zero or minus stars.

Title: Rubbish
Review:
This is the worst film I have watched this year. It is beyond my understanding how it was even considered for an Oscar never mind win any!

When I say I watched it both my wife & I sat through 45 minutes looked at each other in disbelief then turned it off.

It started off reasonably well hence 1 star then who ever wrote the script must have been on some kind of medication. The fight scenes were yawning long and have been seen countless other times. Then the characters became more and more bizarre as if trying to make the audience react to such puerile so called humour.

Glad I didn't spend any money going to see such nonsense.

Title: Very disappointing
Review:
I had high hopes for this film. I love Michelle Y. She is a brilliant and talented actor. However this film is a big let down. Her acting is excellent as usual. The plot is all over the place. It is random to the point of feeling like some sort of bizarre circus show from an alternative Universe.

I am completely baffled by the rating and can only concur that it's high because of the pretty high standard of visual effects and constant barrage of random action.

I Felt like I was eating 10 portions of sticky toffee pudding and needed to vomit by the end but I was to delirious to find a place to release the contents of my stomach and therefore had to hold it in. Not a great feeling!

This film had huge potential. The cast is great. It ended up feeling lazy and confusing. Maybe that was the intended effect? Maybe this is a film that is feeding into the random Instagram/Tik Tok scrolling generation?

For those with huge attention deficit this film might be a blessing.

Not for me I'm afraid. A big waste of talent.

Title: Every bad wierd movie all at once
Review:
I've seen alot of wierd films. I was interested in giving this one ago whilst ignoring my better judgement. This is beyond wierd. Really daft and maybe a little bit woke. This film seems like it was written for school kids and tried waaay to hard to be funny. It was embarrissingly silly and stupid. One of the few films I would have quit after 20 minutes had I not been watching it with the missus (green lantern was the other). IMDb 8.1 rating!!!. I can only guess this is because the majority of the views don't watch much out of typical Hollywood movies and found it different (maybe I'm wrong). Imo it's possibly the worst film iv'e every seen. Next time I'll trust my judgement.

Title: Fresh in today - The Emperor's New Clothes
Review:
What a total mess. Ask just one question, just one, and this whole film fall apart at the seams. I confidently estimate a ratio of holes 98%, plot 2%. There was an episode of Family Guy where Brian and Stewie venture across multiple universes. It was funny, clever, entertaining and believable. Yes, I know. A cartoon talking baby and dog in 25 minutes do the whole multiverse thing with panache. EEAAO is horrible. Frustrating and non-sensical. Some good acting - look at the rubbish they had to work with. Fight scenes were there to pad it out and added nothing. Just a dull reference to Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon, which was incidentally another ridiculously hyped film.

It's 2 1/4 hours of my life I won't get back.

I would refer my learned colleagues to the words of Public Enemy.

"Don't believe the hype, don't believe the hype".

That was hard to watch. The movie started well and got me and my family's attention. We were excited for a fun family movie until... But things took a turn and things got weird. Super weird. It has good moral lesson and the premise is good but execution is messed up... 4 stars for the production and acting. Messed up movie.

Title: I feel duped... Wow... so bad
Review:
My first review in five years, but I feel duty bound to 'report' this shocker of a movie. I cannot comprehend how this film has garnered so much praise, let alone the fact it was voted 'Best Picture' by the Academy. I am sitting here trying to remember a worse picture I have seen, but nothing springs to mind. Overrated in every department. Acting so so, effects childish and overblown, plot utterly incoherent, no storyline. I checked the time remaining at least a dozen times, probably more. Coercion? Persuasion? Suggestion? How did so many people come to like this? I am truly baffled, reeling in shock.

Title: Terrible!

I have rarely seen such an incoherent mess with no redeeming features whatsoever garner so much undeserving praise. After managing three quarters of this pretentious tripe on a Saturday night I had to turn it off as I could feel the will to live physically draining from me, and decided to go for something far more visually and intellectually stimulating, and better acted too (even by the CGI!)...Godzilla v. Kong. Every award, at every ceremony everywhere, all at once, has been terminally damaged by supporting this tripe for one reason and one reason only that I can see!

Title: Academy got this wrong
Review:
This film was extremely overrated and overly hyped. While the over all plot concludes to a well intentioned crescendo, the meat of the film contains nothing more than brash interpretations of a lucid, recreational drug induced state. The high jinx meshed into the film was a nauseating collision of Benny Hill meets Monty Python. With the fore-mentioned producing better quality. One would be better to view Bubba Hotep, than this film...and gain much more from it. Save your money, and watch when it is free and you are extremely bored. This film was about an hour too long. Sadly disappointed and the end couldn't come quick enough.

Title: Just stupid.
Review:
I admit: normally I only add a score when I watched it completely. But this was so bad, I switched it off after 40 minutes. Really, WTF. It's stupid, bad, and extremely childish. I can assume a 12 year old will like it though. It's not that I don't like movies with "stranger" themes, on the contrary. But what is this? Is it supposed to be a comedy? Slapstick? Children's adventures movie? It all looked very stupid and utterly brainless to me. The only time I think of I'll be able to watch it, is when I'm completely wasted and drunk. But as that happens like only once in a decade.... To be honest: it was sooo bad, that I'm furious it got so many Oscar's. I feel so sorry for the other nominees.

Title: Almost defies the rating system
Review:
I used to make sure I watched the January Man each year on New Years' day. I took pride in liking the film so much when more than one film guide described it using words to the effect 'in the weird movie museum, this film has its own wing'. Everything Everywhere...has its own museum.

Ever been in a group on a project trying to come up with ideas and writing them all down to select the better ones? The writers did that without the selection part. They just used all of the ideas constantly throughout. To say the film lacks focus is to say Mozart wrote some music.

There is a false ending not far from the film's climax that could as easily have been the real thing. I remember watching 8 1/2 and falling asleep for 45 minutes. Never felt like the film made less sense. Everything Everywhere... is like that.

Title: Horrible
Review:
I don't get it. My adult children told me that I had to see this movie. So one day we all sat down and streamed it on my home theater. I kept on saying to myself that this movie has to get better, it never did.

Who knows maybe it is generational. However, I am in my 50's and I am not a snob when it comes to movies. Just entertain me and give me some plot. This movie failed on both counts. The only thing I can think of was that the screenplay writer was on some LDS trip when writing this movie. Hot dog fingers? Really? I know this movie will get some attention due to the many awards it won at the Oscars. However, a classic movie like Gandhi or Gone With the Wind it is not.

Title: I had to collect myself before reviewing this "piece"
Review: It's the day after viewing the movie and I deliberately wanted some time to pass before giving my opinion on it. Maybe I missed the point or was in a foul mood and it possibly deserves a second viewing. Maybe I'll read some of the other reviews and see if it influences what I saw. I've never dropped acid so I can't honestly tell if my opinion/assessment is valid but I have two comments to make with reference to this movie and drugs. First of all it's my belief that watching it under the influence of LSD would make little to no difference in the "experience" of witnessing what unfolds. And secondly is the Academy and/or people who thought this was good in any way....well are you people on crack? And I'm not exaggerating. In what universe would this be considered a major Oscar winning film? The plot I suppose could have been an intriguing concept to explore. However I was in utter disbelief this was an actual contender for best film and all the other catalogues that it won in. The acting...well there was none. The director after giving a vague idea of the plot could have just as easily said "be crazy and stupid" and we'll include it in the film. It was like a bad dream I would never wish to have. If one can't describe in reasonable detail what happens from scene to scene to scene to another person, something is wrong. Think about what I just said. Even with a photographic memory you couldn't. And you know why? Because there has to be some logic as an aid to help you remember. This was absent, TOTALLY absent. THIS THING WAS A JOKE.

Title: Am I crazy or what?
Review:
I spent much of the day trying to determine whether I and the seeming minority of others who watched this film and despised it are just crazy or what. Multiverse? Hot dog fingers? A bagel that is a metaphor for life choices. Best Picture? OMG...is this what the motion picture industry champions as quality?

Where is Schindler's List, Quiz Show, The Godfather, Chariots of Fire, or even Arthur? What about Dances with Wolves, Shawshank Redemption, and Psycho? Shall I continue going back? Citizen Kane, Wizard of Oz, Gone with the Wind, City Lights?

Undoubtedly, it's time for Asian Americans to get their due in Hollywood. But with this vehicle? I'M SO CONFUSED!

Title: The most overrated movie of all time
Review:
Of all the bad copies of Rick and Morty that appeared recently, this one is by far the worst. It feels like an overlong saturday morning cartoon on cocaine, aimed at five year olds with ADHD. I've never seen a movie that felt so long and boring, while also being hectic and overexcited at the same time.

It remains a total mystery to me why this bunch of silly nonsense is praised by the whole wide world. I really would rather rewatch Titanic II than Everything Everywhere...oh, I should also mention that the title is a disaster in its own right.

If you want some good sci-fi-comedy, watch Back to the Future or Mars Attacks. If you want some headaches, watch this one.

Title: Hyper manic and unwatchable
Review:
I was looking forward to this movie after hearing the premise but 20 minutes in my head was already hurting. 100 mile an hour dialogue, some subtitled some in English even within the same conversation, quick cuts, manic overacting by absolutely everyone. Interesting seeing Jamie Lee Curtis in a different sort of role but didn't last any longer than her first scene before deciding I could live a better life by putting a different movie on. Best thing about it was it was free on Prime so my 20 minute mistake only cost me my time. I feel very lucky to have dodged this bullet based on other reviews.
18 out of 32 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: I wanted to like it, I really did but...plugs?
Review:
I'm a big fan of a lot of the actors in this movie so I was very excited to watch it. Honestly, I wasn't exactly sure what to expect. I guess Michelle Yeoh's character is visited her husband who teaches her how to move through varying universes, which she needs to do so in order to save...something I don't know exactly. I was good until sausage fingers and but plugs happened, then, not so much. There's an underlying theme about family dynamics which is displaced and disjointed. This movie could have stood on its own without the Syfy, kung foo, silliness going on and been only about the family dynamics which would have been better...for me anyway.

I have liked almost everything Jamie Lee Curtis has ever been in, except the last 2 Halloween Movies and this one. She seemed to be over doing it in parts, but that's less on her and more on the director, but somehow, I think it was meant to be that way.

There are a lot of inside jokes to this movie that I just don't get. Maybe it was a book, and the written story would have played out better in my head than this one did on film. Butt plugs? Really?

I didn't get it, I didn't like it, I ended up losing interest and going and making dinner instead of watching this. I really REALLY wanted to like is so badly and had heard great things about it, maybe I just didn't get the joke or I missed a critical piece that would have tied it all together, but I don't think so.

I do recommend watching this movie, if for no other reason, you get to see Ke Huy Quan, famous for the "Goonies," and "Indiana Jones and the Temple of doom," in action again. Jamie Lee Curtis' character is almost funny, Michelle Yeoh carried the movie, and she really did a good job, she deserved an Oscar for holding up this movie. Also, I hadn't seen James Hong in anything in a while. The actors were ok, I just didn't get the whole thing, maybe you will.

Butt plugs? Really?

Title: Oh come on.
Review:
Question. What is the hype around this movie? It is complete nonsense, quite badly made and we have a universe where everyone has hot dogs for fingers....

Some of the acting is cheap, the writing is cheap, the imagination of alternate universes is cheap, the 'message' of the movie is corny an cheap.

It is BAFFLING how this movie has been nominated for Oscars for any category, let alone best film. The Oscars and their credibility have sunk even further down the pan. It whiffs of token gestures. It's an insult to anyone's intelligence watching it and suggesting to them this is possibly the best movie of the last 12 months.

It tries to be funny, Jamie Lee Curtis's performance comes closest to achieving anything like comedic. The end. Even that storyline goes cringe in the end though.

I'll try and end on a positive and say I've sat through worse. That's the best I can do. Complete rubbish.

Title: The film's comedic relief was on the most immature level that it continuously conflicted with the more stable and rational parts of the film.
Review:
If there was ever a film that I wanted so badly to see, and wanted so badly to walk away from within thirty minutes of watching, but tried to stick it out to the end with the expectation that it had to get better, only to be disappointed, it was this film.

Obviously, the main cast of the film was terrific and the directing of the film was incredible. Certainly, the acting was pretty good and the storyline was promising. These qualities gave this film the potential to be one of the greatest of all time, and yet it wasn't.

The film's comedic relief was on the most immature level that it continuously conflicted with the more stable and rational parts of the film. This made such an intelligent concept seem at times down right stupid, and I don't' like stupid films.

Title: WHAT A MESS
Review:
Best picture of the year...are you serious?

Acting awards for the 2 leads...you've got to be kidding me!

What a jumbled mess...glad I didn't pay to see this terrible movie...I want to be entertained...not even close to being entertained...somebody ought to look into what the academy was smoking when they voted for this disaster...film makes absolutely no sense...don't waste your time on this God awful film...then again if you like to movies and not be entertained and enjoy being confused then this dud is for you...you have been warned..and since there is this dumb requirement of number of letters I added this useless mention...

Title: Unbelievably overrated
Review:
Storyline is not that good. It's confusing and chaotic. Pivoting around an (very) stereotypical Chinese family and their gay daughter. At the same time the movie doesn't care about their problems, divorce etc., but mostly a chaotic view to the "pressures" of life, (very very complex) relationships and family and the expectations from the children.

Then you'll have the right to ask am I getting old or is every movie nowadays written from a teenager's point of view to the life?

If you're somehow interested in the concept but expect a nice and meaningful movie, I strongly recommend Mr. Nobody. :)

Title: I get the point, I don't get the treatment...
Review:
I'm happy for anyone on this planet (or Universe) who found depth, mystical salvation, soul liberation or just plain satisfaction from "Everything, Everywhere All at Once". As a detractor, I am in the minority (unless it's a silent majority?) but I won't address my category for there's no point in convincing 'myself'. My mind is broad enough to concede that the concept was innovative and even heartfelt... but Iet me tell the enlightened fans why I didn't like it.

It's not that I don't get "it" whatever "it" is, I have a problem with the stylistic treatment of a rather interesting idea. The exposition does a good job showing a Chinese immigrant lavatory-owner family struggling with financial and relationship crisis (doesn't everybody?) and as they try to fix a fiscal issue, Waymong, the husband (Key Huy Quan), tells his wife Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh) that she can connect herself to an alternate universe where she leads a different life. As a fan of "Butterfly Effect" time travels, alternate scenarios or parallel universes √† la "Matrix", I was on the edge of my seat, ready to embark in one helluva ride.

The excitement didn't last.

The film gets quickly over-the-top with long choreographed fight scenes and characters acting weird before we would get used to their 'normal' selves. Jamie Lee Curtis starts as a colorful tax clerk but quickly turns into some Godzilla-Frankenstein-like creature making hard to take either part seriously. Evelyn is realistically reluctant to 'play the game' and manages to hold the viewers who need elements of empathy ... but once the stakes skyrocket to the level of universe destruction and many Sci-fi/Fantasy archetypes are thrown all over the place, I felt ejected to a live-action anime where anything can happen for the sake of visual shock.

Now, I love thought-challenging high-concept movies, but this one is simply overkilling it. I wouldn't recommend it to any seizure-prone individual for there's such an abundance of jump cuts and dizzying flashy images that I didn't get to my smartphone out of boredom but for relief. It might appeal to viewers accustomed with images popping all out of nowhere without any semblance of coherence. I won't deem the 'TikTok' generation but being fed with so much non sequitur flashiness might build a certain predisposition for embracing weirdness and reassembling a 5000 piece puzzle to get the 'deep' picture.

But maybe my idea of a 'multi-layered movie' is one that doesn't exceed three or four scenarios or subplots or where a certain linearity is maintained. Movies like "Inception", "Run Lola Run" or "Butterfly Effect" had a common thread nonetheless and even the awkward bits were properly overarched. Maybe there's a public who feels like no truth is sacred enough not to be deconstructed and that mayhem can be constructive. That's an interesting theory but I just don't think that narrative shouldn't be fluid, especially when everything else is.

I won't say the film has no depth but I wasn't put in a mood to dig into its creative soil and separate the good weird (talking rocks) from the bad (really, fingers as sausages?). I won't even say it's a cultural thing.

Indeed, ever since "Parasite", the Academy has been partial to Asian cinema with at least two or three major awards for an Asian production or artist. I'm no American, no Caucasian, and I applaud the way Asian visual mastery has conquered the field of entertainment (I just finished "Beef" and that statement also applies for TV productions). That said, I don't think the film should be the figurehead of a new form of entertainment that favors style at the expenses of basic storytelling and this comes from someone who loves Asian cinema. Kurosawa first toyed with narrative conventions and I would have loved to call this film a new "Rashomon".

Some also criticized the agenda. Well, I don't want to get into that turf because of the polemical undertones but let's not pretend the film is politically neutral... the advantage of having so many images popping out is that you can insert any 'Yvan eht Nioj' stuff in the process; when a troubled teen daughter Joy (Stephanie Hsu) hits security guards with a big dildo, turns a hunky mustachioed cop into Carmen Miranda or when a man gets spanked, BD-SM style, it doesn't take a Peterson or Shapiro mindset to find a certain stance against masculinity disguised as an ode for tolerance.

Now, I understand the film was a mainstream phenomenon that couldn't get unnoticed but so were many movies that didn't get a pass for the awards, despite their cult status. The Academy wanted to be in line with a certain hip mentality and award a foreign production... but why so many awards?

Reward editing or art-direction or even directing although it did a better job in misdirecting... but acting? The film doesn't challenge the notion of story but of roles. What's the point of rewarding a performance where one character can be so many at once, when you have countless vignettes, one for vulnerability, one for goofiness, one for badass fighting skills etc. Where is the merit of the actor compared to those who display versatility through one personality, character-development through one specific predicament?

There have been dual personalities or actors playing many characters at once, but the role-fluid button has been so pressed so hard I can't believe this film would forever be in the company of "Network" or "A Streetcar Named Desire" as three acting award winners.

Anyway, I could give a film 1 or 2 out of anger but I do understand the appeal. I tried to appreciate it, but I can't say it's superior or equal to most Best Picture winners, I'd give it a 5 for its technical inventiveness, daringness and catchy title... I won't call it one of the worst films ever but allow me one superlative: it's certainly one of the most frustrating.

Title: Surprised this won 7 categories in Oscars
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Overrated parody
Review:
The movie had potential to go into a serious direction but instead it became a parody comedy with bad special effects. It looked liked a Youtube video from 2012 that imitates a music video. The randomness destroyed all the meaning in the plot.

Title: Utter Rubbish
Review:
Based on the plotline, storytelling, screenplay and effects, Pinocchio would have been a much more worthy winner of the Oscar rather than this drivel. This has been all done before and much better in the Matrix and the MCU. The incoherent plot reminded me of Tenet..... remember that one! Sadly, I watched this film till the very end and yes, I was disappointed. The panel who voted for this at the Oscars must be living in LaLa Land (a much better film) - a classic case of "The Kings New Clothes" syndrome. I shan't be returning to this to see if I missed something - the experience would be too painful.

Review:
This is an odd movie. I hated some of it, didn't like more than I hated, then I enjoyed a bit, and had a few beautiful moments. Kinda like life I guess. The acting was good all around. But, it was just too lonnnggggg, it just kept going and going and I wanted it to end. I gave it 5 stars because I did enjoy some of it.

Title: Worst Best Picture Ever !
Review:
A catchy title. Aside from that it's a complete mess.

I did like the cast but was very disappointed in what they were given to work with. I'm shocked that the Academy would select this film as the Best Picture of the year. Certainly it is not a crossover picture for all demographics. I would think that it primarily attracts a Gen Z audience. I thought that Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis were mostly wasted in their roles. I was happy for Ke Huy Kwan to get back into film but felt he was over the top in his role. The whole film is disjointed, jumbled and confusing.

I did think that some of the action scenes were visually striking but became somewhat repetitive as the film dragged on for over 2 hours.

One viewing was more than enough for me.

I hope the Academy redeems itself next year with a film worthy of Best Picture.

Title: Nothing, Nowhere and Once is too Much
Review:
The best thing about this movie is two rocks on an alien planet falling off a cliff. I'm not kidding! While Hollywood congratulated itself with a bunch of Oscars, the rest of us are scratching our heads trying to figure out what producers were thinking. The film wanted to convey messages about family, love, hardship, duty, and regret. But all the preaching was lost in frantic scene shifting. Even the funny Hollywood veteran, Jamie Lee Curtis couldn't save this outer space shipwreck. Hollywood wants to be relevant and hip. But this two hours-plus waste of outer space is Nothing Nowhere and Once is Too Much.

Title: In the minority, obviously, but I really found it bland.
Review:
Many films, most of them really, tell the same stories. It's just the approach, the style that differs (in some of them, even the style is the same). Daniel Scheinert and his filmmaking partner made it clear in their debut film, 'Swiss Army Man,' what kind of style they were going for: a quirky, absurdist style, and even though I didn't like it, I don't like it, I respected it for its newness. In this film, Daniel takes the story of 'The Matrix' and tells it in his fashion. He makes it seem fresh and original, but the bore I got from watching this was of Olympic proportions.

Dense! You think 'Tenet' was convoluted - buries that! But, if the things in 'Tenet' do start to make sense if you stop to think about them, here, I'm not sure they do. There's so much information coming from everywhere, suffocating you. The film takes you down and then starts beating you to a pulp. But I'm not sure. Maybe I couldn't keep up with it. The whole story felt like it had so many plot holes. Like, a lot of the stuff that happened didn't make any sense. It's weird because the film sells itself as a very grounded movie, regardless of the premise, which it isn't - I'm talking about the filmmakers' approach - but then it switches in the absurdist elements, and it just didn't feel like it all fit nicely. It didn't fit at all.

Most of the films that leave me convoluted also leave me with the urge to rewatch them, but this one doesn't. I didn't appreciate this film, and I don't think I'll ever touch it again. But, who knows? Maybe I'll find myself in the right circumstances - I'll lose a bet or a dare or something, else, there's no way - and I'll watch it again, love it, and think of how wrong I'm being right now. But as of now, as of this first watch, I think 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' is one of the most tedious and tasteless pieces of film I've come across recently. And, to think I've had some bland and distasteful film experiences lately.

Title: Everything about donation (not prizing) of an Oscar to Ugly images
Review:
I should have saved my money not paying the ticket price for this movie and not to listen to pre-oscar predictions, nominations, sick-minded propagandas for sick minded producers of this garbage images; not even attributing it to movie or cinema as art or industry.

The film which is full of incoherent/ugly and mind disturbing images and noises is a terrible insult to viewers' intellects and their presumed capacity to distinguish good from bad, beauty from ugliness and good substance in story development and a garbage bin of ideas treated to become film. The theme and story is so messy and worthless that I do not have to write any more about it and also about those who donated an Oscar to it while disregarding artistic values & aesthetics. The contents, direction and ugly casting is evidently so low and downgraded that it is not worth to spend any more lines on this, let alone paying a single penny to watch.

Title: 4stars
Review:
I gave this movie a four-star rating because, I felt confused the whole time. Even after the movie ended, I still couldn't understand the story fully. "Everything Everywhere All at Once" stands out from other films due to its unconventional approach. The transitions between the past, present, and future added layers of complexity, making it challenging to understand the film.. However, I really liked the visual aesthetics. Such as characters costumes and settings.

Honestly, I don't think I would want to watch this type of movie again because it was difficult for me to follow and understand...

Title: Too much too long all at once
Review:
This movie shows many of the good and bad features of modern cinema. As you can see from the rating, the bad wins.

It is visually stunning, but too much all the time. You can't digest what you see. For something to stand out, it needs contrast: fast/slow, light/darkness, moving/still, and so on. And there is no contrast here.

It is action-packed, but again too much. The tension doesn't build up to explode, it is high all the time. But that is just not the way our brain works. You can't engage in a 2 hour long action scene, so you just disconnect every now and then.

The script has interesting and original concepts about philosophy, mother-daughter relations and life as a whole, but those are just drops in an ocean that is too overcrowded, and thus they don't create the impact they should.

It feels as if the whole movie were a plateau instead of a mountain (or a mountain range). It is high, but it is so flat it feels like a plain. So it becomes boring.

All of the above combined is utterly irritating, and makes the movie hard to watch.

On the other side, the cast is great, there are funny moments, and the whole concept of a middle aged wife as an action hero is brilliant. Maybe 45 minutes less would have helped?

Title: I literally woke up farting
Review:
By the time the raccoon was revealed under the cook's toque as if it was a clever other-dimensional manifestation of Ratatouille's Remy, I had checked out of this movie so hard that I fell asleep and woke myself up with a fart. That's how bad this movie was. If that doesn't make sense don't worry, the rest of the movie won't either. I get the underlying "what you focus your love and attention and compassion on will bear meaningful moments and relationships in your life" storyline, but I've never seen it so painfully and sense-assaultingly portrayed in a movie. In that way, yes it's an original and unique movie. But in that and every other way, I literally hated it.

Title: Immature and Repetitive
Review:
In each scene, the central character needs to summon super fighting powers to survive. The powers are summoned by doing something silly and immature (e.g. Elf inflicted paper cuts between fingers, or finding old bubble gum stuck under a table and using it to blow bubbles, etc.) This same repetition continues from scene to scene. Oddly staged fight scene after fight scene. The central character was also being attacked by her own daughter. Somehow she needed to save her daughter. After several scenes, I felt like I was watching paint dry. There was really nothing new that happened. Perhaps more entertaining for a 10 year old that enjoys goofy comedy.

It very hard to understand how this movie was able to get nominations and win awards.

Title: Hmmm
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Overrated cartoonish mess
Review:

Not much more than a bunch of over CGI'd action/fight scenes for who knows what purpose. 3rd act tries to bring together some semblance of story (or rationale for movie) of mother and daughter coming closer together, but there's no been reason to care or about the characters.

Title: Why all the hype?
Review:
I heard nothing but good things about this movie, then it cleaned up at the Oscars, so I went in expecting something decent.

It's not often I can't finish a film, and I watch some real trash on Prime, but I couldn't get through this. Convoluted plot, woeful acting from everyone other than JLC, just an awful, boring mess. I gave up after some mass brawl in an office block and I don't intend revisiting it. Some of the absolute dirge that gets highly rated in the modern day truly puzzles me it really does. You'd expect a multi-Oscar winner to be in the realms of The Godfather - comic book nonsense like this should be winning Nickleodeon awards at best.

I wonder, if all the characters had been white, would this be so revered? It seems there's a real need to reward diversity nowadays, even if it's to the detriment of quality. How Cate Blanchet missed out on best actress will be a conundrum for the future film students to ponder for decades. Data from the Goonies grabs one for his first major role since the '80s, and he was as wooden as he was back then.

Title: don't waste your time
Review:
Literally just made an IMDB account only for me to rate this boring film 1 star. Don't waste your 2 hours watching this awful movie. 30 minutes in and I'm already yawning. I thought the (minor) twist was going to save it but no it just kept going down and down until the end of the movie. These 1 star reviews you see are true, believe us.

Title: Does not live up to hype
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: An embarassment - Cinema is dying
Review:
I love cinema.

This is not it.

I tried to watch this movie three times, every time after being convinced by some acquitance of the sheer greatness and uniques of the film.

On my third watch (that is going on as I am writing this), I had to make this review. I hate saying it, but its really trash, lowest-tiered entertainment with philosophical aspirations that are laughable.

The key purpose that it served is that it showed that no reliance can be made to film reviewers, critics and that cinema seems to be on a steep downward road.

If this movie was made say 15 years ago, when there was actual competition, the movie and its creators would be ridiculed.

Title: I don't know what I watched
Review:
My wife is Chinese and I am American, and we both just watched what I thought would be an interesting movie being an Oscar winner for 7. However, this winning solidifies that Eternal Sunshine on a spotless mind should have won to all those years ago. There were parts my wife fell asleep, parts that made me laugh, and even parts that were jackass the movie strange. It was hard to follow with language going in and out, and with action sequences it made me a little sick, but it's what Hollywood and todays society want, kindness and love. Except, the world doesn't work that way in parts of it. I honestly am just happy Jamie and Goonies guy got an Oscar, but I have to go watch something else or I will have bad dreams tonight.

Title: Utterly and abomination!
Review:
What the heck! Literally this is an utterly joke ... For the fist time in my life I walked out of the screening room. What's wrong with the film industry nowadays? With the Oscars ? They should be ashamed, Michelle Yeoh should be ashamed, Jamie Lee Curtis... everyone should be so ashamed of accepting awards for this big fiasco.

I came to the movie theatre for all the good reasons: first Asian woman to win an Oscar in a leading role, references to kung fu classics, indie films, original script, kitsch photography etc all that was so badly executed form the beginning without any sense.

I hope soon they will come out with a statement to clarify, that this was actually a joke or an experiment to defy the modern standards in the film industry or something, because this is unbelievable.

Title: The best part of this movie?
Review:
Reading the 8, 9 and 10 star reviews here as people go overboard with superlatives trying to "sell" this movie. Some of the reviews feature adjectives that aren't even actual words.

I gave up on this with a half-hour yet to go.

At the core of this movie is an unoriginal concept about how our lives would be very different if we made different choices in life. In this movie the mechanism isn't angels ("It's a Wonderful Life","The Family Man") but the now overused narrative device of "the multi-verse".

The emotional core of the movie is about a harried Asian woman and her gentle-mannered husband as well as her strained relationship with their daughter.

So far so good.

Then it goes off the rails. It all gets buried under a ton of overdone wire-work martial arts, much shouting and screaming and lots of frantic special effects.

Like a LOT. Like about sixty minutes too much.

I think it was the point where our heroine is fighting two dudes who have anal plugs dangling from their asses that I just rolled my eyes and gave up on it.

At this point I was losing the thread of the plot and, honestly, didn't care about it anymore.

I wanted to get on with an actual story, but we see the same scenes more or less repeated over and over. Crazy fight scene... heroine dies or seem thoroughly defeated... no, wait! She's back up again for another crazy fight scene. And another. And another. Quiet emotional scene with husband or daughter. Then MORE fighting.

It's exhausting and you're a better person than I am if you can get through this endurance contest.

Title: I really liked...
Review:
...the frenetic pace, the humor, all of the absurd parts, but underneath the fun, this movie is just another young adult melodrama, with a bunch of talented actors pushing the emoting up to 11, but around issues that are just petty and banal. The second half, in particular, is just a series of supposedly meaningful dialogue presented with tears and trembling lips. The humor cannot take away from the fact that this movie has nothing to say, really, but takes itself very seriously still. Piling on the allegory does not cover up that the conflicts underneath are just not very interesting or profound. Even Michelle Yeoh was a disappointment.

Title: Over hyped and over rated.
Review:
So that's what a bad acid trip would feel like! It left me with a but of a headache to be honest, why it won all the Oscars is beyond me, however I do feel like a lot of the praise is from those not wanting to be seen as not "getting it" .. well I didn't "get it" but then I lost interest about half way though so? I agree it was original, original in the way that if Kill Bill, The Matrix and Inception had a baby, when that baby grew up a bit, went to university and took drugs, it would have made this movie. I am so glad I didn't pay to watch it in the cinema, it was just too, too much, everywhere, all at once.

Title: Crazy times, brain usage forbidden
Review:
It's a bad movie, but as a comedy is not bad, it has a few funny moments, typical Chinese humor. I lived in China for many years, I know mandarin, I understand their humor (although I don't find it funny, it's very childish) and I know that everyone likes Michelle and they want her to be celebrated. Ok fine, but we'll just, out of nowhere, pretend that meritocracy doesn't exists? We'll just award a product not for its content but for its meaning? Saying this movie is good is the same thing as saying bugs taste good. Bugs have protein, so let's just say bugs are much more delicious than steaks, because of how it represents environmentally. It's more politically correct, so let's all forget about flavor, taste quality, appearance, let's just play the pretend game and just pretend disgusting things are awesome, they're the best stuff in the world. That's what Hollywood and their shills are saying, awarding this movie and saying this is the best movie ever. This is a crazy comedy movie, almost unwatchable, unless you're just passing time, chatting with friends and checking your phone while watching the movie.

People, can we just go back to award stuff that is actually good? And don't bring that "oMG yOu diDnT uNdeRstAnD", we all understood the movie, it's a stupid movie for depressing people who spend their whole day on social media, this movie is basically a long tiktok video.

But some part of me just says: Ah, nevermind this, no one cares about the oscars anymore, and let them have their fun, they're happy. We had our fun with great masterpieces like Goodfellas, The Godfather, Training Day, Inception, The Wolf of Wallstreet, Interstellar, all those really good movies. Now it's time for the... simple people have their fun. I guess we too should pretend that this movie is good, so that you guys feel good. So, yeah... OK.

Cheers.

Title: Best Actors in one of the Worst Movies of 2022
Review:
I am a big fan of Michelle Yeon. In fact, been watching her martial arts movies and other movies that she starred in over the years. Here too she is doing a great job. And her screen husband, Ke Huy Quan is a gem in martial arts. And Jamie is unrecognisable and amazing in her role.

But that is where it ends. The story, utter rubbish from Marvel garbage. The screenplay all over the place. The visual effects, not sure if there is any.

Yes, I endured it for 43 mins as I felt guilty to switch it off earlier due to the nominations and the great actors work.

But this is unwatchable. I really hope the makers take a hard look next time.
27 out of 40 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Drivel - Not Great -
Review:
In what universe is a film starring Jamie Lee Curtis with hotdogs for fingers considered Oscar-worthy? The answer to that question seems to be 'this one', Everything Everywhere All At Once having been nominated in eleven categories at the 2023 Academy Awards. I'm beginning to wonder if I've somehow slipped into an alternate reality where a film's worth is measured by how quirky, irritating and baffling it is.

I believe that this film's success is down to viewers not wanting to admit that they don't 'get' it - "It's A24, and that means it's intellectual, and if I say I don't understand it everyone will think I am stupid". Well I think you're stupid for playing along.

So what's the film about? Well, Michelle Yeoh plays laundromat owner Evelyn Wang, who discovers that the universe is made up of infinite parallel realities, each one different, and that an evil force is attempting to... ah, who am I kidding? I can't sum up this film. I tried to follow the plot, but there's so much random crap crammed into the excruciatingly tedious 139 minutes, all edited so as to induce a migraine, that I soon found myself struggling, not just to understand the plot, but to stay watching till the end.

Title: Some Sort of Insane, Drug-Induced, Deranged Version of the Matrix
Review:
Michelle Yeoh can usually be counted on to be in decent films but I knew this was going to be bad when it immediately starts off with their daughter dating an ugly tatted up lesbian while the manic mother (Yeoh) kept making a bad Jewish joke about actress Jenny Slate having a "big nose" yet she is the best looking actress in the entire film.

There is this odd trend in certain films of trying to make gibberish into science fiction. In this doing moronic nonsense like eating ChapStick, chewing old gum stuck under a table and giving yourself paper cuts between your fingers helps activate a plot device. I literally felt myself getting dumber the longer it went on and the more I watched, the more I wanted to kill myself.

Jamie Lee plays an obnoxious IRS agent who turns into some zombie terminator in the most cringe inducing way possible. I don't know if the writer, producer or director were all high on drugs when they decided to make this but it is painfully bad. Over and over again they inject weird and bizarre scenes with lame Kung-Fu sequences to the point of a migraine.

If I could give this film a negative 10 rating I would, as it is some sort of insane, drug-induced, deranged version of the Matrix. Avoid at all costs.

Title: When you get misled by user reviews
Review:
There are many more lower rated movies worth watching compared to this.

I always hate movies that are pretentious. People tend to give them interpretations and meanings that are not really there. Aside from it being dragging on many occasions, I find the presentation a bit chaotic; like some abstract art where there is a bandwagon consensus of a deeper meaning and a more profound message that is non-existent.

Title: Subversive
Review:
If you don't have anxiety about the IRS, you will after watching this. If your teen child is uncooperative, you will start to worry big time after the watching this. If you always wanted a butt plug, watch this. If you wanted to listen to hours of unpleasant speech, watch this. If you want to be bombarded with lightening images amidst chaos, watch this. Whatever you do, say you love it. And agree with Oscar morons who must own Asian stock. This film is unpleasant to watch.

It is excruciating to listen to. I have seen other majestic Asian films. Why would anyone think this has humor? The receipts spread out for an audit is a nightmere. The IRS is never something to joke about. The multi universe is just more unpleasantness. I bought the dvd hoping for greatness. I discovered subversion.

Title: Stunningly bad
Review:
I'm honestly amazed that anyone could give this complete mess a good review. That fact is a clear reflection of how far our society has fallen.

This may not be the worst movie ever made, but it is so close to the worst that you can just consider it so. Incomprehensible, stupid beyond words, offensive and disgusting at parts.

If there is a point of redemption for this movie it must have come in the last hour, because, at the point where the words "The End" came across the screen we said "thank God", only to see that there was actually another hour to go. At that point we said "no way" and turned this cinematic disaster off.

How this qualified to even be in the running for an Oscar is hard to comprehend, let alone win so many. Could all of the other movies actually be so incredibly bad that this rose to the top?

Title: Too long.
Review:
If this move had been 1.5 hours it would have been a fun and amusing watch, with good acting and witty connections between generational gaps, Asian parenting set against a clever underlying set of multiverse of you with different skills. 2.2hours turned the movie into one I was just happy ended as it had no new ideas and it dragged out the silly making them dull. Great performance by Michelle Yeoh.
13 out of 20 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: I Expected Greatness...I Got Jipped.
Review:
I heard someone say this should win "Best Picture". When it did, I thought maybe the Oscar's got it right.... No! How this measures up to Best Pictures in the past is beyond me.

The term "multiverse" should have been a tip to my disappointment but I watched. As others mentioned. I enjoyed the last part, but the other parts were just a movie. Jamie Lee Curtis did not deserve an Oscar for that role. If I were given the choice, I thought the daughter, Joy, was more deserving.

I just don't get why this won all these awards and such praise. Oscars, as usual, are NOT a measure of greatness...at least not in this universe.

Title: What a mess
Review: I really had to force my way through this one. The plot makes no sense whatsover. Some funny moments and cool ideas regarding the multiverse and how we are living all these parallel lives. Not sure that is true or not but it's fun to think so especially when nothing goes our way. The characters are boring and miserable except the dad who is quite sweet and has some serious kung fu moves! The trippy sequences were not done very well. Reminded me a bit of that film Mr. Nobody which i never got. And also the show Legion which did this kind of thing at a very masterful level with cool, sexy characters with dark humor and great music mixed in (unlike in this besides Debussy piano toes part, that was funny). At least the film is attempting something different which i can appreciate. Just never connected with the story or characters, I felt like I am having a bad trip and please be over soon and it just kept on going and making less and less sense. I wish it would've ended the first time it said The End when there was still an hour to go. Anyways, I'm Markus and this is my first review. Go listen to my music on spotify, just search for Vicevoids. And connect with me on social media. Hope you enjoyed my review. Bye. Good luck to anyone even trying to write spoilers for this! Not possible.

Title: What a Load of Rubbish
Review:
No stranger to psychedelic experiences or to knowing a good movie when I see one.

There are very few movies I've turned off before the end. This one was stuck in a boring loop of inter-portal jumping while nothing really happened and could not bear it any more.

I'm confused as to how this nonsense received any attention when there are other films on display this year that are astoundingly brilliant and moving.

Is this some kind of statement being made by the awards panels which I do not know about or understand?

I've always held the Oscars in high regard, like the Olympics and the World Cup for example, but for this rubbish to win, and not powerful, memorable, heart-wrenching performances and stories in at least 3 other films is absolutely beyond me. The Oscars have lost their worth.

Review:

Title: Unbearable
Review:
I watched it from start to finish wondering if Hollywood is living in a parallel reality.

Confusing characters, no charisma. Bad performances. Confusing and non-linear plot.

Jaime Lee Curtis put a final nail in her coffin.

I couldn't even laugh or cry. I paused many times to see if I understood the purpose of this despicable joke.

How to identify if it's science fiction, adventure, comedy with this crazy script?

Honestly what a disappointment.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences showed that to win an Oscar you don't need to have quality.

Sadly, the Oscar went to the worst movie I've ever seen.

Title: Jumbled Confusing Mess
Review:
I gave this a 1, it is probably more deserving of a 5 but I thought I'd try and offset some the ridiculous 10's that it has been given. I watch movies to be entertained not to give my a brain a workout trying to understand what is going on. Movies in my opinion shouldn't be hard work and that's what this movie was hard work from start to ever so long finish. 2 hours and 19 minutes of crazy.

Title: I guess I just didn't "get it"
Review:
When I walked out after the movie was finished, all I could think was "what the heck was that?" I mean the cinematography was great, the effects were great... But the story... well not so great.

It really fell apart in the third act with no explanation of how such unknown random acts would give them "powers" where earlier there was a whole process to lead them to them.

Like I said, I guess I just didn't "get it".

Review:

Title: Disappointed
Review:
I was really excited to see this after watching the previews. I thought awesome, this should be a decent sci-fi film. Well, like so many times before, the science fiction is a fake wrapper designed to hook more viewers. There is little of substance here in that regard and you'll be angry afterwards. I went back and re-watched Jet Li's "The One" to rescue the situation.

The remaining aspects of the film are a blend of cheese, stupidity, crass attempts at humor and of course woke preaching. Funny how none of the 'verses featured a normal nuclear family, since that wouldn't fit the accepted narrative.

So ultimately a waste of time.

Title: Good Story Lost in a Convoluted Mess
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Totally overrated!
Review:
I have a high expectations of this movie not only the high rating but also with positive reviews about its creativity and implication. I end up getting a sound sleep at the last half hour. It starts off not that bad with developing some funny characters but then it get lost with having just a single plot about a woman's head splitting. This scene pops up over hundred times which becomes a kind of nuisance and chaos.

Title: Minority View
Review:
I'm going to be in the minority view here.

Because from the title on down, this film made little sense. I'll say up front, maybe I have to watch it again. It put me to sleep at some points.

Title: It's not the ubiquitous, all-encompassing, relatable story the name suggests. It's a very specific, unique perspective told of events that quite honestly, will never happen to most of us (read: any).

Because, while Im a massive fan of Marvel, this film's clumsy take on the multiverse setting is either a cheap imitation or a poorly executed one. And overly complicated, as with the Marvel movies.

Minorities: Probably I'm not allowed to speak of this, but just because you have actual Asian actors, doesn't mean you can use the same cliches: laundry store- owning, helicopter-y, disapproving traditional mom, slavishly beholden to her aging parents, poorly understanding the complicated American system... And there's more that I can't even think of now.

But come one, much of this was cringey, and I'm not in the afflicted minority. I'm surprised there aren't, if not protests in the streets, at least a little more backlash from "critics." I'm usually on board with the prevailing sentiment on these "great" films, but here's one I have to be in the minority upon.

Title: Second time I've walked out the movie theater early in my life
Review:
Walked out after 40 minutes, was anxiously waiting to tell my gf I painfully can't watch this anymore. The movie was stupid, I love the concept of the multiverse but it was done in a silly stupid way, not scientific. Like how are you going to be stupid enough to go into a different universe when you're in mid convo with the IRS. Why would you fight security in the IRS when they have all of your info... why would anyone think you're a hero for that. I was originally excited to see it because of the reviews, but in my entire patience I sat and watched as long as I could. I think im just a deeper thinker and have read and watched a lot of science based theory's. The execution of the concept was boring and stupid to be blunt. I do not recommend the movie and am baffled at how it has been getting high reviews.

Title: I felt like I took drugs, and got a bad trip...
Review:
So, the movie Everything Everywhere all at once (2022).

The first few minutes of the movie are really promising.

Just a normal intro. But then it gets really weird, and not in a good way. It also gets really boring.

Thats why I lost my interest really quickly.

The music in the movie is okay, and the images are also okay (could be better though).

I didn't see any famous actor, when I recall it correctly.

For anyone who wants to watch this movie, I would say DO NOT DO IT. ITS A WASTE OF YOUR TIME.

I always check the trailers on for head of the movies and series online. Hoping this will help.

Title: Complete Waste of Time
Review:
I watched about 2/3's of this. Just couldn't force myself to watch the rest.

It's weird and bizarre and just didn't flow very well.

The filming was good and character did their job. Some of the scenes would have been better to just leave them out. Just because you can do something doesn't mean you should.

This movie sucks, I stopped halfway. All this nonsense talking from the start of the film gave me stress and headache. It is overly hyped by this people.

Title: 7 Oscar's, countless 10/10 ratings... OMG!
Review:
Somewhere in the middle is a 3 min scene with 2 stones talking. Really sweet and... moving! 2 points for that! And that's it! You can skip the rest. Find this scene in a preview/trailer and you're good.

The movie is hard to watch because it is confusing. Constantly skipping from scene to scene and mixing English and Chinese dialogs. This constant skipping gets on your nerves because it is pointless and random. You can mix these scenes in any order and it's the same movie. I bet that if somebody would do that, nobody would notice when watching a second time. Better, you can take an one hour nap and you won't notice because it's the same crap repeating itself at random.

Content was grotesque. Doing random bodily harming and sexual actions to move between universes is daft and a script for low IQ audience.

Oscar's for acting? Really? Acting was just ok. A plus for JL Curtis.

Personally I stopped watching after 90 min and forced myself to resume the second day to discover the promised deep meaning that everybody is talking about. There is none! Just endless crap.

Title: Awful.
Review:
We all know why this has been showered with awards and praise, and it has nothing to do with the quality of the movie itself.

All it's to do with, is back slapping about how virtuous and inclusive Hollywood is. So tiresome, and no wonder Hollywood is struggling when a niche product like this is praised to the heavens, and movies genuinely loved by film goers are left out in the cold.

When are Hollywood going to wake up and realise they need to start appealing to the masses again if they're to survive?

Going to the cinema isn't a cheap night any longer, and promoting stuff like this that is going to appeal to a small minority of people, isn't going to convince people to go again.

Title: After the Oscars
Review:
This mess of a movie is totally insulting to the general population of movie goers. The possibility exists that the Producers, writers and directors thought they could use "the emperors new clothes" tack and make a really idiotic movie. They were hoping one critic would love it and the praise would snowball. However, the general population sees through it (see how many folks here rated it very low). I've seen thousands of movies in my lifetime and almost all of the 95 Best Picture Oscar winners. Some were great and other mediocre, BUT nothing even comes close to this insulting, moronic, idiotic movie. We should all feel insulted that the Academy members voted for this movie and gave it 7 awards and the critics gave it high praise. They must think we are really stupid. How dare they. They have forgotten they still need our support or they just don't care.

Before the Oscars This movie has a unimaginable plot line that moves so quickly you are not able to follow it. There are so many quick changes and poorly done special effects it renders the plot line totally confusing. There are some really good actors, but I wonder how they felt about the finished product. The Hollywood elite gave it 11 Oscar nominations. Why on earth! For those of you who liked this movie, I am glad you did, but you need to check out past Oscar nominated/winning movies to see the difference. I started watching this a few weeks ago and stopped after 20 minutes realizing what a bad movie it was, but after the nominations I decided to give it another chance. I barely finished it while shaking my head in disbelief the entire time.

Title: A Movie About Nothing
Review:
I realize that I'm old-fashioned, but I prefer movies that have a plot. This is a movie about nothing. The fight scenes rapidly got tedious because nothing was ever settled; they just jumped to another universe. And I never figured out what they were fighting about anyway. I wasn't sure whether the parts that I thought were funny were actually intended to be humorous. The ending was corny. I gave it 3 stars for the creativity that it took to come up some of the universes. And because it's not the worst movie that I've ever seen, or even the worst that I've seen in the last year (Top Gun Maverick was worse).

Is it possible for this movie to have as many Oscars as Lawrence of Arabia????? What's going on here??? The Oscars were to be shared between Tar and All quiet from the western front.

I put the two stars just for the effort!!

Title: Reminds me of "Sucker Punch"
Review:
A woman with lots of problems - financial, family - escapes mentally into different parallel worlds where she is some kind of heroine determined to save all worlds and fights against an evil entity which she thinks has taken over the tax collector and her daughter and is to blame for everything. Some unneccessary vulgarity, very boring plot, non-interesting characters. Inconsistent ways to travel to parallel universes - e.g. Pee your pants, blow into the nose of somebody or start dancing. It is like a low-budget movie made by students. This movie is way too long for what it delivers, should have finished after part 1 (there are three parts - everything, everywhere and all at once). I did not enjoy a single scene. The references to - much better - movies like "Ratatouille" and "The Matrix" were childish and lame. I cannot comprehend why this movie won any Oscar.

Title: Much ado about a bad trip!
Review:

There's absolutely zero narrative that gets you from the beginning to the end. It's two hours of nonsensical mind mash. I cannot fathom all the Oscars, in particular, and I mean no disrespect to a great actor, Jamie Lee Curtis. Her character was quirky yet pointless, she did her best but Oscar worthy, no! All I can say is don't believe the hype, this is awful!

Title: Overhyped
Review:
I thought it was decently made, really incredible idea, but not necessarily unique. It makes you ingest a ton of depressive ideas, which are difficult to follow at times, before it delivers the emotional antidote. Makes you feel like depresion is the default if you're not able to achieve anything. This made it difficult to enjoy, since the climax of the delivery was based on your acceptance of some pretty sorrowful views to begin with. Superb acting, great effects, and lovely idea, but the execution was misguided imo. The amount of hype is a bit egregious at this point, since only the acting and effects were award worthy.

Title: Contrary Opinion- Not Impressed
Review:
The movie's production value itself is quite incredible and I found myself frequently enjoying the action scenes and the character growth.

I however, dislike the basis of which the plot forms. It centers around a nihilistic approach on life that nothing matters and our dent in the universe is basically zero. The life of the characters is seen as meaningless and that nothing matters. It also puts too much of an emphasis on choices when our reality is that our freedom isn't as much as we think.

The movie itself was very difficult to follow. Lots of jumps and cuts. The mechanisms of action are hard to understand. Events happen in the plot simply without explanation as to why. The producers couldn't seem to determine if this movie was a drama, a comedy, or a sci-fi.

Title: Pseudo-intellectual chaos
Review: It's one of those things with the Oscar winners of recent years. Most of the time, not many viewers want to see the films and the question always arises whether commercialism is fundamentally not worthy of an award and whether the Oscars must always be about art, which is often very subjective. In the case of the winning film of 2023, I can only say that I am not really happy with the decision. After 30 minutes I didn't understand what it was all about and even though I think Michelle Yeoh is well worth seeing, I am left with a question mark as to whether I would really have given her the Oscar for best actress. Strangely enough, this comedy as such doesn't work at all. Hectic, overloaded with prejudices, including racist moments, which, however, originate from the supposed Chinese woman, comedy that is more reminiscent of bad slapstick and individual performances that don't add up to anything. After 30 minutes I was no longer prepared to get involved in the story, which is unravelled in such a confused way that I suspect that quite a few viewers will not have experienced the ridiculous kung fu scene in the tax office at all.

Title: Horrible
Review:
I don't understand the hype surrounding this movie. I suspect it is the Lemming syndrome where everyone is jumping off the cliff with glee together.

I am not one to agree just because others do. I thought this production was pure crap, and I clearly land in the minority on that point according to the vast majority of reviewers. But I'm totally ok with being where I am on this one.

For starters I don't like sub titles, secondly I find asian dialects irritating at the best of times, then when the sub titles were turned off I could barely pick out any words due to the very thick accents. I totally dismissed this garbage when a female actor laid a beating on someone using a pair if dildos as weapons. Pretty much the worst piece of garbage I've ever wasted my time watching. Oscar sweep? Laughable.

Title: Cinema is dying

Just a bad videogame - everything, everywhere is killing the love of cinema. Really, nothing happens. You just observe something irrelevant in a certain set... Next minute, the film changes set, just because. There's nothing fantastic in it, just a change of set as if you were playing a videogame: one button to to the left, one button to the right... and some characters mumbling an irrelevant dialogue. Title: The film for our times
Review:
Unlikely award winner Everything Everywhere All At Once is perhaps the first film to capture the chaotic mental dopamine of constant Internet use, which is not necessarily a good thing, though obviously most people can relate. Attempting philosophy, action, and comedy all at once, the film can be best summed up as a mixture of the Matrix, a Stephen Chow or Jackie Chan film, It's a Wonderful Life, and Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen. A disparate set of influences, nearly all of which are better films.

Stylistically, the Daniels borrow the most from Michael Bay here, pushing his type of rapid-cut, juvenile sensory overload to arty levels. They nevertheless lack both Bay's sense of composition (con), and also his misanthropy (pro, though the stuff they do to Jamie Lee Curtis goes beyond unflattering). Still, the overall effect the film produces is about the same, especially when it comes to the humor.

Unlike the Kung-fu comedies of Chow, the humor of EEAAO lacks a sense of comic delirium and is mostly fractured and crude instead. When in Chow's 'Shaolin Soccer' a soccer game transforms into a trench war, it's funny not only because it's unexpected, but also because it parodies the intensity of the sport. Had the Daniels made that film they would have just as likely turned the game into a sex dungeon. Too often they're only willing to throw random stuff at you in place of actual wit---the concept that alternate realities can be experienced through statistically improbable actions is funny at first, but gets dull very quickly, especially as it's used almost exclusively for high school gross-out humor: inhaling flies, sticking mucus in someone's mouth, etc.

The resulting action scenes lack the smooth inventiveness of even a lesser Jackie Chan film. For another example, the fight in 'The Accidental Spy' where Chan, completely naked, tries to beat off several assailants (while covering his privates with anything at hand) is infinitely funnier than anything offered here. The main reason is that the best humor, like Chan's, needs some basis in reality so you can understand the characters' reactions and frustrations. The Daniels have that in the opening scenes but quickly abandon it, choosing instead to indulge a kind of TikTok randomness.

It can still be imaginative (I'll give it that) but only up to a certain point. You'd think a reality where people evolved giant hot dogs for fingers would look entirely different even in terms of simple objects such as doorknobs and shirts, but the Daniels merely show us the same world, only where people play the piano with their toes and squirt condiments at each other. Again, this is more about throwing random crap at the screen instead of allowing the premise to develop naturally.

So the film fails as a comedy, but how about as a philosophical tract? Like 'It's a Wonderful Life', EEAAO deals with the lost chances of life, 'what might have been' through alternate reality. It goes without saying that Capra's film is far more mature and thoughtful, but it's also more emotionally moving. The Daniels are able to engage nihilism head-on, since especially in the face of the infinite multiverse any form of meaning melts away. The problem is that they don't know how to address it; the idea that humans are no more than insignificant specks is only indirectly repudiated, and the final message is spoken: 'We don't know what's happening in this world, but just be kind to each other!' This conclusion is so basic that it's beyond criticism, except for the fact that it is so basic. EEAAO lacks Capra's edge---advocating as he did kindness and happiness even in the face of intolerant cruelty---though the Daniels' shallow Hollywood Gnosticism has obviously struck some kind of chord in our culturally confused, digitally-addled times.

Title: There isn't enough Rick And Morty to make this "Cloud Atlas 2.0" enjoyable.
Review:
The main draw for me to see "Everything Everywhere All At Once", was the fact that Ke Huy Quan was in it, since I really enjoyed his performances as a child actor, ever since "Indiana Jones And The Temple Of Doom", I figured it would be interesting to see him in something new, all grown up, all these years later...

Also, I hated "Cloud Atlas"; any movie that's insane and makes no sense, does not mean it's smart or intelligent, let alone does it make a great film.

I have been a fan of Rick And Morty for several years now, I have been behind the idea of there being many alternate realities / multiple universes for over a decade now, however, this film fails in everything that could have made that concept interesting on a cinematic level.

Nauseating editing and quick cutting, over the top and ridiculous acting, cheap effects that resemble a low budget "skit" like you'd see on Saturday Night Live (especially involving a dumb parody of the 2007 Pixar film "Ratatouille"), everything that this film did, was done better many, many times before in different films, however it DOES succeed in being as migraine-inducing as "Cloud Atlas".

Nothing is explained well through any of this film's dialogue, instead leaving me no choice but to resort to the e-Cliff's Notes site (aka Wikipedia) just to make any sense of what was going on for the third act (chapter 3 or what ever).

The Matrix did it better, Kill Bill did it better, Ratatouille did it better, The Jacket (2005) did it better... oh, and Turning Red, did it better.

This film kept making me want to turn it off and switch to watching something else throughout, or well, at least after the first 30 minutes or hour; morbid curiosity, at just how far and how crazy it could possibly go, is what kept me watching until the end.

I did enjoy seeing Ke Huy Quan, though... but wow, he seriously deserves better roles and work. I mean, if he enjoyed making this film, I guess that I'm happy for him then.

Title: One of the worst movies ever
Review:
My wife and I had to stop watching this garbage after 45 minutes or so. The only reason we watched this long was the 8.1 rating it had with almost a quarter million ratings. We finally got to the point we couldn't tolerate the stupidity and nonsense any longer. Don't waste your time. There isn't one redeemable quality to this movie. Annoying actors, no decent dialogue, no redeemable plot. Nothing. The funny thing was I instantly recognized the one actor as Data from the Goonies and Indiana Jones movies. Jamie Lee Curtis sure got old too. I'm just writing this last stuff to meet the minimum character requirement.

Terrible movie. Just terrible!
