Title: Where are we going to?
Review:
The fact that this movie was even nominated speaks volumes of what we already knew long ago about the Oscars.

That it gets nominated, that there are good reviews and critics, speaks about money. However, that people out there is saying convincingly it is good, that it has 9/10 ratings, is a bleak outlook of our future.

I could not force myself to watch the entire... thing. Believe me, I tried. Did not have the stomach, and frankly, nor the time.

Extremely bad script, horrible photography, bursts of bad acting by everyone, and I mean everyone. Terrible directing, sad attempts to comedy, very cheap production. No plot line. Nothing to rescue here.

One thing that baffles me, is that no one involved in this movie said "I'm sorry, this is wrong, I can't"

Title: I am wondering if there are voting bots that gave this film 30% 10/10 votes.
Review:
This film had an interesting premise and some interesting ideas and some interesting images. Unfortunately, those who made the film did not now that "less is often more" and they tried to overwhelm the viewer, reiterating the same ideas, recycling the same (or similar) fighting scenes, hitting you over the head over and over, until one wants to shout at the screen "enough! I got it already!". It gives the impression of a dish in a restaurant where they pile up the spices, the calories, the textures - just to impress you.

If someone would have edited this film to about 70% of its actual length, it may have ended up a more than decent film.

I would have American directors spend some time watching (quality) European or Japanese films and learn why "less is more" and that "louder", "shocking" and "overwhelming" are not conveyors of quality.

Title: What a hot mess of weirdness
Review:
After all the acclaim and Oscar nominations, I sought out this film ready to be wowed. Wow, alright.

This was just weird and, frankly, boring. Really boring. That people claim to have been mesmerized and profoundly impacted by this film is frightening.

I don't care to work that hard when I'm the one who's supposed to be entertained. After nearly 1 hour, I still had no clue what was going on or why I would care in the least.

I was so disappointed because, and I'm not joking, this film seemed more like a very amateur foray into, I don't know, Scifi? Action? Mind freaking? Creativity?

Bolognie. This is nothing more than David Lynch weirdness or Cronenburg weirdness, just not as good.

Title: Emperors new clothes
Review: I love indie movies. So when I read abou this movie, I was hoping to see a good one, but it was a big let down. The movie isn't original, the message is generic and done before, and the acting is moderate. Especially if you consider the previous movies they all played in before. To me this is a case of 'the emperors new clothes'; people like it because other people say so. Even if they don't understand it, they have to like it because of FOMO. I also watched the other oscar contenders and it's painfullly clear this movie didn't deserve the awards. It's good Aian actors got an award, but as said before, they've been in much better movies. I am look at you Crouching tiger, hidden dragon, which is btw more a representation of what Chinese people like to see than this movie. EEAO just tries to be different and dazzle you with cheap effects and a pseudo-science sauce, but not once it gets the right message across. This could've been a much better movie if they changed the wacky style. This is not a movie for the public, this is a movie for the directors themselves, and thus they don't appreciate their viewers. It gave me a headache after four viewings. I wanted to like it, but no... avoid this one.

Title: Make it make sense!
Review:
Once upon a time I decided to watch this movie to see why it was getting so many award nominations. I was shocked to find out how hard this movie was to watch. All the characters talk over each other, the scenery is a mess, the plot is a mess, and honestly, you'll have a better time if you turn down the volume and just imagine up the dialogue yourself. Title: I love this movie, but I hate it.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: A Mess
Review:
I watched this film based on the 8.1 rating and some of the rave reviews and I am astounded at such praise for this mess of a film.

It started out fine as Michelle Yeoh and her husband are called to an IRS office in a dispute over the taxes they owe on their laundry.

Jamie Lee Curtis is funny as the IRS auditor who is making their lives difficult.

Early on the film turns completely bizarre with Yeoh entering an alternate universe with a series of nonsensical scenes and endless kung fu encounters with numerous villains.

A giant bagel is at the center of the story and it left me scratching my head in bewilderment.

Please take my advice and save yourself from two hours and nineteen minutes of nonsense.

Title: Def. not Oscar worthy
Review:
Sitting through the first 30 minutes was hell. Trying to keep up with whatever was happening was exhausting. The characters were definitely trying too hard, everything about this film was outrageous. I wouldn't recommend it to anybody I know :)

Sometimes a very "unique" movie makes the cut, and gains a lot of attention-"EEAaO" was it this time around for the Oscars. The fact that it won 7 out of its 11 nominations does not make it a great movie, just a lucky one-the Academy just perceived it as a great one, but it's not.

I strongly disagree with some of the Oscars it won, including Best Supporting Actress (Jamie Lee Curtis) and Best Actress (Michelle Yeoh)-it is clear that these two awards should've gone to Angela Bassett for her performance in "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever", and Cate Blanchett for her performance in "T√°r". Snubs aren't really strange at the Oscars, it happens all the time, but what a shame for the other great films and actors that could've won.

Title: Love it or Hate It (I hated it)
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

Title: Unentertaining
Review:
The main actors and actresses were good. There was not much of a story to follow and no structure to anything. Everything was a mash of very brief absurdities / bizarre happenings (hence other reviewers referring to it as an acid trip). I kept hoping it might get better and saw it through to the end. It was really long and boring. Confusing if asking oneself - why is this still going on and what has happened to the story?

Based on reading the positive reviews, it seems like viewers feel positive from finding hidden messages about emotions and human behaviour. Perhaps too, from happenings in the film triggering personal memories.

Maybe you'll like it if you consider yourself full of emotion and have good memory.

Not entertaining if you like what you're watching to have something of a structure or a story. It was a sore disappointment.

The rating of 8.1 and top #200 makes me wonder if a lot of bots are involved. Always check the newest reviews for more reliable ones.

Title: There is no story, plot, or events that you can link together
Review:
There is no story, plot, or events that you can link together and follow.. The movie is about excerpts that have no link between them. They were put together with weak plots (which won an Oscar).. I do not know how these major awards such as the Oscar, BAFTA, or Golden Globe are awarded?? ? Is it for films that do not contain a coherent story .. This insignificance wins an Oscar ? The Oscars, rather, it is correct to depend on its location in the box office, which means whether or not the film deserved to have people pay money or money to watch it. However, I regret wasting more than two hours of my life on this insignificant film.

Title: Pretentious Altered Reality
Review:
After all the hype and buzz, we finally sat down to stream "Everything, etc." tonight. My first reaction is, why all the hype and buzz? There's not much here that we haven't seen in one form or another before.

* Failing relationships confronted and reevaluated? Check.

* Multi-cultural confusion? Check.

* Alternate universes? Check.

* Altered reality? Check and double check.

With the exception of the concept and script, this is a well crafted film. It's visually stunning, with exceptional acting by Michelle Yeoh. At least some of those Oscar nominations are well deserved. The martial arts sequences are technically well done, if overlong. But at its core, it's still a mishmash of pretentious clich√©s - Kill Bill meets Interstellar meets The Matrix.

Title: Terrible and profoundly boring
Review:
I'm a fan of absurd humour. I like Jackie Chan & Michelle Yeoh. I like films which have a long build up... but this... this... something is just boring, pointless, stupid (oh yes, and I like slapstick humour). I couldn't even watch it till the end and had to turn off after an hour and a half, my worst spent 90 minutes. Avoid... just...avoid.

PS: my reference to Jackie Chan is meant for this second class Jackie Chan look alike...

Title: Overrated
Review:
I was really looking forward to watching Everything Everywhere All at Once, but I was sorely disappointed by this overrated and silly B-grade sci-fi drama. The premise sounded intriguing: a Chinese-American woman who can access infinite realities and use her alternate selves to save the universe. But the execution was sloppy, confusing and boring. The movie tried too hard to be quirky and meta, but it ended up being a mess of clich√©s and nonsense. The characters were flat and unlikable, the plot was full of holes and contradictions, and the special effects were cheap and cheesy. The movie wasted the talents of Michelle Yeoh, who deserved a better script and direction. I don't understand why this movie got so much hype and praise from critics and audiences alike. It was a waste of time and money. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

Title: I passionately hate this film.
Review:
My instincts told me to avoid after watching the trailer. It reeked of being the sort of try-hard artsy, divisive loved/hated sort of film that happens every so often. I should've listened to my instincts.

If you want a "fun, silly" ride, this ain't it, at least not for me. I recommend watching RRR (Rise Roar Revolt) instead. RRR was delightfully absurd and over-the-top but in an enjoyable way that leaves you in a great mood. I was similarly skeptical with that film at first, but before I knew it three hours flew by and I was only disappointed it had to end.

I had similar hopes for this film. Nope.

In comparison, EEAO is a flaming dumpster floating down a flooded street in a hurricane of pretentious nihilistic post-modern suck, that just leaves you feeling like you finally escaped an intensely exhausting ordeal with someone having a psychotic break.

It was painful to watch from beginning to end.

The family of characters is introduced, and they are cliche, irritating in different ways, and unlikable. You may hope that will change. It won't. The plot is paper thin with no room or time for them to believably change.

The film gradually ramps up with increasing absurdity like a bad acid trip, and once it's fully off the rails, it stays there for what seems like an insufferable eternity.

The humor: So outlandish, vulgar, and immature that even my raunchy-comedy/adult-cartoon loving partner grew tired of it very quickly.

The action/fighting: Relies heavily on the absurdity of the above humor rather than exciting originality or execution. It's stunningly dumb and unbelievable, which in turn makes it boring and unimpressive to watch. As an action fan, this probably pained me the most. I won't even mention how many films it ripped off, poorly, even as a parody.

Take the comedy, the action, and add in an extremely shallow, barely fleshed out concept of a multiverse to disappoint the sci-fi fans, and then beat it to death over and over because apparently the audience is too dumb to get it the first 50 times. It's as if the filmmakers were so utterly impressed with themselves for being 'So creative! So quirky! So edgy!' that they just couldn't stop, move on, and get on with it.

Then in the last half hour or so, the filmmakers suddenly remembered they were supposed to be making a movie and clumsily shoehorned in a bad attempt to have a point and character development. But it was too little, too late, feeling completely forced and frankly unwelcome after the pile of garbage I just endured.

I've lost a great deal of respect for anyone involved with or involved with promoting this film. I hated virtually every tortured minute of it.

Glad individually they got Oscars but overall film was really not great :(

Apparently I need to carry on writing as my review is too short. Seems a bit weird as I'd already written pretty much all I had to say, but as 600 words is the minimum I need to keep going... almost done... phew!!!

Title: Too much of everything & all at once.
Review:
This movie got very high ratings. And I get it - it's imaginative, different, crazy, unconventional. But at two hours-plus, it is also unrelenting and wearisome.

I thought it was melodramatic and ironically I had this feeling of "I am watch this from another dimension". I wasn't in the story, I was spectating a movie instead.

Similarly ironic, I didn't care about any of the characters whatsoever because everything could happen at any moment, all at once. There was no purpose to invest in the story because there wasn't any real threat, just chaos. The daughter said it herself: "it is all purposeless because everything is possible". Very nihilistic in a way.

It was fun to see the protagonist gained skills from other dimensions, but set aside the funny visual gags and fighting scenes, I didn't think that concept was leveraged that much creatively.

A movie that bombarded me with so much visuals and melodramatic craziness left me bored and uninvested.

I did love the way how the mind made the travel between dimensions possible. The production value: editing, direction, post-production, etc was top notch. The acting was average. Not bad but nothing that'll remember tomorrow.

Title: A Kung fu, Zombie, Slasher dud
Review:
Imagine giving millions of dollars to a bunch of sophomores at film school and asking them to make a kung fu, zombie, slasher movie within a multiversal time-loop so the audience trapped inside a video game. Then with a slender plot device, stage it as a three-act play to better fool sophisticates into imagining they're seeing something weighty.

If you think that's a great idea for the best movie of the year welcome to the 2023 Academy Awards where "Everything Everywhere All at Once" just won seven Oscars. So, now you don't have to sit (and sleep) through two hours and twenty minutes of a futuristic fable, because I already did. And what's the moral of this fairy tale? Be nice to your daughter and by all means tell her grandpa the truth.

Title: I must be really stupid
Review:
I tried to watch this twice but could not finish it. What an awful, tasteless, senseless, pretentious pile of garbage.

The only reason I tried to watch it a second time was to try to understand what I was missing. Since most viewers loved the deep deep messages in this movie, I must be shallow and stupid.

I must admit I do not enjoy martial arts scenes very much. But I can tolerate a long fight scene if it fulfills a meaningful purpose in the plot. Even a meaningless fight scene with good choreography may be enjoyable if it does not take a very long portion of the movie. This movie takes meaningless fight scenes to a new level and sprinkles in disgusting content for added enjoyment.

Maybe I am not that stupid but I accidentally sent myself to an alternate universe where tastelessness is appreciated.

Title: Worst movie I've seen
Review:
The director tries to make the film look like TikTok videos. This idea might have been good at first, but the result is hard to watch. The fast editing and bright colors make you feel dizzy and tired.

From the beginning, it is hard to understand what is happening in the movie. The quick cuts do not let you focus on the story. It is unclear if there is a real story or if the movie is just about showing off the visuals.

The actors in the movie are talented, but their performances are too much. They act in a very exaggerated way, which makes it hard to care about the characters. The main actors' acting is annoying instead of interesting.

The other actors also struggle with their roles. Their characters are like stereotypes of people on the internet, which makes them seem shallow. The things they say do not sound natural. It is hard to know if this is because of the actors or the script.

The movie is confusing and hard to follow. There are many problems with the story, and it is hard to understand what the director wants to say.

When the movie ends, you feel relieved. This film does not entertain you, but instead makes you feel bad for watching it. The movie tries to be different and modern, but it does not work. In the end, it shows that sometimes trying to be creative can go very wrong.

Title: Boring nonesense
Review:
I have tried to watch this movie twice. I could watch about 30 mins at first try, second time about an hour, then I realized it's just waste of time. I don't get how this movie got an 8.2 score, I even had doubts about the movie's file I've downloaded, I had to check the trailer on YouTube to be sure.

The main problem of this movie is that there is no logic. The story won't remain loyal even to its own logic. The first 15 minutes is just irrelevant prologue about the lesbian daughter and stressful life of business and family. Then in the elevator scene we get informed that husband is from another dimension and there is no time, So the main character has to defeat an "enemy" in another dimension in the middle of an IRS meeting. After that, there is no destination or logic, just random battles and random dimension visits without any hurry. After an hour, comes the realization that the story hasn't progressed even a tiny bit and probably there is no story.

So this movie is a great example of why movies should have stories, non-random-well-thought stories. A better title for the movie would be "Everything everywhere all at random in favor of protagonists, because we couldn't think of anything more sensible". From other positive reviews, I suspect that maybe you have to be a stoner or acid user (which I am not) to enjoy this film. With all said and bad acting, the only relatively positive side of this movie is special effects. Bottom line: This is a bad Kong fu movie with some stupidest sci-fi backstory, that some may enjoy.

Title: Tried hard to like it
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: This is not Kung Fu Hustle
Review:

This cast was actually in 50 movies, blended into 1. By the end of the film you are left with scraps from the original act. The characters you bond with in the opening timeline were never real, which diluted the premise of the climax to the point where you simply wanted it to end. The quantum mechanics of linear timelines is an ongoing science, that has been the new hype since Back to The Future. Fortunately the classics will never be forgotten, unlike this flash in the pan shock drama.

Title: I tried - it really did
Review:

But .... It just went over my head. It's like an endless series of vaguely connected visuals. It's done very well, and is great to look at, but overall it's just a bit too bonkers for me. I can see why some people like it though, it's one of those films that you either get, or you don't. I didn't.

Five stars, one for the three main character performances, and two for the Rocks. The Rocks were the best part. By far.

Title: Love it or Hate kind of a Movie
Review:
Well, I go to the movies with my kids every now and then, especially when they insist on how great those movies are, in the majority of those cases I literally enjoy the movies sitting with my kids with popcorn and drinks along with blankets and good movies like Black Panther, Coco, Up and several others. This time around my daughter dragged me to this movie.

Just within 15 minutes into the movie I started feeling sleepy and after 30 minutes I was struggling to keep my eyes open, there are two things that kept me awake one the jarring outburst of sound, and second, I don't want my daughter to feel bad that I am really not enjoying the movie.

Well, I watched the movie several months back, the question is why not wrote the review then, well, as you guess, I am literally furious after last night's Oscar awards when this movie bagged every major award including a Best picture which literally boiled my blood, so please bear my rant and hence this review.

If we remember a couple of years back Academy awarded The Parasite as the best movie, well, I liked the movie to be honest, except I still don't think that movie deserved the Best Picture award.

But, this nonsense, overhyped, overacting, over VFX, basically everything over and as the name of the movie, all over the place, everywhere and without any sense of storyline, character development or cinematography, or direction.

Every now and then, our friends got divided on a few movies where a few friends thought a movie is really great and gives like 5 stars, but, the majority of us, think otherwise and give 1 star, then during the discussion, we asked those who gave 5 stars what they see that we couldn't able to see, they usually just couldn't justify or answer that question, it seems like they just try to look cool and think that if they give 5 stars to some stupid dump movie, they might look very intelligent.

This is exactly the case with this movie and I do not even have a shred of doubt, those who gave more than 5 to 6 stars, didn't even understand this movie, they just think that giving one or two stars would make them look stupid, so let us give 8-9-10 stars and look intelligent, but the reality is something different if you ask them few straight questions about this movie they won't able to answer.

And make no mistake this movie is not something like the Inspection kind where we were divided, but not as bad as this movie, we mostly ended up giving 3 stars out of 5, but others gave 5 stars, so we were kind of in the middle. But with this overhyped movie, we are firm 1 star and no one can convince us or is able to convince us through anything yet, to increase our rating to at least 2 stars, because they simply can't, there is no base on which they can able to do that, in simple term, this is the garbage movie and a waste of time and money.

It seems like Academy judges have a new trend of giving awards to some crazy Asian movies to look cool and intelligent, here is the news Academy, please go and watch the movie and just don't give an award for the sake of looking cool or intelligent, in fact, you look more stupid than a 6-year-old.

Well, the best part of the movie, of course the ending, not because the movie finished, well, that really was the best part, but in my case, my daughter realized that I didn't enjoy the movie a bit, but she said something which made it all worth. Thanks, Baba, I know you don't enjoy the movie and I dragged you into this movie, but you just sit and pretend like you were enjoying the movie just for me...I love you Baba.

Title: Just wasted 2 hours of my life on this garbage
Review:
I usually don't write reviews, but this "movie" encouraged me to do so after I feel a victim to a bunch of 10/10 reviews and decided to give it a shot.

Tasteless, with "humour" deserving low-budget student-made film, this pretentious piece tries to touch philosophical matters but does it with so little quality it almost pains to watch. Just a set of arbitrary kung-fu scenes mixed with tasteless humour.

If we look at IMDB Top-250 we will see "12 Angry men", "Seven samurai" and other amazing movies having similar rating to this. Does anyone even dare to compare those movies to this piece?

I wish people who rate it 10/10 and mark as "masterpiece" would explain why they think it is so. Watched until the end trying to find any sense to absolute failure. Wish would have walked out.

Title: Disappointing! (Maybe a me problem tho)
Review:
I was amazed at the reception of this film, seeing all the glowing reviews and praise this film was getting. It was encouraging to see plus the fantastic box office as well meaning it wasn't just snobby critics that liked this film but general audiences as well.

Wow was I disappointed by the outcome after watching this film. I feel as if I have watched something completely different to what everyone else saw.

Firstly I completely respect the craftsmanship this film is made with, it is very unique, original and bold. I have to give the filmmakers/writers credit with that. Cannot claim they are doing something boring and re-done many many times. I can also understand how that would resinate with people and become popular, plus the allure of an A24 production. Also what a boost this must be for the Asian community having such a huge film like this be so popular in "western" culture, huge win!

It's all good being original, however its still got work as one cohesive film. That is why I do sort of feel that this film might be a "me" problem as well. I never got on board with the story right from the get go. Never got behind the characters, never felt attached to them in any way shape or form. This 100% feels like a film that needs multiple viewings to be appreciated and understood fully. However I was never enjoying myself watching this.........the multi-universe wall breaking concept, although fascinating, becoming very boring quickly! At some points it was almost cheesy, not a good sign!

More felt like "To much going on" all at once! Nothing felt cohesive as if this film had like 20 writers working on it all at once. This film aims for stars, for me it facepalms the moon....... I can see where its going and its potential however for me I just never could get into the story. It introduces a new thing and then within minutes its onto the next, nothing gets to marinade and breath.

Maybe I'll re-watch it again in the future and it'll click for me? I'm on the fence, I appreciate and can see the talent on had with the concept of the story and the directing....(acting is also fine in the film)......Sadly for me it doesn't work overall.

50% out of 100.

Title: Hugely disappointing and overrated
Review:
This feels like 2 people playing at make believe in school break. Seriously absolute s###.

You swap your shoes to wrong feet shut your eyes and imagine your in a janitors cupboard and all of a sudden you're in a parallel universe? Are they having a laugh?

It alternatively peal a piece of gum from under a desk and there you are again?

The best thing about it is Jamie Lee Curtis zombie IRS worker!!

However acting has to be credited for keeping a straight face for the period of each shot.

I've read a lot of books similarly themed but this one just doesn't hold together. Not sure if it's serious or a comedy and if you have to ask....

Title: Too much, in too many places; not what I wanted.
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: What's all the fuss about?
Review:
It's a mystery to me how this film managed to get so many accolades. I enjoyed Babylon a hell of a lot better, regardless of what the critics had to say. This film isn't so esoteric that one cannot decipher the point that life has inherently no meaning; every action and thing has a meaning in and of itself. Okay, fine. I'm not sophisticated like others in interpreting film, so I'm not going to pretend I can explain the various layers of this one or point out all the metaphors to sound smart. I'll suffice it to say my final thoughts in the movie theater were, "I can't believe I spent the last two hours and 20 minutes feeling like I was on acid." With that being said, I was totally on board with the Raccaccoonie Universe. I love raccoons!

Title: If you don't understand the multiverse, don't watch it!
Review:
Written post Oscars.

This film had a lot of press pre Oscars, so I made sure I watched it before the awards. I really wanted to like this film. Michelle Yeoh is a superb actress. Jamie Lee Curtis is brilliant. However, this is a multiverse film and if, like me, you don't understand this concept then don't waste your time watching it. I enjoyed the acting. It was superb. It was great to see Short Round all grown up. I understand the bit about love, families, choices. But it was such a disappointment and I was thankful I didn't waste my money seeing it at the cinema. I was bored and couldn't wait for the credits to roll.

Heavily overrated IMHO, don't let the camera switching scenes 3 times per second distract you from the fact that this is not an exciting movie. 5/10.

Title: Boring and juvenile
Review:
I could see this being being a kids movie if you removed the explicit scenes. I found myself constantly checking the time left in this movie because I just wanted it to end. I ended up stopping with 40 minutes left because I just couldn't watch anymore.

Title: Rubbish
Review:
I don't think I'm stupid. I've just come from a Alex McQueen exhibition at our NGV. Alex McQueen is a brilliant costume designer who unfortunately left us far too soon. As far as film making goes I thoroughly enjoyed Being John Malkovich. That too is about multiuniverses. Charlie Kaufman is a brilliant writer who wrote a very clever script. Mulholland Drive is a David Lynch film that delves in alternative realities. That too is clever with an ambivalent ending that is open to interpretation.

As far as this one goes, if the intentions of the writers is to say something about the human condition using the metaphors of multiuniverses, then sorry, I missed it. The initial premise of a laundrymat being audited by the IRS I can understand. Taxes drive me crazy. I normally reach for alcohol after I've been audited. The character in this movie I think took a tab of acid and that explains the rest of the movie. I kept with the movie till the end. I'm sorry I did because at the one hour 10 minute mark the credits appeared on the screen. The sensible thing at that point would have been to walk out of the movie. It kept going another hour and I stayed with it, which shows I'm not a sensible person.

Sorry, this movie is a convoluted mess. One star.

Title: Couldn't finish it
Review:
I tried. Watched an hour even though I'd had enough after 40 minutes. I hung in there hoping I'd connect but it was so tedious I just couldn't keep going. It was hard to follow and hard to enjoy. It still had an hour to go when I bailed so maybe . . . But I just couldn't.

I suppose I should be more specific. There is a constant barrage of changing universes which is annoying. The characters aren't likeable although Michele Yeoh's character is tolerable. I got to a point where I didn't want to watch anymore. I don't know how it all got resolved and unfortunately I don't care. Maybe I'll try again but I doubt it.

Title: Oh dear, where did this all go wrong?
Review:
I wrote this before the Oscar awards.

Interesting concept which seems to have been abandoned for a heavy handed attempt at moralising.

Everything everywhere all at once is what is happening in the life of Michelle Yeoh. Chaos reigns. For "reasons" she gets sucked into the a multiverse. And what a disappointing mutlitverse it is.

Ke Huy Quan was by far and away the best actor in this movie.

Much as I like Jamie Lee Curtis I have rarely seen more ham outwith a delicatessen.

Michelle Yeoh is a fine actor but nothing outstanding here.

No idea why this film is being praised so highly, it is not one I would recommend.

Title: Completely Confused
Review:
This movie made me feel confused all the time. I understood all the philosophical strands, but this was just badly executed. I've just felt annoyed and wishing the movie would end soon enough.

Title: I feel nowhere all at once.
Review:
Not the worst movie ever but best picture is beyond generous. I'm not sure if this is satire or not, it seems to poke fun at a particular movie that is far superior to this one. The acting is fair but nothing to brag about. This is a worst best picture winner than "Crash", and I am surprised to say this. It felt like a marathon getting through this and I would not return to this ever, unless I'm watching the reaction of someone else watching it.

The best picture winners have not been strong the past several years, but if "Big Trouble in Little China" came out today, I feel like it would win best picture because I get similar vibes from these two movies. If you need a laugh and truly want to scratch your head over how this won seven Oscars, check it out.

Title: WTF is this?
Review:
I couldn't stand more than 15 or 20 minutes of this inane garbage.

One of the most ridiculous excuses for cinema I've ever seen.

It's the equivalent of someone throwing up, ecasing it in plastic, and calling it "modern art".

I'm sure some will say I didn't understand it, but the idea of a movie is to entertain it's audience........this is totally without any entertainment value.

I wasn't shocked when I saw that this thing won multiple Oscar's, that seems to be the direction the academy has gone in the past couple decades.

Apparently there's a severe lack of talent in Hollywood these days.

I'd be more entertained watching paint dry.

Title: Not my kind of multiverse
Review:
The thought of paralell universes, the multiverse, has always been interesting and intriguing for our 'noble' human mind; unable to process 'unreachable situations' of such magnitude.

We stand scared and fascinated of such a reality, the possibility that another of ourselves exists, needless to say many more, throughout the cosmos. Different paths, alternate life choices.

Well, fascinating as this looks, the film does not manage to approach accordingly. It is chosen a more ridiculous, unfunny, frustrating and tiringly long view of the matter. After some time into the film, the desire of the viewer is not to continue and eagerly see what is going to happen, but instead stop watching early; as soon as possible. Continuation feels undesirable and require some kind of bravery and patience.

It is true, have not doubt about that, nothing matters really...about this film and in this film, everywhere, everything and all at once!

Title: Terrible picture
Review:
A convoluted mess of a movie that tries too hard to be clever and profound but fails miserably. The plot is confusing and disjointed, jumping back and forth between different dimensions and timelines without any clear direction. I love quirky, strange movies. "Blue Velvet" is one of my favorites. There is a dream logic at work there. Throwing around a bunch of weirdness for weirdness sake does not make a good movie. There is nothing good here-juvenile humor, cheap effects and poor writing.

I can't believe that this movie won seven awards, including best picture. It should be nominated for a Razzie.

Ten times worse than the previous worst Oscar winner, "Crash."

Title: this is the worst movie I have ever seen
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Simple story, too much decoration
Review:
Simple enough story, but way too much decoration in terms of the special effects, battles, multiple characters and universes. It was sensory overload after a while it became tiresome and added nothing. It was so repetitive. Constantly changing props, and outfits of the characters just wasn't making the scenes any more interesting. More certainly could have been added in terms of character development in stead of so much energy going towards all the special effects fluff. It would have made me more sympathetic to the individual characters. It was in three parts and I kept hoping it was over before it really was.

So I quit.

Title: One of the worst movies I've ever seen
Review:
It was so weird and hard to follow. Nothing made sense. It kept jumping around in a random order and it got so confusing that I finally had to turn it off. The worst part is that I was actually angry by the time I turned it off. I was angry because I was trying really hard to follow it and I kept getting blindsided with absolute nonsensical jumps from one scenario to the next. With no flow or aim. Who made this and why? That was my main question and I still feel that way. I got absolutely nothing out of it- not even a story line. Major thumbs down.

I would not recommend this movie to anyone- unless you are a glutton for punishment lol.

Title: Disappointed-I Just Don't Get It
Review:
I borrowed the DVD from my local library, but I kept procrastinating about watching it. I guess there was a good reason. I wanted to see it on the big screen, because there are a lot of action scenes that I thought would be more impressive than seeing them on TV. Well, I didn't get around to seeing it in the theater, so I took what I could get.

The story line, such as it is, was confusing. At first, I thought Michelle Yeoh's husband was her brother. Then after I figured that out, they went to the IRS building to meet with an agent, taking her father along with them, though he was in a wheelchair. The movie, which was already chaotic, became even more so. I bailed after about 35 minutes and I don't think I'll try to watch it again. It's partly my fault. My DVD player sometimes makes a droning sound and it's difficult to make out the conversations between the characters.

The movie was just weird. I'm not a fan of sci-fi or fantasy movies or TV shows, so already I was primed not to like it. I was glad that the heroine is an older woman who looks like a typical person, not a fantastic superwoman like some of the actresses in action movies. Maybe it's unfair of me to rate the film, because I'm judging it by the first 30 minutes or so. Even if it was free, and it is, I can't stick with it. Now that I know the directors made that movie about the corpse with Daniel Ratcliffe in it, it makes more sense that I wouldn't like this film. No, I didn't see the other one with the corpse. I just heard about it.

A friend of mine knows someone who saw EEAAO and warned him that the film was confusing. I agree. I had to laugh at some of the Kung fu fighting scenes, but otherwise I was not interested enough to continue watching it. I'm glad the actors who were nominated won Oscars, because it seems like they went through a lot. But otherwise, you can have it.

Title: Maybe it's me but why did I waste time on this.
Review:
I'm sure the cast had a great time, that's about the best I can say. I think there was a plot and a message but I have no idea what it was.

Sometimes the industry gets an attack of "Emperor's new clothes" where no one wants to point out that something is just plain poor rubbish. In my opinion this is one of those. I felt the same about Spiderman into the Spider-verse if that helps you judge whether you may feel the same. This has a similar feel but without the Spiderman.

Simple questions, If it's a comedy was it funny? - No, If it's a thriller was it compelling? - No, If it's a moralistic message did that message get though? - No, If you had spent money watching this would you be happy? - Unlikely, Will this be something you look back on snd fondly watch the reruns in 5, 10, 15 years? I very much doubt it.
15 out of 22 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Shame on you, Oscars academy.

20 minutes into the film and I started to feel my blood living my body. It's not funny, it's not entertaining, nothing makes sense.

I wonder how the other nominees felt when they heard the announcement.

It's a clear message to whoever puts all their knowledge, creativity and skills on movie making that for the academy that means nothing... it's a shame but it's the truth.

Title: Unwatchable!
Review:
The movie is terribly long and boring, packed with unnecessary amount of low quality special effects!

I know it just won a ton of oscars but that doesn't mean it's a good film!

It was excruciatingly incoherent and amateurish you'd think it was made for children. I understand the events were all connected and leading to an specific purpose but most top films have delivered much better concepts in a considerably shorter time and hell of a lot more exciting scenarios.

The actors were fifty shades of terrible too, most of 'em were obviously extremely untalented and inexperienced, specially the husband, that makes you really doubt the intentions of the academy.

There were many better alternatives for the oscars that were wasted on this piece but such a shame!

Title: Pure marmite
Review:
Quite how this won the Best Picture Oscar against All Quiet on the Western Front is beyond me. I'll admit that I'm not a huge fan of Sci Fi movies in general but this is truly weird and all of the place. Not exactly a coherent piece of film making imho. Nor an enjoyable one. I daresay some will love it simply because it won Best Picture and ergo must be great. I didn't love it because it was exceptionally silly without being funny enough to compensate. I can't really comment on the 2nd half because I didn't last that long - I had lost all interest long before then. I'm just glad I watched it on Amazon Prime and didn't have to waste money on cinema tickets. Small comfort, mind you!

Title: Switched off 45mins in (sorry)
Review:
I really hate to write and give a bad score like this one. However myself watching with my mum both agreed it was time to turn off around the 45minute mark.

It's just such a bizarre movie, at first I was intrigued as to what may come next, but I was only left with confusion and uncertainty.

For me it was in comparison albeit no where near its level to a "fake" inception movie but as previously mentioned no where near the class or production to even compare.

Upon seeing this currently rated at time of writing this review at a steady 8.1 out of 10 I'm left disapproved and dissatisfied, and begin to wonder if the ratings mean anything anymore?

Just really wasn't for myself or mum this turn round.

Title: Ambitious but doesn't work on many levels
Review:
I always go for these types of crazy, imaginative, unique, out-there, weird movies. I give major props for the ambition and for showing me so many things I've never seen before. And the fight scenes, although scarce, are pretty awesome. Unfortunately this movie really doesn't work for me.

The first major issue is the comedy. I laughed a few times but most of the comedy fell completely flat for me. Comedy is subjective, so others might feel differently. My audience laughed more than me but not nearly as much as the movie wanted them to.

Another major issue is the weird factor. It goes way too far. Most of it is amusing but at some point it starts feeling weird for weird's sake. This is especially true when it comes to the story. There's not enough concrete to grasp onto. It starts feeling like a bunch of nonsense.

Lastly, the pacing and narrative don't feel smooth at all. It was difficult to tell where I was in the movie (for example, nearing the climax). Here's my theory on why:

Some movies will have what I call an epiphany moment. A moment where everything comes together, usually accompanied by heightened musical score and flashes to different moments. It usually happens in the climax and evokes emotion. In this movie, the epiphany moments comprise what seems like 35% of the movie. Scattered throughout the movie, not just at the end. But nothing ever comes together. It just keeps getting stranger with more questions.

In the end I had a pretty bad time with this movie. And I'm annoyed I drove 40 minutes to watch it in one of two theaters playing it in the Chicagoland area, which has 100+ theaters. (1 viewing, 4/4/2022)

Title: Feel Compelled
Review:
I feel compelled to write this after the Oscars sweep. It's nice that Michelle Yeoh won an Oscar. As for the movie--I continue to be mystified. It starts out by introducing the main and supporting characters. Yeoh's character is the owner of a laundromat and she hasn't been keeping up with her taxes. She wants to divorce her husband. It seemed unpleasant but I kept watching, expecting a family drama of some sort. Then Yeoh and her family go to the IRS office and what could be more boring than that? Then there's a sharp twist, as it turns into a supernatural Kung Fu movie. A character starts beating up innocent people in the IRS office and I found that to be repellent, as the character is supposed to be one of the good guys. I guess it's ok to not pay your taxes and to beat up innocent people. At this point I stopped watching, but I've seen various clips from the rest of the film. It's a lot of over-the-top costumes. The overall impression I had is that this film is psychotic. I'm giving it five stars for the cast, otherwise it would be one star.

Title: Chaotic ride through the multiverse
Review:
This is one of the two movies released in 2022 that got a rating of 8 or higher. This is in comparison to other years a poor and shocking number. Movies are getting worse. This is a fact. And what do you say if I tell you that this movie in my opinion does not earn this rating either?

Well, in terms of editing and cinematography, maybe sound, too this movie is top quality, that is not debatable but if we talk about the story which is told in a confusing and complicated way this is just solid and nothing more. As I watched it I felt a bit dissapointed because I had quite some expectations. Unfortunately the multiverse story could not catch me.

And this may be the key point if the movie fits to you or not. Do you like multiverse and stories told in a complicated way like Christopher Nolan? Than this is your movie. If not, stay away from it.

Title: Waste of time

Today i spent two hours fixing my daughters iPhone, and two hours watching this crappy movie. Four hours i will never get back. At least fixing the iPhone was useful.

OK, this is not my genre, but this was just a mess. How this movie could win 7 Oscars is a big mystery to me.

Might be some elegance in the colourful production, some funny scenes...i dont know, but where to start...the story is chaotic, bouncing from one end to the other. Leaving me thinking ¬´Titanic¬ª felt like a short movie (1 hour longer).

So i will keep this short. If you are not into fantasy or science-fiction, watch another movie instead. This just felt like a waste of time. I understand i am in opposision to most people, but someone has to yell it out: this was a crappy movie!

Title: Utterly overrated
Review:
Awfully absurd and meaningless!

I just wasted my time watching this silly movie.

The quality of movies just dropped dramatically after COVID, but seriously this movie deserved an Oscar???? No way!

Next time if a movie won an Oscar, I may skip watching it... Overratedddddd!!!!

If you make zero logic out of a movie, the movie is not a masterpiece or a pioneer. It's just rubbish. I don't know how some people calls such stupid stuff rebellious and deep. Silly is silly....

Title: Academy Ajokes
Review:
I was thinking to myself yesterday, when the thought residue that the Oscars are taking place floated through my mind, how giddy I once was on the day. Yes, I love movies. I still do, somehow.

How many years, now, has it been that without any ill will I simply could not care to tune in? At least four, maybe a few more. But this happened gradually, by natural erosion of faith and trust. In what? Human taste? Intelligence? You pick.

I won't speak to the movie. Scroll down the reviews for that. I wonder if its rise is yet another communal rebellion against quality, driven by the fear of being the first to stop clapping in a digital auditorium with an eye in the sky.

Title: Please let me escape from this world
Review:
When the The Banshees of Inisherin got 0 Oscars, and this ART gets 7 - I want to teleport to other multiverse. Now.

Title: Migraine induced movie
Review:
Let's start by clarifying this. Those who give 8-10 stars are either morons who are easily brainwashed by media hype, or are paid to write glowing reviews. I am a filmmaker and I am very critical when analyzing movies with little biases and prejudices. Being Asian myself, I am more than willing to champion good Asian movies that are worth praises. BUT this movie ain't it. It's one of the worst movies I have ever watched. And I could not bare myself to finish it. Incoherent plot and mediocre actings; little character development. Bad editing! Little to no substance! There are more worthy movies that are being ignored. All quiet on the water front, which deserves more praise and awards, but got overlooked. Maverick is more entertaining by many miles. It's a hot mess from the beginning to the end. I got migraine watching it while trying to understand its reasoning and the plot. There are better movies that have the same messages about kindness and understanding out there but of course the academy was already bought and determined to give this all the awards it could fake and come up with. My advice is stay away from it, unless its free and you feel the need to torture yourself. This is movie should be a punishment by the court to all criminals, cause I am sure they would never want to commit any more crimes if the sentence is having to watch this garbage!

I sincerely hope the academy will pull its head out of its ass and start being real and objective in finding the best movie out there to consider for the awards. Either that or shut it down. Maybe Elon Mush should buy it and destroy it all together or revamp it by hiring people who know movies and those you cannot be bought.

Title: "Everything Everywhere Matters to Everything"
Review:
I like the 'Daniels'. I thought Swiss Army Man was a sweet and tender loving little dark comedy with a four-quadrant head on it's shoulders telling a tale about how life sucks and life is beautiful. It showed a disturbed, singled-out, man who gave up on everything and found a deceased suicide-victim who came to life with supernatural powers. These supernatural powers gave him the life to live while also learning about life from the "soon-to-be" suicidal. It showed empathy, gave nostalgia, and the flaws of man. The most POWERFUL line in that movie was: "Everything everywhere matters to everything".

This movie does a complete 180 degrees in terms of morality and says everything means nothing and we don't know anything and you are stupid to say you "know" an exact one thing. While I agree with the message "Be kind", it detracts the ideology about diversity. I hate politics and social justice issues being forced down people's throats but isn't the point of diversity being able to co-exist with one another? Or rather The Daniel's saying "We shouldn't exist, we don't matter." - a line from a very famous yet skeptic nihilist Nietchze who, in my opinion, couldn't tell a goat from an amoeba.

The positives: This movie is very beautifully shot, very well edited and they deserve a raise. The team is insanely good at recurring shots with different make-up and the cinematography is more beatiful than I've ever seen. The actors go 110% with what they're given. This movie is eye-candy.

The negatIves I already spoke about but I'll end it with this: It's a very pretentious movie with two men who want to forecast their beliefs with a hammer to your head about "life"; whereas their previous gem Swiss Army Man taught hope and acceptance in the simpler term that we can co-exist and be happy with one another rather than reject every belief system and accept oblivion.

Title: 5.5 overrated
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Fell asleep
Review:
Saturday night, I made a bowl of popcorn, and signed up for a seven-day trial period of Showtime (notating on my calendar when I should cancel if I didn't wish to pay $10.99). The plan was to watch "Everything Everywhere...", an Oscar nominated movie. It was going to be great!

The opening was promising, fast moving, colorful with multiple things going on, interesting characters, eating, talking, customers in the laundromat etc. I laughed and felt optimistic about the film. And then a family trip to the IRS, but I'll say no more so as not to ruin "the plot".

Jamie Curtis was funny, as some sort of odd cartoon-like caricature of an ugly, older woman, government official. But then the movie slips seriously into that alternate people, universes, broom closet, who know what reality......and then some sort of kung fu martial arts thing with people flying around in the air, and by that time I was losing interest. It's starts to get confusing..How does one get into that alternate universe? By chewing chapstick or pushing the green light on your headphone...and then looking at your cellphone for the GPS coordinates?. (Did the app come from the Apple store?).

You know how four year old children in nursery school like to dress up and run around acting out some plot, that no adult can understand, but makes perfect sense to them? One might have a cape on, the other with a fairy tiara and tutu, the other has found a toy sword and plastic knight's armor vest. They run around, calling after each other, hiding and pretending to fight some imaginary enemy. It's amusing for adults to watch for a few minutes, but usually the game goes on for about ten minutes or less, not one and a half hours.

That is how I feel about the characters and plot of the movie. It seems to turn into some sort of cartoon/action/matrix-like film and as another reviewer said, I think viewers in general don't want to admit it's hard to understand. At some point I fell asleep, unintentionally. That pretty much sums up the film for me. I might give it one more try before my "free trial" expires.

Title: I am a bit puzzled
Review:
Sincerely... I tried already 5 times to watch and I cannot reach the half of it. Maybe the second part is great but the first part is a boring non-sense mixture of poor martial arts and some sort of multiverse future. I did not even like the performances which were kind of "funny" as if it was a comedy. I still did not get what kind of movie this is. Is it a comedy, a thriller, a martial art movie or a hymn to women? Please explain. And believe me I tried. It is frustrating not being able to see the end of the movie because it is so boring you cannot get towards the end. So maybe I should just resist and keep going? My advise is no. Do not waste your time.

Title: Shallow flashy movie with good cinematography and no cinsistency.
Review:
Do you know what a MacGuffin is? Basically it's a plot device with no reasoning or depth, that exists only to move the plot. Well here, you have a movie where every character is a MacGuffin. Cinematography is the only thing that stands out with quality here, and for that I give it 5 stars. The story is all over the place, non of the characters have depth to them. Evil guys are evil just to be evil, good guys are good just to be good, main special person is main and special JUST because they needed someone to be so. You will see a lot of scenes "inspired" by old classics, but it feels like the creators didn't see any of them, relying on the movie poster to understand what those classics were all about. Imagine if all you knew about "2001: A Space Odyssey" is that it's a movie where monkeys find an obelisk, and that's it. This movie doesn't borrow from years of quality cinema, it is a shallow attempt to pretend to be one of the cool kids.

Maybe you will like the movie if you're drunk or high.
8 out of 10 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: Dreadful
Review:
Now, I must declare an interest. I'm a martial arts expert and kung fu movies do nothing for me - I see the fakery. The entire movie seemed to be a loop of the same fight scene. Boring.

The parellel universe has been done to death in other movies and no matter how bad they were, they were better than this.this.

It is the only film I have watched to the end and still hated - how did it get so many 10 star reviews???

I didn't care a jot about any of the characters, could care less how it ended or who won. Take this movie and remake it word for word, scene for scene, with unknowns and most would have given it a one star. The ratings are more for who is in it than the actual content. Dire, dire, dire.

Title: Every meme everywhere all at once
Review:
As much as I enjoyed Michelle Yeoh's acting, the movie itself is no more interesting than a series of combined social media memes. It will appeal to a younger generation but the visuals were not for me and thus had no comedy quality. What was left then was an interesting storyline that would have been better off without the unnecessary goofy elements such as the bagel which for me ruined the entire movie and made it seem like it was trying too hard to be symbolic, accessible and popular. The underlying messages and references were nothing but a sweeping acceptance and self-acceptance thing. Not so much to think upon.

I found the opening scene to be much more promising when it stayed in the realm of realism which made the title less literal and the story somehow deeper. Being everywhere all at once with no time for yourself to figure out what is happening in your life is a great theme and a more realistic portrayal of the situation would have led to the same amount of absurdity, only maybe more subtle than what it turned out to be.

Title: Unbearable
Review:
!

It was good for ten minutes. Then -- for the 1.5 hours I could bear it -- it was a procession of kung-fu fight scenes, scene after scene after scene after scene, merged with a really bad video game, written by a ten-year-old who stayed up for three nights by drinking several tank loads of coffee.

Truly unbearable.

Title: Nothing Nowhere Never!
Review:
I watched the first fifteen minutes hoping that the film would become less unwatchable, but it never did - in fact the opposite was true. Equally offensive to eyes and ears, and full of characters to instantly dislike, I had no option but to quit before I wasted any more time on this truly awful film. I cannot understand the hype, the Oscar buzz, or the glowing reviews on this website - all of which are as unfathomable as this movie. A classic case of The Emperor's New Clothes, with the only saving grace being that I had not wasted any money on my aborted viewing. Do yourself a favour and avoid this movie like the plague!

Title: Not worthy of even being nominated for an Oscar
Review:
Thought this might be worth a try given the number of Oscars its just picked up, however we gave up and turned off after enduring it for forty minutes, very confusing story line, total nonsense, with some very ridiculous scenes.

Plus as someone with hearing loss the dialogue was difficult to follow and I'm afraid I didn't feel the acting was any more than average either.

All Quiet on the Western Front was far more gripping and thought provoking and for entertainment value the Irish Goodbye and Top Gun were leagues ahead of this drivel.

If anything this has left me feeling disappointed for those who missed out on picking up an Oscar due to this very poor film, which shouldn't have even been nominated, getting in the way.

Title: Amateurish
Review:
Quite possibly the stupidest movie I've seen in many years. It looks like it was made by a high school movie class. Silly special effects, low budget "sci-fi" props (2 Bluetooth headsets used together? Really?). I cannot for the life of me figure out why this is nominated for anything. Apparently this is "the film" this year. Really dumb.

From the outset of this movie I kept waiting for it to get interesting, the only thing I could think of throughout the movie was that the actor who played the grandfather was the same actor who played the manager of the Chinese restaurant in the famous Seinfeld Chinese restaurant episode. Every time he was on screen I kept hearing him say "Cartwright?" Unfortunate for him, I'm sure he's a talented actor.

Really, don't spend a dime to watch this. It'll be streamable for free soon enough. It's just bad.

Title: Very overrated
Review:
While I do love stories involving the multiverse I found this one to be very fast paced, very weird and confusing.

It's on the order of Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy with it's outrageous and nonsensical theme, only this one is somewhat more extreme.

The action sequences, and there are a lot, were great and the acting was good with Michelle Yeoh and Ke Guy Quan in the lead parts along with a very unrecognizable Jamie Lee Curtis, but to categorize this as an Academy Award contender just shows me how the Oscars are out of touch with so much when it comes to these action and science fiction films.

Don't listen to the critics and their high appraisal of the movie because they don't look at these like an everyday viewer and solely place their opinions on the artistic approach or the type of cast involved. I also have my doubts as to the high approval rating coming from the audiences.

But, don't take my word for it. Watch it for yourself and make your own judgement. Just be prepared to say that you want your 2 hours and 19 minutes back.

Title: Not for me
Review:
I watched this after all the hype so maybe my expectations were too high, but this movie wasn't for me. I thought the acting was great and I did like the message of it, but it had too much going on without enough explanations and character development. It really is everything all at once and not in a good way. The concept of the multiverse and what was happening sometimes in scenes were not explained in a way to make everything conducive. I saw some reviews say the idea is kind of like the Matrix and I do agree a bit - full disclosure, I'm not a fan of the Matrix either. Maybe I just don't like these types of movies lol. I felt like I needed to be drunk or something to enjoy the ride to be honest.

Title: Chaotic
Review:
I understand the message. Nice message hence two stars but the film is absurdly chaotic and more like a colorful circus performance than a superb film. I do not understand how this film can receive so many Oscar nominations! I am a movie buff and also studied film theory at University. This movie is a tornado of incoherence and you cannot wait until the tornado moves through so you can collect your thoughts after the storm. Reminds me of Symphony Fantastique by Berlioz, which was allegedly composed under the influence of drugs. However, Symphony Fantastique is actually an fascinating piece of Program music.

Title: Original? Yes. Deserving of best film? No.
Review:
To say the least, the story does have a point. However, getting to it is an excruciating experience. If you're extremely disciplined, you might manage to get to the last thirty minutes or so, and realize that there is some decent content to be found. However, the first two-thirds of the movie will have many people walking out of the room, or simply turning the film off. Most of it is a well-edited, extremely confusing story which can best be described as an incoherent The Matrix. There are lots of colours, some good martial arts, and the feeling that everything possible is being thrown at the screen. However, it is neither dramatic nor funny. It is also neither compelling nor thought-provoking. It really is a pain in the ass to watch, and however acceptable the ending is, a viewer is still likely to feel as though he or she has wasted their time.

Title: So bad it makes me angry
Review:
The utterly dismal state of cinema today is represented here in this charmless, frenetic, yet unwatchable piece of dross. There is not one award this has been given to this film that could be justified in any sane, civilised society. The first scene was quite watchable as the characters were introduced in a busy laundry run by Michelle Yeoh. Her life seems utterly out of control as so many elements of work and family collide. The customers like to hang out there and despite the family entanglements the laundry seems to have an important place in the community.

Then it all goes south when she visits the IRS. The remainder of the film is so breathtakingly confusing and lacking any kind of entertainment value.

Think a bucket of 'The Matrix' that has been emptied into a stroboscope.
17 out of 30 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: So much for so little
Review:
This can't possibly be the best movie of the year. Yes, I know the Oscars rarely pick the best movie of the year but to choose this one they seem to have lost the plot.

It starts very well, basically until they go to the tax office and go into the parallel universe. From that moment on it's a fantasy movie full of nonsense characters and nonsense action scenes most of them Kung fu like that I don't buy, I don't understand, I don't follow.

Beautiful photography and settings but that's it. It had so much potential if they didn't go into the fantasy world after about the first 15 min.

Luckily I watched it at home and not in a cinema because it would have been embarrassing to be nodding off during the last hour of running time.

Title: In some universe, this was a good movie. Just not in this one.
Review:
In some universe someone bothered to hire a writer to transform their random thoughts into a script.

And then an editor, who politely explained that you can't just throw your moodboard at viewers. Your acid trip isn't a finished movie.

And then a marketing team, who transferred the viewers from that universe to leave reviews in ours. That is unethical marketing practices and should be called out.

I didn't hate it as much as others, some parts were sort of cute, but so diluted in endless nonsense that in the end made it just a pretentious waste of time. There was nothing life-changing or thought-provoking, at least not beyond thoughts any functioning brain has dealt with by the age of 15.

There was hardly anything funny either. It just tried too hard to be shocking and deep and absurd, but it all stayed on the surface, without being willing to put in any work to create some substance underneath.

Title: Just really poorly done movie.
Review:
I really wanted to like this movie. Didn't see it when it first came out. Heard raving reviews, saw the Oscar wins, thought it must be great! Then I started watching it, was painfully bored. Turned it off after 10-12 minutes. Was painful to watch. Then a few days later decided to give it another try... got maybe 30 minutes in and immediately wanted that 30 minutes of my life back. Was just really bad. Not interesting. Not realistic. Gave me no reason to continue watching. I didn't care about the movie, the story, the characters, nothing. Completely dumbfounded by its success. The back and forth between Chinese and English along with the on and off subtitles was very annoying. It was unique, I'll give it that, but in the worst ways. Honestly couldn't stand it.

Title: One big headache
Review: The concept of multiple dimensions and parallel universes is overused but still they somehow made it that for the life of me i couldn't grasp the plot of this movie, The movie is a major disappointment from start to finish. While it had the potential to be an engaging and thrilling experience, it ultimately fell flat due to an incomprehensible plot and a predictable ending that left little room for surprise or excitement. The constant cuts and jarring transitions left me with a pounding headache and the feeling of disorientation. The editing choices seemed almost gratuitous, with rapid-fire cuts and dizzying camera movements that served no real purpose other than to create a sense of chaos. The result was a film that felt disjointed and overwhelming, leaving me feeling disoriented and unable to fully engage with the story, just waiting for the ending. One thing that cannot be denied though is the strength of the actors performances. Despite the challenges presented by the disjointed plot and dizzying editing, the cast delivered powerful and convincing performances that were truly captivating. In particular, Evelyn Wang deserve special recognition for her outstanding work. Her performances were nuanced, heartfelt, and incredibly moving, and she managed to elevate the film despite its many flaws.

Title: Not worth the hype

The only differentiating thing is probably that no one has explored this kind of plot and movie. But that's not enough to make a good movie IMO. The last 30 mins just drag along and you wait for the movie to end.

I didn't understand why its being praised critically. It could have been more structured in its message and stuck to conveying 1 message. But sadly, that's not the case. Recommend to not watch.

Title: IT'S JUST ANOTHER BAD MOVIE
Review:
IT'S JUST ANOTHER BAD MOVIE, Everything Everywhere All at Once review - nothing nowhere over a long period of time Despite some smart gags, this broadly buzzed-about comedy turns out to be an oddly mediocre misfire.

This mad succession of consequence-free events, trains of activity which get cancelled by a switch to another parallel world, means that nothing is actually at stake, and the film becomes a formless splurge of Nothing Nowhere Over a Long Period of Time. Again, this film is much admired and arrives adorned with saucer-eyed critical notices ... I wish I liked it more.

IT'S JUST ANOTHER BAD MOVIE.

Title: Sensory overload!
Review:
This movie about meaninglessness is, ironically, equally meaningless.

Except for tiny emotional touches of depth near the end about the only emotionally engaging thing in the film; the dysfunctional family relationships, dysfunctional family patterns and how to grow as a person and not be a heartless robot going through the monotony of a self-chosen way of life.

They should've kept to the story and cut out completely useless and nonsensical headache and seizure-inducing visuals.

I suggest watching Dirk Gently instead for way more fun (eeaao wasn't funny in the slightest Except with the rocks) and more meaningful craziness. Also Cloud Atlas.

Title: Seriously
Review:
Was hopeful that this would be another solid vehicle for Michelle Yeoh. Was hopeful that this would be a thought provoking venture and kind of sci-fi.

Unfortunately it was neither. I watched it in a flight, but I'm pretty sure that's the only reason I watched it to the end. I had a feeling that the producers and directors were have a bit of a laugh to see what they could get past the audience.

Frenetic, hard to watch. I fully accept the martial arts aspect of it and how that arises and fits within the Chinese genre / idiom, but it did feel a lot like Kung Fu Hustle. At least that movie was honest. I am completely bemused how the movie community can allocate a range of significant nominations for this movie.

Title: Uhhh ... no
Review:
I think this was supposed to be entertaining. Instead, the chucklheads who came up with this disassociation come on camera ... before their movie ... giggling about how many times everyone has supposedly seen the film. Let me put it simply. I'd rather tear off each of my fingernails, one by one, than watch this movie again. Maybe it had potential at some point. Until the same "verse jump" theme is played over for the 35th time and you're wondering how, during filming, that the actors weren't slamming speedballs on top of 5ths of Vodka to stay sane. Maybe they did have unlimited Peruvian flake for the cast and crew. That might explain things. 30 minutes in, I was done. I was seriously contemplating standing up in the theater and screaming something unhinged about 1.5 hours in.

Then I looked at the online reviews. I feel like my heart has been forcibly removed from my chest and my eyes have been pierced with ice picks. WTAF is wrong with people??
