Title: Too long
Review:
Did this sci-fi-comedy/family-drama (there's a new category, huh?) have an editor? Two hours and nineteen minutes of exhausting images relentless thrown at the viewer is way too much. There is no repose. I found that it has to be taken in 20-minute chunks. This could have been a reasonable 90-minute film. It could even be a very good 30-minute short. At 139 minutes, it's excruciating. And it's nominated for a bunch of Oscars? The premise is simple and accurate: 1. Whatever life you're stuck with is better with an unconditionally loving, kind partner and 2. If you have a LGBTQ kid, be supportive or you'll mess them up.

Title: Overrated and loses direction
Review:
Ok so yes a lot of the reviews on here are right, I have no idea why this film was so highly rated by the academy. It was probably political, and some of the performances weren't that outstanding (JL Curtis in particular).

I feel that despite its efforts to be groundbreaking it's neither that new (other films have handled the whole multiple universe thing better) nor deep (the tedious interaction between Jobu and Evelyn was meant to make us think...but it was trite and shallow and overly obvious).

It's a film of two halves, which is done on purpose, and it starts off excitingly - there's a baddie and a goodie and one has to prevail. A good amount of people die at the hands of Jobu. She's cruel and unforgiving. Sets it up nicely. Unfortunately in the second half the whole thing unravels, it gets lost and slightly preachy and also the humour just doesn't work. The ending is saccharine, and left me feeling...meh. What about all the innocent dead people? It's as if they ran out of ideas and went for the easiest option which again is not very groundbreaking. Just the usual Hollywood fare but with some good fight scenes because of the actors involved.

Title: What is all the fuss about?
Review:
How did this become such a success? I really don't get it. It is a cheap Chinese B movie with a plot that I could predict after a few minutes. In the end it was not even a dream, this was suppososed to be real. A 2D sketched universe, yeah right. A good actor can make me forget who she really is, but Michelle Yeoh did not do that for me, so why the Oscar, beats me. I found the dougther Joy more convincing. Jamie Lee Curtis was acting good, but sadly way over the top becoming some kind of zombie some times. The grandpa was the worst actor in there. Waymond and Michelle Yeoh did not show chemistry for me, not even as a married couple. The only thing funny was the scene with the Rocks, the rest was just absurdidty. You will miss nothing if you did not watch this movie.

Title: What the?
Review:
I just don't understand who votes for Academy Awards? This is the most bizarre and out there nonsense I have seen since The Shape of Water which also cleaned up at the awards?? From the start, this movie is erratic and difficult to follow, . By the conclusion I was sitting dumbfounded as to its popularity wondering if I had missed something that everyone else seemed to be getting? I did get a giggle out of Jamie Lee Curtis's character though... All in all, my advice to fellow movie buffs would be to ditch the remote for this one and go and find your local coffee house and have a latte and brownie instead!!

Title: Vulgar and absurd
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Well that was weird
Review:
I think I am in the minority when it comes to my thoughts about this movie. As at the time of reviewing this (movie), it had an IMDB score of 8.1 (Jan 2023). I gave it 5 stars, and I was being generous at that.

For me, the story was confusing, with only limited spots of action here and there. But overall, it's not an easy movie to follow, and was disappointed for the reason given why all the caos is happening. Its saving grace is the suberb cast. The movie is well acted (it's why I gave it 5 stars), but the story pace is all over the place. Very slow in the beginning, then fast, then slow, then even more slow. Some great action when it happened, but nothing new that we haven't seen before, and they (action) come far and few in-between. The interaction between the characters is not great neither. There is no chemistry with all of them. Although it was good to see "Data" and "Short-Round" (aka Ke Huy Quan), all grown up.

I really wanted to like this movie, but in the end it just left me confused, and the journey to my confusing wasn't really as entertaining as I would have hoped.

VERDICT: If you're a fan of Michelle Yeoh and like multi-verse type movies, then this could be your cup of tea.

Title: Worst movie ever...seriously.
Review:
This was such a horrible movie, I don't even know where to start. My sister and I stopped the movie about 1/4 of the way through, and I have literally NEVER done that.

It was a complete hot mess. I love Michelle Yeoh - fantastic actress - but this movie was beyond bad. I had heard so much hype about it and couldn't wait to watch, but it was the most disappointing movie. My sister and I were trying to think if we had ever watched such a bad movie, and we couldn't think of any movie this bad. So, it receives the WORST MOVIE award ever, from both of us. Just....blegh!! Don't waste your precious time watching this film.

Title: Utter nonsense
Review:
I'm disappointed to see one of my favourite actresses working so hard in this awkward and non sensical film. Michelle Yeoh is great, but this conglomeration of ridiculous ideas is just vomit inducing. The storyline is pretty weak and jumps all over the place. The cheesy dialogue is horrible.

The premise is good and could have accomplished something that was inspiring and meaningful, instead, it seems like a film that's trying to be quirky just for the sake of it...

I wanted to turn it off half way through but also wanted to see if it got better. It didnt, however, and now I feel like I've wasted an evening..

Title: There is order in chaos
Review:
A chaotic group of vignettes with no order.

Neo on LSD.

Obsession with butt plugs and dildos.

Karate woman.

Multiverse.

What the hell is going on?

I've never seen so many one star reviews.

Shill: A person who acts as an enthusiastic customer to entice or encourage others.

Sorry, your review is too short. It needs to contain at least 600 characters.

So I have to keep typing.

Best movie, actress, supporting actress and actor. I started at 4 stars.

The more I think about this the lower/higher the rating. Depends on which multiverse I'm in.

Minimum character limit met. THE END!

Tried to be original, profound and funny. Just didn't stick the landing.

Time keeps on slippin' slippin' slippin' into the multiverse.

Title: Not my cup of tea.
Review:
I am still puzzled by the number of people that give this film such high ratings. I watched the movie with the expectation that it was a great film but a third of the way through I just wanted it to end or just fast forward it to see where it was going. But no, regretfully, i watched the the whole thing, hoping there would be some revelation. Yes, some of the acting is good, but at the end of this too long movie, I left with nothing, not caring for any of the poorly developed characters. There are so many great movies with the same premise, fast action scenes (the fights) and good acting but this one fails in everything and everywhere!

Title: Popcorn-TikTok-Absurd movie
Review:
I absolutely do not understand how you can seriously evaluate this popcorn-tiktok-absurd movie for acting, etc. Well, except for the editing and costumes. I don't mean it's a bad movie. This is a good movie for once. I have a feeling that there are 15 years old teenagers of Marvel fans sitting in the film academy, who, in addition, are also preoccupied with various types of perversions. Are you seriously? What's wrong with you? You just spit on the entire history of cinema. You are losing respect for yourself. It feels like you haven't watched the movies before at all. If you think that toilet humor is worthy of an award, then I feel sorry for you. Create a separate award for such movies. Don't touch history. It's not professional at least.

Title: So, So Bad
Review:
Parallel universes, flaccid plotting, over long, poor acting, jokes that don't land, and massive hype. There is so much to dislike about this film. At some point, when all the noise around award nominations and wins has died down, people will step back and take a cooler analytic look at this film and recognise it for what it is: ill structured nonsense. Yeoh, Quan, Hsu, Curtis.etc. Can't be blamed for the mess for they are just fitting into that the director/writers have constructed. Watch the trailer, and if you have even the slightest reservations, don't subject yourself to the whole 2hr 19m debacle. Stupidly I didn't follow my instinct and let someone persuade me to watch this. Oh, but the regret. This film is so, so bad.

Title: Ridiculous
Review:
It appears that the makers of this movie wanted to take a shortcut to success. It is customary in arts to bend the rules, or amend the customs. This seems to appeal to critics. What the makers or Everything, Everywhere, All at once seem to have missed is that you need to learn the rules, and perhaps prove that, before you break them. The mediocre acting and inferior story-telling of this movie are best described as someone who paints for the first time in their life, and calls that surrealism.

The movie attempts to associate itself with thoughtfulness when it talks, plainly, about how little we are in this universe, when it addresses the importance of not letting go of your loved ones, and when it encourages people to love and appreciate their lives as it is. However, it all seems forced upon the two meaningleas hours before that.

Title: Absolute disappointment
Review:
Beautiful actors... BUT this movie only in an another universe could justify all the Oscar nominations.

JAMIE LEE CURTIS: Wonderful career. Lucky to take this Oscar. I am sorry to say this. I prefer to see you on the red carpet not on this movie.

INDIANA JONES BOY: Career stopped suddenly. The only one that deserved a true recognition. Prefer to see him in an other movie. That was just a comeback.

BEST ACTRESS : Politically correct trophy winner. She is worth it. But who can take it from her, she can live happily ever after.

Go see Whale 2022. It was a masterpiece.

If you want to fall asleep choose it.

Title: Chinese Matrix Meets Legion (not in a good way)
Review:
Ow! My head!

This movie is WAY too confusing. It's as if someone had an ok concept for a 30-min TV show (Love, Death, and Robots) and stretched it to over 2 hours. It was entirely too long which added to the confusion. There were numerous extraneous characters (grandfather, big nose, etc) that they tried to build up, but ultimately failed because there wasn't enough time. And the fight scenes were confusing because they were meant to be confusing to add to the story.

The ONLY reason this is up for Best Picture at the Oscars is because it's Chinese. Chinese actors, Chinese writer, Chinese director, Chinese stereo types (laundry). The Chinese have bought Hollywood and now are buying awards.

Take your money and get drunk. Your hangover will feel the same, but at least you had fun getting there.

Title: I didn't like the movie at all
Review:
From the opening scene I knew I wasn't going to like this, despite really trying to. I'm 19 years old but this movie went way too fast in different languages and with so many multiverse switches so fast and by the end I had no idea why anything was happening, why I should care or what I was supposed to feel. I felt nothing and I was happy when it was over. I watched a different movie then everyone who gave it a 6 or higher I think. I do reaaally appreciate the effort it must have taken to make this movie especially with the editing but overall I just really wanted to like it and was disappointed by it, hated it even.

Title: Unable to get involved
Review:
Unable to get involved. Chaos, poor acting, unoriginal etc.

Everyone sees it clearly. Plenty of films like that we wish not to waste time on.

But we should not concentrate on this particular one as much as on the Academy Award committee. Those people are responsible for promoting lack of quality. If it is a political decision - okay, I can understand it.

Otherwise any Oscar nomination for Everything Everywhere All at Once makes the Asian community really embarrassed. The Asian cinematography is proud of many fantastic productions that have past unnoticed. And you choose EEAAO just to take the piss out of Asia.

Sad.

Title: What a profoundly shallow movie
Review:
The topic of familial relationships could have been interesting. Unfortunately, it has been glossed over in favor of superficial fight scenes, overcomplicated multiverse nonsense, wannabe philosophy, crude unfunny jokes and scenes.

There must definitely be some herd mentality effect behind so many positive reviews.
28 out of 46 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Popcorn; leave your brain at the entrance
Review:
In my opinion it's like a Tarantino: very well executed, very well acted, very well directed, very well photographed, funny, but completely devoid of any semblance of an interesting or worthy world view. I had fun up to the middle and then I stopped caring -- it became completely boring when I realized they had nothing solid to say.

The philosophy defended in the story is just awful. A work of art, especially a sci-fi comedy such as this, requires a layer of meaning, which here is so wrong that I am not being unfair in considering it totally missing.

140 minutes that should either have been only 70 or turned into something worthy, instead of self-indulging in dirty jokes.

I am not a religious person; it's just that if you think about the one-sentence moral of the story, you quickly realize it's nonsense.

If you are looking for a sci-fi comedy, you are better off watching "Back to the Future" again, and there's no way this is as worthy of that, or worthy of all the praise. I predict everyone will have forgotten this film very soon.

Title: Not Oscar worthy
Review:
This movie did not deserve the awards. Remember when Shakespeare in love won best picture, best actress? To me it's the same what the hell is going on moment. It was boring. I love Jamie Lee Curtis and her scenes were great and at times very funny but everything else about this movie just didn't work. Yes I understood the message. No it didn't go over my head. Title: Avoid
Review:
Stunningly bad. Anime-like overacting. Heavily edited jump cutting in fight scenes. Incredibly poor, chaotic story line. Tasteless, heavy-handed attempts at humor. Home-brew quality special effects and props.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is essentially the rebirth of Kung Pow: Enter the Fist. Twenty years later, without humor, and lacking the self-deprecation of Kung Pow. At least Kung Pow knew what it aspired to be.

Title: Totally garbage interpretation of the multiverse
Review:
What a load of unwatchable nonsense. This movie pretends to explore the concept of a multiverse, but it is nonsense. It is completely implausible that a new universe is birthed every time any individual makes a decision, as there are billions of people who continually make decisions that seem trivial at the time they are made that change everything downstream. Even worse is that the alternative multiverses contain key elements that defy evolution - for an alternate reality to exist, it would still have to make sense. If you want to watch something that has something real to say, watch Beef and skip this garbage.

Title: Biggest pile of total junk I have ever seen. Winning an Oscar is now officially a new low.
Review:
If you have an IQ of less than 1 you will love this movie. Total mindless junk. Insult to class movies from 2022 such as 'No Time to Die' and 'Top Gun Maverick' which should have won Oscars just for their closing credits compared to this senseless movie.

Michelle's acting was great but what a total waste of talent. Her fight scenes were good but that was it. It amazes me that it won 7 Oscars and as such I will now associate more Oscars wins with more reasons to avoid watching movies. There was nothing 'deep' about this movie. Just a mish mash of random scenes of absolute brain cell obliterating garbage.

I wish I could get that 2+ hours of my life back. I can't. But you can-avoid this at all costs. You'd happily rather watch paint dry I can assure you.

Title: Is it sci-fi? Is it comedy? Is it drama? Is it kung-fu? It is all and fails miserably
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: What the hell did I just watch???
Review:
I love artsy, indie, sci-fi, etc but I can't even tell you what genre this is supposed to be... first thought it was satire but halfway through felt as if my brain was undergoing a torture experiment -- it is definitely not comedy. It tries WAY TOO HARD to explore themes that frankly have been done better many times (Matrix, etc). I'm always up for a good mind-bender (Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind and Interstellar are 2 of my favorites) but this is a mess from beginning to end. It's chaotic and leaves you wondering what the plot even was. I expected "arthouse," but this should end up in the "outhouse."

Title: The Oscars are a joke
Review:
Seven Oscars for this? A confused mess of a movie that is way too long, tries to be too clever and rewards people that don't really deserve it. I don't think anyone would seriously begrudge Michelle Yeoh the Oscar for best actress but the simple fact is that Cate Blanchett should have won for 'Tar'. I like Jamie Lee Curtis but was this an Oscar winning performance? Not in my opinion.

If there was one Oscar that was truly deserved it was for editing and there is no doubt that it is superb in this movie. But overall this most definitely did not deserve to clean up the way it did, hell I even hit the fast forward button as I was bored to tears towards the end. Over hyped and overrated.

Title: So bad....
Review:
It's like this movie wanted to try to be an impressive movie, but I was left lacking in so many aspects. From the plot to the acting to the frantic directing to the unfortunate attempts at humor in the writing, it was a complete flop. I really don't understand where it received any awards.

I think that the multiverse is a real interesting concept and the attempt to draw the viewer into it was the right theory. But it didn't come across well at all. The characters weren't anyone I cared about nor felt compelled to support. The larger fight that they were supposed to save didn't make you appreciate the weak, unfortunate characters that they were.

Title: Nothing Nowhere Never
Review:
Could be the most overrated and under preforming movie I've ever attempted to enjoy. A juvenile portrayal of life's challenges. A typical Hallmark inspired movie plot reimagined in a delusional drug fueled haze.

Obvious self taught special effects are comical, but not in a funny or entertaining way.

When the writers also direct the movie ,there is a tendency to go ploughing through the script full speed ahead, whether it works or not.

I found this movie unwatchable. I enjoy good science fiction. I enjoy good portrayals of alternative universes or interconnected multiverses, unfortunately this has neither.

For whatever reasons the reviews are amply peppered with 9s and 10s. I know I watched the same movie as they did, but I guess I decided to review on it's over all merit rather than a bunch sight gags and badly veiled references, although the Ratatouille reference was a high point. Can not recommend on any level. My condolences to all competitors who lost an award to it.

Title: Too Much! Everywhere All At Once!
Review:
I consider myself to have a pretty open mind when it comes to film but this was just too much! Is all the hype surrounding this movie Hollywood's attempt to be more inclusive?

Too bad Crazy Rich Asians, which actually had a storyline, wasn't recognized with a few more Oscars nominations a few yrs back.

Yes. Every decision we make alters our lives forevermore and puts us in an alternative universe but WOW! Sensory overload!

I appreciate the overall message and theme of the film - Be loving and kind and be grateful for what you have. Accept life as it is. Not what it could have been.

Everything, Everywhere All At Once in my opinion is a BOMB!

Title: Tedious, uninteresting
Review:
The makers had a thought like:

'Hey, how badass would be a trailer look with a lady punching her way through different lives?' "Tight, but what's the story?" 'Am sure we can contrive something'.

They couldn't. The film is disconnected, it fails to create any tone right from the beginning. One doesn't empathize with the protagonist. One doesn't feel the urgency when she's said to be in danger and one doesn't feel thrill when she starts fighting. Leave alone the lackluster 'theory'. I spent a freaking 45 minutes, trying to connect with it, finally gave up on it and felt like I should warn others to save their time.

Title: No, never ever an Oscar movie
Review:
Given I have watched this movie after a long (I'm in Europe) and sleepless Oscar night, but I doubt this has risen my expectations too high to be fair. Based on a very simplistic view at the concept of multiverses and stuffed with every personal problem a family encounters nowaday, fast editing, some fair actors and few cheap visual tricks fail to cover a flat script.

Everything is connected in some way to everything and husbands and daughters aren't much help if you cannot cope with your own demons, but can anybody tell me, why this movie is worth over 2 hours of my own life? Even the first half of Monty Pythons 'Meaning of Life' offers more insights, fun and katharsis than this overlong, overstuffed and overrated roller-coaster ride into the emptiness of life, without even realizing that this movie is part of the problem it apparently tries to find a solution to.

Even a 'box of chocolates' give me more entertainment than this doughnut and I didn't even like other movie.

Title: [3.5] Butts and sausages
Review:
A horrible, nonsense and nonsensical movie with near zero and sub zero everything, refrigerating and freezing viewers minds with utter trash mumbo jumbo and that is a disgrace to the mumbo jumbo expression and meaning.

How it managed to win so many "fields" in the Oscars is just mind numbing, completely baffling and in my opinion just showing corrosion and downgrade, year by year of what once was a hallmark of standard, quality, deep thinking and marvelousness in the motion pictures (industry).

Though i very much like Korean productions, but this one is just good for a stoned pastime played at 1.8x lightning speed.

Screenplay/story: 4 Development: 5 Realism: 2 Entertainment: 2 Acting: 5 Filming/cinematography: 4 VFX: 7 Music/score: 5 Depth: 5 Logic: 2 Flow: 3 Action adventure comedy 3 Ending: 3.

Title: Overhyped
Review:
I went to see it because of the hype and reviews like "near flawless movie". I found this film to be boring, predictable, silly and unoriginal.

To me there were too many parallels to The Matrix: Jumping between the worlds, regular people turning into "agents", downloading skills, love will save everything, etc..

The childish fraternity-style sexual humor was not funny and seemed unnecessary.

Switching between English and Mandarin was annoying. I get it. They are family of immigrants, so thick accent explains it fully. Why do you need to switch to Mandarin with English subtitles? It's distracting.

.Way below expectations.

Title: Ridiculous overrated mess
Review:
This film is a grossly overrated , disjointed , boring giant meandering mess. It has a weak plot with no significant character development . I Watched most all of it to give it a chance and I can't find anything that worked other than maybe the special effects . I'm at a complete loss as to how this film could hold anyone's interest . If wasn't interesting , coherent, fun, or funny. Yiu can't tell whether they intend to be serious or funny or if it's just a very bad attempt at a black comedy . Either way it doesn't work and mid way through , you just don't care about the story or the characters and at that point even the special effects become as annoying as the actors and the bad dialogue. This film just went nowhere very slowly and very painfully .

Title: Seriously???
Review:
I turned the movie off three times before I made it to the end on the fourth try. What the heck was that? This was pretty much torturous to watch. Is this what the Oscars have come to? Simply produce the strangest, offbeat movie you can imagine. The Academy will see it as art and award it regardless of how inane the storyline. One thing that I did try to focus on was the acting performances. I didn't find that either Jamie Lee Curtis or Michelle Yeoh had enough dialogue to be considered for any 'best of' awards. For the most part the movie spends a good amount of time between scenes with no dialogue, just a good amount of siezure inducing flashbacks. Not recommended!!!

Title: Wannabe Philosophers
Review:
This movie is around average, I really couldn't connect to the main plot. It uses some exaggerated multiverse concept that none can actually understand, inorder to try to solve a family crisis. The jokes are pretty awful, idk maybe they'll be funny in another universe ü§î

I think most of the high reviews are from people who want to think that they are some big shot philosophers who have just witnessed a movie about the infinite multiverse, which apparently (according to the movie) the same infinite multiverse can fit in a floating donut.

I really wanted to like this movie, and to be true, it's an experience. I won't advice against watching it but if you do watch it, make sure there's lot of popcorn and be prepared for shallow jokes and ton of weirdness.

Good luck !

Title: Not even mushrooms made this enjoyable
Review: I was on mushrooms watching this and still had a terrible time. Why all the acclaim for this asinine production? Take notes, film students: You, too, can win all of the awards if you include allll the things! Do you like peach cobbler? Make an entire set dedicated to peach cobbler! You can have peach cobbler chairs and peach cobbler clothes and-no wait! Now you should suck everyone into a new setting altogether because creative whiplash is cool now! We might revisit peach cobbler later for no reason, but now let's focus on horse racing where the protagonists are the horses, and the jockeys are pterodactyls (but, like...in a sad way). The creative direction here was akin to having someone scream in my face about 100 different topics while flashing a nearly continuous strobe of various colors for 2h 19m. I can only imagine this what it's like to be in the mind of a completely psychotic individual. The acting was good in that it was chaotic and ranged the spectrum of emotions, but that's all I got in terms of praise. This movie threw spaghetti at the wall in every possible way: costumes (You don't like bagel hair? Well how about hot dog fingers!); setting (Don't get too attached to the laundromat idea, because we're about to spend an insane amount of time looking at rocks in silence); themes (Love? No, betrayal! Actually, revenge! Sorry, it really was love...but then shame. Also fear. And of course there's the recurring you-can-do-anything-as-long-as-you-have-a-Bluetooth-earpiece-no-one-has-used-in-two-decades). I can't believe how much praise this is garnering. I'm just a millennial, but I really hope this kind of film doesn't become the norm. Watch Casablanca and then watch this, and tell me we're headed in the right direction.

Title: chaotic, confusing, exaggerated, weak plot, incomprehensible, poor character development, forced dialogues, unbelievable, clich√©, messy.
Review:
This film is a perfect example of chaotic storytelling, with a disjointed and often confusing plot that leaves viewers struggling to follow along. The pacing is frantic, and the sheer amount of over-the-top action sequences only serves to further muddle the narrative. The storyline is weak and far from engaging, and the lack of proper character development makes it difficult to invest in any of the on-screen personalities.

The dialogues feel forced and contrived, with many clich√©d lines that detract from the overall experience. The film's relentless chaos detracts from any meaningful emotional or thematic exploration, ultimately making it an exhausting watch. Despite its ambitious premise, this film fails to deliver on multiple fronts, earning a disappointing 4 out of 10 rating.

By the time we were 40 minutes in my wife says, I have no idea what's going on. Relief struck as I surely thought it was just me. She says to me, I can't watch this, my feelings were mutual and with one click of a button we made this rubbish disappear and agreed that the Academy truly has no credibility.

Title: Off the rails ... and into the ditch
Review:
Although the first 30 minutes of this movie was quite compelling and showed much promise, the remainder of the film consisted of senseless vignettes that failed to engage me and included various attempts at humor which were often in poor taste, if not outright disgusting. Eventually, it became an embarrassment to watch.

Did I understand the plot? Yes. Was it easy to follow? Yes.

A movie like this begs to be watched multiple times, to discover the hidden gems inside (think, for example, of Mulholland Drive). Unfortunately, I could not bear to watch Everything Everywhere All At Once a second time, let alone a 3rd, 4th, or 5th viewing.

Title: Very misleading trailer
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: And everything and everywhere all again and repeat...
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once is undeniably awesome in its payoffs, but it just really isn't good at building those up. In this movie, Michelle Yeoh travels around the multiverse, looking at her different lives. Scenes often get thoroughly climatic, like the one where Yeoh's character bursts through all the different lives she lives in the multiverse. The way it was shot, with all the color flying before our eyes, was so adrenaline-pumping that I wanted to leap out of my seat and cheer. But the movie is rapidly losing its magic when this kind of scene is played for about the hundredth time. We have to go to all the universes again. Imagine my exhaustion.

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a fair description of the movie's pacing. Scenes overwhelm us with flashes and blasts. Once in a while, Michelle Yeoh would showcase her performance when the script required her to give a heartfelt speech. Those are touching for the first time, not so much for the twentieth.

A big selling point is the martial arts in the movie. Yeoh is obviously an expert, but the fights themselves don't get better than a Jackie Chan movie. I found them maybe too choreographed, and I didn't get the use of extreme slow-mo. The moves are predictable; when a bad guy raises a fist towards our protagonist, we already know that she will block it, and make a counter-attack. And so on.

I do get why the story is so beloved: The protagonist doing taxes is a fairly clever idea, except a tax office is too bland of a place to have half your movie take place in. I struggle to take the whole multiverse aspect seriously. Everytime there is a smart idea, the spotlight of it gets stolen by a joke. Example: The backstory of the villain involves them experiencing every universe, every life all at once, but unimpressed by what they encountered. They decide to destroy everything with...a giant bagel. And this whole villain arc is solved by...that's right, another heartfelt speech. I acknowledge the creativity and craft behind Everything Everywhere All at Once, but I don't really buy its structure.

Title: You wil love or hate it
Review:
This is pretty much a love or hate movie. And I dislike it. The start was ok, you learn about a normal family and their everyday drama and how to deal with them.

But then it turns into a madness of effects, hilarious setups and fighting scenes that is a love or hate.

I do like action movies, when done right, but no - when each action turns into is a matter of doing disgusting stuff to change to a world where you can learn.

It turned out to be nonsense and off putting in 3the degree.

I love comedy, but no where here the effects used to make a situation "funny" worked. I did not laugh at all.

If you like action, nonsense, and funny effects that are at the lowest level, go ahead, you might even love the movie.

Title: Handbook for filmmaking that forgot to add a plot
Review:
This was two-plus hours of how-to vignettes on how to add razzle-dazzle to your film. Pick and choose which one will work for YOUR film!

Like....

Here, have her move down the aisle at light speed in her chair. Wow! Pretty neat!

Here, have her relocate - again at light speed! - to another universe and, yeah, track the universes on a cell-phone screen with pixels left over from PacMan. Cool!

Here, a sex toy! Use it somehow! Cool!

Oh wait, need some faux philosophy. Let's use something my kid wrote during therapy. Cool, just cool.

Then they realized that with all these vignettes that you too(!) can insert into your film that they needed a plot. So naturally have it all happen at a laundromat! Continuity!

Ok, Everything team, you really do know how to film gimmicky scenes.

So I know exactly what this is. It's a Filming Gimmicky Scenes documentary.

As a documentary, 10!

As a feature film with a plot requirement, 1.

Average: 2 (the plot being missing counted more than the documentary part).

Title: Everything is Too Much
Review:
I listen to a film podcast The Filmcast (great show) where the hosts actively avoid using the word "pretentious" when describing a film. I generally agree with their view on not using the adjective, since it rarely describes the movie and often short shrifts its content. This time, however, I must say I find it very difficult not to use this word in describing Everything Everywhere All at Once; the title of the movie already begs for the adjective, after all.

I found this movie to be extremely boring and opportunistic, while at the same time it was trying way too hard to be inventive. There is a fake ending at around the half point of the film, which was a cruel joke. After that scene, the film seemed to drag on even worse. The technical directing, on the other hand, was masterful. Unfortunately, beautiful moving images aren't enough to keep me entertained.

Title: Sentimental psychodelia: powerful but partially ruined.
Review:
It has to be said that, for all its originality, it's still the same three-act movie Hollywood has been making for decades, the only one they'll ever make, this time spiced up with sentimental chinese psychedelia. A24 is still part of the industry. But, for a moment, it really is fresh, fast and fun. Michelle Yeoh is a star, the action is great and there's one of the funniest scenes I've ever witnessed on a screen.

Some very strong film-making. However, at one point, the film disintegrates. First, it struggles with the task of actually explaining what's going on, and suffers from it. Next, it struggles to maintain an ever-increasing momentum, throwing at the viewer, well, everything all at once. Like making a cocktail with everything at the bar, nothing sticks, it becomes something on your screen for a period of time (sorry). And yet, some occurrences, such as the raccoon, are still absolutely irresistible.

My main issue is in the end it shifts priorities, it becomes worried about being taken seriously as a thoughtful piece of drama with pseudo-philosophical musings. That hurts the film immensely. I was disappointed, checking my watch, wondering why this movie suddenly was trying to over-explain basic human emotions. I guess a big part of the audience needs to be reminded of what makes them human. I'm ok with it, though, I'm not going to complain about a possitive message, the problem is there is so much noise the emotional climax is non-existent, or maybe I was numb.

Of course, as expected, there is a subtext of criticism of the Chinese family, supposedly severe, diligent and demanding, contrasted with the permissiveness, communication and affection of the "new" American family. The daughter is eventually the one being right, conveniently English-speaking.

It will undoubtedly be one of the most powerful films to come out of USA in a few years, it's got everything to please today's film fauna. I enjoyed the first half greatly and I personally hope it soon establishes itself as the best multiverse film because that would mean no more are made.

Title: As ambitious as the title suggests, this surreal philosphical morality-tale is so complicated it's perplexing.
Review:
In "Everything Everywhere All At Once" Michelle Yeoh's an inner-city laundromat owner bogged by: dad James Hong's birthday party; hubbie Ke Huy Kwan wanting a divorce; daughter Stephanie Hsu wanting independence; & tax auditor Jamie Lee Curtis doing her job. But when an alternate universe cuts sharply in she sees limitless alternate versions of all these (and herself) waging often violent battles rooted in questions like 'What's the point?' & 'Will love conquer all?'. Co-director / co-writers Dan Kwan & Daniel Scheinert sure were ambitious with this surreal philosphical morality-tale, but too much so - being so complicated as to be perplexing.

Title: When does it get good?

Title: It's really difficult....
Review:

Why isn't this movie sold as a foreign movie, like Parasite was? If I want to read I'd get a book. Movies are a visual medium and although there are rare examples, like the aforementioned Parasite where the movie might be significant enough to make the odd exception I want my movie watching experience to be focused on looking at the acting, cinematography, sets etc. Not a ticker tape of text at the bottom of the screen. So that's how to write 600 characters on a 15 second movie. Crushed it!

Title: Worst movie ever!
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Title: Nothing Special
Review:
I didn't know anything about this, other than the fact that the approval ratings were high. I had also knew it had Oscar buzz, so I thought I would check it out. I watched it on-demand. I actually had to fight not to fall asleep.

I am giving it a five because it is imaginative, but otherwise I probably would have given it a 3.

The story itself was all over the place early, but by the end it became predictable. To me, It was shot in the style of The Matrix. Lots of fight scenes with fast cuts then going to slow motion.

The story itself was quite original for about 45 minutes. They took you in all kinds of directions and it was hard to follow. Then they seemed to realize they needed to pick a story and they settled on a common, somewhat boring, family drama. They were still doing The Matrix style with more fighting, but it really didn't move the story along as quickly. The second half of the film ran out of steam.

Title: I don't get why this is so highly rated
Review:
I don't get why this is so highly rated. I love indie films but honestly after 30 minutes I was losing the will to live. Very disappointing. Maybe the chaos was just not my cup of tea. I appreciate others love it, but I don't get why, so rather than sitting through all 2 hours I gave up. Maybe it would have become the visionary masterpiece others believe it to be. Or maybe it's best appreciated by people with first hand experience of psychedelic drugs. I feel that the actor's talents are wasted, but if they enjoyed making it, good for them. I realise I'm in a minority, but that's ok. If you insist on watching it some really good snacks will help!

Title: A Twilight Zone episode on steroids
Review: This film is like a twilight zone episode on steroids. If it had been a twilight zone episode, it would've been great done in less than 30 minutes given commercials in a half hour show me made back in the 60s. Unfortunately, this movie runs for two hours and 19 minutes give or take considering the end credits. There really wasn't very much original in the plot, considering the twilight zone plots. We're filmed over a half a century ago. There were some good roles for the leads, but like the plot, they lose some of their punch when stretched over such a needlessly long film. It took me four days to complete watching the film because I kept falling asleep and had to stop and watch some thing else and then come back to try and digest another chunk. By the time I watched half of it I had invested enough time in it, that I felt the need to finish it and see if the film had any redeeming qualities. In the end, it's another empty-nester film. How do parents bring up their children to be independent from them and then actually grant them that independence, complete with a heartwarming, happy ending where everyone finds true understanding of themselves and others. Grant you there is the Chinese cultural overlay, but this story plays out in every culture in millions of families every year for hundreds of years and has been made into films and TV shows many times. Again, it could've just an is as easily been made in a 30 minute episode of the twilight zone.

Title: Good message, but...
Review:
...way too long. Some great moments about crucial wisdom that hopefully every human comes to realize in their lifetime. If this movie helps people gain that understanding then that's great. So through most of it I debated walking out of the theater. But I'm glad I was there for the payoff in last 25 minutes or so of the movie.

Title: The Emperor Has No Clothes: The Most Overhyped Movie of All Time
Review:
I recently had the misfortune of watching Everything Everywhere All at Once and must say that it was a massive disappointment. The movie tries too hard to be eccentric and quirky without actually having anything substantial to offer. The plot is convoluted and lacks coherence, making it difficult to follow or invest in the storyline.

In terms of direction and pacing, the film was all over the place, making it tough to understand the purpose of specific scenes or why they were included in the first place.

The acting was the only bright spot. However, that's about the only bright spot.

Overall, Everything Everywhere All at Once is a lackluster attempt at being avant-garde that falls flat in every aspect. Save your time and avoid this film at all costs.

Title: Utter chaos
Review:
As soon as I had heard the amount of Oscars this movie had won and the recommendations from a friend of mine, I set pretty high expectations for this movie. Even though the premise about the effects of life choices on the course of our lives is very intriguing and promising, I was deeply disappointed with a piece of cinema that resembles the blasting sensory stimulation of TikTok and all its alternatives.

At times the movie felt like a B-tier parody of The Matrix or a bad comedy with disengaging action scenes and poorly executed butt plug jokes. Acting was not convincing, and the plot itself does not engage the viewer, since the high speed of alternating scenes at most causes disturbance and discomfort. The only things that seem to keep viewer somewhat interested are special effects and scenery. However, these visually well made parts are buried by many ridiculous plot choices by the writers.

As this big black hole of the film script has devoured the last bits of interest from the audience, the movie tries too hard to convey its two main messages: Kindness and love cures everything & If you do not care about anything (judgement, opinions, your past), you can do and become anything you dream of. The messages undoubtedly carry lot of importance in modern world, even though they may sound a bit cheesy for some. However, the means of conveying these messages just do not hit the spot.

This film is either a hit or a miss for the viewer. The film gives a flawless depiction of what type of content attracts the majority of today's society, a fast paced and poorly structured line of meaningless events, where meaning is drawn from chaos. In my opinion, this type of chaotic storytelling is synthetic and it fails to make you identify with characters, their struggles and growth. Simultaneously it backfires at conveying the intended message. However someone who is used to watching content that requires only few second attention span might have completely opposite opinion about the movie. Personally, I hope this is not the direction of storytelling in film making.

Not Oscar worthy

It is funny, heartwarming, unique and well done, but massively overratewould I recommend it 100%. It's good fund, really sweet and does give you something to think about.

Should you expect one of the most awarded films of all time to deliver? No.

Title: Throw everything at every wall, all at once, to see what sticks...
Review:
I had heard so many rave reviews about this, that I had to give it a go, but I'm afraid I wasn't impressed.

Michelle Yeoh is good, as always, and it was great to see Ke Huy Quan again, who makes the best out of a somewhat thankless role. Beyond that, the movie is a drawn out, somewhat ponderous effort.

Have you ever asked yourself, are there only so many stories that can be written and only so many songs that can be sung? Have all the ideas been used up? If so, what is left, and what would you need to do, to grab someone's attention?

That's what this movie feels like. When all the ideas are gone, lets throw absolutely everything at the wall in a blinding kaleidoscopic mish-mash of so many half-baked ideas and details, that nobody will notice that there is no real story going on and nothing really happens.

I'll grant it a '5', because on first watch it's odd enough to maintain your curiosity, rather than simply switching off. Although it feels at least an hour too long. Perhaps more... It's the kind of thing that would have been better suited to a 25 minute Twilight Zone episode.

Title: Best Picture?
Review:
One of the worst movies I have ever seen. The most pointless script ever. How such an awful movie could win many academy awards is just testament to how lame the members are. Special effects are quite good, but to what point? There is none. When it's all over you can only wonder if you could have devised a bigger waste of time than watching this movie. I remember seeing the actors and other contributors to the movie seemingly surprised beyond belief about all of the awards they were winning at the Oscars. I understand why now. If like to watch splashy special effects for more than too hours and wonder where it's all going, then this is the movie for you.

Title: Overrated
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: a loss of 2+ hours of this lifetime in my universe
Review:
I am not a movie snob. I watch, and mostly enjoy, many many movies per week. A great story told well is a great movie.

However... after 15 minutes of this story i was befuddled; after 60 minutes i was confused; after the movie ended i was looking for the time i lost on this one.

EEAAO reminded me of the kind of psychedelic slop put together to warn kids from using hallucinogens back in the 60's. I was waiting for a flash back from my hallucinogen days while watching this 'story'....

on the plus side, really interesting use of lighting and editing.

Take a half of a xanax before this movie-- Look out if you like closed captioning, as you may miss tons of dialog and possibly go blind.....

Title: Unique but convoluted
Review:
I am a big Michelle Yeoh fan.....I knew and liked her before Crouching Tiger made her internationally known. I really like Jamie Lee Curtis. And the actor that played the husband is an excellent actor and was the most believable in switching emotions. Even the guy in the wheelchair is famously known and played the main villian in 'Big Trouble in Little China'. So the movie got it right with the casting but there is another huge problem....story and pacing. While the story seems original, it is a mishmash of 'The One'(multiple universes) & Sense 8(grabbing abilities from other selves) & Matrix(alternate reality).

The problem is the movie is trying to be all three while trying to be a comedy and family drama with the already science fiction/fantasy/kung fu elements that exists. Does that statement sounds confusing? Then you understand how this movie will be. It is extremely chaotic, jarring and the combination of drama, comedy, scifi, fantasy brings down the movie. There is so much going on and so much explanation needed to understand that the director should have slowed it down a few times in the beginning so that the audience can understand the rules. Instead each scene is explaining something new as if they are making it up as they go. After a while, you are tired and don't care anymore as the director tries to amp up the action and special effects of a scene without explaining why the scene is even happening.

To put this in perspective, imagine Color Purple, Fast and the Furious, Jackie Chan movie smashed together and directed by Michael Bay and that is what you have here.

Title: Too weird and chaotic
Review:
I understand the movie was very creative and was trying to communicate lots of deep statements. However, i just didn't like it. My GF also hated every minute of this.

If you are an artist you would probably enjoy this. But if you are not into scifi and lots of craziness then this would not be for you.

It was a bit on the funny side though. But I couldn't sit through the craziness.

Title: 4 stars, just for the effort and jobs created
Review:
As the title review mentions, I offered 4 stars just for the effort and the jobs created while making this movie.

Apparently, script, story and everything else does not matter when you have to follow a political agenda. We need to give Oscars to Asians, because they never got one. Next time on Oscars - we need to give Oscars to Africans because they never got one. And so on, until everybody feels included, even though their movies are crap, without essence or authenticity.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is the start of a new era, where talent doesn't mean anything, as long as it's socially correct.

Jamie Lee Curtis got the Oscar for this movie just because she was fading away, so there was no other chance to award her for years of activity.

Title: Modern Day Eraserhead on Steroids and Hallucinogens
Review:
Surreal, hyper and ADHD satisfying paced cinema that should come with a prerequisite course to prepare the viewer of its intentions and meaning. Like the vintage Eraserhead, it can leave the viewer agitated and confused instead of entertained. For some, they "get it" and that's ok. For others like me, it's too much work to invest in getting satisfaction. The Oscar accolades and numerous awards are an overreach but I do agree that there is talent demonstrated in the concept and cinematography. Whether Hollywood is attempting to show its acceptance of the Asian community with all of these awards remains a question, in my opinion. Frankly, I'm impressed but not to the point of believing it deserved so many awards.

Title: Overlong, Overstuffed and Ultimately Ridicilous
Review:
I watched "Everything Everywhere All at Once" recently. It is a very strange movie about multiple realities intersecting and affecting the entire universe. It is up to a middle-aged Chinese immigrant (Michelle Yeoh) to save the universe! Also involved is Jamie Lee Curtis as an overzealous IRS auditor! To me, it seemed like being in an overlong acid trip (although I have never taken LSD, it seemed like something one might experience on that drug!). So, I am not sure I can recommend this movie, except that Michelle Yeoh and especially Jamie Lee Curtis's performances are very good. I found the movie itself to be overstuffed, overlong and ultimately ridiculous. 5/10.

Title: Came for the nihilism, left disappointed
Review:
Went in with high expectations, especially as someone who enjoys mindscrew media and nihilism, but this was a mess of a movie. The first 45 minutes telling the story of a struggling immigrant family had me engaged, despite the rather hamfisted misunderstood lesbian daughter drama, but as soon as they go to the IRS office, the entire movie goes off the rails and turns into a wacky kung-fu romp. I struggled to suspend my disbelief because the writing was so stereotypical that I just assumed they were going to pull back the veil to reveal they were parodying bad science fiction, but no, they spend two hours on this weak plot. Most frustratingly, Ke Huy Quan (Waymond) mumbles and rushes through most of his lines and switches frequently between Mandarin and English, making his frenzied explanations incoherent and hard to follow. This was an annoying and disappointing watch and I found myself constantly checking to see when it would be over.

Title: One word: illogical
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Too much hyped
Review:
I had a lot of expectations for this movie after hearing so much positive about the movie from both critics and the audience. The makers tried to be deep and profound, but what resulted was two hours of head-splitting chaos and confusion. I just don't understand the hype for this movie. They tried too hard to be weird. I think at the end they were trying to pull the heartstrings, but I was too confused to know for sure. I'm not even sure what the movie was about. Whatever it was, they should have had an epileptic seizure warning. Overall, it was just a messy movie with bad editing and it was just movie's luck that it worked at box office.

Title: What a mess!
Review:
I've struggled through many movies before, but this one takes the cake. I get what it was trying to do, it just didn't do it as well as Rick & Morty have done with multiverse and interdimensional travel. I didn't feel for any of the characters at all. The father was memorable from Seinfeld..."Sign-fell.....FOUR!". Yeah, it's that guy. I just cannot believe how long this movie was for such a thin plot. I can see a lot of effort was put into effects and visuals, but they should worked on presentation of the story itself. The jumping around to ridiculous segwes was more aggravating than intriguing. It was really unwatchable for me and it took me four tries to get through it. I'm pretty tolerant and forgiving with movies of all kinds, but with all of the hype this received, it was more overreach and overcompensation of a terrible movie. And no, it wasn't deep or too intellectual for me. It was being made it up as they went along. I was hoping to be challenged and to grow from it. It failed me.

Title: Celebrates naturalistic violence
Review:
I was really hyped to see this movie, especially to see the multiverse visualization and it was the first film I wanted to watch in a cinema for years.

I also wanted to watch it on my birthday in an open air cinema but that didn't happen due to torrents of rain and I am glad. Why?

This movie celebrates naturalistic violence. It starts innocently enough depicting a realistic family facing all kinds of struggles, mostly about money and relationships.

Then it suddenly descends into graphic cruelty towards average people (think a tax officer, low level unarmed government building security or innocent bystanders).

If you enjoy average people viciously hit in the face, necks snapped and inflicting pain this one is for you.

I watched this with my date who was a victim of brutality (indeed her face was broken once) so I suggested to leave the cinema after 20 minutes or so as the graphic violence just got worse and worse.

We went home and had some intimate sex instead. That was the best part of the movie.

The multiverse idea is just used as an excuse to justify depictions of sadism and gore. The fact that this celebration of naturalistic violence received so many Oscars proves the poor state of our world and how numb audiences are who actually laugh about physical harm inflicted to their fellow human beings.

And don't think that I did not watch some Eastern type of movies in the past where supernatural fighters would fly and do kung fu in fantasy historical settings. This movie here is different in that people like me and you get hurt.

Title: Eyes hurting from all the rolling...
Review:
This movie tries way too hard. Maybe it's an attempt to match the the extreme pace of so many movies these days - trying to dazzle audiences with constant action, humour, emotions and story so we don't lose attention...or something. I suppose many of us have lost the patience to appreciate the character development, subtlety, and simplicity of well-crafted plots. Maybe we have been conditioned by Marvel, tik tok and YouTube to crave bursts of action, CGI, flashing lights and simple, accessible, and lazy comedy. This movie fails to capture my attention because it's all there, all at once. I don't have to wait for anything, and I don't have time to wonder what will happen next. Mind you, it's too random for this anyway. I'm disheartened to see this movie rated so highly. Nothing but cheap thrills here.

Title: Everything (a) Bagel?? Very overrated movie
Review:
Lots of thoughts and colourful spots. Like an abstract expressionist painting. But this movie doesn't fulfill a simple definition of art: "A work of fiction that creates its own reality." No. This movie has no reality. Only bits and pieces of craftsmanship that add up to 2 hours of nothing. Heard (and seen) in dialogue like "I want to be Your daughter in a place that is not this but somewhere where that place is me". (Or something similar. I paraphrased). If the amount of energy to write childish and primitive, repetitive jokes about bodily functions or adult toys would have been invested in plot, characters, and more than two and a half funny dialogue lines - well, the movie could have been okay. And hopefully 65 minutes shorter.

Title: Who doesn't find sausage hands hilarious?
Review:
This movie reminded me of two other movies that I've seen in my life which were so terrible that I had a hard time watching them. These were 'This is the end' and 'Dumb and Dumber To'. In both cases, I watched the movies because a friend chose them. However, this time, I had only myself to blame for sitting through 140 minutes of the film and wondering "What am I watching? Where do the 8 stars on IMDB come from? When will it get better? Is this supposed to be make me laugh?"

Usually, I check IMDB before watching a movie as it gives me an idea of the quality of the movie. This particular one had received an 8 out of 10, yet I had never been more disappointed with a movie. The plot was incoherent and bizarre, while the attempt at humor consisted of oddities that seemed like they were meant to be funny just because of their randomness. If the idea of an alternate universe where people have hotdogs for hands makes you chuckle, you might want to check out this movie. But only do so if you also enjoy childish humor, tasteless unnecessary sex jokes, and a cheap 'message' that is slapped in your face. Otherwise don't bother.

If you're curious, read a few other mixed or low rating reviews first (I wish I had done that) and you'll find out soon enough if this movie is for you or not. But I would suggest skipping it altogether. I don't regret watching it, but I do regret finishing it because it never got any better and it was a waste of time.

Title: Virtuoso performances, but a bit of a drag overall
Review:
There's nothing not to love about the utterly stellar performance of Michelle Yeoh; never was an Oscar more richly deserved. And she's supported by a terrific cast, with Ke Quy Kwan as the husband, and Jamie Lee Curtis - an inspired casting choice - playing a dowdy (but powerful!) IRS agent.

That being said, the film was too long for its content, and I thought it lacked coherence. Rather than one film, it felt as though I was watching about 5 very similar films all spliced together, and by about half way through I'd begun to lose interest. (My partner outdid me in lack of interest and fell asleep.) And by the end I was checking my watch with impatience.

In a way it was like watching a virtuoso violinist or pianist playing brilliant music - you start off being entertained and amazed at the sheer technical mastery and wizardry of the musician, but after a while you get bored by the pyrotechnics and wish for something with a bit of heart. This film was a bit like that - intensely full-on, a madcap wild ride, but ultimately lacking heart.

My partner was also uncomfortable about the scenes with the dog being used a sort of catapult or sling shot.

There was humour of quite a broad sort (who will ever look at a butt-plug the same way again?) which I felt was a bit out of character for the film. I should say that I'm no prude, I just thought that these scenes were gratuitous.

In short, too long for its content, and lacking depth of feeling.

Title: Torturous
Review:
2+ hours of vapid filmmakers screaming at me, demanding that I acknowledge their brilliance. Through 139 minutes of screamed cliches and bumper-sticker psychology, they continue to pound home some meaningless insight(?) like a self-impressed 14 year-old. Loud and piercing, this movie is entirely populated by shallow, miserable characters, none of whom are likable nor draw us into their stories. The movie noticeably changes gears right about the time the viewer wishes it to simply end: realizing that whatever its intention was is not working, it quickly devolves from dumb to ridiculous to patently stupid. A total regret.

Title: Tries too hard to be everything at the same time
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Trying to hype the multiverse theory?
Review:
I am seriously struggling to understand the amount of praise being heaped on this movie. Granted, the lead (M Yeoh) and a few others provide commendable performances, but this barely compensates for the jarring scene transitions and often weak/trite dialog.

While the pastiche of colour and special effects was meant to help convey humour and levity, it's overuse became tedious and harder to watch as this lengthy movie progressed.

Efforts to "Mormanise" the audience with their repeated religious 'be kind' messaging, felt contrived, inauthentic and predictable.

In summary, attempting a smorgasbord of sci-fi humour and relying upon an Asian laundromat setting & often-clunky special effects failed to deliver on expectations. However, I've happily scored a solid 3, acknowledgment of the first time I've seen this (multiverse) premise being explored in a comedy.

The mother seem to have a hard time doing this because of how easily her own father was willing to send her away. In the end the movie was long and drawn out I do not recommend.

Title: I guess I was in the wrong universe to enjoy this film.

I decided to give "Everywhere, Everything, All at Once" another try. I watched it all the way through but it never captured my attention. The presentation of the multiverse didn't work for me. I guess I'm just limited by my linear thinking.

The actors were engaging but the story was not. I know the movie was trying to convey some grand message on living one's life but it was lost on me.

On a technical side it should win the Oscar for Editing!

Title: What?
Review:
I watch movies to be entertained. I watch documentaries to learn. I watch comedies to be amused. I watch horror to be frightened. I watch sci-fi's to make me dream of the future. You get the idea.

What I don't want to watch is movies, like this one, that I get nothing from. It's someone's idea of a comedy, not mine. It's a bunch of dumb situations, with people doing dumb things to get dumb results.

For me, it was a gigantic waste of time. I only watched to the end to see if it had ANY redeeming qualities that would make people want to give it an Academy Award for Best Picture. I didn't see any.

But, I guess in this world where people vote in politicians like Donald Trump and company, where crazy theories get people to March on our Congress, etc. The universe really is going crazy and in that crazy universe this just might be considered an excellent movie.

God help us!

Title: The Most Baffling Movie
Review: When I first heard about this movie all I heard was praise. Everyone around me was going on about how good this movie is, among reviews online saying it was the best movie of the year. From my curiosity, I played this movie. At first I was extremely confused. I came into the movie blind not knowing much about it at all. I only had it hyped in my head (my first mistake). I continued to watch this movie and as this movie went on. I thought at some moment there would be a movie changing moment and cinema moment. There was nothing. The entire movie was absurdism and just plain unfunny. Humor of what? Fighting with dicks? Hot dogs for fingers? Did I watch the same movie as everyone else. The same movie that won over a multitude of awards. The most baffling thing was that this movie won 7 Oscars. I did not think the performances in this movie was out of this world or anything crazy to deserve that many awards. At first I thought it was just me. All the people around me were crying over this movie. So I rewatched the movie again. It became painfully harder to watch this time. The movies runtime is so long and it is just plain boring to me. I ended up giving this movie one more chance with a third watch. The third watch made me realize that the movie simply was not for me. I understood the movie. I understood that the movie was about a mother becoming accepting about her daughter. For reference I'm a bi girl with immigrant and homophobic parents. So it is not that the movie did not relate to me. I just for the life of me can not understand how people are rating this the best or their favorite movie. It for certain did not deserve all the awards it received either.

Title: Avengers endgame bad remake, and with no super heroes, boring

Who let this movie go? Who did give this movie a YES? It should have stayed in a project, there must be so many original ideas out there, powerful and talented writers, look at THE OA series, why arent those scripters making a ton of movies??? I only give 1 star because of Stephanie Hsu, she was a surprise, the only good thing in the movie, her acting was beyong this universe, the rest of the movie is a 0, 1 star for the priceless acting of Steph! A girl with a great future.

Title: No wonder it's free with Prime
Review:

Hubbie would give it 1 as it gave him a headache with the constant diatribe of burbling drivel. The main character, Everlyn has a husband who should have been cast as her son (by appearance of age). I imagine the chaotic storyline and acting requirements must be a credit to the actors. As you can guess, not my kind of movie and as with all movies, it's personal taste. Sadly I was drawn to it for its Oscars but I would class this film as definitely a "Marmite" offering. Typically one could separate the storyline from the quality of the actors; well they deserve a "bravo" for sticking it out and I'll try not to let it prejudice what I choose to watch in the future.

Title: Puerile
Review:
Let's just say the unsayable... this movie is puerile. That single worded description sums it up better than anything. It has nothing. It is childish, silly and painfully unfunny. There is an attempt to present big spiritual, universal themes, which just come off as confused, shallow teenage tropes. The "humour" is nerdy, lacks sophistication, wit and is devoid of actual laughs. Whatever comedy is there is cringe worthy, and you find yourself referring to your viewing partner to see if they are as silently bewildered by its lameness as you are. It's got colour, multiverse-jumping madness, martial arts, quantum physics I'm told. All of that is fun and great, but there is nothing of substance in any of it. No story, no feeling, no guts.

It also suffers that thing so many bad films do... running massively overtime by trying to be an otherworldly epic. It drags on an hour past it's natural cut off time. Just an attenuated, over-boiled mess that results in nothing significant.

I wanted to like this film, I really did. I saw it well before the Oscars hype and was beguiled by how bad it was because I was genuinely looking forward to it going in. At first it was unpopular opinion to say it's not actually good, but after being the most overrated film in living memory (especially post-Oscars) I can see a steady pushback fomenting from the unconvinced masses.

My guess is Tik Tok has ruined people's brains and attention span and so this is the kind of movie they enjoy: cheap comedy, very short scenes that make no sense and shallow 'philosophical' ideas. Totally depressing. I was expecting to at least see Yeoh performing some quality martial arts scenes, but not even that. They've added so many ridiculous special effects that the fight scenes become embarrassing to watch. They're not funny at all. Disgraceful. I'm giving a 1 in order to maybe save some people from having high expectations as I did and wasting their money in the kino. Total garbage that may please social media addicted adolescents, that's it.

Title: The movie equivalent of Thumbelina (with kung fu)

Title: Peurile Junk
