Title: Disappointed really...
Review:
I guess I don't really know what I was expecting... I came to this movie on the recommendation of a movie influencer I follow but purposefully didn't look into it much. I knew it was about exploring other universes and that is usually right up my street.

I was expecting something like "About Time"and "Butterfly Effect" - quite moving storylines with real substance.

Unfortunately I found this verged on the ridiculous. Which I know you have to expect a little with a 'time-travel' style film, but there's ways to it without it becoming silly.

I'm sure some people will find some scenes moving or emotional but I unfortunately I didn't care about the characters enough. It did make me laugh in parts big overall, it was a miss from me.

Title: Hyped spoof ripoff of Matrix + Inception
Review:
Insanely hyped ripoff collage of The Matrix + Inception but in a Steve Martin spoof comedy style.

The equation is: Chinese Kungfu B-Movie from the '70s + The Matrix + Inception - great concepts - the meaningful parts - the great CGI.

The film itself is a comedy, so suspension of belief and all, but it's rather dumb, even demented here and there, with a few funny peaks in Monthy Python style. Its attempts at being spiritual, deep and dramatic are but cheesy, silly and all in all the gullible same ol' family issues that seemingly afflict most people out there. Or so Hollywood seems to think anyway.

If you love forced tears, hypocritical hugs and last minute redemptions, you are in for a treat. Like, I can live 99% of my life as a complete jerk to everyone I know, but I did that because I was worried about bills. I can always turn into somebody completely different in 3 seconds, share a few tears, hug the people I mistreated for decades and all will fall magically into place. With a hug. A very cheesy one.

The film itself is a so so comedy, but I am so annoyed by the insane hype that this is going to be a well placed 1.

Yes, I will cheat this time. It's 1/10 and I ain't sorry folks. Next time be more honest in your ratings. If you give this dough a 10/10, what would you give to its originals (The Matrix, Inception)? 250/10?

And what about, say, any Kurosawa masterpieces? 3500/10?

Get a grip, ladies and lads. Come back down to planet Earth.

Title: Matrix meets post truth world
Review:
It was hard to tell what this movie was trying to get at. It was like a reflection of the philosophy of the age: everything. I mean really everything, is possible, and it iis up to you to choose it. And yet it didn't really believe that either, because it was fatalistic also, like toppings on a bagel. You have no control of it. There ate good themes, but they are jumbled up. Yet on the surface apparent selfless love wins through in the end for mo apparent reason.

The acting was brilliant, but the mediocrity of the script means it will be one of those movies that we will be wondering in years to come how on earth it won so many oscars.

Title: Oh so bloated
Review:
Remarkable performances by Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan and Jamie Lee Curtis. Fight scenes were well choreographed. It's filled with countless metaphors (some of which are clever) in its attempt to deliver a worthwhile message.

But- It goes on and on and on implying that the audience is just too dim to grasp its deep meaning unless it explains it with another "universe", another parallel world. It is the equivalent of a hot pink prom dress with way too may ruffles, sequins, bugle bead fringe and peacock appliqu√©s. And it just goes on and on and on and on when it could have easily ended 20 universes in.

Title: Quite a whirlwind
Review:
I appreciate the technical craft required to make this movie, and just how inventive the story is. I was with it for about half, but then it just got too weird for me. The main story about Evelyn and her family was not too hard to follow and executed pretty well. It was the story going on in the different multiverses that I started to get lost in. The multiverse with the hot dog fingers was a bit too much for me. I did laugh quite a bit during the first half, but a lot less in the second half. I see why people like it; it's just not my type of movie. I'll be interested to see how well it does at the Academy Awards.

Title: The Matrix , Inception , Men in Black 3 All at Once
Review:
For me this is pure Joke. Literally for 2 h and 20 minutes , there are two scenes that mean something: the first one in the laundry and the last one (the hug). Everything in between is complete nonsense. Even LaLa Land deserved more the Oscar than this. Argo wasthe most boring and confusing Oscar winner for me but this tops it.

I barely can say anything positive: maybe the act of Jamie Lee Curtis and Ke huy Quan are goods of the movie.

I think that the creators try to make a visual resuscitation for someone already in brain death !!!

Just watch the movies I mention above and don't waste 2 hours of your time.

Title: I didn't like it BUT...
Review:
After five attempts to watch this movie I gave up and came here to write a negative review. Then I read the review which said it gets better in the second half, so I went back for a sixth time. After about 10 minutes I FF'd to try to find that part, but I give up. I'm not a fan of CGI in general and this had so much I just couldn't stand it. But let me tell you about the parts I did like: Ke Huy Quan's moving Oscar speech, and the interview of 94 year old James Hong on the red carpet. They both brought me to tears. I am 75, so I have seen Hong my whole life, mostly in bit parts. He talked about the Chinese Exclusion Act (a part of US history some people don't want you to know about), and how he felt when he could not get parts in films about Asians because they were given to white actors with taped up eyes. It was good to see Asian actors finally get the parts and appreciation they deserved, but for me that is the best part about this film.

Title: Total Chaos and Outrageousness
Review:
I don't see what people see in this movie. I was in an audience that was mostly 20 year-olds. What I found gross and offensive, a lot of the audience found to be funny. To use violence and sick humor to make points about how to treat others correctly and compassionately just doesn't do it for me. It's trying to please viewers' in a sensorial way which is totally contrary to the feeling, gracious way of creating a lasting worthwhile message in a film. There's just too much emphasis on sick, sensorial thrills in this. Let's make better movies, filmmakers that really touch and audience in a genuine way!

Title: Conservative
Review:
The film's incredible importance lies in its unintentional depiction of what it means to be lost and confused (both artistically and practically) in a world of destabilized values.

Along the "whacky" journey, certain themes emerge: histrionic pity/compassion, tawdry humor, fragile weakness, the exhaustion of spirit, and the frightening, crippling fear of characters partaking and marginally succeeding in barely achieving the average/mediocre life. In essence, it therefore represents a narrative that dangerously projects a common ideal as if it is superior and noble.

In all the commotion, tiresome tricks, and "shocking" artistic choices (rocks, shameless sexual humor, etc.) the narrative does not fail to argue for its own set of specific values (weak kindness, categorical acceptance/tolerance, passivity, etc.). These values do not reflect courage, to me, but rather the voice of an exhausted nihilism.

As a whole this film desperately searches and lunges for something meaningful among the "wild" (not that wild) "multiverse" (not that multi). However, it forgoes any chance for meaning because it does not take the time and energy to create meaning itself.

Instead it shuns the responsibility of meaning to the viewer: please make something of this madness for me! In my opinion that is its appeal. But, the meaning made, the final conclusion of the audience is ultimately one and the same: there is no great standard for judgement anymore.

Perhaps worst of all, this film fails to realize that the inclusion of all things is precisely what it partially argues for. But, the inclusion of everything is itself the creation of meaninglessness since distinctions and judgements are necessary for making meaning. Ironically, that very meaningless it unintentionally creates is also what forces it to settle for the average as its goal.

Finally, its main contradiction is the second thing the film argues for: its own exclusive ideas which I touched on above (kindness, etc.). Therefore it rejects any complete concept of "everything." For example, it has a tendency to include the loud, unpredictable, overly-sensory, etc., but excludes the subtle, graceful, patient, delicate, confident, proud, healthy, tasteful, or beautiful.

In the end, despite its rowdy favoritism towards 1) over-stimulation 2) timid adventure, 3) cheap novelty, 4) the debasement/confusion of the human, and 5) alcoholic escapism, it only drifts back to common conservative values. In that it resembles an accidental advertisement for conservatism.

Title: It's imaginative, new and bloody tedious
Review:
This film has moments of real quality throughout, it is beyond wacky and is the modern day Dr Strangelove in its out there brilliance. 5 sittings it took to watch the whole movie as it was like a constant buzz saw, unrelenting and demanding, an unruly child that wouldn't give up. I kind of liked it but will never watch it again as it is so in your face for such an awful long time that I had to keep stopping the movie and come back another day to continue.

The actors are good and I love the minimalist cast and the multi-roles, I can see this style working on the stage with minimalist sets and cast and it is very cleverly worked. Action scenes are great although the hot dogs are gross.

It just feels like too much and I love long narrative and FX laden movies but this was too much for me.

Title: Too complicated for me
Review:
I'm sorry I actually paid to see this piece of art. I expected a science fiction movie with a touch of comedy. What I got instead was a nonsense script that got worse as the story progressed. The acting was great, however the story was confusing and made me wonder why this picture got so many good reviews. Maybe people saw something I didn't see. The fact is, if you want to be entertained without having to do some brain work, go somewhere else. This movie require a lot of attention and thought. I was looking for something light so I got disappointed. I hope this review helps people like me who are looking for some simple and funny form of entertainment.

Title: Rick and Morty ripoff
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Messy, exhausting, just tiresome
Review:
To be fair: it wasn't that bad. It was certainly unique, but uniqueness doesn't mean greatness. There were a lot of interesting layers of this film, but the chaos and ADHD-like performing was just too dominating. It had slightly similar energy to 'dirk gently's hollistic detective agency'. The exception being that the latter didn't cause a seizure. There is nothing wrong with a bit of mind-bending and chaotic story telling, but when a movie is almost 2.5 hours of a headache causing LSD-trip, i'd rather just take the LSD. And yes, to be fair, it wasn't that bad. I'd give it a 4-5. But seeing the rating it currently holds, I just felt I had to bring the average down, cause it wasn't that good either.

I'm sure you can do better things that watching this horrible film , if o can call it "film "

Title: Stupid
Review:
Super stupid movie! I watched until the end, just to see if it all made sense! Stupid as night, this world is going to hell. I won't apologize, what I like, I like. And this film simply - no. I gave myself time, listened to other people's opinions to really see if I was missing something when it comes to this movie, then watched it again and I just liked it even less. Title: An overhyped disaster .... :(
Review:
Given all of the Academy Awards accolades, my wife and I had great expectations for this film. What we found instead was a loosely based storyline regarding a mother wanting to regain her relationship with her daughter, while somehow caught up bouncing between universes. Ninety percent of the movie is spent jumping around unexplainably and bizarrely from universe to universe without any storyline cohesion, as if the story tellers were striving to see how many weird scenes they could fit into the movie's 2hr -19min runtime. My wife and I looked at each other repeatedly asking "where is this going?" and "is it over yet?". Yes, the performances by the key actors were good given the material, but the movie itself was a total waste of time, never to be seen again. Ironically, Top Gun Maverick - which was the film truly deserving of Oscar recognition and which brought viewers back to theaters - didn't get on the Academy's radar. Instead, their votes went to this disaster.

Title: Don't be fooled by the rating; this movie is awful.
Review:
I was so disappointed in the film, that I actually took the time to confirm my email address in order to leave a review. Completely borrowed storyline, basically a spoof of the Marvel multi-verse concept. Ridiculous, bizarre, shock-value stunts throughout, with no real meat or heart to the plot. Cliche and predictable ending. The only reason I'm giving 2 stars instead of 1 is that they *tried* to have a feel-good movie about life choices and regrets, but it leaves way too much to be desired.

I don't understand the good rating whatsoever- usually IMDB is spot on, but not this time. Avoid this movie at all costs.

Title: Why so Many Oscars? Wasted my precious time.
Review:
Really unsure how did this movie get so many Oscars... billions of people in the world will waste their precious time watching this rubbish movie because of Oscar hype like I did. How did it also get 7 Oscars? Don't waste your time. Boring movie with multiverse concepts going haywire.

Oscar folks please do your job properly next year and don't Rob people's precious hours by recommending movies like this.

The movie was so boring that I had to watch the movie in multiple days. I however watched the movie in my third sitting and the story, the make ups, animations etc makes no sense. And how is this movie a sci-fi movie! It's a bad categorisation. Humorous May be at some places but a childish humour in my opinion. I usually don't rate movies bad, but I had to rate it for those who haven't watched it yet. Don't bother watching and don't waste your time. Watch something else - don't go with Oscar awards hype - that's the lesson learnt for me with this one.

Title: Tried really hard
Review:
I get what they were trying to achieve. As the mother of 2 daughters, as a Mum you try to be everything, everywhere, all at once.

Just missed the mark. By a few universe.

Jumps around so much it's hard to keep up.

No idea what the hot dog fingers are all about. Seemed a bit of a stretch.

Cinema-photography was good. Michelle Yeoh was also amazing in her role. It jus seems the story line tried to pack too much in.

Not sure how this won so many Oscars. Love love love JLC but don't know how she won an Oscar for this, think she was on screen for 20 mins tops. So many other more deserving roles she has played.

Overall. Disappointing.

Title: Asian porography won 7 Oscars AMPAS
Review:
Blame Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences that at 95th Academy Awards, gave an Asian porography picture 7 Oscars. I wanted to see who AMPAS awarded this year, 2023. Fortunately for me, in order not to waste my time with messes, I scanned this so called film, and I came across a more than disgusting scene, euphemistically speaking. On wikipedia, you'll found "absurdist comedy-drama film". I didn't understand where the comedy was. The scene is absurd, really. But what I saw next, was a mud stain, on the whole activity of the Academy. Like Jack Nicholson said "I guess this proves there are as many nuts in the Academy as anywhere else." They are totally out of their minds to give 7 Oscars. The producers made a movie according to their level of intelligence and unbalanced mental level. They are not to be blamed: they were, are and will be, all kinds of crazy people in this world. To blame is Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences that awarded them.

Title: Worst movie
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Only Worth An Oscar In An Alternate Reality
Review:
Wanted to like it as a I like the actors in it, but it was a lousy cable B movie at best. I have never been in such disagreement with people who felt this incoherent mess was worthy of an Oscar in my life! I'd like to ask anyone who felt it was a good movie specifically what they enjoyed so much? It made Jackie Chan's the Tuxedo look like the Godfather. The only thing that didn't make me want to turn it off was the idea of alternate universes, but I enjoyed the execution of that idea much better in the latest Spiderman film. I can only assume the real talent behind this mess of a film is whoever ran it's Oscar campaign. As to individual appeal it must cater to the taste of minds as jumbled as the film itself.

Title: Not really that original
Review:
Was really looking forward to watching this but was hugely disappointed. This just felt like another Hollywood liberal moral finger wagging project. Why can't we all just get along. I'm so misunderstood. Nothing about the journey in this movie was significantly insightful or revealing. The characters didn't change that much either. There have been plenty other movies about time and space that were much more interesting. There have been plenty other better movies about love and understanding and redemption. Like plenty other reviewers I agree it has been way over hyped. Every time I saw it promoted it was described as an indescribable story. I found it pretty easy to follow and pretty easy to see what the film was trying to promote. Really glad Xfinity showed this as one of their free this week movies cause I almost shelled out $20 last week and that would probably have made me rate this movie even lower.

Title: Extended Vine Gag
Review:
The cinematography was aesthetically and visually stunning but it didn't save this movie from being an extended Vine. Insulting stereotypes (so much so they had to go back and change a characters name), disgusting sexual gags, and corney morals all mashed into a Hollywood budget (that couldn't save this movie). I had to look up the directors to make sure they were both over 18 because I felt a lack of maturity.

I will commend the actors for what they put into it despite all the stupidness going on around them. Still they couldn't prevent it from going off the rails. Great to see James Hong tho'. Like always, he eats up every scene.

Unfortunately I can't pull out examples because I really didn't understand what was going on for 90% of the film or what they dubbed "Chapter 1". Then hastily wrapped things up in seven or so minutes in "chapter 2" üòí See the imbalance here.

So yeah, I perplexed at the 8+ rating. Must be a ton of pubescent boys trolling this site.

Title: Oscar is a joke!
Review:
How could they have given 7 oscars to this irritating and extremely poorly written piece of "movie"?

This movie proves that hollywood hasn't changed, it's still the same madness as usual, not that in the old days there weren't overrated, exaggerated and poorly written movies that also won oscars, but they never won as many statues as this meaningless mess I bet the audience for this edition must have been even lower than last year.

This movie is a mess, it's all over the place (literally), the acting is nothing but decent, it sucks, it's overrated, and it's extremely boring most of the time.

Title: WTH
Review:
I've always been a film fan. I can appreciate sub-text, nuance and metaphor as well as the next person. Or at least I thought I could, Because I don't get this 7 times Academy award winning film at all. In my opinion it's quite simply boring and repetitive. Maybe it perked up at the end; I didn't make it that far.

Whichever universe you're in I think this will be equally boring and irritating. Apparently the critics enjoyed it. Or maybe they got their 13 year old kids to watch it for them? Because that's the only audience I can imagine (barely) enjoying this film. A real example of 'emperor's new clothes'. In my opinion, of course.

Title: So bad
Review:
By far the dumbest movie I've tried watching. I've stopped watching it 3 times but every time I decided to give it another chance. If this is what passes for Oscars now, then Oscars have set a very low bar. I guess this is what appeals to the young audience right now, and when I say young, I mean teenagers. I don't think any adult in their right mind would want to waste time on this stupidity. If this is the best that the film makers have to offer, then the film making is dead.

Title: Unwatchable
Review:
Well, this is as far from Seventh art as it is Earth from Andromeda galaxy. It is simply unwatchable and anyone who tells you otherwise is full of BS. Hollywood is in a deep crisis, that's obvious. No ideas, no good scripts, it's all about CGI nowadays, but at least they could have kept the decency to evaluate the movies properly. Shame on you academy. As for the movie, there's really no point of describing it, you will have identical experience while watching your washing machine doing centrifuge. So, do not bother and forget about it like it never existed. I'm pretty sure that Fellini and Bergman are turning in their graves. Cheers.

Title: Observations
Review:
* Polarized reviews due to art being subjective.

* It's lot of abstract allegorical metaphors to illustrate the extremely intense dynamics in families - between mothers & daughters especially.

* If you do not like abstract art, you will hate this. It is basically live action abstract art.

* In spite of understanding it, I'm still glad I only spent $2.15 to rent this . . .

* This might be a fun one for Mystery Science Theater . . .

* Michelle Yeoh is one of my fav actresses . . .

*DVD special features were interesting.

Title: Mildly Funny
Review:
So the Oscar winner for best picture is a mildly entertaining and mildly funny comedy with a story that is, well, how to describe it, nonsense trying to look smart. I for sure can enjoy nonsense but it must be entertaining and here Everything Everywhere All at Once fails - I wasn't engaged, entertained nor was my neural network on fire but, well, most of the time watching I was half asleep or my mind wandered off (maybe in some alternative reality or dimension). Like Babylon, Everything Everywhere All at Once got a few good fun moments, but that this one got the Oscar award of best movie - like Coda last year (also a rather mediocre and overpraised movie) - leaves me rather perplexed. The production is okay but nothing remarkable, the acting mostly solid. I'm pretty sure a decade earlier, neither Everything Everywhere All at Once nor Coda would have been nominated, and winning? I don't believe so.

Title: Brilliant and boring
Review:
That just about sums it up. Wonderfully acted and directed and shot but I was just bored throughout. It might be the multi-universe thing - how implicated can we be if 'nothing matters'? How can we care about a character if the character is one of thousands of versions of themselves? How can we bothered how a story ends or whether someone dies or not if all possible endings exist in the totality of universes? Well, we can't. And who was 'the baddie' and why were they trying to take over the world (or whatever it was they were trying to do or for whatever reason they had to be fought)? I don't know. As a philosophy BA and a lover of 'boring' films - Antonioni, anyone? - I had great expectations for this one but they simply weren't met.

Title: Unnecessarily complicated and confusing
Review:
Some Chinese movies are made intentionally complicated and confusing because the directors want to show off their "high" skills. Otherwise they are afraid people will say it's too simple. On the other hand, many good movies are very simple and not much complicated plots. The performing skills of actors/actresses are the key of successful movies. The movie also has a very weak ending. Too many morals mean no moral.

Title: A piece of garbage
Review:
I could not believe the positive high ratings for this movie. My spouse and I walked out of a theater half way through this film because it was so awful and this was before it became noted. We tried to watch it again online after it was nominated for a best film Oscar thinking we had missed something. It is even worse on a second viewing. If you hated this movie you are not alone. You are simply guilty of good taste. This movie deserves a Raspberry not an Oscar.

This is one of the worst films in cinematic history. Avoid this travesty at all cost. I cannot describe how terrible this film is. Under The Rainbow and Mr. Mike's Mondo Video are classics in comparison. Ed Wood deserves an Oscar before the director of this movie deserves one. Awful film. Avoid.

Title: A weird movie that tries to hard
Review:
I dont know how to feel about this movie. After I saw it, I felt the need to give it a 8. I also feel the need to give it a 2. What was I watching really?

Movie plot and character motivation felt very lacking. Or well, almost non-existant. Story was mediocre at best. Acting was rather good. The storyline was decent but the development and progression of it was awful.

This movie mixes 2 genres that in my book wont really mix that well; Action/sci-fi and drama/deep meaning. Its not awful but it's certainly not a masterpiece either.

It relies on an attempt of great mature storytelling, trying to explain the true purpose of life, which is fine. And in the next scene people are jumping on buttplugs or tries to forcefully pee themself.

It feel like this movie's audience is either very young people or stoners.

Title: Not Science Fiction at all
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Title: Worst movie I've seen in 60 years
Review:
This is easily the worst movie I've ever seen. I generally make it through most movies I start, after having checked reviews, but this I didn't make past 30mins and that with some effort in order to give it a chance.

Just an incoherent mess with some of the worst acting i've ever encountered from all involved.

If this is what Hollywood is giving awards to then they have lost the plot big style.

It signals the end of an era in which there has been so much great entertainment. Nothing ever lasts forever but in the case of this nonsense it should never have existed in the first place.

It makes me wish I lived in an alternate reality, one in which this film doesn't exist!

Here's hoping at some point things get back on an even keel and return to some semblance of sanity, in more ways than this.

Title: If a character has to explain the plot then the film fails
Review:
I was curious to watch this movie because I had heard good things about it and I am a big fan of Michelle Yeoh. I was very disappointed by this mess of a movie. It started off well enough but then devolved into a series of jarring story shifts that overwhelmed any coherent story being told. Several times in the movie Evelyn's guide in an alternate universe delivers a rambling summary of what is going on. If a character in a film has to explain what is going on in the film then the filmmaker has failed in their primary task: making the film coherent to the audience. There is way too much dialogue attempting to describe what is going instead letting the story unfold on its own. The premise of the plot is interesting, but the story in the mind of the director was not translated before the camera effectively.

Title: Emperors New Clothes
Review:
After all the praise and Oscar nods, and being a film buff of sorts, I thought I'd best watch this... and OMG, its really rubbish!

Its like a bad chinese movie of the 80s, with money thrown at it, spliced with Matrix/Multiverse theories willy nilly.

Michelle Yeoh, as always was amazing, but a very poor script and bad storyline there is nothing that can be done to save this movie.

In my opinion, I think the Oscar elites are thinking they are being clever in nominating this movie in so many categories, because they are somehow enlightened individuals who see so many levels in this film, but the truth is, Emperors New Clothes - there is nothing good to see as there is nothing good here!

Title: 2GenZ4U
Review:
The film strikes a good balance between stimulus overload and actually having a lesson to teach. Although the moral of the story has been told before, it is the mind bending form that sets this film apart. Though the film gets conceptual (and quirkily random UwU) really quickly, it does so with clarity and grace - Nolan take note. On the other hand, it does lose pace in the middle and desperately reiterates the same point. (Kinda like a kid telling a joke and asking if you got it, numerous times.) Also the setting gets a bit mundane as the film progresses.

All in all, the experience is worth it as the film attempts a striking a deeper note by allowing character transformations and reappraisals, something it's younger target audience can do well to follow.

Title: Just another Hong Kong action movie but more expensive
Review:
I am so disappointed. Watched the film because I thought it was worth all thr Oscars. However, it wasn't. The story isn't new. The jokes are ok, but they don't make you die of laughter. Pictures are ok, sound effects are ok But not great. The emotions is the worst part. And the touching moment, oh, they try hard to make you cry but it was so boring. It wasn't touching. 7 Oscars, seriously? I'm not surprised that it's successful at the cinema, but the Oscars, really?

It can be a good movie to have fun with friends on Saturday evening, but I definitely won't watch it again. I would love to see the Oscar to be more inclusive, but I think they are forcing too hard.

Title: Nihilistic twaddle
Review:
I watch a lot of movies and take the time to watch those that are thought provoking more than once.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a very special as this is the first film that I have watched twice and can only conclude that in hindsight, I wish I had watched it zero times. This movie is a mess. It takes nihilism to the next level. I cannot ever recall watching such rubbish and trust me, I have seen some extremely bad movies over the years. Even with such a great leads with Michelle Yeoh and Ke Huy Quan at the helm of this sinking ship. There is no turning the tide. This is one ship that needs to be torpedoed, as at 139 minutes, it is taking far to long to go down. I suspect that most Millennials will love it (though not this one), as it takes pretentiousness to new levels. If you are curious to see for yourself, watch the first thirty minutes and you have seen the whole movie. Just remember, it is thirty minutes that you will never get back.

Title: Awful Mess
Review:
Everything Everywhere All At Once is bad filmmaking, absurd editing, bad acting, lazy writing, bad visual effects, and above all, it's a void and boring mess. The movie has A LOT of glaring continuity goofs and plot holes. Nobody in this world believes this deserves the best picture and best director awards. I still remember seeing Evelyne's ring in one hand and then the same ring in the other hand, that is very glaring, and everybody saying wtf in my screening... I strongly believe this is a click-bait, paid media awards driven thing. Absolutely believe that the academy just watch reels, not the entire movies. Like The Hurt Locker this is absurd, forgettable garbage. 1/10.

Title: Two wasted hours
Review:
The Evelyn character was interesting, it was an interesting take on a family that owns a laundromat and is having trouble with the IRS, the costumes were interesting, the acting was pretty good, and that's about it. All the science fiction has been done before. It was ok, but very boring after the first hour. It is not a movie I'd watch again like Rocky,, or Bridge over the River Kwai. Rotten tomatoes should have given it less than 50 percent, I have no clue why it won Best Picture, it was free to watch, of which I'm glad, because if I hadn't been watching it with someone, I'd have turned it off. Title: If Shooms Were Legal!
Review:
I might have enjoyed this movie a bit more. As it was, they are not. And I did not... enjoy this.

It's a mess! It really is everything, everywhere, all at once. But it's one of those movies where it seemed the shoom rip fell off and they tried to remain edgy. Until it reached a point quite beyond "Really? This is not an organic mind altering/expanding experience."

Maybe the people just failed to properly translate their trip. Like a song in a dream. Or like when I actually was able to translate my dream songs they ended up sucking quite badly.

In any case, this experience failed for me. But the core message was nice. However, a majority of the theater left mid-show this time. And I had no questions on why.

In IMDB, 6.x means something to see, if not memorable. This - for me - was not a slight fail, but a rather big fail. So -2.

Title: Visually stunning and ambitious but ends up boring and empty.
Review:
Everything Everywhere All at Once started ambitious and interesting but ended up being an overlong boring mess with an orgy of random colorful stuff thrown around, and non-stop action, that doesn't allow the audience to breathe. My head hurt so bad after.

It's always fascinating to me how much people's opinions differ. Contrary to the laudatory reviews, the film has very little substance and message. The creators laid the foundations, but did not fill it with content, the conclusion is quite a cliche, and yes, in the end, life is a bunch of old truisms that can be deep and charming in their simplicity if the road leading to them, is real. But this film quickly gets lost in a madly spinning merry-go-round of colors, movements, words, and sounds. You can cut half of the movie and it won't change the message or the ending, the movie is 40 minutes too long. This isn't coherent vision at all and it just leaves you confused and with a headache. Someone may say that this form is intentional because that's exactly how life is, but sorry, the creators can't get a pass so easily. If you claim you made a movie with a real message it's your job to make the audience care, to show something that is raw and true not bore people to death and just throw random things around over and over again.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is in the end tedious and loud, and it leaves you with very little not some grand wisdom.

It's absolutely not an 8, 9 or 10. It's technically and visually well done, but the story itself pretends to be more profound than it really is. This is def one of the most overrated movies this year.

Title: Pathetic Trash/Sorry I made you finish it
Review:
I know better than to let awards tempt me into watching a film. Any reviewer that liked this repetitive, chaotic, and confusing excuse of a film is simply trying to appear to be uniquely aware of hidden messages and full of deep intellect. I say that this movie is complete nonsense. I know trash when I see it. This was complete trash.

I made my spouse watch till the end hoping that something would tie the nonsense and chaos into a meaningful message. Never happened. I had to apologize. The pointless, never ending fight scenes were poorly made and tacky. I can enjoy a complex film with abstract presentations of real life messages and themes. This film didn't deliver anything but disappointment, confusion, and pure boredom. Don't fall for the awards credentials. They are 100% fake and unjustified in this case.

Title: INCREDIBLY OVERRATED!
Review:
It's absolutely impossible to understand why critics and Hollywood considered this ridiculous and boring movie as one deserving to be recommended, or nominated for 11 Academy Awards, including the Best Picture category.

Even though the film has lots of expensive special effects, and good performances of the whole bunch of actors involved in it (including Jamie Lee Curtis' part as the IRS agent), it is absolutely void of any artistic essence.

While suffering watching this naive product, I was thinking about other films which had been nominated to several Oscars before, like the excellents "BEN HUR", "GONE WITH THE WIND", "THE GODFATHER", "OUT OF AFRICA', "LAWRENCE OF ARABIA", "PATTON", "THE DEER HUNTER", "APOCALYPSE NOW", etc.; and came to the conclusion that films taste has unfortunately decayed through the years.

Title: Utter nonsense
Review:
"I recently watched a film that can only be described as utter nonsense, and I have to say, it was quite the experience. From start to finish, this film was a wild ride of bizarre events and nonsensical plot twists that left me scratching my head in disbelief. The characters were equally absurd, with their actions and dialogue making little to no sense.

Despite its lack of coherence, the film managed to keep me entertained throughout. The over-the-top humor and absurd visuals made for a truly unique viewing experience that I won't soon forget.

If you're looking for a film that defies all logic and reason, and is just a fun, silly romp, then this nonsense film is definitely worth checking out. Just don't expect to make sense of it all, because this film is all about embracing the absurdity.

Overall, I would rate this nonsense film a 2 out of 10 for its entertaining value and memorable viewing experience, but deduct points for its complete lack of structure and coherence." Well, these are the words of the infamous ChatGpt AI.

Title: The Purple Pill
Review:
A random movie I seen on the discount shelf. I decided I like a good random flick.

Oh boy... It's just another Matrix, Inception movie.

January 22 2023

About: A Chinese lady living in the USA is drawn into random stuff. Why? I don't know.

Story and production: it's another confusing sown up movie. Why? Who? What? Is happening I can not answer.

The quality I good. It's a creative movie.

The Wayne guy and some parts reminds me of William Janus from South Park. Where William Janus turns out to be Tuong Lu Kim who has multiple personality disorder.

Overall, a creative movie though its confusing me.

Genre: Sci-Fi, Chinese.

Soundtrack: It good.

Duratiom: 2 long bloody hours...

What can be learned? Do you really control your reality?

Should you watch this? Meh... If your confused by Matrix and Inception then that's what you'll Get. A headless dog... Haha!

I don't know what people see in these types of messy movies. Maybe it's the randomness or someone getting beat by a Private part. I didn't laugh once because I thought it was nasty.

Title: Both a mess and a waste of time
Review:
Oscars or no Oscars when there is bad filmmaking, there IS bad filmmaking. When you can't understand the lead who is supposed to make any kind of sense of this messy, out of control, unrecognizable film, the viewer is in trouble.

There is a reason why this actor has not acted in decades! And dto give him the lead, was ridiculous.

Can you tell I am angry?

I AM ANGRY.

WhenI think about film, I am reminded that it starts with a STORY. A comprehensible, beginning, middle and end.

This film did not have ANYTHING that resembled a cohesive story.

I can see where this "thing" would appeal to gamers. It's fast-paced, loud (except for the dialogue, that was unintelligible, was that on purpose because there was no there, there... What a mess, a sorry mess.

What was the Academy non com thinking?

I give up hoping that today's audience even cares about quality stories any more. Maybe COVID has not only made us sick but has hindered our taste as well.

Title: Awful
Review:
2 hours and 19 minutes that i will never get back. An awful movie I've had huge expectations for it after all the hype but apparently the taste is no longer good enough, I don't recommend anyone to waste his time , go juggle or do laundry and believe me you will have fun more than watching this garbage movie Everything everywhere all at once is a disappointed

Everything everywhere all at once is a disappointed.

Title: Awful, Overhyped, Mess
Review:
What did I just watch? This was a messy, weird multi-verse, time hopping, butt plugged, morass with no plot. Completely over hyped and in my opinion not worthy of the nominations received. Perhaps, for special effects, but really nothing else. My husband suggested we watch this quagmire on a Saturday morning. How I wish I could have those two and a half hours back! I've seen some weird movies in my time, but this just really takes the cake. I truly think the script writers were on acid when writing this. Truly, madly, deeply disappointed in this mess. Watch it if you like, but certainly don't expect much.
6 out of 11 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Worse Than Boring
Review:
Ah, this film... Looking back, it would've been much better had I stared at a wall or graphic pictures of crime scenes for two hours. I suppose there is room in the universe for a movie like this: Two hours of nonstop A/V assault on the viewer. A thin plot, endlessly restated.

Heed my warning, gentle viewer. Set aside two hours of your life for literally any other purpose. Meditate. Pet a dog. Do the dishes. Read to blind orphans. Then congratulate yourself for dodging the bullet that is this movie.

Do not, under any circumstances, watch this movie. I do not believe any of the people who birthed this movie are inherently evil or beyond redemption, but they need to seriously reexamine why they are on this earth.

Permalink

Title: Don't waste your time.
Review:
45 min in, turned it off as it was getting annoying.

Cringe level: high.

The premise build is vaguely strung together via flashbacks that are literally flashes. Language is near impossible to follow as mixed with chinese and english and only partial subs (for the chineses).

Scenes are very short with incoherent dialogue. There is very little flow in any scene. Granted there is a lot going on, but it equates to a rather incoherent jumble of mediocre scenes and dodgy cinematography struggling to build anything resembling a storyline.

The storyline that does transpire is neither inviting or interesting.

This is one of those films where you wonder what anyone involved with the production was thinking. If this is what the editors could muster as a final version, then how bad must have the overall direction been?

The level of discomfort felt for the actors being required to enact the script, assuming there actually was one, was significant.

How this film can receive positive acclaim is bewildering.

No idea who is making the 5***** reviews, but they can't be real people.

Title: Pfffff
Review:
Cannot believe these reviews, overhyped and such a boring movie. I watched it for 60 minutes but then had to stop. I am really lost why this should be such a great movie.
7 out of 12 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: Dumping trash
Review:
Stale plot with action-packed visual give rise to a movie that aims to simulate the audience. The goals of the writers is to explore the unimaginable... resulting in weird things and ideas.

There are aspects of Asian-American lifestyle that I experience myself. The characters also act in a very raw manner. Blurting out words and phrases in Chinese for example. I thought the beginning of the movie showcases the Asian-American lifestyle.

But, the film does downhill from there. The pacing increases, visuals pop-up, and the film ends with some open-ended idea.

Who knows that you are supposed to learn from this?
9 out of 19 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: I'm Sorry, but I Just Can't
Review:
I just couldn't get through it. How this film fetched so much attention is more shocking to me than how the Avatar films became so popular. The film, mimicking typical Hollywood films, consists of two plus hours of unintentional ridiculousness and ham-fisted moralism about accepting people, regardless of how odd their oddities happen to be. The film especially lays it on with regard to child-rearing, specifically, how traditionalist parents have an obligation to simply accept their children's novel additions to their family's moral culture and sensibilities. It fails to so much as consider the question of whether children could be wrong or hasty in their changes (they are children after all), or whether the children should work with parents to evaluate them. Here, parents are simply obligated to "get with the times" and support the child's wishes lest they push the child toward evil.

The two redeeming qualities of this film are the gravitas brought by the lead actor (she is excellent), and the strange sense that I experienced in viewing the actor who played her husband. I am going out on a limb in saying this before checking it, but I think he is the same person who played a little boy in "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom." It was a bit haunting to hear him speak, now as an aging man, with the same inflections of voice and general mannerisms of the child of nearly forty years ago. Other than these items, I can't see clear to lionize this film as so many have done.

Title: What the hell did I just watch!!!
Review:
O-M-G!

Really, what the hell did I watch for 2 hours?? Total mess and complete waste of time with enormous confusion on my face whole time! Really, what was the message of the movie that dictates us? Tax law? Family? Love? Parallel universes and weird characters? Costco hot dogs? Not really sure if the director was trying to point out something else but I am still lost.

Title: All that flash, No substance
Review:
This film is just noise on the TV screen with a very mediocre plot.

The next generation may have a low attention span, so it feels like they have catered for that. They have tried to juice up the plot with a feel good experience, but it it feels like it they are just jamming it down my throat.

The film pace is completely wrong. This film leaves know time to feel, and imagine. I guess it goes with the title.

The only thing they have done of interest is cast a older Asian lady as a protagonist in a big budget pile of garbage.

Save your eyes for something that's worth savouring.

Best film of the year it wouldn't make my top 100.

Title: For adults, like me, who feel they MUST watch this...
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Incomprehensible Confusiion
Review:
Basically an exercise in post-modern cinematography, "Everything Everywhere All At Once" lives up to its tenet that "nothing matters" by ignoring elements such as a plot. Character development is dispensed with by giving each actor multiple characters with both good and evil qualities. Watching this picture could be dangerous for those susceptible to epileptic incidents or subject to migraine headaches.
5 out of 8 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Nothing Nowhere Never Again!
Review:
Wow! With all the awards hype around this movie I expected to at least be mildly entertained. I was not. It is relentlessly over wrought, banal and narratively obsequious. Not worth reviewing frankly. What is going on with movies these days? Remember when 'Nomadland' won best picture? That was weird but you could blame it on the pandemic. Maybe if I saw it in a theatre where I'd be trapped into making more of an investment. This makes my list of worst movies ever. After the first ten minutes I paused the movie only to discover that I was forty five minutes in! All I could think of is what decisions had I made in my life that found me in a portion of the multiverse where this is considered a good movie! Yikes!

Title: I'm in the middle of watching it and just come here to check if I am the only one disappointed.
Review:
Turned out I am not. I've rolled my eyes, felt embarrassed and cringed multiple times so far. The storyline is a mess. I guess they try to make it philosophical and profound but they really went way way to far into the abyss of confusion and nonsense. I'm Taiwanese so I can understand every Mandarin sentence perfectly and this makes watching it even more painful. I don't think this movie will stand the test of time and I think its right score will be four point something. Hugely overrated. Now I will go back and finish it. This is the kind of person I am but I guess I will have to find creative ways to amuse myself to hang on to the end. To those of you who really finished watching it, you deserve a big hand for your incredible tolerance of bad movies. It's slow death.

Title: When will it end!!!
Review:
Started with an interesting premise of multiple universes but dragged on interminably with repetitive fight scenes triggered by a fall into ( or from) another universe. By the time it finished it was hard to tell what was the point of the movie, apparently a mother - daughter relationship.

Title: Worst film I have ever had to sit through
Review:
It is hard to fathom why such amazing actors, who have delivered some of the most unforgettable performances in cinema history, would agree to participate in a project so devoid of creativity and originality.

This sci-fi movie was the epitome of rubbish. The special effects were poor, the plot was uninspired, and the pacing was sluggish. It required a great deal of patience to make it to the end, and even then it failed to deliver any payoff. It was easy to see why it would be a great movie for someone trying to torture answers from their prisoners because it was pure torture to watch. It is perplexing how such talented actors could be involved in such an utter disappointment of a movie. It is best to avoid this film at all costs.

Title: Horrible
Review:
What to say? Waste of my time...

I cannot believe I survived until the end. The story is nonsense and the only good part is the special effects (thus the rate 2 out of 10).

Seriously, why is this movie in the oscar nominations? Pointless.

Two hours and a half of kung fu fighting with random objects, silly humor, mom and daughter relationship and crazy effects.

That is literally all there is. The plot is silly and the end is also bad.

Try not to waste your time with this. I have no idea why people hype this s*.

Waste of time, I wish I could have my 2h30 back so I could do something worth.

Title: Can't Believe This Won Best Picture
Review:
I wanted to see this since it had such rave reviews. Honestly cannot believe this movie won for Best Motion Picture. It was a decent movie, reminded me of a 21st century sci fi version of the Wizard of Oz, but just all over the place. The entire time I was watching it, I kept saying "I can't believe this won best picture." Michelle did a great job...loved her since Crouching Tiger...very iffy on Jamie Lee Curtis winning supporting actress...out of all the movies she's been it, I didn't see it with this one. It was a good Saturday night movie, don't think I will watch again. Just wasn't my cup of tea.

Title: Cab I give it a negative rating?
Review:
I was completely confused by whatever that was I was watching. I had no idea what was supposed to be going on, or what all the fuss was about. The fact I made it 15 minutes before shutting it off surprises me. I wanted to stop sooner, but kept waiting for something, anything, to keep my interest. Unfortunately that never happened. I'm upset I wasted that much time on this mindless nonsense. It did leave me with one great hope. If this piece of garbage can win so many awards, whats to stop me from writing the next great piece of mindless drivel and becoming rich? I'll tell you what. I will look at it again, just to see how easy it can be to come up with a nonsensical idea that will win awards and fool people the world over!

Title: This movie starts off promising and ends up bad 3/10
Review:
I truly wanted to enjoy this movie especially after the first 25 minutes, but then it just ends up being trite, boring, pedestrian rubbish. It's not convoluted, it's easy to follow, but my lord it takes forever to get anywhere with substance.

This movie could easily have been and hour and 25 minutes long and better for it, though it would still have been childish nonsense in the main.

Have to say this; just because the movie is bad, doesn't mean all the acting is, the acting is the best part of the movie.

Title: I'll never get that time back.
Review:
Where should i start? For me this movie was a complete disaster. I went to see it on the ratings from imdb and boy were they wrong for me. 2 hours 20 minutes for a final reconciliation that they could have done five minutes into the movie. I don't usually do "other peoples trips" but in rare instances they can be mesmeric just like Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas or The Matrix 1. But for me this didn't work at all. The acting was seriously poor, the comedy was juvenile, it was difficult to follow rambling from one scene to the next and it was way too long. The worst part was when some of the actors began to put pointed ornaments in their backsides. It wasn't funny but rather childish and crude. But all this is just my opinion. I heard people behind me say they enjoyed it and thats fair enough. Maybe something extra to enhance the experience was necessary but for me im just sorry i actually paid for the experience in time and money. If there were a minus on the scale id give it -10.

Title: "it's a wonderful life" ... on crack!
Review:
I've never done heavy drugs but I'm sure an acid trip is equivalent to what I just watched. It was like the Matrix meets It's a Wonderful Life meets the 90s TV show Sliders... all on really heavy drugs. I kept hoping for an explanation or an understanding as to what the heck was happening... but it never came. I have no idea how this won best picture. Nothing against the actors, they all did a wonderful job considering what they were asked to portray. I'm sitting here, writing this seconds after just finishing the movie and I still couldn't tell you what I just watched. Save yourself the 2.5 hrs and watch something else. Thank me later.

Title: This is my first review - I just need to unleash my amazement
Review:
This is my first review. I simply just cannot understand all the hipe about this movie. It's a chaotic mashup of massive nonsense put up in a extremely camp and cheesy way.

The acting is very good (and my 5 stars are due to that) but I'm sure other actors deserved to get the academy awards more than the three that work in this movie and got them.

Technically the movie is overwhelming -but not in the right way. The cinematography and the visual effects are confusing, cloying, and sometimes stunningly cheap.

The music is just fine.

The storyline is a compost of absurdities that end up in an astonishingly sickly-sweet, mawkish, tricky and fake fable about love and acceptance.

I definitely think humanity has gone bananas. This movie and its success and the awards that it got are just another little evidence.

Title: Like most A24 movies, this is another extremely overhyped pile of trash
Review:
The 8.4 score is unjustified. The movie has nothing going for it. The comedy is predictable. The story is boring. The telling of the story is amateurish. The characters are stereotypical. The length of the movie is too long for the substance that's there to work with.

I would rather watch paint dry than to watch this steaming pile of garbage.

Title: What the...? How can this "motion picture" win so many awards?
Review:
I don't usually write reviews. If I watch a movie till the end I will rate it a 10 or 9( if it annoys me too much, but not enough to become unbearable-like Gravity for example ). If it becomes unbearable, I simply stop watching it and don't bother rating. I will make an exception now because of the many awards this movie won.

What the...?

When a fish-like thingy had intimal relations with a woman in the Best Motion Picture of the Year in 2018, I was very disappointed but, hey,.. it's art, right?

But this movie is making me really worried. Will we allow competitiveness to stop being the fundamental drive of our society? Will our decisions become agenda dependent? Will we praise paintings done by throwing... paint( I know what you were thinking of and you were not wrong :) ) on canvases? This is an utterly bad movie, everyone knows it, but to be so overrated? How did we end up here? I think the Judgement at Nuremberg 's ending shows us the path we are walking on.

This review does not contain any spoiler, as it is nothing to spoil.

Title: Embarrassing
Review:
The movie starts with an interesting script and aesthetics, which misleads you to think it's going to be a good movie. Until they enter in the IRS building I was into it, despite nothing substantial had happened yet. At this point, the characters are introduced satisfyingly enough so you think a good movie is about to start.

Was downhill from there.

In the first minutes in the IRS building scenes I thought it was going to be perhaps a movie about mental illness, or that the main character was having a seizure or something.

But then I discover that a seizure from cringing was what I was about to have.

It was just absolutely cringe.

Despite liking the costumes in particular, that were very creative for an action movie, the plot is just downright bad, boring and messy. The movie is not funny enough, it takes itself too seriously and makes an obvious point as if it was a incredible spiritual insight.

By the way, the only good acting was from Michelle, the other actors were mediocre and some of them even cringe, and I just cannot believe this movie swept all the Oscars of 2022. By the way, I loved Midsummer and don't aligned with the haters of A24. But this movie was just bleh.

Sad that Banshees of Inisherin, so well acted, softly moving and at the same time dramatically violent, a tale for the days we live, didn't won the deserving recognition that was otherwise given to this overrated movie...

Title: Truly bizarre & awful
Review:
This film is like a sci fi Jackie Chan film, & that's not good.

Quite simply it's bizarre with a plot from a B movie sci fi film from the 1950's that makes little sense.

It's bound to have a cult following in the same way The Firth Element does, an equally bizarre & awful film.

You can't fault the acting but the script & plot are woeful. As is the way it jumps around all over the place between the 'multi verses' with same actors playing multiple versions of themselves in the same place & the same time.

Confused? You will be.

It also comes across as just being.... silly.

So bizarre, confusing, awful, woeful & silly.

Title: Everything everywhere for no reason
Review:
I had high expectations for this movie, but it was pointlessly confusing to a point that it got annoying. I can see why some people might like it, but not my cup of tea. I enjoy fast paced movies, but this movie seemed fast paced for the sake of it. I don't get the 8.1 rating, for me it below average, especially when it comes to plot and screenplay. The dialog is just cringy and pointless. The whole metaverse concept seems to be used more and more recently, unfortunately most times badly with the aimjust to impress the viewer.

Short review: confusing, pointless, empty, bright, fast paced. A cornucopia of plastic candy, looks exciting from far away, but disappointing when you get closer to it.
8 out of 14 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: One of the more accurate portrayals of a nightmare captured in a movie
Review:
Oscar megabuzz made me find out what the fuss is all about. Free on prime at the moment, so let's go.

Self styled zany/wacky directing duo the "Daniels" ... present an unusual take on female midlife crisis.

The title character, raised in Asia but living in America, is coming to terms with a stressful time in her life. Her business under investigation by tax officials, a failing relationship with her husband, and having to accept her daughter's homosexuality. This plays out in the movie as a kind of anxiety fuelled fever dream, where you guessed it, "everything all at once" occurs.

We are then inundated with scene after scene of chaotic imagery, not unlike a vivid lucid dream we all have experienced at some point. Yeoh's everywoman character is somehow on a mission to defeat the "bad guy" through travelling multiverses, aka a metaphor for anxiety (infinite what if? Scenarios). It seems to follow a similar theme to the original Matrix, with value added bizarreness and sassy/crude attempts at humour, which makes me think intent might have been a kind of spoof of this trope.

And my review ends here. Have to admit, I didn't make it to the end, a particular plug-based sex toy scene was just too much to spend another hour of my life on it. Not for me, thanks.

Tl;Dr: Tick the boxes: Middle aged female leads Asian-american average family life Gay daughter Sci fi fantasy elements Is it unique? Absolutely Is it original? Kind of Is it entertaining? Maybe to some, polarising

Is it Oscar worthy?

Absolutely not for any of the main awards and would make a mockery of the academy if they were to give it any. Watch a past winner after this and you too should come to the same conclusion.

Title: Love it and Hate it.
Review:
Great performances by the key cast members in an original presentation of unoriginal ideas. In structure it is a very conventional 'Heroes Journey' with all of the required elements of the reluctant hero, her quirky new friends and an ever growing, life threatening challenge. Some very cute moments and ideas, such as the 'everything bagel', but it ran out of ideas after an hour and just relied on never ending jumpcuts of combat scenes. As such, it could have been cut down to one hour instead of its totally unnecessary 2:20. Credits to the editor for the massive amount of work in putting this together, but after the first hour, the story did not advance at all and the scene after scene after scene of pointless fights got tedious and boring.

There was also a problem with the premise of saving the infinite universes. I suppose the key character did, but the issue sort of fell off the edge of the table and was not addressed. If you have to blow up the death star to save the galaxy, then you need to show the death star being blown up. You don't go straight to the awards ceremony without showing us what happened.

So ya, some great stuff and a lot of tedious, pointlessness.

Title: You can't please everyone
Review: This film proves the old adage that 'you can't please everyone' - not even everywhere and all at once. A mash up of Matrix/Parasite/and any Jackie Chan movie you care to name, this film simply doesn't work. It starts reasonably well, however, and in the first 30 minutes shows great promise. But then it degenerates into a farcical parade of kung-fu style dance routines that are not only boring but incredibly poorly choreographed. The premise of the film - some sort of interdimensional slippage brought on by stress and self-worth (or the lack of it) - as only explained in the most convoluted and bizarre way that one can only assume it is because the writers don't really want the viewer to know what's going on (clever eh? Not!). The Jackie Chan throw away comedy is laughable in its obviousness and the sight gags are childish to say the least. The acting is pretty good but then, what ARE they acting? No-one knows, least of all it seems the writers and the director! I suspect this film is doing well at the awards simply because, like the emperor's clothing, no-one in the 'arts' world is game enough to say they didn't get it (to admit, if you like, that they are not clever enough to divine this film's 'deep and meaningful message'. Well, folks, the joke's on them because there simply isn't one. This is a self-indulgent film editor's wet dream masquerading as something profound. In short, not worth the 2 hours invested in watching it.

Title: 2h30min ago I could swear I never did drugs. Now, not so sure
Review:
My mistake, I trusted an IMDB rating of 8.0 and thought this would be about an Asian family cultural conflict with US, or something along the lines. Did not watch the trailed.

The title made no sense but hey, artistic license, right? Wrong. The title is appropriate and descriptive of the movie.

I find the art in this movie is a thin brightly painted veneer over a rock tumbler, mixing and crushing any strand of narrative that may have inadvertently formed during shooting. It's like someone drunk trying to piece together last night's events. It feels heavy, pungent and ultimately hopeless. Flashing lights warning.

The whole movie could have been 5 minutes if the loopy kung-fu wannabee art, which felt mostly surplus quality, would be stripped away.

Fun factor: 6/10 akin to TikTok for 2h - you will laugh a bit Narrative: absent WTFs/hour: new world record Message: 2/10 Time management: nope, none Acting: decent.

Title: Everything and Nothing At All
Review:
Call me whatever you want but that was the most tedious, boring, intellectually bereft movie I've seen since Mars Attacks. It was free on Showtime so I thought how lucky I was to be able to see this often awarded show for free. Afterwords I felt totally ripped off.

Editing had to be a nightmare and it looked that way almost from the beginning. The humor was butt plug level the martial arts were rarely decent (not that I'd know) but the movies overall message could have easily been communicated and many times more interesting in one 30 minute episode of Twilight Zone.

All I can say is what the Academy's choice of this film as Best Motion Picture Of The Year was a bigger disaster than THE SLAP from 2022.

Title: This movie made me so confused that I cringe while watching it...
Review:
Being an Asian myself, having grown up watching Chinese Kungfu movies, and then Jackie Chan's Rush Hour, I understand how people, especially Americans, love Kungfu. And although Michelle Yeoh is very good at martial arts, and I also adored her for 'Memoirs of a Geisha', this is not a good Kungfu movie. The film's Kungfu performances are really boring and lifeless.

In terms of content, I find there are 3 aspects to evaluate this movie, one: the appeal of the story, two: the humor, the third: the emotion and the message.

About the story, the multiverse theory is explained in quite detail, but it seems that due to the low budget, what we see is only described through Waymond's words. And the little dots on the screen or whatever screen. It's too simple to enjoy. And the detail of the ear device for multiverse communication is ridiculous and meaningless. The character Becky and the grandpa ended up having no role at all, completely hopeless. Why is Joy the villain? The story goes on and on and forces the viewer to accept everything. The multiverse is something huge and has a very wide impact, but the story here revolves around only a few people? Wtf not to mention that there are some universes that are just created for the purpose of comedy and have no meaning, and that humor is, I will say, = Zero. I can't laugh a bit when I see the humor in this movie. If you want funny Kungfu movies, watch a movie by Jackie Chan or Stephen Chow.

Fortunately, this film has a message and emotion, which is the commendable point of the film. The editor of this movie is Paul Rogers and he deserves an Oscar, the universes are shown continuously, especially towards the end,the scenes are also constantly transferred between different universes making it nearly impossible for the viewer to adapt and keep up with what's going on everywhere, but the music ties it all together perfectly. I like the music in the movie. Especially at the end when the meaning of family is gracefully expressed. From the very beginning we know that family is the heart of the movie. Although everything is shown quite chaotic and a bit boring, but the feeling of family is well put so viewers can still feel it. But this is also what makes viewers like me feel quite uncomfortable, I don't know whether to enjoy this movie in a serious way or just for fun? So I would be quite hesitant if I want to watch this movie again. And although the acting of the actors are impressive, but 7 Oscars? Please... At this rate, in the years to come I'll probably stop believing in Oscars...

Title: Please don't waste your time
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Second-tier sci-fi/fantasy
Review: One couple I know walked out on it. Another friend loved it. They are all smart people with a good sense of humor. But it is also continually mentioned as a shoo-in at the Oscars. I feel that I had an open mind when I bought my ticket. The story, as far as I could tell, is about a Chinese-American woman who is kidnapped and thrown into alternate universes when she's overcome by stress. And that's what happens in this movie. He marriage is basically over, her daughter just came out as a lesbian, her ailing father, who lives with her and constantly criticizes her, demands attention. The family business (a laundromat) is failing, the IRS is harassing them, and she is haunted by her failed career as a singer. In the alternative universes she has superhuman strength and is a martial arts expert. That's a good thing because she's also being pursued by an arch-villainess who is determined to kill her off in every one of those alternative universes. There are a lot of fight scenes (mostly CGI). There are also some laughs along the way, but nothing truly hilarious, unless you like jokes about sticking objects where-the-moon-don't-shine. I guess it comes down to the fact that this is just not my kind of movie. The audience I saw it with was composed mostly of young people who seemed to enjoy it enormously. The makeup was outstanding. I did not recognize Jamie Lee Curtis at all. Since most people confuse acting with makeup, I predict that she'll win the Oscar. But ultimately, to me, it was just silly.

Title: Really, really bad
Review:
I will almost never stop watching a movie, but this was so bad, I actually gave up. Some of the performances were solid, but the overall story was just plain unbelievable, and bad. Not even worth the hour and a half I gave it. I really wanted to like it, and my favorite performances were by Jamie Lee, and the really cool actor who started his journey in Temple of Doom. I was happy to see Jamie Lee Curtis finally win an Oscar, so many great performances she was snubbed for, but she finally got one, and I would say her performance was a highlight of my wasted time watching this strange film, it really could have been monumentally better, but casting was it's greatest accomplishment.

Title: Best Movie of 2022!!!!

I didn't suggest the movie for family night, but as I kept saying... "hey, it's the best movie of 2022. There must be a reason the Academy voted for it."

Yup. There is a reason. The academy did not vote this as best picture because it is a good movie, but rather because of its theme and message.
