Title: i Get it: everything at once and is a BAD movie. √çm HK origin. European Grown. Loved HK movies of the 90s. And I know why Western culture people love it...i hate it
Review:
Spoiler: I have seen 30 min of the film then multiverse jumped the film to the end because it is so BAD and this is my reason: 1.- The film style is a modern version of HK comical films of the 90s, which made Stephen Chow famous and also trying to mix nonsense laught and a touch of "human wisdom and morality", this make you feel good...like "oh...i got it...there is a moral lesson here...others who do not like this film...it is because they are stupid and did not get it, im special".

2.-I love "no sense laught films"...but this one..the gags..are copy of older films... like the sausages fingers... 3.-Try to touch lot of sensitive and tender feelings: marriage, gender, family, frustation, hardship of being foreighters, etc etc...this is so "cheap" way to gain the audience.

Western people may love this film...because this idea of "nonsense + morality" in an asian flavour is new for them...but for me...it is only old ideas, mix it with current moral hot topics, but made in a really un tasty way...

I dont understand how the Oscars gone this way...

Title: Bucking the all or nothing trend
Review:
And saying that this movie is ok. Not great, not terrible. Just ok. Watch half and you have seen the whole. Visually amusing then slightly annoying. Acting great although the squeaky male lead grates after a while and somehow it is difficult to take the 'fat' (using the movie's nomenclature as am sure I would be cancelled if I used it without quotation marks) daughter too seriously. But then not much is too serious about this and that's part of its charm. For my part I felt the message was received way before the finale. To the point where I just willed it to end so I could be done with it and wonder why it was nominated for an Oscar. There are good things for sure but the self indulgence and unnecessary hammering home of the themes just got boring for half of the movie. Shame as the first half was fun.

If I had not been watching with friends I would have switched off in the first half hour, but it seems each of us only put up with the full viewing because we thought the others were enjoying it, and afterwards we all agreed it was a complete waste of our evening. Title: Hot steamin' garbage
Review:
Recieving oscars has lost its meaning as a quality marker. Something is off in the Academy for sure if this pile of junk recieves 7 oscars. Save your money and dont watch this, you'd find more amusement and spare yourself a headache by lighting your money on fire.

Title: Not my kind of movie, but maybe it's yours?
Review:
I didn't particularly enjoy this movie. It was technically well done, well enough acted and so on. But it's a comedy and very silly one at that, and it just got too over the top for my kind of humor.

It has some vague hints to concepts from The Matrix and The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, one of my favorite movies of all time and one of my favorite books of all time. But there's nothing profound about this story. It's just stupid in my opinion.

And the movie is too long. The last 30 min I just wanted it to be over.

If this is your kind of movie you'll probably love it. Personally, I just want my two hours back.

Review:

Title: Not an oscar worthy movie
Review:
I started watching the movie without any real expectations, although based on the trailer I knew that the plot would be somewhat unconventional.

I made it through the first 30 minutes even though it was not pleasant, as the only thing that was going on was fast paced bickering between the main characters. Afterwards the story "takes off" with one bizzare sequence after another, with several failed attempts at humor inbetween. Halfway through the movie I started waiting for the moment which would give sense to everything, however after 2/3 of the movie had passed I lost hope and the moment never came.

The only positive thing is the acting of the lead actress, even though there was nothing intersting and likeable about her character. The humor attempts were juvenile and at the level of stoner comedies but executed at a subpar manner. There were a few intersting lines, thoughts and exchanges between the characters, however FAR FAR from any level of profound depth and thought provoking substance. Would not recommend the movie, let alone give it any awards.

Title: Gobbledegook
Review:
A third rate B Movie, that belongs in an old flea pit "Art-house" cinema in the backstreets of a broken down district in town.

A discombobulated mash up of Matrix, The Way of the Dragon/The Karate Kid, Back to the Future (Parts 1-3) and Crossroads.

A script that can only have been written by some 1st grade teenybopper, who's been overloaded with pink ice cream, laced with ketamine.

The director, high on super grade tabs of Acid has force fed the thing through an old Hoover vacuum cleaner pipe and blown it out onto some spare celluloid in his toilet.

Jamie Lee Curtis stated that she couldn't understand the script. Well, quite frankly, no one can.

Actors and acting? In the role that she's been given; Jamie Lee Curtis is like a fish out of water, floundering around trying to make sense of it all on a stage with other actors who are all at sea in this nonsense.

VFX? Looked like they were something pulled out of a recycle bin and pasted in. That was explained, when I read that the VFXers had taught themselves from free online tutorials.

Anything good to say about it? Yes, I had a fabulous Lamb Madras Curry delivered from Kashmiri Spice in Burnage (superb food & recommend to all) before the start of the movie. Full to the gunnels after that, I fell fast asleep in the middle of this empty, noisy embarrassment of a thing for 40mins, saving me from the full 139min exposure. Thank the Lord.

7 x Oscars for this bs .. joke.

Good people; Don't waste139mins of your life watching this twaddle. Thank you.

Wanna see it though? Np .. you'll be able to pick up a copy from the Blu-Ray basement/reject box for 50p/60c .. ¬£1/$1.20 for three in a weeks time.

PS Why have I given it two stars then? Well, it's a one star jobby that's for sure, but heah, I'm feeling generous today.

Title: Trvialized treatement of multiverse concept
Review:
A real hot mess. This film is an ADHD addled buffet of a bevy of realities none of which make cogent sense.

I am a very seasoned 100% Asian American science fiction buff(2001, Star Wars, The Matrix, Star Trek, Outer Limits, Twilight Zone, Body Snatchers, etc etc) Familiar with many multi verse films/alt reality cyber fiction( Groundhog Day, Butterfly effect, Looper,etc and of course The Matrix) this is a film that trivializes and mocks the concept of what a real multiverse would look and be like. Even the amateurish Butterfly effect at least attempted to handle the consequences of screwing with a multi verse. I'd recommend films like Deja Vu of if you absoleutely needed a comedic take any of the Back to the Future films.

I couldnt buy in on the Asian American laundry trope either sorry is this a "World of Suzy Wong" remake in 2023. The short martial arts scenes were OK but mostly this is a waste of Michelle Yeoh's emormous talent. For Asian action flicks any of the Ip Man series would be well worth the time instead of this drivel.

Title: Noisy but dull; a mess
Review: I concur with the naysayers on this one. It has an unpromising opening, with drab images inside a laundry operated by a Chinese-American woman, who is suffering from relationships with her meek husband, her cranky father, and her annoying daughter who happens to be in a same-sex relationship with a non-ethnic Chinese. You got it. This is a soap opera, but dressed up with a very sloppy sci-fi scenario about time and space travel, alternate universes and such. The main visual inspiration seems to have been "12 Monkeys" but that is a much superior film on every level, including the musical score. The musical score here consists of sotto voce pizzicato strings and randomized sounds with emphasized sound-effects. The problem is, whatever music they could have chosen, likely wouldn't have saved this movie. I walked out after 30 minutes. If you read the reviewers who gave this only 1 star, you'll see they are angrier than I am, because they stayed the length, lol. At this moment, the naysayers on this film seem to be a minority, but that is only among the small number of reviewers; the majority when you consider that most of the public, is ignoring the film; and we'll have to see if it even manages to break even. Not that I believe this is the ultimate arbiter of any film; but it is something to keep in mind. (Even if it ends up doing well, I fear it will not be for me. Chacun a son gout!).

Title: Everything is Incoherent and Lame
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Something is wrong here!!
Review:
This movie wasn't even worth nomination. 7 Oscars, REALLY??! It wasn't even worth watching. The only explanation is that they gave this movie 7 OSCARS by mistake. Is this the standard of movies these days . I characterize this movie in the "straight to video" category. I don't blame the other nominees for been bitter. The worst nominated actor/actress is far more deserving than any actor/actress in this movie. It's a shame that other movies didn't get the recognition they deserve. I haven't watched all of the nominated movies , but I'll bet my house that they're better than this weird and waste of time movie.

Title: A grade topuc but C grade production
Review:
The core subject to explore family relationships are good but the story telling and presentations are totally chaos. The language switch among English, Chinglish, Mandarin, Cantonese are awkward and awful, especially those two Chinese men. Michelle played with hearts but it is still unacceptable to be produced like this chaotic and cheap looking manner. Mostly the movie is too long, it tortured me for 140 minutes !

Title: Nothing Nowhere individually
Review:
This is not an actual review, it is just my point of view. Who am I to review an Oscar-winning movie?

Read it and leave it as one of the things you saw on the internet.

Nothing Nowhere individually

Everything everywhere all at once is not good enough for an Oscar, I think. The movie sums up as a family drama with some essence of the Multiverse of madness and the Matrix.

How odd it is to make a movie about a person who is lost in life and fighting with everyone because they are not able to figure out what they should do, and in the end, they do what everyone is telling that person to do.

Just so normal.

Title: Endless Stupidity
Review:
The world needs to be mourned for that it has come to a point that not only there exists the possibility of existence of a festival of endless torturous-to-watch garbage, it is praised like movies weren't invented before. How out-of-touch, numb, indifferent, superficial, and ignorant can one be to the realities and horrors of human existence to make this, enjoy watching it, or for god's sake, praise this and shower it with prizes and acclaim. Please do not waste your time watching this; go read the newspapers instead, listen to the radio, take a nap even, walk around the block, eat an ice cream, but do not watch this. Thank you.
7 out of 11 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Absolute rubbish
Review:
Strongly agree with the reviewer that stated the following: This might be the worst waste of time masquerading as a movie that ever existed in the history of the modern world. So bad, so senseless, so ridiculous, no plot, no writing, just nonsense.

ALSO... anyone that thought this "movie" was brilliant, great, amazing, etc... SHOULD NOT BE ALLOWED TO REVIEW A MOVIE... EVER.

I watched the movie and about 20 minutes in was already not connecting with any of the characters or the plot/storyline. Wanted to be fair so I continued to watch with an open mind and about an hour and a half in just couldn't take it anymore and shut it off.

I am in my middle years and time is getting more precious...like others stated....felt like this was just a waste of my time.

Title: it's not a movie it's a movie imitation
Review:
There is intense pollution, and the references to other films are extremely careless, both in terms of color and sound. It was almost like throwing a randomly prepared dish in front of us with a pot.

I perceive this movie as a criticism made to the audience. It is an imitation of a film devoid of aesthetics, devoid of pleasure, full of messages. If there was a rating lower than one star I would give it. Everyone can be sure that even if this movie gets a single Oscar, I will lose my respect for the Oscar.

Here, I also offer my condolences to those who praise the film with such conspicuous effort. It's clear that some of us who don't like it, or you, don't understand the movie.

Title: Had to pause for a nap
Review:
Terrible movie, great actors but no wonder it flopped, I admit it has a message by the end, a nice one btw, but everything you have to bare to get there is not worth it, everyone that managed to watch this all the way, deserves a prize, this being the "best movie" only confirms why hollywood is going downhill. We all should be grateful for actors like Tom Cruise, making real good movies, no wonder Spillberg told him he saved the movie industry, bringing people back to theaters, the message was clear and still the academy decides to give prizes to this, whatever this is... I guess it is easy to live alienated from what the public really wants to see while the Tom Cruises saves the industry. Btw 600 charactes to be able to publish the review is bs....

Title: OMG, so stupid!
Review:
No one can imagine the stupidity and absurdity level of this movie. You see some similarity with the Matrix, but with too much nonsense and disgusting scenes at which you close your eyes, wish they are over, but when you open your eyes they're still there and then you wish you never have started to watch it.

So, this movie got 7 Oscars, ok actors and actresses performed well on their roles, but what if the story and all the details are childish. Then the acting is just useless right?

I give it a 1 just because you cannot rate it as zero.

When making a movie please consider the people.

What a loss of time.

Title: Biggest scandal in Oscars' history
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: while watching, have an airline vomit bag handy
Review:
This has to be one of the stupidest, most worthless movies I've ever seen ... or tried to see, because I couldn't bring myself to watch it from beginning to end and had to take a break in the middle. I have no idea how anybody could like, let alone love, this movie. After watching even a portion of this movie, I underwent a neurological scan at the NYU Langone Ambulatory Care Center in Manhattan, to see whether I had sustained permanent brain damage. Thankfully, I had not. Thereafter I consulted a psychiatrist for an evaluation of my post-traumatic stress disorder. Unfortunately, our meeting did not end well: when I described the movie to him, he began foaming at the mouth and became hysterical and had to be sedated.

Title: Worst movie to win best picture
Review:
This is the worst movie I've ever seen to win best picture. I do think it had an interesting premise, but it was maybe the park poorly executed movie I've seen. The movie could not get out of its own way. Every time there was a dramatic or heartfelt scene it was undercut by something ridiculous or just silly such as the hot dog fingers or the bagel. The movie is well over 2 hours long and I was looking at the clock 10 minutes in. In addition to being ridiculous it was just boring at times and the choreography of most of the fight scenes was pedestrian at best.

It's an embarrassment to the academy that this movie was not only nominated, but it won best picture. The dark knight was not even nominated, they should be ashamed.

Title: Lame moive with lots of Action and Lots of Asian Actors
Review:
This movie was trying to supposedly make a simple point. It had lots of action that never really related well to carrying the story. It had lots of Asian actors and the only reason I can see it getting 11 Academy Award Nominations was to try to play to equal opportunity after Hollywood's blatant and recent failures.

The cinematography was good and effects good so that can get it several valid nominations (but not likely awards) but it clearly is another over-hyped Hollywood promotion. I would never again come close to this movie even on late night horrible cable and drunk out of my mind. I sat thru it in the theater just to see if anything decent came up and it did not. I will be sure to tell my friends and family.

Title: Legal weed = love for this movie
Review:
Legalized weed explains the love for this movie. Appreciating someones' creation is helped by getting into the mindset of the creators. MJ helps approximate what the creators were on. So inhale or munch down before watching this hodgepodge film. Otherwise you risk being bored. Shallow storyline and message, lots of filler. Rudimentary cinematography and haphazard continuity. Sound editing was poor, and dialogue was hard to hear, frequently. Maybe by design. The attempts at humor fell flat. A movie like Vengeance is tighter, more profound, funnier, witty even, more "current", more relevant and one that will better stand the test of tome - - MJ or no.

Title: Made me question my love of movies
Review:
Look, there's always some offbeat movie that gets plenty of play around Oscar season. This isn't an offbeat farce. It's a calamity of plagiarism. If you took a bunch of stories from and references to good films and threw them against a wall, you could get this movie. The fights were tired and unimaginative. The dialogue was confusing and disjointed. By the end I was questioning how this was nominated. Is there something about movies I don't get? I thought I liked movies. I'm willing to compensate for the fact that every once in a while there will just be a movie I don't like that will win Best Picture; too artsy, too smart, stuff like that. But this isn't that. It's just bad. And everyone down to the caterer is nominated and I have no idea why.

Title: No Nutrients At All
Review:
Probably this review may contradict the vast majority's but not commenting is simply an insult to my existence.

Whatever good intentions were totally destroyed with how the message was presented... no nutrients at all to foster a healthy mindset - making things way more complicated and more toxic.

Credits though to the actors and crew behind the camera, but unfortunately it was not entertaining at all.

Overly chaotic, over-thinking, unrealistic imagination. Extremely hard to watch till the end - no idea how the movie bagged so many awards. Definitely not a movie I would watch repeatedly... seeing the ending gave me a rejoicefully good riddance.

Title: What? What was this movie?
Review:
I honestly can't even begin to describe this movie except as a complete mess. I love Michelle Yeoh and she certainly showed her superb acting chops in this movie. I just wish I understood the movie. It is a complete mish-mash of confusion, under the timely guise of the very popular notion of multi-verses. I am a fan of sci-fi, comedy, action, martial arts and acrobatics, bullet-time, slow-mo fight scenes - but geez, all in one scene!? And, what's with the raccoon? A nod to Rocket? I son't know. All I know is that Michelle Yeoh's character comes out of it ok.

Sorry, it's just waaaayyyyy over-rated.

Title: Not my cup of tea
Review:
I had decided that I should at least try to watch a movie which won the Best picture at the Academy awards. I regret this decision. I had supported The Banshees of Inisherin as I thoroughly enjoyed this quiet, sweet little film. In contrast, Everything was a blur of frenetic activity and pointless action. I turned it off after about 45 minutes. I do not know what sort of political situation inspired the award for this film. I was not invested at all in the lives of the characters. Perhaps I am too old, but I don't believe I would have liked it any more twenty years ago. In my case, a total waste of time!

Title: overrated
Review:
The movie had an extremely quick pace (hard to follow) and a lot of clich√© meanings.....like we are all insignificant, human relations are the most important part of our lives etc.

There were moments that the movie was actually amusing but in general it makes you feel like you want to stop watching it and see something else. The triangle of sadness is actually a better movie or even The Banshees of Inisherin, but nowadays if something differentiate from other movies we immediately embrace it like a masterpiece. Although it will win a bunch of Oscars, actually is like a home movie, the one that you will see while eating your lunch.

Title: Doesn't make any sense! Extremely confuse...
Review:
I wonder if the writers were under cocaine or if they smoke their carpet while writing this... This movie doesn't make any sense, we see things happening, while we can enjoy some fat humor and the acting of Michelle Yeoh, this is 2h of "WTF is going on here?". People are shooting and fighting everyone without really understanding what is going on. They die and then they're back alive, even if they switch bodies and so on, you must at least have some consistency with that, which this movie doesn't have. We see images follow one another without any sense. I lost 2h watching this stupidity. Was all the movie a dream? The ending seems to erase everything that happened... Maybe we could consider this as such. I don't recommend this, and don't understand all the praise for it.

Title: Disappointing movie
Review:
When I saw the movie poster I thought (like everyone) 'ah yes the Oscar one, great!'. At that point my excitement level was 100% and 15 minutes in the movie it started to decrease steadily to reach pure boredom around 15 minutes before the end. On one hand it has some interesting-ish characters, a story that could have really captured people imagination, and some well edited sequences. On the other hand it is without a question too long (I do like long movie but this one is just repetitive. Very repetitive. Extremely repetitive). To make things worst, it tries too hard to be clever (you know like when a teenager discovers irony). After a while it just becomes oh so predictable and, frankly, a bit painful to finish. Overall I have liked some bits of it and there was clearly a good performance from the actors so I don't think is it fair to call it complete rubbish. However, be warned, unless you are 15, you're not going to find it stellar either.

Title: A monument to trash masquerading as art
Review:
If you thought this might be good (or even watchable), check out The Heroic Trio with Michelle Yeoh back when she was Michelle Kahn as Invisible Woman! It's quirky fantasy nonsense as well, but it's good. Less fantastic but especially recommended are Dynamite Fighters (aka Magnificent Warriors) and Royal Warriors (aka In the Line of Duty). She plays female versions of Indiana Jones and Dirty Harry, respectively.

These films are all Hong Kong releases with original language in Cantonese. English subtitles and/or English dubs available.

It's great that she received an Oscar, but search out one or more of her early classics.

Title: Like the old Batman series
Review:
Boom, Splash, Bang, Poff, Sapp, Shing, but without the fun graphics and instead trick-shot "for real". It goes on for for 90(??) neverending minutes, instead of the 10 seconds in Batman and it is all about jumping/fighting scenes. And without any real story behind it.

Sure, they jump between "worlds" like the dreams of Inception, and it is probably technically well executed. But it never ends...

This could be the worst movie I have seen. I fell asleep after 30 minutes of Boom, Splash etc, of pure boredom. I woke up 30 min later and understood the story as easy as jumping into any of the Love Boat episodes. I really cannot understand how this movie has gained so much appreciation.

Title: Felt like an Edgar Wright movie
Review:
I enjoyed this movie but there were definitely a lot of moments I felt a little embarriced to be there. The movie itself wasn't anything I've never seen before going off the plotline trend of movies like the matrix, Lego movie, free guy (ordinary person becomes hero and unlocks and learns their full potential through trial and error). The quirkiness and craziness is definitely it's selling point which makes it unique in its own way but gets cringey as it tries to hold its momentum and maintain the chaoticness for the grandiose finale. Felt very Scott pilgrim-ey, Edgar Wright would have loved to make this movie, I also thought the whole multiverse thing was really pushed in the wake of this new marvel narrativev and the Anthony/Joe Russo producer credits make that a little suspect. Overall decent but a little cringe, nice moral of the story (we need more positive messages in films)

Title: Huge letdown

There's something rotten in Denmark for this movie to be anywhere near awards other than a dozen Razzies. Oscars? Top Gun with The Fabelmans a close second.

Title: Stupidest movie I've ever seen
Review:
Don't waste your time. This movie is nonsensical rubbish. A complete onslaught of ridiculous images that just left us shaking our heads. Certain parts left me questioning why and how they could've been allowed or even entertained to be included. Parts that were meant to be funny were cringeworthy. Parts that were meant to be touching or wise were an ill attempt to add some kind of meaning to the film. I was so disappointed with this movie. It had me saying "what the f%#* was that?" too many times. Seriously such a poorly executed film. I guess the only good thing I can say is that we kept watching until the end.

Title: Overrated
Review:
Unbelievable that this movie could get an Oscar. I usually never comment here, but this time it was needed for everyone's sake. Seeing that it has around eight in average rating is not fair to all the users who are tricked into thinking that the movie is really good and pay money to see it. I may have missed something genius, but the fact that it received Oscars and high ratings is a sign of some kind of herd mentality and good marketing by the studio.

At the end of the day, shouldn't the Oscars go to something the majority of the population likes? In this case, it seems to be extremely polarized, either the film gets a 9-10 or a 1-3.

Title: Tragically overrated and depressing
Review:
If you've ever force-fed peanut-butter sandwiches on a group of strangers, you'll recognize that most of the group will consume it as a hearty snack, while a small percentage of them will literally die. The absurdity of that hypothetical scenario is exactly the problem with Everything Everywhere All at Once. Of about 25 people in the audience, 4 left partway through, and after the movie 2 were seen in a comatose state of tears and deeply in need to be held while the rest of the audience was busy repeating the mantra that it was the best movie they had ever seen (in stark contrast). The ubiquitous positive reception by the majority only adds insult to injury.

This comedy is a story of nihilism and the mundane constancy of 'laundry and taxes' (aka death and taxes). In the story, a mother who owns a 'laundromat', which serves as a symbolic place for hundreds of 'machines' or 'multiverses' to cycle constantly in a pointless cycle of life and death, is audited at multiple levels for her worthiness to rescue her daughter (and as a consequence the multiverse). It meticulously and powerfully makes a concerted effort to reconstruct the mind of a victim of depression inside the minds of the viewers. It intentionally overwhelms the senses and adds increasing doses of chaos until a conglomerate of elated misery and confusion is fully formed in the mind of the viewer, much like in the mental state of a person who suffers from depressive trauma. It then makes a feeble attempt at dissolving this toxic construct with a caustic fallacy that long term depression can be solved with love. It invites those who have truly felt depression to reawaken any past horrors and then face them with no warning or preparation, and to be left with an aftermath of feeling worthless whilst asking them to contemplate suicide. All within a guise of fast-paced hilarious scenes that make it highly appealing, much like rat poison covered in frosting.

Most unfortunately, the comedy is well constructed and the narrative is cohesive, which makes it quite a powerful and well-made story. However, with great power comes great responsibility, something which is tragically ignored. The writers welcome us to contemplate the meaninglessness of life in this free ride to hell. Any who have inner demons will be snatched out of there seats and into an introspective trial with their worst horrors. All else will be able to pass this off as a light-hearted comedy with mediocre story. This is why food with peanuts comes with allergy warnings.

Title: I honestly just need to sit down after that.
Review:
Like watching a Wes Anderson backwards. Reading William Falkner upside down. A circus performance, on roller skates, during a light show, on a tab of acid... and you have epilepsy.

All the impact, none of the effect.

Perhaps I am one who does not take kindly to exorbitant, grandiose displays of trigger-happy cinematography and CGI, finding beauty more in subtlety and nuance - but I'd imagine the Daniels, in crafting their art, make no attempt at such frivolity.

(I would, however, find great entertainment in how Mr. Kwan, and Mr. Scheinert explained the conception of such a film to investors, without the presence of psychedelics.) 'Everything Everywhere All at Once' - a mouthful true to the visual storm, explosion of colour, and stark novelty that it captured. The frantic attempts to squeeze as many effects possible into the given time frame, rendered it - less a movie with a coherent storyline; and more a 2hr compilation of chaotic energy drink ads. The question is: would it have received such acclaim, if without such an exorbitant visual effects budget? Visual effects that left my head sore like it had just been punched square between my eyebrows.

However, Mr. Kwan, and Mr. Scheinert painted in a new colour (supposedly a shade of green that washed the audience's faces at the Oscars) and I will award praise to anything that stretches the lines of convention.

Title: Meaningless and silly
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Am I watching a different film?
Review:
In what universe does this film win all these awards? Yes it's unique I'll give it that. But being unique and weird doesn't make it a great movie. Utter nonsense such as sausage fingers, black hole or center of the universe bagel, giant profound rocks, dildo fight, and jumping on a giant butt plug to increase your superpowers. Apparently switching between a fight scene and two pinatas is profound and artistic. Who cares if there is a deeply profound message buried inside this crap sandwich this movie makes wish I'd read more books. This movie is correct, there is always something to love. I'd love to get my money back and forget I wasted two hours on this mess.

Title: Abominable. A disgrace to the word Movie
Review:
I've literally never written a review and I probably don't even have the right skills to do it but this one has disgusted me in such a way that I feel the urge to write this or else I go completely crazy.

Does no one see this has the full recipe for commercial success in 2023 ? Take Jamie Lee Curtis and you have the "big name". It doesn't matter if her role is irrelevant and brings a huge embarrassment to her entire career. The rest of the actors might as well have 0 acting skills. Add some fancy expensive CGI's that almost require an epilepsy warning. Take a script writer, hit his head on the keyboard until making him unconscious and voil√†, your success is granted.

I've always followed this golden rule of not making comments about movies unless I watch them until the end. After this one I really need to reconsider this self torturing principle because I honestly felt body pains while waiting for it to end. Just thinking that this stands a real chance to win the Oscar makes me want to projectile vomit until dehydrating to death.

The only good part is that I now know not ever to trust the ratings on IMDB because people only want to act cool by liking nonsense, timewasting disasters. This trend needs to stop although I feel it's only going to get worse like everything else on this planet.

Title: More Pseudo-intellectual Hype Train Drivel
Review:
People who plotz over this movie as if its the best thing ever, are, I think, just obsessed with wanting to impress the neighbors, to join the hype train and pretend they're smarter than everyone else. There are a few profound moments in this movie, very few, certainly not enough to justify sitting in a theater for over 2 hours of excruciating boredom. This movie lost my attention within the first 30 minutes. I'm sure the hot-dog fingers were an attempted metaphor at something profound. I'm sure the giant bagel was, too, but all the pointless, plot-less, frenetic action just made it all unwatchable. I don't need happy endings, simple plots or pretty people to enjoy a movie. I like a thought-provoking film as much as the next free-thinking person, but this film, and its success, are nothing more than hype-train drivel lead by well-meaning low-vibe sycophants.

Title: Maybe too original
Review:
The basic premise as described is great, and the technical execution was top-notch, and rightfully acknowledged by the Oscars, but:

Fast-paced, and sometimes chaotic conversations are an acquired taste, and sometimes tiring to keep up with.

Couple that with aesthetic choices that can make Legion seem tame, to the point of occasionally becoming gross,and some will be hard-pressed to find a reason to keep watching.

In short, the Oscars have done it again: This movie, like 'The Revenant', before it has a lot to offer to those interested in technical aspects of film making, or just keen to see something completely different, but difficult to enjoy for those looking for casual entertainment.

Title: Love it or hate it
Review:
One thing for sure, it is very accurately named indeed, but Everything Everything All at Once amounted to not much as far as I am concerned.

It's definitely a "love it or hate it" flick, unfortunately I leaned on the latter and couldn't keep watching beyond the first hour. The progression of the story is just too erratic and the pace too exhausting without much to keep my curiosity entertained. The quirkiness didn't grow on me at all, the humour fell flat at my feet and everything (all at once) felt rather forced.

If I were generous I'd say it's a movie that wasn't made for my generation, but since I'm snobbish I'll rather assume that 15 years of formulaic Marvel franchises have severely lowered viewers' standards for this movie to receive such rave reviews.

Title: Disappointing. Too Heavy on the Sci Fi front.
Review:
Swooping 7 Academy Awards in an array of cinematic fields. Everything Everywhere All at Once is an explosive package, a fast-paced spectacle designed for the most avid sci-fi fans.

A Chinese immigrant gets unwillingly embroiled in an epic adventure where she must connect different versions of herself in the parallel universe to stop someone who intends to harm the multiverse.

Personally, the multiverse is not a favoured setting for myself, neither is an overload of breaking the extents of human capabilities. Therefore, I had low expectations for a film with such high acclaim.

Undoubtedly, the cinematic features are like we've never seen before. Flawless. Sensational. The directory work of Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert in manipulating the camera giving it a supernatural edge even in scenes of simplicity. The sound and effects are timed appropriately, leaving a lasting memory of every scene and stamping contributing to the fast-pace adventure of the watch.

The clever use of comedy contrasting with scenes of distress is measured perfectly. Main character Evelyn goes on an emotional journey in contrasting what her life could've been, to the life she lives today. The humour value provided by her husband and the exceptional supporting role Jamie Lee Curtis' character gives us, is the perfect tonic to the suffering the protagonist experiences.

Equally, scenes of combat / conflict are able to contrast with scenes of stillness, a loud vs quiet comparison acts as a resemblance of reality vs fantasy.

The on-screen acting performances are a joy to behold. Three Oscars deservingly going to Michelle Yeoh, Ke Huy Quan and Jamie Lee Curtis respectively, as they all immerse themselves into this sci-fi, action world created. Understanding their roles and ensuring the film keeps its serious, yet authentic feel - doing the sublime screenplay justice.

Certainly a cinematic experience worth living. Though, as anticipated, the film leans too heavy on the side of sci-fi and fantasy, escaping reality entirely. It wasn't for me, but it is for many. Give it a go.

As for the plot, this felt like the adult and more chaotic version of "Turning Red," it's the same general message about the mother daughter relationship. But just overly chaotic and definitely and made me not see the value of this movie.

Title: not what i expected
Review:
When i think of classic movies i think of the dark knight, shawshank redemption and return of the king not just because they did well at the oscars (shawshank redemption did not win one) but because they were good movies. The fact that every thing every where all at once has won not one oscar but seven is borderline robbery for other movies like elvis and batman mainly because it does not deserve half of the oscars it won.

I'm not saying it is a bad movie i am saying it is alright just highly overrated. I would have been happy with the movie if it had no unnecessary hype around it and i could just watch it but no, for some reason half of the planet thinks this is one of the greatest movies ever. Also just the fact that every thing every where all at once got nominated for 11 is just a disgrace in it self in short they are saying this movies is better that movies like the shawshank redemption, inception, the departed and 12 angry men and many other movies.

In short watch the movie but don't be swayed by a plethora of overrated reviews because you will only find yourself more disappointed and asking more questions on how this won 7 oscars.

By FT.

Title: This is rated an 8.2 out of 10?
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: A Waste of My Life
Review:
2hrs36mins in the cinema, wasting my life at a film I can say is the only one that did less for me than Tenet. I didn't follow it, stopped wanting to and kept nodding off. This was the 're-released' version which basically had the additions of the Daniels' introduction where they came across as two spoiled students trying to be funny and 8 minutes of very boring and unfunny outtakes following the credits. It seems like these are two trusted filmmakers who have had money thrown at them and been allowed to indulge some drunken student fantasies. Definitely not for me.

Title: I don't get this movie!
Review:
This movie is boring! I love science fiction, I love martial arts, love action, love comedies. I don't get this movie. It is a ridiculous plot. It's not funny. The action sequences and special effects are not good. The plot really is silly. Not entertaining at all.

I'm happy to fill the rest of this review just to get the correct number of characters but my first paragraph says it all. I'm not criticizing the acting. I think the creator of this movie had no idea what he was doing. Jumping around from one reality to another is perfectly fine if you except that idea as a science fiction, but mixing these unknowing characters into that complex plot is just silly. Not funny not interesting. Some random person coming in to see their accountant and getting sucked into another reality. Great, that is so exciting.....

Title: I get it, I get it, and then I get it again and again and....
Review:
This movie could've been told in half the time. It is the definition of self indulgent. There are a couple lovely sequences, but this film could have been told in 35or 40 minutes and not be over two hours it is. If I was in a theatre I think I would have walked out. Although I love the actors, and the ideas I cannot recommend this film.

Title: Mediocre nothing else!
Review:
Very interesting concept, very well presented, this is something new I must admit. Some kind of psychedelic-bloody-slightly perverse atmosphere works here with some kind of forced and partial perverted comedy that is not funny at all. There is some action throughout the film, if we can call it action at all, the description says it's an adventure, but I didn't see any trace of adventure here. It's immediately obvious that this definitely is not for everyone taste. I'm bothered by the bilingualism that drags through the film, it's somehow disorienting and uninteresting. The actors did their job properly, the only thing I don't like is the portrayal and characteristics of the character played by Stephamie Shu, that role sets the film back quite a bit and makes it uninteresting in parts and boring. All in all, I partly see why the rating of the film is so high, but I think that the rating is definitely not fully justified, this is a mediocre time killer with some boring and uninteresting scenes and nothing more.

Title: WHERE TO STARTüò±?!?!?!
Review:
It struck me half way through this film that the whole viewing experience would have been greatly enhanced if you were on mind altering drugs üòÇ.

From a benign somewhat average start the film quickly descends into a cheap amalgamation of eclectic film genre. Cliche after clich√© attempt to sew together sometimes incomprehensible material. Explanations were faulty and hurried leaving you guessing and missing the next hurried onslaught.

It was, I can only explain as a poor attempt at combining a Monty Python film with a sub standard Matrix offering that then gave birth to Rom Com offspring.

Ultimately empty and meaningless which I believe was the point of the film. Hey maybe that was the intention behind this mess of a movie ??

Title: Overrated
Review:
They gave 7 Oscars to what is basically a crossover between Disney's "Brave" and "Rick and Morty".

Milking the meme culture of our age that makes anything meme-able or gif-able automatically successful.

It is just an opinion but I don't believe that being absurd makes you funny, or that hot-dog hands and butt plugs are original and clever sources of humour.

The only thing that it got accurately was how noisy the mother - daughter relationship is and how most of the time it doesn't make sense. But, again, a Disney film can do that too, it's nothing groundbreaking and definitely cannot "save" the rest of the film.

Title: I hope I never see another movie as bad as this
Review:
I agree with all the other 1 ratings. (Wish I could have rated it a 0!)

This movie had no redeeming value. And, the only reason I sat through the whole, excruciating, 2 hours and 12 minutes of it was because I thought my friend wanted to. (Turned out she thought as little of it as I did.)

How anyone in their right mind could find anything interesting about this film is beyond me.

I'm no aficionado of martial arts, but even that didn't seem well done, to me. Years ago, I saw several Jackie Chan movies, but, as I recall, the martial arts scenes were captivating; the ones in this movie just seemed like senseless violence.

Title: Pretentious and averrated, pure hype.
Review:
Prologue or important clarification: I don't recall ever giving a star on any review. Please don't think this is hate or something. I don't know the actors or the directors, there is nothing personal. I even had high hopes for the movie as it was highly recommended to me, but I don't see how this movie can have more than one star.

Also, maybe some will want to call me a boomer or something. To them I would clarify that I have seen quite absurd movies before. From the top of my head I can think of: Pink Flamingos, Begotten, Nirvana, Crash, A Serbian Film, Ebola Syndrome, Even Dwarfs Started Small, Mermaid in a Manhole, Riki-Oh: The Story of Ricky, Nekromantik, Schramm, La Matanza Cannibal de los Garrulos Lisergicos... Okay, I don't find them good, but I think they are better than a star, well, maybe not the last one...

Going back to the movie in question, some say it is deep and meaningful, but there is certainly nothing deep in the pseudo-philosophical and pseudo-scientific plot. There is not the slightest hint of a new idea or a new perspective, never mind a good exposition of what it purports to be.

The argument is tedious, absurd, illogical and also predictable. The way the creators of this movie want to avoid the above is by introducing absurd elements that want to distract you from the childish plot. The film ends with the classic Hollywood clich√© where love finally triumphs.

If you want an original movie, you won't find it at Everything Everywhere All at Once. If you want a pretentious, nonsensical plot that aspires to be edgy or deep, you might be in the right place. This movie is completely forgettable and I'm sure no one will talk about it in the future. It's just a gimmick that will pass with the tide.

The only reasons I could give another star is the original music and the acting. The acting is heroic considering how bad the movie is. It's fascinating how well the actors managed to do ther job, so kudos to them. Maybe I could give it another star, but the movie is too bad for the reasons stated.

Anyway, I find it fascinating to read the comments, especially those who say that it is one of the best movies ever and that it is in their top 3 or 5 of favorites. I bet they'll almost forget about this, their 'favorite' movie in a couple of years.

Title: Not Everything It's Cracked Up To Be
Review:
Michelle Yeoh and Jamie Lee Curtis star, and provide their typical solid perfomances in this (soft-)sci-fi/fantasy about a family which becomes enmeshed in a conflict spanning a multiverse, where all possible outcomes of their past choices and actions exist simultaneously. Against this backdrop, the film explores issues of communication, understanding, and acceptance within family and society.

While admittedly ambitious in scope, this effort quickly devolves into a frenzied, farcical, sometimes ludicrous, acid trip of disjointed ideas and imagery, and plays like an exhausting looney-toon mashup of "The Matrix" and "The Mask".

Is it creative and original? Certainly. However, these alone don't make a film enjoyable or praiseworthy, and this hodgepodge quilt of interesting ideas, pieced together with duct tape and bubble gum, ultimately falls short of anything which can be called "good". Hardcore cinemaphiles may enjoy the experimental storytelling, but I expect most others will likely be disappointed, and perhaps even disturbed.

Due to mostly solid acting, originality, and a few laughs, I'll give this 3 stars, despite its otherwise near unwatchability.

Title: Worst Movie. Don't waste your precious time.
Review:
The directors' experience before making this drivel was a DN Snake video an SD c g get s movie 'Swiss Army Man'. That's all you need to know.

That this and 'Oscar' are even mentioned in the same sentence tells you how broken the nominating process is.

I don't really know who's ramming this movie down everyone's throats, but I've seen more plausible plots in old Troma movies. Here, the creators just throw everything at the screen, hoping something will stick. They figure if the plot/location/time/scene changes often enough, then people will be too busy trying to make sense of it all instead of realizing they're being duped.

Possibly the stupidest movie I've seen in 2-3 decades.

Title: Don't bother
Review:
I watched about half this movie before I gave up. It's garbage. It's stupid. It's so American stupid, it screams American stupidity at every corner. I don't know where to start. The constant switching between Mandarin and Cantonese is so confusing to people who understand one but not the other language, like myself. The story makes absolutely no sense at all. It's a collection of offensive scenes designed to shock and confuse the simple minded; it's amateurish nonsense at the worst high school level you can think of. It's shameful to subject anyone to watch this nonsense. It has no bearing on anything that matters, it's a waste of time and a waste of money. And, I am fluent in Chinese so I can only say that I thought the Mandarin dialogues were understandable but did not add anything to the story. This is not about Asian American anything. It's dumb.

Title: Overrated But Not Awful
Review:

Loved the hotdog fingers and butt plug awards. I can see why people either love it or hate it though. I can see this becoming a cult classic down the road.

Title: No substance
Review:
This is a movie that has had the most accurate review written hundreds of years ago by Shakespeare.

"It is a tale Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, Signifying nothing." This movie was all sound and fury without any substance. All of the attempted emotional scenes fell flat and don't connect. It seemed like the writers just threw a bunch of disparate movie ideas at a wall and where they stuck was how it was in the movie. Very visual stylish and meaning nothing.

The action scenes were well don but just got stupid and silly almost immediately for no reason. The whole movie was just unconnected randomness with only the most tenuous of connections. It does not hold my attention or interest.

I'm a fan of hard sci-fi and martial arts movies and this just missed the mark in everything it tried. The writing seemed like it was written by a stupid person trying to be a smart person. It's transparent in it's ridiculous attempt to be clever and falls on it's face.

The acting was very good given the limited nature of the story they were given and can't be faulted for a failed story.

This film didn't connect with me on any level and I won't be recommending it to anyone.

Title: A Total Disappointment!!
Review:
"Everything Everywhere, All At Once" is a film that is practically unwatchable. Despite its good costume design and individual scenes, the movie is disjointed, overly long, and ultimately a waste of time. I would rate this film a 1 out of 10.

The plot of the movie is convoluted and difficult to follow, with too many storylines and characters to keep track of. The film's attempts at humor and action fall flat, and the overall tone is confusing and inconsistent.

The only redeeming quality of the film is its impressive costume design and some visually striking scenes. However, these brief moments of enjoyment are not enough to make up for the film's many flaws.

Title: Dissapointed
Review:
So I Saw it won Oscar's, so I had to see it. I have never seen a movie so bad win an Oscar. Bad acting, utterly ridiculous confusing story.

I don't understand how this can even get nominated when you see the other winners. This is is really a step back in moviemaking. Sad to say.

I have tried to keep an open mind and believe in movies trying to create new ways of moviemaking, but where is the good character acting here?

The story is lacking a clear red line and meaning. What exactly is it trying to tell us? It's like a mixture of bad kung fu movies from 80's and matrix but lacking originality. Sorry but as a movie lover I appreciate the many fantastic movies there are out there, but this one is not among them.

Title: Wacky
Review:
The three stars are for imaginative. But I think at some point the creators of this film couldn't tell the difference between good creative ideas and bad ones. To me it was a mess, it was throwing everything onto a canvas, paint, feces, glitter, ground beef, spit, glue, and melted crayons, then smearing it around and hoping the audience decides to make more of it than it really is. Yes, the movie has a message. And it's a good message. But how a message is delivered matters, and this one was delivered through an unpleasant, loony movie.

Review:

Title: Raunch and bizarre humour
Review:
Telling a coherent story and building emotional connections with the audience are at the bottom of the list for this twisted raunchy trek through what is essentially one long stylized action scene. Combining themes from horror genres and low-brow humour, this is one film that attempts to mash a Christmas carol with nihilism and sex toys.

The writing is deliberately bizarre, with a story that is too convoluted for most, but don't mistake this for a deep philosophical film, nay, to the contrary, it has a social agenda (It's hard to find a film that doesn't these days). If you find plot devices like people having to do statistically improbable things like inserting a butt plug in the middle of a fight scene, or beating someone with a pair of oversized artificial genitalia funny, then by all means you may find this entertaining. If however you find such things deeply offensive, or pretentious, then this is one film probably left alone.

Title: Stupidity hid its true beauty
Review:
My friends were raving about this movie (RAVING!) and I hate to say I was sadly disappointed. I really loved the idea of it, though, and the message it was trying to send. But the story line was so difficult to follow, it led me into instant confusion. My biggest issue with this movie was that it could have done without the ridiculous fighting scenes and universes (a universe where humans have hot dog fingers? And they eat their fingers with mustard coming out?). These details distracted me from the true message behind this film. It could have been so much more, way more poignant, without the overload of stupidity. This inundation kept it from being the true gem it could have been.

Title: Maybe the 6th or 7th Best Movie
Review:
This movie was not even close to the best picture. Several of the nominees were better films. This year turned out to be Asian recognition day. Let's hope next year the Academy can pick the best picture without some agenda.

And Michelle Yeoh was a self-absorbed, conceited, egotistical winner. Not once did she recognize the wonderful performances of the other nominees. What a snub to those ladies.

The best picture was probably The Whale which wasn't even nominated. Brendan Frasier was just amazing.

The Fablemans was a wonderful movie and deserving of BP. The wrong Michelle won the best actress award.

All Quiet was an epic and normally the BP.

Elvis was another great movie.

Women Talking is really good. A sleeper.

So many excellent choices. You blew it Academy.

Title: Bloated nonsense, overlong and meaningless.
Review:
If this movie wasn' so overhyped and so overrated, I would just dismiss it as a meh kind of movie. But as it is so overhyped and overrated, I kind of start to hate it.

But to not waste a lot more time on this nonsense, I will just point out the main reasons why the movie failed for me.

1.) The movie failed to establish an emotional connection between the viewer and what is happening on the screen i. E. in the movie. One of the reasons for that being: the movie was driven by nonsense. Whenever the main characters are stuck in a situation, the have to perform some nonensical bullcrap, so that they can crazy-deus-ex-machina their way out of the situation. Again and again and again and again and again.

2.) The other reason for the failed emotional connection is that there were no sympathetic characters given to connect with. Everyone is just a self-absorbed a-hole or douchebag. What they are fighting for is a chaotic piled up mess (because they are unable to fix anything and to improve, so they prefer having a meanignless mess to having nothing).

So, my main problem was: I just didn't care for anything happening in the movie.

If you think that it is a profound philosophical question to ask how your life would be if you would have sausages for fingers (just to give you an example), this may be a movie you. But if you think that such a question is just stupid and stopped being funny since you turned 8 years old, maybe you should avoid spending timeor money on this movie.

But there are some few reddeming qualities of this movie, hence I did give it 3/10.

Which are:








But again, at the end of the day, I didn't care for the pile of nonsense that the movie is.

Title: All At Once Everything Everywhere Was Original But A Lacking Let Down In Its Visual Flow!
Review:
Hollywood has drifted into another phase of repetitive story plot films, the "Multiverse" era. In the superhero fantasy world it works tremendously (and may do so in non fantasy films of the future) but, it failed totally in this films story. I love Michelle Yeoh as an actress - I have followed and watched her screen career for many years - and it made for the only reason I watched this; having read the film synopsis in the press outputs, I was not impressed and would have given it a miss but for her being in it.

The trouble with the film is that we are given no reason whatsoever (neither at the start and right to the finish line) as to why everything was happening and, the causes that led up to it. It just jumps straight into a 3 parts cacophony of riotous confusion. The comedy throughout was very few and far between, though a couple of scenes gave rise to a big smile from me, and therefore, I can only assume that all the reviewers are very easily amused by scenes that were meant to be comical but just lacked that sincerity and timing. With the complexed plot it was attempting to draw the viewer in with it should have had a far better explanation.

I was also very disappointed to see Michelle Yeoh in a film with the "F" word in it (she never does that kind of film work as far as I am aware) and, to be honest there was no real reason to use it here; something like, "Oh crap!" would have sufficed instead!

I, if asked by my circle of friends, would only tell them to not expect anything hilariously funny, logical or reasonably enjoyable and, to forget about any forewarning insight into the unfolding plot. Its a very well presented digital visual of technical excellence (the reason why I have given it a 5 star) but, its a dull 2hr:12mins and the worst film I have ever seen Michelle (Yeoh) act in.

Title: Complete Waste of TIme
Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Title: Things are happening and then it's over. Not.
Review:

Nothing makes sense, nothing is interesting, there is nothing at stake, no goal. It's not even especially pretty to look at (although it think it is).

Title: Lots of LGBT propaganda
Review:
Not as good as they say.

First hour is okay-if you decide to ignore the blatant lgbt propaganda shoved into your face as early as the establishing shots.

The gradual introduction of the multiverse will leave most viewers confused, since we never get a clear idea of how things work.

It simply is a plot device which allows the filmmakers to get away with anything.

From sixty to ninety minutes the action kicks in and things get better, but it does not last for long. You will know when the good part is over because The End is going to appear on the screen.

The trouble begins after the fake ending credits. The remaining forty minutes are the most goddamn awful thing you've ever seen. It was excruciatingly painful to deal with those. Each second was a masterclass in cringiness, sappiness, and ultra boredom. Kinda like a Chinese blockbuster, only worse!

Title: Overcooked and cheesy...
Review:
What a waste of time....seriously...it tries to tackle some very serious things in a funny way...but after half an hour all the fun feels old..repetitive...and overlong...the absurdity of life can be fun...but this movie tries to tackle them with cheesy old cliches

The movies highly rated by critics these days are just like this...in order to be politically correct and to break new ground...they just end up inane , stupid and absurd...

How on earth this movie has an 8+ rating on IMDB is beyond comprehension...

Just watch Michael Gondry if u want similar mind bending plot but with a lot more fun and sense...

Kind of wasted my 2 hour.just avoid.

Title: Nothing Nowhere Over a Long Period of Time - most accurate
Review:
The Guardian review para-titled "Nothing Nowhere Over a Long Period of Time", remains the most accurate review I have come across to date on this colossal waste of time, unless you actually read the plot synopsis that contains "insane adventure" and "other universes" and then still proceeded to watch two hours and twenty minutes of gen Z hyper nonsense.

This failed attempt at inspirational movie making from an industry largely bereft of an original thought, will no doubt feed the coffers of its producers, by those still caught up in over-hyped media messaging, delusional story lines, and possibly kaleidoscopes.

Gen Z Oscar bait if ever there was one.

Title: Sentimental Ending, Disappointing Journey
Review:
I recently watched a movie that has received mixed reviews from the audience and I must say, I understand why. When I first started watching it, I was drawn in by the visuals and the ambitious editing style. However, as the movie progressed, I found myself getting more and more confused. The storyline lacked coherence and meaning, making it difficult for me to follow along.

The long running time also didn't help matters, as it made the experience even more tedious. What was particularly frustrating was the awkward explanation of the filmmakers' intent, which only added to the confusion. I couldn't help but feel that the movie was trying to be too pretentious and showy.

Another issue I had with the movie was the characters. I found them to be annoying and uninteresting, which made it even harder for me to engage with the story. The ending was sentimental and, in my opinion, a way to forget the painful experience of watching the movie. It felt like the filmmakers were trying to wrap things up quickly and make the audience forget the confusing and lackluster journey they had just gone through.

Overall, my experience with this movie was negative. I wouldn't recommend it to others and would suggest they look for a more enjoyable and coherent film. The visuals and editing style were impressive, but they couldn't make up for the lack of coherence and the frustrating storyline.

Title: Exhausting
Review:
"Exhausting" is the one word review that I wanted to leave here but am not permitted to because of the minimum character requirement for these reviews. But "exhausting" really does say it all. From the get-go this film assaults you with input from a thousand directions. You feel as though you're being overwhelmingly battered by two or three prize fighters at once, but the rounds aren't three minutes, they are more like 120 minutes. So, no respite or opportunity to regroup. It just keeps jerking you around without mercy. I was able to stay with it for about thirty minutes, then I had to just turn it off. I'll say it again, it's just simply exhausting. Good luck to you if you want to give it a try.

Title: Disjointed, perplexing story line makes it a disappointing, difficult watch.
Review: There are two reasons why I wanted to see this movie. One, it had a high rating of 8.1 and two it was considered a high probability of being selected for the award of best film, for Michelle Yeoh for best actress, for Jamie Lee Curtis for best supporting actress and for Ke Huey Kwan for best supporting actor. While the acting awards seemed justified since the acting was good, I have very strong reservations about the best picture bit. The movie described in Wikipedia as an "absurdist science fiction comedy drama" is extremely difficult to sit through and a torturous watch for most of the time. It can be described as inane, bizarre, aweful, nonsensical, chaotic, crazy, strange, trite, mind numbing, cringe worthy and basically an assault on the senses which drains you physically and mentally. After the first 40 minutes starts the madness which gets worse with time. The fights, the VFX, the fast paced martial arts, the high decibel music are okay for some time but it gets excruciating if one has to sit through for 2 hour 19 minutes of runtime. I was disappointed big time. The background of a parallel universe with virtual reality didn't help to make things interesting and made it look strange. The disjointed, meandering and confusing narrative and the superfast editing pace had me flummoxed. What a mess it looked.

Title: Am I crazy for hating this film?
Review:
I have seen just about every kind of movie out there. This is the worst.

This is my first imdb review because usually I don't care about sharing my opinion on a movie online but this time I have something I need to get of my chest.

I might have missed an explanation at the end as I left the cinema about 75 minutes in but what is going on? A lot of the people I've talked to actually enjoyed the whole movie and I'm stuck wondering if I'm just "not getting it".

I truly believe that this is the worst film I've ever seen and the reason I'm giving this review is to find out if I'm just crazy/not getting it or if this really is a legitimate waste of time. It's nothing short of ridiculous that it was nominated for an Oscar and, to me, downright criminal that it won.

How anyone could wholeheartedly enjoy and recommend it is beyond me.

Title: The real story: Solipsism on Steroids
Review:
"Look at me! I'm Evelyn! I might seem like a bland middle aged woman, but I'm the center of the universe. I'm the center of universes-ses-ses! I create universes. With every decision I make, another universe is born. In one universe I turn out to be a piano wizard, in others I'm a knife wizard, a martial arts wizard, a wizard of wizardry. There is an endless amount of glorious roads my life could take and thanks to the invention of parallel universes, some version of me is taking each and every one of them. But still, I, myself, I am the most important one. I didn't achieve much in my life, all my potentials still lie dormant, an explosive mixture, just waiting for a spark to ignite it.

I'm a quirky person. People love that about me. Sometimes I start to sing, sometimes I start to dance, or whatever. This movie about me is a quirky movie. Lots of fun stuff from science fiction movies, horror movies, kung fu movies has been thrown into a blender to create something that is as multi-faceted and fun as I am. So don't you dare to nitpick! Don't be a smart-aleck! This movie is not about logic. It is not about you!

This movie is about me realizing that even if I didn't do much with my life, I'm actually everything, everywhere, all at once.

My name is Evelyn, God of Gods! Look at me, you mighty, and despair!"

---

As I'm not Evelyn, I found the whole thing a bit boring, actually. This crazy, trippy, far out stuff wasn't my cup of tea. But obviously there are lots of Evelyns out there who really love it. So just ask yourself one question: Are you an Evelyn? Well, are you ...?

---

The funniest joke of this movie is the cardigan with "PUNK" written on the back that Evelyn wears. Vivienne Westwood, eat your heart out!

Title: Nothing new for those who've watched "Rick&Morty"
Review:
This movie is Not bad, is Not going to save you life, is not going to change your life, because for those of us who've watched the animated TV Show "Rick&Morty" this movie is nothing new!!.... as a matter of fact, I call it "Rick&Morty" for newbies!! Haha.

In general the concept of Multiverses has been done many times (Including the TV Show "Loki") so there is not a lot new in here

The acting is good but I still insist it should've been Jackie Chan playing the husband!! He has a far longer and more interesting career than "Ke Huy Quan", Jackie Chan was ROBBED of that oscar and other awards!! Such an injustice!

Title: So Terrible - I'd give a zero if I could
Review:
I don't get the hype surrounding this film at all. Eleven! 11 Academy Award nominations, really?

I suffered through the entire movie hoping it would improve and wishing it would just end. It is the visual equivalent of a bad LSD trip . I wondered what kind of drugs the writers were on when they wrote this. I wanted to like this because I like Michelle Yeoh; I typically like SciFi movies; and I'd read that this was much better than Dr Strange MoM and it absolutely is NOT better, which is saying a lot because MoM is a chaotic mess.

I also asked my 30-something son to watch it so I could get the opinion of someone else who I know for a fact has common sense and who is not narcissistic or nuts like many of his peers. Looking forward to his comments.

My advice, don't wast your time.

Title: Not exactly Sci-fi and a tad predictable
Review:

How this even has the Sci-fi moniker is beyond me as the connection is cheaply done by using rather poor wardrobe. It is tediously repetitive with too much unnecessary albeit well choreographed fight scenes. I guess they filled the gaps left by the mediocre story. Michelle Yeoh is a great actress but wasted here despite her Oscar, as all her acting was just changing her facial expression but she did have a few good lines. Jamie Lee did an okay job but an Oscar performance really. I guess it was another light year for great movies so they overhyped this one to get it through the door. It will be forgotten as quickly as you can say Kung Fu.

Review:
I have trouble turning off my brain. Anxieties, worries, mundane to-dos, even positive things, sometimes feel like they're swirling around in a chaotic funnel cloud and I would like nothing more than to sit in physical and mental silence.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" felt like the inside of my head. In a world of non-stop, 24/7 news, most of it bad, how is a person like me, who has trouble filtering out things that affect me directly from all of the other things that are just out there happening in general and over which I have no control, supposed to cope?

One answer is to decide that nothing matters anyway and give up caring. But that means deciding that my wife doesn't matter. And that my kids don't matter. And that art, and nature, and things that bring joy to my life, don't matter.

Another way is to decide that some things, ok maybe most things, don't matter, but that there are things that do, and those are the things that make it all worth it. I get to decide what those things are.

The first approach is nihilistic. The second approach is empowering. This film explores both approaches, and I was a sobbing mess at the end.

I will say there were times that I was a bit exhausted by this movie. It throws a lot on the screen and at the viewer, and occasionally it can't keep up with its ambitions. But this was mostly a home run.

Michell Yeoh does terrific work in this, but the MVP is Ke Huy Quan (Short Round from the "Indiana Jones" movies).

Grade: A.

Review:
The worst movie I have ever seen in my life. A bad version of Nolan who is also a bad filmmaker. People think it's a masterpiece because they don't understand it.
